title: List of Presbyterian churches in the United States
intro: This is a list of notable Presbyterian churches in the United States, where a church is notable either as a congregation or as a building. In the United States, numerous churches are listed on the National Register of Historic Places or are noted on state or local historic registers. Also more than 300 Presbyterian historic sites have been listed by the Presbyterian Historical Society onto the American Presbyterian/Reformed Historic Sites Registry (APRHS); those sites which are churches are . in progress . being added here.
lm_description: The Presbyterian Church of Atlanta, New York, erected in 1895 and listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2010, stands at 2 Main Street in Queen Anne and Gothic Revival styles. Batavia’s First Presbyterian Church, built in 1854 and NRHP-listed in 2004, occupies the corner of East Main and Liberty Streets in Gothic Revival form. Bedford Presbyterian Church, dating to 1872 and listed in 1973, sits at 44 Village Green within the Bedford Village Historic District, also Gothic Revival. Schenectady’s First Presbyterian Church, built in 1809 and NRHP-listed in 2000, stands at 115 Union Street in New England style and belongs to the Presbyterian Church in America. Batchellerville’s Greek Revival church, built in 1867 and listed in 2000, lies on County Route 7. Central Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, founded in 1821 and housed since 1922 at 593 Park Avenue, is a Gothic Revival structure originally built as Park Avenue Baptist Church by John D. Rockefeller, Jr., and is now part of the Evangelical Presbyterian Church. Brockport’s 1852 Greek Revival First Presbyterian Church, NRHP-listed in 1999, stands at 35 State Street. Setauket Presbyterian Church and Burial Ground, built in 1812 and listed in 1996, is located at 5 Caroline Avenue in Brookhaven in Federal style. Cuyler Presbyterian Church, designed by Edward Sargent in Greek Revival, was built in 1892 at 358-360 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, and NRHP-listed in 2001. Buffalo’s First Presbyterian Church, founded in 1812, erected its current building in 1891. Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, built in 1894 and NRHP-listed in 2009, stands at 875 Elmwood Avenue in Romanesque Revival style. Chester’s First Presbyterian Church, built in 1854 for $10,000 and NRHP-listed in 1998, is at 106-108 Main Street in Greek Revival style. Cochecton Presbyterian Church, built in 1903 and NRHP-listed in 1992, sits on County Road 114 east of the Delaware River Bridge in Akron Plan Late 19th and Early 20th Century American Movements style. Silliman Memorial Presbyterian Church, designed by Fuller & Wheeler in 1897 and NRHP-listed in 1979, stands at Mohawk and Seneca Streets in Cohoes in Romanesque and Richardsonian Romanesque styles. Canterbury Presbyterian Church, built in 1826 and NRHP-listed in 1996, is in Federal style. Cortland’s First Presbyterian Church Complex, built in 1889 and NRHP-listed in 2002, stands at 23 Church Street in Late Victorian and Late 19th and 20th Century Revivals styles. Hopewell Presbyterian Church, built in 1831 and NRHP-listed in 1998, is located at the junction of NY 302 and NY 17 in Crawford in Gothic Revival style. Delhi’s First Presbyterian Church, built in 1882 and NRHP-listed in 2006, stands on Clinton Street in Late Victorian style. South Presbyterian Church, built between 1868 and 1869 and NRHP-listed in 2000, is in Dobbs Ferry in Gothic Revival style. Reformed Presbyterian Church Parsonage, built circa 1829 and NRHP-listed in 1984, stands on Duanesburg Churches Road in Federal Vernacular style.

title: Looney Tunes Super Stars' Pepe Le Pew: Zee Best of Zee Best
intro: Looney Tunes Super Stars' Pepé Le Pew: Zee Best of Zee Best is a DVD featuring all 17 Pepé Le Pew cartoons (14 new-to-DVD and three previously-on-DVD) and was released on December 27, 2011. The pre-53 shorts are presented in full screen while the post-53 shorts have both widescreen and full screen options (except for 1956's Heaven Scent which is only available in full screen). This was also the last Looney Tunes Super Stars series to feature a matted 1:85 widescreen format option for the post-1953 shorts and the only Warner Bros. home media release to feature the entire filmography of a major Looney Tunes character.
lm_description: Chuck Jones launched Pepé Le Pew on January 6, 1945 with Odor-able Kitty for Looney Tunes, returned two years later with Scent-imental Over You, then scored an Oscar on November 12, 1949 when For Scent-imental Reasons paired the skunk with Penelope. Arthur Davis took a one-off detour on October 2, 1948, letting Wellington the dog face Pepé in Odor of the Day. Jones resumed control, moving to Merrie Melodies for Scentimental Romeo (March 24, 1951) and Little Beau Pepé (March 29, 1952), then switched back to Looney Tunes for the solitary Wild Over You on July 11, 1953. Friz Freleng borrowed the character on January 2, 1954, squeezing Sylvester and Tweety into Dog Pounded, after which Jones reteamed with Penelope for The Cats Bah (March 20, 1954) and, through 1955-1962, delivered five more romances—Past Perfumance, Two Scent’s Worth, Heaven Scent, Touché and Go, Who Scent You?—all for Merrie Melodies except the last. Abe Levitow directed Penelope once in Really Scent (June 27, 1959), before Jones closed the canon with A Scent of the Matterhorn (June 24, 1961) and the Parisian finale Louvre Come Back to Me! (August 18, 1962), adding Claude the cat to Penelope’s company.
to_index_text:
Looney Tunes Super Stars' Pepe Le Pew: Zee Best of Zee Best

title: Patrick Chapin
intro: Patrick Chapin is an American Magic: The Gathering player. Also known for his writing, and deck-design, Chapin has made five Pro Tour top eights, spanning three decades, and four Grand Prix top eights. In 2012, Chapin was voted into the Magic: The Gathering Hall of Fame. His induction took place during Pro Tour Return to Ravnica in October 2012.
lm_description: Patrick Chapin placed eighth at the 1996–97 Pro Tour in New York, playing Booster Draft from 30 May to 1 June 1997, and two seasons later took sixth at the Los Angeles Pro Tour that ran 26–28 February 1999 under Rochester Draft rules. In May 2002 he finished second at the Standard-format Grand Prix Milwaukee, and in December 2007 repeated that runner-up finish at the Special-format World Championship back in New York. Returning to the Pro Tour, he earned sixth place at the Standard event in Paris held 10–13 February 2011, then secured third at Grand Prix Pittsburgh on 27–28 August 2011 and second at Grand Prix Orlando 14–15 January 2012. Chapin reached the pinnacle of his career by winning the Block Constructed Pro Tour Atlanta 16–18 May 2014, and subsequently placed second at the Special-format World Championship in Nice, 2–7 December 2014. He closed this competitive stretch with sixth place at Grand Prix Indianapolis, 31 October–1 November 2015, again in Standard.

title: List of schools in the Australian Capital Territory
intro: This is a list of schools in the Australian Capital Territory, which houses Australia's capital city, Canberra. The Territory's education system consists of primary schools, which accommodate students from kindergarten to Year 6, high schools, which accommodate students from Years 7 to 10, and secondary colleges, which are specialist Year 11-12 institutions. As a result of development in newer areas and mergers in existing areas, some schools accommodate more than one of the above year ranges. Certificates are awarded on the basis of continuous assessment of students' progress at the end of years 10 and 12 by the ACT Department of Education and Training.
lm_description: The AME School operated first in Campbell from 1972 to 1976, then reopened in Weston Creek’s Weston suburb, continuing as an independent institution until 1996. In North Canberra, Our Lady of Mercy Primary School served Catholic families in Braddon between 1935 and 1973, while St Brigid’s Primary School in Dickson educated students from 1960 to 1986, and St Michael’s Primary School in Lyneham functioned from 1961 to 1973. South Canberra’s Forrest hosted St Christopher’s School from 1928 to 1971, and Yarralumla’s St Peter Chanel’s Primary School operated from 1956 to 1989. In Tuggeranong, Padua Catholic High School in Wanniassa opened in 1978 and closed in 1997, the same year St Peter’s Catholic College in Isabella Plains ceased instruction after only eight years, having opened in 1989.

title: South Africa at the 2010 Summer Youth Olympics
intro: South Africa competed at the 2010 Summer Youth Olympics, the inaugural Youth Olympic Games, held in Singapore from 14 August to 26 August 2010. The nation was represented by the South Africa Olympic Committee, which sent a total of sixty-two athletes to compete in thirteen sports. The flagbearer at the opening ceremony for the nation was fencer Wanda Matshaya.
lm_description: Chad le Clos struck gold in the youth men’s 200 m medley on 16 August and added three silvers, finishing second in the 400 m freestyle on the 15th, the 100 m butterfly on the 16th and the 200 m butterfly on the 20th. Jacques Du Plessis claimed the boys’ discus gold on 21 August. Ruan Greyling took silver in the boys’ 400 m on the same day, while Izelle Neuhoff earned hers in the girls’ medley relay on the 23rd. Dylan Bosch secured bronze in the 200 m medley on 16 August, and together with Chad le Clos, Murray McDougall and Peter Keune he added a second bronze in the youth men’s 4 × 100 m freestyle relay that day. Samantha McIntosh contributed equestrian bronze in team jumping on 20 August, and Rudolph Pienaar leapt to bronze in the boys’ long jump on 22 August.

title: List of flag bearers for Uruguay at the Olympics
intro: This is a list of flag bearers who have represented Uruguay at the Olympics. Flag bearers carry the national flag of their country at the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games.
lm_description: Dolores Moreira carried Uruguay’s flag in the 2016 Summer Games as a sailor, following rower Rodolfo Collazo who did so in 2012, Alejandro Foglia in 2008, and Ricardo Fabini in 1992. Swimmer Serrana Fernández held the honor in 2004, preceded by athlete Mónica Falcioni in 2000, tennis player Marcelo Filippini in 1996, and rower Jesús Posse in 1988. Basketball player Carlos Peinado was flag bearer in 1984, while Gabriel Hottegindre represented Uruguay at the 1998 Winter Olympics in skiing. Earlier, Darwin Piñeyrúa led the delegation in 1972 as an athlete, Ana María did so in 1968 as a swimmer, Rubén Etchebarne in 1964 as a cyclist, and Luis M. Aguiar in 1960 as a rower. Héctor Costa carried the flag in 1956 as a basketball player, Estrella Puente in 1952 as an athlete, and Guillermo Douglas inaugurated the sequence in 1932 as a rower.

title: 2009 A Championship
intro: The 2009 A Championship was the second season of the A Championship. The season was sponsored by Newstalk. The league featured 18 teams. Shamrock Rovers A were the champions while the runners up, Salthill Devon, were promoted to the First Division.
lm_description: Bohemians A played out of Phibsborough at the AUL Complex, while Bray Wanderers A were based in Bray and used Jackson Park. F.C. Carlow, hailing from Ballon, hosted matches at The Valley, and Cobh Ramblers, rooted in Cobh, occupied St Colman’s Park. Cork City A represented Cork at Turner’s Cross, and Sporting Fingal A operated from Fingal with home games at the ALSAA Sports Complex. St Patrick’s Athletic A, from Inchicore, played at Richmond Park, whereas champions Shamrock Rovers A, stationed in Tallaght, staged their fixtures at Tallaght Stadium. Tralee Dynamos, finally, called Tralee home and lined up at Cahermoneen.

title: Srijit Mukherji
intro: Srijit Mukherji (born 23 September 1977), is a film director and screenwriter who predominantly works in Bengali cinema. His regular collaboration with veteran superstar Prosenjit Chatterjee brought him into the limelight. His first feature film Autograph (2010), was a critical and commercial success, where he had written the script with Chatterjee in mind. Since the time of Autograph, Chatterjee and he went on to deliver some of the biggest commercial hits of all time. His fifth film, Jaatishwar, won four national awards at India's 61st National Film Awards (2014). He won the National Film Award for Best Director and Best Original Screenplay for his sixth film, Chotushkone, at India's 62nd National Film Awards. His eighth film, Rajkahini had been remade into a Hindi film titled, Begum Jaan, starring Vidya Balan in 2017. His 2018 release Ek Je Chhilo Raja won the 'Best Bengali Film' Award at India's National Film Awards.
lm_description: In 2009 Srijit Mukherji wrote lyrics for Abhijeet Guha and Sudeshna Roy’s Cross Connection, scored by Neel Dutt and starring Abir Chatterjee, Payel Sarkar and Rimjhim Mitra, and again for Anjan Dutt’s Madly Bangalee with the same composer alongside Biswajit Chakraborty, Chandan Sen and Supriya Choudhury. The next year he provided lyrics for Ravi Kinagi’s Josh, composed by Jeet Ganguly and starring Jeet and Srabanti, while Prasenjit Mukherjee and Priyo Chattapadhyay joined him on lyrics for Raj Chakraborty’s Le Chakka, composed by Indradeep Dasgupta and featuring Dev and Payel Sarkar. In 2011 he contributed lyrics to Aparna Sen’s Iti Mrinalini alongside Rabindranath Tagore and Sunil Gangopadhyay, with Debojyoti Mishra composing for Aparna Sen, Konkona Sen Sharma and Rajat Kapoor, and also wrote lyrics for Ghente Ghaw, acted in Flop-e, and saw Srijato’s lyrics set to Indradeep Dasgupta’s score in Anindo Banerjee’s Chaplin with Rudranil Ghosh, Soham Maitra and Mir Afsar Ali. 2012 brought lyrics for Anjan Dutt’s Dutta Vs Dutta, again composed by Neel Dutt and starring Anjan Dutt, Ronodeep Bose, Arpita Chatterjee and Roopa Ganguly, and for Abhijeet Guha and Sudeshna Roy’s Bapi Bari Jaa with Jeet Ganguly and featuring Arjun and Mimi Chakraborty, while Kaushik Ganguly’s Shabdo featured Ritwik Chakraborty and Raima Sen. Rituparno Ghosh co-wrote lyrics with him for Mainak Bhaumik’s 2013 Maach Mishti & More, composed by Neel Dutt and starring Parambrata Chatterjee, Raima Sen, Parno Mittra and Swastika Mukherjee, and in 2018 he wrote lyrics for Pratim D Gupta’s Ahare Mon, scored by Neel Dutt and featuring Paoli Dam, Ritwick Chakraborty, Parno Mittra and Adil Hussain.

title: Australian rules football in Queensland
intro:
Australian rules football in Queensland has a history which dates back to the mid-1860s. By the early 1880s it was the most prominent football code in the colony, but was progressively overtaken by the Rugby code, resulting in the local game disbanding in the early 1890s. The sport was revived in the early 1900s and continued to be played throughout the twentieth century, despite the majority of the state being considered for much of the century to be well behind the Barassi Line (the notional line dividing Australia into Australian rules and Rugby 'territories'). Australian rules football's continued surge in popularity in south east Queensland is most likely due to the continued success of the Brisbane Lions in the national Australian Football League (AFL) competition, combined with the AFL's financial support for the local game. That support saw the introduction of a second AFL club in Queensland, the Gold Coast Suns in 2011. [citation needed]
 In Queensland, the sport is typically referred to as AFL, or less frequently Australian Football, Aussie Rules or Australian Rules.
lm_description: Jason Akermanis, raised in Brisbane, debuted in 1996 and kicked 421 goals in 325 games, winning a Brownlow and a place in Queensland’s Team of the Century after representing the Australian Football Alliance. David Armitage came from Morningside to debut in 2007 and has 150 games and 89 goals, while Marcus Ashcroft, the Gold-Coast-raised Southport product who first pulled on AFL boots in 1989, became the first Queenslander to 300 games, finished with 318 and 145 goals, and claimed three Brisbane Lions premierships plus Team of the Century honours. Claye Beams, Labrador-raised, joined the elite in 2011 for 30 games and 21 goals, and his Southport-raised brother Dayne Beams followed in 2009, amassing 112 games, 118 goals, a 2010 Collingwood flag and 2012 All-Australian selection. Clint Bizzell, born and bred in Brisbane via Wilston Grange, debuted in 1996 for 163 games and 79 goals, and Mount Isa product Simon Black, 1998 debutant, has 320 games, 170 goals and a Brownlow. Maryborough-born Jamie Charman, from Sandgate Hawks, started in 2001 for 129 games and 55 goals and represented the 2008 AFL Dream Team, while Cairns-raised Che Cockatoo-Collins, originally from Brisbane, kicked 215 goals in 160 games after debuting in 1994. Robert Copeland, Northern Eagles graduate, debuted in 2001 for 143 games and 39 goals, and Brisbane-born Gavin Crosisca, from Western Districts, played 246 games and 64 goals from 1987, represented Queensland and sits in the Team of the Century. Morningside pair Courtenay Dempsey (2006, 133 games, 35 goals) and Scott Harding (2006, 50 games, 15 goals) followed, with Cairns-raised Charlie Dixon (Redland, 2011, 49 games, 53 goals), Northern Eagles product Josh Drummond (2005, 94 games, 35 goals), Brisbane legend Jason Dunstall (Coorparoo, 1985, 269 games, 1254 goals, four State of Origin appearances, Allies representative, Hall of Famer and Team of the Century), Queensland-raised Mitch Hahn (Zillmere, 2000, 181 games, 164 goals), dual-Hawthorn-premiership Gold-Coaster David Hale (Broadbeach, 2003, 237 games, 217 goals), Cairns-born Jarrod Harbrow (2007, 120 games, 34 goals) and Charleville’s Rhan Hooper (Ipswich Eagles, 2006, 54 games, 56 goals) completing the Queensland-born AFL roll-call.
to_index_text:
Australian rules football in Queensland
Australian rules football in Queensland has a history which dates back to the mid-1860s. By the early 1880s it was the most prominent football code in the colony, but was progressively overtaken by the Rugby code, resulting in the local game disbanding in the early 1890s. The sport was revived in the early 1900s and continued to be played throughout the twentieth century, despite the majority of the state being considered for much of the century to be well behind the Barassi Line (the notional line dividing Australia into Australian rules and Rugby 'territories'). Australian rules football's continued surge in popularity in south east Queensland is most likely due to the continued success of the Brisbane Lions in the national Australian Football League (AFL) competition, combined with the AFL's financial support for the local game. That support saw the introduction of a second AFL club in Queensland, the Gold Coast Suns in 2011. [citation needed] In Queensland, the sport is typically referred to as AFL, or less frequently Australian Football, Aussie Rules or Australian Rules.
Jason Akermanis, raised in Brisbane, debuted in 1996 and kicked 421 goals in 325 games, winning a Brownlow and a place in Queensland’s Team of the Century after representing the Australian Football Alliance. David Armitage came from Morningside to debut in 2007 and has 150 games and 89 goals, while Marcus Ashcroft, the Gold-Coast-raised Southport product who first pulled on AFL boots in 1989, became the first Queenslander to 300 games, finished with 318 and 145 goals, and claimed three Brisbane Lions premierships plus Team of the Century honours. Claye Beams, Labrador-raised, joined the elite in 2011 for 30 games and 21 goals, and his Southport-raised brother Dayne Beams followed in 2009, amassing 112 games, 118 goals, a 2010 Collingwood flag and 2012 All-Australian selection. Clint Bizzell, born and bred in Brisbane via Wilston Grange, debuted in 1996 for 163 games and 79 goals, and Mount Isa product Simon Black, 1998 debutant, has 320 games, 170 goals and a Brownlow. Maryborough-born Jamie Charman, from Sandgate Hawks, started in 2001 for 129 games and 55 goals and represented the 2008 AFL Dream Team, while Cairns-raised Che Cockatoo-Collins, originally from Brisbane, kicked 215 goals in 160 games after debuting in 1994. Robert Copeland, Northern Eagles graduate, debuted in 2001 for 143 games and 39 goals, and Brisbane-born Gavin Crosisca, from Western Districts, played 246 games and 64 goals from 1987, represented Queensland and sits in the Team of the Century. Morningside pair Courtenay Dempsey (2006, 133 games, 35 goals) and Scott Harding (2006, 50 games, 15 goals) followed, with Cairns-raised Charlie Dixon (Redland, 2011, 49 games, 53 goals), Northern Eagles product Josh Drummond (2005, 94 games, 35 goals), Brisbane legend Jason Dunstall (Coorparoo, 1985, 269 games, 1254 goals, four State of Origin appearances, Allies representative, Hall of Famer and Team of the Century), Queensland-raised Mitch Hahn (Zillmere, 2000, 181 games, 164 goals), dual-Hawthorn-premiership Gold-Coaster David Hale (Broadbeach, 2003, 237 games, 217 goals), Cairns-born Jarrod Harbrow (2007, 120 games, 34 goals) and Charleville’s Rhan Hooper (Ipswich Eagles, 2006, 54 games, 56 goals) completing the Queensland-born AFL roll-call.

title: 1950 United States Census
intro: The United States Census of 1950, conducted by the Census Bureau, determined the resident population of the United States to be 150,697,361, an increase of 14.5 percent over the 131,669,275 persons enumerated during the 1940 Census. This was the first census in which:
lm_description: New York City led the 1950 United States Census with 7,891,957 residents, followed by Chicago’s 3,620,962 in Illinois and Philadelphia’s 2,071,605 in Pennsylvania, while Los Angeles claimed 1,970,358 to rank fourth in California and Detroit counted 1,849,568 to rank fifth in Michigan. Baltimore, Maryland, held 949,708 people, Cleveland, Ohio, 914,808, and St. Louis, Missouri, 856,796, placing them sixth through eighth. Washington, District of Columbia, reached 802,178, barely edging Boston, Massachusetts, at 801,444 for ninth and tenth. San Francisco’s 775,357 ranked it eleventh in California, Pittsburgh twelfth with 676,806 in Pennsylvania, and Milwaukee thirteenth with 637,392 in Wisconsin. Houston, Texas, grew to 596,163, Buffalo, New York, held 580,132, and New Orleans, Louisiana, 570,445, occupying ranks fourteen through sixteen. Minneapolis, Minnesota, counted 521,718, Cincinnati, Ohio, 503,998, Seattle, Washington, 467,591, and Kansas City, Missouri, 456,622, closing the top twenty.

title: Social Democratic Federation election results
intro: This article lists the Social Democratic Federation's election results in UK parliamentary elections. It also includes the results of its successor, the British Socialist Party.
lm_description: Tom Kennedy stood for Aberdeen North and polled 1,935 votes, 25.1 %, placing second. Dan Irving contested Accrington, winning 4,852 votes, 38.3 %, also second. Edward Hartley fought Bradford East with 3,090 votes, 22.8 %, coming third. H. M. Hyndman stood in Burnley, securing 4,932 votes, 32.5 %, third place. Jack Jones ran in Camborne, receiving only 109 votes, 1.5 %, third. Northampton fielded two candidates: James Gribble gained 2,366 votes, 10.9 %, sixth, while Jack Williams took 2,544 votes, 11.7 %, fifth. Harry Quelch stood in Southampton, earning 2,146 votes, 8.0 %, fifth.

title: La Liga
intro: The Campeonato Nacional de Liga de Primera División,[a] commonly known as La Liga[b] (La Liga Santander) for sponsorship reasons with Santander), is the men's top professional football division of the Spanish football league system. Administered by the Liga Nacional de Fútbol Profesional (English: National Professional Football League), also known as the Liga de Fútbol Profesional (LFP), La Liga is contested by 20 teams, with the three lowest-placed teams at the end of each season relegated to the Segunda División and replaced by the top three teams in that division. A total of 62 teams have competed in La Liga since its inception. Nine teams have been crowned champions, with Real Madrid winning the title a record 33 times and Barcelona 26 times. Barcelona won the inaugural La Liga in 1929 with Athletic Bilbao claiming several titles in the league's early years. During the 1940s, Valencia, Atletico Madrid and Barcelona emerged as the strongest clubs winning several titles. Real Madrid and Barcelona dominated the championship in the 1950s, winning four La Liga titles each throughout the decade. During the 1960s-1970s Real Madrid dominated La Liga winning 14 titles, with Atletico Madrid winning four. From the 1980s-1990s, Real Madrid were prominent in La Liga, but the Basque clubs of Athletic Bilbao and Real Sociedad had their share of success, winning two Liga titles each. From the 1990s onward, Barcelona have dominated La Liga winning 16 titles up to date. Although Real Madrid have been prominent, winning 8 titles, La Liga has also seen other champions, including Atlético Madrid, Valencia, and Deportivo de La Coruña. According to UEFA's league coefficient, La Liga has been the top league in Europe over the last five years and has led Europe for more years (22) than any other country.
lm_description: Alavés play in Vitoria-Gasteiz at the 19,840-seat Mendizorrotza, while neighbours Athletic Bilbao occupy the 53,332-capacity San Mamés in Bilbao. Atlético Madrid have moved to the 68,000-seat Wanda Metropolitano in Madrid, where city rivals Real Madrid stage matches in the 81,044-seat Santiago Bernabéu. Barcelona’s vast 99,354-seat Camp Nou dominates the Catalan capital, mirrored across the region by Espanyol’s 40,000-seat RCDE Stadium in Cornellà de Llobregat. Celta Vigo host at the 29,000-seat Abanca-Balaídos in Vigo, and tiny Eibar’s Ipurua accommodates just 7,083 in the Basque hills. Getafe’s Coliseum Alfonso Pérez holds 17,000, Leganés pack 12,450 into Butarque, and Granada’s Nuevo Los Cármenes seats 19,336. Levante and Valencia share the city of Valencia: Levante at the 25,354-seat Ciutat de València, Valencia at the 50,000 Mestalla. Mallorca’s Son Moix in Palma provides 24,262 places, Osasuna’s El Sadar in Pamplona 17,286. Real Betis and Sevilla divide Seville between the 60,720-seat Benito Villamarín and the 43,883-seat Ramón Sánchez Pizjuán. Real Sociedad play in the 39,500-seat Anoeta in San Sebastián, Valladolid’s José Zorrilla offers 26,512, and Villarreal’s Estadio de la Cerámica welcomes 23,500.

title: List of New Jersey Devils award winners
intro: The New Jersey Devils are an American professional ice hockey team based in Newark, New Jersey. They are members of the Metropolitan Division of the Eastern Conference in the National Hockey League (NHL). The Devils entered the League as the Kansas City Scouts in 1974. After just two years in Kansas City, they moved to Denver, Colorado, where they were known as the Colorado Rockies. In 1982, the team moved again to New Jersey. They currently play their home games at the Prudential Center. The franchise and its members have won numerous team and individual awards and honors. They have captured the Prince of Wales Trophy as the Eastern Conference playoff champion five times, while they have also won Stanley Cup three times, in 1995, 2000 and 2003. Former goaltender Martin Brodeur is the team's most decorated player, having won the Vezina Trophy four times and the William M. Jennings Trophy five times, and the Calder Memorial Trophy once, along with several selections to the NHL First and Second All-Star teams. Scott Stevens played in ten NHL All-Star Games, more than any player in team history. Taylor Hall is the only player in franchise history to have won the Hart Memorial Trophy. Five players have had their numbers retired by the team.
lm_description: Herb Brooks was honored in 2002 after serving the Devils during the 1992-1993 season, while Neal Broten received recognition in 1998 following his 1995-1996 tenure. Mike Emrick, honored in 2004, had two separate stints with the team from 1982-1986 and again from 1993-2011. Phil Housley was honored in 2008 after his single 1996 season, whereas Mark Johnson received his honor in 2011 for his service from 1985-1990. Lou Lamoriello was recognized in 1992 during his long tenure from 1987-2015, Max McNab was honored in 1998 after serving from 1983-1987, and Lou Vairo received his honor in 2000 following his 1984-1986 service with the organization.

title: Celebrity Bainisteoir
intro: Celebrity Bainisteoir is a prime-time reality programme broadcast by RTÉ and produced by Animo Television/Kite Entertainment. Created by Fiona Looney, it involved a number of celebrities competing against each other as a Gaelic football team coach; the title derives from the Irish word for a manager, bainisteoir [ˈbanʲəʃtʲoːɾʲ]. During and after its eight-part original run in 2008, the hugely popular RTÉ Television tournament was widely mentioned in the media including such newspapers such as An Phoblacht, The Belfast Telegraph, the Evening Echo, the Irish Examiner, the Irish Independent, the Irish News and The Irish Times. During the first series, a pop culture website asked its readers If you werent watching Celebrity Bainisteoir last night, then where were you? In the wake of the successful first series, the Evening Herald of Dublin reported in September 2008 that RTÉ was seeking out a new set of celebrities for a second series of Celebrity Bainisteoir set to air in summer 2009, and that a Celebrity Bainisteoir special would air during the Christmas season in 2008. The second series began on 22 March 2009. The series was axed in 2013 and replaced with Ireland's Fittest Family.
lm_description: Radio presenter Ray D'Arcy took charge of Rathangan in Kildare, while journalist John Waters managed St Michael’s of Cootehall in Roscommon. Comedian-actress Katherine Lynch guided St Patrick’s, Dromahair in Leitrim, and The Den’s children’s TV host Emma O’Driscoll led St Patrick’s of Limerick. Rugby analyst George Hook handled Cuala in Dublin, model Andrea Roche oversaw Rockwell Rovers in Tipperary, TV presenter John McGuire directed Sneem in Kerry, and fellow broadcaster Derek Davis steered Glasdrumman in Down.

title: Live with Regis and Kelly (season 18)
intro: This is a list of Live with Regis and Kelly episodes which were broadcast during the show's 18th season. The list is ordered by air date. Although the co-hosts may have read a couple of e-mails during the broadcast, it does not necessarily count as a Regis and Kelly Inbox segment.
lm_description: On June 1, Kelly Ripa welcomed Vince Vaughn as co-host and Denis Leary as sole guest. Jimmy Kimmel joined Ripa the next day for Famke Janssen, Sandra Bernhard and a Grill Friday segment. Regis Philbin returned June 5 alongside Ripa, launching Broadway Week with Kevin Connolly and Anna Paquin, followed by Ludacris and Julia Stiles on June 6, Liev Schreiber and The Apprentice winner on June 7, Charles Gibson and Kyra Sedgwick on June 8, and Kevin Dillon and Bonnie Hunt combined with Grill Friday on June 9. After Julie Andrews and Lauren Conrad visited June 12, Paris Hilton and Janice Dickinson appeared June 13, Rita Wilson June 14, Keanu Reeves plus Claudia Cohen’s Father’s Day report June 15, and Sandra Bullock with David Krumholtz for another Grill Friday June 16. Kelly Ripa then paired with Jeff Gordon June 20 to host Miley Cyrus, Wendie Malick and Corinne Bailey Rae. Regis and Kelly resumed June 21 with All-American Rejects, welcomed Adam Sandler and toy expert Chris Byrne June 22, Kate Beckinsale for Grill Friday June 23, Def Leppard with Carson Kressley co-hosting June 26, Meryl Streep and Brandon Routh June 27, Kate Bosworth June 28, and closed the stretch June 29 with Anne Hathaway and India.Arie.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Camden County, Missouri
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places listings in Camden County, Missouri. This is intended to be a complete list of the properties and districts on the National Register of Historic Places in Camden County, Missouri, United States. Latitude and longitude coordinates are provided for many National Register properties and districts; these locations may be seen together in a map. There are 10 properties and districts listed on the National Register in the county.
lm_description: Camp Hawthorne Central Area District and Camp Pin Oak Historic District, both northeast of Camdenton inside Lake of the Ozarks State Park, entered the National Register on 28 February 1985 and 27 June 1985 respectively. Also within that park, the Lake of the Ozarks Recreational Demonstration Area Barn/Garage in Kaiser Area, Rising Sun Shelter, and Shelter at McCubbin Point were listed on 28 February and 26 February 1985. The park’s Camp Clover Point Recreation Hall and Camp Rising Sun Recreation Hall followed on 4 March 1985, while the Highway 134 Historic District west of Brumley gained recognition on 26 February 1985. Pin Oak Hollow Bridge, inside the park at Pin Oak Hollow, was added on 13 September 1985. Nearly two decades later, the Urbauer Fishing Lodge Historic District at 442 Riverbird Lane in Camdenton joined the register on 8 November 2006.

title: List of National Hockey League retired numbers
intro:
This is a complete list of numbers retired by the National Hockey League (NHL). A retired number is a jersey number that is taken out of circulation by a team as a way of honouring a former member of that team who wore that number; after the number's retirement, members of that team are not permitted to wear the number on their jerseys unless by permission of the original number holder. The first team to retire a number was the Toronto Maple Leafs, which retired Ace Bailey's number 6 on February 14, 1934, prior to an All-Star game organized in his honour. The NHL currently has 128 retired numbers, 3 pending number retirements, 7 former retirements, and 23 honoured numbers. Most of the numbers retired by the Hartford Whalers and Quebec Nordiques were put back in circulation when those franchises relocated and became the Carolina Hurricanes and Colorado Avalanche
, respectively, although the Hurricanes keep Gordie Howe's number 9 unofficially retired. The Minnesota North Stars' two retired numbers were carried over when that franchise relocated to become the Dallas Stars, and remain retired today. The Arizona Coyotes had a policy of retaining the numbers retired when the franchise was the Winnipeg Jets but reversed it after the Phoenix Coyotes were sold and became the Arizona Coyotes. Honoured numbers are similar to retired numbers, except that they remain available for use by other players. Presently, only the Calgary Flames, and the St. Louis Blues employ this designation. The Philadelphia Flyers have also unofficially retired number 31 in honour of goaltender Pelle Lindbergh since his death in 1985. Wayne Gretzky's number 99 has been retired league-wide in 2000, although the Edmonton Oilers and Los Angeles Kings separately retired Gretzky's number. Upon joining the league in 2000, the Minnesota Wild had a ceremony retiring number 1 from circulation as a tribute to their fans.
lm_description: Ace Bailey’s number 6 was retired by the Toronto Maple Leafs on February 14, 1934, the league’s first such honour, while Bill Barilko’s 5 joined the rafters on October 17, 1992, and both Syl Apps and George Armstrong shared the October 15, 2016 retirement of number 10. Detroit Red Wings legend Sid Abel’s 12 was lifted on April 29, 1995, and Daniel Alfredsson’s 11 was put out of circulation by the Ottawa Senators on December 29, 2016. Glenn Anderson’s 9 was retired by the Edmonton Oilers on January 18, 2009, the same digit the New York Rangers withdrew for Andy Bathgate on February 22, 2009. Philadelphia Flyers stalwarts Barry Ashbee and Bill Barber saw 4 and 7 retired on October 13, 1977 and October 11, 1990 respectively. Montreal Canadiens immortalized Jean Beliveau’s 4 on October 9, 1971 and Emile Bouchard’s 3 on December 4, 2009. Ray Bourque uniquely had 77 retired twice within two months: by the Boston Bruins on October 4, 2001 and by the Colorado Avalanche on November 24, 2001. Mike Bossy’s 22 was raised by the New York Islanders on March 3, 1992, Rob Blake’s 4 by the Los Angeles Kings on January 17, 2015, Michel Briere’s 21 by the Pittsburgh Penguins on January 5, 2001, and Rod Brind’Amour’s 17 by the Carolina Hurricanes on February 18, 2011. Toronto further honoured Johnny Bower and Turk Broda by retiring number 1 for both on October 15, 2016.

The first team to retire a number was the Toronto Maple Leafs, which retired Ace Bailey's number 6 on February 14, 1934, prior to an All-Star game organized in his honour. The NHL currently has 128 retired numbers, 3 pending number retirements, 7 former retirements, and 23 honoured numbers. Most of the numbers retired by the Hartford Whalers and Quebec Nordiques were put back in circulation when those franchises relocated and became the Carolina Hurricanes and Colorado Avalanche , respectively, although the Hurricanes keep Gordie Howe's number 9 unofficially retired. The Minnesota North Stars' two retired numbers were carried over when that franchise relocated to become the Dallas Stars, and remain retired today. The Arizona Coyotes had a policy of retaining the numbers retired when the franchise was the Winnipeg Jets but reversed it after the Phoenix Coyotes were sold and became the Arizona Coyotes. Honoured numbers are similar to retired numbers, except that they remain available for use by other players. Presently, only the Calgary Flames, and the St. Louis Blues employ this designation. The Philadelphia Flyers have also unofficially retired number 31 in honour of goaltender Pelle Lindbergh since his death in 1985. Wayne Gretzky's number 99 has been retired league-wide in 2000, although the Edmonton Oilers and Los Angeles Kings separately retired Gretzky's number. Upon joining the league in 2000, the Minnesota Wild had a ceremony retiring number 1 from circulation as a tribute to their fans.
Ace Bailey’s number 6 was retired by the Toronto Maple Leafs on February 14, 1934, the league’s first such honour, while Bill Barilko’s 5 joined the rafters on October 17, 1992, and both Syl Apps and George Armstrong shared the October 15, 2016 retirement of number 10. Detroit Red Wings legend Sid Abel’s 12 was lifted on April 29, 1995, and Daniel Alfredsson’s 11 was put out of circulation by the Ottawa Senators on December 29, 2016. Glenn Anderson’s 9 was retired by the Edmonton Oilers on January 18, 2009, the same digit the New York Rangers withdrew for Andy Bathgate on February 22, 2009. Philadelphia Flyers stalwarts Barry Ashbee and Bill Barber saw 4 and 7 retired on October 13, 1977 and October 11, 1990 respectively. Montreal Canadiens immortalized Jean Beliveau’s 4 on October 9, 1971 and Emile Bouchard’s 3 on December 4, 2009. Ray Bourque uniquely had 77 retired twice within two months: by the Boston Bruins on October 4, 2001 and by the Colorado Avalanche on November 24, 2001. Mike Bossy’s 22 was raised by the New York Islanders on March 3, 1992, Rob Blake’s 4 by the Los Angeles Kings on January 17, 2015, Michel Briere’s 21 by the Pittsburgh Penguins on January 5, 2001, and Rod Brind’Amour’s 17 by the Carolina Hurricanes on February 18, 2011. Toronto further honoured Johnny Bower and Turk Broda by retiring number 1 for both on October 15, 2016.

title: Russia in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest
intro: Russia first competed in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest in 2005. Their first win came in 2006, when the Tomachevy Twins won for Russia with Vesenniy Jazz. Their second win came in 2017, when Polina Bogusevich won for Russia with Wings. Their worst result as of date has been achieved by Tatyana Mezhentseva and Denberel Oorzhak with the song A Time for Us in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2019 where they placed 13th. RTR has represented Russia at the Junior Eurovision Song Contest. The broadcaster has selected Ekaterina Ryabova to represent Russia at the Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2009 in Kiev with the song Malenkiy prints. Ekaterina Ryabova represented Russia once again in 2011 with the song Kak Romeo i Dzhulyetta. She was also the first returning artist in the history of the Junior Eurovision.
lm_description: Russia debuted at Junior Eurovision 2005 with Vladislav Krutskikh’s Russian-language “Doroga k solntsu,” finishing 9th with 66 points, then soared to victory in 2006 when the Tolmachevy Twins sang “Vesenniy jazz” for 154 points. Alexandra Golovchenko placed 6th in 2007 with “Otlichnitsa,” Mikhail Puntov 7th in 2008 with “Spit angel,” and Ekaterina Ryabova took silver in 2009 with “Malenkiy prints,” scoring 116 points. After Liza Drozd and Sasha Lazin repeated that runner-up spot in 2010 with the bilingual “Boy and Girl” on 119 points, Ryabova returned in 2011—becoming the contest’s first ever returning artist—and finished 4th with 99 points for “Romeo and Juliet.” Lerika, Dayana Kirillova and the Water of Life Project each placed 4th in 2012, 2013 and 2016 respectively, while Alisa Kozhikina’s “Dreamer” brought 5th place in 2014 and Mikhail Smirnov’s “Mechta” 6th in 2015. Polina Bogusevich gave Russia its second win in 2017, earning 188 points with “Wings,” before Anna Filipchuk slipped to 10th in 2018 with “Unbreakable.” The nation’s lowest result came in 2019 when Tatyana Mezhentseva and Denberel Oorzhak placed 13th with 72 points for “A Time for Us.”

title: Gabriel Macht
intro: Gabriel Swann Macht (born January 22, 1972) is an American actor and film producer best known for playing The Spirit in the eponymous 2008 film adaptation, as well as for his role as Harvey Specter on the USA Network series Suits.
lm_description: Gabriel Macht first appeared on television in 1991 as Tal Weaver in the Beverly Hills, 90210 episode “Leading from the Heart.” He followed with the 1995 TV movie Follow the River, portraying Johnny Draper, and later dropped by Spin City in 1997 as The Naked Guy in the “Snowbound” episode. In 1998 he played Barkley, a model-obsessed artist, in Sex and the City’s “Models and Mortals,” then took the role of Luke in the 1999 Wasteland installment “Best Laid Plans.” Macht embodied William Holden in the 2000 TV movie The Audrey Hepburn Story that same year he began a 13-episode run as Dr. Mark Gabriel, the main character of the short-lived series The Others. After an unaired 2005 Numb3rs pilot appearance as Don Eppes, he surfaced in the Archangel miniseries as R.J. O’Brian. From 2011 through 2019 Macht starred as Harvey Specter across nine seasons and 134 episodes of Suits, also serving as producer, and briefly reprised the role in a 2019 Pearson episode.
to_index_text:
Gabriel Macht
Gabriel Swann Macht (born January 22, 1972) is an American actor and film producer best known for playing The Spirit in the eponymous 2008 film adaptation, as well as for his role as Harvey Specter on the USA Network series Suits.
Gabriel Macht first appeared on television in 1991 as Tal Weaver in the Beverly Hills, 90210 episode “Leading from the Heart.” He followed with the 1995 TV movie Follow the River, portraying Johnny Draper, and later dropped by Spin City in 1997 as The Naked Guy in the “Snowbound” episode. In 1998 he played Barkley, a model-obsessed artist, in Sex and the City’s “Models and Mortals,” then took the role of Luke in the 1999 Wasteland installment “Best Laid Plans.” Macht embodied William Holden in the 2000 TV movie The Audrey Hepburn Story that same year he began a 13-episode run as Dr. Mark Gabriel, the main character of the short-lived series The Others. After an unaired 2005 Numb3rs pilot appearance as Don Eppes, he surfaced in the Archangel miniseries as R.J. O’Brian. From 2011 through 2019 Macht starred as Harvey Specter across nine seasons and 134 episodes of Suits, also serving as producer, and briefly reprised the role in a 2019 Pearson episode.

title: List of former local government areas of Queensland
intro: The local government areas (LGAs) of Queensland, Australia are the defined areas within which legally constituted local government authorities, known as councils, have responsibilities to provide local services. Determining the size and shape of the local government areas is the sole responsibility of the Queensland Government. In the past, many local government areas (especially in South East Queensland and the Darling Downs region) have been amalgamated or abolished, either voluntarily or involuntarily. The most significant of these processes took place in March 2008, when 97 local government areas and 20 indigenous councils were amalgamated under a statewide reform process - until this time, the majority of Queensland's local government areas had remained unchanged for decades and some even dated back to the establishment of local government for regional areas in 1879.
lm_description: In 1925 the South-East Queensland shires of Balmoral, Belmont, Coorparoo, Enoggera, Kedron, Moggill, Sherwood, Stephens and Taringa, together with the part-shires Tingalpa and Yeerongpilly, were abolished and folded into the new City of Brisbane. The same fate befell the former City of Brisbane itself, the City of South Brisbane, and the towns Hamilton, Ithaca—proclaimed in 1903—Toowong, Windsor and Sandgate, all absorbed into the enlarged capital city at the same moment.
to_index_text:
List of former local government areas of Queensland
The local government areas (LGAs) of Queensland, Australia are the defined areas within which legally constituted local government authorities, known as councils, have responsibilities to provide local services. Determining the size and shape of the local government areas is the sole responsibility of the Queensland Government. In the past, many local government areas (especially in South East Queensland and the Darling Downs region) have been amalgamated or abolished, either voluntarily or involuntarily. The most significant of these processes took place in March 2008, when 97 local government areas and 20 indigenous councils were amalgamated under a statewide reform process - until this time, the majority of Queensland's local government areas had remained unchanged for decades and some even dated back to the establishment of local government for regional areas in 1879.
In 1925 the South-East Queensland shires of Balmoral, Belmont, Coorparoo, Enoggera, Kedron, Moggill, Sherwood, Stephens and Taringa, together with the part-shires Tingalpa and Yeerongpilly, were abolished and folded into the new City of Brisbane. The same fate befell the former City of Brisbane itself, the City of South Brisbane, and the towns Hamilton, Ithaca—proclaimed in 1903—Toowong, Windsor and Sandgate, all absorbed into the enlarged capital city at the same moment.

title: List of Olympic venues in tennis
intro: For the Summer Olympics, there are 15 venues that have been used for tennis. This counts separately the two different venues of the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club at Wimbledon: The original Worple Road venue (now used by Wimbledon High School) was used for the 1908 Summer Olympics; the current Church Road venue, opened in 1922, was used for the 2012 Summer Olympics. (Each venue was also used that year for the Wimbledon Championships.)
lm_description: Athens 1896 staged its tennis on clay at both the Athens Lawn Tennis Club and the Neo Phaliron Velodrome, the latter holding 7,000 spectators, while Paris 1900 used the clay courts of Cercle de Puteaux. Francis Field in St. Louis 1904, also clay, hosted the tournament, and London 1908 switched to grass at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club. Stockholm 1912 chose clay at the Östermalm Athletic Grounds, Antwerp 1920 returned to grass at Beerschot Tennis Club, and Paris 1924 again favoured clay at Stade de Tennis de Colombes. After a long hiatus, Seoul 1988 built a 15,000-seat Olympic Tennis Center with hard courts, followed by Barcelona 1992’s clay Vall d’Hebron complex seating 8,000. Atlanta 1996 erected the 27,500-capacity Stone Mountain Tennis Center on hard courts, Sydney 2000’s NSW Tennis Centre held 10,000 on hard courts, and Athens 2004’s Olympic Tennis Centre seated 8,600 on the same surface. Beijing 2008’s Olympic Green Tennis Center accommodated 17,400, London 2012 returned to the All England Club’s grass with 30,000 seats, Rio 2016’s Olympic Tennis Centre held 18,250 on hard courts, and Tokyo 2020’s Ariake Tennis Forest Park closed the list with 18,000 hard-court seats.

title: ISO 3166-3
intro: ISO 3166-3 is part of the ISO 3166 standard published by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO), and defines codes for country names which have been deleted from ISO 3166-1 since its first publication in 1974. The official name of the standard is Codes for the representation of names of countries and their subdivisions - Part 3: Code for formerly used names of countries. It was first published in 1999. Each former country name in ISO 3166-3 is assigned a four-letter alphabetic code. The first two letters are the ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 code of the former country, while the last two letters are allocated according to the following rules:
lm_description: Between 1974 and 2010, twenty country names vanished from ISO 3166-1 and received four-letter “formerly-used” codes. Burma became Myanmar (BUMM) while keeping numeric code 104; Dahomey turned into Benin (DYBJ); New Hebrides adopted the name Vanuatu (NHVU); East Timor restyled itself Timor-Leste (TPTL); French Afars and Issas emerged as Djibouti (AIDJ); Byelorussian SSR simplified to Belarus (BYAA). Czechoslovakia split into the Czech Republic and Slovakia (CSHH), Gilbert and Ellice Islands separated into Kiribati and Tuvalu (GEHH), Netherlands Antilles dissolved into Bonaire-Sint Eustatius-Saba, Curaçao and Sint Maarten (ANHH), and the Pacific Trust Territory fragmented into Marshall Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, Northern Mariana Islands and Palau (PCHH). The Neutral Zone was absorbed partly by Iraq and partly by Saudi Arabia (NTHH). Several territories merged into larger entities: British Antarctic Territory and Dronning Maud Land into Antarctica (BQAQ, NQAQ), French Southern and Antarctic Territories into Adélie Land/Antarctica and French Southern Territories (FQHH), Johnston and Midway Islands into United States Minor Outlying Islands (JTUM, MIUM), Metropolitan France back into France (FXFR), German Democratic Republic into Germany (DDDE), Canton and Enderbury Islands into Kiribati (CTKI), and the Panama Canal Zone into Panama (PZPA).

title: List of mosques in Taiwan
intro: As of February 2018, there are eight mosques in Taiwan. The following table is the list of mosques in Taiwan. Taipei Grand Mosque is the largest and oldest mosque in Taiwan.
lm_description: Taipei Grand Mosque, founded in 1947 and rebuilt in 1960 in Da’an, Taipei, is Taiwan’s oldest and largest mosque. Kaohsiung Mosque followed, begun in 1949, re-erected in 1951, and replaced again in 1992 in Lingya, Kaohsiung. Taipei Cultural Mosque started in 1950 and gained its present building in Zhongzheng, Taipei, in 1982. Taichung Mosque originated in 1951 and moved into its current Nantun, Taichung, structure in 1990. Longgang Mosque, launched in Zhongli, Taoyuan, in 1967, was reconstructed on the same site in 1989. Tainan Mosque opened in September 1996, also in Nantun, Taichung. At-Taqwa Mosque, known locally as Dayuan Mosque, was completed in Dayuan, Taoyuan, on 9 June 2013. An-Nur Tongkang Mosque began serving Donggang, Pingtung, on 18 February 2018, and Hualien Al-Falah Mosque welcomed worshippers in Hualien City starting 18 March 2018.

title: 2008 in video games
intro: 2008 has seen many sequels and prequels in video games. New intellectual properties include Army of Two, Dead Space, Left 4 Dead, LittleBigPlanet, Mirror's Edge, Race Driver: Grid, Grand Theft Auto IV and Spore.
lm_description: Rockstar’s Grand Theft Auto IV arrived on 29 April 2008 for both PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360, earning 98 from Metacritic and 97.04% or 96.67% on GameRankings. Sony Computer Entertainment released LittleBigPlanet on 27 October 2008 for PlayStation 3, scoring 95 and 94.75%. 2D Boy’s World of Goo debuted 13 October 2008 on Wii with 94 and 94.04%, and the Windows version the same day managed 90 and 92.27%. BioShock landed on PlayStation 3 on 17 October 2008 via 2K Games, achieving 94 and 93.66%. Konami shipped Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots on 12 June 2008 for PlayStation 3, gaining 94 and 93.53%. Microsoft Game Studios launched Gears of War 2 on 7 November 2008 for Xbox 360, scoring 93 and 93.32%. Bethesda Softworks’ Fallout 3 released 28 October 2008 on Xbox 360, earning 93 and 92.85%. Nintendo’s Super Smash Bros. Brawl arrived 31 January 2008 on Wii with 93 and 92.84%. Number None’s Braid debuted 6 August 2008 on Xbox 360, achieving 93 and 92.15%. Nintendo’s Flipnote Studio released 24 December 2008 on Nintendo DS, scoring 93 and 91%. Blizzard Entertainment’s World of Warcraft: Wrath of the Lich King launched 13 November 2008 on Windows, earning 91 and 92.68%. Stardock’s Galactic Civilizations II: Twilight of the Arnor released 30 April 2008 on Windows, gaining 92 and 92.33%. Atlus’ Persona 4 arrived 10 July 2008 on PlayStation 2, scoring 90 and 92.28%. MTV Games’ Rock Band 2 released 14 September 2008 on Xbox 360 (92 and 92.25%), Wii (92 and 91.33%), and PlayStation 3 (91 and 91.5%). Square Enix’s Chrono Trigger launched 20 November 2008 on Nintendo DS, achieving 92 and 91.98%. Sony Computer Entertainment’s God of War: Chains of Olympus debuted 4 March 2008 on PlayStation Portable, earning 91 and 91.44%.

title: List of the busiest airports in Canada
intro: The following is a list of the busiest airports in Canada. The airports are ranked by passenger traffic and aircraft movements. For each airport, the lists cite the city served by the airport as designated by Transport Canada, not necessarily the municipality where the airport is physically located. Since 2010, Toronto-Pearson and Vancouver International have been the two busiest airports by both passengers served and aircraft movements. Toronto-Pearson's location within the most populous metropolitan region of Canada solidifies its top spot amongst all of Canada's airports, serving more passengers and having more aircraft movements than the top two other airports combined. Given its advantageous position on the west coast of Canada, Vancouver International has long served as Canada's hub for flights bound for Asia and Oceania.
lm_description: Toronto Pearson International Airport leads Canada with 44,335,198 passengers, up 8.0%, serving Greater Toronto. Vancouver International follows with 22,288,926 passengers, a 9.7% rise, for Metro Vancouver. Montréal-Trudeau ranks third, carrying 16,589,067 travelers, 6.9% more than the previous year, for Greater Montreal. Calgary International handled 15,680,616 passengers, growing 1.3%, for the Calgary Region. Edmonton International welcomed 7,523,864 passengers, up 5.7%, to the Edmonton Metropolitan Region. Ottawa Macdonald-Cartier served 4,743,091, a 1.9% increase, for the National Capital Region. Winnipeg Richardson saw 4,015,200 passengers, 6.3% higher, for the Winnipeg Capital Region. Halifax Stanfield accommodated 3,908,799, up 5.6%, for Halifax. Billy Bishop Toronto City Airport, on the downtown island, carried 2,700,000 passengers, surging 9.0%. Victoria International reached 1,856,421 travelers, 8.5% more, for Greater Victoria. Kelowna International climbed to 1,732,113 passengers, 8.7% growth, for Kelowna and the Okanagan Valley. Québec City Jean Lesage handled 1,615,750, up 2.0%. St. John’s International served 1,600,000, rising 4.3%. Saskatoon John G. Diefenbaker carried 1,450,000, edging up 0.5%. Regina International welcomed 1,262,899, up 0.6%. Thunder Bay International reached 807,041 passengers, 4.5% higher. Fort McMurray International soared 32.3% to 744,798. Greater Moncton Roméo LeBlanc handled 657,272, up 2.0%. Yellowknife Airport served 575,000, climbing 7.0%. Abbotsford International closed the top twenty with 530,643 passengers, up 8.8%, for Abbotsford and the Fraser Valley.

title: Dick Hyde (musician)
intro: Richard John Hyde (July 4, 1936 - July 15, 2019), sometimes credited as Slyde Hyde, was an American trombonist who played several brass and woodwind instruments. He was a member of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (NARAS) Hall of Fame. He worked as a session musician and sideman for Count Basie, Herbie Hancock, Frank Sinatra, Jaco Pastorius, Steely Dan, Earth, Wind & Fire, The Beach Boys, Tom Waits, Supertramp, Temptations, Box Scaggs, Ringo Starr, Carole King, Madonna, and Donna Summer.
lm_description: In 1960 Dick Hyde played trombone on Ann Richards and Stan Kenton’s Capitol jazz-pop album “Two Much!”. Six years later he supplied the same horn for Nancy Sinatra’s Reprise set “Sugar”, and in 1967 doubled on trombone and tuba for Ian Whitcomb’s rock outing “Yellow Underground” on Tower while also blowing trombone for Harpers Bizarre’s Warner Bros. pop-rock release “Feelin’ Groovy”. 1968 found him switching to woodwinds for Van Dyke Parks’ “Song Cycle” and returning to trombone for Mason Williams’ “The Mason Williams Phonograph Record”, both on Warner Bros. The next year he contributed trombone to the multi-genre “Fused” by The Mike Post Coalition, Bob Jung’s big-band “Jung! : The Big Band Syndrome” on Command, Bugsy’s pop-rock “Inside Bugsy” on Dot, and Blue Mitchell’s funky “Collision in Black” on Blue Note. Hyde’s 1970s sessions began with trombone on David Axelrod’s jazz-rock “Earth Rot” for Capitol and Neil Diamond’s rock opus “Tap Root Manuscript” on Uni, followed by Chet Baker’s Verve jazz set “Blood, Chet and Tears”. He then played trombone on Rita Coolidge’s 1971 A&M album “Rita Coolidge”, Dory Previn’s folk-country “Reflections in a Mud Puddle” on United Artists, and David Axelrod’s jazz-funk “The Auction” on Decca. In 1972 he shifted to horn for Henry Mancini’s RCA Victor soundtrack “Music from the TV Series: The Mancini Generation”, and in 1973 supplied horn for Arlo Guthrie’s “Gypsy Davy” track on “Last of the Brooklyn Cowboys”, Cheech & Chong’s comedy-rock “Los Cochinos” on Ode, and trombone for Claudia Lennear’s funk-soul “Phew” on Warner Bros.
to_index_text:
Dick Hyde (musician)
Richard John Hyde (July 4, 1936 - July 15, 2019), sometimes credited as Slyde Hyde, was an American trombonist who played several brass and woodwind instruments. He was a member of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (NARAS) Hall of Fame. He worked as a session musician and sideman for Count Basie, Herbie Hancock, Frank Sinatra, Jaco Pastorius, Steely Dan, Earth, Wind & Fire, The Beach Boys, Tom Waits, Supertramp, Temptations, Box Scaggs, Ringo Starr, Carole King, Madonna, and Donna Summer.

title: List of Michigan State Historic Sites in Chippewa County
intro: The following is a list of Michigan State Historic Sites in Chippewa County, Michigan. Sites marked with a dagger (†) are also listed on the National Register of Historic Places in Chippewa County, Michigan.
lm_description: Allen House at 126 E. Water Street in Sault Ste. Marie became a Michigan State Historic Site on October 1, 1971, the same day the Old Union Carbide dock at the foot of Johnstone Street was honored as the Louis W. Hill site. Bishop Frederick Baraga’s house at 501 E. Water Street and the John Johnston House at 415 East Waters Street both received their historic status on February 19, 1958. The Bay City House Hotel, 501 East Portage, was listed March 22, 1983, while the Carnegie Library at 315 Armory Place joined the register January 8, 1981. Central Methodist Church, 111 East Spruce Street, gained recognition June 17, 1993, and the Church of Our Saviour, Friend of Children on North Shore Road of Sugar Island’s Payment Settlement was honored January 19, 1978. Elmwood, 435 E. Water Street, dates to September 25, 1956, and the Federal Building, 209 East Portage Avenue, to December 14, 1976. Birch Lodge on 21830 S. Birch Lodge Drive in Trout Lake was listed November 20, 1987. Fort Brady, bounded by C.O.E. Service Plaza, Portage, Brady, and Bingham streets, and Fort Colyer on Drummond Island’s Whitney Bay, trace to August 23 and November 27, 1956. Fort Repentigny and Governor Cass and the Indians informational designations at Park Place and River Street and Brady Field both date to February 18, 1956. Johnston Homestead on Neebish Island near Barbeau was listed April 4, 1975. Lake Superior State College at West Easterday and Meridian roads, Larke Road at Three Mile Road, Legends of Hiawatha at Tahquamenon Falls State Park in Whitefish Township, and the Emerson Informational Site along M-123 near Paradise followed in 1975, 1982, 1959, and 1979.

title: Ebony Shoe
intro:
The Ebony Shoe award (Dutch: Ebbenhouten schoen, French: Soulier d'ébène) is a football award in Belgium given annually to the best African or African origin player in the Belgian Pro League. The jury is composed of the coaches of league clubs, the Belgian national team manager, sport journalists, and one or more honorary jurors. [citation needed]
 As of 2019, Mbark Boussoufa (3 wins), Daniel Amokachi (2 wins) and Vincent Kompany (2 wins) are the only players to have won the trophy more than once.
lm_description: Democratic Republic of the Congo dominates the Ebony Shoe with ten victories: 1997, 2000, 2004, 2005, 2011, 2012, 2014, 2015, 2017 and 2018. Nigeria followed with five straight wins from 1992 through 1996. Morocco claimed four awards in 2006, 2008, 2009 and 2010. Ghana, Guinea, Egypt, Burkina Faso, Ivory Coast, Burundi, Senegal, Algeria and Tanzania each lifted the trophy once, respectively in 1998, 1999, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2007, 2013, 2016 and 2019.
to_index_text:
Ebony Shoe

[citation needed] As of 2019, Mbark Boussoufa (3 wins), Daniel Amokachi (2 wins) and Vincent Kompany (2 wins) are the only players to have won the trophy more than once.

title: List of places of worship in Mole Valley
intro: As of 2020, the district of Mole Valley has more than 70 current and former places of worship: 56 buildings are in use by various Christian denominations and other religions, and a further 16 are no longer in religious use but survive in other uses or - in two cases - as ruins. Mole Valley is one of 11 local government districts in the English county of Surrey - a small inland county south of London which is characterised by small market towns, ancient villages and 20th-century suburbs. The latest census results show that the majority of residents are Christian. Dorking, one of the district's two main towns, has a Muslim community centre and mosque, but all other places of worship serve Christian denominations. The Church of England - the country's Established Church - is represented by the largest number of churches. The Roman Catholic Church and the larger Protestant Nonconformist groups such as Methodists, Baptists and the United Reformed Church each have several buildings and congregations of their own. Quakers, Christian Scientists, Plymouth Brethren and other smaller groups also have their own chapels and meeting rooms, mostly in Dorking and the other main town of Leatherhead. English Heritage has awarded listed status to 29 current and three former places of worship in the district. A building is defined as listed when it is placed on a statutory register of buildings of special architectural or historic interest in accordance with the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990. The Department for Culture, Media and Sport, a Government department, is responsible for this; English Heritage, a non-departmental public body, acts as an agency of the department to administer the process and advise the department on relevant issues. There are three grades of listing status. Grade I, the highest, is defined as being of exceptional interest; Grade II* is used for particularly important buildings of more than special interest; and Grade II, the lowest, is used for buildings of special interest.
lm_description: St James’s at Abinger Common, Grade II*, is a restored 12th- and 13th-century Surrey vernacular church whose Lawrence Lee 1967 east window holds the county’s finest modern glass. In Ashtead, the 13th-century St Giles, Grade II*, keeps 16th-century stained glass from Herckenrode Abbey, while its 1905 brick chapel-of-ease St George’s was designed by Blomfield’s firm; nearby, Ashtead Baptist Church, registered in 1924, succeeded an 1895 chapel, and St Michael’s Roman Catholic Church, registered October 1967, replaced a 1948 building with Peter French’s octagonal brick design. Betchworth’s Grade I St Michael’s, mid-13th-century but reworked 1851 and 1870, memorialises Sir Benjamin Collins Brodie. Box Hill’s St Andrew’s, completed 1969, links to Brockham’s Christ Church, Ferrey’s 1850 Grade II limestone-and-firestone cruciform. Buckland’s Grade II St Mary the Virgin was wholly rebuilt 1860 by Henry Woodyer with Bargate stone and a shingled bell turret; Woodyer also rebuilt Capel’s 13th-century St John the Baptist in 1865 with similar materials. Capel’s 1724-25 Quaker meeting house, Grade II, serves a 1650s congregation. Charlwood’s Grade I St Nicholas shows Norman origins, 13th-century aisle and 15th-century reconfiguration. Coldharbour’s 1848 Christ Church, Ferrey’s sandstone chapel rebuilt 1904 by Caröe, crowns a hilltop. In Dorking, St Paul’s (1857) and St Martin’s (1868-77, Grade II*) share Ferrey and Woodyer designs; St Martin’s now houses Methodists whose earlier chapels are gone. Crossways Baptist (1869/76) and Dorking Baptist Chapel’s 1910 tin-tabernacle-cored building serve Baptists, while Moores Road shelters the First Church of Christ, Scientist. The former Plymouth Brethren room on Hart Road, registered 1984, became the 100-capacity Dorking Muslim Community Association and Mosque in 2006; Brethren now meet in the Mint Gardens room registered March 1997.

title: 1991 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships
intro: The 26th Artistic Gymnastics World Championships were held in Indianapolis, United States, in the Hoosier Dome from September 6 to 15, 1991. This was the last championships at which the Soviet Union competed.
lm_description: Grigory Misutin of the Soviet Union topped the standings with 9.875, while Germany’s Andreas Wecker took second at 9.862 and Italy’s Yuri Chechi claimed third at 9.837. Li Xiaoshuang earned fourth place for China with 9.812, followed by Soviet Valeri Liukin in fifth at 9.800. Americans Scott Keswick and Japan’s Yukio Iketani tied for sixth, each scoring 9.775, and Li Jing of China closed the list in eighth with 9.362.
to_index_text:
1991 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships
The 26th Artistic Gymnastics World Championships were held in Indianapolis, United States, in the Hoosier Dome from September 6 to 15, 1991. This was the last championships at which the Soviet Union competed.
Grigory Misutin of the Soviet Union topped the standings with 9.875, while Germany’s Andreas Wecker took second at 9.862 and Italy’s Yuri Chechi claimed third at 9.837. Li Xiaoshuang earned fourth place for China with 9.812, followed by Soviet Valeri Liukin in fifth at 9.800. Americans Scott Keswick and Japan’s Yukio Iketani tied for sixth, each scoring 9.775, and Li Jing of China closed the list in eighth with 9.362.

title: List of ViacomCBS television programs
intro: This is a list of television series produced and/or owned by ViacomCBS' brands, including Paramount Television Studios, CBS Television Studios, CBS Television Distribution, CBS News, and ViacomCBS media networks. This list also includes shows produced or distributed by ViacomCBS' predecessor companies, including CBS Productions, Viacom Productions/Enterprises, the older incarnation of Paramount Television, Rysher Entertainment, Republic Pictures Television, Worldvision Enterprises/Taft Entertainment, Group W Productions, KingWorld, Desilu Productions and Spelling Television.
lm_description: The Fugitive ran on ABC from 1963 to 1967 in partnership with United Artists Television, while The Invaders occupied the same network a year later, 1967-1968. Dan August followed on ABC for the 1970-1971 season, after which CBS launched Cannon, a 1971-1976 crime drama that Viacom later handled in syndication. ABC’s The Streets of San Francisco spanned 1972-1977, with Warner Bros. Television involved only on the pilot and first season. Over on CBS, Barnaby Jones solved cases from 1973 to 1980, Woodruff Productions stepping in for its last two seasons, and The Manhunter tracked fugitives across 1974-1975. ABC closed the 1970s with the single-season Caribe in 1975, Bert D’Angelo/Superstar in 1976—later syndicated by Viacom—and the 1976-1977 manhunt series Most Wanted. NBC entered the Quinn Martin stable in 1977 with Quinn Martin’s Tales of the Unexpected, continued with The Runaways (1978-1979) alongside New Vistas Productions, and ended the decade with A Man Called Sloane in 1979, again with Woodruff Productions.

title: List of Historic Sites of Japan (Tottori)
intro: This list is of the Historic Sites of Japan located within the Prefecture of Tottori.
lm_description: Kotoura shelters the vanished Sainoo temple and the mountain palace where emperors once paused at Senjōsan, while nearby Ōtaka preserves the offices that once administered the region. Kurayoshi guards three ancient tombs—Amidaji, Sanmyōji and the tower bases of Ōhara and Ōmidō temples—echoing a time when courtiers and monks shared the same hills. Tottori city itself claims the tomb of Ifukibe Tokotari-hime, the solid Kajiyama burial mound, and the Aoyakamiji ruins where early farmers left their pots. Iwami’s Iwai Haiji once rose in pagoda form above the coast, and Misasa’s forested Mount Mitoku still carries the memory of ascetic monks. Yurihama’s Hashizu tombs and Yonago’s Mukoeyama and Aoki sites trace the same kofun culture, while the sprawling Mukibanda settlement spills across both Yonago and Daizen. Wakasa keeps the ghost-story stones of Oniga Castle, and Kamiyodo Haiji in Yonago marks another lost temple yard. Farther south, the old Chizu Road climbs over Shitosaka Pass, a route once traveled by merchants and warriors alike.

Farther south, the old Chizu Road climbs over Shitosaka Pass, a route once traveled by merchants and warriors alike.

title: Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge
intro: Sidney Sussex College (referred to informally as Sidney) is a constituent college of the University of Cambridge in England. The college was founded in 1596 under the terms of the will of Frances Sidney, Countess of Sussex (1531-1589) wife of Thomas Radclyffe, 3rd Earl of Sussex and named after its founder. It was from its inception an avowedly Protestant foundation; some good and godlie moniment for the mainteynance of good learninge. In her will, Lady Sussex left the sum of £5,000 together with some plate to found a new college at Cambridge University to be called the Lady Frances Sidney Sussex College. Her executors Sir John Harington and Henry Grey, 6th Earl of Kent, supervised by Archbishop John Whitgift, founded the college seven years after her death.
lm_description: Sir Thomas Adams, 1st Baronet, born 1586 and dying 1667/8, served as Lord Mayor of London. William Ross Ashby, 1903–1972, pioneered cybernetics. Tony Badger, born 1947, is Paul Mellon Professor of American History at Cambridge and Master of Clare College. Karan Bilimoria, Baron Bilimoria, born 1961, is a businessman, Chairman of Cobra Beer, and Chancellor of the University of Birmingham. Lawrence Booth, born 1975, edits Wisden Cricketers' Almanack. Ronald N. Bracewell, 1921–2007, was a physicist. John Bramhall, 1594–1663, became Archbishop. Asa Briggs, 1921–2016, was a historian. Ann Copestake, born 1959, is Professor of Computational Linguistics at Cambridge. Stuart Corbridge, born 1957, is Vice-Chancellor of Durham University. Oliver Cromwell, 1599–1658, was Lord Protector. Rebecca Evans, born 1976, is a politician. Thomas Fuller, 1608–1661, was an author, churchman, and historian. William Du Gard, 1602–1662, was a printer. Sue Gibson, born 1960, is Research Chemist, Chair in Chemistry, and Director of the Graduate School at Imperial College London. Chris Grayling, born 1962, is Secretary of State for Transport. Dick Heckstall-Smith, 1934–2004, was a musician. John Herivel, 1918–2011, was a Bletchley Park cryptanalyst and science historian. Ronald Holmes, 1913–1981, was a colonial government official. Alex Horne, born 1978, is a comedian.

title: List of Presidents of the Senate of Puerto Rico
intro: This is a list of people that have held the post of President of the Senate of Puerto Rico. The Senate has elected its own President from more than 103 years since the Jones-Shafroth Act formally established the post on March 2, 1917.
lm_description: Antonio R. Barceló, a Unionist, served as the first President of the Puerto Rico Senate from 1917 to 1929, working alongside pro-tempore presiders Eduardo Georgetti (1917-1921), Juan Hernández López (1921-1924), and Luis Sánchez Morales (1926-1929). Luis Sánchez Morales, a Republican, succeeded him from 1929 to 1933 with Celestino Iriarte Miró as pro-tempore. Rafael Martínez Nadal, also Republican, held the presidency from 1933 to 1941, first with Bolívar Pagán (1933-1940) and later Luis Padrón Rivera (1940-1941) as pro-tempore. Luis Muñoz Marín of the PPD served from 1941 to 1949, with Francisco M. Susoni Abreu (1941-1944) and Samuel R. Quiñones (1945-1949) as pro-tempore. Samuel R. Quiñones continued as president from 1949 to 1969 with Luis Negrón López as pro-tempore. Rafael Hernández Colón (1969-1973) and Juan J. Cancel Ríos (1973-1977), both PPD members, served consecutively with Juan J. Cancel Ríos and Miguel Hernández Agosto as their respective pro-tempores. Luis A. Ferré Aguayo of the PNP served from 1977 to 1981 with Manuel Ramos Barroso as pro-tempore, followed by Miguel Hernández Agosto (PPD) from 1981 to 1993 with Sergio Peña Clos (1981-1988) and Miguel Deynes Soto (1989-1993). Roberto Rexach Benítez (PNP) served from 1993 to 1997 with Nicolás Nogueras Cartagena (1993-1995) and Luisa Lebrón de Rivera (1995-1997). Charles A. Rodríguez Colón (PNP) held office from 1997 to 2001 with Aníbal Marrero Pérez (1997-2000) and Luz Z. Arce Ferrer (2000-2001). Antonio Fas Alzamora (PPD) served from 2001 to 2005 with Velda González de Modestti as pro-tempore. Kenneth D. McClintock Hernández (PNP) served from 2005 to 2009 with Orlando Parga Figueroa. Thomas Rivera Schatz first served from 2009 to 2013 with Margarita Nolasco Santiago, then returned in 2017 to serve until the present with Larry Seilhamer Rodríguez as pro-tempore. Eduardo Bhatia (PPD) served from 2013 to 2017 with José Luis Dalmau as pro-tempore.
to_index_text:
List of Presidents of the Senate of Puerto Rico
This is a list of people that have held the post of President of the Senate of Puerto Rico. The Senate has elected its own President from more than 103 years since the Jones-Shafroth Act formally established the post on March 2, 1917.
Antonio R. Barceló, a Unionist, served as the first President of the Puerto Rico Senate from 1917 to 1929, working alongside pro-tempore presiders Eduardo Georgetti (1917-1921), Juan Hernández López (1921-1924), and Luis Sánchez Morales (1926-1929). Luis Sánchez Morales, a Republican, succeeded him from 1929 to 1933 with Celestino Iriarte Miró as pro-tempore. Rafael Martínez Nadal, also Republican, held the presidency from 1933 to 1941, first with Bolívar Pagán (1933-1940) and later Luis Padrón Rivera (1940-1941) as pro-tempore. Luis Muñoz Marín of the PPD served from 1941 to 1949, with Francisco M. Susoni Abreu (1941-1944) and Samuel R. Quiñones (1945-1949) as pro-tempore. Samuel R. Quiñones continued as president from 1949 to 1969 with Luis Negrón López as pro-tempore. Rafael Hernández Colón (1969-1973) and Juan J. Cancel Ríos (1973-1977), both PPD members, served consecutively with Juan J. Cancel Ríos and Miguel Hernández Agosto as their respective pro-tempores. Luis A. Ferré Aguayo of the PNP served from 1977 to 1981 with Manuel Ramos Barroso as pro-tempore, followed by Miguel Hernández Agosto (PPD) from 1981 to 1993 with Sergio Peña Clos (1981-1988) and Miguel Deynes Soto (1989-1993). Roberto Rexach Benítez (PNP) served from 1993 to 1997 with Nicolás Nogueras Cartagena (1993-1995) and Luisa Lebrón de Rivera (1995-1997). Charles A. Rodríguez Colón (PNP) held office from 1997 to 2001 with Aníbal Marrero Pérez (1997-2000) and Luz Z. Arce Ferrer (2000-2001). Antonio Fas Alzamora (PPD) served from 2001 to 2005 with Velda González de Modestti as pro-tempore. Kenneth D. McClintock Hernández (PNP) served from 2005 to 2009 with Orlando Parga Figueroa. Thomas Rivera Schatz first served from 2009 to 2013 with Margarita Nolasco Santiago, then returned in 2017 to serve until the present with Larry Seilhamer Rodríguez as pro-tempore. Eduardo Bhatia (PPD) served from 2013 to 2017 with José Luis Dalmau as pro-tempore.

title: Hiragana and katakana place names
intro: The hiragana cities of Japan are municipalities whose names are written in hiragana rather than kanji as is traditional for Japanese place names. Many hiragana city names have kanji equivalents that are either phonetic manyōgana, or whose kanji are now obsolete. [citation needed] Others, such as Tsukuba in Ibaraki Prefecture, are taken from localities or landmarks whose names continue to be written in kanji.
lm_description: Ama in Aichi is officially あま市 though its kanji 海部 survives, while Fukui’s Awara appears as あわら市 beside the older 芦原. えびの市 names Ebino in Miyazaki, written 蝦野 in kanji, and えりも町 stands for Erimo in Hokkaidō, whose kanji 襟裳 is still recognised. Ibaraki gives two examples: Hitachinaka is ひたちなか市 with 常陸那珂, and Kasumigaura is かすみがうら市 paired with 霞ヶ浦. Mie’s Inabe is いなべ市 against 員弁, Kōchi’s Ino appears as いの町 beside 伊野, and Chiba’s Isumi is いすみ市 though 夷隅 remains. Fukushima’s Iwaki is written いわき市 while 磐城 persists, and Ishikawa’s Kahoku is かほく市 against 河北. Wakayama supplies Katsuragi as かつらぎ町 with 葛城 and Minabe as みなべ町 with 南部. Gunma counters with Midori written みどり市 though 緑 is known, and Minakami as みなかみ町 beside 水上. Aichi’s Miyoshi is みよし市 paired with 三好, Hokkaidō’s Mukawa is むかわ町 against 鵡川, and Aomori offers Mutsu as むつ市 with 陸奥 and Oirase as おいらせ町 with 奥入瀬. Akita’s Nikaho completes the set as にかほ市 though 仁賀保 is remembered.

title: West Germany at the 1976 Winter Olympics
intro: West Germany (Federal Republic of Germany) competed at the 1976 Winter Olympics in Innsbruck, Austria.
lm_description: Rosi Mittermaier dominated Alpine skiing for West Germany, winning gold in the women’s downhill and slalom and adding silver in the giant slalom. Wolfgang Zimmerer and Manfred Schumann teamed up for silver in the two-man bobsleigh, then joined Peter Utzschneider and Bodo Bittner to take bronze in the four-man event. Josef Fendt claimed silver in the men’s individual luge, while Hans Brandner and Balthasar Schwarm did likewise in the men’s doubles. Urban Hettich earned silver in the Nordic combined individual contest. The West German men’s national ice hockey squad—featuring Erich Weißhaupt, Anton Kehle, Rudolf Thanner, Josef Volk, Udo Kiessling, Stefan Metz, Klaus Auhuber, Ignaz Berndaner, Rainer Phillip, Lorenz Funk, Wolfgang Boos, Ernst Köpf, Ferenc Vozar, Walter Koberle, Erich Kühnhackl, Alois Schloder, Martin Hinterstocker and Franz Reindl—took bronze in the men’s competition, and Elisabeth Demleitner added another bronze in the women’s individual luge.
