title: 2002 MLS SuperDraft
intro: The 2002 Major League Soccer SuperDraft was held on February 10, 2002 in Lake Buena Vista, Florida. One month earlier, MLS had contracted two clubs: Tampa Bay Mutiny and Miami Fusion. In conjunction with the contraction, the league conducted both an Allocation Draft and a Dispersal Draft in which the top 2002 SuperDraft picks of Tampa Bay and Miami, as well as players from those clubs, were made available to remaining MLS clubs.
lm_description: With the 26th pick Chicago Fire tabbed Virginia midfielder Steve Totten, and Los Angeles followed at 27 by snapping up UNC-Greensboro forward Alejandro Moreno. Colorado used back-to-back selections, 28 and 29, to pluck Washington defender Bryn Ritchie and Furman midfielder Daniel Alvarez, then struck again at 34 to take Stanford midfielder Matt Moses. MetroStars chose UConn defender Sam Forko 30th, D.C. United grabbed SMU forward Mohammed Fahim 31st, and Kansas City selected Long Island Rough Riders forward O'Neil Peart 32nd. San Jose claimed California midfielder Chris Roner 33rd, while Columbus took Furman forward John Barry Nusum 35th. Chicago returned at 36 to add St. Louis forward Dipsy Selolwane, Kansas City again took a defender at 37 in Southwest Missouri State’s Chris Brunt, the Galaxy closed the 38th slot with Brown defender Cory Gibbs, and San Jose finished the sequence by drafting Duke defender Kevin Sakuda 39th.
to_index_text:
2002 MLS SuperDraft
The 2002 Major League Soccer SuperDraft was held on February 10, 2002 in Lake Buena Vista, Florida. One month earlier, MLS had contracted two clubs: Tampa Bay Mutiny and Miami Fusion. In conjunction with the contraction, the league conducted both an Allocation Draft and a Dispersal Draft in which the top 2002 SuperDraft picks of Tampa Bay and Miami, as well as players from those clubs, were made available to remaining MLS clubs.
With the 26th pick Chicago Fire tabbed Virginia midfielder Steve Totten, and Los Angeles followed at 27 by snapping up UNC-Greensboro forward Alejandro Moreno. Colorado used back-to-back selections, 28 and 29, to pluck Washington defender Bryn Ritchie and Furman midfielder Daniel Alvarez, then struck again at 34 to take Stanford midfielder Matt Moses. MetroStars chose UConn defender Sam Forko 30th, D.C. United grabbed SMU forward Mohammed Fahim 31st, and Kansas City selected Long Island Rough Riders forward O'Neil Peart 32nd. San Jose claimed California midfielder Chris Roner 33rd, while Columbus took Furman forward John Barry Nusum 35th. Chicago returned at 36 to add St. Louis forward Dipsy Selolwane, Kansas City again took a defender at 37 in Southwest Missouri State’s Chris Brunt, the Galaxy closed the 38th slot with Brown defender Cory Gibbs, and San Jose finished the sequence by drafting Duke defender Kevin Sakuda 39th.

title: 1884 New Zealand rugby union tour of New South Wales
intro: The first New Zealand team was selected in 1884, for a tour to New South Wales, Australia. It was a privately organized selection as the New Zealand Rugby Union was founded not until eight years later. On 22 May 1884, before the tour start, the team played a test match against the Wellington Rugby Football Union team, winning 9 to 0. During the tour, the team recorded eight wins in eight matches in Australia.
lm_description: On 28 May 1884 the New Zealand tourists opened their New South Wales campaign by overwhelming Cumberland County 33-0 at Parramatta Ground, Sydney. Three days later they defeated the NSW Waratahs 11-0 on the Agricultural Society Ground, and on 3 June they beat Combined Suburbs 23-5 at the Cricket Ground. After travelling to Newcastle on 5 June they routed Northern Districts 29-0 at the Sports Ground, then returned to Sydney to overcome the Waratahs again, this time 21-2 on 7 June at the Agricultural Society Ground. A country fixture followed on 11 June in Bathurst where Western Districts were beaten 11-0 at the Bathurst Ground, and the next day back in Sydney the combined Wallaroo & University NSW side were defeated 23-10 at the Cricket Ground. The tour concluded on 14 June with a third victory over the NSW Waratahs, 16-0, again on the Agricultural Society Ground, sealing eight wins from eight matches played.
to_index_text:
1884 New Zealand rugby union tour of New South Wales

On 22 May 1884, before the tour start, the team played a test match against the Wellington Rugby Football Union team, winning 9 to 0. During the tour, the team recorded eight wins in eight matches in Australia.
On 28 May 1884 the New Zealand tourists opened their New South Wales campaign by overwhelming Cumberland County 33-0 at Parramatta Ground, Sydney. Three days later they defeated the NSW Waratahs 11-0 on the Agricultural Society Ground, and on 3 June they beat Combined Suburbs 23-5 at the Cricket Ground. After travelling to Newcastle on 5 June they routed Northern Districts 29-0 at the Sports Ground, then returned to Sydney to overcome the Waratahs again, this time 21-2 on 7 June at the Agricultural Society Ground. A country fixture followed on 11 June in Bathurst where Western Districts were beaten 11-0 at the Bathurst Ground, and the next day back in Sydney the combined Wallaroo & University NSW side were defeated 23-10 at the Cricket Ground. The tour concluded on 14 June with a third victory over the NSW Waratahs, 16-0, again on the Agricultural Society Ground, sealing eight wins from eight matches played.

title: List of auto racing tracks in the United States
intro: This is a list of all auto racing tracks in the United States. The track length stands for the standard, full courses for each track. The major series listed are only series that currently hold a race at the track.
lm_description: Anderson Speedway in Indiana runs a high-banked 0.25-mile oval that doubles as a figure-8 course and hosts CRA series, Legends, Asphalt Midgets, Modifieds, Asphalt Late Models, Bandoleros, Super Trucks, Thunder Cars, Winged Asphalt Sprint Cars, plus School Bus and Late Model Figure 8s. Sunny South Raceway at Grand Bay, Alabama; Huntsville Speedway in Huntsville; Sayre Speedway in Sayre; North Pole Speedway near Fairbanks; Alaska State Fairgrounds in Palmer; North Star Speedway outside Wasilla; Havasu 95 Speedway in Lake Havasu City, Arizona; Lucas Oil I-10 Speedway at Blythe, California; The Speedway At Willow Springs in Rosamond; I-25 Speedway in Pueblo, Colorado; Auburndale Motor Speedway outside Winter Haven, Florida; Avon Park Rotary Legends Challenge in Avon Park; Bullring at AMS in Hampton, Georgia; Stateline Speedway in Post Falls, Idaho; Meridian Speedway in Meridian; Rockford Speedway in Illinois; and Sportdrome Speedway in Jeffersonville, Indiana all measure 0.25 miles and stage everything from Go-Karts, INEX Legends, Bandoleros, Late Models, Sprint Cars, Street Stocks, Hornets, Figure 8s to NASCAR K&N Pro Series West events. Allen County War Memorial Coliseum Expo Center in Fort Wayne compresses a 0.167-mile indoor concrete oval for USAC Midgets, Ford Focus Midgets, 600cc Modified-Midgets, Quarter Midgets and Karts. Indianapolis Speedrome’s 0.20-mile oval and figure-8 layout fields Modifieds, Hornets, Roadrunners, Bomber 8s, Outlaw Stocks and Late Model Figure 8s.

title: 2010 Belmont Stakes
intro: The 2010 Belmont Stakes was the 142nd running of the Belmont Stakes. The race took place on June 5, 2010, and was won by Drosselmeyer, who was ridden by jockey Mike Smith and trained by Bill Mott. It was televised in the United States on the ABC television network. As the final jewel in the United States Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing, the race was run without the elusive championship at stake due to 2010 Kentucky Derby winner Super Saver's loss in the Preakness Stakes. Both the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winners did not run in the race. Uptowncharlybrown finished fifth, but was disqualified and placed last due to losing the eight pound handicapping weight on the backstretch.
lm_description: Drosselmeyer, breaking from post 7 under Mike E. Smith and trained by Bill Mott, paid $12 for every dollar bet to win the 142nd Belmont Stakes. Fly Down, the 9-2 second choice from post 5 with John Velazquez up for Nick Zito, rallied for second. First Dude, the 7-2 favorite with Ramon Dominguez and Dale Romans, held third. Game On Dude, 10-1 under Martin Garcia for Bob Baffert, finished fourth. Stay Put, 20-1 with Jamie Theriot for Steve Margolis, crossed fifth. Interactif, also 12-1 with Javier Castellano for Todd Pletcher, came in sixth. Stately Victor, 15-1 with Alan Garcia for Mike Maker, took seventh. Ice Box, the 3-1 chalk with Jose Lezcano for Nick Zito, faded to eighth. Make Music For Me, 10-1 with Joel Rosario for Alexis Barba, ended ninth. Dave in Dixie, 20-1 with Calvin Borel for John Sadler, placed tenth. Spangled Star, longest shot at 30-1 with Garrett Gomez for Rick Dutrow, finished eleventh. Uptowncharlybrown, 10-1 with Rajiv Maragh for Kiaran McLaughlin, was disqualified from fifth and placed last for losing his eight-pound weight pad on the backstretch.

title: List of songs recorded by Dennis Wilson
intro: This list is an attempt to document every song recorded and released under the name of Beach Boys band member Dennis Wilson, whether on an album, single, compilation or anthology album (not necessarily songs written by him).
lm_description: Dennis Wilson cut “Album Tag Song” on 22–23 March 1977, a 3:45 self-penned track that surfaced only on the 2008 re-issue of Pacific Ocean Blue, co-produced with John Hanlon and Gregg Jakobson. Carli Muñoz supplied both “All Alone” (June 1978, 3:44) and “It’s Not Too Late” (May–July 1978, 4:32), each produced with Wilson, while Muñoz and Rags Baker’s “Constant Companion” (June 8 & July 5 1978, 3:22) shares the same credits. Wilson and Jakobson co-wrote nearly everything else: “Are You Real?” (1978, 3:38), “Cocktails” (1977, 3:00), “Common” (April 3 & 13 1978, 3:34), “He’s a Bum” (July–August 1977, 2:50), “Holy Man” (February 12 1975, 4:24), “I Love You” (October 15 & November 1 1978, 2:02), “Love Remember Me” (March 3 & early August 1977, 4:04), “Love Surrounds Me” (1978-79 sessions, 3:40), and “Only with You” (September 1976–77, 3:57). “Dreamer” (March 18 1977, 4:22), “End of the Show” (March 29 & April 19 1977, 2:55), “Farewell My Friend” (April 21 1976, 2:26), “Friday Night” (3:09) and “Moonshine” (2:27) all appear on the original 1977 Pacific Ocean Blue, produced by Wilson and Jakobson. “Lady,” recorded December 26 1969–January 26 1970 (2:24), was released only as a 1970 single, producer uncredited, while “Mexico” (May 1 1978, 5:13) completes the re-issue set.

title: List of NBA franchise post-season streaks
intro: This is a list of National Basketball Association (NBA) franchise post-season appearance streaks. This list includes the all-time and the active consecutive playoffs appearance. Aside from the NBA Playoff appearance streaks, this list also includes the NBA Finals appearance streak and the NBA championships win streak. On March 24, 1971, the Philadelphia 76ers (formerly known as the Syracuse Nationals) set an NBA record of 22 consecutive playoff appearances in the time between the 1950 NBA Playoffs and the 1971 NBA Playoffs. The 76ers won two NBA championships during their streak. As of 2019, the San Antonio Spurs are tied for the NBA record of 22 consecutive playoff appearances. The Spurs' streak started in the 1998 NBA Playoffs and is, as of 2019, the longest active playoff streak in any major North American sports league. The Spurs have won five NBA championships during their streak. The Boston Celtics hold the longest consecutive NBA Finals appearance streak with ten appearances between 1957 and 1966. During the streak, the Celtics won eight consecutive NBA championships - also an NBA record.
lm_description: The Boston Celtics dominated the late 1950s and 1960s with a 13-season Conference Finals run from 1957 to 1969, capturing 12 conference titles across 1957–1966 and 1968–69. The Los Angeles Lakers answered with two separate six-season streaks: first from 1982 to 1989 they took seven conference crowns (1982–85, 1987–89), and earlier from 1968 to 1973 they secured four (1968–70, 1972–73). St. Louis Hawks stayed in the mix for six straight years (1956–61) and won four conference titles (1957–58, 1960–61), while the New York Knicks earned three conference championships (1970, 1972–73) during their six-season stretch from 1969 to 1974. Detroit’s Pistons twice logged five-season runs, first from 1987 to 1991 with three conference wins (1988–90) and later from 2003 to 2008 with two (2004–05). Minneapolis Lakers grabbed three conference titles (1952–54) across five straight appearances (1951–55), and the franchise later added another five-season streak (1959–63) with three more crowns (1959, 1962–63). Chicago Bulls (1989–93) and Golden State Warriors (2015–19) each posted five-season streaks, the Bulls winning three conference titles (1991–93) and the Warriors sweeping all five (2015–19). Syracuse Nationals (1954–57), Philadelphia 76ers (1965–68 and 1980–83), Miami Heat (2011–14), and Cleveland Cavaliers (2015–18) each sustained four-season Conference Finals appearances, securing two, one, three, four, and four conference titles respectively.

title: Discus throw
intro: The discus throw (pronunciation), also known as disc throw, is a track and field event in which an athlete throws a heavy disc - called a discus - in an attempt to mark a farther distance than their competitors. It is an ancient sport, as demonstrated by the fifth-century-BC Myron statue Discobolus. Although not part of the modern pentathlon, it was one of the events of the ancient Greek pentathlon, which can be dated back to at least to 708 BC, and is part of the modern decathlon.
lm_description: Jay Silvester opened 1968 with a 68.40 m heave in Reno, then reclaimed the spotlight in 1971 by reaching 70.38 m at Lancaster. Between those American highlights, Sweden’s Rickard Bruch dominated 1969-74, recording 68.06 m in Malmo, 67.14 m the next year in the same city, 68.40 m in Stockholm 1972, 67.58 m in Skellefteå 1973, and 68.16 m in Helsingborg 1974. John Powell interrupted the Swedish run with 69.08 m at Long Beach 1975, before Mac Wilkins soared to 70.86 m in San Jose 1976 and followed with 69.20 m at Westwood 1977. Wolfgang Schmidt pushed the standard to 71.16 m in Berlin 1978, yet Wilkins answered in 1979-80, throwing 70.66 m at Walnut and 70.98 m in Erfurt. Powell returned to win 1981 with 69.98 m in Modesto, while Luis Delís reached 70.58 m at Salinas 1982. Yuriy Dumchev raised the bar to 71.86 m in Moskva 1983, and Powell matched 71.26 m in San Jose 1984. Imrich Bugár equalled that 71.26 m in San Jose 1985, before Jürgen Schult shattered the progression, hurling 74.08 m at Neubrandenburg 1986 and closing the sequence with 69.52 m there in 1987.

Discus throw

It is an ancient sport, as demonstrated by the fifth-century-BC Myron statue Discobolus. Although not part of the modern pentathlon, it was one of the events of the ancient Greek pentathlon, which can be dated back to at least to 708 BC, and is part of the modern decathlon.
Jay Silvester opened 1968 with a 68.40 m heave in Reno, then reclaimed the spotlight in 1971 by reaching 70.38 m at Lancaster. Between those American highlights, Sweden’s Rickard Bruch dominated 1969-74, recording 68.06 m in Malmo, 67.14 m the next year in the same city, 68.40 m in Stockholm 1972, 67.58 m in Skellefteå 1973, and 68.16 m in Helsingborg 1974. John Powell interrupted the Swedish run with 69.08 m at Long Beach 1975, before Mac Wilkins soared to 70.86 m in San Jose 1976 and followed with 69.20 m at Westwood 1977. Wolfgang Schmidt pushed the standard to 71.16 m in Berlin 1978, yet Wilkins answered in 1979-80, throwing 70.66 m at Walnut and 70.98 m in Erfurt. Powell returned to win 1981 with 69.98 m in Modesto, while Luis Delís reached 70.58 m at Salinas 1982. Yuriy Dumchev raised the bar to 71.86 m in Moskva 1983, and Powell matched 71.26 m in San Jose 1984. Imrich Bugár equalled that 71.26 m in San Jose 1985, before Jürgen Schult shattered the progression, hurling 74.08 m at Neubrandenburg 1986 and closing the sequence with 69.52 m there in 1987.

title: Restriction enzyme
intro: A restriction enzyme, restriction endonuclease, or restrictase is an enzyme that cleaves DNA into fragments at or near specific recognition sites within molecules known as restriction sites. Restriction enzymes are one class of the broader endonuclease group of enzymes. Restriction enzymes are commonly classified into five types, which differ in their structure and whether they cut their DNA substrate at their recognition site, or if the recognition and cleavage sites are separate from one another. To cut DNA, all restriction enzymes make two incisions, once through each sugar-phosphate backbone (i.e. each strand) of the DNA double helix. These enzymes are found in bacteria and archaea and provide a defence mechanism against invading viruses. Inside a prokaryote, the restriction enzymes selectively cut up foreign DNA in a process called restriction digestion; meanwhile, host DNA is protected by a modification enzyme (a methyltransferase) that modifies the prokaryotic DNA and blocks cleavage. Together, these two processes form the restriction modification system. Over 3,000 restriction enzymes have been studied in detail, and more than 600 of these are available commercially. These enzymes are routinely used for DNA modification in laboratories, and they are a vital tool in molecular cloning.
lm_description: EcoRI from Escherichia coli reads 5'-GAATTC-3' and severs after the G, while its sibling EcoRII targets 5'-CCWGG-3' without offset. Bacillus amyloliquefaciens supplies BamHI, which clips between G and GATCC within 5'-GGATCC-3', and Haemophilus influenzae contributes two enzymes: HindIII, nicking AAGCTT after the first A, and HinFI, cutting GANTC between G and ANTC. Thermus aquaticus yields TaqI, splitting 5'-TCGA-3' after T, whereas Nocardia otitidis provides NotI, severing GCGGCCGC between GC and GGCCGC. Staphylococcus aureus offers Sau3AI, slicing straight through 5'-GATC-3'. Proteus vulgaris PvuII and Serratia marcescens SmaI both generate blunt ends, the former cleaving CAGCTG between CAG and CTG, the latter bisecting CCCGGG between CCC and GGG. Haemophilus aegyptius HaeIII cuts 5'-GGCC-3' in the middle, Arthrobacter luteus AluI severs AGCT between AG and CT, and Escherichia coli EcoRV opens GATATC between GAT and ATC. Escherichia coli also produces the Type III enzyme EcoP15I, which recognizes asymmetric 5'-CAGCAGN25NN-3'. Klebsiella pneumoniae KpnI clips GGTACC after T, Providencia stuartii PstI cuts CTGCAG after A, Streptomyces achromogenes SacI severs GAGCTC after T, Streptomyces albus SalI cuts GTCGAC after T, and Streptomyces caespitosus ScaI opens AGTACT between AGT and ACT.

title: List of SC Bastia players
intro: This list includes the SC Bastia players all play. Charles Orlanducci, where more than 429 matches with the match, the team holds the record for the player. Claude Papi, made by the player who scored 117 goals with the team record for a maximum holds. This list, the team has addressed all the players playing.
lm_description: French midfielder Lilian Nalis played 81 games and scored 4 goals for Bastia between 1999 and 2002, while compatriot defender César Nativi amassed 216 appearances and 4 goals across two spells from 1978-1986 and 1988-1991. Fellow French forward Frédéric Née struck 48 times in 183 matches during his two stints from 1998-2001 and 2003-2007, and Victor Negroni featured as a forward from 1956-1964. Argentine midfielder Ricardo Neumann made 34 appearances and scored 7 goals in the 1974-1976 seasons, Congolese forward Gaspard N'Gouete netted 21 goals in 31 games during 1986-1987, and Ivorian striker Guy-Roland Niangbo Nassa registered 2 goals in 39 matches from 2008-2011. Brazilian goalkeeper Macedo Magno Novaes has kept goal 98 times without scoring since 2008, and Luxembourgish forward Victor Nuremberg played in the 1963-1964 campaign.

title: List of former heads of regimes who were sentenced to death
intro: This is an incomplete list of former heads of regimes, like Presidents, Prime Ministers, Monarchs, who were sentenced to death by the succeeding regime following their removal from power.
lm_description: Ion Antonescu, Romanian prime minister from 1940 to 1944, was executed by firing squad on 1 June 1946, while his fellow Bulgarians Ivan Bagryanov, Dobri Bozhilov and Bogdan Filov, who successively led Bulgaria during the war, were all executed in early 1945. Turkey’s Celal Bayar, president from 1950 to 1960 after earlier serving as prime minister, saw his death sentence commuted and was freed in 1964, whereas Adnan Menderes, Turkish premier from 1950 to 1960, was hanged on 17 September 1961. Pakistan’s Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, president then prime minister during the 1970s, was hanged on 4 April 1979, and Central African Emperor Jean-Bédel Bokassa, after ruling as president then emperor, had his sentence commuted and walked free in 1993. Romania’s Nicolae Ceauşescu, president from 1967 to 1989, was shot by firing squad on Christmas Day 1989. Charles I, king of England Scotland and Ireland from 1625 to 1649, was beheaded on 30 January 1649, and France’s Louis XVI, king from 1774 to 1792, was guillotined on 21 January 1793. Collaborationist China’s Chen Gongbo and Liang Hongzhi were both executed by firing squad in 1946, Iran’s premier Amir-Abbas Hoveida was shot on 7 April 1979, Equatorial Guinea’s Francisco Macías Nguema was executed in 1979, Congo-Brazzaville’s Alphonse Massemba-Débat was executed in 1977, and South Korea’s Chun Doo-hwan, president from 1980 to 1988, had his sentence commuted and was released in 1997.

title: National Basketball Association
intro:
The National Basketball Association (NBA) is a men's professional basketball league in North America, composed of 30 teams (29 in the United States and 1 in Canada). It is one of the four major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada, and is widely considered to be the premier men's professional basketball league in the world. [better source needed]
 The league was founded in New York City on June 6, 1946, as the Basketball Association of America (BAA). It changed its name to the National Basketball Association on August 3, 1949, after merging with the competing National Basketball League (NBL). The NBA's regular season runs from October to April, with each team playing 82 games. Its playoffs extend into June. NBA players are the world's best paid athletes by average annual salary per player. The NBA is an active member of USA Basketball (USAB), which is recognized by FIBA (also known as the International Basketball Federation) as the national governing body for basketball in the United States. The league's several international as well as individual team offices are directed out of its head offices in Midtown Manhattan, while its NBA Entertainment and NBA TV studios are directed out of offices located in Secaucus, New Jersey.
lm_description: The Boston Celtics have captured 17 championships—1957, 1959-66, 1968-69, 1974, 1976, 1981, 1984, 1986 and 2008—while finishing second in 1958, 1985, 1987 and 2010, giving them 21 total Finals appearances and 4 losses. The Minneapolis/Los Angeles Lakers have gone 16-15 in 31 trips, winning in 1949-50, 1952-54, 1972, 1980, 1982, 1985, 1987-88, 2000-02 and 2009-10, and losing in 1959, 1962-63, 1965-66, 1968-70, 1973, 1983-84, 1989, 1991, 2004 and 2008. The Philadelphia/San Francisco/Golden State Warriors own 6 titles—1947, 1956, 1975, 2015, 2017-18—and 5 runner-up finishes in 1948, 1964, 1967, 2016 and 2019. Chicago’s perfect 6-0 record came in 1991-93 and 1996-98. San Antonio went 5-1 with crowns in 1999, 2003, 2005, 2007 and 2014, dropping only the 2013 Finals. Syracuse/Philadelphia 76ers won in 1955, 1967 and 1983 and lost in 1950, 1954, 1977, 1980, 1982 and 2001. Fort Wayne/Detroit Pistons triumphed in 1989-90 and 2004, falling in 1955-56, 1988 and 2005. Miami Heat earned 3 titles in 2006, 2012-13 and were runners-up in 2011 and 2014. New York Knicks won in 1970 and 1973, losing in 1951-53, 1972, 1994 and 1999. Houston Rockets repeated in 1994-95 after defeats in 1981 and 1986. Cleveland finally broke through in 2016 after losses in 2007, 2015, 2017 and 2018. St. Louis/Atlanta Hawks won their lone crown in 1958, losing in 1957, 1960 and 1961. Baltimore/Washington Bullets captured 1978, falling in 1971, 1975 and 1979. Seattle SuperSonics/Oklahoma City Thunder won 1979 and lost in 1978, 1996 and 2012. Portland Trail Blazers won 1977, lost 1990 and 1992. Milwaukee Bucks triumphed in 1971, fell in 1974. Dallas Mavericks reversed 2006 heartbreak with 2011 glory. Folded Baltimore Bullets, Rochester Royals and Toronto Raptors each own one perfect Finals appearance—1948, 1951 and 2019 respectively.

title: 1996 Australian Grand Prix
intro: The 1996 Australian Grand Prix was a Formula One motor race held at Melbourne on 10 March 1996. It was the first race of the 1996 Formula One World Championship, and the first Australian Grand Prix to be held at Melbourne, taking over from Adelaide. The 58-lap race was won by Damon Hill, driving a Williams-Renault. Hill's teammate Jacques Villeneuve, making his Formula One debut, took pole position and led for most of the race, before an oil leak enabled Hill to catch and pass him in the closing laps. Eddie Irvine finished third in a Ferrari.
lm_description: Jacques Villeneuve planted his Williams-Renault on pole with a 1:32.371 lap, edging teammate Damon Hill by 0.138 s. Eddie Irvine’s Ferrari slotted into third, a further 0.380 s adrift, while Michael Schumacher’s sister Ferrari lined up fourth, 0.754 s off the pace. Mika Häkkinen’s McLaren-Mercedes headed the next pack in fifth, followed by the Benetton-Renault duo of Jean Alesi and Gerhard Berger in sixth and seventh. Rubens Barrichello’s Jordan-Peugeot, Heinz-Harald Frentzen’s Sauber-Ford and Mika Salo’s Tyrrell-Yamaha completed the top ten, each separated by fractions. Olivier Panis (Ligier-Mugen-Honda), Jos Verstappen (Footwork-Hart) and David Coulthard (McLaren-Mercedes) filled rows eleven to thirteen within 0.022 s. Johnny Herbert’s Sauber-Ford, Ukyo Katayama’s Tyrrell-Yamaha and the Minardi-Ford pair of Giancarlo Fisichella and Pedro Lamy followed, trailed by Ricardo Rosset’s Footwork and Martin Brundle’s Jordan. Pedro Diniz brought up the rear of the 20-car Melbourne grid, 3.927 s behind Villeneuve’s benchmark.

title: List of Phi Beta Sigma chapters
intro: The list of Phi Beta Sigma chapters includes active and inactive chapters of Phi Beta Sigma (ΦΒΣ). Founded on January 9, 1914 on the campus of Howard University in Washington, D.C., Phi Beta Sigma has opened chapters at other colleges, universities, and cities, and named them with Greek-letters. The fraternity's expansion started with its second (Beta) and third (Gamma) chapters, chartered at Wiley College and Morgan State College respectively in 1915. Today, the fraternity serves through a membership of more than 200,000 men in over 700 chapters in the United States, Europe, Asia, and the Caribbean. The fraternity has reserved the designation Omega chapter as a memorial to those brothers who are deceased. Graduate chapters are indicated by Sigma at the end of their chapter name.
lm_description: Phi Beta Sigma’s Alpha chapter was chartered at Howard University in Washington, DC on 15 April 1914 and remains active. Virginia State University hosts the active Alpha Alpha Alpha chapter chartered in 1931, while Lock Haven University of Pennsylvania’s Alpha Alpha Gamma, Binghamton University’s Alpha Alpha Xi, Christopher Newport University’s Alpha Alpha Pi, Johnson & Wales University’s Alpha Alpha Tau, Medgar Evers College’s Alpha Alpha Phi, Wesley College’s Alpha Alpha Psi, and Bryant University’s Alpha Beta Epsilon chapters were chartered in 1990, 1990, 1991, 6 December 1993, 30 December 1993, 6 May 1994, and an unspecified date respectively; Alpha Alpha Pi is inactive, the rest are active. Hofstra University’s Alpha Alpha Iota chapter joined in 1993 and is active. City College of New York at Harlem’s Alpha Delta chapter dates from 1929 and is active. Slippery Rock University of Pennsylvania’s Alpha Zeta Alpha was chartered 7 June 1995 and is active. West Virginia State University’s Alpha Theta, Bluefield State College’s Alpha Iota, University of Maryland Eastern Shore’s Alpha Mu (1935), Swarthmore College’s Alpha Mu Alpha, Seton Hall University’s Alpha Nu Alpha, Allen University’s Alpha Omicron (1935), Robert Morris University’s Alpha Pi Alpha (1996), and University of Pennsylvania’s Alpha Chi Alpha (1998) chapters are all active.

title: European Youth Forum
intro: The European Youth Forum (from French: Youth Forum Jeunesse, YFJ) is the platform of the national youth councils and international non-governmental youth organisations in Europe. It strives for youth rights in international institutions such as the European Union, the Council of Europe, and the United Nations. The European Youth Forum works in the fields of youth policy and youth work development. It focuses its work on European youth policy matters, whilst through engagement on the global level, it is enhancing the capacities of its members and promoting global interdependence. In its daily work, the European Youth Forum represents the views and opinions of youth organizations in all relevant policy areas and promotes the cross-sectoral nature of youth policy towards a variety of institutional actors. The principles of equality and sustainable development are mainstreamed in the work of the European Youth Forum. As of July 2017, it consists of 43 National Youth Councils and 61 international youth NGOs, a total of 104 bodies from across Europe.
lm_description: Carina Autengruber of Austria led the European Youth Forum as president during 2019-2020, preceded by Spain’s Luis Alvarado Martínez for 2017-2018 and Finland’s Johanna Nyman for 2015-2016. Slovenia’s Peter Matjašič held the presidency across four years, 2011-2014, immediately after fellow Slovene Tine Radinja’s 2009-2010 term. Austria’s Bettina Schwarzmayr headed the forum in 2007-2008, following Lithuania’s Renaldas Vaisbrodas for 2005-2006 and Italy’s Giacomo Filibeck for 2003-2004. Finland’s Henrik Söderman presided in 2001-2002, Spain’s Pau Solanilla in 1999-2000, and Finland’s Pauliina Arola in 1997-1998.

title: List of football clubs in Spain
intro: This is a list of men's association football clubs in Spain. Currently the governing body of football in Spain is the Royal Spanish Football Federation (RFEF), which is in charge of its national teams and its leagues, with the highest one being La Liga. RFEF was founded in 1909 and is a member of both FIFA and UEFA.

La Nucía, promoted as Tercera División group 6 champions, stepped up in 2019-20 to the Camilo Cano. Llagostera, topping Tercera group 5, returned in 2019-20 to the Municipal de Llagostera after first reaching this level in 2011-12. Lleida Esportiu, 6th, have been ever-present since 2011-12 at Camp d'Esports. Olot, 10th, came back in 2017-18 to the Municipal d’Olot, having debuted nationally in 2013-14. Orihuela, Tercera group 6 winners, re-entered in 2019-20 at Los Arcos after earlier stints since 2002-03. title: Live with Regis and Kelly (season 19)
intro: This is a list of Live with Regis and Kelly episodes which were broadcast during the show's 19th season. The list is ordered by air date. Although the co-hosts may have read a couple of emails during the broadcast, it does not necessarily count as a Regis and Kelly Inbox segment.
lm_description: Regis Philbin and Kelly Ripa opened February with Sienna Miller and Katharine McPhee on the 1st, followed the next day by Jeff Probst and Charlize Theron. Chad Lowe visited on the 5th, Phil McGraw and Alex Rodriguez on the 6th, and Ashley Tisdale on the 7th. Tyler Perry and Carly Simon appeared on the 8th, and the 9th was devoted to LIVE’s Wedding 2007. Hugh Grant and Hayden Panettiere dropped by on the 12th, Drew Barrymore and Dr. Ruth on the 13th. Valentine’s week peaked on the 14th with Nicolas Cage, Katherine Heigl, a hidden-camera lingerie exposé and last-minute gift ideas. Eva Mendes, children’s group Hi-5 and kids discussing love filled the 15th, while Martin Lawrence, Gabrielle Union and Daniel G. Amen guested on the 16th. Beautiful Baby Week began on the 19th alongside Marisa Tomei and bubble scientist Fan Yang, continued on the 20th with Heather Graham and the fresh Daytona 500 winner, welcomed William H. Macy on the 21st, John Travolta and Richard Roeper on the 22nd, and on the 23rd featured Billy Bob Thornton, Jesse L. Martin, Geraldo Rivera and toy expert Chris Byrne. The show traveled to Los Angeles on the 26th for Tim Allen, Masi Oka and Joan & Melissa Rivers’ Oscar recap, stayed for Courteney Cox, David Boreanaz and Five for Fighting on the 27th while Regis revisited favorite L.A. spots, and wrapped the month on the 28th with Emily Procter, Ryan Seacrest and Regis touring the Deal or No Deal set.

title: Sports magazine
intro: A sports magazine is usually a weekly, biweekly or monthly, magazine featuring articles or segments on sports. Some may be published a specific number of times per year. Major sports magazines in print include:
lm_description: 11 Freunde covers German association football monthly, while the United Kingdom’s weekly Autosport follows motorsport. The United States fields two baseball titles: Baseball America every two weeks and Baseball Digest eight times yearly. Basketball Times appears monthly in the United States, joined there by Dime Magazine ten times a year and the bi-monthly Hoop. The United Kingdom offers weekly Boxing News and monthly Boxing Monthly; Fight! Magazine brings American readers monthly MMA coverage. FourFourTwo and France Football serve monthly and bi-weekly association-football audiences from the United Kingdom and France respectively, Germany’s Kicker also ships bi-weekly, and the United Kingdom’s weekly Match rounds out the football group. Golf Magazine tees off monthly in the United States, The Hockey News slides onto Canadian newsstands weekly, Lacrosse Magazine publishes monthly stateside, Pro Football Weekly tackles the NFL weekly in the United States, and Pro Wrestling Illustrated grapples for monthly attention there too.

title: CZW Cage of Death
intro: The Cage of Death is Combat Zone Wrestling (CZW)'s biggest show since 1999. It always features the Cage of Death match, a steel cage with various weapons littered in the cage. electrified cage walls, cacti, tables, light tubes, glass, thumbtacks, baseball bats, barbed wire and numerous other weapons and objects have been used in it. The first two were simple either pin and/or submit to win cage matches with weapons littered in and around the cage. The Cage of Death also has different formats and stipulations: singles, tag team, or gauntlet. Each Cage of Death features two or more wrestlers in the cage. For Cage of Death 5, 6, and 7, WarGames stipulations were used.
lm_description: Ty Street opened the night battling his own doppelgänger, Fake Ty Street, in a singles contest that ended inconclusively. The H8 Club—Nate Hatred and Nick Gage—then overpowered Jay and Mark Briscoe in straight tag action, while Joey Corman pinned both Samir and Brad Michaels to survive their triple-threat. John Zandig and Danny Rose fought to a chaotic no-contest, and The S.A.T. (Joel, Jose and Will Maximo) saved Pastor Jim’s CZW career by besting Chris Divine, Quiet Storm and Brian XL in a six-man wager. Jon Dahmer and Fast Eddie Valentine claimed a three-way tag victory over Chri$ Ca$h & GQ and Chris Stylz & Ian Knoxx. Trent Acid unified the CZW and BJW Junior Heavyweight titles by dethroning Ruckus, Johnny Kashmere downed Menace one-on-one, and Mad Man Pondo survived Z-Barr in a hardcore brawl. Adam Flash snatched the CZW Iron Man Championship from defending Nick Berk and Nick Mondo in a Falls-Count-Anywhere triple-threat, and, in the night’s culmination, Justice Pain kept his CZW World Heavyweight crown by defeating Wifebeater inside the lethal Cage of Death.

title: List of public corporations by market capitalization
intro: The following is a list of publicly traded companies having the greatest market capitalization. This list is primarily based on the Financial Times Global 500. Market capitalization is calculated from the share price (as recorded on selected day) multiplied by the number of outstanding shares. Figures are converted into USD millions (using rate from selected day) to allow for comparison. Only companies with free float at least 15% are included, value of unlisted stock classes is excluded. Investment companies are not included in the list.
lm_description: Microsoft leads the world’s public companies with a market capitalization of 264,003 million USD, anchored in the software industry and headquartered in the United States. Close behind, General Electric, a U.S.–based conglomerate, is valued at 259,647 million USD, while Exxon Mobil, the oil-and-gas giant also based in the United States, holds 241,037 million USD. Retail titan Wal-Mart follows at 234,399 million USD, still within U.S. borders. Pfizer, specializing in health care, claims 195,948 million USD, and Citigroup, in banking, reaches 183,887 million USD. Johnson & Johnson, another health-care leader, is appraised at 170,417 million USD. Breaking the U.S. streak, Royal Dutch Shell of the Netherlands, an oil-and-gas major, is valued at 149,034 million USD, while the United Kingdom’s BP, also in oil and gas, stands at 144,381 million USD. IBM, dual-rooted in computer software and hardware and based in the United States, closes the top ten at 139,272 million USD.

title: Hiragana and katakana place names
intro: The hiragana cities of Japan are municipalities whose names are written in hiragana rather than kanji as is traditional for Japanese place names. Many hiragana city names have kanji equivalents that are either phonetic manyōgana, or whose kanji are now obsolete. [citation needed] Others, such as Tsukuba in Ibaraki Prefecture, are taken from localities or landmarks whose names continue to be written in kanji.
lm_description: Akiruno in Tokyo writes its name in hiragana as あきる野市, while its full kanji forms 秋留野 and 阿伎留野 linger as historical variants. Ichikikushikino, Kagoshima’s いちき串木野市, keeps the hiragana prefix but matches its kanji 市来串木野 exactly. Higashikagawa, Kagawa’s 東かがわ市, inserts hiragana for “kagawa” where the kanji 東香川 renders the whole in characters. Higashimiyoshi, Tokushima’s 東みよし町, likewise uses hiragana for “miyoshi” against the full-kanji 東三好. Kinokawa, Wakayama’s 紀の川市, slips a hiragana “no” between the kanji elements of 紀之川. Minamiawaji, Hyōgo’s 南あわじ市, spells “awaji” in hiragana though the kanji 南淡路 supplies the traditional form. Izunokuni, Shizuoka’s 伊豆の国市, keeps the hiragana “no” where 伊豆之国 writes “country” in kanji. Fujimino, Saitama’s ふじみ野市, renders “fujimi” entirely in hiragana while 富士見野 preserves the kanji for “see” and “field.”

title: 2008 Kazakhstan Premier League
intro: The 2008 Kazakhstan Premier League was the 17th season of the Kazakhstan Premier League, the highest football league competition in Kazakhstan, and took place between 8 March and 5 November.
lm_description: Vladimir Mukhanov led Aktobe from Central Stadium, which holds 13,200, while Bernd Storck coached Almaty in the same 23,804-seat Central Stadium shared by Vakhid Masudov’s Kairat and Vladimir Gulyamkhaidarov’s Megasport. Vyacheslav Ledovskih directed Astana at the 12,350-capacity Kazhymukan Munaitpasov Stadium, Sergey Andreyev handled Atyrau at 9,500-seat Munaishy Stadium, and Vladimir Linchevskiy guided Energetic-2 from Ekibastuz’s 6,300-seat Shakhter. Evgeny Yarovenko’s Esil Bogatyr played for Petropavl at 11,000-seat Karasai Stadium, Oirat Saduov’s Irtysh represented Pavlodar in the 15,000-seat Central Stadium, and Vladimir Nikitenko’s Kaisar performed in Kyzylorda’s 7,000-seat Gani Muratbayev Stadium. Viktor Rymar’s Okzhetpes used Kokshetau’s 4,158-seat Okzhetpes Stadium, Jovica Nikolić’s Ordabasy filled Shymkent’s 20,000-seat Kazhimukan Munaitpasov Stadium, Ivan Azovskiy’s Shakhter Karagandy occupied Karagandy’s 20,000-seat Shakhter Stadium, Dmitriy Ogai’s Tobol staged matches in Kostanay’s 8,323-seat Central Stadium, Oleksandr Holokolosov’s Vostok welcomed fans to Oskemen’s 8,500-seat Vostok Stadium, and Ilie Karp’s Zhetysu competed in Taldykorgan’s 4,000-seat Zhetysu Stadium.

title: Vijayawada (Lok Sabha constituency)
intro: Vijayawada (Lok Sabha constituency) is one of the twenty-five lok sabha constituencies of Andhra Pradesh in India. It comprises eight assembly segments and belongs to Krishna district.
lm_description: Harindranath Chattopadhyaya won the inaugural 1952 Vijayawada seat as an Independent. Dr. Komarraju Atchamamba took it for Indian National Congress in 1957, after which K. L. Rao secured three straight victories for the same party in 1962, 1967 and 1971. Godey Murahari kept the seat with Indian National Congress in 1977, followed by Chennupati Vidya under the Indian National Congress (I) banner in 1980. Vadde Sobhanadreeswara Rao switched it to Telugu Desam Party in 1984, lost it back to Chennupati Vidya of Indian National Congress in 1989, then regained it for Telugu Desam Party in 1991. Parvathaneni Upendra gave Indian National Congress two consecutive wins in 1996 and 1998, before Gadde Ramamohan returned the seat to Telugu Desam Party in 1999. Rajagopal Lagadapati restored Indian National Congress fortunes in 2004 and repeated the feat in 2009. Finally, Kesineni Srinivas captured the constituency for Telugu Desam Party in both 2014 and 2019.

title: 2011 Southeastern Conference football season
intro: The 2011 Southeastern Conference football season began on Thursday, September 1, 2011 with Kentucky taking on Western Kentucky on ESPNU. The season concluded on January 9, 2012 as the Alabama Crimson Tide shut out LSU Tigers, 21-0 in the Allstate BCS National Championship Game at the Mercedes-Benz Superdome in New Orleans to claim their 14th national championship in school history.
lm_description: Georgia’s offense revolved around sophomore quarterback Aaron Murray, protected by senior tackle Cordy Glenn, with junior tight end Orson Charles as a prime target. In the backfield, South Carolina featured sophomore Marcus Lattimore, while Alabama countered with junior Trent Richardson. The receiving corps paired Arkansas senior Greg Childs with South Carolina junior Alshon Jeffery. Up front, Alabama’s line was anchored by junior Barrett Jones and senior center William Vlachos, flanked by Mississippi senior Bradley Sowell and Kentucky junior Larry Warford.
to_index_text:
2011 Southeastern Conference football season
The 2011 Southeastern Conference football season began on Thursday, September 1, 2011 with Kentucky taking on Western Kentucky on ESPNU. The season concluded on January 9, 2012 as the Alabama Crimson Tide shut out LSU Tigers, 21-0 in the Allstate BCS National Championship Game at the Mercedes-Benz Superdome in New Orleans to claim their 14th national championship in school history.
Georgia’s offense revolved around sophomore quarterback Aaron Murray, protected by senior tackle Cordy Glenn, with junior tight end Orson Charles as a prime target. In the backfield, South Carolina featured sophomore Marcus Lattimore, while Alabama countered with junior Trent Richardson. The receiving corps paired Arkansas senior Greg Childs with South Carolina junior Alshon Jeffery. Up front, Alabama’s line was anchored by junior Barrett Jones and senior center William Vlachos, flanked by Mississippi senior Bradley Sowell and Kentucky junior Larry Warford.

title: Sports in Atlanta
intro: Sports in Atlanta has a rich history, including the oldest on-campus NCAA Division I football stadium, Bobby Dodd Stadium, built in 1913 by the students of Georgia Tech. Atlanta also played host to the second intercollegiate football game in the South, played between the A&M College of Alabama (now Auburn University) and the University of Georgia in Piedmont Park in 1892; this game is now called the Deep South's Oldest Rivalry. The city hosts college football's annual Chick-fil-A Peach Bowl and the Peachtree Road Race, the worlds largest 10 km race. Atlanta was the host city for the Centennial 1996 Summer Olympics, and Downtown Atlanta's Centennial Olympic Park was built for and commemorates the games. Atlanta is home to professional franchises for five major team sports: the Atlanta Braves of Major League Baseball, the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association, the Atlanta Falcons of the National Football League, the Atlanta Dream of the Women's National Basketball Association, and Atlanta United FC of Major League Soccer. Atlanta has also has top level teams in the Georgia Swarm of the National Lacrosse League, the Atlanta Blaze of Major League Lacrosse, and Rugby ATL of Major League Rugby.
lm_description: Atlanta Blaze, founded in 2016, plays field lacrosse at Fifth Third Bank Stadium in Major League Lacrosse and has yet to win a title. The Atlanta Gladiators, an ECHL ice-hockey side established in 2003, skate at Infinite Energy Arena without a championship. Atlanta Reign, born in 2018, competes in the Overwatch League at Coca-Cola Roxy and remains title-less. Atlanta United 2, a 2018 USL Championship soccer club, also uses Fifth Third Bank Stadium and has no silverware. The College Park Skyhawks, a 2019 NBA G League basketball outfit, host games at Gateway Center Arena and have not yet claimed a title. Georgia Swarm, launched in 2015, plays box lacrosse at Infinite Energy Arena and captured the National Lacrosse League crown in 2017. Gwinnett Stripers, a 2009 International League (AAA) baseball team, play at Coolray Field without a championship. Rugby ATL, founded in 2020, fields a rugby-union side at Lupo Family Field in Major League Rugby and is still seeking its first title.
to_index_text:
Sports in Atlanta
Sports in Atlanta has a rich history, including the oldest on-campus NCAA Division I football stadium, Bobby Dodd Stadium, built in 1913 by the students of Georgia Tech. Atlanta also played host to the second intercollegiate football game in the South, played between the A&M College of Alabama (now Auburn University) and the University of Georgia in Piedmont Park in 1892; this game is now called the Deep South's Oldest Rivalry. The city hosts college football's annual Chick-fil-A Peach Bowl and the Peachtree Road Race, the worlds largest 10 km race. Atlanta was the host city for the Centennial 1996 Summer Olympics, and Downtown Atlanta's Centennial Olympic Park was built for and commemorates the games. Atlanta is home to professional franchises for five major team sports: the Atlanta Braves of Major League Baseball, the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association, the Atlanta Falcons of the National Football League, the Atlanta Dream of the Women's National Basketball Association, and Atlanta United FC of Major League Soccer. Atlanta has also has top level teams in the Georgia Swarm of the National Lacrosse League, the Atlanta Blaze of Major League Lacrosse, and Rugby ATL of Major League Rugby.
Atlanta Blaze, founded in 2016, plays field lacrosse at Fifth Third Bank Stadium in Major League Lacrosse and has yet to win a title. The Atlanta Gladiators, an ECHL ice-hockey side established in 2003, skate at Infinite Energy Arena without a championship. Atlanta Reign, born in 2018, competes in the Overwatch League at Coca-Cola Roxy and remains title-less. Atlanta United 2, a 2018 USL Championship soccer club, also uses Fifth Third Bank Stadium and has no silverware. The College Park Skyhawks, a 2019 NBA G League basketball outfit, host games at Gateway Center Arena and have not yet claimed a title. Georgia Swarm, launched in 2015, plays box lacrosse at Infinite Energy Arena and captured the National Lacrosse League crown in 2017. Gwinnett Stripers, a 2009 International League (AAA) baseball team, play at Coolray Field without a championship. Rugby ATL, founded in 2020, fields a rugby-union side at Lupo Family Field in Major League Rugby and is still seeking its first title.

title: 1965 College Baseball All-America Team
intro: An All-American team is an honorary sports team composed of the best amateur players of a specific season for each team position - who in turn are given the honorific All-America and typically referred to as All-American athletes, or simply All-Americans. Although the honorees generally do not compete together as a unit, the term is used in U.S. team sports to refer to players who are selected by members of the national media. Walter Camp selected the first All-America team in the early days of American football in 1889. From 1947 to 1980, the American Baseball Coaches Association was the only All-American selector recognized by the NCAA.
lm_description: The 1965 College Baseball All-America Team honored Ohio State’s Steve Arlin and Saint Louis’ John Marcum Jr. as the nation’s top pitchers, while Washington State’s John E. Olerud claimed the catcher spot. Stanford’s Pete Middlekauff earned first-base recognition, Arizona State’s Luis Lagunas took second base, Texas A&M’s Mike McClure manned third, and Columbia’s Archie Roberts held down shortstop. Outfield accolades went to Western Michigan’s Bill Guerrant, Cincinnati’s Billy Wolff, and Arizona State’s Rick Monday.

title: 1994 in film
intro: This is a list of films released in 1994. The top worldwide grosser was The Lion King, becoming the highest-grossing Walt Disney Feature Animation film of all-time, although it was slightly overtaken at the North American domestic box office by Forrest Gump, which won the Academy Award for Best Picture. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer celebrated its 70th Anniversary in 1994.
lm_description: Disney’s The Lion King led 1994’s global box office with $763,455,561, while Paramount’s Forrest Gump followed at $677,945,399. 20th Century Fox placed third with True Lies at $378,882,411 and fifth with Speed at $350,448,145. Warner Bros claimed two spots: The Mask earned $351,583,407 in fourth place, and Dumb and Dumber took seventh with $247,275,374, while Interview with the Vampire nabbed ninth at $223,664,608. Universal’s The Flintstones landed sixth with $341,631,208, Gramercy’s Four Weddings and a Funeral eighth at $245,700,832, and Paramount rounded out the top ten as Clear and Present Danger collected $215,887,717.

title: List of Texas Tech University alumni
intro: Texas Tech University, often referred to as Texas Tech or TTU, is a public, coeducational, research university located in Lubbock, Texas. Established on February 10, 1923, and originally known as Texas Technological College, it is the leading institution of the Texas Tech University System and has the sixth largest student body in the state of Texas. It is the only school in Texas to house an undergraduate institution, law school, and medical school at the same location. Initial enrollment in 1925 was 910 students; as of 2009, the university has 30,049 students from more than 110 countries, all 50 U.S. states and the District of Columbia. Since its first graduating class in 1927 of 26 students, Texas Tech has awarded more than 221,000 degrees, including 45,000 graduate and professional degrees to its alumni. The Texas Tech Alumni Association, with over 27,000 members, operates more than 120 chapters in cities throughout the United States and the world. Throughout Texas Tech's history, alumni have played prominent roles in many different fields. Among the university's Distinguished Alumni is Demetrio B. Lakas, President of the Republic of Panama from 1969 to 1978. Three United States Governors, Daniel I. J. Thornton, Governor of Colorado from 1951 to 1955, John Burroughs, Governor of New Mexico from 1959 to 1961, and Preston Smith, Governor of Texas from 1968 to 1972, are graduates of the university. Three astronauts, including Rick Husband, the final commander of Space Shuttle Columbia and recipient of the Congressional Space Medal of Honor. U.S. Marine Corps Major and Medal of Honor recipient, George H. O'Brien, Jr., is a distinguished alumnus. Richard E. Cavazos is a two-time Distinguished Service Cross recipient and the first Hispanic and Mexican American to advance to the rank of four-star general in the U.S. Army.
lm_description: W. J. Adkins, who earned a 1938 M.A., founded and led Laredo Community College from 1947 to 1960. B W Aston collected three Texas Tech degrees—B.S. 1962, M.S. 1964, Ph.D. 1972—and became a noted historian, as did Paul H. Carlson after completing his 1973 Ph.D. and specializing in Texas and the American West. Jo Carr, a 1947 graduate, served as a United Methodist minister, while Margaret Formby, class of 1950, established the National Cowgirl Museum and Hall of Fame. Sandra S. Harper, a 1974 alumna, presides over Our Lady of the Lake College in Louisiana, and Michael Hinojosa, who finished in 1979, has twice led Dallas ISD (2005-2011 and since 2015) after a stint at Cobb County. Walter B. Huffman, stacking a 1967 B.A., 1968 M.Ed., and 1977 J.D., directed Texas Tech’s law school and served as a U.S. Army Judge Advocate General. Billy Mac Jones governed Southwest Texas State and Memphis State universities, William N. Ellis became the nineteenth president of Howard Payne, and Barry B. Thompson channeled his Texas Tech studies into the chancellorship of the Texas A&M System. David J. Schmidly, B.A. 1966 and M.S. 1968, later presided over Oklahoma State, Texas Tech, and the University of New Mexico. Historians Willard Hughes Rollings (Ph.D. 1983) and Ernest Wallace (1935) illuminate Native American and regional history, while Keith E. Whitfield oversees academic affairs at Wayne State.

title: Behind the Scenes (American TV series)
intro: Behind the Scenes was a 10-part television miniseries aimed towards 8- to 12-year-olds about various aspects of the arts, that was broadcast on PBS in 1992. The series was executive produced by Alice Stewart Trillin and Jane Garmey, produced and directed by Ellen Hovde and Muffie Meyer, and hosted by Penn & Teller. It was developed to illuminate the creative process underlying the working of artists.
lm_description: David Hockney demonstrates how to create the illusion of depth in drawing, with Bobby McFerrin adding musical insight, in the opening episode. Carrie Mae Weems then explores photography through the art of framing, while conductor JoAnn Falletta unpacks texture in music. Wayne Thiebaud and Matt Groening examine the power of line, and Julie Taymor reveals how to set a scene for theatre. Allen Toussaint, joined by Jane Ira Bloom and Bobby McFerrin, shows how melody works, after which painter Robert Gil de Montes delves into color. Choreographer David Parsons and B.H. Barry demonstrate pattern through dance, drummer Max Roach, MC Lyte and The Blue Man Group break down rhythm, and sculptor Nancy Graves concludes the series by explaining balance.

title: List of Major League Baseball annual saves leaders
intro: The following is a list of annual leaders in saves in Major League Baseball (MLB), with separate lists for the American League and the National League. The list includes several professional leagues and associations that were never part of MLB.
lm_description: In 1882 Eddie Fusselback of the St. Louis Brown Stockings recorded the first recognized save, a lone one. The next year Bob Barr and Tony Mullane matched that single save while splitting their seasons between Pittsburgh and St. Louis. Four pitchers—Oyster Burns, Frank Mountain, and Hank O'Day, representing Baltimore, Columbus, and Toledo—shared the 1884 lead with one save apiece, after which Burns alone topped the 1885 ledger with three for Baltimore. The 1886 crown splintered among six men: Bones Ely, Dave Foutz, Nat Hudson, Ed Morris, and Joe Strauss, each finishing one save for either Louisville or St. Louis. Adonis Terry then posted three for Brooklyn Grays in 1887, and in 1888 Pop Corkhill, Bob Gilks, and Tony Mullane each collected one while wearing Cincinnati or Cleveland uniforms. Mullane doubled his previous total by saving five for Cincinnati in 1889, Herb Goodall followed with four for Louisville Colonels in 1890, and Boston Reds teammates Bill Daley and Cinders O'Brien closed out 1891 with two saves each.

title: S. P. B. Charan
intro: Sripathi Panditharadhyula Balasubrahmanyam Charan, popularly known as S. P. B. Charan, or Charan is an Indian film playback singer, actor, and producer known for his works primarily in Tamil cinema. He is the son of the Indian singer S. P. Balasubrahmanyam. He first worked as a playback singer in Tamil and Telugu cinema. He ventured into acting with the 2003 Kannada film Hudugigagi and is probably best known for his performance in the 2008 film Saroja. He has established a film production company called Capital Film Works, and produced several Tamil films, including the cult hit Chennai 600028 in 2007 and the National Film Award-winning Aaranya Kaandam in 2012.
lm_description: S. P. B. Charan produced Samuthirakani’s 2003 drama Unnai Charanadainthen, casting himself alongside Venkat Prabhu. Two years later he backed S. Rajkumar’s romantic Mazhai starring Jayam Ravi and Shriya Saran. In 2007 Charan’s Capital Film Works released Venkat Prabhu’s cricket-comedy Chennai 600028, assembling Jai, Nithin Sathya, Shiva, Premji Amaren and Vijayalakshmi. Rajamohan’s 2009 debut Kunguma Poovum Konjum Puravum followed, featuring newcomers Ramakrishnan and Tharshana. Charan then produced Shakthi’s 2010 heist thriller Naanayam with Prasanna and Sibiraj, and Thiagarajan Kumararaja’s National-Award-winning neo-noir Aaranya Kaandam in 2011, headlined by Jackie Shroff, Ravi Krishna and Sampath Raj. Caarthick Raju’s 2014 cop-comedy Thirudan Police brought Attakathi Dinesh and Iyshwarya Rajesh together under the banner. In 2015 Charan reunited his father S. P. Balasubrahmanyam with Lakshmi, K. Bhagyaraj and fresh faces Arjun Chidambaram, Venkatesh Harinathan and Aditi Chengappa for Madhumitha’s Moone Moonu Varthai. Finally, 2016 saw the reunion of the original Chennai 600028 ensemble—Jai, Nithin Sathya, Shiva, Premji Amaren and Vijayalakshmi—under Venkat Prabhu once more for the sequel Chennai 600028 II.

title: Peter Witt streetcar
intro: The Peter Witt streetcar was introduced by Cleveland Railway commissioner Peter Witt (1869-1948) who led the transit agency from 1911-1915 and designed a model of streetcar known by his name that was used in many North American cities, most notably in Toronto and Cleveland.
lm_description: J. G. Brill Company of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States, and Canadian Car and Foundry of Montreal, Quebec, Canada, both built Peter Witt cars for their respective markets. In Italy, Carminati & Toselli in Milan, Officine Elettroferroviarie Tallero also in Milan, Officine Ferroviarie Moncenisio in Condove, Turin, and Officine Ferroviarie Meridionali del Vasto in Vasto, Chieti, supplied the type to Italian systems. Cincinnati Car Company of Cincinnati, Ohio, and G. C. Kuhlman Car Company of Cleveland, Ohio, kept production in Witt’s home state. Ottawa Car Company of Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, and Preston Car Company of Preston, Ontario, Canada, served Canadian operators, while St. Louis Car Company of St. Louis, Missouri, United States, added further North American capacity. Farther afield, Petersburg Tram Mechanical Factory in Leningrad, Russian SFSR, Soviet Union, manufactured the design for Soviet networks.

title: Microstate
intro: A microstate or ministate is a sovereign state having a very small population or very small land area, and usually both. The meanings of state and very small are not well-defined in international law. Recent attempts, since 2010, to define microstates have focused on identifying political entities with unique qualitative features linked to their geographic or demographic limitations. According to a qualitative definition, microstates are modern protected states, i.e. sovereign states that have been able to unilaterally depute certain attributes of sovereignty to larger powers in exchange for benign protection of their political and economic viability against their geographic or demographic constraints. In line with this and most other definitions, examples of microstates include Liechtenstein, Monaco, San Marino, Andorra, the Cook Islands, Niue, and the Federated States of Micronesia. The smallest political unit recognized as a sovereign state is Vatican City, with 842 citizens as of July 2013 and an area of only 44 hectares (110 acres). However, some scholars dispute qualifying Vatican City as a state, arguing that it does not meet the traditional criteria of statehood and that the special status of the Vatican City is probably best regarded as a means of ensuring that the Pope can freely exercise his spiritual functions, and in this respect is loosely analogous to that of the headquarters of international organisations. Microstates are distinct from micronations, which are not recognized as sovereign states. Special territories without full sovereignty, such as the British Crown Dependencies, the Chinese Special Administrative Regions, and overseas territories of Denmark, France, the Netherlands, Australia, Norway, the United States, and the United Kingdom, are also not considered microstates.
lm_description: Vatican City, Europe’s 842-person sovereign enclave, packs 1,913.6 people into every square kilometre around its同名 capital. Nauru, the next-smallest polity, shelters 9,488 Nauruans on its reef-fringed island without designating any capital at all. Tuvalu’s 10,782 residents concentrate in Funafuti, while Palau’s 21,186 islanders spread thinly enough to yield 46.2 per km² and seat government in Ngerulmud. San Marino’s 32,742 citizens share 536.8 per km² within their mountaintop capital, dwarfed by Monaco’s staggering 18,469.3 per km² for 37,308 residents clustered around Monaco-Ville. Liechtenstein’s 37,313 inhabitants enjoy Alpine space at 233.2 per km² from Vaduz. Across the Atlantic, Saint Kitts and Nevis counts 51,538 people at 197.5 per km² under Basseterre’s sway, while Dominica’s 73,449 live more spaciously at 97.8 per km² around Roseau. The Marshall Islands’ 70,983 pack 392.2 per km² into Majuro’s atoll. Andorra’s 85,458 Pyrenean villagers occupy 182.6 per km² centred on Andorra la Vella. Antigua and Barbuda’s 91,295 cluster near St John’s at 206.1 per km², mirroring Seychelles’ 91,650 around Victoria on its Indian-Ocean granite. Kingstown governs 102,918 Vincentians at 264.6 per km², while Tarawa’s 104,488 I-Kiribati share 128.8 per km². Palikir presides over 105,681 Micronesians at 150.5 per km², Nukuʻalofa over 106,440 Tongans at 142.5 per km², and St George’s over 110,152 Grenadians at 320.2 per km². Castries shelters 163,362 Saint Lucians at 265.2 per km², and São Tomé anchors 190,428 São Toméans at 197.5 per km² on its equatorial volcanic isle.

Palikir presides over 105,681 Micronesians at 150.5 per km², Nukuʻalofa over 106,440 Tongans at 142.5 per km², and St George’s over 110,152 Grenadians at 320.2 per km². Castries shelters 163,362 Saint Lucians at 265.2 per km², and São Tomé anchors 190,428 São Toméans at 197.5 per km² on its equatorial volcanic isle.

title: Live with Regis and Kelly (season 21)
intro: This is a list of Live with Regis and Kelly episodes which were broadcast during the show's 21st season. The list is ordered by air date. Although the co-hosts may have read a couple of emails during the broadcast, it does not necessarily count as a Regis and Kelly Inbox segment.
lm_description: On October 1, Regis Philbin and Kelly Ripa welcomed Kate Walsh, Kellie Pickler, and the Quaker Oatmeal Dance Your Heart Out segment; the next day they repeated the dance bit with Jo Frost and Diane Sawyer. October 3 saw Kelly Ripa co-hosting alongside husband Mark Consuelos, interviewing Blair Underwood, the Jon & Kate Plus 8 clan, and Robin Thicke. Regis returned October 6 with Alicia Keys, John Lithgow, and another Quaker dance segment, followed October 7 by the Toy of the Year Awards, Gary Sinise, and Sarah McLachlan. Debra Messing, Bill O'Reilly, and the Project Runway finalists appeared October 8; Molly Shannon and animal handler Peter Gros visited October 9; Russell Crowe and Isaac Mizrahi closed out the first week on October 10. Kelly Ripa paired October 13 with Randy Jackson to chat with Christian Slater and Ed Westwick, then October 14 and 15 with Anderson Cooper hosting Queen Latifah, Rusty Wallace, Nobu Matsuhisa, James Marsden, and Michael Urie. Bryant Gumbel joined Ripa October 16 for Edward Norton, Bernadette Peters, and the Project Runway winner, while Howie Mandel helped October 17 welcome Kim Raver and Billy Bob Thornton with The Boxermasters. Regis and Kelly reunited October 20 for Judge Judy, Corbin Bleu, and the CFA-Iams Cat Championship, then October 21–23 showcased Vanessa Hudgens, Jason O'Mara, Gavin Rossdale, Zac Efron, Shawn Johnson, Whoopi Goldberg, and Ashley Tisdale. Michael Chiklis co-hosted October 24 with Gisele Bündchen and John Slattery, before Regis and Kelly finished October 27–28 with Marcia Cross, Katie Brown, Charles Gibson, Tom Nardone, and Craig Horner.

title: List of submissions to the 37th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film
intro: The following 18 films, all from different countries, were submitted for the 37th Academy Awards in the category Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film. The titles highlighted in blue and yellow were the five nominated films, which came from France, Israel, Italy, Japan and Sweden. Italy won the award for romantic comedy Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow, starring Sophia Loren and Marcello Mastroianni. Czechoslovakia, Israel and Turkey submitted films to the competition for the first time.
lm_description: Brazil entered Glauber Rocha’s Portuguese-language epic *The Black God and the White Devil* under its original title *Deus e o Diabo na Terra do Sol*, but it was not nominated. Czechoslovakia, competing for the first time, sent Oldřich Lipský’s Czech western satire *Lemonade Joe* (*Limonádový Joe*) without success, while Denmark offered Annelise Hovmand’s Danish chamber piece *Sextet* (*Sekstet*) and Egypt submitted Atef Salem’s Arabic domestic comedy *Mother of the Bride* (*أم العروسة*), both likewise passed over. France secured a nomination with Jacques Demy’s sung French romance *The Umbrellas of Cherbourg* (*Les parapluies de Cherbourg*), and Israel, also a first-time participant, saw Ephraim Kishon’s Hebrew social satire *Sallah Shabati* advance to the final five. Italy triumphed with Vittorio De Sica’s Italian triptych *Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow* (*Ieri, oggi, domani*), which went on to win the Oscar, while Japan’s entry, Hiroshi Teshigahara’s Japanese existential drama *Woman in the Dunes* (*砂の女*), and Sweden’s contender, Bo Widerberg’s Swedish coming-of-age tale *Raven’s End* (*Kvarteret Korpen*), completed the roster of nominees. Among the remaining hopefuls, South Korea entered Shin Sang-ok’s Korean tragedy *The Deaf Samyong* (*벙어리 삼용*), the Netherlands offered Bert Haanstra’s Dutch documentary *The Human Dutch* (*Alleman*), Poland submitted Andrzej Munk and Witold Lesiewicz’s Polish Holocaust drama *Passenger* (*Pasażerka*), Spain sent Manuel Summers’s Spanish adolescent comedy *The Girl in Mourning* (*La Niña de luto*), Taiwan presented Lei Pan’s Mandarin romance *Lovers’ Rock* (*情人石*), Turkey, another newcomer, entered Metin Erksan and David E. Durston’s Turkish rural drama *Dry Summer* (*Susuz Yaz*), and Yugoslavia closed the list with Veljko Bulajić’s Macedonian documentary *Skoplje ’63* (*Скопје 63*), none receiving nominations.

title: 2004 Aerobic Gymnastics World Championships
intro: The 8th Aerobic Gymnastics World Championships were held in Sofia, Bulgaria from June 3 to June 5, 2004.
lm_description: Galina Lazarova and Marian Kolev topped the 2004 Aerobic Gymnastics World Championships with 19.780 points for Bulgaria. Spain’s Alba de las Heras and Jonatan Canada followed just 0.030 behind at 19.750, while Romania’s Izabela Lăcătuș and Remus Nicolai claimed third with 19.700. Italy’s Giovanna Lecis and Wilkie Satti Sanchez placed fourth on 19.250, and South Korea’s In Yung Choi and Jong Kun Song were fifth with 18.800. Russia’s Elena Kopylova and Aleksander Shulga earned 18.530 for sixth, Brazil’s Juliana Antero and Marcisnei Oliveira scored 18.400 for seventh, and Chile’s Carolina Chacon Molinez and J.P. Olivares Arancibia closed the rankings at 18.050.

2004 Aerobic Gymnastics World Championships

Olivares Arancibia closed the rankings at 18.050.

title: List of Michigan State Historic Sites
intro: The following is a List of Michigan State Historic Sites. The register is maintained by the Michigan State Historic Preservation Office, which was established in the late 1960s after the passage of the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966. Sites marked with a dagger (†) are also listed on the National Register of Historic Places in Michigan. Those with a double dagger (‡) are also designated National Historic Landmarks. As of June 2011, there were more than 2,700 total listings distributed through each of Michigan's 83 counties. In addition, several historical markers have been erected outside of Michigan.
lm_description: The Bradley House, standing at the corner of Cook Road and Main Street in Midland, earned its Michigan State Historic Site status on April 23, 1971, and is also listed on the National Register. The Chemical Industry Informational Designation, located on the 700 block of West Main Street, was recognized much earlier, on September 17, 1957. Out in the Midland vicinity, the Homer Township Cemetery at 1136 East Prairie Road, bordered by Pine River and Prairie roads, was listed on September 19, 1991. Downtown at 505 Main Street, the John and Almira Kelly House joined the register on September 24, 1984. The Midland County Courthouse, situated at 301 West Main Street, was designated on May 21, 1985, and carries National Register recognition. Nearby at 812 West Main Street, the James T. Pardee House was listed on March 19, 1987, also holding National Register status. Spanning Currie Parkway over the Tittabawassee River, the Upper Bridge was honored on August 18, 1988. Finally, the Alden Dow House and Studio at 315 Post Street was listed on June 29, 1989.

title: List of Philadelphia Phillies team records
intro: The Philadelphia Phillies have participated in 127 seasons in Major League Baseball since their inception in 1883. Through 2009, they have played 19,035 games, winning 9,035 and losing 10,162, for a winning their tenure as members of Major League Baseball's National League. Chuck Klein, the franchise's only batting Triple Crown winner, holds the most franchise records as of the end of the 2009 season, with eight, including career slugging percentage, career on-base plus slugging (OPS), and single-season extra-base hits. He is followed by Billy Hamilton, who holds seven records, including career batting average and the single-season runs record. Several Phillies hold National League and major league records. Pitcher/outfielder John Coleman is the most decorated in this category, holding three major league records, all from the franchise's inaugural season. Coleman set records for losses, earned runs allowed, and hits allowed, all in 1883 when he also set three additional franchise pitching records. Shortstop Jimmy Rollins broke Willie Wilson's record for at-bats in a single season with 716 in 2007, and first baseman Ryan Howard also set the major league record for strikeouts in a single season that same year with 199, before it was broken by Mark Reynolds of the Arizona Diamondbacks the following year. The 1930 Phillies, who went 52-102, set two more National League records, allowing 1,993 hits and 1,193 runs in the regular season.
lm_description: Ed Delahanty’s 1899 season still towers with a .410 batting average, while Ryan Howard crushed 58 home runs in 2006. Chuck Klein drove in 170 runs during 1930, the same year he hammered 59 doubles, 107 extra-base hits and 445 total bases for a .687 slugging percentage and 1.123 OPS. Billy Hamilton raced across the plate 192 times in 1894, posted a .523 on-base percentage that same season, and in 1891 swiped 111 bases. Lefty O’Doul collected 254 hits in 1929, tying Richie Ashburn’s 181 singles mark set in 1951. Sam Thompson legged out 28 triples in 1894. Jimmy Rollins logged 716 at-bats in 2007 and earlier strung together a 36-game hitting streak in 2005. Lenny Dykstra drew 129 walks in 1993, and Ryan Howard whiffed 199 times in 2007.

title: Awards, lectures and medals of the Royal Society
intro: The Royal Society presents numerous awards, lectures and medals to recognise scientific achievement. The oldest is the Croonian Lecture, created in 1701 at the request of the widow of William Croone, one of the founding members of the Royal Society. The Croonian Lecture is still awarded on an annual basis, and is considered the most important Royal Society prize for the biological sciences. Although the Croonian Lecture was created in 1701, it was first awarded in 1738, seven years after the Copley Medal which is the oldest Royal Society medal still in use and is awarded for outstanding achievements in research in any branch of science
lm_description: The Armourers and Brasiers’ Company Prize, created in 1984, is awarded every two years for excellence in materials science and technology, carries a £2,000 gift, and was most recently given to Steven Armes in 2018. The GlaxoSmithKline Prize and Lecture, established in 1976, is a biennial £2,500 award for original contributions to medical and veterinary sciences published within the previous decade; originally sponsored by the Wellcome Trust, it was renamed in 2002 and last went to Andrew Hattersley in 2016. Since 1986 the annual Michael Faraday Prize has honoured excellence in communicating science to UK audiences, providing £2,500 and a lecture, with Martyn Poliakoff receiving it in 2019. The Milner Award, launched in 2012 and supported by Microsoft Research, is an annual honour for outstanding European achievement in computer science named after Robin Milner; Cordelia Schmid won in 2020. The Mullard Award, dating from 1967, targets early-career UK scientists or engineers whose work promises national prosperity, adds £2,000, and was presented to Hagan Bayley in 2019. Created in 2016, the Royal Society Africa Prize gives an £11,000 research grant, a bronze medal and £1,000 to an Africa-based biologist advancing capacity building; Henry Mwandumba took the 2019 award. Also founded in 2016, the biennial Royal Society Athena Prize rewards UK individuals or teams advancing STEM diversity with a medal and £5,000, most recently to Emma Chapman in 2018. The Royal Society Insight Investment Science Book Prize, begun in 1988, annually crowns the year’s best general-science book for lay readers with £25,000; Andrea Wulf won in 2016. The Rosalind Franklin Award, instituted in 2003, annually grants £30,000 for outstanding STEM contributions by a woman, and Nguyễn Thị Kim Thanh claimed it in 2019.

title: List of Catholic churches in the United States
intro: This is a list of notable Catholic churches and cathedrals in the United States.
lm_description: The Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, a Gothic Revival landmark at 125 Eagle Street in Albany, New York, was built in 1902 and listed on the NRHP in 1976. St. Stanislaus Church, a Late Gothic Revival structure at 50 Cornell Street in Amsterdam, New York, dates to 1897 and gained NRHP status in 1999. In Binghamton, the Late 19th & 20th Century Revival Saints Cyril and Methodius School stands at 144-146 Clinton Street, constructed in 1920 and NRHP-listed in 2007. Buffalo hosts several notable churches: the Lombard Romanesque Blessed Trinity Church at 317 LeRoy Ave, built in 1906 and NRHP-listed in 1979; the Gothic Revival St. Joseph Cathedral at 50 Franklin Street, dating to 1862; the Modern Movement St. Rose of Lima Church at 500 Parker Ave, NRHP-listed in 2017; the Gothic Revival St. Theresa's Church at 1970 Seneca St., also NRHP-listed in 2016; and the Romanesque Revival St. Thomas Aquinas Church at 432 Abbott Rd., NRHP-listed in 2017. Our Mother of Sorrows Church in Greece, New York, a Romanesque building from 1859, was NRHP-listed in 1989. The National shrine Our Lady of Victory Basilica in Lackawanna, New York, built in 1926 at 767 Ridge Road, serves as a popular pilgrimage site in the Diocese of Buffalo.

title: FIRS Inline Hockey World Championships
intro: The Inline Hockey World Championships are an annual inline hockey tournament organized by the Comité International Roller In-Line Hockey (CIRILH), an organization and discipline of Fédération Internationale de Roller Sports (FIRS). First held in 1995, it is the sport's highest profile annual international tournament. The first World Championship that was held was in 1995 in which twelve nations participated in pool play followed by single elimination games to determine the champion. This basic format would be used until 2006 (although the number of teams changed). The modern format for the World Championship features eight teams in Group 1, and if there are more than eight teams, the rest compete in Group 2. All teams play a preliminary round, then the top six teams in Group 1 and top two teams in Group 2 play in the playoff medal round and the winning team is crowned World Champion. The remaining teams (bottom two in Group 1 and remaining teams in Group 2) play in a playoff round for the National Team World Cup, and the winning team is crowned World Cup champions. The World Championships are open to all players, both professional and amateur. The FIRS requires that players are citizens of the country they represent and allow players to switch national teams provided that they play in their new nation for a certain period of time. The United States is the tournament's first dominant team, winning the tournament 14 of the 18 events held (as of 2012), as well as medaling in all but one tournament. The Czech Republic is the next most successful team, winning the tournament twice and winning 14 medals.
lm_description: In 2007 the United States beat the Czech Republic for gold in Düsseldorf, Germany, while Germany itself took bronze. Great Britain stunned the United States 5-4 in the 2008 final in Philadelphia, with Canada earning bronze. The Czechs then began a four-year reign: in 2009 they defeated Canada in Varese, Italy, leaving the United States with bronze; in 2010 they edged the United States again in Düsseldorf while France claimed bronze; in 2011 they repeated the same medal order in Roccaraso, Italy; and in 2012 they overcame host Colombia in Bucaramanga, the United States settling for bronze. Anaheim 2013 saw the Czechs beat the United States once more, Canada third. France broke through in 2014, downing Canada in Toulouse with the Czechs third. The Czech Republic returned to the top in 2015 in Rosario, Argentina, ahead of France and Italy, then in 2016 defeated Italy on home ice in Asiago/Roana, Switzerland taking bronze. France regained the title in 2017 in Nanjing, China, over Spain with Italy third. The United States reclaimed gold in 2018 in Asiago/Roana, Italy, ahead of Italy and Spain. In 2019 the Czechs again edged the United States in Barcelona, Spain, with Spain third. Cartagena, Colombia, was slated to host the 2020 championship.
