title: List of ethnic groups of Africa
intro: The ethnic groups of Africa number in the thousands, with each population generally having its own language (or dialect of a language) and culture. The ethnolinguistic groups include various Afroasiatic, Khoisan, Niger-Congo and Nilo-Saharan populations. The official population count of the various ethnic groups in Africa is highly uncertain, both due to limited infrastructure to perform censuses and due to the rapid population growth. There have also been accusations of deliberate misreporting in order to give selected ethnicities numerical superiority (as in the case of Nigeria's Hausa, Fulani, Yoruba and Igbo people). A 2009 genetic clustering study, which genotyped 1327 polymorphic markers in various African populations, identified six ancestral clusters. The clustering corresponded closely with ethnicity, culture and language. A 2018 whole genome sequencing study of the world's populations observed similar clusters among the populations in Africa. At K=9, distinct ancestral components defined the Afrosiatic-speaking populations inhabiting North Africa and Northeast Africa; the Nilo-Saharan-speaking populations in Northeast Africa and East Africa; the Ari populations in Northeast Africa; the Niger-Congo-speaking populations in West-Central Africa, West Africa, East Africa and Southern Africa; the Pygmy populations in Central Africa; and the Khoisan populations in Southern Africa.
lm_description: The Akan of Ghana and Ivory Coast speak a Niger-Congo Kwa language and number 20 million. In the Horn of Africa, Abyssinians span Ethiopia and Eritrea with Afro-Asiatic Semitic speech, while their Amhara kin within Ethiopia alone total 22 million (2007). Central Africa’s Chewa, Malawi and Zambia’s 12-million-strong Niger-Congo Bantu speakers, neighbour the 15-million Hutu of Rwanda, Burundi and DR Congo. West Africa’s Fulani, a 20-million-strong Niger-Congo Senegambian people, range from Mauritania to Sierra Leone, whereas the Hausa, 43 million Afro-Asiatic Chadic speakers, dominate Nigeria and Niger and spill into seven further states. Nigeria’s Igbo, 34 million (2017) Niger-Congo Volta-Niger speakers, share the region with the Yoruba, whose 40 million members extend from Nigeria across Benin, Togo, Ghana, Ivory Coast and Sierra Leone. Kanuri, Nilo-Saharan Saharan speakers, count 10 million in Nigeria, Niger, Chad and Cameroon. Central Africa’s Kongo, Luba and Mongo each claim 10 or 15 million Niger-Congo Bantu speakers in DR Congo and Angola. North Africa’s Maghrebis, 100 million Afro-Asiatic Semites, blanket Mauritania to Libya. Nilotes, 22 million (2007) Nilo-Saharan Nilotic speakers, stretch from South Sudan to Ethiopia. Oromo, 35 million (2016) Afro-Asiatic Cushites, and Somali, 20 million (2009) Cushites, share the Horn with Kenya. Shona, 15 million (2000) Niger-Congo Bantoid people, straddle Zimbabwe and Mozambique, while 12 million (2016) Zulu complete the arc in South Africa.

title: List of Methodist churches in the United States
intro: This is a list of Methodist churches in the United States. It includes notable churches either where a church means a congregation (in the New Testament definition) or where a church means a building (in the colloquial sense). It also includes campgrounds and conference centers and retreats that are significant Methodist gathering places, including a number of historic sites of camp meetings. This very limited list includes only historically or architecturally significant buildings, and omits many of the currently very largest and influential congregations which do not meet that standard. Methodism was founded with a large component being a rejection of past churches and was developed by John Wesley and others in large open-air gatherings in Great Britain. In the United States, Methodists (along with Baptists and other Protestants) were major participants in the Second Great Awakening wherein people would travel from a large area to a particular site to camp out, listen to itinerant preachers, and pray. The list also includes selected notable Methodist theological buildings. In the United States, numerous Methodist churches are listed on the National Register of Historic Places and on state and local historic registers, many reflecting the values of plainness, of Gothic architecture, of simple adornment. The Greek Revival style is also simple and came to be adopted for numerous American Methodist churches.
lm_description: The Methodist Church of Alberton, the Methodist Episcopal Church of Anaconda, its counterpart in Bozeman, the Methodist Episcopal Church and Parsonage in Bridger, the Fromberg Methodist-Episcopal Church, the First Methodist Episcopal Church and Parsonage in Glendive, the First United Methodist Church Parsonage and the Union Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church—both in Great Falls—the Scandinavian Methodist Church in Kalispell, the Methodist-Episcopal Church of Marysville, the Stevensville Grade School-United Methodist Church, the Methodist Episcopal Church in Third Forks, and the Stateler Memorial Methodist Church in Willow Creek are all NRHP-listed Montana landmarks. The First Episcopal Methodist Church of Chester, erected in 1911, gained NRHP recognition in 1997, as did the 1894-built Methodist Episcopal Church South in Corvallis, honored the same year.

title: Copa Libertadores (trophy)
intro: The Copa Libertadores trophy, or simply Copa Libertadores, is a trophy awarded annually by CONMEBOL to the football club that wins the Copa Libertadores.
lm_description: Boca Juniors have lifted the Copa Libertadores six times, in 1977, 1978, 2000, 2001, 2003 and 2007. River Plate have four titles, earned in 1986, 1996, 2015 and 2018. Olimpia, São Paulo and Grêmio each have three: Olimpia in 1979, 1990 and 2002; São Paulo in 1992, 1993 and 2005; Grêmio in 1983, 1995 and 2017. Independiente won twice, in 1975 and 1984, as did Cruzeiro (1976, 1997), Nacional (1980, 1988), Peñarol (1982, 1987), Atlético Nacional (1989, 2016), Internacional (2006, 2010) and Flamengo (1981, 2019). Argentinos Juniors claimed their lone trophy in 1985, Colo-Colo in 1991, Vélez Sársfield in 1994, Vasco da Gama in 1998, Palmeiras in 1999, Once Caldas in 2004, LDU Quito in 2008 and Estudiantes in 2009.

title: List of LGBT characters in modern written fiction
intro: This is a list of LGBT characters in modern written fiction. The historical concept and definition of sexual orientation varies and has changed greatly over time; for example the word gay wasn't used to describe sexual orientation until the mid 20th century. A number of different classification schemes have been used to describe sexual orientation since the mid-19th century, and scholars have often defined the term 'sexual orientation' in divergent ways. Indeed, several studies have found that much of the research about sexual orientation has failed to define the term at all, making it difficult to reconcile the results of different studies. However, most definitions include a psychological component (such as the direction of an individual's erotic desire) and/or a behavioral component (which focuses on the sex of the individual's sexual partner/s). Some prefer to simply follow an individual's self-definition or identity. See homosexuality and bisexuality for criteria that have traditionally denoted lesbian, gay and bisexual (LGB) people.
lm_description: Sheridan Le Fanu’s 1872 novella Carmilla features the eponymous Carmilla, a lesbian vampire who inaugurates the lesbian-vampire tradition. Alan Dale’s 1889 A Marriage Below Zero presents Arthur Ravener and Captain Dillington in what is hailed as the first English-language gay-themed novel, while Bayard Taylor’s 1870 Joseph and His Friend: A Story of Pennsylvania follows Joseph Asten and Philip Held in the first American gay-themed novel. Between 1835 and 1847 Honoré de Balzac introduces Jacques Collin, alias Vautrin or Trompe-la-Mort, across five volumes of La Comédie humaine, often cited as French literature’s first openly homosexual character. Oscar Wilde’s 1890 The Picture of Dorian Gray portrays the gay artist Basil Hallward and the bisexual Dorian Gray. The anonymous 1881 pornographic novel The Sins of the Cities of the Plain centers on Jack Saul, a male prostitute who cross-dresses and services men, one of the earliest English works devoted almost solely to homosexuality. Similarly, the anonymously published 1893 Teleny, or The Reverse of the Medal—attributed to Wilde—depicts the fervent affair between René Teleny and Camille de Grieux. Adolfo Caminha’s 1895 Bom-Crioulo rounds out the century with the gay character Amaro.

title: List of U.S. Open Cup finals
intro: The U.S. Open Cup is an American soccer competition open to all United States Soccer Federation affiliated teams, from amateur adult club teams to the professional clubs of Major League Soccer. With five titles each, Bethlehem Steel of Bethlehem, Pennsylvania and Maccabi Los Angeles have won the domestic cup more times than any other American soccer club. In a joint tie for third, the Chicago Fire, Fall River Marksmen, Greek American Atlas, Philadelphia Ukrainians, Seattle Sounders FC, and Sporting Kansas City have won the title four times. In the cup's 105-year history, 63 different clubs have won the tournament.
lm_description: Maccabi Los Angeles and Bethlehem Steel each own five U.S. Open Cup titles, Maccabi’s last coming in 1981 and Bethlehem’s in 1926, with Maccabi finishing second in 1982 and Bethlehem in 1918. Chicago Fire, Greek American AA, Philadelphia Tridents, Seattle Sounders FC, Fall River Marksmen and Sporting Kansas City follow with four wins apiece: Chicago last lifted the trophy in 2006 and were runners-up in 2011, Greek American AA in 1967 and 1989, Philadelphia Tridents in 1966 and 1964, Seattle in 2014 and 2012, while Fall River and Sporting Kansas City have never lost a final, their fourth triumphs coming in 1931 and 2017 respectively. Stix, Baer and Fuller collected three titles, the last in 1935, and were beaten in the 1937 final. New York Pancyprian-Freedoms also have three wins, their most recent in 1982, without ever finishing second. D.C. United’s three victories culminated in 2013 after losing the 2009 final. Brooklyn Italians earned back-to-back wins, their second in 1991 after being runners-up in 1990. Brooklyn Hispano secured two titles, the last in 1944, without ever finishing second. Los Angeles Galaxy and FC Dallas each have two wins, Galaxy’s in 2005 after losing the 2006 final, Dallas in 2016 after falling in 2007.

title: Australasia at the Olympics
intro: Australasia was a combined team of athletes from Australia and the Dominion of New Zealand that competed together at the 1908 and 1912 Summer Olympics. When the Olympic Games resumed in 1920 after World War I, the two nations sent separate teams to the Games, and have done so ever since.
lm_description: At the 1908 London Games, the Australasia side struck gold when its rugby union squad won the men’s competition, while Snowy Baker pocketed silver in the boxing middleweight division and Frank Beaurepaire claimed two swimming medals: silver in the men’s 400 m freestyle and bronze in the 1500 m. Harry Kerr added a bronze in the 3500 m walk. Four years later in Stockholm, Fanny Durack topped the women’s 100 m freestyle, with Mina Wylie taking silver behind her. The men’s 4 × 200 m freestyle relay title went to Cecil Healy, Malcolm Champion, Leslie Boardman and Harold Hardwick; Healy also gained silver in the individual 100 m, and Hardwick earned bronze in both the 1500 m and 400 m. Anthony Wilding completed the haul with bronze in the men’s indoor singles tennis.
to_index_text:
Australasia at the Olympics
Australasia was a combined team of athletes from Australia and the Dominion of New Zealand that competed together at the 1908 and 1912 Summer Olympics. When the Olympic Games resumed in 1920 after World War I, the two nations sent separate teams to the Games, and have done so ever since.
At the 1908 London Games, the Australasia side struck gold when its rugby union squad won the men’s competition, while Snowy Baker pocketed silver in the boxing middleweight division and Frank Beaurepaire claimed two swimming medals: silver in the men’s 400 m freestyle and bronze in the 1500 m. Harry Kerr added a bronze in the 3500 m walk. Four years later in Stockholm, Fanny Durack topped the women’s 100 m freestyle, with Mina Wylie taking silver behind her. The men’s 4 × 200 m freestyle relay title went to Cecil Healy, Malcolm Champion, Leslie Boardman and Harold Hardwick; Healy also gained silver in the individual 100 m, and Hardwick earned bronze in both the 1500 m and 400 m. Anthony Wilding completed the haul with bronze in the men’s indoor singles tennis.

title: Intercity (Deutsche Bahn)
intro: Intercity is the second-highest train classification in Germany, after the ICE. Intercity services are loco-hauled express train services, usually over long-distances. There are Intercity routes throughout Germany, and routes generally operate with a two-hour frequency, with multiple routes giving a more frequent service on core routes. Intercity services are operated by the DB Fernverkehr sector of Deutsche Bahn. The Intercity name was introduced in Germany in 1971, replacing the old F-Zug category, and was the top category of train in Germany until the introduction of the ICEs in the early 1990s. With the proliferation of ICE services, the role of IC trains has diminished slightly, and they have taken on the character of many former InterRegio trains. Nonetheless, Intercity trains still offer a very high standard of speed and comfort - all services convey first class accommodation, and most include catering - usually a Bistro Cafe, but some services include a restaurant. A number of Intercity services serve destinations outside Germany; most of these are under the EuroCity classification.
lm_description: Intercity Line 26 links Hamburg, Hannover, Kassel, Gießen, Frankfurt, Heidelberg and Karlsruhe every two hours, with through coaches continuing from Binz and Rostock via Hamburg to Konstanz, from Hamburg via Kassel, Würzburg and Nuremberg to Passau, from Kassel via Würzburg, Ansbach, Augsburg and Munich to Berchtesgaden, and from Munich through Zell am See to Schwarzach St. Veit. Line 27 runs every two hours from Hamburg through Wittenberge, Berlin and Dresden to Prague, with extensions from Westerland and from Binz via Stralsund to Berlin and onward to Vienna, Budapest and Villach. One daily train pair of Line 28 connects Berlin, Leipzig, Nuremberg, Augsburg and Munich. Every two hours Line 30 runs from Hamburg via Bremen, Münster, Dortmund, Düsseldorf, Cologne, Koblenz, Mainz, Mannheim, Heidelberg to Stuttgart, with through coaches from Binz and Heringsdorf via Rostock and Hamburg to Chur via Basel and Zürich. Line 31 links Hamburg, Bremen, Münster, Dortmund, Wuppertal, Cologne, Koblenz, Mainz and Frankfurt every two hours, with extensions from Kiel and from Puttgarden via Lübeck to Hamburg and from Frankfurt via Würzburg and Nuremberg to Passau. Line 32 runs every two hours from Dortmund via Essen, Düsseldorf, Cologne, Koblenz, Mainz, Mannheim, Heidelberg, Stuttgart and Ulm to Munich, with through coaches from Berlin via Hannover and Hamm to Dortmund, from Münster to Essen, from Stuttgart to Tübingen, from Ulm to Innsbruck via Lindau, and from Munich to Klagenfurt via Salzburg. Line 35 starts every two hours in Norddeich Mole, runs through Emden, Münster, Gelsenkirchen, Oberhausen, Düsseldorf and Cologne to Koblenz, and continues to Luxembourg, to Stuttgart via Mainz and Mannheim, and to Konstanz via Karlsruhe and Offenburg. Line 50 links Leipzig, Naumburg, Erfurt, Eisenach, Fulda, Frankfurt and Frankfurt Airport every two hours, with through coaches from Binz via Stralsund and Berlin to Naumburg, from Dresden to Leipzig, from Eisenach via Kassel to Dortmund, and from Frankfurt via Darmstadt and Mannheim to Saarbrücken. Every two hours Line 55 runs from Leipzig via Halle, Magdeburg, Hannover, Hamm, Dortmund and Wuppertal to Cologne, with extensions from Dortmund via Düsseldorf to Stuttgart and Oberstdorf, and from Riesa to Dresden. Line 56 connects Dresden, Leipzig, Halle, Magdeburg, Hannover, Bremen and Oldenburg every two hours, with branches from Cottbus via Berlin to Magdeburg, from Magdeburg to Warnemünde via Stendal and Rostock, and from Oldenburg to Emden. Line 60 runs every two hours from Karlsruhe via Bruchsal and Stuttgart to Munich, with through coaches from Basel to Karlsruhe and from Munich to Salzburg. Line 61 links Karlsruhe, Pforzheim, Stuttgart, Ansbach and Nuremberg every two hours, with extensions from Basel via Freiburg to Karlsruhe and from Nuremberg to Leipzig via Jena. Every two hours Line 62 runs from Frankfurt via Heidelberg, Stuttgart, Munich to Salzburg, with through coaches from Siegen to Frankfurt, from Saarbrücken via Mannheim to Stuttgart, and from Salzburg to Graz, Linz and Klagenfurt. One train pair of Line 75 travels from Hamburg via Lübeck and Puttgarden to Copenhagen. Line 77 runs every two hours from Berlin via Wolfsburg, Hannover, Osnabrück and Bad Bentheim to Amsterdam, with a branch from Osnabrück to Münster. Every two hours Line 87 connects Stuttgart, Singen, Schaffhausen and Zürich, with through coaches from Frankfurt to Stuttgart. Four train pairs of Line 88 link Munich, Lindau, Bregenz and Zürich. Every two hours Line 89 runs from Munich via Rosenheim and Innsbruck to Italy. Four train pairs of Line 95 run from Berlin via Frankfurt (Oder) and Poznań to Warsaw, with an extension from Poznań to Gdańsk and Gdynia. One train pair of Line 99 travels from Hamburg via Lüneburg, Stendal, Berlin and Cottbus to Wroclaw.

Every two hours Line 89 runs from Munich via Rosenheim and Innsbruck to Italy. Four train pairs of Line 95 run from Berlin via Frankfurt (Oder) and Poznań to Warsaw, with an extension from Poznań to Gdańsk and Gdynia. One train pair of Line 99 travels from Hamburg via Lüneburg, Stendal, Berlin and Cottbus to Wroclaw.

title: Dancing with the Stars (Greek season 4)
intro: The Greek reality show version of Dancing with the stars returned for its fourth season on October 20, 2013 from ANT1 TV channel. The show is based on the United Kingdom BBC Television series Strictly Come Dancing and is part of BBC Worldwide's Dancing with the Stars franchise. The theme song is It's personal performed by Swedish indie pop band The Radio Dept. The host of this season was Doukissa Nomikou while on the backstage was the season three winner, Ntoretta Papadimitriou. Giannis Latsios, Alexis Kostalas, Galena Velikova and Katia Dandoulaki returned as the judges of the show. The celebrities who were competed this season were 8 women and 6 men; Chrispa, Katerina Stikoudi, Klelia Pantazi, Konstantina, Mary Synatsaki, Gogo Mastrokosta, Evagelia Aravani, Eleni Chatzidou, Lakis Gavalas, Michalis Mouroutsos, Thanos Kallioras, Sakis Arseniou, Isaias Matiamba and Alex Kavdas. The professional partners were revealed on October 17, 2013. On November 16, 2013, it was announced that on week 4, Giorgos Liagkas would make a guest appearance on the show and will be the fifth judge for the night. On week 8 Eugenia Manolidou, who competed in the first season of the show and got the third place, was the second guest judge of the season. On week 9 the show had its third guest judge, Themos Anastasiadis. The three guests gave a score to the contestants but their score was symbolic and didn't count for the final result of that week. On week 7 the couples were free to choose a favorite song of theirs to dance to and the routine was Freestyle.
lm_description: Klelia Pantazi and Katerina Stikoudi shared the Cha-Cha-Cha summit with a perfect 40, while Eleni Chatzidou, Konstantina and Gogo Mastrokosta all scraped the bottom with 22. Michalis Mouroutsos owned the Tango high of 33, leaving Lakis Gavalas stranded on 20. Katerina Stikoudi and Isaias Matiamba waltzed to 40 in the Viennese Waltz as Chrispa managed only 17. Isaias Matiamba’s Jive hit 40, dwarfing Sakis Arseniou’s 15. Katerina Stikoudi’s Samba dazzled to 40, contrasting with Eleni Chatzidou’s 16. In Paso Doble, Stikoudi scored 39 while Thanos Kallioras managed 19. Freestyle saw Stikoudi on 37 and Chrispa on 18. Rumba brought Stikoudi 36 and Gogo Mastrokosta 22. Lakis Gavalas peaked at 28 in Bachata yet also bottomed at 22. Klelia Pantazi’s Argentine Tango reached 40 while Chrispa managed 24. Isaias Matiamba’s Mambo scored 38, Alex Kavdas 19. Mary Synatsaki and Stikoudi Quickstepped to 36, Gavalas lagged on 26. Salsa saw Pantazi and Stikoudi on 36, Mary Synatsaki on 28. Foxtrot gave Matiamba 37, Klelia Pantazi 33. Fusion dance put Michalis Mouroutsos on 33, Lakis Gavalas on 24. Solo dance crowned Matiamba with 40, Pantazi with 37.

title: List of museums in Northumberland
intro: This list of museums in Northumberland, England contains museums which are defined for this context as institutions (including nonprofit organizations, government entities, and private businesses) that collect and care for objects of cultural, artistic, scientific, or historical interest and make their collections or related exhibits available for public viewing. Also included are non-profit art galleries and university art galleries. Museums that exist only in cyberspace (i.e., virtual museums) are not included.
lm_description: Alnwick Castle in Alnwick is a multi-themed attraction offering castle tours, a Napoleonic Wars military museum, the Fusiliers Museum of Northumberland, British and Irish archaeology, and 19th-century vehicles. Armstrong’s Household and Farming Museum in North Charlton displays antique household and farming items in room settings, including a toy-filled nursery, World War II memorabilia, a milking parlour, washing room, agricultural tools, and local needlework. Aydon Castle in Aydon, run by English Heritage, is a 13th-century manor house castle. Bailiffgate Museum in Alnwick covers local history, culture, fishing, agriculture, railways, mining, and art. Bamburgh Castle in Bamburgh, still inhabited since Norman times, houses a museum on engines, technology, and the industrialist William Armstrong, 1st Baron Armstrong. Bellingham Heritage Centre in Bellingham explores local history, the Border Counties Railway, the Border Reivers, mining, farming, a recreated smithy, and rural-life photographs. Belsay Castle in Belsay, managed by English Heritage, is a 14th-century medieval castle, while Belsay Hall in Belsay is a 19th-century unfurnished country mansion with gardens and park, also under English Heritage. Berwick Gymnasium Gallery in Berwick-upon-Tweed, within Berwick Barracks, hosts contemporary art installations by Berwick Visual Arts. Berwick Museum & Art Gallery in Berwick-upon-Tweed, likewise in Berwick Barracks, presents fine art, Asian porcelain, historic glass, medieval Berwick and castle stories, local and social history, trades, mining, and fishing. Blyth Battery in Blyth, a military site, preserves World War I and II coastal-defence buildings and displays military and local history. Cherryburn in Mickley, National Trust property and birthplace of artist-ornithologist Thomas Bewick, exhibits his life and engravings. Chillingham Castle in Chillingham is a medieval castle with state rooms. Chesters Roman Fort in Walwick, English Heritage-run, is a preserved Roman fort on Hadrian’s Wall with an artifact museum. Corbridge Roman Site in Corbridge, also English Heritage, is a preserved Roman fort south of Hadrian’s Wall with artifacts. Cragside in Rothbury, National Trust site, is the 19th-century technologically innovative country home of Lord Armstrong. The Fusiliers Museum of Northumberland is located inside Alnwick Castle. George Stephenson’s Birthplace in Wylam, a National Trust 18th-century stone cottage, commemorates the rail pioneer with railway exhibits. The Grace Darling Museum in Bamburgh, operated by the RNLI, tells the story of Victorian heroine Grace Darling, who with her father rescued 13 people from the SS Forfarshire in 1838. Heatherslaw Mill in Etal is a 19th-century water-driven corn mill.

title: Michael Sheen performances
intro: Michael Sheen, OBE (born 5 February 1969), is a Welsh stage and screen actor. After training at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, Sheen made his professional debut in 1991, starring opposite Vanessa Redgrave in When She Danced at the Globe Theatre. He worked mainly in theatre throughout the 1990s and made notable stage appearances in Romeo and Juliet (1992), Don't Fool With Love (1993), Peer Gynt (1994), The Seagull (1995), The Homecoming (1997) and Henry V (1997). His performances in Amadeus at the Old Vic and Look Back in Anger at the National Theatre were nominated for Olivier Awards in 1998 and 1999, respectively. In the 2000s, while continuing to make sporadic stage appearances, Sheen became known primarily as a screen actor. In 2003, he was nominated for a third Olivier Award for his performance in Caligula at the Donmar Warehouse and had a breakthrough performance as the British politician Tony Blair in the television film The Deal. He received a BAFTA Award nomination in 2004 for his work in the ITV drama Dirty Filthy Love. In 2006, Sheen starred as the troubled comic actor Kenneth Williams in BBC Four's Fantabulosa! and came to the attention of an international audience when he reprised his role as Blair in The Queen. Both performances were BAFTA Award-nominated. Sheen received a fourth Olivier Award nomination in 2006 for portraying the broadcaster David Frost in Frost/Nixon at the Donmar Warehouse and he later revisited the role of Frost in the 2008 film adaptation of the play. In 2009, Sheen appeared in two fantasy films, Underworld: Rise of the Lycans and The Twilight Saga: New Moon, and starred as the outspoken football manager Brian Clough in The Damned United.
lm_description: Between 1993 and 1999 Michael Sheen voiced Claudio for the BBC’s 1993 Much Ado About Nothing, then narrated Naxos AudioBooks’ Crime and Punishment in 1994, the same year he appeared in BBC Radio 4’s Strangers on a Train and spoke Great Poets of the Romantic Age for Naxos. He continued as Naxos narrator for 1995’s The Idiot, The Picture of Dorian Gray and Dangerous Liaisons, playing Valmont in the latter, while on BBC Radio 4 he voiced Frank in Alaska and Jack in The Importance of Being Earnest. In 1996 he read The Old Testament and The Great Poets – John Keats for Naxos, followed by 1997 narrations of Poets of the Great War, Lady Windermere’s Fan as Lord Darlington, Romeo and Juliet as both Romeo and director, and The Great Poets – Samuel Taylor Coleridge, plus BBC Radio 4 roles as Gorse in The West Pier and narrator of A White Merc With Fins. He returned to Naxos in 1998 to narrate Walton’s Henry V and to BBC Radio 3 that year to play Paris in Troy, closing the decade by narrating the 1999 Naxos poetry anthology A Lovers Gift: From Him to Her.

title: 2010 FC Seoul season
intro: The 2010 season is FC Seoul's 28th season in the K League Classic.
lm_description: Kim Yong-Dae guarded the goal wearing the No. 1 shirt, while defenders Choi Hyo-Jin, Kim Jin-Kyu, Adilson and Hyun Young-Min, respectively numbered 2, 6, 8 and 13, formed the back line. Midfielders Choi Tae-Uk (33), Ha Dae-Sung (16), Djeparov (88) and Lee Seung-Yeoul (28) controlled the center of the park, and up front Jung Jo-Gook (9) and Dejan (10) led the attack for FC Seoul during the 2010 K League Classic campaign.

title: List of colleges and universities in Oregon
intro: This is a list of colleges and universities in the U.S. state of Oregon. Seven public universities, overseen by the Oregon Office of University Coordination, are operated by boards appointed by the governor, and seventeen community colleges are operated by locally elected boards. There are also numerous private degree-granting institutions. The oldest college is Willamette University, which was established 1842, and is the oldest university in the Western United States. The oldest community college is Southwestern Oregon Community College which was established in 1959 (Year conflicts with Institutions list below). The college has about 14,500 students (Enrollment conflicts with Institutions list below) which have access to the over 150 acres (61 ha) of campus. This list includes all schools that grant degrees at an associate level or higher, and are either accredited or in the process of accreditation by a recognized accrediting agency.
lm_description: Portland hosts the for-profit American College of Healthcare Sciences, founded 1978, enrolling 1,032 health-professions students, while the city’s Lutheran Concordia University, dating from 1905, educates 1,404 in master’s programs and Multnomah University, a 1936 Protestant religious school, counts 763. Salem counters with two Baptists: Corban University, established 1935, serving 754 master’s students, and Chemeketa Community College, opened 1970, teaching 9,228 associate-seekers. Public associates colleges dot the state: Pendleton’s Blue Mountain, 1962, enrolls 2,216; Bend’s Central Oregon, 1949, 4,048; Oregon City’s Clackamas, 1961, 6,902; Astoria’s Clatsop, 1958, 1,610; The Dalles’ Columbia Gorge, 1989, 831; Klamath Falls’ Klamath, 1996, 1,619; Eugene’s Lane, 1964, 9,110; Albany’s Linn-Benton, 1967, 5,391; Gresham’s Mt. Hood, 1965, 7,817. Newberg’s Quaker-founded George Fox University, 1891, is a 3,382-student research university, whereas Eugene’s tiny Gutenberg College, 1994 Protestant, enrolls only 48. McMinnville’s Linfield College, 1858 Baptist, and Portland’s Lewis & Clark, 1867, are liberal-arts colleges with 2,606 and 3,259 respectively. La Grande’s Eastern Oregon University, 1929, enrolls 3,338 master’s students, and St. Benedict’s Mount Angel Seminary, 1887 Catholic, educates 177.

title: List of Summer Olympics venues: L
intro: For the Summer Olympics, there were a total of 45 venues that started with the letter 'L'.
lm_description: La Romareda in Barcelona hosted 1992 Olympic football for 43,000 spectators, while Laakso outside Helsinki staged 1952 eventing riding for 12,500. Lagoa Rodrigo de Freitas welcomed Rio 2016 canoe sprint and rowing to 14,000 seats, and Lake Albano outside Rome did the same for 10,000 in 1960. Lake Casitas served Los Angeles 1984 canoe and rowing to 4,680, Lake Lanier carried Atlanta 1996 canoe sprint and rowing to 17,300, Lake Sagami held Tokyo 1964 canoe for 1,500, and Lake Wendouree hosted Melbourne 1956 canoe and rowing for 14,300. Lahti’s 82,000-capacity ground handled 1952 Helsinki football, and Lansdowne Park welcomed 30,000 for Montréal 1976 football. Beijing 2008 built three Laoshan venues: a 4,000-seat BMX circuit, a 2,000-seat mountain-bike course, and a 6,000-seat track velodrome. L’Aquila Communal Stadium held 9,285 for Rome 1960 football, while Lazio Pigeon Shooting Stand seated 2,000 for 1960 shotgun-trap events. Le Havre provided sailing courses for Paris 1900 and again in 1924, the latter listing 541. Le Stade Olympique Reims seated 420 for 1924 trap and running-target shooting, and Le Stand de Tir de Versailles offered 82 places for 1924 modern-pentathlon shooting plus 25 m rapid-fire pistol and running deer. Lee Valley White Water Centre carried 12,000 for London 2012 canoe slalom.

title: Minnesota Vikings draft history
intro: This page is a list of the Minnesota Vikings NFL Draft selections. The first draft the Vikings participated in was the 1961 NFL Draft, in which they made Tommy Mason of Tulane their first ever selection.
lm_description: Clinton Jones, a Michigan State running back, opened Minnesota’s 1967 draft haul as the second overall pick, followed at eighth overall by fellow Spartan Gene Washington, the first of three wide receivers selected. Notre Dame defensive tackle Alan Page arrived at fifteenth overall, while Oregon State’s Bob Grim came off the board twenty-eighth. Missouri wideout Earl Denny was the sixty-first choice, Minnesota’s own Ken Last the 115th, and South Carolina cornerback Bobby Bryant the 167th. California tight end John Beasley (197), Holy Cross guard Bill Morris (219), Nebraska running back Pete Tatman (244), Washington State defensive tackle Bob Trygstad (271), and Saint John’s guard Fred Cremer (296) rounded out the middle rounds. Tulsa defensive back Charles Hardt was taken 323rd, Howard Payne linebacker Jimmy Hargrove 348th, Eastern New Mexico defensive back Jimmy Shea 375th, Virginia Union’s Gene Beard 400th, and North Dakota State’s Todd Vandal 427th, closing the seventeen-round class.
to_index_text:
Minnesota Vikings draft history
This page is a list of the Minnesota Vikings NFL Draft selections. The first draft the Vikings participated in was the 1961 NFL Draft, in which they made Tommy Mason of Tulane their first ever selection.

Notre Dame defensive tackle Alan Page arrived at fifteenth overall, while Oregon State’s Bob Grim came off the board twenty-eighth. Missouri wideout Earl Denny was the sixty-first choice, Minnesota’s own Ken Last the 115th, and South Carolina cornerback Bobby Bryant the 167th. California tight end John Beasley (197), Holy Cross guard Bill Morris (219), Nebraska running back Pete Tatman (244), Washington State defensive tackle Bob Trygstad (271), and Saint John’s guard Fred Cremer (296) rounded out the middle rounds. Tulsa defensive back Charles Hardt was taken 323rd, Howard Payne linebacker Jimmy Hargrove 348th, Eastern New Mexico defensive back Jimmy Shea 375th, Virginia Union’s Gene Beard 400th, and North Dakota State’s Todd Vandal 427th, closing the seventeen-round class.

title: List of association football clubs in the Republic of Ireland
intro: Traditionally, association football clubs in the Republic of Ireland have been classified as either senior, intermediate or junior. These classifications effectively categorise clubs who compete in national, provincial and county leagues respectively.
lm_description: Bray Wanderers play at Carlisle Grounds in the seaside town of Bray, while Dundalk host matches at Oriel Park in Dundalk itself. Sporting Kilmore, based in Coolock, use Oscar Traynor Road as their home pitch, and Monaghan United occupy Gortakeegan in Monaghan. Peamount United B, from Newcastle in South Dublin, stage games at Greenogue, whereas Raheny United welcome opponents to St Anne’s Park in Raheny. St Francis call John Hyland Park in Baldonnel, Dublin, their home, and St Catherine’s take the field at Walkinstown Avenue, serving both Walkinstown and The Liberties areas of Dublin.

title: List of fictional rodents in literature
intro: This list of fictional rodents in literature is subsidiary to the list of fictional animals and covers all rodents appearing in printed works of literature including beavers, chipmunks, gophers, guinea pigs, marmots, prairie dogs, and porcupines plus the extinct prehistoric species (such as Rugosodon).
lm_description: Albert, the playful star of Eleanor May’s Mouse Math series, shares his adventures with sister Wanda, while Daniel Keyes’s Algernon is a laboratory mouse whose artificially boosted intelligence drives the tragedy of Flowers for Algernon. William Steig sends the seafaring mouse Amos into friendship with the whale Boris, and Eve Titus’s Anatole, a French mouse determined to clear his species’ name, first appeared in 1956. Katherine Holabird’s ballet-mad Angelina Mouseling twirls through mishaps alongside Alice, and Graham Oakley’s Arthur and Humphrey share church-yard escapades in Whortlethope with their feline ally Sampson. Robin Jarvis plunges Audrey Brown into Deptford’s sewers to battle an evil rat god, while Eve Titus also created Basil of Baker Street, the mouse detective who lives beneath Sherlock Holmes. Margery Sharp’s Bianca and Bernard belong to the Mouse Prisoner’s Aid Society, rescuing the distressed, and Julia Donaldson’s Big Bad Mouse terrifies predators with invented Gruffalo tales until the monster proves real. William Wise’s domestic explorer Christopher Mouse survives perilous travels, and Richard Peck’s Cranston family—Helena, Louise, Beatrice, Lamont, Vicky and Alice—navigate Secrets at Sea. Kate DiCamillo’s big-eared Despereaux Tilling, the sole survivor of his litter, is an outcast castle-mouse, while Douglas Adams’s Frankie and Benjy, hyper-intelligent mice, commissioned planet Earth. Edizioni Piemme’s jittery adventurer Geronimo Stilton chases emerald treasure, Beatrix Potter’s Hunca Munca and Tom Thumb wreck then repair a doll’s house, and Jane Breskin Zalben’s Jensen redecorates a museum with abstract art. Beatrix Potter also pairs the urbane Johnny Town-Mouse with country cousin Timmy Willie, each unnerved by the other’s home, while Brian Jacques’s Martin the Warrior escapes slavery, reclaims his father’s sword from Badrang the Tyrant, and saga-spans Mossflower and The Legend of Luke. Finally, Enid Blyton’s exiled Mary Mouse becomes maid to Sailor Doll in the dolls’ house.

title: Automotive industry in the United Kingdom
intro:
The automotive industry in the United Kingdom is now best known for premium and sports car marques including Aston Martin, Bentley, Caterham Cars, Daimler, Jaguar, Lagonda, Land Rover, Lister Cars, Lotus, McLaren, MG, Mini, Morgan and Rolls-Royce. Volume car manufacturers with a major presence in the UK include Honda, Nissan, Toyota and Vauxhall Motors (subsidiary of Opel, subsidiary of the French automotive company Groupe PSA). Commercial vehicle manufacturers active in the UK include Alexander Dennis, Ford, IBC Vehicles (owned by Groups PSA), Leyland Trucks (owned by Paccar) and London EV Company (owned by Geely). In 2018 the UK automotive manufacturing sector had a turnover of £82 billion, generated £18.6 billion in value to the UK economy and produced around 1.5 million passenger vehicles and 85,000 commercial vehicles. In that year around 168,000 people were directly employed in automotive manufacturing in the UK, with a further 823,000 people employed in automotive supply, retail and servicing. This declined to 147,000 including supply industry in 2014 (-18%)
The UK is a major centre for engine manufacturing and in 2018 around 2.71 million engines were produced in the country. The UK has a significant presence in auto racing and the UK motorsport industry currently employs around 38,500 people, comprises around 4,500 companies and has an annual turnover of around £6 billion. The origins of the UK automotive industry date back to the final years of the 19th century. By the 1950s the UK was the second-largest manufacturer of cars in the world (after the United States) and the largest exporter. However, in subsequent decades the industry experienced considerably lower growth than competitor nations such as France, Germany and Japan and by 2008 the UK was the 12th-largest producer of cars measured by volume. Since the early 1990s many British car marques have been acquired by foreign companies including BMW (Mini and Rolls-Royce), SAIC (MG), Tata (Jaguar and Land Rover) and Volkswagen Group (Bentley). Rights to many currently dormant marques, including Austin, Riley, Rover and Triumph, are also owned by foreign companies.
lm_description: AC Cars builds the AC MKVI at its West Norwood facility, while Alexander Dennis assembles Enviro buses and chassis in Falkirk and Guildford. Ariel hand-assembles 70 Atom sports cars annually at Crewkerne, and Ascari Cars produces the Ecosse and A10 at Banbury. Aston Martin Lagonda's Gaydon plant turned out 5,323 One-77, Cygnet, DB9, DBS, Vantage, Virage, Vanquish and Rapide models in 2010. Bentley Motors, owned by Germany's Volkswagen Group, manufactures Azure, Brooklands Coupé, Continental Flying Spur, Continental GT and Mulsanne models at Crewe, producing 10,014 vehicles. Briggs Automotive Company builds the BAC Mono in Liverpool, and Bristol Cars assembles Blenheim, Fighter and Blenheim Speedster models at Filton. Caterham Cars produced 435 R400 and CSR260 vehicles at Dartford in 2003. Dennis Eagle, owned by Spain's Ros Roca SA, manufactures Duo, One Pass and Beta 2 models at Warwick. Ginetta Cars, under LNT Automotive, builds G40, G50, G55 and G60 models at Leeds. GM Manufacturing Luton, part of Germany's Adam Opel AG, produces 77,836 Opel/Vauxhall Vivaro, Renault Trafic and Nissan Primastar vehicles. Honda of the UK Manufacturing, owned by Japan's Honda Motor Company, produced 134,146 CR-V, Jazz, Civic and Civic Type-R vehicles at Swindon in 2016. Tata Motors of India operates Jaguar Land Rover's Castle Bromwich, Halewood and Solihull plants, which together produced 234,647 vehicles including XF, XJ, XK, F-Type, Discovery Sport, Evoque, Defender, Discovery 4, Range Rover Sport and Range Rover models. Leyland Trucks, owned by America's Paccar, manufactures 17,478 DAF CF, LF and XF trucks at Leyland. LEVC, owned by China's Geely, produced 2,346 TX taxis at Coventry in 2003, while Lotus Cars, also Geely-owned, builds Elise, Exige and Evora models at Hethel, producing 2,935 vehicles combined with GM.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Wrangell–St. Elias National Park and Preserve
intro: N/A
lm_description: The Bremner Historic Mining District, listed on June 15, 2000, lies along Golconda Creek roughly 47 miles southeast of Chitina. Chisana’s two entries—the Historic District added November 29, 1985, and the adjoining Historic Mining Landscape registered May 14, 1998—sit near the airstrip at Chisana and at an undisclosed Northway location respectively. Kansky’s, entered May 16, 1997, stands at mile 42 on Nabesna Road two miles north of the old Nabesna Mine. The Kennecott Mines, recorded July 12, 1978, occupy the east side of Kennicott Glacier about 6½ miles north of McCarthy. In McCarthy itself, the General Store gained recognition January 31, 1978, on the corner of Kennicott Avenue and Skolai Street, while the Power Plant followed on April 26, 1979, beside McCarthy Creek off Shushanna Avenue. The Nabesna Gold Mine Historic District, enrolled May 25, 1979, rests at the base of White Mountain at the road’s end. Finally, the Valdez Trail–Copper Bluff Segment, listed February 12, 1998, parallels the Richardson Highway at milepost 106.5 near Copper City.

title: 2005 Campeonato Paulista
intro: The 2005 Campeonato Paulista de Futebol Profissional da Primeira Divisão - Série A1 was the 104th season of São Paulo's top professional football league. The competition began on 19 January and ended on 17 April. São Paulo were the champions for the 21st time in history.
lm_description: América arrived from São José do Rio Preto to contest the 2005 Campeonato Paulista after finishing 12th the previous year, while Atlético Sorocaba, 15th in 2004, hoped to climb from their Sorocaba base. Corinthians, based in São Paulo, carried the weight of a disappointing 16th-place campaign, as did Guarani from Campinas, who had ended 2004 in 17th. Inter de Limeira earned promotion as 2004 Série A2 champions, and Ituano, 14th last season, returned from Itu. Marília, 10th in 2004, and Mogi Mirim, 18th, both aimed higher, while Palmeiras, fourth in 2004, sought the title from their São Paulo home. Paulista, runners-up in 2004, came from Jundiaí with title ambitions. Ponte Preta, seventh last year, and Portuguesa, 13th, both represented Campinas and São Paulo respectively, as Portuguesa Santista, sixth in 2004, arrived from Santos. Rio Branco, 11th the prior season, hailed from Americana, while Santo André, ninth in 2004, and Santos, third, both targeted the trophy. São Caetano entered as reigning 2004 champions, São Paulo, fifth last year, chased a record 21st crown, União Barbarense, eighth in 2004, came from Santa Bárbara d'Oeste, and União São João, 19th the previous season, arrived from Araras hoping to survive.

title: 2005 NFL Draft
intro:
The 2005 NFL draft was the procedure by which National Football League teams selected amateur college football players. It is officially known as the NFL Annual Player Selection Meeting. The draft was held April 23-24, 2005. The league also held a supplemental draft that year, which was held after the regular draft but before the regular season. The draft took place at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York City, and was televised for the 26th consecutive year on ESPN and ESPN2. The NFL draft had been held at Madison Square Garden since 1995, but was moved to the Javits Center in 2005. The draft featured the San Francisco 49ers selecting first overall Alex Smith from the
University of Utah. The main storyline going into the draft was the mystery surrounding when Quarterback Aaron Rodgers would be drafted, as well as his subsequent fall to the Packers. Compensatory selections were distributed amongst fourteen teams, with the Philadelphia Eagles and the St. Louis Rams garnering the most with four picks each. Three of the first five picks were running backs, an NFL draft first. The 255 players chosen in the draft were composed of:
lm_description: Arizona drafted Penn State tight end John Bronson, Lehigh tight end Adam Bergen, Notre Dame wideout Carlyle Holiday and BYU safety Aaron Francisco. Atlanta chose Western Washington punter Michael Koenen. Wisconsin safety Jim Leonhard went to Buffalo, California linebacker Lorenzo Alexander to Carolina, and San Jose State receiver Rashied Davis to Chicago. Cleveland added Kent State returner Josh Cribbs and Toledo receiver Lance Moore. Dallas selected Maryland long snapper Jon Condo and Nevada guard Harvey Dahl. Denver plucked Oregon State cornerback Brandon Browner and Colorado State tackle Erik Pears. Green Bay took Michigan linebacker Roy Manning, while Jacksonville drafted Southeast Missouri State guard Dan Connolly. Miami stocked up with Miami quarterback Brock Berlin, BYU long snapper John Denney, Kent State safety Abram Elam and UCF safety Atari Bigby.

title: List of solar thermal power stations
intro: This is a list of the largest facilities generating electricity through the use of solar thermal power, specifically concentrated solar power.
lm_description: The Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum Solar Park Phase IV in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, leads the list with 700 MW of electrical capacity, combining parabolic trough and solar tower technologies. Golmud CSP, a 200 MW power tower installation, operates in Golmud, Qinghai province, China. Chile’s Cerro Dominador Solar Thermal Plant (Atacama 1) near María Elena in Antofagasta delivers 110 MW via a solar power tower. China dominates the smaller-capacity segment: Urat Middle Banner CSP in Inner Mongolia generates 100 MW with parabolic troughs, while five 50 MW plants—Erdos Solar Power Plant in Hanggin Banner, Dacheng Dunhuang CSP using Fresnel reflectors in Gansu, Gansu Akesai CSP and Rayspower Yumen CSP both employing parabolic troughs, and Hami CSP with a power tower in Xinjiang—each contribute 50 MW. Luneng Haixi CSP in Haixi Zhou, Qinghai Sheng, also produces 50 MW via a power tower, and Yumen CSP in Gansu adds another 50 MW using an innovative beam-down tower design.

title: List of current members of the Rajya Sabha
intro: The Rajya Sabha or Council of States is the upper house of the Parliament of India. Membership is limited to 250 members, and the present Rajya Sabha has 245 members. 233 members are elected by the Vidhan Sabha members and 12 are nominated by the President for their contributions to art, literature, science, and social services. Members sits for six years term, with one-third of the members retiring every two years. The nominated and state-wise list given below lists the number of seats against each category (nominated and state-wise list) and the number of vacant seats (if any).
lm_description: Raghunath Mohapatra, Sonal Mansingh, Rakesh Sinha and Ram Shakal were all nominated on 14 July 2018 as BJP voices in art, literature and social work, each holding the seat until 13 July 2024. Sambhaji Raje, carrying the BJP banner for social work, began his term earlier, on 13 June 2016, and will retire on 3 May 2022. Roopa Ganguly, Suresh Gopi and Subramanian Swamy, all BJP members, entered the house on 25 April 2016 for contributions to art and economics, with their terms ending on 24 April 2022. Narendra Jadhav, Mary Kom and Swapan Dasgupta, though nominated without party labels, share the same 25 April 2016 start and 24 April 2022 retirement dates, representing economics, sport and journalism respectively. K. T. S. Tulsi, nominated for law, is the senior-most, appointed on 25 February 2014 and retiring on 24 February 2020.

title: Convoy ON 67
intro: Convoy ON 67 was a trade convoy of merchant ships during the Second World War. It was the 67th of the numbered series of ON convoys Outbound from the British Isles to North America. The ships departed from Liverpool on 14 February 1942 with convoy rescue ship Toward, and were escorted to the Mid-Ocean Meeting Point by escort group B4.
lm_description: Convoy ON 67, which sailed from Liverpool on 14 February 1942, comprised twenty merchant vessels. The 7,984-GRT British freighter Adellen, built in 1930, was torpedoed and sunk by U-155 on 22 February, while the 8,009-GRT British Anadara, launched in 1935, succumbed to combined fire from U-558 and U-587 two days later. Norway’s 8,325-GRT Belinda, completed in 1939, continued safely toward the West Indies, as did the 4,847-GRT British Consuelo, bound for New York City and already a veteran of convoy HX 228. Cristales, a 5,389-GRT British ship from 1926, carried Convoy Vice-Commodore Captain R H R MacKay OBE toward Halifax but collided on 24 February. Daghestan and Empire Spray, both 1941-built CAM ships of 7,248 and 7,242 GRT respectively, also headed for Halifax, while the Soviet 7,363-GRT Dekabrist, dating from 1903, steamed for New York. The 8,146-GRT British Diloma, damaged by U-158, nevertheless reached Halifax, and the 8,142-GRT Dolabella and 8,036-GRT Dromus both shaped course for Curaçao. Empire Druid, Empire Steel, Empire, and Empire Celt—modern 1941 British ships of 9,813, 8,138, 8,134, and 8,032 GRT—were routed to Port Arthur, Baton Rouge, and Port Arthur respectively; Empire Celt was sunk by U-158 on 24 February. That same day, the Norwegian 9,432-GRT Eidanger and 9,551-GRT Finnanger, both built in the late 1930s, were also sunk by U-558. The 6,409-GRT Norwegian Glittre, bound for Aruba, survived only to be lost a year later in convoy ON 166, while the 3,071-GRT British Gloucester City, launched in 1919, made for Philadelphia, and the 6,578-GRT Norwegian Hamlet joined the convoy from Iceland on 19 February.

The 6,409-GRT Norwegian Glittre, bound for Aruba, survived only to be lost a year later in convoy ON 166, while the 3,071-GRT British Gloucester City, launched in 1919, made for Philadelphia, and the 6,578-GRT Norwegian Hamlet joined the convoy from Iceland on 19 February.

title: Reginald VelJohnson
intro: Reginald VelJohnson (born Reginald Vel Johnson; August 16, 1952) is an American actor. He is best known for playing policeman characters such as Carl Winslow on the sitcom Family Matters, which ran from 1989 to 1998, and LAPD Sgt. Al Powell in the films Die Hard and Die Hard 2.
lm_description: Reginald VelJohnson first appeared on television in 1985 as Harmon Hunter in The Equalizer episode “Lady Cop,” returned to the series in 1986 as Arthur Williams for “Dead Drop,” and again in 1988 for “Sea of Fire.” In 1988 he played The Santa Thief in the 227 Christmas episode “The Night They Arrested Santa Claus,” then introduced Carl Winslow on Perfect Strangers in the 1989 episode “Crimebusters,” a role he carried through 215 episodes of Family Matters from 1989 to 1998. He voiced Dad in the 1994 television movie A Cool Like That Christmas, portrayed Det. Bob Hymes in the 1994 television movie One of Her Own, and appeared as Ed Conroy in the 1996 television movie Deadly Pursuits. VelJohnson checked in as a Hotel Guest for the 1992 Tales from the Crypt episode “Werewolf Concerto,” suited up as Santa for the 1993 Dream On episode “Silent Night, Holy Cow,” and played Dr. David Sinclair in the 1998 Diagnosis: Murder episode “The Last Resort.” From 1999 onward he turned up as Rev. Bennett on The Hughleys episode “Daddy’s Going to Hell,” Dr. David Bryant on Twice in a Lifetime episode “Whistle Blower,” Maurice Beaumont on The Fugitive episode “Lagniappe,” Dr. Phillip Kane across two 2002 CSI: Crime Scene Investigation episodes, Mr. Holden on Crossing Jordan episode “Someone to Count On,” Dr. Kaplan on Will & Grace episode “It’s the Gay Pumpkin, Charlie Brown,” Sterling Oglevee on The Parkers episode “A Sterling Relationship,” Dikembe the Ambassador on That’s So Raven episode “The Royal Treatment,” Danny Small on Ghost Whisperer episode “Undead Comic,” and Rev. Everett on Eve episode “Oh, Brother.”

title: Taniec z Gwiazdami (season 12)
intro: The 12th season of Taniec z Gwiazdami, the Polish edition of Dancing With the Stars, started on 5 September 2010 and ended on 28 November 2010. It was broadcast by TVN. Katarzyna Skrzynecka and Piotr Gąsowski continued as the hosts, and the judges were: Iwona Szymańska-Pavlović, Zbigniew Wodecki, Beata Tyszkiewicz and Piotr Galiński.
lm_description: Monika Pyrek and Patricia Kazadi both peaked at 40 in the Cha-Cha-Cha, while Dorota Zawadzka bottomed out at 24. Edyta Górniak claimed the Waltz ceiling of 40 and Marcin Kwaśny its floor of 28. Patricia Kazadi’s Quickstep hit 40, leaving Maria Niklińska on 27. Paweł Staliński, Patricia Kazadi and Edyta Górniak all maxed the Rumba at 40; Anna Kalata managed only 20. Edyta Górniak’s Jive reached 39, with Robert Korzeniowski at 23. Patricia Kazadi, Maria Niklińska and Monika Pyrek all scored 40 in the Tango, whereas Marcin Kwaśny scraped 19. Patricia Kazadi dominated Foxtrot with 40, Andrzej Gołota lagged on 25. Paso Doble saw Patricia Kazadi and Paweł Staliński at 40, Anna Kalata again on 20. Maria Niklińska and Edyta Górniak shared 40 in the Samba, Dorota Zawadzka 24. Viennese Waltz perfection came from Edyta Górniak, Paweł Staliński and Monika Pyrek at 40, Andrzej Gołota 25. Patricia Kazadi’s Salsa earned 40, Gołota 22. Maria Niklińska’s American Smooth Waltz scored 39, Dorota Zawadzka 18. Andrzej Deskur led the American Smooth Quickstep with 28. Paweł Staliński topped American Smooth Foxtrot on 37. Argentine Tango saw Paweł Staliński, Monika Pyrek and Edyta Górniak all at 40. Freestyle ended with Paweł Staliński and Monika Pyrek on 40.

title: List of towns in India by population
intro: The entire work of this article is based on Census of India, 2011, conducted by the Office of the Registrar General and Census Commissioner, under Ministry of Home Affairs (India), Government of India.
lm_description: Wadgaon Road, a census town in Maharashtra, counted 40,884 residents in 2011, while nearby Wai, a municipal council, held 36,025 and Wani, also a municipal council, reached 58,840; Warora, another Maharashtrian municipal council, totaled 46,532, dwarfing Warud’s 6,386. Across Gujarat, Wadhwan municipality housed 75,755 people and Wankaner municipality 43,881. Karnataka’s Wadi, governed by a town municipal council, had 37,988 inhabitants. In Telangana, Wanaparthy municipality recorded 60,949. Madhya Pradesh’s Wara Seoni municipality contained 25,103, whereas Uttar Pradesh’s Warhapur nagar panchayat held 23,456 and Bihar’s Warisaliganj nagar panchayat 34,056. Farther northeast, Nagaland’s Wokha town committee comprised 35,004. Maharashtra’s Washim municipal council, largest among these, reached 78,387.
to_index_text:
List of towns in India by population
The entire work of this article is based on Census of India, 2011, conducted by the Office of the Registrar General and Census Commissioner, under Ministry of Home Affairs (India), Government of India.
Wadgaon Road, a census town in Maharashtra, counted 40,884 residents in 2011, while nearby Wai, a municipal council, held 36,025 and Wani, also a municipal council, reached 58,840; Warora, another Maharashtrian municipal council, totaled 46,532, dwarfing Warud’s 6,386. Across Gujarat, Wadhwan municipality housed 75,755 people and Wankaner municipality 43,881. Karnataka’s Wadi, governed by a town municipal council, had 37,988 inhabitants. In Telangana, Wanaparthy municipality recorded 60,949. Madhya Pradesh’s Wara Seoni municipality contained 25,103, whereas Uttar Pradesh’s Warhapur nagar panchayat held 23,456 and Bihar’s Warisaliganj nagar panchayat 34,056. Farther northeast, Nagaland’s Wokha town committee comprised 35,004. Maharashtra’s Washim municipal council, largest among these, reached 78,387.

title: Planet Snoopy
intro: Planet Snoopy is a Peanuts themed area for children at several Cedar Fair Entertainment Company amusement parks.
lm_description: Cedar Point welcomed Planet Snoopy on 12 May 2008, replacing Peanuts Playground with eight kid-sized rides. California’s Great America followed on 28 March 2010, swapping both Nickelodeon Central and, five years later, KidZville for a fifteen-ride Peanuts zone. Canada’s Wonderland opened its fourteen-ride version on 1 May 2010, simultaneously retiring Nickelodeon Central and The Happy Land of Hanna-Barbera. Kings Dominion launched twenty attractions on 2 April 2010 after phasing out Nickelodeon Central that year and KidZville in 2013, while Kings Island debuted nineteen rides on 17 April 2010 in place of Nickelodeon Universe. Dorney Park & Wildwater Kingdom unveiled sixteen attractions on 4 May 2011 on the former Camp Snoopy site, Valleyfair introduced seventeen rides on 14 May 2011 after removing KidWorks, and Worlds of Fun presented seventeen attractions on 16 April 2011, likewise replacing Camp Snoopy.

title: Scottish Junior Football North Super League
intro: The Scottish Junior Football North Super League (also known as the McBookie.com North Superleague for sponsorship reasons) is the highest division of the North Region of the Scottish Junior Football Association. It was established in 2001 and since 2007, the league champions have qualified for the following season's Scottish Cup.
lm_description: Banks O’ Dee topped the 2017-18 Scottish Junior Football North Super League from their Spain Park ground in Aberdeen under the joint charge of Tommy Forbes and Sandy McNaughton, while fellow Aberdeen side Aberdeen East End earned promotion as North Division One (East) winners and play at New Advocates Park with Lee Youngson as manager. Hermes finished second at Uniconn Park in Bridge of Don where Neil Dawson oversees affairs, and Dyce Juniors came third from Ian Mair Parl under the co-management of Mike McKenzie and Murray Rattray. Culter ended fourth at Crombie Park in Peterculter with Duncan Ord, Ellon United fifth at The Meadows with Steven Main, and Maud sixth at Maud Pleasure Park led by Chris Allsop and Mike Cramp. Montrose Roselea took seventh at Broomfield Park under James Collier, Dufftown eighth at Westburn Park with Michael Morrison, and Stonehaven ninth at Glenury Park with Ian Esslemont. Hall Russell United finished tenth at Denmore Park in Bridge of Don with John Carroll, Colony Park eleventh at Colony Park in Inverurie with Richard Davidson, and Bridge of Don Thistle twelfth at Gallowshill Park in Newburgh under Lewis Muirhead. Nairn St. Ninian, managed by Mike Hendry at Showfield Park, join as North Division One (West) champions.

title: List of lunar features
intro: The surface of the Moon has many features, including mountains and valleys, craters, and maria - wide flat areas that look like seas from a distance but are probably solidified molten rock. Some of these features are listed.
lm_description: Dorsum Buckland stretches 380 km across the Moon, memorializing the English geologist William Buckland (1784-1856), while the 268 km Dorsum Oppel honors German paleontologist Albert Oppel (1831-1865). Dorsum Von Cotta, 199 km long, bears the name of Carl Bernard von Cotta (1808-1879). Dorsum Heim, 148 km across, commemorates Swiss geologist Albert Heim (1849-1937), and the 121 km Dorsum Grabau remembers American geologist Amadeus William Grabau (1870-1946). Dorsum Scilla, 108 km long, is named for Italian scientist Agostino Scilla (1639-1700), while Dorsum Arduino, 107 km, honors Italian geologist Giovanni Arduino (1714-1795). Dorsum Azara, 105 km, memorializes Spanish naturalist Félix Manuel de Azara (1746-1811). Dorsum Cloos, 100 km, bears the name of German geologist Hans Cloos (1885-1951). Dorsum Bucher and Dorsum Termier, each 90 km, honor Walter Hermann Bucher (1889-1965) and Pierre-Marie Termier (1859-1930) respectively. Dorsum Cayeux, 84 km, remembers French geologist Lucien Cayeux (1864-1944), while Dorsum Cushman, 80 km, is named for American geologist Joseph Augustine Cushman (1881-1949). Dorsum Gast, 60 km, commemorates Paul Werner Gast (1930-1973), as does Dorsum Higazy for Egyptian geologist Riad Higazy (1919-1967). Dorsum Nicol and Dorsum Niggli, each 50 km, honor William Nicol (1768-1851) and Paul Niggli (1888-1953). Dorsum Guettard, 40 km, remembers Jean-Etienne Guettard (1715-1786), while Dorsum Owen, 50 km, is named for George Owen (1552-1613). Dorsum Thera, only 7 km, uniquely takes its name from a Greek feminine name.

title: List of public corporations by market capitalization
intro: The following is a list of publicly traded companies having the greatest market capitalization. This list is primarily based on the Financial Times Global 500. Market capitalization is calculated from the share price (as recorded on selected day) multiplied by the number of outstanding shares. Figures are converted into USD millions (using rate from selected day) to allow for comparison. Only companies with free float at least 15% are included, value of unlisted stock classes is excluded. Investment companies are not included in the list.
lm_description: General Electric leads the ranking with a market capitalization of 372,089 million USD, operating as a U.S.-based conglomerate. Microsoft follows in second place at 326,639 million USD, representing the software industry from its U.S. headquarters. Exxon Mobil ranks third with 299,820 million USD, operating in oil and gas from the United States. Wal-Mart holds fourth place at 273,220 million USD as a U.S. retail giant. Citigroup stands fifth at 255,299 million USD, operating in banking from the United States. Pfizer ranks sixth with 249,021 million USD in healthcare, based in the United States. Intel Corporation places seventh at 203,838 million USD in computer hardware, headquartered in the United States. BP breaks the U.S. dominance by ranking eighth at 200,794 million USD in oil and gas, headquartered in the United Kingdom. Johnson & Johnson ranks ninth at 197,912 million USD in healthcare, based in the United States. Royal Dutch Shell completes the top ten at 189,913 million USD in oil and gas, headquartered in the Netherlands.

title: 2013 Campeonato Pernambucano
intro: The 2013 Campeonato Pernambucano, named Pernambucano Coca-Cola 2013 - Série A1 for sponsorship reasons, was the 99th edition of the state championship of Pernambuco. With the return of Copa do Nordeste in 2013 and the participation of three teams from the state (Santa Cruz, Sport and Salgueiro), the formula of this edition was not the same as the previous championship. The competition is started on January 20 and concluded on May 19. Santa Cruz won their 27th championship, with Sport as runner-up. Petrolina and Belo Jardim were relegated to the second division of Campeonato Pernambucano.
lm_description: Defending champion Santa Cruz entered the 2013 Pernambucano as 26-time winners from Recife and top-seeded holders playing at the 60,040-seat Arruda, while city rivals Sport, 39-time champions last crowned in 2010 and fresh off a 2012 runner-up finish, staged matches at Ilha do Retiro for 32,983 fans. Náutico, fourth in 2012, brought 21 titles (most recently 2004) to Aflitos, a 22,856-capacity Recife ground. Salgueiro, third the previous year, hosted at Cornélio de Barros (10,240), and Petrolina, fifth in 2012, used Paulo de Souza Coelho (5,000). Caruaru supplied two clubs: Central, tenth in 2012, and Atlético do Porto, seventh, both sharing 19,548-seat Lacerdão. Promoted sides Chã Grande, 2012 Série A2 champions, and Pesqueira, that division’s runners-up, stepped up to Barbosão (4,000) and Joaquim José de Brito (3,500) respectively. Serra Talhada (ninth), Ypiranga of Santa Cruz (sixth) and Belo Jardim (eighth) rounded out the field at Nildo Pereira, Limeirão and Mendonção/SESC, each holding 5,000 or fewer; none of these clubs had ever lifted the trophy.

title: List of Indian states and territories by highest point
intro: This is the alphabetical list of the highest points of the Indian states and union territories.
lm_description: Saddle Peak rises 732 m (2,402 ft) on North Andaman Island, making it the loftiest summit in the Andaman & Nicobar Islands. Chandigarh’s highest ground is an unnamed 383 m (1,257 ft) point within its Capital Area, while neighbouring Dadra and Nagar Haveli tops out at 424 m (1,391 ft) on an unnamed hill near Khanvel. Diu Island’s unnamed highpoint reaches only 30 m (98 ft), matching the 30 m (98 ft) elevation of Puducherry’s Les Montagnes Rouges in the Red Hills. Delhi’s Ridge culminates at 319 m (1,047 ft) inside Fort Tughlaqabad. Far to the north, Nun Peak towers at 7,135 m (23,409 ft) in Jammu & Kashmir’s Western Himalayas, yet Ladakh’s Saltoro Kangri in the Karakoram Range surpasses it at 7,742 m (25,400 ft). Lakshadweep’s low coral terrain peaks at a mere 15 m (49 ft) on Agatti Island.

title: 2014 in sports
intro: 2014 in sports describes the year's events in world sport.
lm_description: Cruz Azul captured the 2013-14 CONCACAF Champions League crown after a final played 6 August 2013. Lexi Thompson won the 2014 Kraft Nabisco Championship on 3-6 April, while Sébastien Ogier and co-driver Julien Ingrassia steered their Volkswagen to victory in the Rally de Portugal the same weekend. Pineau de Re, ridden by Leighton Aspell and trained by Richard Newland, took the 5 April Grand National. Javier Gómez and Jodie Stimpson opened the ITU World Triathlon Series with wins in Auckland on 5-6 April. Estonia earned promotion to Division I-B and Israel dropped to Division II-B as Spain rose to Division II-A and Turkey fell to Division III after the IIHF World Championship Division II tournament held 5-15 April. Lewis Hamilton claimed the 6 April Bahrain Grand Prix for Mercedes, and Fabian Cancellara won the Tour of Flanders for Trek Factory Racing that day. Bulgaria moved up to Division II-B after the IIHF Division III event 6-12 April, while the Czech women advanced to the Elite Division and Slovakia slid to Division I-B, Latvia climbed to Division I-A and Kazakhstan descended to Division II-A during the Women’s World Championship Division I. Italy’s women rose to Division I-B and Australia dropped to Division II-B from Division II-A. Alberto Contador dominated the Tour of the Basque Country 7-12 April. Bubba Watson slipped on the green jacket after the 10-13 April Masters. The United States topped the AIBA Youth World Boxing Championships with three titles. Igor Stefanovski won Category I and Simone Faggioli Category II in the FIA European Hill Climb Championship season that ran until 21 September. Wilson Kipsang Kiprotich and Edna Kiplagat struck London Marathon glory on 13 April, the same day Niki Terpstra conquered Paris-Roubaix for Omega Pharma-Quick-Step. Marc Márquez, Maverick Viñales and Jack Miller won MotoGP, Moto2 and Moto3 respectively at the Motorcycle Grand Prix of the Americas, while José María López and Sébastien Loeb shared Citroën one-two in the WTCC Race of Morocco. Ramy Ashour ruled the El Gouna International squash event 13-18 April.

Cruz Azul captured the 2013-14 CONCACAF Champions League crown after a final played 6 August 2013. Lexi Thompson won the 2014 Kraft Nabisco Championship on 3-6 April, while Sébastien Ogier and co-driver Julien Ingrassia steered their Volkswagen to victory in the Rally de Portugal the same weekend. Pineau de Re, ridden by Leighton Aspell and trained by Richard Newland, took the 5 April Grand National. Javier Gómez and Jodie Stimpson opened the ITU World Triathlon Series with wins in Auckland on 5-6 April. Estonia earned promotion to Division I-B and Israel dropped to Division II-B as Spain rose to Division II-A and Turkey fell to Division III after the IIHF World Championship Division II tournament held 5-15 April. Lewis Hamilton claimed the 6 April Bahrain Grand Prix for Mercedes, and Fabian Cancellara won the Tour of Flanders for Trek Factory Racing that day. Bulgaria moved up to Division II-B after the IIHF Division III event 6-12 April, while the Czech women advanced to the Elite Division and Slovakia slid to Division I-B, Latvia climbed to Division I-A and Kazakhstan descended to Division II-A during the Women’s World Championship Division I. Italy’s women rose to Division I-B and Australia dropped to Division II-B from Division II-A. Alberto Contador dominated the Tour of the Basque Country 7-12 April. Bubba Watson slipped on the green jacket after the 10-13 April Masters. The United States topped the AIBA Youth World Boxing Championships with three titles. Igor Stefanovski won Category I and Simone Faggioli Category II in the FIA European Hill Climb Championship season that ran until 21 September. Wilson Kipsang Kiprotich and Edna Kiplagat struck London Marathon glory on 13 April, the same day Niki Terpstra conquered Paris-Roubaix for Omega Pharma-Quick-Step. Marc Márquez, Maverick Viñales and Jack Miller won MotoGP, Moto2 and Moto3 respectively at the Motorcycle Grand Prix of the Americas, while José María López and Sébastien Loeb shared Citroën one-two in the WTCC Race of Morocco. Ramy Ashour ruled the El Gouna International squash event 13-18 April.

title: Dancing with the Stars (South Korean season 3)
intro: Dancing with the Stars: Season 3 (Korean: 댄싱 위드 더 스타3) was the third season of the Korean TV show based on the British television series Strictly Come Dancing. The hosts were Lee Deok-hwa and Kim Gyu-ri.
lm_description: Fei dominated the season, topping five dances: she scored 28 for both Samba and Paso Doble, 27 for Jive, 26 for Rumba, 22 for Quickstep and a season-high 29 for Cha-cha-cha. Lee Jong-won opened with a 21-point Swing but later sank to 19 for Samba and 21 for Tango. Nam Bo-ra peaked at 22 in Viennese Waltz yet bottom-scored 19 in Jive, Tango and Paso Doble. Kim Wan-sun’s 25-point Tango stood as that dance’s best, while Seungho’s 22-point Waltz earned top marks before he slipped to 19 in Viennese Waltz. Lee Eun-gyeol claimed Salsa with 24 and shared the 29-point Latin-based Freestyle spotlight with Fei, also posting 26 for Fusion. Hye Park’s 20-point Foxtrot was best in that style, leaving her at 19 for Rumba. Woo Ji-Won managed 19 in Jive and a low 17 in Quickstep. Kim Dae-ho repeatedly landed at the bottom—18 in Foxtrot, 20 in Cha-cha-cha, 21 in Tango and Fusion—while Oh Mi-hee scored 19 for both Waltz and Cha-cha-cha, Jeanette Lee hit 18 in Salsa, and Kim Kyung-ho ended with 19 in Jive and 26 in Latin-based Freestyle.

Fei dominated the season, topping five dances: she scored 28 for both Samba and Paso Doble, 27 for Jive, 26 for Rumba, 22 for Quickstep and a season-high 29 for Cha-cha-cha. title: Southwest Division (NBA)
intro: The Southwest Division is one of the three divisions in the Western Conference of the National Basketball Association (NBA). The division is located in the South Central United States and consists of five teams, the Dallas Mavericks, the Houston Rockets, the Memphis Grizzlies, the New Orleans Pelicans and the San Antonio Spurs. Three of the teams, the Mavericks, Rockets, and Spurs, are based in Texas. Consisting of some of the most historically competitive teams in the NBA's Western Conference, the division was created at the start of the 2004-05 season, when the league expanded from 29 to 30 teams with the addition of the Charlotte Bobcats. The league realigned itself into three divisions in each conference. The Southwest Division began with five inaugural members, the Mavericks, the Rockets, the Grizzlies, the Hornets (now Pelicans) and the Spurs. The Mavericks, the Rockets, the Grizzlies and the Spurs joined from the now-defunct Midwest Division, while the Pelicans joined from the Central Division. The Spurs have been dominant since the division's inaugural season, having won the most Southwest Division titles with nine. The Mavericks and Rockets have won two titles each, and the Pelicans have won one title. The Grizzlies have never won the Southwest Division title. Four NBA champions came from the Southwest Division. The Spurs won the NBA championship in 2005, 2007 and 2014, while the Mavericks won in 2011.
lm_description: In 2004-05 the San Antonio Spurs claimed the division with a 59-23 (.720) mark and went on to win the NBA Finals. They repeated as division kings the next year at 63-19 (.768) but fell in the Conference Semifinals. Dallas seized the 2006-07 crown behind a blistering 67-15 (.817) record yet were stunned in the First Round. New Orleans, still the Hornets, took the 2007-08 title at 56-26 (.683) before bowing out in the Conference Semifinals. San Antonio returned to the top in 2008-09 with a 54-28 (.659) ledger but lost in the opening playoff round, and again in 2010-11 at 61-21 (.744) with the same early exit. Dallas regained the division in 2009-10 at 55-27 (.671) yet could not survive the First Round. The Spurs rattled off three straight division wins: 2011-12 at 50-16 (.758) before a Conference Finals loss, 2012-13 at 58-24 (.707) before a Finals defeat, and 2013-14 at 62-20 (.756) before capturing another NBA title. Houston broke through in 2014-15 at 56-26 (.683) and pushed to the Conference Finals. San Antonio answered with 67-15 (.817) in 2015-16 and 61-21 (.744) in 2016-17, exiting in the Semifinals and Conference Finals respectively. Houston closed the span with back-to-back crowns: 65-17 (.793) in 2017-18 and 53-29 (.793) in 2018-19, both seasons ending in the Conference Finals and Semifinals.

title: Cebu Schools Athletic Foundation, Inc.
intro: The Cebu Schools Athletic Foundation, Inc. (CESAFI) is a sports association of 12 schools, colleges and universities in Cebu, Philippines. The CESAFI was established in 2001.
lm_description: Cebu Eastern College, founded in 1915, fields the Dragons from its Cebu City campus as a private, non-sectarian CESAFI member. Cebu Institute of Technology–University, established 1946, sends the Wildkittens into competition under the same private, non-sectarian banner. Don Bosco Technology Center, a Salesian institution born in 1954, enters the Baby Greywolves from Cebu City. Across the Mandaue border, Sacred Heart School–Ateneo de Cebu, Jesuit since 1955, flies the Magis Eagles colors. Southwestern University PHINMA, dating to 1946, slithers in with the Baby Cobras, while the University of Cebu, founded 1964, counters with the Junior Webmasters. Its younger sibling, University of Cebu–Lapu-Lapu and Mandaue Campus, created 1995, adds the UCLM Junior Webmasters from Mandaue. The venerable University of San Carlos, tracing roots to 1595 and run by the Society of the Divine Word, charges forth as the Baby Warriors. University of San Jose-Recoletos, Augustinian Recollect since 1947, prowls as the Baby Jaguars. University of Southern Philippines Foundation, launched 1927, unleashes the Baby Panthers, and University of the Visayas, opened 1919, gallops in as the Baby Lancers.

title: List of bus transit systems in the United States
intro: The following is a list of presently-operating bus transit systems in the United States with regular service. The list excludes charter buses, private bus operators, paratransit systems, and trolleybus systems. Figures for daily ridership, number of vehicles, and daily vehicle revenue miles are accurate as of 2009 and come from the FTA National Transit Database.
lm_description: ACTA links Ashe County’s seat, Jefferson, while neighboring Watauga County relies on AppalCART for Boone. Buncombe County’s Asheville Transit System serves Asheville itself, and Durham County is covered twice: the Bull City Connector and Duke Buses both operate within Durham, joined by the Durham Area Transit Authority (DATA). Wake County fields two systems—Capital Area Transit (CAT) for Raleigh and Cary Transit (C-Tran) for Cary—while Chapel Hill Transit unites Chapel Hill and Carrboro. Mecklenburg County’s Charlotte Area Transit System (CATS) centers on Charlotte; Chatham Transit Network radiates from Siler City in Chatham County, and Cleveland County Transit works county-wide without naming a single hub. Craven Area Rural Transit System (CARTS) connects New Bern, Cumberland County’s FAST links Fayetteville with Spring Lake, and Gastonia Transit stays within Gaston County’s Gastonia. GATEWAY serves Wayne County from Goldsboro, GTA covers Guilford County’s Greensboro, and Hi tran does the same for High Point. Greenway Public Transportation spans Alexander, Burke, Caldwell, and Catawba counties, while ICATS focuses on Statesville in Iredell County.

title: 129th Ohio General Assembly
intro: The One Hundred Twenty-ninth Ohio General Assembly was a meeting of the Ohio state legislature, composed of the Ohio State Senate and the Ohio House of Representatives. It met in Columbus, Ohio from January 3, 2011 until December 20, 2012. While Ted Strickland was Ohio Governor for the first week of the biennium, John Kasich was sworn in during the second week. The apportionment of districts was based on the 2000 United States Census. This was the last time the 2000 census was used by the General Assembly to determine the apportionment of legislative districts. While the Ohio Senate was retained by the Ohio Republican Party, they won control of the Ohio House of Representatives from the Ohio Democratic Party.
lm_description: Craig Newbold, a Republican from Columbiana elected in 2010, represented District 1 until term-limited in 2018, while fellow 2010 GOP newcomers Andrew Brenner of Powell and Ron Amstutz of Wooster, the latter first elected in 2008, served Districts 2 and 3 with term limits of 2018 and 2016 respectively. Matt Huffman of Lima and Gerald Stebelton of Lancaster, both Republicans first elected in 2006, faced term limits in 2014 for Districts 4 and 5, as did Randy Gardner, the Bowling Green Republican appointed in 2008 for District 6. Democrats Kenny Yuko of Richmond Heights, first elected in 2004, and Timothy J. DeGeeter of Parma, appointed in 2003, were term-limited in 2012 for Districts 7 and 15, while Armond Budish of Beachwood, Barbara Boyd of Cleveland Heights, Sandra Williams of Cleveland, and Michael Foley of Cleveland, all Democrats first elected or appointed in 2006, faced 2014 term limits for Districts 8, 9, 11, and 14. Bill Patmon of Cleveland, John E. Barnes Jr. of Cleveland, and Nickie Antonio of Lakewood, all Democrats elected in 2010, were set for 2018 term limits in Districts 10, 12, and 13. Republicans Nan Baker of Westlake, elected in 2008, and Marlene Anielski of Walton Hills, Mike Dovilla of Berea, and Anne Gonzales of Westerville, all elected in 2010, represented Districts 16, 17, 18, and 19 with term limits of 2016 or 2018, while Democrat Nancy Garland of New Albany, elected in 2008, served District 20 until term-limited in 2016.
