title: List of Venezuelan submissions for the Academy Award for Best International Feature Film
intro: Venezuela has submitted films for the Academy Award for Best International Feature Film[nb 1] since 1978. The award is handed out annually by the United States Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to a feature-length motion picture produced outside the United States that contains primarily non-English dialogue. Venezuela has had twenty-nine films accepted by AMPAS for Oscar consideration, but none have yet been nominated for an Academy Award. However, in 2014 the official submission The Liberator was included in the January shortlist along with nine other foreign submissions. In 2005, their official submission, 1888: El Extraordinario Viaje de Santa Isabel, did not arrive in time due to a dispute with a rival film, Secuestro Express. Venezuelan submissions are selected annually by the Centro Nacional Autónomo de Cinematografía
lm_description: Venezuela entered Román Chalbaud’s El Pez que Fuma for the 50th Academy Awards in 1978 and, after a six-year gap, submitted Jacobo Penzo’s The House of Water as La casa de Agua for the 57th. Fina Torres’s Oriana followed for 1985, then Luis Alberto Lamata’s Jericho for 1991, Alejandro Saderman’s Golpes a mi Puerta (nominated as Knocks at My Door) for 1994, and José Ramón Novoa’s Sicario for 1995; none advanced. Alberto Arvelo’s One Life and Two Trails, retitled Una vida y dos mandados, represented the country in 1997, Julio Sosa’s Rizo, released internationally as Loop, in 1998, and Elia Schneider’s Huelepega: Ley de la Calle, shortened to Huelepega, in 1999. Novoa reappeared in 2000 with Oro Diablo, again unrewarded. The 2001 entry, Alberto Aruelo’s Una casa con vista al mar, became A House with a View of the Sea, while 2002 brought Luis Manzo’s La pluma del arcángel, anglicised as The Archangel’s Feather. Leonardo Henriquez’s Sangrador represented 2003, Elia Schneider returned with Punto y Raya for 2004, and Alfredo Anzola’s 1888: El Extraordinario Viaje de Santa Isabel, submitted as 1888: The Extraordinary Voyage of the Santa Isabel, was disqualified in 2005. Solveig Hoogesteijn’s Maroa: Una Niña de la Calle, shortened to Maroa, entered the 79th awards, Mariana Rondon’s Postales de Leningrado became Postcards from Leningrad for 2007, Alberto Bellame’s El tinte de la fama was listed as The Color of Fame in 2008, Efterpi Charalambidis sent Libertador Morales, el Justiciero under its full Spanish title in 2009, and Marcel Rasquin closed the decade with Hermano in 2010; all remained un-nominated.

title: List of Living National Treasures of Japan (performing arts)
intro: The List of Living National Treasures of Japan (performing arts) contains all the individuals and groups certified as Living National Treasures by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology of the government of Japan in the category of the performing arts (芸能, geinō). The performing arts are divided into eight categories: Gagaku, Noh, Bunraku, Kabuki, Kumi Odori, Music, Dance, and Drama. The categories are subdivided into a number of subcategories, usually by role or instrument. Those working in the performing arts are eligible for recognition either individually (Individual Certification) or as part of a group (General Certification).
lm_description: Reibo Aoki, born 1935, became a Living National Treasure in 1999 for shakuhachi, the same subcategory in which Hōzan Yamamoto II, two years his junior, was honored in 2002. Shōin Yamase, born 1932, and Fumiko Yonekawa II, born 1926, were recognized in 2001 and 2008 respectively for koto. Kisaburō Kineya XV, born 1923, and Tetsuo Miyada, born 1934, received their honors in 1997 and 1998 for nagauta vocals, while Masatarō Imafuji, born 1935, was designated in 2013 for nagauta shamisen and Kisaku Katada III, also born 1935, in 1999 for nagauta narimono. Komanosuke Takemoto, born 1935, was honored in 1989 for gidayūbushi vocals, and Tomoji Tsuruzawa, born 1913, in 1998 for gidayūbushi shamisen. Shibun Uji VII, born 1933, and Bunchō Uji, born 1935, received recognition in 1999 and 2001 for icchūbushi vocals and shamisen respectively. Setsuko Yamabiko, born 1920, was designated in 1994 for katōbushi vocals, and Senko Yamabiko, born 1946, in 2009 for katōbushi shamisen. Senroku Miyazono II, born 1944, became a Living National Treasure in 2007 for miyazonobushi vocals. Wakasanojō Tsuruga 11, born 1938, and Nakasaburō Shinnai, born 1940, were both honored in 2001 for shinnaibushi vocals and shamisen. Ichihadayū Tokiwazu, born 1930, received the designation in 1995 for tokiwazubushi vocals, and Eiju Tokiwazu, born 1929, in 1992 for tokiwazubushi shamisen. Eijudayū Kiyomoto, born 1935, was recognized in 2003 for kiyomotobushi vocals.

title: 2008 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships
intro:
The 2008 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships were held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil on 12 October 2008. This event was first announced as the 2008 IAAF World Road Running Championships, but in November 2007, the IAAF announced that the name of the IAAF World Road Running Championships would revert to its original title of the IAAF World Half Marathon Championships. Detailed reports on the event and an appraisal of the results were given both
for the men's race and for the women's race.
lm_description: Ethiopia’s trio of Aselefech Mergia, Genet Getaneh and Abebu Gelan crossed first in 3:30:59, just 25 seconds ahead of Kenya’s Pamela Chepchumba, Peninah Arusei and Julia Mombi Muraga who finished in 3:31:24. Japan’s Yukiko Akaba, Miki Ohira and Yuko Machida took third place in 3:40:58. The United States foursome of Melissa White, Dorothy McMaham and Kristen Nicolini placed fourth in 3:45:06, followed by Russia’s Olesya Syreva, Lyudmila Biktasheva and Tatyana Khmeleva-Aryasova fifth in 3:48:47. Brazil’s Maria Baldaia, Marizete dos Santos and Edielza Guimarães were sixth in 3:51:11, Argentina’s Rosa Godoy, Roxana Preussler and Estela María Martínez seventh in 4:00:51, and Venezuela’s Maria Isabel Montilla, Zuleima Amaya and Mileydy Jaimes eighth in 4:00:58. Puerto Rico’s María Díaz, Zenaida Maldonado and Carmen Vallés did not finish.
to_index_text:
2008 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships
The 2008 IAAF World Half Marathon Championships were held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil on 12 October 2008. This event was first announced as the 2008 IAAF World Road Running Championships, but in November 2007, the IAAF announced that the name of the IAAF World Road Running Championships would revert to its original title of the IAAF World Half Marathon Championships. Detailed reports on the event and an appraisal of the results were given both for the men's race and for the women's race.
Ethiopia’s trio of Aselefech Mergia, Genet Getaneh and Abebu Gelan crossed first in 3:30:59, just 25 seconds ahead of Kenya’s Pamela Chepchumba, Peninah Arusei and Julia Mombi Muraga who finished in 3:31:24. Japan’s Yukiko Akaba, Miki Ohira and Yuko Machida took third place in 3:40:58. title: List of archdeacons in the Church of Ireland
intro: The archdeacons in the Church of Ireland are senior Anglican clergy who serve under their dioceses' bishops, usually with responsibility for the area's church buildings and pastoral care for clergy.
lm_description: Terry Scott has served as Archdeacon of Armagh since 2014, while Andrew Forster holds the companion post of Archdeacon of Ardboe in the same diocese from 2016. In Down and Dromore, David McClay has been Archdeacon of Down since 2013 and Roderic West Archdeacon of Dromore from the same year. Connor diocese supports three archdeacons: Stephen McBride as Archdeacon of Connor since 2002, Paul Dundas as Archdeacon of Dalriada from 2018, and George Davison as Archdeacon of Belfast since 2013. Robert Miller has been Archdeacon of Derry since 6 September 2012, with David Huss becoming Archdeacon of Raphoe in 2013. Brian John Harper was appointed Archdeacon of Clogher in 2014. Craig McCauley has held the Archdeaconry of Kilmore since 2010, and Isaac Hanna that of Elphin and Ardagh from 31 January 2016. Stephen McWhirter concurrently serves as Archdeacon of Tuam and Archdeacon of Killala and Achonry, both appointments dating from 2018. David Pierpoint has been Archdeacon of Dublin since 2004 and Neal O'Raw Archdeacon of Glendalough since 2009. Leslie Stevenson has held the united Archdeaconry of Meath and Kildare since 2009. Bob Gray became Archdeacon of Cashel, Waterford and Lismore and also Ferns in 2015, while Andrew Orr was appointed Archdeacon of Ossory and Leighlin in 2014. Adrian Wilkinson has served as Archdeacon of Cork, Cloyne and Ross since 2014.

title: Yukon Energy
intro: Yukon Energy Corporation (YEC) (French: Société d'énergie du Yukon) is a Canadian Crown corporation in Yukon that provides electrical power to Yukon. YEC is a subsidiary of Yukon Development Corporation that was established in 1987 to take over the Yukon assets of the Northern Canada Power Commission. The company's headquarters is in Whitehorse, Yukon.
lm_description: Yukon Energy’s Aishihik hydro station on Aishihik Lake, commissioned with two 1975 units and a third added in 2011, delivers 37.5 MW. At Dawson City, five fixed and one movable diesel back-up units stand ready, while Faro maintains three fixed diesel back-ups and Mayo keeps two. Whitehorse hosts both the 0.81 MW Haeckel Hill wind farm—its 1993 Bonus 0.15 MW turbine joined by a 2000 Vestas V47-660 0.66 MW turbine—and the 40 MW Whitehorse Rapids hydro plant on Schwatka Lake, built in stages during 1958, 1969 and 1985. A separate 5 MW Mayo Hydro plant, dating from 1951 with two 2.5 MW units, operates alongside the Mayo diesel back-ups, and Whitehorse Rapids also has seven fixed plus one movable diesel back-up units.

title: South Korea at the 2009 Asian Martial Arts Games
intro: South Korea competed at the 2009 Asian Martial Arts Games held in Bangkok, Thailand from August 1, 2009 to August 9, 2009. South Korea finished with 10 gold medals, 6 silver medals, and 3 bronze medals.
lm_description: Bang Gui-Man, Song Dae-Nam and Kwon Young-Woo swept the men’s judo golds at 73 kg, 81 kg and 90 kg, while Chung Jung-Yeon and Jeong Gyeong-Mi claimed the women’s titles at 48 kg and 78 kg. Lee Gyu-Jin and Hwang Dae-Sung added taekwondo welterweight and middleweight crowns at 78 kg and 84 kg, Kim Min-Jung and Jang Eun-Suk taking the women’s fin- and flyweight golds at 47 kg and 51 kg, and Kim Jun-Yul topped wushu men’s sanshou 56 kg. Silver medals went to judoka Hwang Ye-Sul at 70 kg and Kim Na-Young at +78 kg, karateka Lee Ji-Hwan at 60 kg, taekwondists Kim Jae-Bong at 54 kg and Lee Woorinala at 58 kg, wushu fighter Yu Hyeon-Seok at 60 kg, and wushu woman Kim A-Ri at 48 kg. Bronze medals were earned by judoka Kim Ki-Yong at 60 kg and taekwondo heavyweight Oh Min-Ah at +72 kg.

title: List of Olympic medalists in luge
intro: Luge is one of the seven Olympic sports currently contested at the Winter Olympic Games. It has been a constant presence in the Olympic program since its introduction at the 1964 Winter Olympics in Innsbruck, Austria, in the form of three events: men's singles, women's singles, and doubles. [a] A mixed team relay event was contested for the first time at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi.
lm_description: At the 1964 Innsbruck Games, Thomas Köhler led a German sweep of the men’s singles podium ahead of Klaus Bonsack and Hans Plenk. Manfred Schmid gave Austria gold in 1968, while former champion Köhler took silver and compatriot Klaus Bonsack bronze, both now for East Germany. East Germans filled every step at Sapporo 1972 as Wolfgang Scheidel, Harald Ehrig and Wolfram Fiedler claimed gold, silver and bronze. Detlef Günther kept the East German streak alive in Innsbruck 1976, edging West Germany’s Josef Fendt and teammate Hans Rinn. Bernhard Glass made it five straight East German titles at Lake Placid 1980, ahead of Italy’s Paul Hildgartner and West German Anton Winkler. Hildgartner reversed the order in Sarajevo 1984, winning gold while Soviets Sergey Danilin and Valery Dudin completed the podium. Jens Müller restored East German supremacy at Calgary 1988, followed by West Germany’s Georg Hackl and Soviet Yuri Kharchenko. Georg Hackl then began his own dynasty, winning gold for unified Germany at Albertville 1992 ahead of Austrians Markus Prock and Markus Schmidt, repeating the feat at Lillehammer 1994 with Prock second and Italy’s Armin Zöggeler third, and again at Nagano 1998, this time ahead of Zöggeler and German Jens Müller. Zöggeler finally reached the top at Salt Lake City 2002, relegating Hackl to silver and Prock to bronze, and defended his title in Turin 2006 ahead of Russia’s Albert Demchenko and Latvia’s Mārtiņš Rubenis. Germany regained the summit at Vancouver 2010 through Felix Loch, with teammate David Möller second and Zöggeler third, and Loch repeated in Sochi 2014 ahead of Demchenko and Zöggeler once more. Austria’s David Gleirscher claimed Pyeongchang 2018 gold, the United States’ Chris Mazdzer took silver and Germany’s Johannes Ludwig bronze.

title: Christine Baranski
intro: Christine Jane Baranski (born May 2, 1952) is an American actress, singer, and producer. She is a 15-time Emmy Award nominee, winning once in 1995 for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series for her role as Maryann Thorpe in the sitcom Cybill (1995-98). Baranski has received further critical acclaim for her performance as Diane Lockhart in the legal drama series The Good Wife (2009-2016) and its spinoff series The Good Fight (2017-present), as well as her recurring role as Dr. Beverly Hofstadter in the sitcom The Big Bang Theory (2009-2019) for which she received four Emmy nominations. She is also known for her roles in numerous successful TV films, such as her portrayal of Kate in To Dance with the White Dog (1993), Prunella Stickler in Eloise at the Plaza, and Eloise at Christmastime (both 2003), and Amanda in Who Is Simon Miller? (2011). Baranski won two Tony Awards for Best Featured Actress in a Play for the original Broadway productions of The Real Thing in 1984 and Rumors in 1989. Her other major Broadway credits include Hide and Seek (1980), Hurlyburly (1984), The House of Blue Leaves (1986), Nick & Nora (1991), and Boeing Boeing (2008). Baranski has starred in numerous films, including 9½ Weeks (1986), Legal Eagles (1986), Reversal of Fortune (1990), Addams Family Values (1993), Jeffrey (1995), The Birdcage (1996), Bulworth (1998), Cruel Intentions (1999), Bowfinger (1999), Dr. Seuss's How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000), Chicago (2002), Mamma Mia! (2008), The Bounty Hunter (2010), Into the Woods (2014), A Bad Moms Christmas (2017), and Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again (2018).
lm_description: Christine Baranski’s screen career began with bit parts: in 1982 she was the blonde in the bar in Soup for One, and the following year she played a nymphomaniac in Lovesick. She stepped up to named roles as Maxine in 1984’s Crackers, then as Thea in 9½ Weeks and Carol Freeman in Legal Eagles, both released in 1986. After portraying Harriet in 1987’s The Pick-up Artist, she took the real-life part of Andrea Reynolds in 1990’s Reversal of Fortune. 1993 brought three turns: Lucy in The Night We Never Met, Carol in Life with Mikey, and Becky Martin-Granger in Addams Family Values. She spent 1994 juggling Connie Chasseur in The Ref, Mrs. Margaret Maggie Higgs in Getting In, and Miss Strapford in The War. A 1995 prosecutor in New Jersey Drive preceded her Ann Marwood Bartle in Jeffrey. She then appeared as Katherine Archer in 1996’s The Birdcage, Thelma in 1998’s The Odd Couple II, and Constance Bulworth in Bulworth the same year. She closed the decade as Bunny Caldwell in Cruel Intentions and Carol once more in Bowfinger, both 1999 releases.

title: List of programs broadcast by Adult Swim
intro: This is a list of television programs formerly or currently broadcast on Cartoon Network's late night block, Adult Swim in the United States. Although both networks share the same channel space, Adult Swim is classified as a separate entity for the purposes of Nielsen ratings.
lm_description: Adult Swim’s specials begin with the 2016 Adult Swim Golf Classic: Daly vs. Scott, a 72-minute match posted online after its April 8, 2016 linear debut. In 2004 Space Ghost interviewed Meatwad, Sharko and Early Cuyler for Anime Talk Show, a tongue-in-cheek rebuttal when Perfect Hair Forever bumped the Squidbillies pilot. Bagboy arrived February 20, 2015, the same night Brett Gelman’s Dinner in America premiered, followed a year later by Brett Gelman’s Dinner with Family with Brett Gelman and Family; the franchise had begun with Dinner with Friends with Brett Gelman and Friends on April 24, 2014. Michael Cusack’s 11-minute Bushworld Adventures Rick and Morty parody surprised viewers at 11 p.m. on April 1, 2018, while Maxime Simonet’s six-hour Gēmusetto Machu Picchu miniseries landed unannounced the night of March 31, 2019. Christmas in December (2009-10) mocked yuletide infomercials, Earth Ghost (April 1, 2011) replaced George Lowe and every guest with shoddy CGI clones, and Freaknik: The Musical (March 7, 2010) condensed the abandoned That Crook’d ‘Sipp series into a 60-minute T-Pain, Rick Ross and Lil Wayne special. The Greatest Event in Television History sporadically aired 2012-14, Infomercials has lampooned graveyard sales pitches since 2009, and Hunky Boys Go Ding-Dong has run since 2018. Joe Pera Helps You Find the Perfect Christmas Tree debuted December 9, 2016, KRFT Punk’s Political Party dropped March 8, 2019, and Mary Elizabeth Ellis and Artemis Pebdani’s 45-minute play adaptation Mother, May I Dance with Mary Jane’s Fist? screened at midnight January 7, 2018. Metalocalypse: The Doom Star Requiem rocked for an hour on October 27, 2013, Mr. Neighbor’s House (Brian Huskey, Jason Mantzoukas, Jesse Falcon) has spoofed Mister Rogers since 2016, and Scavengers landed December 24, 2016.

title: List of LDAP software
intro: The following is a list of software programs that can communicate with and/or host directory services via the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP).
lm_description: Red Hat offers an LDAP solution under a GPL linking exception that explicitly permits linking to non-GPL code, while another Red Hat product built on 389 Directory Server is released straight GPL. Microsoft, Apple, CA Technologies, Critical Path, ForgeRock, IBM, and NetIQ all distribute proprietary LDAP software. Michael Ströder and the Apache Software Foundation each provide Apache License 2.0 offerings. Stefan Bebbo Franke and the Mandriva development team publish GPL-licensed packages. Atos (formerly Siemens) is also listed among the developers. Mark Cavage’s work carries the MIT License, whereas Martin Hedenfalk and OpenBSD use the ISC license. The Open Identity Platform Community and Sun Microsystems both choose CDDL, and Kurt Zeilenga’s Slapd-based project is available under the OpenLDAP Public License.

title: List of fictional ungulates
intro: This list of fictional ungulates is a subsidiary to the list of fictional animals. The list is restricted to notable ungulate (hooved) characters from various works organized by medium. This paraphyletic list includes all fictional hooved characters except fictional horses, fictional pachyderms (elephants, hippopotamuses, and rhinoceroses), and fictional swine, as each has its own list.
lm_description: Dash the live-action donkey grazes in Big Barn Farm alongside Ewenice the sheep, Gobo the goat, and Madam the cow, while Cranky Doodle Donkey and Matilda, a male and female donkey couple, trot through My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic. Elliot the puppet moose stars in his own show Elliot Moose, just as Mr. Moose the puppet moose jokes on Captain Kangaroo, and Lamb Chop the puppet ewe appears across various Shari Lewis programs. Muffin the mule, a 1933 Hogarth Puppets creation, headlines Muffin the Mule, while the puppet alpaca duo Nuzzle and Scratch host their self-titled series. Shaun the stop-motion sheep leads Shaun the Sheep, and Zaza the puppet zebra trots through De Fabeltjeskrant.

title: 2011 New Zealand Warriors season
intro: The New Zealand Warriors 2011 season was the New Zealand Warriors 17th first-grade season. The club competed in Australasia's National Rugby League. The coach of the team is Ivan Cleary while Simon Mannering is the club's captain. The Warriors lost to the Manly Sea Eagles 10-24 in the 2011 NRL Grand Final. The Junior Warriors won the Toyota Cup for the second consecutive year while the Auckland Vulcans finished second in the NSW Cup. The finals form of the Warriors in 2011 increased the NRL's television audience in New Zealand by 29 per cent this year.
lm_description: Anthony Gelling, a centre-cum-second-rower who played for the Sydney Roosters NYC in 2010, joined the Warriors alongside Darin Kingi, a hooker from the Manurewa Marlins, and Johnny Aranga, a fullback-winger recruited from the Mt Albert Lions. Prop-second-rower Peter-George Rata arrived from the Waicoa Bay Stallions, while versatile Sema Mataora, who can lock or play halfback, came from the Otahuhu Leopards. Shaun Metcalf, a centre-second-rower who spent 2010 with the Auckland Vulcans, was joined by Sonny Walker, a winger-centre from the Pukekohe Pythons, and Tulson Caird, a second-row-lock forward who previously played for the Te Atatu Roosters.

The Junior Warriors won the Toyota Cup for the second consecutive year while the Auckland Vulcans finished second in the NSW Cup. The finals form of the Warriors in 2011 increased the NRL's television audience in New Zealand by 29 per cent this year.
Anthony Gelling, a centre-cum-second-rower who played for the Sydney Roosters NYC in 2010, joined the Warriors alongside Darin Kingi, a hooker from the Manurewa Marlins, and Johnny Aranga, a fullback-winger recruited from the Mt Albert Lions. Prop-second-rower Peter-George Rata arrived from the Waicoa Bay Stallions, while versatile Sema Mataora, who can lock or play halfback, came from the Otahuhu Leopards. Shaun Metcalf, a centre-second-rower who spent 2010 with the Auckland Vulcans, was joined by Sonny Walker, a winger-centre from the Pukekohe Pythons, and Tulson Caird, a second-row-lock forward who previously played for the Te Atatu Roosters.

title: List of colleges and universities in New York's Capital District
intro: The colleges and universities of New York's Capital District are a varied lot, consisting of four year and two year institutions, universities and community colleges, private and public institutions.
lm_description: SUNY Adirondack, founded in 1961, serves Queensbury as part of the State University of New York System, while Columbia-Greene Community College, established five years later, is based in Hudson under the same system. Albany hosts a cluster of specialized institutions: Albany College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences, dating to 1881, shares the University Heights joint campus with Albany Law School, the nation’s oldest independent law school, founded in 1851, and Albany Medical College, tracing its origins to 1839, all three operating within Union University. The College of Saint Rose, a private college established in 1920, and Maria College, a four-year Catholic college founded in 1958, also call Albany home, as do Excelsior College, a private institution since 2001 after two decades as SUNY Regents College, and Mildred Elley, dating to 1917. Troy houses Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the English-speaking world’s oldest technological university, founded in 1824, alongside Russell Sage College, established in 1916, and Hudson Valley Community College, dating to 1953, with the latter also serving Northbush. The Sage Colleges network includes Sage College of Albany, founded in 1957 on the University Heights campus, and Sage Graduate School, established in 1949, operating in both Troy and Albany. Empire State College, created in 1971, maintains administrative offices in Saratoga Springs and learning centers in Latham, Queensbury, Schenectady, and Johnstown. Schenectady County Community College, founded in 1967, and Fulton-Montgomery Community College, dating to 1963, are SUNY community colleges located in Schenectady and Johnstown respectively. Bryant & Stratton College, a proprietary institution since 1854, and Siena College, a Catholic college established in 1937, are both situated in Colonie, while the Graduate College of Union University, the newest entry, opened in Schenectady in 2003.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Randolph County, Arkansas
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places listings in Randolph County, Arkansas. This is intended to be a complete list of the properties and districts on the National Register of Historic Places in Randolph County, Arkansas, United States. The locations of National Register properties and districts for which the latitude and longitude coordinates are included below, may be seen in a map. There are 17 properties and districts listed on the National Register in the county. Another two properties were once listed but have been removed.
lm_description: Campbell Cemetery, tucked off Muddy Lane southeast of Imboden, entered the National Register on 25 May 2005. Cedar Grove School #81, five miles north of Pocahontas on Highway 115 in Brockett, followed on 21 January 2004. The Hillyard Cabin, standing on the west side of Old Burr Road northeast of Warm Springs, was listed 16 August 1994, while the Looney-French House at 1325 Deer Run Trail in Dalton joined the register on 23 September 2004. Marr’s Creek Bridge on South Bettis Street, Pocahontas, was honored 24 January 2008. Old Davidsonville Historic Site, northeast of Black Rock on the Black River, dates to 18 January 1974, and the Old Randolph County Courthouse at Broadway and Vance in Pocahontas to 24 April 1973. Old Union School on 504 Old Union Road, Birdell, was listed 12 November 1993, and the Old US 67 segment from Biggers to Datto along Biggers-Reyno Road, 1st Street, and County Road 111 on 24 September 2004. The Pocahontas Commercial Historic District, roughly bounded by Rice, Thomasville, Jordan, and McDonald streets, entered 12 June 2009; Pocahontas Federal Savings and Loan at 201 West Broadway on 24 January 2019; the Pocahontas Post Office at 109 Van Bibber Street on 16 May 2002; and the current Randolph County Courthouse at the southwest corner of Broadway and North Marr on 22 August 1996. Ravenden Springs School on Highway 90 was listed 14 January 2004, the Rice-Upshaw House two miles south of Dalton on Highway 93 on 6 October 2004, St. Mary’s AME Church-Pocahontas Colored School at 1708 Archer Street on 5 August 2002, and Yadkin Church on the west side of Upper James Creek Road north of its junction with Lower James Creek Road in Ravenden Springs on 30 May 2019.

title: List of radio stations in the United Kingdom
intro: This is a list of radio stations in the United Kingdom.
lm_description: Chelmsford Calling served Chelmsford on 104.4 FM until it closed in February 2007, while Hackney’s Sound Radio broadcast on 1503 AM until June 2007. TGR Sound signed off Bexleyheath’s 103.7 FM on 22 June 2008, and Enniskillen’s Vibe FM left 105.3 FM in October 2009. Forest of Dean Radio, which had reached Cinderford on 1521 AM and Newent on 1503 AM, fell silent on 31 December 2009. Link FM’s 92.2 FM for Harold Hill ended on 28 June 2010, and Belfast’s Féile FM closed 103.2 FM on 25 March 2011. Boundary Sound’s 102.6 FM for Newark shut down on 23 June 2011, the same summer that Voice Radio’s DAB 11C service for Cardiff and Newport ceased on 20 July 2011 and Wayland Radio’s 107.3 FM for Wayland, Norfolk, ended on 27 August 2011. Burngreave Community Radio’s 103.1 FM for Burngreave, Sheffield, closed in September 2011, followed by Radio Sandwell’s 106.9 FM for Sandwell, West Midlands, in November 2011. XS—formerly Afan FM—left Neath on 97.4 FM and Port Talbot on 107.9 FM on 13 December 2011. Cheshire FM closed Mid Cheshire’s 92.5 FM on 27 January 2012, Rossendale Radio signed off 104.7 FM for Haslingden and Rawtenstall on 5 March 2012 (returning in December 2018), Diversity FM ended Lancaster’s 103.5 FM on 31 March 2012, and The Park closed Lymington’s 97.9 FM on 8 June 2012. ON FM left Hammersmith, London, on 101.4 FM in January 2013, OX105 FM shut Oxford’s 105.1 FM on 2 October 2013, and Stroud FM ended Stroud’s 107.9 FM on 12 February 2014.

title: List of tallest buildings in China
intro: China has the largest number of tall buildings in the world, surpassing that of the second and third largest, the United States (800+) and Japan (250+), combined. As of early 2017, China has more than 1400 skyscrapers above 150 meters (492 ft) of which 48 are super-tall 300 meters (984 ft and above). The tallest tower in China is currently the Shanghai Tower, located in the namesake city at a height of 632 meters; it is the second-tallest building in the world. The previous 2 tallest buildings in mainland China have also been in Shanghai. The Chinese economic reform from 1978 onwards lead to a significant improvement in quality of living and economic capital. Of the 64 buildings (completed and architecturally topped out) which reach a height of 350 metres (1,150 ft) or more in the world, 32 of them are in China (including Hong Kong).
lm_description: Goldin Finance 117 rises 597 m with 117 floors and was finished in Tianjin in 2020. The 588 m, 119-floor Baoneng Binhu Center T1 will crown Hefei in 2024, while its neighbour Evergrande International Financial Center T1 reached 518 m with 112 floors in 2021. Nanning’s 420 m Skyfame Center Landmark Tower opened in 2021 with 90 floors. Dalian Greenland Center tops out at 518 m across 88 floors and was completed in 2019. Wuhan Greenland Center reaches 475 m with 85 floors and will finish in 2022. Matching 468 m, Chengdu Greenland Tower carries 100 floors and was done in 2019, the same height and year as Chongqing’s 99-floor International Commerce Center 1. Baoneng Binhu Center T2 will add a 465 m, 96-floor sibling in Hefei by 2027. Shijiazhuang’s 450 m Tianshan Gate of The World, with 106 floors, is due in 2025. China Resources Centre Block A in Nanning stands 402 m with 85 floors and was finished in 2019. Riverview Plaza in Wuhan hit 436 m with 73 floors in 2018. Haikou Tower and Shandong IFC both rise 428 m, the former with 94 floors in 2020, the latter with 86 floors in 2022. Ningbo Center reached 408 m with 80 floors in 2022. Shenzhen’s Gemdale Gangxia Tower 1 topped out at 375 m with 80 floors in 2020. Golden Eagle Tiandi Tower A in Nanjing stands 368 m with 76 floors since 2018. Gezhouba International Plaza in Wuhan reaches 350 m with 69 floors and will finish in 2022, while Jinan Center Financial City hit 333 m with 69 floors in 2021.

title: West Bromwich Albion F.C.
intro: West Bromwich Albion Football Club (/ˈbrɒmɪdʒ, -ɪtʃ/) is an English professional football club based in West Bromwich, West Midlands, England. They currently play in the Championship, the second tier of English football. The club was formed in 1878 and has played at its home ground, The Hawthorns, since 1900. Albion were one of the founding members of the Football League in 1888, the first professional football league in the world, and have spent the majority of their existence in the top tier of English football. They have been champions of England once, in 1919-20, and have been runners-up twice. Albion have reached ten FA Cup finals, winning the Cup on five occasions. The first win came in 1888, the year the league was founded, and the most recent in 1968, their last major trophy. They also won the Football League Cup at the first attempt in 1966. The club's longest continuous period in the top division spanned 24 years between 1949 and 1973, and from 1986 to 2002 they spent their longest ever spell out of the top division. The team has played in navy blue and white stripes for most of the club's history; and the club badge features a throstle perched on a hawthorn branch. Albion have a number of long-standing rivalries with other West Midlands clubs; their traditional rivals being Aston Villa and Wolverhampton Wanderers. Albion contest the Black Country Derby with the latter.
lm_description: Billy Bassett made 311 appearances and scored 77 goals as outside right between 1886 and 1899. Jesse Pennington played 496 matches without scoring as left back from 1903 to 1922. W. G. Richardson struck 228 goals in 354 games as centre forward between 1929 and 1945. Ray Barlow appeared 482 times and scored 48 goals as left-half from 1944 to 1960. Ronnie Allen scored 234 goals in 458 matches as centre forward from 1950 to 1961. Don Howe made 379 appearances and scored 19 goals as right back between 1952 and 1964. Derek Kevan netted 157 goals in 262 games as centre forward from 1953 to 1963. Tony Brown, playing wing half or inside forward, amassed 720 appearances and 279 goals between 1963 and 1981. Jeff Astle scored 174 goals in 361 matches as centre forward from 1964 to 1974. Goalkeeper John Osborne kept 312 clean-sheet appearances across two spells, 1967-72 and 1973-78. John Wile played 619 games and scored 29 goals as centre-half from 1970 to 1983. Willie Johnston made 261 appearances and scored 28 goals as outside left between 1972 and 1979. Bryan Robson appeared 249 times and scored 46 goals as central midfielder from 1974 to 1981. Derek Statham played 373 matches and scored 11 goals as left back between 1976 and 1987. Laurie Cunningham scored 30 goals in 114 games as winger from 1977 to 1979. Cyrille Regis made 302 appearances and scored 112 goals as centre forward between 1977 and 1984. Russell Hoult played 213 matches without scoring as goalkeeper from 2001 to 2007.

title: List of places in London
intro: This is an incomplete list of places in London, England.
lm_description: Barking and Dagenham, Havering and Redbridge share the North East sub-region and the City and East or Havering and Redbridge Assembly seats, while Barnet and Camden jointly represent the North, Barnet partnering Camden in the Barnet and Camden constituency. Bexley and Bromley co-represent the South East, mirrored by the Bexley and Bromley Assembly seat, whereas Croydon and Sutton share both the South West sub-region and the Croydon and Sutton seat. Brent and Harrow cover the North West and West, served by the Brent and Harrow seat, and Ealing and Hillingdon pair in the West under the Ealing and Hillingdon constituency. Enfield and Haringey span the North, united in the Enfield and Haringey seat, and Hounslow and Kingston upon Thames join the South West, Hounslow falling within the South West Assembly area. Inner London’s Camden, Hackney, Islington, Hammersmith and Fulham, Kensington and Chelsea, and Greenwich each align with their sub-regions—North, West, South East—and corresponding Assembly seats: Barnet and Camden, North East, West Central, or Greenwich and Lewisham.

title: List of ocean liners
intro: This is a list of ocean liners past and present, which are passenger ships engaged in the transportation of passengers and goods in transoceanic voyages. Ships primarily designed for pleasure cruises are listed at List of cruise ships. Some ships which have been explicitly designed for both line voyages and cruises, or which have been converted from liners to cruise ships, may be listed in both places. Also included are cargo liners designed to carry both cargo and passengers.
lm_description: RMS Queen Elizabeth, launched in 1938, burned as Seawise University and sank in 1972, later scrapped 1974-75. MS Regal Empress, built 1953 as SS Olympia, ended as Caribe I and was scrapped in 2009. RMS Republic, launched 1903, collided with SS Florida and sank in 1909. SS Rijndam, 1951, renamed Pride of Galveston, sank en route to scrapping in 2003. SS Roma, 1926, became SS Aquila, was scuttled in 1945 and fully scrapped by 1952. SS Rotterdam, 1958, later Rembrandt, survives as a hotelship. MS Sagafjord, 1965, renamed Saga Rose, scrapped Jiangyin 2010. SS Santa Paula, 1958, served as Kuwait Marriott, bombed 1990, scrapped 2002. SS Santa Rosa, 1916, torpedoed 1942 after stints as USS Santa Rosa and SS Oregonian. SS Santa Rosa, 1932, became SS Athinai, scrapped Aliaga 1989. RMS Saxonia, 1954, renamed Leonid Sobinov, scrapped Alang 1999. SS Scharnhorst, 1904, scrapped 1934. SS Scharnhorst, 1934, renamed Shin'yō, sunk by USS Spadefish 1944. SS Shalom, 1964, renamed Regent Sun, sank off Cape St. Francis 2001. MS Sobieski, 1938, scrapped La Spezia 1975. SS Southern Cross, 1955, renamed OceanBreeze, scrapped Chittagong 2003. SS Statendam, 1956, renamed Harmony I, scrapped Alang 2004. TSS Stefan Batory, 1952, scrapped Aliaga 2000. SS Stella Solaris, 1949, scrapped 2003. SS St. Louis, 1894, scrapped Genoa 1924.

title: 2009 Santos FC season
intro: The 2009 season was Santos Futebol Clube's ninety-seventh season in existence and the club's fifty consecutive season in the top flight of Brazilian football.
lm_description: Goalkeeper Felipe, 21, left Santos for Paraná Clube, while another 21-year-old keeper named Felipe headed to Portuguesa Santista and 20-year-old Vladimir transferred to Fortaleza. Defenders Carlinhos (21) and Anderson Salles (21) moved to Mirassol and Juventus respectively, and Domingos (24) joined Portuguesa. Midfielders Dionísio (20), Wesley (22), and Adriano (21) departed for Oeste, Atlético-PR, and São Caetano, and 30-year-old Roberto Brum went to Figueirense. Forwards Mariano Trípodi (21) and Tiago Luís (20) signed with Atlético Mineiro and União Leiria. Patrik (21) and Hudson (21) each left twice, Patrik to Comercial and Uberaba, Hudson to Santa Cruz and Ituano. Filipi Souza (21) and Vinicius Simon (22) respectively joined Uberaba and Santo André.

title: FC Dallas
intro: FC Dallas is an American professional soccer club based in the Dallas suburb of Frisco, Texas. The club competes as a member of the Western Conference in Major League Soccer (MLS). The franchise began play in 1996 as a charter club of the league. The club was founded in 1995 as the Dallas Burn before adopting its current name in 2004. Dallas plays its home games at their 20,500-capacity soccer-specific Toyota Stadium, where they have played since 2005. In the club's early years, Dallas played their home games in the Cotton Bowl. The team is owned by the Hunt Sports Group led by brothers Clark Hunt and Dan Hunt, who is the team's president. The Hunt family also owns the NFL's Kansas City Chiefs and part of the Chicago Bulls. FC Dallas in 2016 won their first Supporters' Shield. In 2010 they were runners-up in the MLS Cup, losing to the Colorado Rapids in extra time. The team has won the U.S. Open Cup on two occasions (in 1997 and again in 2016). Their fully owned USL affiliate, North Texas SC, won the 2019 USL League One regular season and overall championship titles, the third division title in American soccer.
lm_description: Jesse González, the United States goalkeeper wearing number 1, anchors the squad alongside fellow homegrown defenders Reggie Cannon and Matt Hedges, while Swiss veteran Reto Ziegler and Brazilian Bressan complete the back line. Brazilian midfielder Thiago Santos partners Honduran Designated Player Bryan Acosta and Colombian Santiago Mosquera in the engine room, supported by American Ryan Hollingshead and homegrown talents Brandon Servania, Paxton Pomykal and Thomas Roberts. Up front, Jesús Ferreira leads the American contingent flanked by Fafà Picault, with Czech striker Zdeněk Ondrášek, teenage homegrown Ricardo Pepi, Ghanaian Generation Adidas pair Francis Atuahene and Ema Twumasi, and Colombian winger Michael Barrios providing attacking options, while Jimmy Maurer backs up González in goal.

title: List of members of Gray's Inn
intro: The Honourable Society of Gray's Inn, commonly known simply as Gray's Inn, is one of the four Inns of Court in London. To be called to the Bar and practise as a barrister in England and Wales, an individual must belong to one of these Inns. Having existed for over 600 years, members of Gray's Inn include many noted lawyers and judges, such as Francis Bacon, Baron Slynn, Lord Bingham of Cornhill, Lord Hoffmann and others. Outside the Bar and judiciary of England and Wales, members have included the clergy (including five Archbishops of Canterbury), industrialists like John Wynne, astronomers such as John Lee, media figures, like Huw Thomas, and members of the Bar and judiciary of other nations, such as Yang Ti-liang (former Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Hong Kong) and Aitzaz Ahsan (former president of the Supreme Court Bar Association of Pakistan). As well as full members, the Inn also offers honorary membership to particularly distinguished members of society. During the Second World War, for example, both Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill became honorary Benchers, and therefore members. Other than honorary members, this list only contains those individuals who were called to the Bar, not those who simply joined but left before qualifying.
lm_description: William Atwater, called in 1520, rose to become Bishop of Lincoln, while Stephen Gardiner, called in 1555, served as Bishop of Winchester. Richard Bancroft, called in 1588, and John Whitgift, called in 1592, both became Archbishops of Canterbury, as did Lancelot Andrewes, called in 1589, who first served as Bishop of Winchester. William Laud and Joseph Hall, both called in 1615, became Archbishop of Canterbury and Bishop of Exeter respectively. Thomas Morton, called in 1622, became Bishop of Lichfield, while James Ussher, called in 1623, served as Archbishop of Armagh and Primate of All Ireland. William Juxon, called in 1635, also became Archbishop of Canterbury, followed by Gilbert Sheldon, called in 1663, who likewise attained that position.

title: 2000 in country music
intro: This is a list of notable events in country music that took place in the year 2000.
lm_description: Neal McCoy’s 24-7-365 reached No. 28 on the U.S. chart under Giant, while Ronnie Milsap’s 40 # 1 Hits peaked at 19 on Virgin Nashville. Amanda Stott’s self-titled Warner release, Johnny Cash’s American III: Solitary Man hit 11 on Lost Highway, and Jeff Foxworthy’s Big Funny climbed to 15 on DreamWorks Nashville. Ricky Skaggs honored Bill Monroe with Big Mon: The Songs of Bill Monroe at 42 on his own Skaggs Family label, BR5-49’s Coast to Coast reached 46 on Arista Nashville, and Buddy & Julie Miller’s duo album landed at 45 on Hightone. Chris LeDoux’s Cowboy rode to 17 on Capitol Nashville, the Various Artists compilation A Country Superstar Christmas III hit 22 on Hip-O, and Elvis Presley’s posthumous The Elvis Presley Collection - Country reached 19 on RCA. Steve Wariner’s Faith in You peaked at 31 on Capitol Nashville, Jennifer Day’s The Fun of Your Love reached 36 on BNA, and Neko Case issued Furnace Room Lullaby on Mint without a listed chart position. Roy D. Mercer’s Greatest Fits: The Best of How Big a Boy Are Ya? hit 26 on Virgin Nashville, BlackHawk’s Greatest Hits reached 18 on Arista Nashville, Bryan White’s Greatest Hits peaked at 25 on Asylum, John Berry’s Greatest Hits reached 43 on Capitol Nashville, Stompin’ Tom Connors released Greatest Hits/Souvenirs on EMI, and Chet Atkins’s triple-package Guitar Genius/Relaxin’ with Chet/Nashville Gold closed the list at 42 on RCA Nashville.

title: Marlijn Binnendijk
intro: Marlijn Binnendijk (born 12 May 1986 in Zuid-Scharwoude) is a Dutch professional racing cyclist.
lm_description: On 30 July 2004 Marlijn Binnendijk contested the individual pursuit at the Junior Coupe du Monde in Los Angeles, United States. She returned to the same event on 19 February 2005, this time racing the individual pursuit at the Track Cycling World Cup in Sydney, Australia. During the 2006 Dutch National Track Championships held in Alkmaar, Netherlands, she rode three events: the scratch race on 28 December, and both the points race and individual pursuit on 30 December. Switching to the road, she competed in the national road cycling championships on 13 June 2007, finishing the road race in Maastricht, Netherlands. Back on the track in Alkmaar, she entered the points race of the 2007 Dutch National Track Championships on 30 December 2007. Finally, on 17 February 2008, she joined the team pursuit at the Track Cycling World Cup in Ballerup, Denmark.

Marlijn Binnendijk

title: Asian Club Championship and AFC Champions League records and statistics
intro: This page details statistics of the Asian Club Championship and AFC Champions League.
lm_description: South Korea dominates the competition with 11 titles earned by six clubs: Pohang Steelers lead with three, Seongnam FC, Suwon Samsung Bluewings and Jeonbuk Hyundai Motors each have two, while Busan IPark and Ulsan Hyundai added one apiece; Seongnam FC and FC Seoul have each finished runner-up twice, Jeonbuk Hyundai Motors once and Yangzee once. Japan follows with seven trophies shared among Urawa Red Diamonds (two), JEF United Ichihara Chiba, Tokyo Verdy, Gamba Osaka, Júbilo Iwata and Kashima Antlers, while Júbilo Iwata have twice been runners-up and Yokohama F. Marinos and Urawa Red Diamonds once each. Saudi Arabia’s five wins come solely from Al-Hilal (three) and Al-Ittihad (two), yet the kingdom has produced nine runners-up: Al-Hilal four times, Al-Ahli twice, and Al-Ittihad, Al-Nassr and Al-Shabab once apiece. Iran has three titles via Esteghlal (two) and PAS Tehran (one) and five runners-up spots from Esteghlal (two), Sepahan, Zob Ahan and Persepolis (one each). China’s three wins are split between Guangzhou Evergrande (two) and Liaoning Whowin (one), with Liaoning Whowin and Dalian Wanda each finishing second once. Israel has three titles—Maccabi Tel Aviv (two) and Hapoel Tel Aviv (one)—and Hapoel Tel Aviv once runner-up. Qatar’s Al-Sadd have won twice and Al-Arabi been runners-up once; Thailand’s Thai Farmers Bank have two titles and BEC Tero Sasana one runners-up finish. The United Arab Emirates’ sole victory belongs to Al-Ain, who have also been runners-up twice, with Al-Ahli adding one second place. Australia’s Western Sydney Wanderers have one title and Adelaide United one runners-up finish. Iraq, Malaysia, Oman and Syria have each supplied two or one runners-up without yet claiming a title: Al-Shorta and Al-Rasheed for Iraq, Selangor for Malaysia, Oman Club for Oman, and Al-Karamah for Syria.

title: List of Catholic churches in the United States
intro: This is a list of notable Catholic churches and cathedrals in the United States.
lm_description: St. Patrick’s Church, raised in 1915 on Higgins Hill in Bisbee, Arizona, earned National Register recognition in 1995 for its Late Gothic Revival design. Flagstaff’s Our Lady of Guadalupe, completed in 1926, was listed in 1986, while Globe’s 1916 Holy Angels gained NRHP status in 1983. Kingman’s 1906 St. Mary’s, Mission/Spanish Revival in style, and Miami’s 1917 Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament, listed in 2008, anchor their respective towns. Pearce honors the 2004-listed Our Lady of Victory, and Phoenix shelters four treasures: the 1966 Modern Cathedral of Saints Simon and Jude, the 1993 Immaculate Heart of Mary, the 2012-listed Sacred Heart, and the 1902 Mission Revival/Spanish Colonial Revival St. Mary’s Basilica, NRHP-listed in 1978. Prescott’s 1894 Late Gothic Revival Sacred Heart, rectory included, joined the Register in 1978, while Tempe’s Romanesque 1903 St. Mary’s-Our Lady of Mount Carmel did the same. Tucson claims four: the 1881 Gothic Revival Sacred Heart, 1968 Mexican Baroque Cathedral of St. Augustine, 1918 Mission/Spanish Revival Santa Cruz, and 1797 Mission/Spanish Colonial Mission San Xavier del Bac, listed in 1966. Finally, Window Rock’s St. Michael’s Mission, NRHP-listed in 1975, stands north of town off Route 264.

title: Q-Games
intro: Q-Games, Limited is a video game developer based in Nakagyō-ku, Kyoto, Japan which works closely with both Nintendo and Sony.
lm_description: Q-Games released Digidrive for Game Boy Advance on July 27, 2006 as part of the Bit Generations series, then ported it to DSiWare on October 2, 2009 under the title Art Style: DIGIDRIVE. Star Fox Command arrived for Nintendo DS on August 28, 2006, followed by the 3DS remaster Star Fox 64 3D on September 9, 2011, co-developed with Nintendo EAD. The PixelJunk line began with Racers on September 13, 2007 for PlayStation 3, then Monsters on January 24, 2008, which later spread to PlayStation Vita, Windows, Mac and Linux; its expansion Monsters Encore landed April 24, 2008, while the PSP compilation Monsters Deluxe released October 1, 2009. Eden debuted July 31, 2008 on PlayStation 3 and Windows, Shooter arrived December 10, 2009 and ultimately reached PS3, Windows, Mac, Linux, PS4 and Vita, spawning the sequel Shooter 2 on March 1, 2011 and the combined Shooter Ultimate on October 21, 2015. SideScroller followed October 22, 2011, 4am on May 15, 2012, and Visualizer on August 13, 2013. DSiWare saw Trajectile (aka Reflect Missile) November 24, 2009, Starship Defence (Starship Patrol) December 18, 2009, and X-Scape (X Returns/3D Space Tank) May 31, 2010. Nom Nom Galaxy launched August 3, 2015 for Windows, Mac, Linux and PS4, while the free-to-play social-action hybrid The Tomorrow Children reached PlayStation 4 on September 6, 2016.

title: List of craters on Mercury
intro:
This is a list of named craters on Mercury, the innermost planet of the Solar System (for other features, see list of geological features on Mercury). Most Mercurian craters are named after famous writers, artists and composers. According to the rules by IAU's Working Group for Planetary System Nomenclature, all new craters must be named after an artist that was famous for more than fifty years, and dead for more than three years, before the date they are named. Craters larger than 250 km in diameter are referred to as basins (also see § Terminology). As of 2019, there are 401 named Mercurian craters, a small fraction of the total number of named Solar System craters, most of which are lunar, Martian and Venerian craters. [a]
 Other, non-planetary bodies with numerous named craters include Callisto (141), Ganymede (131), Rhea (128), Vesta (90), Ceres (90), Dione (73), Iapetus (58), Enceladus (53), Tethys (50) and Europa (41). For a full list, see List of craters in the Solar System.
lm_description: Mercury’s Gainsborough crater, 95 km wide, honors English painter Thomas Gainsborough and was approved in 1985. Antoni Gaudí i Cornet, the Spanish Catalan architect, lent his name to the 81 km Gaudí crater in 2012, while French artist Paul Gauguin’s 70 km Gauguin crater dates to 1979. Irish stained-glass artist Wilhelmina Geddes is remembered in the 84 km Geddes crater, approved 2010. Lorenzo Ghiberti’s 110 km Ghiberti crater and Giotto di Bondone’s 144 km Giotto crater both received names in 1976. Giambologna, the Flemish sculptor, has the 69 km Giambologna crater approved 2013, and Lebanese-American poet-artist Kahlil Gibran the 106 km Gibran crater approved 2009. Russian composer Mikhail Glinka’s 89 km Glinka crater was named in 2008; Austrian composer Christoph Willibald Gluck’s 100 km Gluck crater in 1979. Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, the German writer, claims the 317.17 km Goethe basin, approved 1979. Russian playwright Nikolai Gogol’s 79 km Gogol crater was approved 1985, South African writer Nadine Gordimer the 58 km Gordimer crater in 2019. Spanish artist Francisco Goya’s 138 km Goya crater, Australian composer Percy Grainger’s 113 km Grainger crater, and Norwegian composer Edvard Grieg’s 59 km Grieg crater all trace to 1976, 2012, and 1985 respectively. Finnish-American ceramist Maija Grotell’s 48.25 km Grotell crater was approved 2012, and Italian music theorist Guido of Arezzo the 58 km Guido d’Arezzo crater in 1976.

title: 2012 AFL draft
intro: The 2012 AFL draft consisted of five opportunities for player acquisitions during the 2012/13 Australian Football League off-season. These were:
lm_description: Richmond and Daniel Connors parted ways by mutual consent on 4 July 2012 after he repeatedly failed to meet club expectations. Hawthorn’s Cameron Bruce retired immediately on 16 July 2012 because of a chronic back injury, while Melbourne captain Brad Green announced on 8 August that he would retire at season’s end. Richmond trio Brad Miller and Kelvin Moore joined Lindsay Gilbee and Ryan Hargrave of the Western Bulldogs in immediate retirement on 16 and 20 August respectively. Collingwood’s Chris Tarrant followed suit on 21 August, Fremantle’s Antoni Grover on 28 August, and Essendon’s Mark McVeigh the next day. Gold Coast’s Josh Fraser closed August by retiring on the 29th. September began with Western Bulldogs delisting Andrew Hooper on the 3rd while teammate James Mulligan retired the same day; Melbourne’s Liam Jurrah and Brisbane’s Amon Buchanan also left on 3 September, Jurrah resigning and Buchanan retiring. Brent Moloney resigned from Melbourne on 4 September, and Greater Western Sydney delisted Steve Clifton and Tim Segrave on 5 September while veteran James McDonald retired and St Kilda delisted Brett Peake.

title: List of Christian monasteries in Denmark
intro: The following is a list, as yet incomplete, of Christian religious houses in Denmark whether extant or not, for both men and for women.
lm_description: Flensburg Friary housed Franciscan friars from 1263 until 1528, while Husum Friary’s Franciscans served 1494-1528. Guldholm Abbey began as a Benedictine monks’ house in 1190/91, but after the community transferred from St. Michael’s Abbey, Schleswig, it became Cistercian and moved to Ryd Abbey in 1210. Ryd or Rüde Abbey near Glücksburg then continued as Cistercian monks from 1210 to 1536. St. Michael’s itself, Schleswig’s Benedictine double monastery founded c. 1030, saw its monks removed for discipline c. 1190 and sent to establish Guldholm, leaving only Benedictine nuns until c. 1200. St. John’s Priory, also in Schleswig, sustained Benedictine nuns from c. 1200 to 1536. Mohrkirchen Hospital sheltered Hospital Brothers of St. Anthony from 1391 to 1535. Schleswig’s Dominican Friary served from 1239 to 1529, and its Franciscan Friary from 1232 to 1530.

The following is a list, as yet incomplete, of Christian religious houses in Denmark whether extant or not, for both men and for women.
Flensburg Friary housed Franciscan friars from 1263 until 1528, while Husum Friary’s Franciscans served 1494-1528. title: 2011 NFL Draft
intro: The 2011 NFL Draft was the 76th installment of the annual NFL Draft, where the franchises of the National Football League select newly eligible football players. Like the 2010 draft, the 2011 draft was held at Radio City Music Hall in New York City, New York, over three days: this year, the first round took place on Thursday, April 28, 2011; the second and third rounds took place on Friday, April 29; with the final four rounds on Saturday, April 30, 2011. The Carolina Panthers, who had the worst record for the 2010 NFL season at 2-14, had the right to the first selection in the draft, where they selected Auburn University quarterback Cam Newton, who was the 2010 Heisman Trophy winner. A second Heisman Trophy winner, running back Mark Ingram Jr. from Alabama was selected by New Orleans late in the first round. This was the eleventh draft which included multiple Heisman winners, and the first time ever that it has occurred in consecutive drafts (Sam Bradford and Tim Tebow in 2010). Five of the first six picks played college football in the Southeastern Conference (SEC). For the second consecutive year - and the third time in NFL history - the top two selections of the draft won Offensive and Defensive Rookie of the Year awards, respectively. The top two picks in the draft, Cam Newton and Denver linebacker Von Miller, played against each other in Super Bowl 50 on the teams that drafted them. This marked the first time that the top two picks in a single draft faced each other in the Super Bowl. The Broncos won, 24-10, with Miller winning Super Bowl MVP. Teams were allowed ten minutes to make each selection in the first round, seven minutes per selection in the second round and five minutes in each of the subsequent rounds. The time allotment ran out for the Baltimore Ravens on their first round pick, allowing the Kansas City Chiefs to move up to the 26th pick and dropping the Ravens to the 27th pick.
lm_description: The Southeastern Conference dominated the 2011 NFL Draft with 38 selections, followed closely by the Atlantic Coast Conference with 35 players chosen. The Pac-10 Conference contributed 31 players, while the Big 12 and Big Ten Conferences saw 30 and 29 of their athletes drafted, respectively. The Big East Conference had 22 players selected. The Western Athletic Conference and Mountain West Conference produced 16 and 10 draftees, respectively. Conference USA contributed 7 players, while both the Southern Conference and Sun Belt Conference each saw 5 of their athletes drafted. The Big Sky Conference had 4 selections, and both the Mid-American Conference and Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference each contributed 3 players. Several conferences, including the Colonial Athletic Association, Lone Star Conference (Division II), Missouri Valley Football Conference, Pennsylvania State Athletic Conference (Division II), and Southland Conference, each had 2 players selected. The Ivy League rounded out the selections with 1 player drafted.

title: Scottish Olympic medallists
intro: This is a list of Scottish medal winners that have competed for Great Britain at the Summer and Winter Olympic Games. This lists also contains medals won by individuals and also the Scottish medals won as part of team that included people from the other constituent country's of the United Kingdom, (England, Wales and Ireland)
lm_description: Andrew Lindsay struck gold for Scotland in the men’s eight rowing, while Shirley Robertson topped the women’s Europe class sailing and Stephanie Cook claimed the women’s modern pentathlon title. Chris Hoy and Craig MacLean sped to silver together in the men’s team sprint on the track, Ian Stark anchored the silver-medal three-day-event equestrian squad, and Gillian Lindsay and Katherine Grainger powered the women’s quadruple sculls to second place. Mark Covell added another Scottish silver in the open Star class sailing.

title: List of Atari arcade games
intro: Atari was an early pioneer in the video game industry, in fact, they virtually created the industry with their introduction of the arcade game Pong. The brand name Atari was used for many years and applied to several other entities that developed products ranging from arcade video games to home video game consoles to home computers to video games for personal computers. Below is a list of arcade video games produced by Atari. These games were produced by Atari, Inc. from 1972 to 1984 starting with Pong and Atari Games from 1984 to 2000. Atari no longer manufacturers arcade games and, in fact, the entity that now owns the brand name (French company, Infogrames) never has. For a full list of games developed or published by Atari from 1972 to 1984, see List of Atari, Inc. games.
lm_description: T-Mek, a 1994 four-player 3D vehicular combat title, put gamers inside MEK war machines to blast one another, while back in 1974 Tank let two tank commanders duel simultaneously, followed by Tank II in 1975 and the eight-player Tank 8 of 1976, the first Atari arcade board ever to carry its own CPU. Tempest arrived in 1980 with color vector graphics and a crab-shaped blaster defending tunnel mouths for up to two alternating players, and the unreleased 1996 one-on-one fighter Tenth Degree sported anime-styled 3D combatants in the Tekken mold. Atari’s 1988 Tetris offered simultaneous two-player block stacking, the same year Toobin’ sent duos paddling downstream to hurl cans at riverbank targets, while 1990’s underwater spy caper ThunderJaws cast two elite agents against Madam Q beneath the waves. The solo, unfinished 1983 flight game Tomcat never launched its F-14, yet 1974’s four-player Touch Me tested timing like a coin-op Simon, 1989’s Tournament Cyberball 2072 let four robot-football squads earn cash for upgrades, 1978’s Tournament Table served Pong-style variants for one to four, and 1977’s monochrome Triple Hunt set one lone hunter on safari.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Sullivan County, Indiana
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places listings in Sullivan County, Indiana. This is intended to be a complete list of the properties on the National Register of Historic Places in Sullivan County, Indiana, United States. Latitude and longitude coordinates are provided for many National Register properties; these locations may be seen together in a map. There are 11 properties listed on the National Register in the county. Properties and districts located in incorporated areas display the name of the municipality, while properties and districts in unincorporated areas display the name of their civil township. Properties and districts split between multiple jurisdictions display the names of all jurisdictions.
lm_description: Center Ridge Cemetery, entered on the National Register on 8 August 2018, occupies 704 W. Johnson St. in Hamilton Township. The Daugherty-Monroe Archaeological Site (12SU13), listed 12 June 1985, lies in the northern half of Section 21, Town 8 North Range 11 West within Turman Township. Merom Site and Fort Azatlan, registered 12 May 1975, stands north of Merom and is shared by Gill Township and the town itself. Merom-Gill Township Carnegie Library, added 11 March 2019, sits at 8554 Market St. in Merom. Shakamak State Park Historic District, enrolled 15 March 2000, centers on 6265 W. State Road 48 west of Jasonville in Jackson Township. Shelburn Interurban Depot-THI & E Interurban Depot, listed 15 December 2015, stands at 3 N. Railroad St. in Shelburn. The Sherman Building, entered 22 September 1986, occupies 2-4 S. Court St. in Sullivan. Sullivan County Courthouse, registered 22 December 2008, anchors 100 Courthouse Square in Sullivan. Sullivan Courthouse Square Historic District, added 4 September 2018, roughly spans the blocks bounded by Section, Wall, State, and Harris Sts. in Sullivan. Sullivan County Poor Home, listed 15 March 2000, stands at 1447 County Road 75N east of Sullivan in Hamilton Township. Union Christian College, enrolled 25 June 1982, occupies the corner of 3rd and Philip Sts. in Merom.

title: List of languages by time of extinction
intro: This is a list of extinct languages sorted by their time of extinction. A language is determined to be an extinct when its last native or fluent speaker dies. When the exact time of death of the last remaining speaker is not known, either an approximate time or the date when the language was last being recorded is given.
lm_description: Sumerian, an isolate tongue of Mesopotamia, fell silent in the early second millennium BCE. Around the same epoch Eblaite, a Semitic language, disappeared from Syria, while slightly earlier, by about 1500 BCE, the isolate Hattic had already vanished from Anatolia. Northwest Anatolia lost Palaic, another Anatolian branch member, around 1300 BCE, and within two centuries Hittite itself, the dominant Anatolian language, was extinct by roughly 1100 BCE. Hurrian, belonging to the Hurro-Urartian family, ceased to be spoken after about 1200 BCE across its wide span from Anatolia through Syria to Mesopotamia. Slightly later, after 1170 BCE, the Syrian coastal Semitic language Ugaritic also fell out of use. Finally, the still-undeciphered Cypro-Minoan script, used on Cyprus, went out of recorded use sometime between 1550 and 1050 BCE.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Spencer County, Indiana
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places listings in Spencer County, Indiana. This is intended to be a complete list of the properties and districts on the National Register of Historic Places in Spencer County, Indiana, United States. Latitude and longitude coordinates are provided for many National Register properties and districts; these locations may be seen together in a map. There are 9 properties and districts listed on the National Register in the county, including 1 National Historic Landmark. Another 2 properties were once listed but have been removed. Properties and districts located in incorporated areas display the name of the municipality, while properties and districts in unincorporated areas display the name of their civil township. Properties and districts split between multiple jurisdictions display the names of all jurisdictions.
lm_description: The Hardy-Baumgaertner House at 105 Walnut St. in Rockport entered the National Register on 29 November 2019. Huffman Mill Covered Bridge, carrying County Road 1490N across the Anderson River east of Fulda within Harrison Township, was listed 1 April 1998. Colonel William Jones House sits west of Gentryville on Troy-Vincennes Road in Jackson Township and gained recognition 12 May 1975. Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial, straddling Carter and Clay Townships along State Road 162 southeast of Lincoln City, was enrolled 15 October 1966. Lincoln Pioneer Village, at the junction of 9th Street and Eureka Road in Rockport, followed on 20 April 1998. The Rockport Historic District, roughly bounded by First, Seminary, Greenwood, Lincoln, Eighth, William, and Pearl Streets, was designated 28 August 2019. St. Boniface Church stands on State Road 545 at Fulda in Harrison Township and was listed 23 October 1980. The Mathias Sharp House, 319 S. 2nd St. in Rockport, joined the Register 16 June 1983. Spencer County Courthouse, occupying the block bounded by 2nd, 3rd, Main, and Walnut Streets in Rockport, was added 12 March 1999.

title: List of alumni of Jesus College, Oxford
intro: Jesus College is one of the constituent colleges of the University of Oxford in England. Its alumni include politicians, lawyers, bishops, poets, and academics. Some went on to become fellows of the college; 14 students later became principal of the college. It was founded in 1571 by Queen Elizabeth I, at the request of a Welsh clergyman, Hugh Price, who was Treasurer of St David's Cathedral in Pembrokeshire. The college still has strong links with Wales, and about 15% of students are Welsh. There are 340 undergraduates and 190 students carrying out postgraduate studies. Old members of Jesus College are sometimes known as Jesubites. From the world of politics, the college's alumni include two Prime Ministers (Harold Wilson of Britain and Norman Manley of Jamaica), one Speaker of the House of Commons (Sir William Williams), a co-founder of Plaid Cymru (D. J. Williams) and a co-founder of the African National Congress (Pixley ka Isaka Seme). Members of Parliament from the three main political parties in the United Kingdom have attended the college, as have politicians from Australia (Neal Blewett), New Zealand (Harold Rushworth), Sri Lanka (Lalith Athulathmudali) and the United States (Heather Wilson). The list of lawyers include one Lord Chancellor (Lord Sankey) and one Law Lord (Lord du Parcq). The list of clergy includes three Archbishops of Wales (A. G. Edwards, Glyn Simon and Gwilym Williams). Celticists associated with the college include Sir John Morris-Jones, Sir Thomas (T. H.) Parry-Williams and William John Gruffydd, whilst the list of historians includes the college's first graduate, David Powel, who published the first printed history of Wales in 1584, and the Victorian historian John Richard Green.
lm_description: John Aspinall, admitted in 1947, left without graduating to run zoos and gamble, famously skipping every lecture and abandoning his finals for Ascot. Sir John Carter took a second-class mathematics degree in 1961 and later led Commercial Union from 1994 to 1998 before chairing the National House Building Council. Sir Geoffrey Cass, graduating in 1954 with a second in PPE, steered Cambridge University Press for two decades and the Royal Shakespeare Company from 1985 to 2000. Geraint Talfan Davies read modern history between 1963 and 1966, then chaired Welsh National Opera after serving as BBC Wales Controller and Arts Council of Wales Chair. Rajeeb Dey, economics and management graduate of 2008, was named O2 X Young Entrepreneur of the Year in 2009. Ffion Hague, English BA 1989, became a writer and spouse of former Conservative leader William Hague. Sir Bernard Miller, first-class historian of 1927, chaired the John Lewis Partnership from 1955 to 1972. Alec Monk, PPE 1965, headed Gateway as chairman and chief executive from 1981 to 1989 and later Charles Wells. Beau Nash, enrolled 1692, gained fame as a dandy despite leaving without a degree amid rumours of dismissal for a local affair. Roger Parry, MLitt 1978, became a media entrepreneur and YouGov chairman. Sir Owen Roberts, third-class Literae Humaniores 1858, spent forty-one years with the Clothworkers’ Company and founded the City and Guilds of London Institute. Crispian Strachan, law graduate of 1971, served as Northumbria Police Chief Constable from 1998 to 2005. John Wynne, admitted 1688, became an industrialist and philanthropist without completing a degree.

title: List of rivers of Sri Lanka
intro: The following table lists most rivers of Sri Lanka. Since Sri Lanka is a trilingual country, some rivers may have a Sinhala name (i.e. Kalu Ganga), while other have an English name (i.e. Kelani River). In the Sinhala language, Ganga (ගඟ) translates to river, where as Oya (ඔය) translates to smaller river. [citation needed] At 335 km (208 mi), the Mahaweli River is the longest river in the island, and has drainage basin covering more than one-fifth of the island.
lm_description: Sri Lanka’s 335-km Mahaweli River rises in Horton Plains and empties at Trincomalee, while the 164-km Malvathu River starts near Dambulla and reaches the sea at Vankalai. From the same Dambulla hills, the 148-km Kala Oya flows through Wilpattu to its mouth, and the 145-km Kelani River descends from Adam’s Peak to Colombo. Ritigala feeds the 142-km Yan Oya that ends at Pulmoddai, and Kurunegala gives birth to the equally long Deduru Oya draining into Chilaw. Adam’s Peak also spawns the 138-km Walawe River, which reaches Ambalantota, and the 129-km Kalu Ganga, which finishes at Kalutara. Maduru Oya, both a river and its own source, travels 135 km to Kalkudah, whereas Hakurugammana’s 134-km Maha Oya waters Negombo. Bandarawela’s Kirindi Oya runs 117 km to Bundala, Lunugala’s Kumbukkan Oya covers 116 km to Kumana, and Namunukula’s Menik Ganga flows 114 km through Yala. Gongala’s Gin Ganga travels 113 km to Gintota, Saliyagama’s Mi Oya winds 109 km to Puttalam, and Yalkumbura’s Gal Oya covers 108 km before reaching Oluvil.

Adam’s Peak also spawns the 138-km Walawe River, which reaches Ambalantota, and the 129-km Kalu Ganga, which finishes at Kalutara. Maduru Oya, both a river and its own source, travels 135 km to Kalkudah, whereas Hakurugammana’s 134-km Maha Oya waters Negombo. Bandarawela’s Kirindi Oya runs 117 km to Bundala, Lunugala’s Kumbukkan Oya covers 116 km to Kumana, and Namunukula’s Menik Ganga flows 114 km through Yala. Gongala’s Gin Ganga travels 113 km to Gintota, Saliyagama’s Mi Oya winds 109 km to Puttalam, and Yalkumbura’s Gal Oya covers 108 km before reaching Oluvil.

title: List of World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom
intro: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) World Heritage Sites are places of importance to cultural or natural heritage as described in the UNESCO World Heritage Convention, established in 1972. There are 32 UNESCO World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom and the British Overseas Territories. The UNESCO list contains one designated site in both England and Scotland (the Frontiers of the Roman Empire) plus eighteen exclusively in England, five in Scotland, three in Wales, one in Northern Ireland, and one in each of the overseas territories of Bermuda, Gibraltar, the Pitcairn Islands, and Saint Helena. The first sites in the UK to be inscribed on the World Heritage List were Giant's Causeway and Causeway Coast; Durham Castle and Cathedral; Ironbridge Gorge; Studley Royal Park including the Ruins of Fountains Abbey; Stonehenge, Avebury and Associated Sites; and the Castles and Town Walls of King Edward in Gwynedd in 1986. The latest site to be inscribed was the Jodrell Bank Observatory in England in July 2019. The constitution of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (commonly referred to as UNESCO) was ratified in 1946 by 26 countries, including the UK. Its purpose was to provide for the conservation and protection of the worlds inheritance of books, works of art and monuments of history and science. The UK contributes £130,000 annually to the World Heritage Fund which finances the preservation of sites in developing countries. Some designated properties contain multiple sites that share a common geographical location or cultural heritage. The United Kingdom National Commission for UNESCO advises the British government, which is responsible for maintaining its World Heritage Sites, on policies regarding UNESCO. The UK National Commission for UNESCO conducted research in 2014-15 on the Wider Value of UNESCO to the UK, and found that the UK's World Heritage Sites generated an estimated £85 million from April 2014 to March 2015 through their association with the global network. World Heritage Site selection criteria i-vi are culturally related, and selection criteria vii-x are the natural criteria.
lm_description: Chatham Dockyard and its Defences in Kent, England, a 17th- to 19th-century naval complex, was listed in 2012 under UNESCO criteria ii and iv with reference 5670. Creswell Crags, the Derbyshire gorge where humans lived 60–15 thousand years ago, gained status the same year under criterion iii as entry 5671. Darwin’s Landscape Laboratory in Greater London, the 1842–1882 Down House environs where Charles Darwin refined evolution theory, was inscribed as 5672 under criteria iii and vi. Across the South Atlantic, the Island of St Helena, a natural site without specified date, entered the list as 5675 under criterion x. Mousa, Old Scatness and Jarlshof—the Zenith of Iron Age Shetland—preserve 4,000-year-old Scottish settlements and were added as 5677 under criteria iii and iv. Gwynedd’s Slate Industry of North Wales, active from the 18th to 20th centuries, became entry 5678 under criteria ii and v. Flow Country, the peat-rich Caithness and Sutherland wilderness, was listed as 5679 under natural criteria ix and x. The Twin Monastery of Wearmouth Jarrow, founded 672/3 and 681 in Tyne and Wear, joined as 5681 under criteria ii, iii, iv and vi. The Turks and Caicos Islands, a Caribbean natural site, were inscribed as 5682 under criterion x. Finally, Bath, Somerset’s part of the transnational Great Spas of Europe, spanning the 1st to 20th centuries, was added in 2014 as 5935 under criteria ii, iii, iv and vi.

title: List of covered bridges in New York
intro: This is a list of covered bridges in New York State. The New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation identifies 29 covered bridges in New York State as historic, but these are not all listed on the National Register of Historic Places. [citation needed] The New York Society of Covered Bridges lists 24 historic covered bridges. One of the NRHPs, Old Blenheim Bridge, has further been declared to be a National Historic Landmark and also has described by a Historic American Engineering Record. It may be the longest single-span covered bridge in the United States or in the world. [citation needed]
lm_description: Downsville Bridge, 174 ft long, was built in 1854 across the East Branch of the Delaware River in Delaware County and joined the National Register of Historic Places in 1999, the same year that county-mates Fitches Bridge (100 ft, 1870, West Branch), Hamden Bridge (125 ft, 1859, West Branch) and the 32-ft Lower Shavertown, or Campbell, Bridge over Trout Creek (1877) were also listed. Delaware County’s Tuscarora Club Bridge, a 38-ft 1870 span across Mill Brook, lacks that listing. Jay Bridge, a 160-ft 1857 structure, carries Essex County traffic over the Ausable River, while 50-ft Salisbury Center Bridge (1875) crosses Spruce Creek in Herkimer County and was listed in 1972. Hyde Hall Bridge, an 1825 53-ft span over Shadow Brook in Glimmerglass State Park, Otsego County, gained registry status in 1998, matched that year by Saratoga County’s 35-ft Copeland Bridge (1879) across Beecher Creek. Schoharie County’s 232-ft Blenheim Bridge, erected in 1855 across Schoharie Creek, was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1964, entered the Register in 1966, was destroyed by Tropical Storm Irene on 28 August 2011 and rebuilt 2017-2018. Sullivan County holds the NRHP-listed 98-ft Beaverkill, or Conklin, Bridge (1865), the 48-ft Bendo, or Willowemoc, Bridge (1860), the 119-ft Halls Mills Bridge (1912) over the Neversink River, and the 117-ft Van Tran Flat, formerly Mott’s Flat or Livingston Manor, Bridge (1860) across Willowemoc Creek. Tompkins County’s 115-ft Newfield Bridge (1853) crosses Cayuga Creek and was listed in 2000, the same year Ulster County’s 62-ft Ashokan, or New Paltz Campus, Bridge (1889) over Esopus Creek joined the Register, along with the 138-ft Perrine’s Bridge (1844) across the Wallkill River, which had already been listed in 1973, and the 66-ft Grants Mills Bridge (1902) over Mill Brook, listed in 1999. Ulster County also has the 27-ft Forge Bridge and 43-ft Tappan, or Kittle, Bridge, both from 1906 and spanning Dry Brook.

title: Santosh Sivan
intro: Santosh Sivan (born 8 February 1964) is an Indian cinematographer, film director, producer and actor known for his works in Malayalam cinema, Tamil cinema and Hindi cinema. Santosh graduated from the Film and Television Institute of India (FTII) and has to date completed 45 feature films and 41 documentaries. He is a founding member of the Indian Society of Cinematographers (ISC) and is the most awarded Director of Photography (DOP) in India. Santosh became the first Cinematographer in the Asia-Pacific region to join the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC) membership. As a cinematographer, he has won five National Film Awards - including four for Best Feature Film Cinematography. As of 2014, he has received eleven National Film Awards, and twenty one international awards for his works. He was awarded the Padma Shri for his contributions to Indian cinema in 2014.
lm_description: Santosh Sivan earned his first National Film Award in 1988 for directing the English short Story of Tiblu, and two years later won Best Cinematography for the Malayalam feature Perumthachan. He repeated that cinematography honour in 1991 for the Malayalam short Mohiniyattam and again in 1995 for Kalapani. Switching to the director’s chair, he guided the Hindi children’s film Halo to the 1996 National Award, then the Tamil features The Terrorist and Malli to top honours in 1998, the latter cited for its environmental message. That same year his camera work on Iruvar (Tamil) and Dil Se (Hindi) both earned National Awards for Best Cinematography. In 2004 he directed Navarasa, which was named Best Tamil Feature, while his 2008 Kannada short Prarambha won for Best Educational Film, and in 2011 he co-produced the Malayalam feature Indian Rupee, recipient of the Best Feature Film in Malayalam award.
to_index_text:
