title: List of NCAA Division I conference realignments (2000–present)
intro: N/A
lm_description: Abilene Christian moved all sports except football from Division II Lone Star to Southland while its football squad became Division I FCS independent. Adelphi’s men’s soccer dropped from Division I independent status to Northeast-10 Division II. Air Force shifted men’s soccer and swimming from MPSF to WAC, and its rifle team left independent ranks for the PRC. Alaska Nanooks men’s hockey exited CCHA for WCHA and their rifle program also joined the PRC. Albany football transitioned from NEC to CAA. Azusa Pacific women’s water polo moved from CWPA to Golden Coast. Binghamton wrestling left CAA for EIWA. Boston University, except for wrestling, left America East for Patriot League, while its wrestling followed Binghamton to EIWA. Bowling Green men’s hockey followed Alaska from CCHA to WCHA. BYU softball switched from PCSC to WCC. Butler’s non-football sports advanced from Atlantic 10 to the 2013 Big East. Charleston’s entire non-football program and its swimming teams both left SoCon and CCSA respectively for CAA. Charlotte 49ers took all sports, including football starting 2015, from Atlantic 10 to Conference USA.

title: List of football clubs in Italy
intro: This is a list of football clubs located in Italy, sorted by division, then alphabetically, and including geographical locations, home stadium information and club positions in the prior season.
lm_description: Albalonga from Albano Laziale plays at the 1,500-seat Pio XII and finished 7th in Serie D Girone G, while Arzachena, housed in the 3,100-capacity Biagio Pirina, came 6th in the same group. Avezzano ended 10th in Girone F at dei Marsi, a 3,692-seat ground, and Città di Castello took 13th in Girone E at the tiny 1,000-seat Corrado Bernicchi. Flaminia of Civita Castellana placed 9th in Girone G at Turrido Madani (1,300), Foligno 8th in Girone E at Enzo Blasone (5,650), and L’Aquila sat 16th in Lega Pro Girone B at the 7,000-seat Gran Sasso d’Italia. Lanusei finished 13th in Girone G at Lixius, Latte Dolce won Eccellenza Sardinia at Vanni Sanna (5,821), and Muravera came 12th in Girone G at Comunale. Nuorese placed 8th in Girone G at Franco Frogheri (7,000), Nuova Monterosi topped Eccellenza Lazio Girone A at Marcello Martoni, Ostia Mare 10th in Girone G at Anco Marzio (1,000), and Rieti 4th in Girone G at Centro d’Italia - Manlio Scopigno (9,980). San Teodoro were Eccellenza Sardinia runners-up at Comunale, Sansepolcro 16th in Girone E at Comunale Buitoni (2,000), Sporting Trestina won Eccellenza Umbria at Lorenzo Casini, and Torres placed 3rd in Girone G at Vanni Sanna (5,821).

title: Big Ten Conference
intro: The Big Ten Conference (stylized B1G, formerly the Western Conference and the Big Nine Conference) is the oldest Division I collegiate athletic conference in the United States. It is based in Rosemont, Illinois. For decades the conference consisted of 10 universities, while the present conference has 14 member institutions. They compete in the NCAA Division I; its football teams compete in the Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS), formerly known as Division I-A, the highest level of NCAA competition in that sport. The conference includes the flagship public university in each of 11 states stretching from New Jersey to Nebraska, as well as two additional public land-grant schools and a private university. The Big Ten Conference was established in 1895 when Purdue University president James H. Smart and representatives from the University of Chicago, University of Illinois, University of Michigan, University of Minnesota, Northwestern University, and University of Wisconsin gathered at Chicago's Palmer House Hotel to set policies aimed at regulating intercollegiate athletics. In 1899, Indiana University and the University of Iowa joined the conference to increase the membership to nine schools. In 1905, the conference was officially incorporated as the Intercollegiate Conference of Faculty Representatives. The conference is one of the nation's oldest, predating the founding of the NCAA by a decade, and was one of the first collegiate conferences to sponsor men's basketball. Big Ten member institutions are major research universities with large financial endowments and strong academic reputations. All institutions except full member University of Nebraska and associate member Notre Dame are members of the Association of American Universities. Large student enrollment is a hallmark of Big Ten Universities, as 12 of the 14 members feature enrollments of 30,000 or more students.
lm_description: Indiana’s Hoosiers play on Bill Armstrong Stadium in Bloomington, a 6,500-seat venue opened in 1981, while Minnesota’s Golden Gophers occupy the 1,000-capacity Elizabeth Lyle Robbie Stadium in Falcon Heights since 1999. Michigan State’s Spartans moved into the 2,500-seat DeMartin Soccer Complex in Lansing in 2008, and Penn State’s Nittany Lions have competed at 5,000-seat Jeffrey Field in State College since 1966. Ohio State’s Buckeyes honor Jesse Owens in the 10,000-seat Jesse Owens Memorial Stadium, which debuted in Columbus in 2001, and Wisconsin’s Badgers have used Madison’s 1,611-seat McClimon Soccer Complex since 1959. Northwestern’s Wildcats relocated to the 20,000-seat SeatGeek Stadium in Bridgeview, Illinois, in 2006, making it the largest soccer-specific home among these programs. Michigan’s Wolverines opened the 2,200-seat U-M Soccer Stadium in Ann Arbor in 2010, Rutgers’ Scarlet Knights have played at 5,000-seat Yurcak Field in Piscataway since 1994, and Maryland’s Terrapins have occupied 7,000-seat Ludwig Field in College Park since 1995.

title: Metrorail (Miami-Dade County)
intro: Metrorail, colloquially called the Metro, is the heavy rail rapid transit system of Miami and Miami-Dade County in the U.S. state of Florida. Metrorail is operated by Miami-Dade Transit (MDT), a departmental agency of Miami-Dade County. Opened in 1984, it is Florida's only rapid transit metro system, and is currently composed of two lines of 23 stations on 24.4 miles (39.3 km) of standard gauge track. Metrorail serves the urban core of Miami, connecting the urban centers of Miami International Airport, the Civic Center, Downtown Miami, and Brickell with the northern developed neighborhoods of Hialeah and Medley to the northwest, and to suburban The Roads, Coconut Grove, Coral Gables, and South Miami, ending at urban Dadeland in Kendall. Metrorail connects to the Metromover in Downtown, which provides metro service to the entirety of Downtown and Brickell. Additionally, it connects to South Florida's commuter rail system at Tri-Rail station, as well as Metrobus routes at all stations. Together with Metromover, the system saw steady ridership growth per annum, with an average of 105,500 daily passengers in 2013. In 2012, Metrorail opened its 23rd station, Miami International Airport station, at Miami International Airport (MIA), opening a newly created 16-station Orange Line between the MIA and Dadeland South stations. The new line is expected to increase ridership significantly, adding millions of riders per year, and allowing residents and visitors alike direct access from the MIA to Downtown Miami, and greater connectivity between various modes of transit throughout Miami-Dade County. Central station provides direct service to Amtrak inter-city rail services, Tri-Rail commuter rail, Greyhound Lines intercity bus, and the Rental Car Center. Miami Central Station is expected to attract 150,000 daily commuters and travelers.
lm_description: Palmetto, opened 30 May 2003, lies 31 minutes from downtown and links only to Metrobus 87, drawing 1,500 weekday riders. Okeechobee, dating to 19 May 1985, trims the ride to 26 minutes via buses 73 and 267 and counts 1,156 passengers. Hialeah, also from 1985, reaches downtown in 23 minutes on buses 29, 37, 54, 112, 135 and serves 1,408 riders. Tri-Rail station, launched 5 June 1989, offers 21-minute access plus Tri-Rail and buses 42, 112 for 1,284 riders. Northside, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Plaza, and Brownsville, all opened 18–19 May 1985, sit 19, 16, and 14 minutes out, respectively, and carry 1,496, 1,216, and 899 passengers with their varied bus connections. Miami International Airport station, newest at 28 July 2012, is 16 minutes from downtown, unites Tri-Rail, MIA Mover, and nine bus routes, and leads the northern tier with 1,776 riders. Earlington Heights and Allapattah, December 1984 veterans, are 11 and 9 minutes out, handling 1,686 and 1,930 riders. Santa Clara, Civic Center, Culmer, and Historic Overtown/Lyric Theatre, all opened December 1984 or May 1984, range 2–7 minutes from downtown; Civic Center peaks at 5,679 riders. Government Center, the system hub since 20 May 1984, records 10,818 riders through Metromover, Metrobus, Broward 95X, and Virgin Trains. Brickell, also 2 minutes out, counts 6,319 riders via Brickell Loop Metromover and multiple buses. Vizcaya, Coconut Grove, Douglas Road, and University, 1984 stations 5–12 minutes south, draw 1,265, 1,748, 3,623, and 2,041 riders, with Douglas Road adding Coral Gables Trolley.

Metrorail is operated by Miami-Dade Transit (MDT), a departmental agency of Miami-Dade County. Opened in 1984, it is Florida's only rapid transit metro system, and is currently composed of two lines of 23 stations on 24.4 miles (39.3 km) of standard gauge track. Metrorail serves the urban core of Miami, connecting the urban centers of Miami International Airport, the Civic Center, Downtown Miami, and Brickell with the northern developed neighborhoods of Hialeah and Medley to the northwest, and to suburban The Roads, Coconut Grove, Coral Gables, and South Miami, ending at urban Dadeland in Kendall. Metrorail connects to the Metromover in Downtown, which provides metro service to the entirety of Downtown and Brickell. Additionally, it connects to South Florida's commuter rail system at Tri-Rail station, as well as Metrobus routes at all stations. Together with Metromover, the system saw steady ridership growth per annum, with an average of 105,500 daily passengers in 2013. In 2012, Metrorail opened its 23rd station, Miami International Airport station, at Miami International Airport (MIA), opening a newly created 16-station Orange Line between the MIA and Dadeland South stations. The new line is expected to increase ridership significantly, adding millions of riders per year, and allowing residents and visitors alike direct access from the MIA to Downtown Miami, and greater connectivity between various modes of transit throughout Miami-Dade County. Central station provides direct service to Amtrak inter-city rail services, Tri-Rail commuter rail, Greyhound Lines intercity bus, and the Rental Car Center. Miami Central Station is expected to attract 150,000 daily commuters and travelers.
Palmetto, opened 30 May 2003, lies 31 minutes from downtown and links only to Metrobus 87, drawing 1,500 weekday riders. Okeechobee, dating to 19 May 1985, trims the ride to 26 minutes via buses 73 and 267 and counts 1,156 passengers. Hialeah, also from 1985, reaches downtown in 23 minutes on buses 29, 37, 54, 112, 135 and serves 1,408 riders. Tri-Rail station, launched 5 June 1989, offers 21-minute access plus Tri-Rail and buses 42, 112 for 1,284 riders. Northside, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Plaza, and Brownsville, all opened 18–19 May 1985, sit 19, 16, and 14 minutes out, respectively, and carry 1,496, 1,216, and 899 passengers with their varied bus connections. Miami International Airport station, newest at 28 July 2012, is 16 minutes from downtown, unites Tri-Rail, MIA Mover, and nine bus routes, and leads the northern tier with 1,776 riders. Earlington Heights and Allapattah, December 1984 veterans, are 11 and 9 minutes out, handling 1,686 and 1,930 riders. Santa Clara, Civic Center, Culmer, and Historic Overtown/Lyric Theatre, all opened December 1984 or May 1984, range 2–7 minutes from downtown; Civic Center peaks at 5,679 riders. Government Center, the system hub since 20 May 1984, records 10,818 riders through Metromover, Metrobus, Broward 95X, and Virgin Trains. Brickell, also 2 minutes out, counts 6,319 riders via Brickell Loop Metromover and multiple buses. Vizcaya, Coconut Grove, Douglas Road, and University, 1984 stations 5–12 minutes south, draw 1,265, 1,748, 3,623, and 2,041 riders, with Douglas Road adding Coral Gables Trolley.

title: Germany at the 2010 Winter Olympics
intro: Germany participated at the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. 153 athletes represented Germany, entering all 15 sports. Figure skater Sarah Hecken (aged 16) was the youngest team member, while Curling European Champion Andrea Schöpp was the oldest at 44. Three time Olympic champion André Lange (bobsleigh) was the flagbearer at the opening ceremony on 12 February 2010. German athletes earned €15,000 for a gold medal, €10,000 for a silver, and €7,500 for a bronze.
lm_description: Felix Loch captured luge men’s singles gold on 14 February, while David Möller took silver in the same event. Magdalena Neuner earned biathlon women’s pursuit gold on 16 February and added women’s mass-start gold on 21 February, having already claimed women’s sprint silver on 13 February. Tatjana Hüfner topped the women’s singles luge on 16 February. Maria Riesch dominated Alpine skiing, winning women’s super-combined gold on 18 February and slalom gold on 26 February. André Lange and Kevin Kuske piloted the two-man bobsleigh to victory on 21 February, just ahead of teammates Thomas Florschütz and Richard Adjei who secured silver. Evi Sachenbacher-Stehle and Claudia Nystad raced to cross-country women’s team-sprint gold on 22 February, the same day Tim Tscharnke and Axel Teichmann claimed men’s team-sprint silver. Viktoria Rebensburg struck giant-slalom gold on 25 February. Stephanie Beckert collected speed-skating silver in the women’s 3000 m on 14 February and again in the 5000 m on 24 February, then joined Daniela Anschütz-Thoms, Anni Friesinger-Postma and Katrin Mattscherodt to capture women’s team-pursuit gold on 27 February. Jenny Wolf sped to 500 m silver on 16 February. Kerstin Szymkowiak slid to skeleton women’s silver on 19 February. Tobias Angerer earned 30 km pursuit cross-country silver on 20 February. Michael Neumayer, Andreas Wank, Martin Schmitt and Michael Uhrmann soared to large-hill team ski-jumping silver on 22 February.

title: List of Virtual Console games for Wii U (North America)
intro: This is a list of Virtual Console games that are available on Wii U in North America. These releases take advantage of the console's unique features, such as Off TV Play with the Wii U GamePad and posting to Miiverse. Some of these games may already be available on the Wii Virtual Console, which can also be played through Wii U's Wii Mode, but these legacy versions lack some features of the Wii U Virtual Console. While Wii Virtual Console titles cannot be played using the Wii U GamePad's controls, a September 2013 system update enabled the use of the GamePad's screen as a display. While some Wii games are also available for download from the Wii U eShop, these are not designated as Virtual Console releases and lack Virtual Console features. The list is sorted by system and in the order in which they were added in Nintendo eShop for Wii U. To sort by other columns, click the corresponding icon in the header row.
lm_description: Nintendo launched the Wii U Virtual Console in North America on April 26, 2013 with its own Nintendo EAD’s Super Mario World and F-Zero, followed on May 15 by Nintendo R&D1’s Super Metroid. Capcom entered the lineup on May 16 with Capcom-developed Super Ghouls ’n Ghosts, while HAL Laboratory delivered three Kirby titles—Kirby Super Star, Kirby’s Dream Course and Kirby’s Dream Land 3—on May 23. Capcom returned May 30 with Mega Man X, and HAL’s Vegas Stakes arrived June 27. Nintendo EAD’s Pilotwings cleared the runway July 4, and the HAL/Ape collaboration EarthBound landed July 18 with a Teen rating. Natsume published Amccus’s Harvest Moon on August 1, Koei Tecmo issued Koei’s Romance of the Three Kingdoms IV: Wall of Fire on August 8, and Capcom released three Teen-rated Street Fighter II variants—The World Warrior, Turbo: Hyper Fighting and Super: The New Challengers—on August 22. Capcom’s Breath of Fire II followed September 5, and the company capped the list October 3 with three Final Fight entries: the Everyone-rated Final Fight, the Everyone 10+ Final Fight 2, and the Teen-rated Final Fight 3.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Hendry County, Florida
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places listings in Hendry County, Florida. This is intended to be a complete list of the properties and districts on the National Register of Historic Places in Hendry County, Florida, United States. The locations of National Register properties and districts for which the latitude and longitude coordinates are included below, may be seen in a map. There are 12 properties and districts listed on the National Register in the county.
lm_description: The Caldwell Home Place at 160 Curry Street in LaBelle entered the National Register on February 13, 2003. Clewiston’s educational heritage is anchored by the Clewiston Historic Schools, listed September 26, 1997, occupying 325 East Circle Drive and 475 East Osceola Avenue. Nearby, the Clewiston Inn, fronting U.S. Route 27 west of its junction with State Road 832, was honored on February 21, 1991, while the Dixie Crystal Theatre at 100 East Sugarland Highway followed on September 25, 1998. Downtown LaBelle’s historic core, the 300 block of North Bridge Street, gained district status March 25, 1999. Clewiston residential landmarks include the Capt. F. Deane Duff House at 151 West Del Monte Avenue, listed January 30, 1998; the Executive House next door at 125 West Del Monte Avenue, listed February 5, 1998; and the Scharnberg House at 325 East Del Monte Avenue, listed April 26, 1999. The First Clewiston Post Office, 111-113 Bond Street, was added March 7, 2017. LaBelle commercial heritage is represented by the Forrey Building and Annex, 264-282 Bridge Street, listed July 28, 1995. The Capt. Francis A. Hendry House, 512 Fraser Street, LaBelle, and the Old Hendry County Courthouse at the junction of Bridge Street and Hickpochee Avenue, LaBelle, were both listed February 5, 1998, and November 8, 1990, respectively.

title: List of ship launches in 1944
intro: This list of ship launches in 1944 is a list of some of the ships launched in 1944.
lm_description: On 1 March 1944 Permanente Metals’ #1 Yard at Richmond, California launched the Liberty ship John Roach, and the next day Todd Houston Shipbuilding Corporation in Houston, Texas added Anna H. Branch while Permanente Metals’ #2 Yard sent Henry M. Stephens down the ways. 3 March was busier: Walsh-Kaiser Company at Providence, Rhode Island launched Jesse H. Metcalf, Southeastern Shipbuilding Corporation at Savannah, Georgia launched John E. Sweet, Bethlehem-Fairfield Shipyards at Baltimore launched Sameden, and Kaiser Shipyards at Vancouver, Washington slid the Casablanca-class escort carrier Cape Esperance into the water. 4 March saw eight launches—Frederick C. Hicks by California Shipbuilding Corporation in Los Angeles, George Steers again by Todd Houston in Houston, Harry Toulmin by Delta Shipbuilding Company in New Orleans, the Great Lakes icebreaker Mackinaw by American Ship Building Company in Toledo, Ohio, Rebecca Lukens by J.A. Jones Construction in Panama City, Florida, Samcolne by Bethlehem-Fairfield in Baltimore, Stanton H. King by New England Shipbuilding in South Portland, Maine, and Willet M. Hays by Permanente Metals’ #2 Yard in Richmond. On 6 March Delta Shipbuilding in New Orleans launched Cecil N. Bean, Permanente Metals’ #2 Yard launched Edward E. Hale, J.A. Jones Construction in Brunswick, Georgia launched Isaac Shelby, Oregon Shipbuilding in Portland launched Netherlands Victory, and California Shipbuilding in Los Angeles launched United States Victory, the last two being Victory ships.

title: Science fiction films in India
intro: The genre of science fiction has been prevalent in the Indian film industry since the second half of the 20th century. Beginning in 1952, the film Kaadu was made, which was a Tamil-American co-production. 1963 Tamil film Kalai Arasi and 1967 Hindi film Chand Par Chadayee also have science fiction in its storyline. The Alien was a science fiction film under production in the late 1960s which was eventually cancelled. The film was being directed by Bengali Indian director Satyajit Ray and produced by Hollywood studio Columbia Pictures. The script was written by Ray in 1967, based on Bankubabur Bandhu, a Bengali story he had written in 1962 for Sandesh, the Ray family magazine. In 1987, the superhero film Mr. India was a huge success which strengthened the hold of sci-fi films in India, especially Bollywood. Indiatimes Movies ranks the movie amongst the Top 25 Must See Bollywood Films. Mr. India brought the idea of science fiction to the general people in India. In 2003, the blockbuster film Koi. Mil Gaya marked the beginning of the successful Krrish film series, which is the first sci-fi/superhero film series in Indian cinema. The 2018 Tamil film 2.0 starring Rajinikanth and Amy Jackson is one of the most expensive and the most successful sci/fi film ever produced in India.
lm_description: Kaadu, the 1952 Tamil-English co-production about woolly mammoths causing animal havoc, became India’s first science-fiction film. Shantilal Soni’s 1964 Hindi Mr.X in Bombay starred Kishore Kumar, Kum Kum and Madan Puri. Satyajit Ray’s cancelled 1965 Bengali-English project The Alien, drawn from his 1962 Sandesh tale Bankubabur Bandhu, would have shown friendly extraterrestrial Mr. Ang visiting a 1960s Bengali village. Mahesh’s 1967 Malayalam Karutha Rathrikal, starring Madhu and Gemini Ganesan with music by MS Baburaj and lyrics by ONV Kurup, re-imagined Stevenson’s Jekyll-Hyde via a split-personality drug invented by a vengeful doctor. Naresh Kumar Saxena, in the 1971 Hindi Elaan starring Vinod Mehra, Rekha and Vinod Khanna, gains invisibility through an atomic ring and battles underworld bosses. M. G. Ramachandran directed and starred in the 1973 Tamil blockbuster Ulagam Sutrum Valiban alongside M. N. Nambiar, Manjula and Thai actress Metta Roongrat. Kamal Haasan produced and headlined the 1983 Tamil Vikram, India’s first showcase of ICBMs and advanced computers. Raj N. Sippy’s 1985 Hindi superhero film Shiva Ka Insaaf starred Jackie Shroff, Poonam Dhillon and Gulshan Grover. Sasi Kumar’s 1987 Malayalam Jaithra Yaathra featured Thilakan as a scientist whose invisibility-locket empowers Nizhalgal Ravi against Babu Antony. Shekhar Kapur’s 1987 Hindi-Urdu superhero hit Mr. India, scripted by Salim-Javed, paired Anil Kapoor and Sridevi against Amrish Puri. In the 1989 Tamil Nalaya Manithan a 21st-century doctor’s resurrection drug creates an immortal zombie; its 1990 sequel Adhisaya Manithan continues the undead rampage. Ketan Desai’s 1989 Hindi Toofan cast Amitabh Bachchan in a double role as crossbow-wielding superhero Toofan and magician twin Shyam. Aditya 369, the 1991 Telugu debut of the genre, centred on a time-machine and diamond heist. Laal Paree, also 1991 Hindi, starred Aditya Pancholi and Sohani in a mermaid romance inspired by Splash. Dinesh Babu’s 2002 Kannada Hollywood showcased Upendra in a triple role including android US 47 alongside Australian actress Felicity Mason. Abhijit Chaudhuri’s 2003 Bengali Patalghar followed criminals hunting an ancient sleeping machine, while the same year’s Hindi comedy Funn2shh sent travellers to the 10th century. Rakesh Roshan’s 2003 Hindi blockbuster Koi… Mil Gaya presented Hrithik Roshan’s Rohit Mehra, a mentally-challenged youth who gains superhuman powers from a visiting alien.

title: 2013 FKF Division One
intro: The 2013 FKF Division One was the second season of FKF Division One and the Golden Jubilee second division season since it began in 1963. It began on 23 March and concluded on 21 December. On 12 April, Murang'a United were suspended from participating in the league any further for the rest of the 2013 season and relegated to the Provincial League for missing three consecutive league games, against Brighter Stars, Maweni City and Kenya Revenue Authority. They were only allowed to participate in the Provincial League from the beginning of the 2014 season, and would not be replaced by any other team during the course of the season. As a result, all their results were nullified. On 25 April, the Football Kenya Federation initially decided to slash the league to 20 teams for the 2014 season. For that to happen, it was decided that the league will consist of top 5 teams in each zone (except the two teams that win the promotion play-offs) in addition to the two relegated Premier League teams. The remaining 28 teams will be relegated to FKF Division Two, which will begin next season, along with the 8 teams promoted from the Provincial League. However, due to the creation of the Kenyan National Super League on 10 July, it was decided that top 5 teams in each zone (except the two teams that win the promotion play-offs) would be promoted to the new league along with the two relegated Premier League teams, while the remaining 28 teams along with 12 teams promoted from the Provincial League would form the new FKF Division One, which is to be the third-tier league from the beginning of the 2014 season.
lm_description: Comply and Top Fry AllStars both make Afraha Stadium in Nakuru their home, while G.F.C. 105 play at The Discipleship Grounds in Eldoret. Kisero, Swan Orchards and Timsales are each based in an unknown stadium; Kisero and Swan Orchards list no specific town, whereas Timsales hail from Elburgon. Kolongolo, Mumcop and West Kenya Sugar share Bukhungu Stadium in Kakamega, Nzoia United occupy Sudi Stadium in Bungoma, Shabana host matches at Gusii Stadium in Kisii, and Zoo Kericho play at Green Stadium in Kericho.

title: Carrier Air Wing Eleven
intro: Carrier Air Wing Eleven (CVW-11) is a United States Navy aircraft carrier air wing based at Naval Air Station Lemoore, California. The air wing is attached to the aircraft carrier USS Theodore Roosevelt.
lm_description: Carrier Air Wing Eleven embarks aboard USS Theodore Roosevelt with nine squadrons: the Black Knights of VFA-154 fly F/A-18F Super Hornets, while the Tomcatters of VFA-31, Blue Diamonds of VFA-146, and Golden Warriors of VFA-87 all operate single-seat F/A-18E Super Hornets. Overhead, the Liberty Bells of VAW-115 keep watch in their E-2C Hawkeyes, and the Gray Wolves of VAQ-142 jam enemy radars with EA-18G Growlers. Logistical lifelines are maintained by the Providers of VRC-30, Detachment 3, flying C-2A Greyhounds, while rotary-wing missions split between the Eightballers of HSC-8 with MH-60S Seahawks and the Wolfpack of HSM-75 wielding MH-60R Seahawks for maritime strike.
to_index_text:
Carrier Air Wing Eleven
Carrier Air Wing Eleven (CVW-11) is a United States Navy aircraft carrier air wing based at Naval Air Station Lemoore, California. The air wing is attached to the aircraft carrier USS Theodore Roosevelt.
Carrier Air Wing Eleven embarks aboard USS Theodore Roosevelt with nine squadrons: the Black Knights of VFA-154 fly F/A-18F Super Hornets, while the Tomcatters of VFA-31, Blue Diamonds of VFA-146, and Golden Warriors of VFA-87 all operate single-seat F/A-18E Super Hornets. Overhead, the Liberty Bells of VAW-115 keep watch in their E-2C Hawkeyes, and the Gray Wolves of VAQ-142 jam enemy radars with EA-18G Growlers. Logistical lifelines are maintained by the Providers of VRC-30, Detachment 3, flying C-2A Greyhounds, while rotary-wing missions split between the Eightballers of HSC-8 with MH-60S Seahawks and the Wolfpack of HSM-75 wielding MH-60R Seahawks for maritime strike.

title: List of submissions to the 42nd Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film
intro: The following 24 films, all from different countries, were submitted for the 42nd Academy Awards in the category Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film. The titles highlighted in blue and yellow were the five nominated films, which came from Algeria, France, Sweden, the USSR and Yugoslavia. Algeria, submitting a film for the first time, became the first African country to receive an Oscar nomination in this category. Algeria ending up winning the award (for the only time) for the political thriller Z, a co-production with France.
lm_description: Algeria’s first-ever submission, Costa-Gavras’s French-language political thriller Z, won the 42nd Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film, making Algeria the first African country both nominated and victorious. France entered Éric Rohmer’s French conversation piece My Night at Maud’s and secured a nomination, while Sweden, the USSR and Yugoslavia also reached the five-film shortlist. Among the also-rans, Austria sent Georg Lhotsky’s German drama Moss on the Stones, Belgium offered Emile Degelin’s Dutch-language Palaver, and Brazil forwarded Glauber Rocha’s Portuguese O Dragão da Maldade contra o Santo Guerreiro, released abroad as Antonio das Mortes. Czechoslovakia’s Czech entry The Cremator came from director Juraj Herz, Denmark submitted the Danish Ballad of Carl-Henning by Lene and Sven Grønlykke, and West Germany proposed Peter Fleischmann’s Bavarian hunting tale Jagdszenen aus Niederbayern. Vasilis Georgiadis represented Greece with the Greek Girls in the Sun, Tang Shu Shuen flew the flag for Hong Kong with the Chinese The Arch, and Sándor Sára brought Hungary’s Hungarian The Upthrown Stone. India’s Tamil Deiva Magan was directed by A. C. Tirulokchandar, Israel entered Gilberto Tofano’s Hebrew Siege (Matzor), and Federico Fellini offered Italy the Italian Fellini Satyricon. Shōhei Imamura’s Japanese 神々の深き欲望 became Kuragejima, Legends From a Southern Island for Japan, Choi Ha-won’s Korean 독 짓는 늙은이 was retitled The Old Craftsman of Jar for South Korea, Harry Kümel shot the Dutch Monsieur Hawarden in the Netherlands, Armando Robles Godoy made Peru’s Spanish La muralla verde (The Green Wall), Andrzej Wajda delivered Poland’s Polish Wszystko na sprzedaz (Everything for Sale), and Gheorghe Vitanidis directed Romania’s Romanian Răutăciosul adolescent (A Woman for a Season); none of these advanced to the final five.

title: Provinces of Zambia
intro: Zambia is divided into 10 provinces for administrative purposes. Each province is headed by a minister appointed by the President and there are ministries of central government for each province. The administrative head of the province is the Permanent Secretary, appointed by the President. There are Deputy Permanent Secretary, heads of government departments and civil servants at the provincial level. Provinces are further divided into districts and all the district headquarters are the same as the district names. There are nine councils in the province, each of which is headed by an elected representative, called councilor. Each councilor holds office for five years. Each council is responsible for raising and collecting local taxes and the budgets of the council are audited and submitted every year after the annual budget. Zambia has predominantly rural provinces and hence there are only three municipal councils. The government stipulates 63 different functions for the councils with the majority of them being infrastructure management and local administration. Western Province was the largest in terms of area, having 126,386 square kilometres (48,798 sq mi), while Lusaka was the smallest with 21,896 square kilometres (8,454 sq mi). In terms of population, Lusaka was the most populated and most densely populated with a population of 2,191,225 and density of 100 persons per square kilometre.
lm_description: Central Province stretches across 110,450 km² from its seat in Kabwe and holds 1,743,999 people at 15.8 per km², divided into 12 districts. On the mineral-rich Copperbelt, Ndola governs 31,328 km² that teem with 2,642,132 inhabitants at 81.2 per km² across 11 districts. Eastern Province, headquartered in Chipata, covers 51,476 km² and counts 1,961,269 residents at 38.1 per km² within 14 districts. Mansa presides over Luapula’s 50,567 km², home to 1,215,294 people at 24 per km² split into 12 districts. Lusaka Province, smallest yet most crowded, unites its capital city and 3,186,336 citizens across 23,490 km² at 135.6 per km² in just 7 districts. Muchinga, run from Chinsali, spreads across 87,806 km² with 1,011,655 people at 11.5 per km² in 10 districts. Solwezi directs sparsely peopled North-Western Province: 125,826 km² hold 902,631 residents at 7.2 per km² in 11 districts. Northern Province, centred on Kasama, occupies 77,650 km² and shelters 1,430,543 inhabitants at 18.4 per km² within 12 districts. Southern Province, governed from Choma, covers 68,410 km² and houses 1,852,361 people at 27.1 per km² across 13 districts. Western Province, largest of all, extends 126,386 km² from Mongu and contains 1,041,500 residents at 8.2 per km² in 16 districts.

title: List of Malaysian football transfers 2014
intro: The following is a list of transfers for the 2014 Malaysian football.
lm_description: In 2014, striker Ahmad Qushairi Mustafa and forward Ahmad Azriddin Rosli both joined Felda United F.C. without a transfer fee, while fellow striker Azahari Radzali moved to Perlis FA under the same free terms. Midfielders Tunku Noor Hidayat Tunku Ishak, Mohd Amirul Hisyam Awang Kechik, Muhd Azri Zulkiflee, Mohd Helmi Hariri Ibrahim, and Muhd Farhan Hazmi Mohd Nasir respectively switched to Penang FA, Harimau Muda A, Kuala Lumpur FA, Kuala Lumpur FA again, and Kuala Lumpur FA once more, all for zero fee. Defender Gusti Ishak Fitri Shah Said also arrived at Kuala Lumpur FA gratis, as did Muhd Faizzwan Dorahim at Perak FA. Utility man Muhd Syazwan Zaipol Bahari, attacking midfielder Muhammad Irfan Zakaria, and defender Mohd Faris Shah Rosli all signed for Harimau Muda B without cost. Central midfielder Muhd Azalinullah Mohd Alias and centre-back Mohd Arif Fadzilah Abu Bakar both transferred to T-Team F.C. for free, goalkeeper Abdul Gafur Samsudin went to Selangor FA on a free, and defender Muhd Azrul Zulkifli joined Sungai Ara F.C. without a fee. Finally, right-sided attacker Muhd Shahrul Hakim Rahim and attacking midfielder Muhd Syahrizal Shaharin both headed to Negeri Sembilan FA for nothing, while central midfielder Shakir Zufayri Ibrahim completed a cost-free move to Terengganu FA.

title: Norwegian First Division
intro: 1. divisjon (often referred to as OBOS-ligaen for sponsorship reasons) is the second-highest level of the Norwegian football league system. Each year, the top finishing teams in the 1. divisjon are promoted to the Eliteserien, and the lowest finishing teams are relegated to 2. divisjon. 1. divisjon was previously known as 2. divisjon (1963-1990) and replaced regional league Landsdelsserien (1951-1962) after the latter was dissolved after the 1961-62 season. The second tier was also prior to Landsdelsserien known as 1. divisjon (1948-1951). Formally, it was a semi-professional league. The tier has been restructured many times and consists of 16 teams at present.
lm_description: Aalesund, third last year, play at the 10,778-seat Color Line Stadion in Ålesund, while HamKam, who finished ninth, host matches at Briskeby Arena in Hamar with room for 7,800. Grimstad’s Jerv ended thirteenth and use the 3,300-capacity Levermyr Stadion, and Oslo’s KFUM, promoted via the 2. divisjon group 2 play-offs, now compete at the 1,500-seat KFUM Arena. Kongsvinger, eighth last season, play at Gjemselund Stadion holding 5,824, and Nest-Sotra, sixth, welcome opponents to Ågotnes Stadion on Sotra with only 1,200 seats. Raufoss earned direct promotion as group 1 winners and stage games at 2,500-capacity Nammo Stadion, whereas Sandefjord, relegated from Eliteserien in sixteenth, bring top-flight experience to Komplett Arena’s 6,582 seats. Sandnes Ulf, tenth, occupy Sandnes Stadion with 4,969 places, and Oslo’s Skeid, champions of 2. divisjon group 2, now face senior opposition at tiny 264-seat Nordre Åsen. Sogndal, fourth, play at 5,622-seat Fosshaugane Campus, Start, relegated in fifteenth, command Kristiansand’s 14,563-seat Sør Arena, Strømmen, eleventh, use 1,850-seat Strømmen Stadion, Tromsdalen, seventh, share Tromsø’s 1,695-capacity Alfheim Stadion, and Ullensaker/Kisa, fifth, host at 3,500-seat Jessheim Stadion.

title: Superliga de Voleibol Masculina
intro: The Superliga de Voleibol Masculina, (SVM) is the top level of the Spanish volleyball. The championship was founded in 1983. Formerly known as Campeonato Nacional de División de Honor Masculina, and, since 1983 as the current name. The administration of the league is carried out by the Real Federación Española de Voleibol.
lm_description: CV Teruel plays at Los Planos in Teruel, a 3,500-seat arena. Unicaja Almería hosts matches at Moisés Ruiz, which holds 1,750 spectators in Almería. Ushuaïa Ibiza Voley fills Es Viver, a 1,000-capacity venue on Ibiza. Urbia Voley Palma occupies Son Moix, the largest hall listed, with 5,076 seats in Palma. UBE L'Illa-Grau uses Ciutat Esportiva, a 700-seat facility in Castellón de la Plana. Textil Santanderina competes at Matilde de la Torre, a 1,000-seat gym in Cabezón de la Sal. Vecindario ACE Gran Canaria gathers 3,000 fans at Pabellón Municipal in Vecindario, Santa Lucía de Tirajana. Conectabalear CV Manacor plays in the intimate 500-seat Na Capellera in Manacor. Río Duero-Soria takes the court at Los Pajaritos, a 2,000-seat arena in Soria. Melilla stages home games at Javier Imbroda Ortiz, a 3,800-seat venue in the autonomous city of Melilla. FC Barcelona occupies Parc Esportiu Llobregat, a 2,500-seat complex in Barcelona. Intasa San Sadurniño closes the list at Pavillón Municipal, the smallest venue with 300 seats in San Sadurniño.

title: List of schools in the Northern Territory
intro: This is a list of schools in the Northern Territory of Australia. The Northern Territory education system traditionally consists of primary schools, which accommodate students from kindergarten to Year 6, and high schools, which accommodate students from Years 7 to 12.
lm_description: Alice Springs Steiner School opened in Ross in 2001, while Milkwood Steiner School began in Berrimah in 2004. Araluen Christian School, founded in Araluen in 1990, joins Gāwa Christian School on Elcho Island (2004), Māpuru Christian School in Mapuru (2010), Nhulunbuy Christian College (1998), Palmerston Christian School in Marlow Lagoon (1988), Sattler Christian College in Humpty Doo (1996) and Marrara Christian College in Karama (1979) as members of the NT Christian Schools network whose system office sits in Berrimah since 1991. Good Shepherd Lutheran College runs a primary campus in Palmerston City from 1997 and a secondary campus in Howard Springs from 2007, complemented by Living Waters Lutheran School in Larapinta (1987) and St Andrew Lutheran School in Leanyer (1983). Haileybury Rendall School in Berrimah opened in 2018, Nyangatjatjara College serves Yulara from 1997, Tiwi College operates on Melville Island, and Yipirinya School has served the Ciccone town camp since 1983. St Philip’s College, a Uniting school, has been in Alice Springs since 1965, and The Essington School Darwin, a Montessori school, opened in Nightcliff in 1990.

title: List of Danish football transfers summer 2010
intro: This is a list of Danish football transfers for the 2010 summer transfer window. Only moves featuring at least one Danish Superliga club are listed. The Danish Superliga 2009-10 season ended on May 16, 2010, with the Danish Superliga 2010-11 season starting on July 18, 2010. The summer transfer window opened on 1 July 2010, although a few transfers took place prior to that date; including carry-overs from the winter 2009-10 transfer window. The window closes at midnight on 31 August 2010.
lm_description: Christian Gytkjær left Lyngby for Nordsjælland on a free transfer on 2 February 2010, while Mathias Nielsen made the same cost-free switch from HB Køge to Nordsjælland on 10 April. Canadian midfielder Atiba Hutchinson departed Copenhagen for PSV Eindhoven without a fee on 22 April, and Swedish defender Benjamin Kibebe moved from Nordsjælland to Swiss club Luzern on 5 May for an undisclosed sum. Kasper Jensen joined Midtjylland from German side Paderborn on a free the next day, and on 19 May Jesper Jensen went from SønderjyskE to Vejle under undisclosed terms. Jesper Mikkelsen returned from French club Troyes to sign with Silkeborg for free on 20 May, and on 25 May both Mads Pedersen and Mark Leth Pedersen left Brøndby—Mads to Danish third-tier FCV on undisclosed terms and Mark Leth also to FCV but without a fee. Peter Ankersen completed a free move from Esbjerg to Vejle on 26 May. Henrik Ipsen followed the same free path from SønderjyskE to Vejle on 2 June 2010, while Czech Martin Raška left Midtjylland for Slovakian side Trnava on 3 June 2009 and Icelandic winger Arnór Smárason arrived at Esbjerg from Dutch club Heerenveen on 7 June 2009, both without transfer fees. When the window officially opened on 1 July 2010, six players returned from loan spells: Swedish goalkeeper Abbas Hassan to Elfsborg from AaB, Danish striker Morten Nordstrand to Copenhagen from Groningen, Danish midfielder Emil Ousager to OB from Næsby, Icelandic forward Gunnar Thorvaldsson to Esbjerg from Reading, Swedish forward Ken Fagerberg to Midtjylland from Örgryte, and Icelandic midfielder Stefan Gislason to Brøndby from Viking, while Danish defender Pierre Kanstrup also returned to Brøndby from Lyngby.

title: List of named passenger trains of Japan
intro: This article contains lists of named passenger trains in Japan.
lm_description: Akatsuki linked Kyoto to Nagasaki from 1965 until JR-West withdrew it in March 2008, while JR East’s Akebono ran nightly between Ueno and Aomori from 1970 to January 2015. JR-West’s Asakaze connected Tokyo with Shimonoseki for nearly half a century, ceasing in March 2005, and the same operator’s Twilight Express carried sleeper passengers from Ōsaka to Sapporo between 1989 and March 2015. JR East’s Cassiopeia offered luxury overnight travel from Ueno to Sapporo from 1999 to March 2016, and jointly with JR Hokkaido the Hokutosei plied the same route from 1988 until August 2015. JR Kyushu’s Dream Nichirin served Hakata to Minami-Miyazaki and Miyazaki Airport from 1993 to 2011, while its Fuji linked Tokyo with Ōita from 1964 to March 2009 and the Hayabusa ran from Tokyo to Kumamoto between 1958 and March 2009. The Naha connected Kyoto to Kumamoto from 1968 to March 2008, and the Sakura spanned Tokyo to Nagasaki from 1959 to March 2005. JR East’s Hokuriku ran between Ueno and Kanazawa from 1947 to March 2010, and its Izumo reached Izumoshi via Tottori from 1972 to March 2006. JR Hokkaido’s Marimo linked Sapporo and Kushiro from 2001 to 2008, the Rishiri joined Sapporo with Wakkanai from 2000 to 2007, and the Okhotsk ran daytime service from Sapporo to Abashiri from 1992 to March 2006. JR-West and JR East jointly operated the Nihonkai between Ōsaka and Aomori from 1968 to March 2012, while JR-West’s Suisei connected Kyoto to Minami-Miyazaki from 1968 to 2005. Since 1998 JR Central and JR-West have jointly run the Sunrise Izumo from Tokyo to Izumoshi via Okayama and the Sunrise Seto from Tokyo to Takamatsu, both still in service.

List of named passenger trains of Japan
This article contains lists of named passenger trains in Japan.
Akatsuki linked Kyoto to Nagasaki from 1965 until JR-West withdrew it in March 2008, while JR East’s Akebono ran nightly between Ueno and Aomori from 1970 to January 2015. JR-West’s Asakaze connected Tokyo with Shimonoseki for nearly half a century, ceasing in March 2005, and the same operator’s Twilight Express carried sleeper passengers from Ōsaka to Sapporo between 1989 and March 2015. JR East’s Cassiopeia offered luxury overnight travel from Ueno to Sapporo from 1999 to March 2016, and jointly with JR Hokkaido the Hokutosei plied the same route from 1988 until August 2015. JR Kyushu’s Dream Nichirin served Hakata to Minami-Miyazaki and Miyazaki Airport from 1993 to 2011, while its Fuji linked Tokyo with Ōita from 1964 to March 2009 and the Hayabusa ran from Tokyo to Kumamoto between 1958 and March 2009. The Naha connected Kyoto to Kumamoto from 1968 to March 2008, and the Sakura spanned Tokyo to Nagasaki from 1959 to March 2005. JR East’s Hokuriku ran between Ueno and Kanazawa from 1947 to March 2010, and its Izumo reached Izumoshi via Tottori from 1972 to March 2006. JR Hokkaido’s Marimo linked Sapporo and Kushiro from 2001 to 2008, the Rishiri joined Sapporo with Wakkanai from 2000 to 2007, and the Okhotsk ran daytime service from Sapporo to Abashiri from 1992 to March 2006. JR-West and JR East jointly operated the Nihonkai between Ōsaka and Aomori from 1968 to March 2012, while JR-West’s Suisei connected Kyoto to Minami-Miyazaki from 1968 to 2005. Since 1998 JR Central and JR-West have jointly run the Sunrise Izumo from Tokyo to Izumoshi via Okayama and the Sunrise Seto from Tokyo to Takamatsu, both still in service.

title: List of horror films of 1975
intro: A list of horror films released in 1975.
lm_description: In 1975 Armando Crispino’s Autopsy terrified Italian screens with Barry Primus, Mimsy Farmer and Ray Lovelock, while Hong Kong offered Lo Wei’s The Bedevilled starring O Chun Hung, Reiko Ike and James Tien, and Ho Meng Hua’s Black Magic headlined by Ti Lung and Lo Lieh. Mexico shivered to Carlos Enrique Taboada’s Blacker Than the Night with Claudia Islas, Helena Rojo, Susana Dosamantes and Lucía Méndez. The United States saw Nick Millard’s Criminally Insane fronted by Priscilla Alden, Curtis Harrington’s The Dead Don’t Die featuring George Hamilton, Linda Cristal and Joan Blondell, Peter Wolf’s Deafula with Wolf and Lee Darel, Robert Fuest’s occult The Devil’s Rain boasting Ernest Borgnine, Eddie Albert and Ida Lupino, Harry Kerwin’s God’s Bloody Acre led by Wayne Crawford, and Chris Munger’s Kiss of the Tarantula pairing Eric Mason, Suzanna Ling and Beverly Eddins. Britain contributed Freddie Francis’s The Ghoul with Peter Cushing, John Hurt and Alexandra Bastedo, Pete Walker’s House of Mortal Sin starring Anthony Sharp, Peter Sasdy’s I Don’t Want to Be Born with Joan Collins, Ralph Bates and Eileen Atkins, plus Francis again directing Peter Cushing in Legend of the Werewolf. Australia’s Terry Bourke filmed Inn of the Damned with Judith Anderson, Alex Cord and Michael Craig; Japan’s Yoichi Takabayashi offered Death at an Old Mansion with Akira Nakao and Takahiro Tamura; Italy added Massimo Dallamano’s The Cursed Medallion starring Richard Johnson, Joanna Cassidy and Ida Galli, Luigi Cozzi’s The Killer Must Kill Again with Cristina Galbó, George Hilton and Femi Benussi, and Aldo Lado’s Last Stop on the Night Train featuring Marina Berti, Franco Fabrizi and Irene Miracle. Steven Spielberg’s Jaws, starring Roy Scheider and Richard Dreyfuss, also premiered that year.

title: List of bodies of the European Union
intro: Below is a list of bodies of the European Union. The first are the seven institutions of the European Union as listed in Article 13 of the Treaty of European Union (TEU). Note that the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) and European Space Agency (ESA) are not EU bodies.
lm_description: The European Parliament convenes 785 MPs in Brussels and Strasbourg under Martin Schulz, while the European Council gathers the 28 Heads of State or Government plus the Commission President in Brussels, chaired by Donald Tusk. The Council of the European Union, also in Brussels, comprises 28 ministers led by a biannual rotating chair. Jean-Claude Juncker presides over the 28-member European Commission in Brussels. Luxembourg hosts the European Court of Justice with 27 judges and 8 Advocate-Generals under Koen Lenaerts, and the Court of Auditors with 24 members and a president, Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira, split between Brussels and Luxembourg. Frankfurt am Main is the seat of the European Central Bank, chaired by Mario Draghi. The European Investment Bank, owned by the EU member states and chaired by Werner Hoyer, is based in Luxembourg. Brussels also houses the 222-member Economic and Social Committee chaired by Georges Dassis and the 344-member European Committee of the Regions led by Markku Markkula. Emily O’Reilly serves as the European Ombudsman in Strasbourg alongside a Secretary.
to_index_text:
List of bodies of the European Union
Below is a list of bodies of the European Union. The first are the seven institutions of the European Union as listed in Article 13 of the Treaty of European Union (TEU). Note that the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) and European Space Agency (ESA) are not EU bodies.
The European Parliament convenes 785 MPs in Brussels and Strasbourg under Martin Schulz, while the European Council gathers the 28 Heads of State or Government plus the Commission President in Brussels, chaired by Donald Tusk. The Council of the European Union, also in Brussels, comprises 28 ministers led by a biannual rotating chair. Jean-Claude Juncker presides over the 28-member European Commission in Brussels. Luxembourg hosts the European Court of Justice with 27 judges and 8 Advocate-Generals under Koen Lenaerts, and the Court of Auditors with 24 members and a president, Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira, split between Brussels and Luxembourg. Frankfurt am Main is the seat of the European Central Bank, chaired by Mario Draghi. The European Investment Bank, owned by the EU member states and chaired by Werner Hoyer, is based in Luxembourg. Brussels also houses the 222-member Economic and Social Committee chaired by Georges Dassis and the 344-member European Committee of the Regions led by Markku Markkula. Emily O’Reilly serves as the European Ombudsman in Strasbourg alongside a Secretary.

title: Georgia Collegiate Athletic Association
intro: The Georgia Collegiate Athletic Association (also known as GCAA) is a college athletic conference and member of the National Junior College Athletic Association in the NJCAA Region XVII. Members of the GCAA include technical and community colleges in the U.S. state of Georgia. Conference championships are held in most sports and individuals can be named to All-Conference and All-Academic teams. The conference is the successor to the Georgia Junior College Athletic Association (GJCAA), which began in 1967. In 2010, All of the existing members of the GJCAA joined the newly organized Georgia Collegiate Athletic Association.
lm_description: The College of Coastal Georgia Mariners from Brunswick spent 2010–2011 in the GCAA before moving to the NAIA Division I Southern States Athletic Conference, the same destination later chosen by the Macon-based Middle Georgia State Knights after their 2010–2014 tenure. Young Harris Mountain Lions exited after one season, stepping up to NCAA Division II and the Peach Belt Conference. Middle Georgia Technical Titans of Warner Robins and Waycross Swamp Foxes both remained through 2013, then respectively consolidated with Central Georgia Technical College and South Georgia State College. Georgia Perimeter Jaguars from Decatur stayed until 2015 before merging into Georgia State University, while Albany’s Darton Cavaliers and Marietta’s Chattahoochee Tech Eagles both competed through 2016, after which Darton consolidated with Albany State and Chattahoochee Tech dropped sports. Georgia Northwestern Bobcats of Rome and North Georgia Wolves of Clarkesville stayed in the league indefinitely before each discontinued intercollegiate competition.

title: Scottish Olympic medallists
intro: This is a list of Scottish medal winners that have competed for Great Britain at the Summer and Winter Olympic Games. This lists also contains medals won by individuals and also the Scottish medals won as part of team that included people from the other constituent country's of the United Kingdom, (England, Wales and Ireland)
lm_description: Andy Murray struck gold for Scotland in the men’s singles tennis, while Callum Skinner topped the podium twice, first in the track-cycling men’s team sprint and later with silver in the individual sprint. On the rowing lake Heather Stanning captured gold in the women’s coxless pair and Katie Archibald did likewise in the women’s team pursuit on the track. Four Scots—Daniel Wallace, Duncan Scott, Robert Renwick and Stephen Milne—shared silver in the swimming men’s 4×200 m freestyle relay, with Scott adding another silver in the 4×100 m medley relay. Katherine Grainger rowed to silver in the women’s double sculls, Karen Bennett and Polly Swann did so in the women’s eight, David Florence in the canoe-slalom men’s C-2 team, and Mark Bennett and Mark Robertson in the rugby-sevens men’s tournament. Sally Conway claimed judo bronze in the women’s −70 kg category, and Eilidh Doyle earned athletics bronze in the women’s 4×400 m relay.

title: Alpha Media
intro: Alpha Media LLC is a radio broadcasting company based in Portland, Oregon, and led by Bob Proffitt. The group does business under the Alpha Media name. It was formed from the merger of Alpha Broadcasting, L&L Broadcasting, and Main Line Broadcasting on July 1, 2014. It owns its radio stations through Alpha Media Licensee, LLC. At its formation, it owned 68 radio stations in 12 markets, along with two theatres (in Portland and San Antonio) and a digital marketing firm in Peoria, Illinois.
lm_description: On 26 June 2013, Triad transferred six Savannah-area stations to the future Alpha Media group: WRWN 107.9 MHz in Port Royal, WGCO 98.3 MHz in Midway, WFXH-FM 106.1 MHz on Hilton Head Island, WUBB 106.9 MHz in Bluffton, WHHW 1130 kHz on Hilton Head Island, and W241CV 93.5 MHz, also on Hilton Head Island. Tama Broadcasting added WXYY 100.1 MHz in Rincon on 3 March 2014. YMF delivered five Columbia, SC signals on 27 November 2013: WWDM-FM 101.3 MHz in Sumter, WHXT-FM 103.9 MHz in Orangeburg, WMFX-FM 102.3 MHz in Saint Andrews, WARQ 93.5 MHz, and WPCO 1230 kHz, both in Columbia. The same day, YMF also transferred six Jackson, MS outlets previously acquired on 24 September 2013: WJNT 1180 kHz in Pearl, WOAD 1300 kHz, WJQS 1400 kHz, WJMI 99.7 MHz, WRKS 105.9 MHz in Pickens, and WKXI-FM 107.5 MHz in Magee. BMP Radio handed over San Antonio’s KJXK 102.7 MHz and KTSA 550 kHz in January 2014.

title: Trailwalker
intro: Trailwalker or Oxfam Trailwalker and the related Trailtrekker are fundraising endurance events conducted across the world by Oxfam, in which teams of four competitors must complete a course of 100 kilometres (62 mi) in a set time limit - typically between 24 and 48 hours. The routes may be point-to-point or follow a circular route returning to the start.
lm_description: The original Trailwalker began in 1981 on Hong Kong’s Maclehose Trail, where walkers left Pak Tam Chung in Sai Kung and had 48 hours to reach Yuen Long. Britain joined the movement in 1997 with a 30-hour South Downs crossing from Petersfield to Brighton Racecourse, later adding the circular Yorkshire Dales Trailtrekker in 2009 that starts and finishes in Skipton the same year Ireland’s 30-hour Trailtrekker ran from Donark Park to Carlingford via Newcastle, County Down. Australia staged four 48-hour events: Sydney 1999 Hawkesbury River to Seaforth, Melbourne 2003 Jells Park to Wesburn Park, Brisbane 2011 Mt Glorious to Mt Coot-tha, and Perth 2013 Darlington to Lesmurdie. New Zealand’s Whakatane edition, Edgecumbe to Whakatane in 48 hours, arrived in 2019, while Japan’s 2007 route linked Odawara City to Lake Yamanaka within the same two-day limit. Europe’s 30-hour challenges include Belgium’s 2008 High Fens trek from Bütgenbach to Eupen, France’s 2010 Parc du Morvan and 2014 Vallée d’Abondance events, and Germany’s 2010 circular Spessart route starting and ending in Bad Orb. Spain prefers 32-hour courses: 2011 Girona Olot to Sant Feliu de Guíxols and 2017 Euskadi’s loop in the Vitoria Mountains. India’s 48-hour Bengaluru and Mumbai events both launched in 2012, linking Anekal or Mekedaatu to Eagleton-Bidadi and Mulshi Lake to Lonavala respectively. Korea completed the list in 2017 with a 38-hour circuit from Gurye Natural Dream Park around Jiri Mountain.

title: List of baronies in the Peerage of Great Britain
intro: This is a list of hereditary baronies extant, extinct, dormant, abeyant, or forfeit, in the Peerage of Great Britain.
lm_description: Baron Carleton, created for the Boyle family on 19 October 1714, expired in 1725, while the same day’s creation for the Temples as Baron Cobham ended in 1749 yet left the 1718 Viscount Cobham line still alive. Watson’s Baron Throwley, also dated 19 October 1714, became extinct in 1746 after its first holder was simultaneously made Earl of Rockingham. Parker’s Baron Parker, dated 10 March 1716, survives and produced the Earls of Macclesfield in 1721. Coningsby’s barony of 18 June 1716 died with him in 1729, taking his Irish barony and the 1719 earldom with it. The Onslow barony of 19 June 1716 endures and generated the UK Earls of Onslow in 1801. Newport’s Baron Torrington of 20 June 1716 lasted only until 1719, whereas Cadogan’s Baron Cadogan of Reading, created 21 June 1716, fell extinct in 1726, though a later 1817 barony survives with the Earls Cadogan. Romney’s barony, born 22 June 1716, is extant and yielded the UK Earls of Romney in 1801. St John’s Baron St John of Battersea, dated 2 July 1716, lives on, its holder also Viscount St John from day one and Viscount Bolingbroke since 1751. Cholmondeley’s Baron Newburgh, 10 July 1716, persists, merging with the earldom and later UK marquessate of Cholmondeley. Newton’s 1717 Baroness of Hampton Court expired in 1761, having been Viscountess and then Countess Coningsby. Paulet’s 1717 Baron Pawlett of Basing died out in 1754 while his older English titles continue. Stanhope’s 1717 Baron Stanhope of Elvaston survives, the viscountcy also created that day and the earldom of 1718 now merged with the Earls of Harrington. The second Baron Cobham, created 23 May 1718 for the Temple-Grenville line, is extant, passing through marquesses and dukes of Buckingham until 1889, then uniting with the Earls Temple of Stowe and Barons Lyttelton. Boscawen’s 1720 Baron Boscawen-Rose endures, paired from birth with Viscount Falmouth and later with a short-lived UK earldom. Moreton’s 1720 Baron Ducie became extinct in 1770, though a 1763 revival continues. Wallop’s 1720 Baron Wallop survives as the viscountcy of Lymington and later earldom of Portsmouth. Lechmere’s 1721 barony ended in 1727, while Byng’s 1721 Baron Byng persists, created Viscount Torrington simultaneously.

title: List of Georgia Institute of Technology alumni
intro:
This list of Georgia Institute of Technology alumni includes graduates, non-graduate former students, and current students of Georgia Tech. Notable administration, faculty, and staff are found on the list of Georgia Institute of Technology faculty. Georgia Tech alumni are generally known as Yellow Jackets. According to the Georgia Tech Alumni Association,
.
lm_description: Robert L. Bidez, class of 1912, founded the Georgia Tech Yellow Jacket Marching Band as a student in 1908 and served as its first director. Jim Butterworth, a 1984 graduate, became a technology entrepreneur and award-winning documentary filmmaker, directing Seoul Train and holding multiple streaming-media patents. Jorge Cham, 1997, created the Piled Higher and Deeper comics while working as a Caltech post-doc. Jeff Crouse, 2006, hacks live internet data into artworks. James Crumley, 1958, wrote violent hardboiled novels, short stories, essays and screenplays. Ed Dodd, 1925, drew the Mark Trail comic strip; painter Lamar Dodd, 1928, portrayed the American South. Comedian Jeff Foxworthy, 1979, launched the Blue Collar Comedy Tour and hosted Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader? Phil Gordon, 1991, plays poker professionally. Grammy-winning producer Bones Howe, 1956, crafted 1960s–70s sunshine-pop hits for The 5th Dimension and The Association. Third Day guitarist Mark Lee graduated in 1995; romance novelist Nicole Jordan in 1976. Bollywood director-actor Nagesh Kukunoor, 1993, 1998 Miss Georgia USA Edlyn Lewis, composer Vivek Maddala, 1995, woodturner Matt Moulthrop, 2004, dance mogul Arthur Murray, 1923, indie director and Nureyev archivist Wallace Potts, 1970, Owly creator Andy Runson (BS 1998, MS 2000), and former NBA player turned TV host John Salley, 1988, all count themselves Yellow Jackets.

title: India at the Paralympics
intro: India made its Summer Paralympic début at the 1968 Games, competed again in 1972, and then was absent until the 1984 Games. The country has participated in every edition of the Summer Games since then. It has never participated in the Winter Paralympic Games. In 1972 at the Heidelberg Games, Murlikant Petkar swam the 50 meter freestyle in a world record time of 37.331 seconds to give India her first ever Gold. India finished 24th out of the 42 participating nations. In 1984, Joginder Singh Bedi won silver at the Men's Shot Put and followed it up with a pair of bronze winning performances in the Discus and Javelin throws. Another Indian, Bhimrao Kesarkar, won the silver medal in the Javelin. India finished 37th out of the 54 participating nations. After the success of the cooperative effort between the IPC and the IOC, which resulted in the 1988 Summer Paralympics in Seoul, the IPC determined the need to expand and include representatives from all nations that had disability sports programs. The 1988 Summer Paralympics were the first Paralympics in 24 years that took place in the same city as the Olympic Games. This was the first time the term Paralympic Games came into official use. They also deemed it necessary to include athletes in the decisions of the Paralympic governing body.
lm_description: Murlikant Petkar captured India’s first Paralympic gold in 1972 Heidelberg by winning the men’s 50 m freestyle 3 in swimming. Twelve years later, at the 1984 Stoke Mandeville/New York Games, Bhimrao Kesarkar took silver in the men’s javelin L6, while Joginder Singh Bedi claimed silver in the men’s shot put L6 and added bronze in both the men’s javelin L6 and discus throw L6. Devendra Jhajharia became India’s second gold medallist by triumphing in the men’s javelin F44/46 at the 2004 Athens Games, the same year Rajinder Singh Rahelu earned bronze in the men’s 56 kg powerlifting. In 2012 London, Girisha Nagarajegowda leapt to silver in the men’s high jump F42. At the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Games, Mariyappan Thangavelu soared to gold in the men’s high jump F42, Devendra Jhajharia repeated his Athens feat by again striking gold in the men’s javelin F46, Deepa Malik secured silver in the women’s shot put F53, and Varun Singh Bhati rounded out the podium with bronze in the men’s high jump F42.
to_index_text:
India at the Paralympics
India made its Summer Paralympic début at the 1968 Games, competed again in 1972, and then was absent until the 1984 Games. The country has participated in every edition of the Summer Games since then. It has never participated in the Winter Paralympic Games. In 1972 at the Heidelberg Games, Murlikant Petkar swam the 50 meter freestyle in a world record time of 37.331 seconds to give India her first ever Gold. India finished 24th out of the 42 participating nations. In 1984, Joginder Singh Bedi won silver at the Men's Shot Put and followed it up with a pair of bronze winning performances in the Discus and Javelin throws. Another Indian, Bhimrao Kesarkar, won the silver medal in the Javelin. India finished 37th out of the 54 participating nations. After the success of the cooperative effort between the IPC and the IOC, which resulted in the 1988 Summer Paralympics in Seoul, the IPC determined the need to expand and include representatives from all nations that had disability sports programs. They also deemed it necessary to include athletes in the decisions of the Paralympic governing body.

title: List of National Historic Landmarks in Mississippi
intro: This is a List of National Historic Landmarks in Mississippi. It includes current National Historic Landmarks (NHLs), and also National Park Service areas in Mississippi that overlap.
lm_description: Ammadelle, the 1859 Italianate villa Calvert Vaux designed in Oxford, Lafayette County, gained National Historic Landmark status on 30 May 1974. On 14 September 1993 the Anna Site, a Plaquemine culture archaeological location in Natchez, Adams County, was likewise designated. Arlington and Auburn, two early historic Natchez homes, joined the register on 30 May 1974, as did the unusual dual-function Commercial Bank and Banker’s House and the House on Ellicott’s Hill. Beauvoir, Jefferson Davis’s post-war Biloxi home and library in Harrison County, became an NHL on 7 November 1993, survived Hurricane Katrina, and was restored by 2008. The Champion Hill Battlefield near Bolton, Hinds County, designated 5 May 1977, marks the Civil War turning point, while the Siege and Battle of Corinth Sites, honored 6 May 1991, straddle Alcorn County, Mississippi, and Hardeman County, Tennessee. Dancing Rabbit Creek Treaty Site in Noxubee County, where Choctaw gathered before their 1830 removal, was listed 19 June 1996. Dunleith, an 1855 Natchez mansion, Emerald Mound Site in Stanton, Grand Village of the Natchez, and Holly Bluff Site in Yazoo County all commemorate Plaquemine culture. Medgar Evers’s Jackson home, designated 16 February 2017, William Faulkner’s Oxford mansion, honored 23 May 1968, Fort St. Pierre Site near Vicksburg, the 9000–7000 BC Hester Site in Monroe County, Highland Park Dentzel Carousel in Meridian, and Jaketown Site near Belzoni complete Mississippi’s NHL roster.

Dancing Rabbit Creek Treaty Site in Noxubee County, where Choctaw gathered before their 1830 removal, was listed 19 June 1996. Dunleith, an 1855 Natchez mansion, Emerald Mound Site in Stanton, Grand Village of the Natchez, and Holly Bluff Site in Yazoo County all commemorate Plaquemine culture. Medgar Evers’s Jackson home, designated 16 February 2017, William Faulkner’s Oxford mansion, honored 23 May 1968, Fort St. Pierre Site near Vicksburg, the 9000–7000 BC Hester Site in Monroe County, Highland Park Dentzel Carousel in Meridian, and Jaketown Site near Belzoni complete Mississippi’s NHL roster.

title: List of Texas Tech University alumni
intro: Texas Tech University, often referred to as Texas Tech or TTU, is a public, coeducational, research university located in Lubbock, Texas. Established on February 10, 1923, and originally known as Texas Technological College, it is the leading institution of the Texas Tech University System and has the sixth largest student body in the state of Texas. It is the only school in Texas to house an undergraduate institution, law school, and medical school at the same location. Initial enrollment in 1925 was 910 students; as of 2009, the university has 30,049 students from more than 110 countries, all 50 U.S. states and the District of Columbia. Since its first graduating class in 1927 of 26 students, Texas Tech has awarded more than 221,000 degrees, including 45,000 graduate and professional degrees to its alumni. The Texas Tech Alumni Association, with over 27,000 members, operates more than 120 chapters in cities throughout the United States and the world. Throughout Texas Tech's history, alumni have played prominent roles in many different fields. Among the university's Distinguished Alumni is Demetrio B. Lakas, President of the Republic of Panama from 1969 to 1978. Three United States Governors, Daniel I. J. Thornton, Governor of Colorado from 1951 to 1955, John Burroughs, Governor of New Mexico from 1959 to 1961, and Preston Smith, Governor of Texas from 1968 to 1972, are graduates of the university. Three astronauts, including Rick Husband, the final commander of Space Shuttle Columbia and recipient of the Congressional Space Medal of Honor. U.S. Marine Corps Major and Medal of Honor recipient, George H. O'Brien, Jr., is a distinguished alumnus. Richard E. Cavazos is a two-time Distinguished Service Cross recipient and the first Hispanic and Mexican American to advance to the rank of four-star general in the U.S. Army.
lm_description: Khalid Ali-M Aldawsari attended Texas Tech but left without graduating and was later convicted of plotting a bomb attack on the United States. Jodey Arrington earned a B.S. in 1994 and an M.P.A. in 1997, served as Chief of Staff of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, returned to Texas Tech as Chief of Staff of the university system, and was recognized as a Distinguished Alumni of the MPA Program. Valinda Bolton, class of 1986, represents District 47 in the Texas House of Representatives. Bob Bullock, a 1955 graduate, served as Texas Comptroller and Lieutenant Governor. John Burroughs, who graduated in 1929, became Governor of New Mexico. Dustin Burrows, class of 2004, has represented District 83 in the Texas House since 2014. Waggoner Carr, a 1940 alumnus, was Texas Attorney General, while his contemporary Warlick Carr became an attorney. Joel Carson III, class of 1994, sits on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. John Carter, who graduated in 1964, represents Texas’s 31st District in the U.S. House. Lauro Cavazos earned both B.S. and M.S. degrees in 1949 and 1951, later presided over Texas Tech and served as U.S. Secretary of Education. Bill G. Chapman, class of 1973, advocates for the blind and writes. Tim Cole left without graduating, was posthumously exonerated by DNA, and inspired the Tim Cole Compensation Act. Louis Conradt practiced law after attending. Kilmer B. Corbin served in the Texas Senate for District 28. Tom Craddick, class of 1965, represents District 82 in the Texas House. Samuel Ray Cummings, a 1967 graduate, is a U.S. District Judge for the Northern District of Texas. James G. Denton, class of 1938, served as Associate Justice of the Texas Supreme Court. Robert L. Duncan, class of 1976, represents District 28 in the Texas Senate. Marshall Formby, a 1932 alumnus, formerly represented District 30 in the Texas Senate.

title: International Six Days Enduro
intro: The International Six Days Enduro (ISDE), formerly known as the International Six Days Trial (ISDT), is the oldest 'off-road' motorcycle event on the FIM Calendar. The ISDT was first held in 1913 at Carlisle, England. It has occurred annually, apart from interruptions due to World War I and World War II, at various locations throughout the world. The early events were a true test of machine, rider skill, and reliability. Held on the 'roads' of that era, today most of the routes are truly 'off-road'. Originally titled the International Six Day Trial, in 1981 the FIM decided to update the name to International Six Days Enduro, the name Enduro having been devised by the Americans and popularised by many motorcycle manufacturers also greater reflected the change in the event from a trial to more akin to a rally featuring skills more associated with cross country motocross. The sport has been associated with many great motorcyclists before its 100th anniversary in 2013; this also includes women such as 1920s-30s star Marjorie Cottle. Up until 1973 the contest was always held in Europe. In 1973 it travelled for its first overseas jaunt, the United States. Since then it has been outside Europe more frequently: twice in Australia (1992 and 1998), once more in the United States (1994), Brazil (2003), New Zealand in 2006, Chile in 2007 and 2018, and Mexico in 2010. The 2014 event was held from the 3 to 8 of November in San Juan, Argentina. The event has attracted national teams from as many as 32 different countries in recent years.
lm_description: The inaugural 1913 Carlisle trial crowned the United Kingdom trio of W. B. Gibb, W. B. Little and Charlie Collers, while T. K. Teddy Hastings became the first American to start. War cancelled the 1914 Grenoble event, but Switzerland’s J. Morand, A. Robert and Eduard Gex won the revived 1920 Grenoble contest and repeated their victory at Geneva in 1921 and 1922. Sweden’s Gustav Göthe, Yngve Eriksson, Bernhard Malmberg and J. A. Bylund dominated Stockholm 1923. Belgium 1924 introduced the Silver Vase, won by Norway’s C. Vaumund, O. Graff and J. Juberget while the UK’s G. S. Arter, C. Wilson and F. W. Giles took the International Trophy. In 1925 Southampton the same British squad—Bert Kershaw, G. S. Arter and F. W. Giles—claimed both trophies, and Australia’s vase entry finished third. Buxton 1926 saw Graham Walker, J. Lidstone and P. Pike double for Britain and a ladies’ team place third for the first time. Ambleside 1927 made history when Marjorie Cottle, Edyth Foley and Louise MacLean became the only women’s team ever to win the Silver Vase, while L. Crisp, Graham Walker and F. W. Giles secured Britain’s International Trophy. Harrogate 1928 kept the UK on top through V. C. King, F. W. Neill and H. G. Uzzell, and the 1929 Munich-Geneva route rewarded G. R. Butcher, George Rowley and F. W. Neill. Italy’s Rosolino Grana, Luigi Gilera and Miro Maffeis won back-to-back trophies at Grenoble 1930 and Merano 1931. Britain regained honours in 1932 with Albert E. Perrigo, George Rowley and N. P. O. Bradley. Nazi Germany’s Ernst Jakob Henne, Josef Stelzer, Josef Mauermayer and Wiggerl Kraus triumphed at Llandrindod Wells 1933 and repeated with Wiggerl Kraus, J. Müller and teammates in Garmisch-Partenkirchen 1934 and Oberstdorf 1935, where Arthur Geiss, Walfried Winkler and Ewald Kluge also gave Germany the Vase. Britain struck back in 1936 as Vic Brittain, George Rowley, W. S. Waycott and E. Belsten won the International event, and in 1937 Brittain, Rowley, Waycott and Gordon Wolsey repeated while the Netherlands’ A. P. van Hammersveld, G. Bakker-Schut and J. Moejes captured the Vase.

title: Live with Regis and Kelly (season 18)
intro: This is a list of Live with Regis and Kelly episodes which were broadcast during the show's 18th season. The list is ordered by air date. Although the co-hosts may have read a couple of e-mails during the broadcast, it does not necessarily count as a Regis and Kelly Inbox segment.
lm_description: Regis Philbin and Kelly Ripa opened November with Billy Crystal and Mike Wallace on the 1st, followed the next day by Terrence Howard, Philip Seymour Hoffman and Kirk Franklin. James Spader visited on November 3, Jake Gyllenhaal on the 4th, and Josh Duhamel shared the couch with Simon Cowell on the 7th. 50 Cent and Peter Gallagher appeared November 8, while November 9 brought Melina Kanakaredes, LeAnn Rimes and Keira Knightley together. Robert Downey Jr., Carrot Top and Daniel Radcliffe formed an eclectic November 10 panel, and Steve Martin, Nicole Richie plus Anderson Cooper closed the second week on the 11th. Richard Gere, Donald Sutherland and Joy Philbin chatted on November 14, Reese Witherspoon and Emma Watson on the 15th, Joaquin Phoenix alongside Jesse L. Martin on the 16th. Rosario Dawson stopped by November 17, Patricia Arquette on the 18th, Usher and Alanis Morissette on the 21st. Judge Judy Sheindlin and Bradley Cooper visited November 22, a full Seinfeld reunion—Jerry Seinfeld, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Jason Alexander and Michael Richards—convened on the 23rd, Lake Bell, John Leguizamo and Jeff Garlin appeared the 25th, Felicity Huffman and NASCAR’s Carl Edwards on the 28th, and Barbara Walters, Tom Arnold and Scott Stapp wrapped the month on November 29.

title: United States Short Course Swimming Championships
intro: The United States Short Course National Championships or USA Swimming Winter Nationals is a national championship meet organized by USA Swimming. The competition is swum short course yards (SCY), in a pool 25-yards long. The meet's most recent incarnation began in 2007, and is an held annually in November or December, on the weekend previously occupied by the U.S. Open. Prior to 1991, the annual Spring version of U.S. Nationals were swum as a 25-yard meet; however, from 1991-2007, the meet was held as a long course (50m) meet. In the mid-2000s, USA Swimming decided to revive a Nationals meet in the short-course-yards format, but decided that the meet should be in December, rather than the late-March/early April time frame that the Spring Nationals had turned into. For 2016 USA Swimming returned to the old format with two short course Nationals in one year, American Short Course Championships in March in Austin and the Winter National Championships in Atlanta in December.
lm_description: Abbey Weitzeil swept the sprint freestyles for Canyon, clocking 21.12 in the 50-yard and 46.47 in the 100-yard on 5–6 March 2016 in Austin. Mallory Comerford of Louisville Cardinals took the 200-yard free in 1:41.17 on 1 December 2017 in Columbus. Katie Ledecky dominated distance, posting 4:29.54 for the 500-yard and 15:13.30 for the 1650-yard free on 4 and 6 December 2014 in Greensboro while representing Nation’s Capital. Natalie Coughlin opened the meet’s modern era with a 50.64 100-yard backstroke on 30 November 2007 in Atlanta for Cal Aquatics. Missy Franklin claimed the 200-yard back in 1:49.18 on 1 December 2012 in Austin for Colorado Stars. Alia Atkinson touched in 57.62 for the 100-yard breast on 6 December 2013 in Knoxville with South Florida, and Laura Sogar followed in the 200-yard breast at 2:05.04 on 1 December 2012 in Austin for the University of Texas. Kelsi Worrell flew to a 49.87 100-yard fly on 1 December 2017 in Columbus for Louisville Cardinals. Katinka Hosszú of USC Trojans doubled, winning the 200-yard fly in 1:51.02 on 4 December 2010 and the 400-yard IM in 4:00.03 on 3 December 2010, both in Columbus. Melanie Margalis captured the 200-yard IM in 1:52.63 on 30 November 2017 in Columbus for Florida Swimming. Relay highlights include SwimMAC Carolina’s 1:27.19 4×50-yard free on 5 December 2013 in Knoxville anchored by Arianna Vanderpool-Wallace, Louisville Cardinals’ 3:12.15 4×100-yard free on 2 December 2017 in Columbus led by Mallory Comerford’s 46.50 split, California Golden Bears’ 6:59.11 4×200-yard free on 6 December 2013 in Knoxville with Missy Franklin’s 1:42.93 lead-off, Arizona Wildcats’ 1:36.46 4×50-yard medley on 30 November 2012 in Austin capped by Margo Geer’s 21.43 anchor, and California Golden Bears’ 3:29.91 4×100-yard medley on 5 December 2013 in Knoxville featuring Elizabeth Pelton’s 51.27 backstroke lead and Missy Franklin’s 47.51 freestyle anchor.
