title: Balaji Motion Pictures
intro: Balaji Motion Pictures is a wholly owned subsidiary company of Balaji Telefilms Limited which is an Indian film production and distribution company established by Shobha Kapoor and her daughter Ekta Kapoor. Based in Mumbai, it mainly produces and distributes Hindi films. The chairman of the company is former Bollywood actor Jeetendra Kapoor.
lm_description: Balaji Motion Pictures opened its 2001 account with David Dhawan’s comedy Kyo Kii... Main Jhuth Nahin Bolta starring Govinda, Sushmita Sen and Rambha, then turned to horror in 2003 with Anurag Basu and Anil Vimal Kumar’s Kucch To Hai featuring Tusshar Kapoor, Esha Deol, Anita Hassanandani and Yash Tonk. Santram Verma’s 2004 chiller Krishna Cottage cast Sohail Khan, Isha Koppikar and Anita Hassanandani Reddy, while 2005 brought Sangeeth Sivan’s comedy-thriller Kyaa Kool Hai Hum with Tusshar Kapoor, Riteish Deshmukh, Isha Koppikar and Neha Dhupia, and Partho Mitra’s romance Koi Aap Sa headlined by Aftab Shivdasani, Anita Hassanandani, Dipannita Sharma and Himanshu Malik. Apoorva Lakhia’s 2007 crime saga Shootout at Lokhandwala crowded Amitabh Bachchan, Sanjay Dutt, Sunil Shetty, Vivek Oberoi, Arbaaz Khan, Amrita Singh, Tusshar Kapoor and Rohit Roy onto the screen, and Lakhia returned in 2008 with the crime thriller Mission Istanbul starring Vivek Oberoi, Shriya Saran and Zayed Khan. Also in 2008, Sachin Yardi’s comedy C Kkompany united Tusshar Kapoor, Anupam Kher, Rajpal Yadav and Raima Sen, while Saurabh Kabra’s social drama EMI – Liya Hai Toh Chukana Parega featured Arjun Rampal, Sanjay Dutt, Urmila Matondkar, Malaika Arora Khan, Aashish Chaudhary and Neha Oberoi. Dibakar Banerjee’s 2010 found-footage experiment Love Sex aur Dhokha introduced Anshuman Jha, Nushrat Bharucha, Sandeep Bose and Rajkummar Rao, the same year Milan Luthria’s gangster epic Once Upon a Time in Mumbaai paired Ajay Devgn and Emraan Hashmi with Kangana Ranaut and Prachi Desai. 2011 delivered Kiran Yadnyopavit’s Marathi drama Taryanche Bait with Vinay Apte, Sachin Khedekar, Ashwini Giri and Ashmita Joglekar; Raj Nidimoru and Krishna D.K.’s Hindi drama Shor in the City starring Sendhil Ramamurthy, Tusshar Kapoor and Nikhil Dwivedi; Pawan Kripalani’s horror-thriller Ragini MMS led by Rajkummar Rao and Kainaz Motivala; and Milan Luthria’s biographical hit The Dirty Picture spotlighting Vidya Balan alongside Emraan Hashmi, Tusshar Kapoor and Naseeruddin Shah. Sachin Yardi’s 2012 comedy sequel Kyaa Super Kool Hai Hum reunited Tusshar Kapoor and Riteish Deshmukh with Neha Sharma, while 2013 offered Kannan Iyer’s supernatural thriller Ek Thi Daayan with Emraan Hashmi, Konkana Sen Sharma, Huma Qureshi and Kalki Koechlin; Sanjay Gupta’s gangster crime follow-up Shootout at Wadala front-lined Anil Kapoor, John Abraham, Kangana Ranaut, Manoj Bajpayee and Tusshar Kapoor; Vikramaditya Motwane’s period romance Lootera paired Ranveer Singh and Sonakshi Sinha; and Milan Luthria closed the list with the crime-romance sequel Once Upon a Time In Mumbaai Dobara starring Akshay Kumar, Imran Khan and Sonakshi Sinha.

title: List of constituencies of the Lok Sabha
intro: The Lok Sabha, the lower house of the Parliament of India, is made up of Members of Parliament (MPs). Each MP, represents a single geographic constituency. There are currently 543 constituencies. The maximum size of the Lok Sabha as outlined in the Constitution of India is 550 members made up of up to 530 members representing people of the states of India and up to 20 members representing people from the Union Territories on the basis of their population.
lm_description: Ganganagar and Bikaner are the first two Lok Sabha seats, both reserved for Scheduled Castes, while Churu, Jhunjhunu, Sikar, Jaipur Rural, Jaipur, and Alwar follow as unreserved constituencies numbered 3 through 8. Bharatpur and Karauli-Dholpur, at positions 9 and 10, revert to SC reservation. Dausa at 11 is the first Scheduled Tribe seat, succeeded by the unreserved Tonk-Sawai Madhopur, Ajmer, Nagaur, Pali, Jodhpur, Barmer, and Jalore up to number 18. Udaipur and Banswara close the list as ST-reserved constituencies 19 and 20.
to_index_text:
List of constituencies of the Lok Sabha
The Lok Sabha, the lower house of the Parliament of India, is made up of Members of Parliament (MPs). Each MP, represents a single geographic constituency. There are currently 543 constituencies. The maximum size of the Lok Sabha as outlined in the Constitution of India is 550 members made up of up to 530 members representing people of the states of India and up to 20 members representing people from the Union Territories on the basis of their population.
Ganganagar and Bikaner are the first two Lok Sabha seats, both reserved for Scheduled Castes, while Churu, Jhunjhunu, Sikar, Jaipur Rural, Jaipur, and Alwar follow as unreserved constituencies numbered 3 through 8. Bharatpur and Karauli-Dholpur, at positions 9 and 10, revert to SC reservation. Dausa at 11 is the first Scheduled Tribe seat, succeeded by the unreserved Tonk-Sawai Madhopur, Ajmer, Nagaur, Pali, Jodhpur, Barmer, and Jalore up to number 18. Udaipur and Banswara close the list as ST-reserved constituencies 19 and 20.

title: List of schools in North Queensland
intro: This is a list of schools in the North Queensland region of Queensland, Australia, and includes schools in North West Queensland. The region is centred on the coastal cities of Townsville and Mackay, and the inland city of Mount Isa. Prior to 2015, the Queensland education system consisted of primary schools, which accommodated students from kindergarten to Year 7 (ages 5-13), and high schools, which accommodate students from Years 8 to 12 (ages 12-18). However, from 2015, Year 7 became the first year of high school.
lm_description: Abergowrie State School has served the Hinchinbrook community since 1953, while Airville State School in Burdekin dates back to 1890. Aitkenvale State School opened in Townsville in 1924, and Annandale State School joined the Townsville suburbs in 1998. Alligator Creek State School and Andergrove State School, both in Mackay, trace their origins to 1896 and 1939 respectively. Ayr hosts two Burdekin schools: Ayr State School from 1886 and Ayr East State School from 1952. Barkly Highway State School has operated in Mount Isa since 1959. Beaconsfield State School in Mackay welcomed students from 1999, while Belgian Gardens State School in Townsville has a longer history dating to 1887. Bloomsbury State School in Mackay opened in 1927, followed by Bluewater State School in Townsville in 1957. Bohlevale State School in Townsville's Bohle suburb began on 20 November 1911. Bowen State School in Whitsunday is among the oldest, established in 1865. Brandon State School and Burketown State School both opened in 1888, serving Burdekin and Burke communities respectively. Bucasia State School in Mackay started in 1985. Bwgcolman Community School on Palm Island opened in 1964, while Cameron Downs State School via Hughenden in Flinders began in 1967.

title: List of Louisiana state historic sites
intro: This List of Louisiana state historic sites contains the 17 state historic sites governed by the Office of State Parks, a division of Louisiana Department of Culture, Recreation and Tourism in the U.S. state of Louisiana, as of 2011. State historic sites were formerly known as state commemorative areas until July 1, 1999 with the passing of House Bill No. 462, which renamed them to state historic sites.
lm_description: Audubon State Historic Site occupies 100 acres in West Feliciana Parish, while Centenary State Historic Site covers 43 acres in East Feliciana Parish. Fort Jesup State Historic Site spans 21 acres in Sabine Parish, and Fort Pike State Historic Site encompasses 22 acres in Orleans Parish. Fort St. Jean Baptiste State Historic Site occupies 5 acres in Natchitoches Parish, whereas Forts Randolph and Buhlow State Historic Site covers 103 acres in Rapides Parish. Locust Grove State Historic Site comprises just 1 acre in West Feliciana Parish, contrasting with Longfellow-Evangeline State Historic Site's 157 acres in St. Martin Parish. Los Adaes State Historic Site covers 14 acres in Natchitoches Parish, and Mansfield State Historic Site spans 178 acres in De Soto Parish. Marksville State Historic Site occupies 42 acres in Avoyelles Parish, while Plaquemine Lock State Historic Site covers 14 acres in Iberville Parish. Port Hudson State Historic Site encompasses 900 acres in East Feliciana Parish, and Poverty Point State Historic Site covers 400 acres in West Carroll Parish. Rebel State Historic Site spans 46 acres in Natchitoches Parish, Rosedown Plantation State Historic Site covers 371 acres in West Feliciana Parish, and Winter Quarters State Historic Site occupies 7 acres in Tensas Parish.

title: List of oldest buildings in Canada
intro: This is a list of the oldest surviving buildings and structures of significance in each province and territory of Canada.
lm_description: Holy Trinity Anglican Church, erected in 1854 at Stanley Mission, stands as Saskatchewan’s earliest documented survivor. Batoche added two 19th-century landmarks: the Mission of St. Antoine de Padoue in 1884 and, eleven years later, the Jean Caron Sr. Farm Home. Saskatoon’s Marr Residence dates to 1885, while Duck Lake shelters both the 1880 Almighty Voice Jailhouse and an 1896 All Saints Anglican Church. Katepwa Beach’s All Saints Anglican Church was built in 1887, Cumberland House received its Powder Magazine in 1890, and Regina raised its Territorial Administration Building in 1891. Fort Qu’Appelle’s Hudson’s Bay Company Store opened in 1897, the same year the Motherwell Homestead rose at Abernethy.

title: List of Living National Treasures of Japan (performing arts)
intro: The List of Living National Treasures of Japan (performing arts) contains all the individuals and groups certified as Living National Treasures by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology of the government of Japan in the category of the performing arts (芸能, geinō). The performing arts are divided into eight categories: Gagaku, Noh, Bunraku, Kabuki, Kumi Odori, Music, Dance, and Drama. The categories are subdivided into a number of subcategories, usually by role or instrument. Those working in the performing arts are eligible for recognition either individually (Individual Certification) or as part of a group (General Certification).
lm_description: Ichikawa Jūkai III, born in 1886, became a Living National Treasure in 1960 for his tachiyaku roles in Kabuki, and Ichikawa Dannosuke VI, born 1876, received the same honor that year as a wakiyaku performer. Ichikawa Sadanji III, born 1898, was designated in 1964, followed by Nakamura Ganjirō II, born 1902, in 1967. Onoe Baikō VII and Nakamura Utaemon VI, both onnagata specialists born in 1915 and 1917 respectively, were jointly honored in 1968, the same year Onoe Taganojō III, born 1887, received recognition for his fukeonnayaku performances. Onoe Shōroku II, born 1913, and Kataoka Nizaemon XIII, born 1903, both became Living National Treasures in 1972. Bandō Mitsugorō VIII, born 1906, and Matsumoto Hakuō, born 1910, were designated in 1973 and 1975 respectively, alongside Nakamura Kanzaburō XVII, born 1909. Takemoto Hinatayū V, born 1898, and Kineya Eizaemon, born 1894, received their honors in 1978 for takemoto and nagauta contributions. Yoshimura Gorōji II, born 1901, followed in 1981. Ichimura Uzaemon XVII, born 1916, was designated in 1990, Nakamura Jakuemon IV, born 1920, in 1991, and Nakamura Tomijūrō V, born 1929, in 1994. Nakamura Matagorō II, born 1914, received recognition in 1997, and Matsushima Jusaburō V, born 1920, in 1998.

title: 2013 Big South Conference men's soccer season
intro: The 2013 Big South Conference men's soccer season will be the 30th season of men's varsity soccer in the conference. It will be the final Big South season for VMI, which will return to the Southern Conference in July 2014. The defending regular season champions are the Coastal Carolina Chanticleers, while the defending tournament champions are the Winthrop Eagles.
lm_description: The Campbell Fighting Camels play on the 1,000-seat Eakes Athletic Complex in Indianapolis, Indiana, while the Coastal Carolina Chanticleers, defending regular-season champions, host matches at the 1,000-capacity CCU Soccer Field in Conway, South Carolina. Gardner-Webb’s Runnin’ Bulldogs occupy Greene-Harbison Soccer Stadium in Boiling Springs, North Carolina, with 800 seats, and the High Point Panthers use 1,100-seat Vert Stadium in their同名 North Carolina city. Liberty’s Flames boast the Liberty Soccer Stadium in Lynchburg, Virginia, holding 2,000, twice the size of Longwood’s 350-seat Athletics Complex in Farmville, Virginia. Presbyterian’s Blue Hose fill 400-seat Martin Stadium in Clinton, South Carolina, whereas Radford’s Highlanders command Cupp Memorial Stadium, the league’s largest at 5,000, in Radford, Virginia. UNC Asheville’s Bulldogs, VMI’s Keydets, and Winthrop’s Eagles each own 1,000-seat venues—Greenwood Soccer Field in Asheville, Patchin Field in Lexington, and Eagle Field in Rock Hill, South Carolina, the latter home to the defending tournament champions.

title: Serbian SuperLiga
intro: The Serbian SuperLiga (Serbian: Суперлига Србије / Superliga Srbije), known as the Linglong Tire SuperLiga for sponsorship reasons, is a Serbian professional league for football clubs. At the top of the Serbian football league system, it is the country's primary football competition. It is contested by 16 clubs, operating a system of promotion and relegation with the Serbian First League (Prva liga Srbija, second Serbian football tier). The SuperLiga was formed during the summer of 2005 as the country's top football league competition in Serbia and Montenegro. Since summer 2006 after the secession of Montenegro from Serbia, the league only has had Serbian clubs. Serbian clubs used to compete in the Yugoslav First League. This competition was formed in 1923 and lasted until 2003. After the downfall of SFR Yugoslavia in 1991 a new Yugoslavia would be formed that would be named FR Yugoslavia with Montenegro and Serbia. They kept the name Yugoslavia until 2003 when the country changed its name to Serbia and Montenegro: this union lasted until 2006 when Montenegro gained independence and formed its own league, the Montenegrin First League. The current SuperLiga champions are Red Star Belgrade. UEFA currently ranks the league 18th in Europe of 55 leagues. The league was known as Meridian Prva liga/Super liga from 2004 until 2008.
lm_description: Red Star Belgrade topped the 2018-19 Serbian SuperLiga, the same season they first entered the top flight in 1946-47, and they play at Red Star Stadium with site crvenazvezdafk.com. Runners-up Radnički Niš date their debut season back to 1935-36, returned to the elite in 2012-13, and host matches at Stadion Čair under fkradnickinis.rs. Third-placed Partizan Belgrade also trace their continuous top-tier presence to 1946-47 and use Partizan Stadium via partizan.rs. Čukarički finished fourth, originally reached the top division in 1995-96, regained promotion in 2013-14, and occupy Čukarički Stadium with fkcukaricki.rs. Fifth-placed Mladost Lučani share the same 1995-96 first-season mark, came back up in 2014-15, and play at Mladost Stadium on fkmladostlucani.com. Napredak, sixth, first appeared in 1951, re-entered in 2016-17, and share Mladost Stadium through fknapredak.rs. Vojvodina placed seventh, debuted in 1931-32, last promoted for 1987-88, and use Karađorđe Stadium at fkvojvodina.rs. Proleter were eighth in their maiden top-flight campaign 2018-19, play at Karađorđe Stadium, and publish at fkproleternovisad.rs. Radnik Surdulica, ninth, entered in 2015-16 and stay at City Stadium via fk-radnik.com. Spartak Subotica, tenth, first played in 1946-47, last promoted in 2009-10, and host at Subotica City Stadium on fkspartak.com. Voždovac, 11th, debuted in 2005-06, returned in 2013-14, and use Voždovac Stadium at fkvozdovac.rs. Mačva, 12th, date back to 1930-31, came up in 2017-18, and play at Gradski stadion Šabac under fkmacva.com. Rad Belgrade, 13th, first reached the top in 1987-88, regained status in 2008-09, and occupy Stadion Kralj Petar I via fkrad.rs. Promoted sides entering in 2019-20 include First-League winners TSC Bačka Topola, who will debut at Bačka Topola City Stadium on fktsc.com; First-League runners-up Javor-Matis, back after first arriving in 2002-03 and using Ivanjica Stadium at fkjavor.com; and First-League third-placers Inđija, returning after their 2010-11 debut season and hosting at Inđija Stadium via fkindjija.com.

Fifth-placed Mladost Lučani share the same 1995-96 first-season mark, came back up in 2014-15, and play at Mladost Stadium on fkmladostlucani.com. Napredak, sixth, first appeared in 1951, re-entered in 2016-17, and share Mladost Stadium through fknapredak.rs. Vojvodina placed seventh, debuted in 1931-32, last promoted for 1987-88, and use Karađorđe Stadium at fkvojvodina.rs. Proleter were eighth in their maiden top-flight campaign 2018-19, play at Karađorđe Stadium, and publish at fkproleternovisad.rs. Radnik Surdulica, ninth, entered in 2015-16 and stay at City Stadium via fk-radnik.com. Spartak Subotica, tenth, first played in 1946-47, last promoted in 2009-10, and host at Subotica City Stadium on fkspartak.com. Voždovac, 11th, debuted in 2005-06, returned in 2013-14, and use Voždovac Stadium at fkvozdovac.rs. Mačva, 12th, date back to 1930-31, came up in 2017-18, and play at Gradski stadion Šabac under fkmacva.com. Rad Belgrade, 13th, first reached the top in 1987-88, regained status in 2008-09, and occupy Stadion Kralj Petar I via fkrad.rs. Promoted sides entering in 2019-20 include First-League winners TSC Bačka Topola, who will debut at Bačka Topola City Stadium on fktsc.com; First-League runners-up Javor-Matis, back after first arriving in 2002-03 and using Ivanjica Stadium at fkjavor.com; and First-League third-placers Inđija, returning after their 2010-11 debut season and hosting at Inđija Stadium via fkindjija.com.

title: Juno Award for Francophone Album of the Year
intro: The Juno Award for Francophone Album of the Year is an annual award presented by the Canadian Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (CARAS) for the best French-language album in Canada. From 1993 to 2003, it was awarded as the Best Selling Francophone Album, based entirely on album sales, but is now chosen by a jury vote.
lm_description: Luc de Larochellière won the 1992 Juno for Sauvez mon âme, edging out François Pérusse’s L’Album du peuple - Tome 1, Kathleen’s Kathleen, Les B.B.’s Snob and Vilain Pingouin’s Vilain Pingouin. Céline Dion took the 1993 prize with Dion chante Plamondon, ahead of Francis Martin’s Quand on se donne, Julie Masse’s À contre-jour and Richard Séguin’s Aux portes du matin. François Pérusse returned in 1994 to claim the award with L'Album du peuple - Tome 2, surpassing Kathleen’s Ça va bien, Laurence Jalbert’s Corridors, Mario Pelchat’s Pelchat and Roch Voisine’s Europe Tour. Roch Voisine himself triumphed in 1995 with Coup de tête, beating Éric Lapointe’s Obsession, France d’Amour’s Déchaînée, Johanne Blouin’s Johanne Blouin chante Noel and Lynda Lemay’s Y. Céline Dion dominated the next three years: D'eux in 1996 over Beau Dommage’s Beau Dommage, Lara Fabian’s Carpe diem, Mario Pelchat’s C'est la vie and Marjo’s Bohémienne; Live à Paris in 1997 over Daniel Bélanger’s Quatre saisons dans le désordre, Lara Fabian’s Pure and Luce Dufault’s self-titled album; and S'il suffisait d'aimer in 1999 against Carmen Campagne’s Enchantée, François Pérusse’s L'Album du peuple volume 1, Kevin Parent’s Grand parleur, petit faiseur and Lynda Lemay’s Lynda Lemay. Marie-Michèle Desrosiers won in 1998 with Marie-Michèle Desrosiers chante les classiques de Noël, ahead of Bruno Pelletier’s Miserere, Dubmatique’s La force de comprendre, Ginette Reno’s Versions Reno and Térez Montcalm’s Parle pas si forte. La Chicane’s En catimini earned the 2000 award, surpassing Bruno Pelletier’s D'autres rives, Jean Leloup’s Les fourmis, Lynda Lemay’s Live and the Notre-Dame de Paris version integrale cast recording. Ginette Reno’s Un grand Noël d'amour won in 2001, topping Garou’s Seul, Isabelle Boulay’s Mieux qu'ici bas and Scènes d'amour, and Nicola Ciccone’s L'Opéra du mendiant. Kevin Parent closed the decade in 2002 with Les vents ont changé, beating Gabrielle Destroismaisons’ Etc ..., La Bottine Souriante’s Cordial, La Chicane’s Disparu and Lynda Lemay’s Du coq à l’âme.

title: Gene Tierney
intro: Gene Eliza Tierney (November 19, 1920 - November 6, 1991) was an American film and stage actress. Acclaimed as a great beauty, she became established as a leading lady. Tierney was best known for her portrayal of the title character in the film Laura (1944), and was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Actress for her performance as Ellen Berent Harland in Leave Her to Heaven (1945). Tierney's other roles include Martha Strable Van Cleve in Heaven Can Wait (1943), Isabel Bradley Maturin in The Razor's Edge (1946), Lucy Muir in The Ghost and Mrs. Muir (1947), Ann Sutton in Whirlpool (1949), Maggie Carleton McNulty in The Mating Season (1951), and Anne Scott in The Left Hand of God (1955).
lm_description: Gene Tierney stepped before the cameras as herself on The Sir Charles Mendl Show in 1947, returned beside Ed Sullivan for Toast of the Town’s episode 6.33 in 1953, and at the 26th Academy Awards in 1954 handed the Costume Design trophy alongside hosts Donald O’Connor and Fredric March. She mystified the panel as the August 25 mystery guest on What’s My Line? in 1957, then played Ellen Galloway opposite host Ronald Reagan in the 1960 General Electric Theater installment “Journey to a Wedding.” In 1969 she portrayed Faye Simpson with Efrem Zimbalist, Jr. in The F.B.I. episode “Conspiracy of Silence” and Lenore Constable opposite Ray Milland in the TV movie Daughter of the Mind. Tierney chatted with Merv Griffin in 1974 and again in 1979, traded quips with Johnny Carson on The Tonight Show in 1980, visited Mike Douglas on his program the same year, and sat down with Dinah Shore for Dinah! also in 1980. She assumed the role of Harriet Toppington alongside Lindsay Wagner in the 1980 TV miniseries Scruples, and posthumously appeared via archive footage in the March 26, 1999 Biography documentary “Gene Tierney: A Shattered Portrait” hosted by Peter Graves.

Gene Tierney

title: WWE
intro: World Wrestling Entertainment, Inc., d/b/a WWE, is an American integrated media and entertainment company that is primarily known for professional wrestling. WWE has also branched out into other fields, including movies, football, and various other business ventures. The WWE name also refers to the professional wrestling promotion itself, founded in the 1950s as the Capitol Wrestling Corporation. As of 2019, it is the largest wrestling promotion in the world, holding over 500 events a year, with the roster divided up into various globally traveling brands, and is available to about 36 million viewers in more than 150 countries. The company's global headquarters is located in Stamford, Connecticut, with offices in major cities around the world. As in other professional wrestling promotions, WWE shows are not legitimate contests, but purely entertainment-based, featuring storyline-driven, scripted, and choreographed matches, though matches often include moves that can put performers at risk of injury, even death, if not performed correctly. This was first publicly acknowledged by WWE's owner Vince McMahon in 1989 to avoid taxes from athletic commissions. Since the 1980s, WWE publicly has branded its product as sports entertainment, acknowledging the product's roots in competitive sport and dramatic theater. The company's majority owner is its chairman and CEO, Vince McMahon, who retains a 42% ownership of the company's outstanding stock and 83% of the voting power. The current entity, incorporated on February 21, 1980, was previously known as Titan Sports, Inc., which was founded that same year in South Yarmouth, Massachusetts. It acquired Capitol Wrestling Corporation Ltd., the holding company for the World Wrestling Federation, in 1982. Titan was renamed World Wrestling Federation, Inc. in 1998, then World Wrestling Federation Entertainment, Inc. in 1999, and finally the current World Wrestling Entertainment, Inc. in 2002.
lm_description: Baron Corbin became 2019 King of the Ring on September 16 in Knoxville by defeating Chad Gable in the tournament final. That same May 19 in Hartford, Brock Lesnar captured the men’s Money in the Bank briefcase after outlasting Baron Corbin, Drew McIntyre, Ali, Andrade, Randy Orton, Ricochet and Finn Bálor, while Bayley won the women’s ladder match over Carmella, Dana Brooke, Ember Moon, Mandy Rose, Naomi, Natalya and Nikki Cross. Drew McIntyre punched his ticket to WrestleMania by winning the 2020 men’s Royal Rumble in Houston on January 26, last ousting Roman Reigns, and Charlotte Flair claimed the women’s Rumble that same night by lastly eliminating Shayna Baszler. In Winter Park on January 29, 2020, The BroserWeights—Matt Riddle and Pete Dunne—took the Dusty Rhodes Tag Team Classic trophy by beating The Grizzled Young Veterans in the final. Braun Strowman won the André the Giant Memorial Battle Royal at WrestleMania 35 in East Rutherford on April 7, 2019, last dumping Colin Jost, and Carmella won the WrestleMania Women’s Battle Royal there by lastly dispatching Sarah Logan. Finally, The O.C.—Luke Gallows and Karl Anderson—won the 2019 WWE World Cup tag turmoil in Riyadh on October 31, lastly ousting the Viking Raiders.

title: Multistars
intro: Multistars is an annual international athletics competition held in Desenzano del Garda (from 1988-2013) and Florence (from 2013 onwards), Italy in early May or late April. International athletes compete in the combined events, decathlon for men and heptathlon for women. Established in 1988, it is part of the IAAF World Combined Events Challenge circuit.
lm_description: Sasa Karan opened the 1988 Multistars with 7554 points while Christine Hoss totaled 5547. Alex Karan lifted the British flag in 1989 by scoring 7637 and Kim Hagger added 6047. Miguel Valle’s 7385 carried Cuba to the 1990 title and Liliana Năstase raised her Romanian record to 6342. Robert Změlík dominated the early nineties, first posting 8297 for Czechoslovakia in 1991 as Năstase climbed to 6482, then repeating in 1992 with 8086 while she peaked at 6565. Sheldon Blockburger’s 8296 gave the United States the 1993 crown as Bulgaria’s Svetla Dimitrova reached 6470. Sándor Munkácsi claimed 7895 for Hungary in 1994 and Belarusian Svetlana Buraga produced 6284. Indrek Kaseorg’s 7998 earned Estonia the 1995 victory; Irina Vostrikova managed 6106. Změlík, now competing for the Czech Republic, returned in 1996 with 8232 while Italy’s Karin Periginelli scored 5887. Beniamino Poserina delighted the home crowd in 1997 by totaling 8069 and Poland’s Urszula Włodarczyk added 6063. Oleksandr Yurkov made it two Ukrainian wins, 8034 in 1998 and 8215 in 1999, as Irina Vostrikova improved to 6162 and Italy’s Gertrud Bacher reached 6185. Jiří Ryba’s 8339 topped 2000 and Kazakhstan’s Svetlana Kazanina managed 6111. Indrek Kaseorg repeated in 2001 with 7834 while Kazanina rose to 6159. Jaakko Ojaniemi’s 8092 gave Finland 2002 and Julie Hollman posted 6093. Dmitriy Karpov scored 8253 for Kazakhstan in 2003 as Ghana’s Margaret Simpson earned 5952. Claston Bernard’s 8050 brought Jamaica the 2004 title and France’s Marie Collonvillé totaled 6228. Phil McMullen registered 8107 for the United States in 2005 while Simpson added 6006. Chris Boyles scored 7855 in 2006 and Poland’s Karolina Tymińska reached 6178. Paul Terek closed the sequence in 2007 with 8134 and Great Britain’s Jessica Ennis amassed 6388.

title: List of nature centers in Mississippi
intro: This is a list of nature centers and environmental education centers in the state of Mississippi. To use the sortable tables: click on the icons at the top of each column to sort that column in alphabetical order; click again for reverse alphabetical order.
lm_description: The Box Environmental Education Center in Brooksville, Noxubee County, sits on the 48,000-acre Sam D. Hamilton Noxubee National Wildlife Refuge and is run by the Starkville School District. Clinton’s 33-acre Clinton Community Nature Center serves Hinds County from the Southwest region. Over in Jackson County’s Southeast corner, the 18,400-acre Grand Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve near Moss Point hosts the Grand Bay Coastal Resources Center Interpretative Area, while the same city also offers the Pascagoula River Audubon Center managed by the National Audubon Society and the City-run Scranton Nature Center inside IG Levy Park. Jackson itself is home to the Mississippi Museum of Natural Science, a Southwest-region natural-history museum with aquarium displays and 2.5 miles of trails tucked within LeFleur’s Bluff State Park. Columbus hosts the Plymouth Bluff Center, an outdoor-education facility run by Mississippi University for Women with its own museum on the Lowndes County landscape of East Central Mississippi. North of them all, the Strawberry Plains Audubon Center spreads across 2,500 Holly Springs acres under National Audubon Society care and showcases a restored 1850s mansion.

title: List of auto racing tracks in the United States
intro: This is a list of all auto racing tracks in the United States. The track length stands for the standard, full courses for each track. The major series listed are only series that currently hold a race at the track.
lm_description: New York City, top-ranked, has no active major tracks but once hosted Meadowlands, Bridgehampton and Trenton. Los Angeles keeps two major tracks including Fontana while Ontario and Riverside are gone. Chicago’s lone current oval is Chicagoland after Cicero closed. Baltimore/Washington, now trackless, lost Baltimore, Marlboro and RFK Stadium. San Jose/San Francisco still runs two majors and once had San Jose and Altamont. Boston’s New Hampshire supplies its single active venue. Philadelphia relies on Pocono after Langhorne, Flemington and Nazareth shut. Dallas/Fort Worth races at Texas with Dallas defunct. Miami uses Homestead, having shed two Miami venues plus West Palm Beach. Houston has none left after Houston and Texas closed. Atlanta and Detroit each count two majors, Atlanta and Michigan respectively. Seattle retains one, Phoenix keeps its oval while an earlier Phoenix faded, Minneapolis/St. Paul, Cleveland and Denver lost their namesakes, San Diego’s Del Mar is gone, Portland never had one, and Orlando’s Daytona endures after Walt Disney World disappeared.

title: 2008 in spaceflight
intro: The year 2008 contained several significant events in spaceflight, including the first flyby of Mercury by a spacecraft since 1975, the discovery of water ice on Mars by the Phoenix spacecraft, which landed in May, the first Chinese spacewalk in September, and the launch of the first Indian Lunar probe in October.
lm_description: Baikonur in Kazakhstan led 2008’s launch tally with 19 missions, 18 fully successful and one partial failure, while Russia’s Plesetsk added six flawless flights and Dombarovsky and Kapustin Yar each contributed one success. The United States split its 11 launches between Cape Canaveral (3), Kennedy (4) and Vandenberg (4), every one rated a success. France’s Kourou site sent up six rockets, all successful, and the Ocean Odyssey platform, flagged International, logged five successes. China conducted 11 launches across Jiuquan (3), Taiyuan (4) and Xichang (4) without a single failure. Japan’s Tanegashima flew once, successfully, and India’s Satish Dhawan matched that perfect record with three launches. Iran’s sole attempt from Semnan ended in failure, while Kwajalein Atoll in the Marshall Islands saw one failure among its four launches.
to_index_text:
2008 in spaceflight

Iran’s sole attempt from Semnan ended in failure, while Kwajalein Atoll in the Marshall Islands saw one failure among its four launches.

title: List of fictional antiheroes
intro: This list is for characters in fictional works who exemplify the qualities of an antihero - a protagonist whose characteristics include the following:
lm_description: Batman, created by Bill Finger and Bob Kane, debuted in Detective Comics #27 in May 1939 as a DC Comics antihero, followed by fellow Gothamite Catwoman in Batman #1 during 1940. Marvel’s irreverent Deadpool first cracked wise in The New Mutants #98 in February 1991, while the Hulk smashed onto newsstands in May 1962 in The Incredible Hulk #1, and Iron Man rocketed from Tales of Suspense #39 in March 1963, both from Stan Lee’s stable. Indian vigilante Doga appeared in 1993’s Curfew, crafted by Sanjay Gupta, Tarun Kumar Wahi and artist Manu, whereas Robert Crumb’s counter-culture feline Fritz the Cat dates back to 1959. Jason Todd, resurrected as the lethal Red Hood, returned in Batman #635 in 2005, and Jhonen Vasquez’s homicidal Johnny C. began his spree in Johnny the Homicidal Maniac #1 in August 1995, both under DC’s banner. Alan Moore, Stephen R. Bissette and John Totleben introduced chain-smoking mystic John Constantine in The Saga of the Swamp Thing #37 in June 1985. Garth Ennis and Steve Dillon launched preacher Jesse Custer in Preacher #1 in April 1995. Magneto, created by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby, first menaced the X-Men in The X-Men #1 in September 1963. Frank Miller’s Marv arrived in The Hard Goodbye in April 1991, with Dwight following in A Dame to Kill For in November 1993. Gerry Conway, John Romita Sr. and Ross Andru debuted the Punisher in The Amazing Spider-Man #129 in February 1974, while Todd McFarlane’s Spawn #1 appeared in May 1992. Bill Everett’s Sub-Mariner predates them all, surfacing in Motion Picture Funnies Weekly in April 1939. Alan Moore and David Lloyd’s masked anarchist V struck in Warrior #1 in March 1982, and Roy Thomas, Len Wein and John Romita Sr. unveiled Wolverine in The Incredible Hulk #180 in October 1974.

List of fictional antiheroes
This list is for characters in fictional works who exemplify the qualities of an antihero - a protagonist whose characteristics include the following:
Batman, created by Bill Finger and Bob Kane, debuted in Detective Comics #27 in May 1939 as a DC Comics antihero, followed by fellow Gothamite Catwoman in Batman #1 during 1940. Marvel’s irreverent Deadpool first cracked wise in The New Mutants #98 in February 1991, while the Hulk smashed onto newsstands in May 1962 in The Incredible Hulk #1, and Iron Man rocketed from Tales of Suspense #39 in March 1963, both from Stan Lee’s stable. Indian vigilante Doga appeared in 1993’s Curfew, crafted by Sanjay Gupta, Tarun Kumar Wahi and artist Manu, whereas Robert Crumb’s counter-culture feline Fritz the Cat dates back to 1959. Jason Todd, resurrected as the lethal Red Hood, returned in Batman #635 in 2005, and Jhonen Vasquez’s homicidal Johnny C. began his spree in Johnny the Homicidal Maniac #1 in August 1995, both under DC’s banner. Alan Moore, Stephen R. Bissette and John Totleben introduced chain-smoking mystic John Constantine in The Saga of the Swamp Thing #37 in June 1985. title: 2013 Latvian Higher League
intro: The 2013 Latvian Higher League was the 22nd season of top-tier football in Latvia. FC Daugava were the defending champions. The season started on 29 March 2013. The league comprised ten teams. The champions of this season were FK Ventspils, followed by Skonto FC
lm_description: FC Daugava Daugavpils entered the 2013 Latvian Higher League under Ivan Tabanov, with Daniel Ola captaining the side in Erreà kits that bore no shirt sponsor. FK Daugava Rīga, managed by Virginijus Liubšys and led by Mantas Savenas, wore Nike shirts, likewise without a sponsor. Alens Vinakurovs guided Ilūkstes NSS with Dmitri Kozlov as skipper, the team also in unsponsored Erreà strips. Sergejs Golubevs’ FK Jelgava paired Deniss Petrenko’s captaincy with Macron kits sponsored by Igate. Mihails Koņevs’ FC Jūrmala relied on Alberts Nikoļskis in unsponsored Givova attire. Jānis Intenbergs’ SK Liepājas Metalurgs fielded Antons Jemeļins as captain in sponsor-free Adidas gear. Andris Riherts’ FS Metta/LU had Artūrs Biezais wearing Nike shirts carrying the SMS Credit.lv logo. Tamaz Pertia’s Skonto FC, skippered by Juris Laizāns, wore Jako kits sponsored by Granat Investment. Jurijs Popkovs led FK Spartaks Jūrmala with Dmitrijs Daņilovs in unsponsored Nike shirts. Champions FK Ventspils, managed by Jurģis Pučinsks and captained by Vitālijs Smirnovs, played the season in Adidas kits bearing the VK Tranzīts logo.

title: Wade Trophy
intro: The Wade Trophy is an award presented annually to the best women's basketball player in National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Division I competition. It is named after three-time national champion Delta State University coach Lily Margaret Wade. The award debuted in 1978 as the first-ever women's national player of the year award in college basketball. State Farm Insurance sponsors the award, and the trophy is presented at the Women's Basketball Coaches Association (WBCA) National Convention. Connecticut has the most all-time winners with nine. Maya Moore is the only player to win the Wade Trophy three times, accomplishing the feat in 2009 (only sophomore ever to win the award), 2010 and 2011. Other multiple award winners include Nancy Lieberman (1979, 1980), Seimone Augustus (2005, 2006), Brittney Griner (2012, 2013), and fellow UConn alum Breanna Stewart (2015, 2016). Three schools are tied for second place in total recipients: Louisiana Tech, Old Dominion, and Texas have three winners apiece. There have never been any ties for the award.
lm_description: Carol Blazejowski of Montclair State opened the Wade Trophy era as the 1977-78 senior forward. Old Dominion guard Nancy Lieberman followed with back-to-back honors, winning as a junior in 1978-79 and repeating the next year as a senior. Kansas senior guard Lynette Woodard claimed 1980-81, Louisiana Tech senior center Pam Kelly took 1981-82, and Long Beach State senior guard LaTaunya Pollard earned 1982-83. Janice Lawrence Braxton, a Louisiana Tech senior forward, won 1983-84, USC junior forward Cheryl Miller dominated 1984-85, Texas senior guard Kamie Ethridge captured 1985-86, and Villanova senior forward Shelly Pennefather closed the decade with the 1986-87 award. Louisiana Tech senior guard Teresa Weatherspoon won 1987-88, Texas senior forward Clarissa Davis followed in 1988-89, and Stanford senior guard Jennifer Azzi earned 1989-90. Tennessee senior center Daedra Charles won 1990-91, Penn State senior forward Susan Robinson took 1991-92, Nebraska senior forward Karen Jennings earned 1992-93, and Minnesota senior forward Carol Ann Shudlick claimed 1993-94. Connecticut began its trophy streak when senior center Rebecca Lobo won 1994-95, senior guard Jennifer Rizzotti repeated in 1995-96, and Florida senior forward DeLisha Milton completed the span by winning 1996-97.

title: Hammer throw
intro: The hammer throw is one of the four throwing events in regular track and field competitions, along with the discus throw, shot put and javelin. The hammer used in this sport is not like any of the tools also called by that name. It consists of a metal ball attached by a steel wire to a grip. The size of the ball varies between men's and women's competitions (see Competition section below for details).
lm_description: Yuriy Sedykh’s 86.74-metre heave in Stuttgart on 30 August 1986 still crowns the all-time list, while fellow Soviet Sergey Litvinov trails at 86.04 m from Dresden two months earlier. Vadim Devyatovskiy reached 84.90 m in Minsk on 21 July 2005, Koji Murofushi of Japan launched 84.86 m in Prague on 29 June 2003, and Belarusian Igor Astapkovich recorded 84.62 m in Seville on 6 June 1992. Ivan Tsikhan’s 84.51 m came in Grodno on 9 July 2008, Igor Nikulin’s 84.48 m in Lausanne on 12 July 1990, and Jüri Tamm’s 84.40 m in Banská Bystrica on 9 September 1984. Adrián Annus threw 84.19 m in Szombathely on 10 August 2003, Paweł Fajdek 83.93 m in Szczecin on 9 August 2015, and Tibor Gécsek 83.68 m in Zalaegerszeg on 19 September 1998. Andrey Abduvaliyev achieved 83.46 m in Sochi on 26 May 1990, Aleksey Zagornyi 83.43 m in Adler on 10 February 2002, Ralf Haber 83.40 m in Athens on 16 May 1988, and Szymon Ziółkowski 83.38 m in Edmonton on 5 August 2001. Olli-Pekka Karjalainen’s 83.30 m came in Lahti on 14 July 2004, Heinz Weis 83.04 m in Frankfurt on 29 June 1997, Balázs Kiss 83.00 m in Saint-Denis on 4 June 1998, Karsten Kobs 82.78 m in Dortmund on 26 June 1999, and Krisztián Pars 82.69 m in Zürich on 16 August 2014.

title: List of University of Oregon faculty and staff
intro: This List of University of Oregon faculty and staff includes presidents, staff, and faculty of the University of Oregon.
lm_description: James E. Brau holds the Philip H. Knight Professorship of Natural Science at the University of Oregon, directs its Center for High Energy Physics, and is noted for his work on the ATLAS experiment at CERN’s Large Hadron Collider, LIGO, and the International Linear Collider. Former chemistry professor Carlos Bustamante is a molecular biologist, while Patrick G. Carrick once directed the Shared Laser Facility. Katharine Cashman, formerly the Philip H. Knight Professor of Natural Science, is a geologist and vulcanologist; Thomas Condon, once a geology professor, was a geologist and paleontologist. Russell Donnelly, retired physics chair, gained renown in low-temperature physics, and visiting assistant psychology professor Jon Driver served temporarily in the department. Sarah Ann Douglas is Professor Emerita of Computer & Information Science, elected to the European Academy of Sciences in 2002 for pioneering human-computer interaction research. Ira Herskowitz, former Institute of Molecular Biology professor, is a geneticist; Stephen Hsu, ex-theoretical physics professor, co-founded SafeWeb. Ray Hyman, psychology professor emeritus, helped found modern skepticism. Ramesh Jasti, chemistry professor, first synthesized cycloparaphenylene, Huaxin Lin is a mathematics professor, and Eugene Luks, computer-science professor emeritus, is known for graph-isomorphism and computational-group-theory algorithms. Stephanie A. Majewski, assistant physics professor, received a Department of Energy Early Career Research award for experimental high-energy particle physics. Brian Matthews, physics professor emeritus, is a biochemist and biophysicist; Helen Neville, psychology and neuroscience professor, is a neuroscientist. Ivan M. Niven, former mathematics professor and ex-president of the Mathematics Association of America, was a number theorist. Aaron Novick founded the Institute of Molecular Biology and was a Manhattan Project member, and Geraldine Richmond, chemistry professor, is a National Medal of Science recipient.

title: George Arliss
intro: George Arliss (born Augustus George Andrews, 10 April 1868 - 5 February 1946) was an English actor, author, playwright and filmmaker who found success in the United States. He was the first British actor to win an Academy Award[citation needed] - which he won for his performance as Victorian-era British prime minister Benjamin Disraeli in Disraeli (1929), as well as the earliest-born actor to win the honour.
lm_description: George Arliss first appeared on screen in 1921 as the enigmatic Dr. Muller in “The Devil” and that same year won acclaim portraying Benjamin Disraeli in “Disraeli.” Through 1922 he embodied Montgomery Royle, a pianist turned recluse, in “The Man Who Played God,” played shipping magnate James Alden in “The Ruling Passion,” and appeared as himself in “The Starland Review.” He then assumed the turban of the Rajah of Rukh for 1923’s “The Green Goddess,” became frugal inventor John Reeves in 1924’s “Twenty Dollars a Week,” and reprised Disraeli for the 1929 sound remake that earned him an Oscar. Arliss returned as the Raja of Rukh in 1930’s “The Green Goddess” and portrayed stubborn sea-captain Sylvanus Heythorp in “Old English.” In 1931 he took the title role of Alexander Hamilton and again played James Alden in “The Millionaire.” During 1932 he revisited Montgomery Royle and appeared as financier Henry Wilton in “A Successful Calamity.” He embodied Voltaire in 1933, revived John Reeves in “The Working Man,” and played Phillip, the King, in “The King’s Vacation.” His final 1934 performances cast him as the Duke of Wellington in “The Iron Duke,” Cabot Barr in “The Last Gentleman,” and both Mayer and Nathan Rothschild in “The House of Rothschild.”

title: List of Belgian football transfers summer 2012
intro: This is a list of Belgian football transfers for the 2012 summer transfer window. Only transfers involving a team from the Belgian Pro League are listed. The summer transfer window will open on 1 July 2012, although some transfers took place prior to that date. Players without a club may join one at any time, either during or in between transfer windows. The transfer window ends on 31 August 2012, although a few completed transfers could still only be announced a few days later.
lm_description: On 2 June 2012 Jimmy Kamghain left Paris Saint-Germain for Kortrijk on undisclosed terms while Tail Schoonjans moved from OH Leuven to Sint-Niklaas for free. Three days later Wout Bastiaens transferred from Westerlo to OH Leuven on an undisclosed fee, Jonas Buyse and Kevin Packet both joined Wetteren on loan from Cercle Brugge, and Donovan Deekman left Lokeren for Sparta with the fee undisclosed. Ivan Lendrić arrived at Zulte Waregem from Hajduk Split and Jef Vogels went from Gent to Rupel Boom, both on undisclosed terms, on 6 June. Guy Dufour switched from Standard Liège to Sint-Truiden on 8 June, the same day that Charly, Lamisha and Tika Musonda all left Anderlecht for Chelsea in undisclosed deals, while Romain Reynaud joined Kortrijk from Châteauroux. Jesper Jørgensen’s 1.5 million-euro move from Gent to Club Brugge went through on 9 June, when Blanstel Koussalouka arrived at Kortrijk from AS Monaco and Stefan Mitrović joined the same club from Metalac Gornji Milanovac, all fees undisclosed. Nick Van Belle and Jonathan Wilmet both headed to Westerlo from Club Brugge and Mechelen respectively on 10 June, and the following day Dudu Biton left Charleroi for Standard Liège while Ludovic Buysens moved from Sint-Truiden to OH Leuven, each transfer again on undisclosed terms.

title: 2012 Carolina RailHawks FC season
intro: The 2012 Carolina RailHawks FC season was the sixth season of the club's existence. The RailHawks FC, played in the North American Soccer League, the second tier of the American soccer pyramid. The RailHawks are the defending NASL Regular Season Champions.
lm_description: Floyd Franks wore the number 0 shirt as a United States midfielder, while fellow Americans Akira Fitzgerald, Nicolas Platter and Ray Burse guarded goal wearing 1, 12 and 18 respectively. Scottish defender Greg Shields patrolled the back line in number 2, joined by American Kupono Low at 3, Costa Rican James Scott at 6, Americans Austen King at 15, Jamie Finch at 16 and Togolese Gale Agbossoumonde at 17. The midfield corps featured Americans Tommy Drake in 4, Amir Lowery in 5, Austin da Luz in 7, Luke Sassano in 8, Mike Palacio in 10 and Nick Millington representing Guyana in 14, with Polish Konrad Warzycha also claiming 6 and South African Ty Shipalane wearing 11. Up front, United States forwards Jason Garey and Brian Ackley sported numbers 9 and 13 respectively.

title: El Gran Show (season 1 of 2011)
intro: Season one of the 2011 edition of El Gran Show premiered on April 14, 2011. This season, the public's favorite couple was not realized more in the program. In addition, the lifeguard was added, a special wildcard that the judges could use to save one of the eliminated couples. On July 23, 2011, Raúl Zuazo and Dayana Calla were crowned champions, Leslie Shaw and Kevin Ubillus finished second, while Vanessa Terkes and Andy Sandoval finished third.
lm_description: Former footballer Carlos Kukín Flores and his dreamer Victoria Cordero were the first to leave on June 11, 2011, followed by actress-vedette Leysi Suárez with Eder Bocanegra six days later. Actress-TV host Mónica Hoyos and Edson del Carpio exited third on July 9, while race-car driver Mario Hart and Diana Burga were eliminated fourth on July 23. That same night saw the departure of actor-TV host-screenwriter Aldo Miyashiro and Isabel Acevedo. Actress Vanessa Terkes and Andy Sandoval secured third place, singer-model-actress Leslie Shaw with Kevin Ubillus claimed runner-up, and actor-film director Raúl Zuazo alongside Dayana Calla were crowned champions on July 23, 2011.

title: List of Michigan State Historic Sites
intro: The following is a List of Michigan State Historic Sites. The register is maintained by the Michigan State Historic Preservation Office, which was established in the late 1960s after the passage of the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966. Sites marked with a dagger (†) are also listed on the National Register of Historic Places in Michigan. Those with a double dagger (‡) are also designated National Historic Landmarks. As of June 2011, there were more than 2,700 total listings distributed through each of Michigan's 83 counties. In addition, several historical markers have been erected outside of Michigan.
lm_description: Alabaster’s US Gypsum quarry at the corner of Benson and Turtle roads became a Michigan State Historic Site on 8 August 1963, while the Alabaster Historic District—bounded by Lake Huron, Gypsum, Keystone, and Rempert roads—earned both state recognition and National Register status on 16 December 1977. Oscoda claims the Edward A. Brackenridge House at 218 West Dwight Street, listed 26 November 1985; the Cooke Hydroelectric Plant at 1201 Cooke Dam Road, listed 2 August 1996 and also on the National Register; the Dock Reserve informational site on the beach at the foot of Michigan, River Road, Dwight and Park streets, listed 21 July 1988; and the Green Pack House at 5014 N US-23, listed 27 January 1983. Au Sable’s Louis Chevalier Claim Informational Site stands at 295 Harbor Street, listed 29 July 1980. Glennie’s Five Channels Dam Archeological District, 6051 State Route 65, joined the state register and the National Register on 13 March 2002. East Tawas hosts the Ladies Literary Club Building at 316 Newman Street, listed 5 April 1974, and the Lumbering on the Huron Shore informational designation within Tawas Point State Park, dating to 19 July 1956. Oscoda Township’s Lumberman’s Memorial at 5401 Monument Road was listed 19 February 1958, while Grant Township’s Pioneer Township Cemetery at 4252 Old State Road followed on 1 September 1963. Tawas Point Light Station on Tawas Point Road, near East Tawas, gained dual state and National Register recognition on 23 April 1971.
to_index_text:
List of Michigan State Historic Sites
The following is a List of Michigan State Historic Sites. The register is maintained by the Michigan State Historic Preservation Office, which was established in the late 1960s after the passage of the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966. Sites marked with a dagger (†) are also listed on the National Register of Historic Places in Michigan. Those with a double dagger (‡) are also designated National Historic Landmarks. As of June 2011, there were more than 2,700 total listings distributed through each of Michigan's 83 counties. In addition, several historical markers have been erected outside of Michigan.
Alabaster’s US Gypsum quarry at the corner of Benson and Turtle roads became a Michigan State Historic Site on 8 August 1963, while the Alabaster Historic District—bounded by Lake Huron, Gypsum, Keystone, and Rempert roads—earned both state recognition and National Register status on 16 December 1977. Oscoda claims the Edward A. Brackenridge House at 218 West Dwight Street, listed 26 November 1985; the Cooke Hydroelectric Plant at 1201 Cooke Dam Road, listed 2 August 1996 and also on the National Register; the Dock Reserve informational site on the beach at the foot of Michigan, River Road, Dwight and Park streets, listed 21 July 1988; and the Green Pack House at 5014 N US-23, listed 27 January 1983. Au Sable’s Louis Chevalier Claim Informational Site stands at 295 Harbor Street, listed 29 July 1980. Glennie’s Five Channels Dam Archeological District, 6051 State Route 65, joined the state register and the National Register on 13 March 2002. East Tawas hosts the Ladies Literary Club Building at 316 Newman Street, listed 5 April 1974, and the Lumbering on the Huron Shore informational designation within Tawas Point State Park, dating to 19 July 1956. Oscoda Township’s Lumberman’s Memorial at 5401 Monument Road was listed 19 February 1958, while Grant Township’s Pioneer Township Cemetery at 4252 Old State Road followed on 1 September 1963. Tawas Point Light Station on Tawas Point Road, near East Tawas, gained dual state and National Register recognition on 23 April 1971.

title: 2011 in the Philippines
intro: 2011 in the Philippines details events of note that happened in the Philippines in the year 2011.
lm_description: On 2 February 2011 Star Cinema opened the year with Chito S. Roño’s horror-comedy “Bulong,” pairing Vhong Navarro and Angelica Panganiban, followed five days later by Marilou Diaz-Abaya’s drama “Ikaw Ang Pag-ibig,” which united Jomari Yllana, Ina Feleo, Eddie Garcia, Marvin Agustin and Jaime Fabregas under Star Cinema and Unitel Productions. Valentine’s season brought GMA Films’ anthology “My Valentine Girls,” directed by Dominic Zapata, Andoy Ranay and Chris Martinez and starring Richard Gutierrez, Solenn Heussaff, Lovi Poe, Eugene Domingo, Rhian Ramos and Jillian Ward. March laughter came from Wenn V. Deramas’ Viva Films release “Who’s That Girl” with Anne Curtis, Luis Manzano and Eugene Domingo, and from Mae Cruz’s Star Cinema hit “Catch Me, I’m in Love” starring Gerald Anderson, Sarah Geronimo and Matteo Guidicelli. April stayed comic as Tony Y Reyes’ “Pak! Pak! My Dr. Kwak!” teamed Vic Sotto, Bea Alonzo, Pokwang, Zaijan Jaranilla and Xyriel Manabat via Star Cinema & MZet. Olivia M. Lamasan’s May romance “In the Name of Love” paired Angel Locsin and Aga Muhlach for Star Cinema, while Cathy Garcia-Molina’s June entry “Forever and a Day” matched Sam Milby and KC Concepcion. July doubled the fun: Chris Martinez’s “Temptation Island” gathered Marian Rivera, Heart Evangelista, Lovi Poe, Solenn Heussaff, Rufa Mae Quinto and John Lapus for Regal & GMA Films, and Soxie H. Topacio’s “The Adventures of Pureza” starred Melai Cantiveros and Jason Francisco via Star Cinema & SineScreen.

title: 2012 in Australian television
intro: This is a list of Australian television events and premieres which occurred, or are scheduled to occur, in 2012, the 57th year of continuous operation of television in Australia.
lm_description: 20th Century Fox Animation’s 2012 output reached Network Ten and its digital offshoot Eleven, while Showtime’s movie channels handled subscription viewing. DreamWorks Animation split its library: older titles stayed on Seven and Nine plus 7mate and GO!, but new releases shifted to Network Ten, Eleven and Showtime, with Movie Network retaining the back-catalogue pay rights. Nickelodeon Movies followed the same Ten/Eleven/Showtime path. Pixar films screened on Seven Network and its digital siblings 7Two and 7mate, and on pay they rotated through Movie Network, Disney Channel and Disney Junior. Sony Pictures Animation’s run on Nine Network and GO! was set to expire late 2012, after which Showtime movie channels would take over. Universal Animation Studios parked its titles on Seven and 7mate with Showtime carriage. Vanguard Animation likewise used Nine and GO! free-to-air and Showtime on pay. Walt Disney Animation Studios mirrored Pixar’s pattern: Seven, 7Two, 7mate free-to-air and Movie Network, Disney Channel, Disney Junior for subscribers. Warner Bros. Animation kept to Nine and GO! on broadcast, while Movie Network and Cartoon Network shared the pay-window.

title: List of baronies in the Peerage of Ireland
intro: This page, one list of hereditary baronies, lists all baronies, extant, extinct, dormant, abeyant, or forfeit, in the Peerage of Ireland.
lm_description: Baron Athenry, created in 1172 for the Bermingham family, slipped into dormancy in 1799 after having also held the Earl of Louth title until that peerage expired. The de Courcy line still holds the 1223-created Baron Kingsale, while the Fitzmaurice family’s Baron Kerry of the same year survives and now graces the Marquess of Lansdowne. FitzGerald’s Baron Desmond, dating from 1259, was forfeited in 1582 after centuries of also being Earl of Desmond. Barry’s Baron Barry, begun in 1261, lasted until 1823, having added Viscount Buttevant and Earl of Barrymore along the way. Butler (later Clifford-Butler) has held Baron Dunboyne since 1324, confirmed by 1541 letters patent. Preston’s Baron Gormanston, created c. 1370, remains extant and also yields the Viscount Gormanston and a UK peerage; Preston’s younger-title Baron Loundres, created 1478, is subsidiary to that viscountcy. Fleming’s Baron Slane, also c. 1370, was forfeited in 1691. St Lawrence’s Baron Howth (1430) expired in 1909 after accumulating Viscount St Lawrence and Earl of Howth. Plunkett’s Baron of Dunsany, perhaps 1439, survives, whereas Plunkett’s Baron Killeen (1449) lasted until 1984 while also serving as Earl of Fingall. Fitzeustace’s Baron Portlester (1462) ended in 1496; Barnewall’s Baron Trimlestown of the same year endures. Bold’s Baron Ratoath (1468) vanished in 1479. Nugent’s Baron Delvin (1486) stands today, later becoming Earl of Westmeath and briefly UK Marquess of Westmeath. Eustace’s Baron Kilcullen (1535), subsidiary to Viscount Baltinglass, was forfeited in 1585. Power’s Baron Power (1535), under the Earl of Tyrone, was forfeited in 1704. Fitzmaurice’s Baron Odorney (1537) expired in 1541. O Conor Faly’s Baron Offaly (1538) ended in 1552.

title: List of GM-EMD locomotives
intro: The following is a list of locomotives produced by the Electro-Motive Corporation (EMC), and its successors General Motors Electro-Motive Division (GM-EMD) and Electro-Motive Diesel (EMD).
lm_description: The FT, built from 1939-1945, paired 555 A units with 541 B units to deliver 2,700 hp through twin EMD 16-567 engines on a B-B+B-B wheel plan. In 1946 the F2 offered 1,350 hp from a single EMD 16-567B, with 74 A and 30 B units, while the longer F3 run of 1946-1949 raised output to 1,500 hp and totaled 1,111 A and 696 B units. The F7, produced 1949-1953, kept the 1,500 hp rating and 567B engine but grew to 2,366 A and 1,483 B units; its passenger variant FP7, built the same years, omitted B units and delivered 1,500 hp to 381 A units. The F9, 1953-1960, upgraded to the 567C for 1,750 hp and comprised 99 A and 156 B units, mirrored by the FP9 of 1954-1959 with 90 A units and 1,750 hp. Finally, the unique 1956-1960 FL9 used a B-A1A layout, could draw 660 V DC from third rail, and offered either 567C at 1,750 hp or 567D1 at 1,800 hp across 60 locomotives.
to_index_text:
List of GM-EMD locomotives
The following is a list of locomotives produced by the Electro-Motive Corporation (EMC), and its successors General Motors Electro-Motive Division (GM-EMD) and Electro-Motive Diesel (EMD).
The FT, built from 1939-1945, paired 555 A units with 541 B units to deliver 2,700 hp through twin EMD 16-567 engines on a B-B+B-B wheel plan. In 1946 the F2 offered 1,350 hp from a single EMD 16-567B, with 74 A and 30 B units, while the longer F3 run of 1946-1949 raised output to 1,500 hp and totaled 1,111 A and 696 B units. The F7, produced 1949-1953, kept the 1,500 hp rating and 567B engine but grew to 2,366 A and 1,483 B units; its passenger variant FP7, built the same years, omitted B units and delivered 1,500 hp to 381 A units. The F9, 1953-1960, upgraded to the 567C for 1,750 hp and comprised 99 A and 156 B units, mirrored by the FP9 of 1954-1959 with 90 A units and 1,750 hp. Finally, the unique 1956-1960 FL9 used a B-A1A layout, could draw 660 V DC from third rail, and offered either 567C at 1,750 hp or 567D1 at 1,800 hp across 60 locomotives.

title: 100 metres hurdles
intro: The 100 metres hurdles, or 100-meter hurdles, is a track and field event run mainly by women (the male counterpart is the 110 metres hurdles). For the race, ten hurdles of a height of 83.8 centimetres (33.0 in) are placed along a straight course of 100 metres (109.36 yd). The first hurdle is placed after a run-up of 13 metres from the starting line. The next 9 hurdles are set at a distance of 8.5 metres from each other, and the home stretch from the last hurdle to the finish line is 10.5 metres long. The hurdles are set up so that they will fall over if bumped into by the runner, but weighted so this is disadvantageous. Fallen hurdles do not count against runners provided that they do not run into them on purpose. Like the 100 metres sprint, the 100 m hurdles begins with athletes in starting blocks. The fastest 100 m hurdlers run the distance in a time of around 12.5 seconds. The world record set by Kendra Harrison stands at 12.20 seconds.
lm_description: Chi Cheng opened the 1970s by clocking 12.93 in Munich, then Karin Balzer sliced the mark to 12.60 in East Berlin the next year. Anneliese Ehrhardt dominated the next three seasons, improving to 12.59 in Munich 1972, defending with 12.68 in Dresden 1973 and 12.66 in Rome 1974. Bożena Świerczyńska took 1975 with 12.91 in Zielona Góra before Grazyna Rabsztyn began her Polish reign: 12.69 in Bydgoszcz 1976, a breakthrough 12.48 in Fürth 1978, and an equal 12.48 in Warsaw 1979. Rabsztyn lowered the bar to 12.36 in Warsaw 1980, but Tatyana Anisimova claimed 1981 with 12.68 in Tbilisi. Yordanka Donkova then seized control, first with 12.44 in Sofia 1982, then the landmark 12.26 in Ljubljana 1986 and finally 12.21 in Stara Zagora 1988; sandwiched between her feats, Bettine Jahn managed 12.42 in Berlin 1983, Lucyna Kalek 12.43 in Hannover 1984, and Ginka Zagorcheva 12.42 in Sofia 1985 and 12.25 in Dráma 1987. Cornelia Oschkenat closed the decade at 12.60 in Barcelona 1989.

title: List of political parties in Northern Ireland
intro: Political parties in Northern Ireland lists political parties in Northern Ireland. The Northern Ireland Assembly is elected by single transferable vote and the composition of the Northern Ireland Executive is by power sharing determined by the D'Hondt system, among the members elected to the Assembly. Party affiliation is generally based on religious and ethnic background. Although Northern Ireland is a part of the United Kingdom, it has a quite distinct party system from the rest of the country, as the Labour Party and Liberal Democrats do not contest elections there (though the Liberal Democrats have links with the Alliance Party), and the Conservative Party has received only limited support in recent elections. Some parties, such as Sinn Féin and the Workers' Party, are organised on an all-Ireland basis. Others such as the Conservative Party are organised on an all-United Kingdom basis. There are many Northern Ireland-specific parties and these, on the whole, predominate. The distinction between unionist/loyalist, nationalist/republican and other is not always easy with some parties and individuals. Some have defined themselves less by their position on the Border Question than on other political issues. For example, the former Republican Labour Party/Social Democratic and Labour Party MP Gerry Fitt's career suggests he was first and foremost a socialist rather than a nationalist and he eventually left the SDLP claiming it had drifted from its founding intentions. Similarly the Workers' Party has its roots in the republican Official IRA but nowadays is considered to be a non-violent socialist and nationalist party. Several parties strive to be avowedly non-sectarian and would not consider themselves to be either unionist or nationalist.
lm_description: Ian Paisley led the Protestant Unionist Party from 1966 to 1971 and then the Democratic Unionist Party until 2008, representing Bannside and North Antrim for 42 years. Ruairí Ó Brádaigh headed Sinn Féin from 1970 to 1983 and later Republican Sinn Féin from 1986 to 2009, totaling 36 years of leadership. Gerry Adams succeeded him at the helm of Sinn Féin from 1983 to 2018, representing West Belfast and later Louth for 35 years. William Norton led the Irish Labour Party from 1932 to 1960, a span of 28 years. Tomás Mac Giolla successively chaired Sinn Féin from 1962 to 1970, Official Sinn Féin until 1977, Sinn Féin The Workers Party until 1982, and finally the Workers' Party until 1988, amounting to 26 years. Hugh Smyth headed the Progressive Unionist Party from 1979 to 2002, a 23-year tenure. John Hume led the Social Democratic and Labour Party from 1979 to 2001, representing Foyle for 22 years. Albert McElroy chaired the Ulster Liberal Party from 1956 to about 1975, roughly 19 years. Lord Craigavon led the Ulster Unionist Party from 1921 to 1940, representing Down and North Down for 19 years. John Redmond headed the Irish Parliamentary Party from 1900 to 1918, representing Waterford City for 18 years. Lord Brookeborough led the Ulster Unionist Party from 1946 to 1963, representing Lisnaskea for 17 years. James Molyneaux chaired the same party from 1979 to 1995, representing South Antrim and Lagan Valley for 16 years. Joseph Devlin led the Nationalist Party from 1918 to 1934, representing Belfast Falls, Fermanagh and Tyrone, and Belfast Central for 16 years. Gerry Fitt first led the Republican Labour Party from 1964 to 1970 and then the Social Democratic and Labour Party until 1979, representing Belfast West and Belfast Dock for 15 years. James Kilfedder headed the Ulster Popular Unionist Party from 1980 to 1995, representing North Down for 15 years. Margaret Buckley led Sinn Féin from 1937 to 1950, a 13-year period. Robert McCartney chaired the UK Unionist Party from 1995 to 2008, representing North Down for 13 years. James McSparran led the Nationalist Party from 1945 to 1958, representing Mourne for 13 years. Oliver Napier headed the Alliance Party from 1972 to 1984, a 12-year span. Thomas Joseph Campbell led the Nationalist Party from 1934 to 1945, representing Belfast Central for 11 years.

title: List of University of Oregon alumni
intro: This List of University of Oregon alumni includes graduates and current students of the University of Oregon as well as former students who studied at the university but did not obtain a formal degree. The university opened in 1876 and the first class contained only five members, graduating in 1878. The university has over 195,000 alumni, 10 of whom are Pulitzer Prize winners, and 2 of whom are Nobel laureates.
lm_description: Amir Aczel earned a 1982 Ph.D. and writes about science and mathematics, while Raymond Delacy Adams, a 1933 bachelors graduate, became a neurologist and Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. Geoffrey R. Ball, a physiology alumnus, co-founded Symphonix Devices Inc., pioneer of middle-ear implants. David M. Beazley completed his 1993 M.S. and is a computer scientist, Python developer and author; Kent Beck, holding 1987 B.S. and M.S. degrees, created Extreme Programming and Test Driven Development. Pamela J. Bjorkman, 1971 B.A. biochemist, is a Caltech Max Delbruck Professor and x-ray crystallography pioneer. Richard Gordon, 1967 Ph.D. theoretical biologist, advanced image processing at the University of Manitoba. Walter Houser Brattain, 1926 M.A., co-invented the transistor and shared the 1956 Nobel Prize in Physics. Clifford E. Brubaker, 1968 Ph.D., founded and once led the Rehabilitation Engineering and Assistive Technology Society of North America, and Robert S. Cunningham earned 1969 M.S. and Ph.D. degrees before becoming CSU Stanislaus computer-science professor emeritus. Stanislas Dehaene, a postdoc alumnus, researches numerical-cognition neuroscience, and 1982 Ph.D. Anne Fernald is a Stanford psychologist. N. Gregory Hamilton, 1971 B.A., is a psychiatrist advocating assisted suicide. Douglas Hofstadter, M.S. 1972 and Ph.D. 1975, won the 1980 Pulitzer for general non-fiction with “Gödel, Escher, Bach” and teaches cognitive science. Anthony Leiserowitz, M.S. and Ph.D. graduate, directs Yale’s Project on Climate Change Communication. Daniel Levitin earned 1993 M.S. and 1996 Ph.D. degrees and works as a cognitive scientist. Esther Pohl Lovejoy, 1894 M.D., was an early female physician and suffrage activist. William Murphy, 1914 B.A., shared the 1934 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. PZ Myers, 1985 Ph.D., is a prominent biologist and science blogger, and Harry F. Noller, also 1985 Ph.D., directs UC Santa Cruz’s Center for the Molecular Biology of RNA, is a National Academy of Sciences member, and elucidated ribosome function.

Walter Houser Brattain, 1926 M.A., co-invented the transistor and shared the 1956 Nobel Prize in Physics. Clifford E. Brubaker, 1968 Ph.D., founded and once led the Rehabilitation Engineering and Assistive Technology Society of North America, and Robert S. Cunningham earned 1969 M.S. and Ph.D. degrees before becoming CSU Stanislaus computer-science professor emeritus. Stanislas Dehaene, a postdoc alumnus, researches numerical-cognition neuroscience, and 1982 Ph.D. Anne Fernald is a Stanford psychologist. N. Gregory Hamilton, 1971 B.A., is a psychiatrist advocating assisted suicide. Douglas Hofstadter, M.S. 1972 and Ph.D. 1975, won the 1980 Pulitzer for general non-fiction with “Gödel, Escher, Bach” and teaches cognitive science. Anthony Leiserowitz, M.S. and Ph.D. graduate, directs Yale’s Project on Climate Change Communication. Daniel Levitin earned 1993 M.S. and 1996 Ph.D. degrees and works as a cognitive scientist. Esther Pohl Lovejoy, 1894 M.D., was an early female physician and suffrage activist. William Murphy, 1914 B.A., shared the 1934 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. PZ Myers, 1985 Ph.D., is a prominent biologist and science blogger, and Harry F. Noller, also 1985 Ph.D., directs UC Santa Cruz’s Center for the Molecular Biology of RNA, is a National Academy of Sciences member, and elucidated ribosome function.

title: List of United States Military Academy alumni
intro: The United States Military Academy (USMA) is an undergraduate college in West Point, New York with the mission of educating and commissioning officers for the United States Army. The Academy was founded in 1802 and is the oldest of the United States' five service academies. It is also referred to as West Point (the name of the military base that the Academy is a part of.) The Academy graduated its first cadet, Joseph Gardner Swift, in October 1802. Sports media refer to the Academy as Army and the students as Cadets; this usage is officially endorsed. The football team is also known as The Black Knights of the Hudson and The Black Knights. A small number of graduates each year choose the option of cross-commissioning into the United States Air Force, United States Navy, or the United States Marine Corps. Before the founding of the United States Air Force Academy in 1955, the Academy was a major source of officers for the Air Force and its predecessors. Most cadets are admitted through the congressional appointment system. The curriculum emphasizes the sciences and engineering fields. The list is drawn from graduates, non-graduate former cadets, current cadets, and faculty of the Military Academy. Notable graduates include 2 American Presidents, 4 additional heads of state, 20 astronauts, 74 Medal of Honor recipients, 70 Rhodes Scholars, and 3 Heisman Trophy winners.
lm_description: William A. Jones III, Class of 1945, rose to colonel in the United States Air Force and earned the Medal of Honor for rescuing a downed pilot. Andre Lucas, Class of 1954, became a lieutenant colonel decorated with the Medal of Honor for holding off a vastly superior force for 23 days. Roger Donlon, who left the Academy in 1959 for personal reasons, later served as a captain and eventually colonel, receiving the Medal of Honor for repelling a much larger enemy force. Humbert Roque Versace, Class of 1959, earned the Medal of Honor as a captain for defying Viet Cong indoctrination while a prisoner of war, an ordeal detailed by fellow POW Nick Rowe in Five Years to Freedom. James A. Gardner, who did not graduate with the Class of 1965, nevertheless received the Medal of Honor posthumously as a first lieutenant for leading his platoon to relieve an embattled company. Frank S. Reasoner, Class of 1962, cross-commissioned into the Marine Corps as a first lieutenant and earned the Medal of Honor for leading a reconnaissance patrol against overwhelming odds while trying to save a wounded comrade. Robert F. Foley, Class of 1963, received the Medal of Honor as a captain for rallying his unit on 11 November 1966, personally destroying three enemy strongpoints; he later served as West Point Commandant of Cadets, president of Marion Military Institute, and director of the Army Emergency Relief Program. Paul William Bucha, Class of 1965, earned the Medal of Honor as a captain for leading his unit against superior forces in Bình Dương Province, Vietnam, and later advised Barack Obama on foreign policy during the 2008 presidential campaign.

title: List of districts of Seoul
intro: The Districts (Gu) of Seoul are the twenty-five gu (districts; 구; 區) comprising Seoul, South Korea. The gu vary greatly in area (from 10 to 47 km²) and population (from less than 140,000 to 630,000). Songpa is the most populated, while Seocho has the largest area. Gu are similar to London's or New York's boroughs or Tokyo's 23 special wards, and a gu's government handles many of the functions that are handled by city governments in other jurisdictions. This city-like standing is underscored by the fact that each gu has its own legislative council, mayor and sister cities. Each gu is further divided into dong or neighborhoods. Some gu have only a few dong while others (like Jongno-gu) have a very large number of distinct neighborhoods.
lm_description: Dobong-gu, a residential district in Seoul’s northeast since 1963, comprises Dobong-dong, Banghak-dong, Ssangmun-dong and Chang-dong and is famed for Dobongsan mountain. Dongdaemun-gu, added in 1936, unites Cheongnyangni-dong, Dapsimni-dong, Hoegi-dong, Hwigyeong-dong, Imun-dong, Jegi-dong, Jangan-dong, Jeonnong-dong, Sinseol-dong and Yongdu-dong around 1911-built Cheongnyangni Station and offers Gyeongdong Market, Hongneung Arboretum and the nearby gate Heunginjimun. South of the Han, Dongjak-gu covers Bon-dong, Daebang-dong, Dongjak-dong, Heukseok-dong, Noryangjin-dong, Sadang-dong, Sangdo-dong and Sindaebang-dong, hosting Seoul National Cemetery on Seodalsan, the lively Noryangjin Fish Market, Boramae Park and Sayuksin Park. Eunpyeong-gu, split from Seodaemun in 1977, includes Bulgwang-dong, Daejo-dong, Eungam-dong, Galhyeon-dong, Gusan-dong, Jeungsan-dong, Jingwan-dong, Nokbeon-dong, Sinsa-dong, Susaek-dong and Yeokchon-dong, with Bongsan Park and Gupabal Fall. Gangbuk-gu, merged in 1949 and separate since 1995, embraces Mia-dong, Beon-dong, Suyu-dong and Ui-dong below Bukhansan and features Dream Forest. Gangdong-gu lists Gangil-dong, Godeok-dong, Gil-dong, Dunchon-dong, Myeongil-dong, Sangil-dong, Seongnae-dong, Amsa-dong and Cheonho-dong, showcasing Saetmaeul Park, Cheonhodong Park, Dunchon Marsh, Kildong Ecological Park. Gangnam-gu spans Apgujeong, Cheongdam, Daechi, Dogok, Gaepo, Irwon, Jagok, Nonhyeon, Samseong, Segok, Sinsa, Suseo, Yeoksam and Yulhyeon, housing COEX Mall, Teheran-ro, Gangnam Station, Bongeunsa, Garosu-gil, Yangjaecheon, Dosan Park and Kukkiwon. Gangseo-gu contains Banghwa, Deungchon, Gaehwa, Gayang, Gonghang, Gwahae, Hwagok, Magok, Naebalsan, Oebalsan, Ogok, Osoe, Yeomchang and is home to Gimpo International Airport, Heojun Museum, Maewha Park. Geumcheon-gu covers Gasan, Doksan, Siheung with Anyangcheon. Guro-gu unites Cheonwang, Gaebong, Garibong, Gocheok, Gung, Guro, Hang, Onsu, Oryu, Sindorim, offering Gocheok Sky Dome, Pureun Arboretum, Sindorim Station. Gwanak-gu, added in 1963 and designated 1973, includes Bongcheon, Namhyeon, Sillim, hosts Seoul National University, Kyujanggak, Gwaneumsa, Nakseongdae, Gwanaksan, Horim Museum. Gwangjin-gu covers Gunja, Guui, Gwangjang, Hwayang, Jayang, Junggok, Neung, featuring Techno Mart, Achasan Park, Children’s Grand Park, Dong Seoul Terminal, Ttukseom Resort. Jongno-gu, rich in dongs like Cheongun, Hyoja, Sajik, Samcheong, Buam, Pyeongchang, Muak, Gyonam, Gahoe, Ihwa, Hyehwa, Sejongno, Jongno-1·2·3·4-ga, Jongno-5·6-ga, Changsin, Sungin, guards Cheongwadae, Heunginjimun, Dongmyo, Gwanghwamun Plaza, Jogyesa, Naksan, Gyeongbokgung, Changdeokgung, Cheonggyecheon, Jongmyo, National Folk Museum, Bukchon Hanok Village. Jung-gu, undivided, centers on Seoul City Hall, Seoul Station, Deoksugung, Dongdaemun Design Plaza, Namdaemun, Myeongdong, Hwangudan, N Seoul Tower, Seoul Museum of Art. Jungnang-gu holds Junghwa, Mangu, Muk, Myeonmok, Sangbong, Sinnae, with Yongma Land and Nadeuri Park. Mapo-gu covers Ahyeon, Changjeon, Daeheung, Dangin, Dohwa, Donggyo, Gongdeok, Gusu, Hajung, Hapjeong, Hyeonseok, Jung, Mangwon, Mapo, Nogosan, Sangam, Sangsu, Seogyo, Seongsan, Singongdeok, Sinjeong, Sinsu, Tojeong, Yeomni, Yeonnam, Yonggang, featuring Digital Media City, Seoul World Cup Stadium, Hongdae, Gyeongui Line Forest. Nowon-gu, between Buramsan and Suraksan, includes Gongneung, Hagye, Junggye, Sanggye, Wolgye, hosts Seoul National University of Technology, Seoul Women’s University. Seocho-gu, Seoul’s largest, embraces Bangbae, Banpo, Jamwon, Naegok, Seocho, Sinwon, Umyeon, Wonji, Yangjae, Yeomgok, hosts Samsung Town, Yangjae Citizens’ Forest, Seoul Arts Center, Seoul Express Bus Terminal, Some Sevit. Seodaemun-gu, around Mount Ansan, includes Daesin, Bongwon, Daehyeon, Sinchon, Bukgajwa, Bugahyeon, Changcheon, Cheonyeon, Hyeonjeo, Naengcheon, Yeongcheon, Okcheon, Chungjeongno, Hap, Migeun, Hongeun, Hongje, Namgajwa, Yeonhui, offers Bongwonsa, Seodaemun Prison, Dongnimmun, Yonsei, Ewha Womans, Sinchon, Independence Park. Seongbuk-gu, long-inhabited northeast of center, covers Anam, Bomun, Donam, Dongseon, Dongsomun, Gireum, Jangwi, Jeongneung, Jongam, Samseon, Sangwolgok, Seokgwan, Seongbuk, Wolgok, Hawolgok, houses Korea University.
