title: Craigkelly transmitting station
intro: The Craigkelly transmitting station is a broadcasting and telecommunications facility located at Craigkelly (grid reference NT233872) north of the Firth of Forth above the town of Burntisland in Fife, Scotland. It has a 125-metre tall free-standing lattice tower. The station came into service in 1968 to improve coverage of BBC 2 to the Edinburgh area, which has a number of hills blocking good reception from Black Hill. In September 1971 it also started broadcasting BBC1 and Scottish Television on 625 lines in colour and though considered a 'main' station, it actually rebroadcast the signal from the Black Hill transmitting station, like a relay. Its tower now also carries antennas for many broadcasting and private radio organisations. This structure was previously used at Emley Moor. The transmitter was originally an A group but has become a K group (or wideband) with the advent of Channel 5 and Digital. Craigkelly is one of the few main transmitters which did not return to its original group at DSO. However, when Craigkelly went through its 700MHz clearance in October 2018 all of the main 6 MUXES returned to the A group, the only two out side are MUXES 7 and 8 (See Craigkelly's graph) which are due to be switched off between 2020 and 2022 anyway. The tower can be clearly seen from many parts of Edinburgh across the Firth of Forth on its prominent position atop the hill known as The Binn.
lm_description: Craigkelly transmits PSB2 (D3&4) on 498 MHz at UHF channel 24 with 20 kW using DVB-T, while PSB1 (BBC A) occupies 522 MHz on channel 27 at the same power and standard. BBC B’s PSB3 service radiates from 474.166 MHz on channel 21+ at 20 kW but employs the newer DVB-T2 system. Local television reaches viewers via LTVmux on 562 MHz channel 32, though at a reduced 5 kW. Commercial multiplexes COM4 (SDN), COM5 (ARQ A) and COM6 (ARQ B) broadcast respectively on 538 MHz channel 29, 554 MHz channel 31 and 602 MHz channel 37, each at 10 kW under DVB-T. High-frequency COM7 (ARQ C) and COM8 (ARQ D) operate at 746 MHz channel 55 and 754 MHz channel 56, both at 15.849 kW and both using DVB-T2.

title: List of alumni of the University of St Andrews
intro: This list of alumni of the University of St Andrews includes graduates, non-graduate former students, and current students of the University of St Andrews, Fife, Scotland.
lm_description: Brian Sonia-Wallace, who took his M.A. in 2011, is a poet, theatre maker and journalist who authored *I Sold These Poems, Now I Want Them Back*. Alistair Moffat, 1972 M.A., served as director of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe and later as Rector of his alma mater. The 1588 M.A. graduate Robert Aytoun combined poetry with law, becoming court poet to the queen of James I and VI and one of the first Scots to write in standard English. Andrew Crumey is a novelist and literary editor of *Scotland on Sunday*. Gavin Douglas, enrolled in 1494, became a bishop, makar and translator, while William Dunbar, M.A. 1479, earned fame as a poet and makar. Alexander Hume holds an M.A. and writes poetry. Robert Fergusson entered in 1763 but left without graduating, yet his verse strongly influenced Robert Burns. Sarah Hall, M.Litt., is a novelist-poet whose *The Electric Michaelangelo* was shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize. Gilbert Hay is known as a poet and translator. American James A. Michener studied as a Lippincott Fellow and won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction. David Lyndsay served as Lord Lyon and wrote poetry. Bruce Marshall’s fiction and nonfiction have been repeatedly adapted for screen and television. Hilary McKay writes children’s books and won the 1992 Guardian Children’s Fiction Prize. Alastair Reynolds earned a PhD here before becoming a leading science-fiction author. William Tennant is a scholar-poet, Fay Weldon a feminist author-essayist-playwright, Timothy Williams took his M.A. in 1970 and later won a Crime Writers’ Association award, Andrew Lang collected folk tales while producing poetry, novels and criticism, and Robert Henryson stands as a celebrated poet and makar.

title: List of metropolitan statistical areas
intro: The United States Office of Management and Budget (OMB) has defined 392 metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs) for the United States and eight for Puerto Rico. The OMB defines a Metropolitan Statistical Area as one or more adjacent counties or county equivalents that have at least one urban core area of at least 50,000 population, plus adjacent territory that has a high degree of social and economic integration with the core as measured by commuting ties.
lm_description: New York-Newark-Jersey City remains the nation’s largest metro, growing 2.11 % to 19,979,477 residents within the New York-Newark combined area, while Los Angeles-Long Beach-Anaheim follows at 13,291,486, up 3.61 % inside the Los Angeles-Long Beach CSA. Chicago-Naperville-Elgin holds third at 9,498,716 with modest 0.40 % growth within its同名 CSA. Texas claims the fastest-expanding giants: Dallas-Fort Worth-Arlington surged 17.33 % to 7,539,711 and Houston-The Woodlands-Sugar Land leapt 18.19 % to 6,997,384, both anchored to their respective combined areas. Washington-Arlington-Alexandria reached 6,249,950, up 10.89 % within the Washington-Baltimore-Arlington CSA, while Miami-Fort Lauderdale-West Palm Beach grew 11.40 % to 6,198,782 inside the Miami-Port St. Lucie-Fort Lauderdale CSA. Philadelphia-Camden-Wilmington rose 2.20 % to 6,096,372 within the Philadelphia-Reading-Camden CSA, and Atlanta-Sandy Springs-Roswell climbed 12.55 % to 5,949,951 within the Atlanta-Athens-Clarke County-Sandy Springs CSA. Boston-Cambridge-Newton gained 7.09 % to 4,875,390 within the Boston-Worcester-Providence CSA, Phoenix-Mesa-Chandler jumped 15.86 % to 4,857,962 within the Phoenix-Mesa CSA, and San Francisco-Oakland-Berkeley grew 9.09 % to 4,729,484 inside the San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland CSA. Riverside-San Bernardino-Ontario expanded 9.41 % to 4,622,361 within the Los Angeles-Long Beach CSA, Detroit-Warren-Dearborn edged up 0.70 % to 4,326,442 within the Detroit-Warren-Ann Arbor CSA, and Seattle-Tacoma-Bellevue surged 14.52 % to 3,939,363 within the Seattle-Tacoma CSA. Minneapolis-St. Paul-Bloomington rose 8.37 % to 3,629,190 within its同名 CSA, San Diego-Chula Vista-Carlsbad grew 8.01 % to 3,343,364, Tampa-St. Petersburg-Clearwater climbed 12.91 % to 3,142,663, Denver-Aurora-Lakewood jumped 15.29 % to 2,932,415 within the Denver-Aurora CSA, and St. Louis inched up 0.64 % to 2,805,465 within the St. Louis-St. Charles-Farmington CSA.

List of metropolitan statistical areas
The United States Office of Management and Budget (OMB) has defined 392 metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs) for the United States and eight for Puerto Rico. The OMB defines a Metropolitan Statistical Area as one or more adjacent counties or county equivalents that have at least one urban core area of at least 50,000 population, plus adjacent territory that has a high degree of social and economic integration with the core as measured by commuting ties.
New York-Newark-Jersey City remains the nation’s largest metro, growing 2.11 % to 19,979,477 residents within the New York-Newark combined area, while Los Angeles-Long Beach-Anaheim follows at 13,291,486, up 3.61 % inside the Los Angeles-Long Beach CSA. Chicago-Naperville-Elgin holds third at 9,498,716 with modest 0.40 % growth within its同名 CSA. Texas claims the fastest-expanding giants: Dallas-Fort Worth-Arlington surged 17.33 % to 7,539,711 and Houston-The Woodlands-Sugar Land leapt 18.19 % to 6,997,384, both anchored to their respective combined areas. Washington-Arlington-Alexandria reached 6,249,950, up 10.89 % within the Washington-Baltimore-Arlington CSA, while Miami-Fort Lauderdale-West Palm Beach grew 11.40 % to 6,198,782 inside the Miami-Port St. Lucie-Fort Lauderdale CSA. Philadelphia-Camden-Wilmington rose 2.20 % to 6,096,372 within the Philadelphia-Reading-Camden CSA, and Atlanta-Sandy Springs-Roswell climbed 12.55 % to 5,949,951 within the Atlanta-Athens-Clarke County-Sandy Springs CSA. Boston-Cambridge-Newton gained 7.09 % to 4,875,390 within the Boston-Worcester-Providence CSA, Phoenix-Mesa-Chandler jumped 15.86 % to 4,857,962 within the Phoenix-Mesa CSA, and San Francisco-Oakland-Berkeley grew 9.09 % to 4,729,484 inside the San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland CSA. Riverside-San Bernardino-Ontario expanded 9.41 % to 4,622,361 within the Los Angeles-Long Beach CSA, Detroit-Warren-Dearborn edged up 0.70 % to 4,326,442 within the Detroit-Warren-Ann Arbor CSA, and Seattle-Tacoma-Bellevue surged 14.52 % to 3,939,363 within the Seattle-Tacoma CSA. title: List of constituencies of the Lok Sabha
intro: The Lok Sabha, the lower house of the Parliament of India, is made up of Members of Parliament (MPs). Each MP, represents a single geographic constituency. There are currently 543 constituencies. The maximum size of the Lok Sabha as outlined in the Constitution of India is 550 members made up of up to 530 members representing people of the states of India and up to 20 members representing people from the Union Territories on the basis of their population.
lm_description: Nandurbar is the first Lok Sabha seat, reserved for Scheduled Tribes, followed by Dhule, Jalgaon, Raver, Buldhana, Akola, Wardha, Nagpur, Bhandara-Gondiya, Chandrapur, Yavatmal-Washim, Hingoli, Nanded, Parbhani, Jalna and Aurangabad, all open constituencies. Amravati and Ramtek are Scheduled Caste constituencies, while Gadchiroli-Chimur and Dindori are the other two Scheduled Tribe seats among these twenty.
to_index_text:
List of constituencies of the Lok Sabha
The Lok Sabha, the lower house of the Parliament of India, is made up of Members of Parliament (MPs). Each MP, represents a single geographic constituency. There are currently 543 constituencies. The maximum size of the Lok Sabha as outlined in the Constitution of India is 550 members made up of up to 530 members representing people of the states of India and up to 20 members representing people from the Union Territories on the basis of their population.
Nandurbar is the first Lok Sabha seat, reserved for Scheduled Tribes, followed by Dhule, Jalgaon, Raver, Buldhana, Akola, Wardha, Nagpur, Bhandara-Gondiya, Chandrapur, Yavatmal-Washim, Hingoli, Nanded, Parbhani, Jalna and Aurangabad, all open constituencies. Amravati and Ramtek are Scheduled Caste constituencies, while Gadchiroli-Chimur and Dindori are the other two Scheduled Tribe seats among these twenty.

title: Media in Thunder Bay
intro: This is a list of media outlets in the city of Thunder Bay, Ontario, Canada.
lm_description: CBC Radio One blankets Northwestern Ontario on FM 88.3 as CBQT-FM, while its French-language sibling Ici Radio-Canada Première occupies 89.3 CBON-FM-20, relaying Sudbury’s signal. Thunder Bay Information Radio Inc. runs 90.5 CKSI-FM, a tourist and emergency channel, and Superior Info Radio’s 97.1 CITB-FM likewise serves visitors. Dougall Media operates two locals: 91.5 CKPR-FM, adult contemporary since migrating from AM 580, and Rock 94 CJSD-FM at 94.3. St. Joseph’s Care Group’s CJOA 95.1 brings Christian music, once echoed at Candy Mountain 93.1 until 2005. First Nations and Christian programming reach the dial via 98.1 CJTL-FM-1, rebroadcasting Pickle Lake’s CJTL-FM. Acadia Broadcasting owns 99.9 The Bay CJUK-FM for classic hits and 105.3 Country 105 CKTG-FM, which carried CJLB call letters until 2005. Lakehead University students air campus voices on 102.7 LU Radio CILU-FM, and CBC Music closes the roster at 101.7 CBQ-FM.

title: Video games in Belgium
intro: This article is about the video game market and culture in Belgium.
lm_description: Apocalypse Hunters, founded in 2015, operates from Brussels and Namur crafting location-based and AR mobile games. Hellion Cat emerged in Mons in 2016 as an indie studio, the same year Invisible Ink Studios began in Wavre and Pajama Llama Games launched in Ghent, both 2015 indie ventures. Studio Raef started in Turnhout in 2014, while TerraNovita Software has been developing indie titles from Rumst since 2005. Happy Volcano and Bunnycopter, both Leuven-based, were founded in 2015 and 2014 respectively as indie developers. Bazookas, established in Bruges in 2012, specializes in serious, educational and entertainment games, whereas Firewolf Engineering from Hasselt, also 2012, handles game development and visualizations. FrostyFroggs joined the Brussels scene in 2015 as indie creators, followed by Crazy Monkey Studios in Kontich since 2011. Quantum Game Studio has been developing indie games from Ostend since 2013, the year Abrakam Creative Entertainment began in Liège combining core and indie games. I-Illusions started indie development in Brussels in 2011, Rusty Bolt in Bruges the same year, while Monkube has been creating indie and mobile games from Brussels since 2010. Larian Studios, veteran of the list, has developed core and educational games from Ghent since 1996, joined later by CatLab Interactive making web and mobile games since 2009, and Newfort, originally Endrone, creating online and mobile games since 2002.

title: List of Russian films of 2008
intro: A list of films produced in Russia in 2008 (see 2008 in film).
lm_description: Admiral, directed by Andrei Kravchuk, casts Konstantin Khabensky, Elizaveta Boyarskaya and Sergey Bezrukov in a 2008 Russian historical drama titled Адмиралъ. Igor Kalyonov’s Alexander, subtitled Невская битва, stars Anton Pampushnyy as a historical action hero. Jaroslav Chevazhevsky keeps the mood light with the seaside comedy На море. Kirill Kuzin gathers Garic Kharlamov, Mikhail Galustyan and Pavel Volya for the parody Самый лучший фильм, while Andrey Malyukov sends Danila Kozlovsky and Andrey Terentev time-travelling in the science-fiction adventure Мы из будущего. Agniya Kuznetsova and Polina Filonenko direct Valeriya Gai Germanika in the intimate drama Все умрут, а я останусь. Konstantin Khabensky reappears alongside Vladimir Mashkov and Chulpan Khamatova in Karen Oganesyan’s thriller Домовой. Valery Todorovsky stages a 1950s musical comedy with Anton Shagin, Oksana Akinshina and Evgeniya Khirivskaya in Стиляги. Fyodor Bondarchuk adapts the Strugatskys’ science-fiction epic Обитаемый остров with Vasiliy Stepanov, Yuliya Snigir and Pyotr Fyodorov. Aleksei Balabanov probes addiction in Морфий, starring Leonid Bichevin, Ingeborga Dapkūnaitė and Andrei Panin. Aleksey German’s Paper Soldier, Бумажный солдат, pairs Merab Ninidze and Chulpan Khamatova in a space-race drama. Andrey Iskanov fuses horror and documentary in Философия ножа, featuring Yukari Fujimoto and Yumiko Fujiwara. Marius Waisberg spoofs the Reich in the comedy Гитлер капут!, led by Pavel Derevyanko and Anna Semenovich. Katya Shagalova’s Однажды в провинции gathers Leonid Bichevin, Elvira Bolgova and Yuliya Peresild for a provincial drama. Oksana Bychkova crosses cultures in Плюс один with Madeleine Dzhabrailova and Jethro Skinner. Karen Shakhnazarov reflects on a vanished era in Исчезнувшая империя, starring Armen Dzhigarkhanyan and Alexander Lyapin. Mikheil Kalatozishvili’s Дикое поле casts Oleg Dolin, Roman Madyanov and Yuriy Stepanov as doctors stranded on the steppe. Kirill Serebrennikov closes the year with Юрьев день, a drama carried by Kseniya Rappoport.

title: JCDecaux
intro: JCDecaux Group (JCDecaux SA, French pronunciation: ​[ʒisedəˈko]) is a multinational corporation based in Neuilly-sur-Seine, near Paris, France, known for its bus-stop advertising systems, billboards, public bicycle rental systems, and street furniture. It is the largest outdoor advertising corporation in the world. The company was founded in 1964 in Lyon, France by Jean-Claude Decaux. Over the years it has expanded aggressively, partly through acquisitions of smaller advertising companies in several countries. JCDecaux currently employs more than 13,030 people worldwide and maintains a presence in over 75 countries. In France alone, JCDecaux employs more than 3,500 people. [citation needed]
lm_description: JCDecaux’s bike-share footprint began modestly in 2003 when Cyclocity rolled out 35 bikes across 4 stations in Córdoba, Spain, followed the same year by Gijon-Bici’s 64 bikes at 8 stands in Gijón. France soon dominated the map: Besançon’s VéloCité started in 2007 with 200 bikes at 30 stations, while Marseille answered with Le vélo’s 1 000 bikes at 130 stations that same year, Mulhouse fielded 240 Vélocité bikes at 40 points, and Lyon—JCDecaux’s 2005 flagship—still runs 4 000 Vélo’v bikes from 348 hubs. Amiens added Vélam in 2008 with 313 bikes at 26 stations, Nancy launched VélOstan’lib the same year with 250 bikes at 29 stations, and Cergy-Pontoise followed in 2009 deploying 400 VélO2 bikes across 42 stations, the same year Brussels unveiled Villo! and its 5 000 bikes at 360 stations. Dublin’s 2009 dublinbikes brought 1 500 bikes to 102 Irish stations, Créteil’s 2010 Cristolib placed 130 bikes at 10 stops, and Gothenburg’s 2010 Styr & Ställ offers 600 bikes from 50 Swedish docks. Later expansions include Ljubljana’s 2011 BicikeLJ with 510 bikes at 51 stations, Kazan’s 2013 VeliK supplying 120 bikes at 6 Russian points, Lillestrøm’s 2013 Bysykkel fielding 50 bikes at 5 Norwegian stands, and Lundahoj’s 2014 debut in Lund with 250 bikes across 17 stations.

title: 2010 in American television
intro: The following is a list of events that affected American television in 2010, a year marked by the usual debuts, cancellations, and continuations of shows; the launches, closures, or rebrandings of channels; but also significant cable/satellite carriage disputes.
lm_description: On April 1, 2010, 92-year-old John Forsythe—remembered as Blake Carrington on Dynasty and the unseen voice of Charlie on Charlie’s Angels—died. Eight days later, Meinhardt Raabe, 94, the Munchkin who triumphantly announces the witch’s death in The Wizard of Oz, passed away. The next day, April 10, brought the loss of 70-year-old Dixie Carter, whose Southern charm animated Designing Women, Diff’rent Strokes, Out of the Blue, The Edge of Night and Family Law. April 12 claimed Peter Haskell, 75, star of Bracken’s World and Ryan’s Hope. Civil-rights figure Benjamin Hooks, 85, the first African-American commissioner of the FCC and former NAACP executive director, died on April 15. Voice-over legend Allen Swift, 86, whose talents shaped The Howdy Doody Show, Mighty Mouse and Underdog, left on April 18. Screenwriter Myles Wilder, 77, who penned episodes of McHale’s Navy and The Dukes of Hazzard, died April 20. The month’s final farewell came April 27 with Dorothy Provine, 75, actress-comedian-dancer-singer who lit up The Roaring 20s, The Alaskans and Man Without a Gun.

2010 in American television

Voice-over legend Allen Swift, 86, whose talents shaped The Howdy Doody Show, Mighty Mouse and Underdog, left on April 18. Screenwriter Myles Wilder, 77, who penned episodes of McHale’s Navy and The Dukes of Hazzard, died April 20. The month’s final farewell came April 27 with Dorothy Provine, 75, actress-comedian-dancer-singer who lit up The Roaring 20s, The Alaskans and Man Without a Gun.

title: 2014 United Football League
intro: The 2014 United Football League was the fifth season of the UFL since its establishment as a semi-professional league in 2009. The UFL League kicked off on Saturday, January 11 with 9 teams in Division I and 12 teams in Division II. Stallion are the defending champions, having won the Division 1 of the 2013 United Football League season. Global outclassed Pachanga Diliman 7-2 on 12 June 2014 to clinch the 2014 United Football League title with three games to spare.
lm_description: Emmanuel Mbata powered Kaya to a 7-1 demolition of Team Socceroo on 23 January 2014. Jeffrey Christiaens starred as Global crushed Philippine Army 9-1 on 1 February 2014, and Christian Pasilan did likewise for Green Archers United in another 7-1 rout of Team Socceroo three days later. Mark Hartmann twice tormented Team Socceroo, first in a 9-0 Global avalanche on 11 February and again in an identical 9-0 repeat on 20 March. OJ Porteria added to Philippine Army’s misery by headlineing Kaya’s 9-1 triumph on 13 February. Diego Barrera provided Team Socceroo’s lone bright spot, edging Stallion 4-3 on 13 March. Milad Behgandom orchestrated Global’s 7-0 blanking of Pasargad on 29 March, while Freddy Gonzalez drove Loyola past Philippine Army 4-1 on 5 April. Jeong Woo Lee sparked Team Socceroo’s 6-2 revenge over Pasargad on 11 May. Izzeldin El Habbib closed the campaign in style, propelling Global to a 7-0 humbling of Team Socceroo on 14 June and capping it with a 9-0 obliteration of Stallion on 26 June.

title: List of major crimes in the United Kingdom
intro: This is a list of major crimes in the United Kingdom that received significant media coverage or led to changes in legislation. Legally each deliberate and unlawful killing of a human being is murder; there are no crimes of assassination or serial killing as such, for example.
lm_description: In 2000 eight-year-old Ivorian Victoria Climbié was tortured and murdered by her aunt and other guardians in London, prompting a public inquiry that rewrote England’s child-protection rules. The same year seven-year-old Sarah Payne was abducted and murdered in East Preston, West Sussex, by convicted paedophile Roy Whiting, who received a life term with a 40-year minimum. Also in 2000 ten-year-old Damilola Taylor bled to death from a thigh wound in Peckham; brothers Ricky and Gavin Preedie were later convicted of manslaughter. On 21 September 2001 the torso of an unidentified Nigerian boy aged four to seven was found in the Thames, believed to be a ritual killing. In 2001 fifteen-year-old Danielle Jones vanished in East Tilbury; her uncle Stuart Campbell was convicted of murder after forensic analysis of text messages sent from her phone, though her body was never found. Thirteen-year-old Amanda Dowler disappeared in Walton-on-Thames in 2002; Levi Bellfield was convicted in 2011, and the News of the World later admitted hacking her phone. In Soham that year Ian Huntley murdered ten-year-olds Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman and received a 40-year minimum life sentence. In 2003 fourteen-year-old Jodi Jones was stabbed to death in Dalkeith by her boyfriend Luke Mitchell. In 2004 Kriss Donald, 15, was abducted and killed by an Asian gang in Glasgow in a racially motivated attack; four men received life sentences. Seventeen-month-old Peter Connelly, Baby P, died in Haringey in 2007 after months of abuse, echoing the earlier Climbié scandal. Eleven-year-old Rhys Jones was shot in Liverpool the same year; Sean Mercer, 18, received life with a 22-year minimum. Sixteen-year-old Ben Kinsella was stabbed in Islington in 2008, sparking anti-knife campaigns. Twelve-year-old Tia Rigg was drugged, raped and strangled by her uncle John Maden in Manchester in 2010; he was told he would never be released. Four-year-old Daniel Pełka starved and abused by his mother and her partner in Coventry died in 2012; both killers died in prison within three years. Six siblings perished in the 2012 Allenton house fire started by parents Mick and Mairead Philpott and friend Paul Mosley, who were convicted of manslaughter. Twelve-year-old Tia Sharp was smothered by her grandmother’s partner Stuart Hazell in Croydon and given a 38-year minimum life term. Five-year-old April Jones disappeared in Machynlleth in 2012; Mark Bridger was convicted despite no body being found. In 2014 fourteen-year-old Breck Bednar was lured online and murdered by Lewis Daynes in Grays, who received a 25-year minimum. Alice Gross, 14, vanished in Hanwell the same year; Latvian Arnis Zalkalns, who had a prior murder conviction, was identified but found hanged before trial. Sixteen-year-old Becky Watts was killed and dismembered in Bristol in 2015.

On 21 September 2001 the torso of an unidentified Nigerian boy aged four to seven was found in the Thames, believed to be a ritual killing. In 2001 fifteen-year-old Danielle Jones vanished in East Tilbury; her uncle Stuart Campbell was convicted of murder after forensic analysis of text messages sent from her phone, though her body was never found. Thirteen-year-old Amanda Dowler disappeared in Walton-on-Thames in 2002; Levi Bellfield was convicted in 2011, and the News of the World later admitted hacking her phone. In Soham that year Ian Huntley murdered ten-year-olds Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman and received a 40-year minimum life sentence. In 2003 fourteen-year-old Jodi Jones was stabbed to death in Dalkeith by her boyfriend Luke Mitchell. In 2004 Kriss Donald, 15, was abducted and killed by an Asian gang in Glasgow in a racially motivated attack; four men received life sentences. Seventeen-month-old Peter Connelly, Baby P, died in Haringey in 2007 after months of abuse, echoing the earlier Climbié scandal. Eleven-year-old Rhys Jones was shot in Liverpool the same year; Sean Mercer, 18, received life with a 22-year minimum. Sixteen-year-old Ben Kinsella was stabbed in Islington in 2008, sparking anti-knife campaigns. Twelve-year-old Tia Rigg was drugged, raped and strangled by her uncle John Maden in Manchester in 2010; he was told he would never be released. Four-year-old Daniel Pełka starved and abused by his mother and her partner in Coventry died in 2012; both killers died in prison within three years. Six siblings perished in the 2012 Allenton house fire started by parents Mick and Mairead Philpott and friend Paul Mosley, who were convicted of manslaughter. Twelve-year-old Tia Sharp was smothered by her grandmother’s partner Stuart Hazell in Croydon and given a 38-year minimum life term. Five-year-old April Jones disappeared in Machynlleth in 2012; Mark Bridger was convicted despite no body being found. In 2014 fourteen-year-old Breck Bednar was lured online and murdered by Lewis Daynes in Grays, who received a 25-year minimum. Alice Gross, 14, vanished in Hanwell the same year; Latvian Arnis Zalkalns, who had a prior murder conviction, was identified but found hanged before trial. Sixteen-year-old Becky Watts was killed and dismembered in Bristol in 2015.

title: 2005 Brazilian Grand Prix
intro: The 2005 Brazilian Grand Prix (formally the XXXIV Grande Prêmio do Brasil) was a Formula One motor race held on at the Autódromo José Carlos Pace in São Paulo, Brazil on 25 September 2005. The 71-lap race was the seventeenth round of the 2005 Formula One season. The race was won by McLaren driver Juan Pablo Montoya, who took the final race victory of his career, ahead of his teammate, Kimi Räikkönen, who finished second. Renault driver Fernando Alonso became the Drivers' Champion for the first time after he finished the race in third place. Only he and Räikkönen had entered the race within mathematical contention of winning the title, and Alonso's podium ensured that he did with two rounds remaining. Alonso also qualified in pole position for the race, but the fastest lap went to Räikkönen.
lm_description: Fernando Alonso planted his Renault on pole with a 1:11.988, just 0.157 s clear of Juan Pablo Montoya’s McLaren-Mercedes. Giancarlo Fisichella made it two Renaults in the top three, 0.570 s adrift, while Jenson Button’s BAR-Honda and Kimi Räikkönen’s silver arrow filled the next spots at +0.708 s and +0.793 s. Christian Klien led the Red Bull charge in sixth, 0.901 s off the benchmark, followed by Michael Schumacher’s Ferrari, Jarno Trulli’s Toyota and the Sauber-Petronas pair of Felipe Massa and Rubens Barrichello, the latter conceding 1.195 s to Alonso. Ralf Schumacher’s Toyota, Jacques Villeneuve’s Sauber and Tiago Monteiro’s Jordan-Toyota slotted 11th to 13th, gaps creeping past 1.3 s. Mark Webber and Antônio Pizzonia shared row eight for Williams-BMW at +1.550 s and +1.593 s, while David Coulthard’s Red Bull trailed by 1.856 s. Narain Karthikeyan and Christijan Albers brought up the rear among those who set times, 2.532 s and 2.775 s behind. Takuma Sato and Robert Doornbos failed to log laps, the Minardi driver spinning.

title: List of Finnish submissions for the Academy Award for Best International Feature Film
intro: Finland has submitted twenty-seven films for consideration in the Academy Award for Best International Feature Film[nb 1] category. The Award is handed out annually by the United States Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to a feature-length motion picture produced outside the United States that contains primarily non-English dialogue. The Finnish Academy Awards submission is selected by an expert jury which is chosen by the Finnish Film Foundation. All 32 films listed below were accepted by AMPAS, although two films- Drifting Clouds and Lights in the Dusk- were withdrawn by director Aki Kaurismäki after the films were sent to Hollywood in both 1996 and 2006. According to Mark Johnson, the chairman of the Academy's foreign-language committee, he was told by the Finnish selection committee that Kaurismaki does not like film competitions. As of 2017[update], only one Finnish film has been nominated for the Foreign Film Oscar- their 2002 submission The Man Without a Past was nominated for an Oscar on January 2003. Ironically, Past was also directed by Kaurismäki, but was not withdrawn. However, Kaurismaki boycotted the Academy Awards ceremony as protest over the U.S. involvement in the 2003 invasion of Iraq. Because of Kaurismaki's withdrawals, Klaus Härö has represented Finland more than any other Finnish director - four times.
lm_description: Rauni Mollberg’s Maa on syntinen laulu represented Finland at the 46th Academy Awards in 1973 but was not nominated, and he returned thirteen years later with Tuntematon sotilas for the 59th ceremony with the same result. Pirjo Honkasalo and Pekka Lehto’s Tulipää went forward in 1980, followed by Jaakko Pakkasvirta’s Pedon merkki in 1981, Heikki Partanen’s Pessi ja Illusia in 1984, Päivi Hartzell’s Lumikuningatar in 1987, Pekka Parikka’s Talvisota in 1990, Christian Lindblad’s Ripa ruostuu in 1994 and Markku Pölönen’s Kivenpyörittäjän kylä in 1995, all unsuccessfully. Aki Kaurismäki’s Kauas pilvet karkaavat was disqualified in 1996 after the director himself withdrew it. Auli Mantila’s Neitoperho took the slot in 1997, Markku Pölönen returned with Kuningasjätkä in 1998, Aleksi Mäkelä entered Häjyt in 1999, Anastasia Lapsui and Markku Lehmuskallio submitted Seitsemän laulua tundralta in 2000, and Jarmo Lampela offered Joki in 2001; none advanced. Kaurismäki finally secured Finland’s only nomination with Mies vailla menneisyyttä at the 75th Oscars. Klaus Härö then shouldered the country’s hopes three times in four years: Neitoperho in 2003, Äideistä parhain in 2005, and in 2006 Kaurismäki again withdrew his own Laitakaupungin valot.

title: List of ethnic groups of Africa
intro: The ethnic groups of Africa number in the thousands, with each population generally having its own language (or dialect of a language) and culture. The ethnolinguistic groups include various Afroasiatic, Khoisan, Niger-Congo and Nilo-Saharan populations. The official population count of the various ethnic groups in Africa is highly uncertain, both due to limited infrastructure to perform censuses and due to the rapid population growth. There have also been accusations of deliberate misreporting in order to give selected ethnicities numerical superiority (as in the case of Nigeria's Hausa, Fulani, Yoruba and Igbo people). A 2009 genetic clustering study, which genotyped 1327 polymorphic markers in various African populations, identified six ancestral clusters. The clustering corresponded closely with ethnicity, culture and language. A 2018 whole genome sequencing study of the world's populations observed similar clusters among the populations in Africa. At K=9, distinct ancestral components defined the Afrosiatic-speaking populations inhabiting North Africa and Northeast Africa; the Nilo-Saharan-speaking populations in Northeast Africa and East Africa; the Ari populations in Northeast Africa; the Niger-Congo-speaking populations in West-Central Africa, West Africa, East Africa and Southern Africa; the Pygmy populations in Central Africa; and the Khoisan populations in Southern Africa.
lm_description: The Aka and Efé, both Nilo-Saharan Pygmy peoples, speak their eponymous languages in the Central/Northern region, the Aka inhabiting the western Central African Republic and northwest Congo while the Efé live in the Ituri Rainforest of Congo, and are joined there by the Sua who also speak a Nilo-Saharan Pygmy language. The Baka Pygmy, speaking Baka, number 0.25 million in Western Equatoria of South Sudan. Banda and Gbaya, each 1.5 million strong and Niger-Congo Ubangian speakers, occupy the Chad Basin within the Central African Republic. The 9 million Chewa, Chichewa-speaking Niger-Congo Bantu, span Botswana, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe, while the 1.1 million Chokwe, speaking Chokwe, live in Angola, Congo (Kinshasa) and Zambia. The 10 million Kongo, Kongo-speaking Niger-Congo Bantu, reside in Democratic Republic of the Congo, Angola and Republic of the Congo, matched in number by the Kanuri, whose Western Saharan Nilo-Saharan language is heard in Nigeria, Niger, Cameroon and Chad. Lingala, a Niger-Congo Bantu tongue, is used in Democratic Republic of the Congo, Republic of the Congo, Angola and Central African Republic. Luba, numbering 13 million, speak Luba-Kasai and Luba-Katanga in Democratic Republic of the Congo. The Afro-Asiatic Chadic Kotoko, fewer than 1 million, speak Lagwan in Cameroon and Chad. Mbunda, 0.5 million, speak Mbúùnda, Chimbúùnda and Mpuono in Angola and Zambia, while the 2.4 million Mbundu speak Kimbundu in Angola and the 4.6 million Ovimbundu speak Umbundu there. Moghamo and Ngamambo, Southern Bantoid Niger-Congo peoples of Cameroon, are 18,000 and 11,000 respectively. The 12 million Mongo, Mongo-speaking Niger-Congo Bantu, live in Democratic Republic of the Congo. The 3.5 million Sara, Central Sudanic Nilo-Saharan speakers, inhabit Chad, Cameroon and Central African Republic.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Big Horn County, Wyoming
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places listings in Big Horn County, Wyoming. This is intended to be a complete list of the properties and districts on the National Register of Historic Places in Big Horn County, Wyoming, United States. The locations of National Register properties and districts for which the latitude and longitude coordinates are included below, may be seen in a map. There are 23 properties and districts listed on the National Register in the county, 1 of which is a National Historic Landmark.
lm_description: Greybull’s American Legion Hall, Post 32, entered the National Register on 27 June 2014 at 130 N. 5th St., while the Carey Block at 602 Greybull Ave. followed on 18 December 2009. Greybull also safeguards the Bear Creek Ranch Medicine Wheel, listed 4 May 1987 but kept at an undisclosed location, and the Lower Shell School House, added 7 February 1985 beside U.S. Route 14. Basin’s Republican-Rustler Printing Building, 409 W. C St., was honored 19 July 1976, and Cowley’s Big Horn Academy Historic District, 25 and 35 E. 1st S., joined the register 26 March 1992. Lovell claims the 29 October 1975 Bad Pass Trail east along the Bighorn River inside Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area, the 22 February 1985 EJZ Bridge over the Shoshone River on County Road CN9-111, the 2009 Hyart Theater at 251 E. Main St., and the 15 July 1992 M L Ranch off Alternate U.S. 14 near Bighorn Lake. Shell’s Black Mountain Archeological District, encompassing the summit and southeast slopes, was listed 2 July 1987, the same year the EJE Bridge over Shell Creek on County Road CN9-57 was entered on 22 February 1985; the Hanson Site, recorded 15 December 1978, remains address-restricted. Hyattville contributes the 22 February 1985 EJP County Line Bridge on Road CN9-60, the 5 July 1973 Medicine Lodge Creek Site at 4800 County Road 52, and the 12 July 1990 Paint Rock Canyon Archeological Landscape District, the latter two with restricted or omitted coordinates. Bridger Immigrant Road–Dry Creek Crossing, 26 miles east of Cody on U.S. 14, was listed 17 January 1975, while Medicine Wheel–Medicine Mountain, near the summit of Medicine Mountain, became a National Historic Landmark on 16 April 1969. Rairden Bridge south of County Road CN9-30 was added 22 February 1985 near Manderson, and Schunk Lodge, roughly a mile north of Red Grade Road in Bighorn National Forest, entered the register on 4 January 2018 in the Big Horn vicinity.

title: Liga EBA
intro: Liga Española de Baloncesto Aficionado (EBA), commonly known as Liga EBA, is a Spanish basketball championship that is the fourth tier level in the Spanish basketball league system, after the Liga ACB, LEB Oro, and LEB Plata. It is administered by the FEB. It was previously the Spanish second tier level competition from 1994 to 1996, the third tier level from 1996 to 2000, and the fifth tier level, from 2007 to 2009. The Liga EBA is made up of five inter-regional groups. After the regular season, sixteen teams advance to the playoffs, where only four teams are promoted to the LEB Plata. The lowest ranked teams of each group, are relegated to the Primera División.
lm_description: AC1+ Piélagos represents Renedo de Piélagos at Fernando Expósito arena in Cantabria, while fellow Cantabrians Arha Hoteles play in Santander’s Palacio de Deportes and CB Solares calls Medio Cudeyo’s Mies del Corro home. Baskonia B, the reserve side from Vitoria-Gasteiz, hosts games at Mendizorrotza in the Basque Country, joined there by CB Santurtzi SK at Mikel Trueba in Santurtzi, Easo at José Antonio Gasca in San Sebastián, Goierri-Iparragirre 2020 at Aldiri in Urretxu, Mondragón Unibersitatea at Iturripe in Mondragón, Tabirako Baqué at Landako in Durango, and Ulacia Zarautz at Aritzbatalde in Zarautz. Castile and León supplies CB La Flecha, who compete in Arroyo de la Encomienda’s La Vega, Manteneo Filipenses in Palencia’s Municipal gym, and Nissan Grupo de Santiago at El Plantío in Burgos. Rounding out the group, Megacalzado Ardoi plays in the Municipal arena of Zizur Mayor-Zizur Nagusia, Navarre.

title: Live with Regis and Kelly (season 19)
intro: This is a list of Live with Regis and Kelly episodes which were broadcast during the show's 19th season. The list is ordered by air date. Although the co-hosts may have read a couple of emails during the broadcast, it does not necessarily count as a Regis and Kelly Inbox segment.
lm_description: Regis Philbin and Kelly Ripa opened the week of July 2 with Claire Danes, Jerry Mathers and Shaquille O’Neal, followed on July 3 by Josh Duhamel and Anneliese van der Pol, and on Independence Day welcomed Aly and AJ, Petra Němcová and Jim Cramer. Kevin Dillon, Connie Britton and the dog Lloyd appeared July 5, while Miley Cyrus, Pamela Anderson with magician Hans Klok, DJ JS-1 and the recurring Grill Friday segment filled July 6. July 9 brought Jason Priestley, Alan Cumming, NASCAR’s Jeff Gordon and Kat DeLuna; Don Cheadle, Bernadette Peters and tennis star James Blake visited July 10; Daniel Radcliffe, Sienna Miller and T-Pain were featured July 11; Emma Watson, Finola Hughes and Maroon 5 stopped by July 12; and Abigail Breslin, Joey Fatone and another Grill Friday closed that week on July 13. A five-day “Family Fitness Week” began July 16 with Queen Latifah and Blair Underwood, continued July 17 with John Travolta, July 18 with Adam Sandler and Zac Efron, July 19 with Jessica Biel and the kids’ group Hi-5, and ended July 20 alongside Kevin James and Grill Friday. Scott Baio and Lifehouse performed July 23; Christopher Walken, Kellie Pickler and Jennifer Hudson guested July 24; Katharine McPhee and Aaron Eckhart appeared July 25; Jennifer Lopez and Nikki Blonsky came July 26; Catherine Zeta-Jones and Paul Rudd closed the stretch with Grill Friday on July 27.

title: Live with Regis and Kelly (season 18)
intro: This is a list of Live with Regis and Kelly episodes which were broadcast during the show's 18th season. The list is ordered by air date. Although the co-hosts may have read a couple of e-mails during the broadcast, it does not necessarily count as a Regis and Kelly Inbox segment.
lm_description: Regis Philbin and Kelly Ripa opened the July 3 episode with Jeremy Piven and Alexis Bledel, plus summer-entertainment tips. On Independence Day they welcomed the 2006 American Idol crew—Kevin Covais, Mandisa, Kellie Pickler, Paris Bennett, Chris Daughtry, Elliott Yamin, Katharine McPhee and Taylor Hicks—for performances. Robert Downey Jr. and James Marsden visited July 5, Orlando Bloom appeared July 6, and July 7 brought Bernadette Peters, piñata-party pointers from Ingrid Hoffmann, psychic John Edward and the first Grill Friday. Tristan Rogers and Sugar Ray Leonard stopped by July 10, the Wayans brothers—Marlon, Shawn and Keenen Ivory—plus Venus Williams on July 11, Heidi Klum and Cheyenne Kimball July 12, Owen Wilson and Rainn Wilson July 13, and another Grill Friday closed July 14. Luke Wilson chatted July 17, Paul Giamatti and Kevin Smith July 18, Rosario Dawson July 19, Bo Bice and Uma Thurman July 20, while July 21 featured Rescue Me Dream Team Ambush Makeovers alongside Grill Friday. Cameron Mathison and Dulé Hill visited July 24, Ashanti and Colin Farrell plus a kids soapbox derby July 25, Jamie Foxx and Miss Universe July 26, Jesse Metcalfe July 27, and Kelly Ripa co-hosted with Geraldo Rivera July 28 for Flavor Flav, LeToya, a kids bowling contest and the final Grill Friday.

title: Live! with Regis and Kelly (season 24)
intro: This is a list of Live! with Regis and Kelly and Live! with Kelly episodes which were broadcast during the show's 24th season. The list is ordered by air date. Although the co-hosts may have read a couple of emails during the broadcast, it does not necessarily count as an Inbox segment.
lm_description: From April 2 through 5 the show decamped to Banff, Alberta, where Mark Consuelos welcomed Jason Biggs, Heejun Han and Scott Harrison before mushing a dogsled, Chris Harrison hosted Caroline Rhea, Jayma Mays, Far East Movement and the Calgary Fiddlers while Gelman cat-skied, Peter Facinelli paired with Johnny Galecki and Melanie Fiona as Kelly snowshoed, and Ben Mulroney greeted David James Elliott and chef Martin Luthi while Kelly tried torchlight skiing. Back in New York on April 9, Howie Mandel’s first day unveiled the new set, introduced house DJ Samantha Ronson and interviewed Sofía Vergara, L.A. Reid and DeAndre Brackensick; Mandel returned April 10 with Christina Applegate, Gabourey Sidibe and DJ Pauly D. Carson Kressley took over April 11 for Cheryl Hines, Monica & Brandy and the New York International Auto Show with DJ Cassidy, followed April 12 by Joel McHale alongside Laura Linney, Bradley Whitford and wow cars with Chrissie Miller, and April 13 by McHale again with John Slattery, Martha Plimpton, SUVs and DJ Twist. D. L. Hughley co-hosted April 16 with Ice T and Paul Wesley, then April 17 with Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Ronnie Wood and Jane Goodall. Mike Greenberg April 18 chatted with Olivia Wilde, Kevin Hart and Science Bob, Seth Meyers April 19 welcomed Zac Efron, Ana Gasteyer and Karina Smirnoff with Gavin DeGraw, and April 20 hosted Candice Bergen, Eva LaRue and Peter Gros. Jesse Palmer April 23 demonstrated five-minute French toast with Kate Walsh and Colton Dixon, then April 24 discussed prom trends with Hugh Grant and Blair Underwood. title: Timeline of free and open-source software
intro: This article presents a timeline of events related to popular free/open-source software. For a narrative explaining the overall development, see the related history of free and open-source software. The Achievements column documents achievements a project attained at some point in time (not necessarily when it was first released).
lm_description: In 1991 Linus Torvalds started the Linux kernel, whose source code released that same year would expand from a few commercially restricted C files to 290 MB under the GNU GPL by 2007, while Guido van Rossum first released Python. The next year Lynne and William Jolitz began public 386BSD releases, Andrew Tridgell wrote the initial Samba at the Australian National University, and frustration over 386BSD’s direction led Chris Demetriou, Theo de Raadt, Adam Glass and Charles Hannum to launch NetBSD in March 1993. December 1993 brought FreeBSD 1.0, Bob Amstadt and Eric Youngdale started Wine to run Windows programs on Linux, and the first Linux Journal appeared in March 1994. Rasmus Lerdorf’s PHP reached the public in June 1995, the same year Spencer Kimball and Peter Mattis created the General Image Manipulation Program and Yukihiro Matsumoto released Ruby, later popularized by Ruby on Rails. Robert McCool’s Apache web server debuted in 1996 alongside Matthias Ettrich’s KDE, Miguel de Icaza and Federico Mena founded GNOME in August 1997, and Sun Microsystems bought StarOffice in 1999, freeing its code as OpenOffice.org that August and dual-licensing it under LGPL and SISSL on 19 July 2000.
to_index_text:

title: List of royalty by net worth
intro: This is Forbes' list of richest royals, as estimated by their personal net worth, excluding properties held by the state, government or Crown, in U.S. dollars in 2011. Since the publication of the estimates from 2011, Qaboos bin Said al Said of Oman, Abdullah of Saudi Arabia and Bhumibol of Thailand have died and Beatrix of the Netherlands and Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani have abdicated. A more recent Forbes Article from 2016 updates some of the Arab members of the list.
lm_description: Thailand’s late King Bhumibol Adulyadej headed the 2011 Forbes roll with $43.8 billion drawn from Crown Property Bureau investments, while Dubai Sheikh Ahmed bin Saeed Al Maktoum followed at $31.7 billion through chairmanship of Emirates Group, Dubai World, Noor Bank and associated insurers. Brunei’s Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah claimed third place with $20 billion in oil-and-gas proceeds, and Saudi Arabia’s King Abdullah bin Abdul Aziz Al Saud, who died in 2015, held $18 billion from petroleum. Abu Dhabi’s President and Emir Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan reached $15 billion via the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, Morocco’s King Mohammed VI held $5.7 billion in SNI and Siger Holdings, and Dubai ruler Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum counted $4.5 billion from Dubai Holding and the same sovereign fund. Liechtenstein’s Prince Hans Adam II commanded $3.5 billion through his family foundation, Qatar’s Emir Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani—who abdicated in 2013—possessed $2.4 billion from assorted enterprises, and Monaco’s Prince Albert II rounded out the billion-dollar tier with $1 billion rooted in casinos and the Société des bains de mer. France-based Aga Khan IV, Karim al-Hussayni, held $800 million via the Aga Khan Development Network, Oman’s late Sultan Qaboos bin Said al Said had $700 million, Britain’s Queen Elizabeth II $450 million in property and jewels, Kuwait’s Emir Sabah Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah $350 million, the Netherlands’ Queen Beatrix—who abdicated in 2013—$200 million in Royal Dutch Shell stock, and Eswatini’s King Mswati III $100 million.

title: Ed O'Neill
intro: Edward Leonard O'Neill (born April 12, 1946) is an American actor and comedian. His roles include Al Bundy on the Fox Network sitcom Married. with Children, for which he was nominated for two Golden Globes, and Jay Pritchett on the award-winning ABC sitcom Modern Family, a role for which he has been nominated for three Primetime Emmy Awards and won four Screen Actors Guild Awards, all for being part of a best Ensemble in a Comedy Series. He has also appeared in the Wayne's World film series, Little Giants, Prefontaine, The Bone Collector and Sun Dogs, and has done voice-work for the Wreck It Ralph franchise and Finding Dory.
lm_description: Ed O’Neill debuted onscreen in 1980 as Detective Schreiber in Cruising and as Terry in The Dogs of War, then spent 1989 as Sergeant Brannigan in K-9 and George Denver in Disorganized Crime. 1990 found him playing Lieutenant Amos in The Adventures of Ford Fairlane and Wilbur Meany in Sibling Rivalry, followed by Dutch Dooley in 1991’s Dutch. He returned as Glen in both 1992’s Wayne’s World and 1993’s Wayne’s World 2, then portrayed Ed in 1994’s Blue Chips and Kevin O’Shea in Little Giants that same year. After embodying Bill Dellinger in 1997’s Prefontaine and an FBI Team Leader in The Spanish Prisoner, he took on Detective Paulie Sellitto in 1999’s The Bone Collector. The new millennium saw him as Dick Simmons in Lucky Numbers, Norman Pinkney in Nobody’s Baby, Burch in Spartan, Congressman Cardone in Steel Valley, a Hollywood Producer in Redbelt, and Chief Justice Renato Corona in Lost Masterpieces of Pornography.

title: United Nationalist Alliance
intro: The United Nationalist Alliance (UNA) is a political party in the Philippines. It was created as a multi-party electoral alliance replacing the former United Opposition (UNO) coalition for the 2013 midterm elections, before it was launched as a single political party on July 1, 2015 by Jejomar Binay for his candidacy in the 2016 presidential election. The acronym UNA spells out the Filipino word for first.
lm_description: Nancy Binay, running under UNA, had no prior political post but is the daughter of Vice President Jejomar Binay, former Makati mayor Elenita Binay, sister to ex-Makati mayor Jun-Jun Binay and congresswoman Abigail Binay. Tingting Cojuangco, also UNA, served Tarlac governor from 1992-1998 and is married to Congressman Jose Cojuangco Jr., cousin to Eduardo Cojuangco Jr., aunt to President Benigno Aquino III and National Youth Commission chairman Bam Aquino, sister-in-law to ex-Senator Robert Jaworski and mother-in-law to former Pasig Rep. Robert Jaworski Jr. JV Ejercito, UNA bet, has been San Juan’s lone congressman since 2010 and is President Joseph Estrada’s son, San Juan mayor Guia Gomez’s child, half-brother to Senator Jinggoy Estrada and cousin to Laguna Governor ER Ejercito. Jack Enrile, running with NPC, has held Cagayan’s 1st district House seat since 2010, is Senate President Juan Ponce Enrile’s son and husband to congresswoman Sally Ponce Enrile. Richard J. Gordon, UNA candidate, was senator 2004-2010, is married to Olongapo mayor Katherine K. Gordon and uncle to Olongapo councilor John Carlos de los Reyes. Gregorio Honasan, UNA slate member, has sat in the Senate since 2007 and lists no relatives in office. Ernesto Maceda, UNA aspirant, was senator 1971-1972 and 1987-1998 and father to Manila 4th district councilor Edward VP Maceda. Mitos Magsaysay, UNA contender, has represented Zambales’ 1st district since 2004, is daughter-in-law to Zambales governor Vic Magsaysay and niece-in-law to Senator Ramon Magsaysay Jr. Juan Miguel Zubiri, UNA bet, served senator 2007-2011, is son to Bukidnon vice-governor Jose Ma. R. Zubiri Jr. and brother to congressman Jose Zubiri III.

title: BN postcode area
intro: The BN postcode area, also known as the Brighton postcode area, is a group of 30 postcode districts in South East England, within 18 post towns. These cover southwestern East Sussex (including Brighton, Hove, Eastbourne, Lewes, Hailsham, Newhaven, Peacehaven, Pevensey, Polegate and Seaford) and southeastern West Sussex (including Worthing, Littlehampton, Arundel, Hassocks, Henfield, Lancing, Shoreham-by-Sea and Steyning). The main sorting office is at the Gatwick Mail Centre in Crawley.
lm_description: Brighton’s BN1 sweeps from the city centre through Coldean, Falmer, Hollingbury, Patcham, Preston, Stanmer and Withdean, straddling Brighton and Hove and Lewes, while neighbouring BN2 covers the eastern quarters—Bevendean, Brighton Marina, Kemptown, Moulsecoomb, Ovingdean, Rottingdean, Saltdean and Woodingdean—under the same two councils. Hove’s BN3 is confined to Aldrington, Hangleton and West Blatchington within Brighton and Hove. Henfield’s BN5 gathers Blackstone, Edburton, Fulking, Small Dole, Wineham and Woodmancote across Horsham and Mid Sussex. Hassocks’ BN6 threads through Albourne, Clayton, Ditchling, Goddards Green, Hurstpierpoint, Keymer, Newtimber, Sayers Common, Streat and Westmeston, shared by Lewes and Mid Sussex. Lewes itself claims BN7 with Cooksbridge, East Chiltington, Iford, Kingston, Offham, Plumpton, Plumpton Green, Rodmell, Southease, Swanborough and Telscombe, while BN8 radiates to Barcombe, Barcombe Cross, Beddingham, Chailey Green, Chiddingly, East Hoathly, Firle, Glynde, Halland, Hamsey, Holmes Hill, Laughton, Newick, North Chailey, Ringmer, Ripe, Shortgate, South Chailey, Southerham, Stoneham and Whitesmith, split between Lewes and Wealden. Newhaven’s BN9 covers Piddinghoe, South Heighton and Tarring Neville; Peacehaven’s BN10 adds Telscombe Cliffs. Worthing’s BN11 stands alone, but BN12 incorporates Ferring and Goring-by-Sea, BN13 reaches Clapham, Durrington, High Salvington, Patching and Tarring, and BN14 takes in Broadwater, Findon, Northend and Tarring, all overlapping Arun and Worthing. Lancing’s BN15 includes Coombes and Sompting within Adur and Worthing. Littlehampton’s BN16 serves Angmering, East Preston, Kingston Gorse and Rustington, while BN17 centres on Littlehampton, Climping, Lyminster and Wick, both under Arun. Arundel’s BN18 stretches from Amberley, Binsted, Burpham, Crossbush, Fontwell, Ford, Houghton, Madehurst, Poling, Slindon, Slindon Common, South Stoke, Tortington, Walberton, Warningcamp, Wepham and Yapton across Arun and Horsham. Eastbourne’s BN20 embraces Beachy Head, East Dean, Friston, Old Town, Ratton, Wannock and Willingdon with Eastbourne and Wealden; BN21 stays in the Old Town within Eastbourne, and BN22 covers Hampden Park and Willingdon shared by Eastbourne and Wealden.

title: List of Olympic medalists in luge
intro: Luge is one of the seven Olympic sports currently contested at the Winter Olympic Games. It has been a constant presence in the Olympic program since its introduction at the 1964 Winter Olympics in Innsbruck, Austria, in the form of three events: men's singles, women's singles, and doubles. [a] A mixed team relay event was contested for the first time at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi.
lm_description: At Innsbruck 1964 Josef Feistmantl and Manfred Stengl gave Austria gold ahead of compatriots Reinhold Senn and Helmut Thaler, while Walter Aussendorfer and Sigisfredo Mair took bronze for Italy. Four years later in Grenoble Klaus Bonsack and Thomas Köhler of East Germany claimed the title, with Austria’s Manfred Schmid and Ewald Walch second and West Germans Wolfgang Winkler and Fritz Nachmann third. In Sapporo 1972 East Germans Horst Hörnlein and Reinhard Bredow shared the top step with Italy’s Paul Hildgartner and Walter Plaikner after no silver was awarded, while bronze stayed with the GDR through Klaus Bonsack and Wolfram Fiedler. Hans Rinn and Norbert Hahn then defended their 1976 Innsbruck victory at Lake Placid 1980, sandwiching silver for Italy’s Peter Gschnitzer and Karl Brunner and bronze for Austrians Georg Fluckinger and Karl Schrott. West Germany struck gold in Sarajevo 1984 via Hans Stangassinger and Franz Wembacher, ahead of Soviet pair Yevgeny Belousov and Aleksandr Belyakov and GDR bronze-medallists Jörg Hoffmann and Jochen Pietzsch, who reversed the order to win four years later in Calgary ahead of compatriots Stefan Krauße and Jan Behrendt. Krauße and Behrendt then won for unified Germany in Albertville 1992 and again in Nagano 1998, sandwiching Lillehammer 1994 where Italians Kurt Brugger and Wilfried Huber edged team-mates Hansjörg Raffl and Norbert Huber. Patric Leitner and Alexander Resch started Germany’s new century with gold at Salt Lake City 2002, while Austrians Andreas Linger and Wolfgang Linger doubled their titles in Turin 2006 and Vancouver 2010 before Germans Tobias Wendl and Tobias Arlt took the next two Olympic crowns at Sochi 2014 and Pyeongchang 2018.

List of Olympic medalists in luge

[a] A mixed team relay event was contested for the first time at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi.
At Innsbruck 1964 Josef Feistmantl and Manfred Stengl gave Austria gold ahead of compatriots Reinhold Senn and Helmut Thaler, while Walter Aussendorfer and Sigisfredo Mair took bronze for Italy. Four years later in Grenoble Klaus Bonsack and Thomas Köhler of East Germany claimed the title, with Austria’s Manfred Schmid and Ewald Walch second and West Germans Wolfgang Winkler and Fritz Nachmann third. In Sapporo 1972 East Germans Horst Hörnlein and Reinhard Bredow shared the top step with Italy’s Paul Hildgartner and Walter Plaikner after no silver was awarded, while bronze stayed with the GDR through Klaus Bonsack and Wolfram Fiedler. Hans Rinn and Norbert Hahn then defended their 1976 Innsbruck victory at Lake Placid 1980, sandwiching silver for Italy’s Peter Gschnitzer and Karl Brunner and bronze for Austrians Georg Fluckinger and Karl Schrott. West Germany struck gold in Sarajevo 1984 via Hans Stangassinger and Franz Wembacher, ahead of Soviet pair Yevgeny Belousov and Aleksandr Belyakov and GDR bronze-medallists Jörg Hoffmann and Jochen Pietzsch, who reversed the order to win four years later in Calgary ahead of compatriots Stefan Krauße and Jan Behrendt. Krauße and Behrendt then won for unified Germany in Albertville 1992 and again in Nagano 1998, sandwiching Lillehammer 1994 where Italians Kurt Brugger and Wilfried Huber edged team-mates Hansjörg Raffl and Norbert Huber. Patric Leitner and Alexander Resch started Germany’s new century with gold at Salt Lake City 2002, while Austrians Andreas Linger and Wolfgang Linger doubled their titles in Turin 2006 and Vancouver 2010 before Germans Tobias Wendl and Tobias Arlt took the next two Olympic crowns at Sochi 2014 and Pyeongchang 2018.

title: Givro Corporation
intro: Givro Corporation (株式会社 ギブロ, Kabushiki-kaisha Giburo) was a Japanese video game development company founded in 1989 in Tokyo, Japan by Takashi Yoneda, who was previously employed by Technos Japan and Enix. The company was originally established under the name Almanic Corporation (株式会社 アルマニック, Kabushiki-kaisha Arumaniku), which it operated under for a few years before changing its corporate name in 1995. Givro would go on to produce games for home consoles such as the Super NES, Genesis, 32X, Nintendo 64 and Sega Saturn. Givro released their final game in late 1997 and quietly dissolved at the end of the following year.
lm_description: Almanic Corporation, later Givro, opened its catalogue on 26 May 1990 with E.V.O.: The Theory of Evolution for Enix on the Japanese PC-98. A year and a half later Treco brought Fighting Masters to Mega Drive audiences in Japan and North America on 6 December 1991. Banpresto followed on 28 August 1992 with the Super Famicom exclusive CB Chara Wars. Enix returned on 19 December 1992 to publish the Super NES evolutionary sequel E.V.O.: Search for Eden in both Japan and North America. Sega took worldwide distribution of Mazin Saga: Mutant Fighter on 25 February 1993, releasing the Mega Drive title across Japan, North America and Europe. Dynamic Kikaku shipped the Super NES side-scrolling shooter Shien's Revenge on 8 April 1994, again for Japan and North America. One week later, on 29 April 1994, Technos Japan Corp issued the Japanese Super Famicom brawler Shin Nekketsu Kōha: Kunio-tachi no Banka. Almanic's final release under that name, Wonder Project J, reached Japanese Super Famicom players through Enix on 9 December 1994.

title: Sports teams in Florida
intro: Sports teams in Florida include many professional, semi-professional, amateur and college teams. In professional sports, Florida has three National Football League teams, two Major League Baseball teams, two National Basketball Association teams, two National Hockey League teams, two Major League Soccer teams, one Women's Soccer team and many minor league teams in various sports. Additionally, since the late 19th century Florida has been a significant spring training destination for Major League Baseball teams and their affiliates.
lm_description: Jacksonville’s Jumbo Shrimp have captured six Southern League crowns—1968, 1996, 2001, 2005, 2009 and 2010—while playing at the Baseball Grounds of Jacksonville, whereas Pensacola’s Blue Wahoos, housed at Pensacola Bayfront Stadium, are still seeking their first title. In the Class-A Florida State League, the Fort Myers Mighty Mussels lead with seven championships (1969-72, 1978, 2018 twice) at Hammond Stadium, followed by the St. Lucie Mets with five (1988, 1996, 1998, 2003, 2006) at Tradition Field and the Tampa Tarpons with five (1994, 2001, 2004, 2009, 2010) at Legends Field. Lakeland’s Flying Tigers earned three (1976, 1977, 1992) at Joker Marchant Stadium, Daytona’s Tortugas three (1995, 2004, 2008) at Jackie Robinson Ballpark, and Charlotte’s Stone Crabs two (1983, 1990) at Charlotte Sports Park, while Bradenton’s Marauders (2016 at McKechnie Field), Clearwater’s Threshers (2007 at Spectrum Field) and Palm Beach’s Cardinals (2005 at Roger Dean Stadium) each boast one. Dunedin’s Blue Jays, Jupiter’s Hammerheads and the Florida Fire Frogs have yet to win. On the hardwood, the Lakeland Magic play in the NBA G League at RP Funding Center without a title, while the Jacksonville Giants have dominated the ABA with three banners (2012, 2013, 2016) at VyStar Veterans Memorial Arena and the Miami Midnites collected three FBA crowns (2014, 2015, 2016) at David Posnack Jewish Community Center; Daytona Beach Sharks, Native Pride and South Florida Gold remain ringless.

title: List of fictional birds of prey
intro: This list of fictional birds of prey is subsidiary to the list of fictional birds. It is restricted to notable bird of prey characters from the world of fiction.
lm_description: Blathers the owl runs the museum in Animal Crossing, while his colleague Celeste oversees its observatory in Animal Crossing: New Leaf. The Mighty Eagle, a bald eagle from Angry Birds, obliterates obstacles when a sardine can is slung, and his Angry Birds Stella counterpart Dahila, a great-horned owl, joins Stella’s flock and dabbles in experiments. Clockwerk, the Eurasian eagle-owl, haunts Sly Cooper as a relentless foe, whereas Skowl the Startling commands parliament owls in Donkey Kong Country: Tropical Freeze. Condor, the vegetable-snatching condor of Ice Climber, forces the Ice Climbers to reclaim their produce, and Crimson Loftwing soars beside Link in The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword. Coo the owl and the titanic Dyna Blade both aid Kirby across the Kirby series. Falco Lombardi, a pheasant ace pilot mistaken for a peregrine falcon, leads Team Star Fox, while Jet the Hawk races through Sonic Riders and its sequels. Kaepora Gaebora offers cryptic guidance throughout The Legend of Zelda, contrasting with Kuro, the owl antagonist of Ori and the Blind Forest. Otus, the owl hero of Owlboy, takes flight, and Silver the peregrine falcon dives into Angry Birds 2. Bloodwing soars nameless above Borderlands, Quintole Force patrols Astro Boy: Omega Factor, and a giant red Eagle ferries Sinbad across The Seven Adventures of Sindbad.

title: List of Eagle Scouts
intro:
Eagle Scout is the highest rank attainable in the Scouts BSA program division of the Boy Scouts of America (BSA). Since it was first awarded to Arthur Rose Eldred on August 21, 1912, Eagle Scout has been earned by more than two million youth. The list below includes notable recipients. As of 2014[update], requirements include earning at least 21 merit badges and demonstrating Scout Spirit, leadership, and service. The requirements include an Eagle Scout Service Project where the Scout must further demonstrate service and leadership. Eagle Scouts are recognized with a medal and a cloth badge that visibly recognizes the accomplishments of the Scout. Eagle Palms are a further recognition, awarded for completing additional tenure, leadership, and merit badge requirements. Typically adult volunteers who have received the Eagle award as a youth wear a smaller patch depicting a square knot. The Distinguished Eagle Scout Award (DESA) is bestowed to Eagle Scouts for nationally renowned distinguished service in their profession and to the community for a period of at least 25 years after earning the Eagle Scout rank. Since its introduction in 1969 by the National Eagle Scout Association, the DESA has been awarded to just under 2000 Eagle Scouts. [a]
 The NESA Outstanding Eagle Scout Award (NOESA) is bestowed to Eagle Scouts who have distinguished themselves at a local-to-regional level or who have not yet met the 25-year tenure requirement to be considered for a DESA. This award was introduced in 2011.
lm_description: Joseph R. Tanner earned Eagle in 1966 and later flew on shuttle missions STS-66, STS-82, STS-97 and STS-115. Ed Tarpley, who became Eagle in 1971, served as District Attorney of Grant Parish, Louisiana from 1991 to 1997. J. L. Tarr, a 1935 Eagle, spent 43 years as a professional Scouter and became the seventh Chief Scout Executive of the BSA. Thomas L. Tatham, an Eagle from 1927, worked as an attorney and Dade County land developer while also serving as former BSA Southeast region vice president. Manti Te’o, who earned Eagle in 2008, became an All-American linebacker for the University of Notre Dame. John Tesh, a 1968 Eagle, became a New Age and contemporary Christian musician and nationally syndicated radio host. Cy Thao, a 1988 Eagle, is a Laotian-born Hmong state representative (DFL) in Minnesota. Paul Theroux, Eagle class of 1955, is a travel writer and novelist. Glenn Thompson, who earned Eagle in 1977, has represented Pennsylvania in Congress since 2009. Leo K. Thorsness, a 1948 Eagle, served as an Air Force fighter pilot, Vietnam War prisoner of war and Medal of Honor recipient. Austin Tice, Eagle 2001, is a 7th-generation Texan, Georgetown graduate, Marine Corps captain and award-winning war reporter. Rex Tillerson, a 1965 Eagle, became chairman and CEO of ExxonMobil and U.S. Secretary of State. Joseph E. Tofalo, 1977 Eagle and American Legion Eagle Scout of the Year, rose to Navy admiral and Commander of Submarine Group 10. Pat Toomey, who earned Eagle in 1977, has served as Pennsylvania’s senator since 2011. Travis Tope, a 2010 Eagle, is an actor from Texas. Alvin Townley, Eagle 1993, wrote the book Legacy of Honor. David Trick, a 1969 Eagle, is a Canadian public servant, university administrator and author. Scott Trimble, Eagle 1993, works as a location scout and manager on films including Transformers, Star Trek and Iron Man 2. Carlisle Trost, 1947 Eagle, became a Navy admiral, submariner and 23rd Chief of Naval Operations from 1996 to 2000. Richard H. Truly, a 1952 Eagle, served as Navy vice admiral, flew on shuttle missions STS-2 and STS-8 and became the first former astronaut to head NASA.

title: British Pacific Fleet
intro: The British Pacific Fleet (BPF) was a Royal Navy formation which saw action against Japan during the Second World War. The fleet was composed of British Commonwealth naval vessels. The BPF formally came into being on 22 November 1944 from the remaining ships of the former Eastern Fleet then being re-designated the East Indies Fleet and continuing to be based in Trincomalee. The British Pacific Fleet's main base was at Sydney, Australia, with a forward base at Manus Island. One of the largest fleets ever assembled by the Royal Navy, by VJ Day it had four battleships and six fleet aircraft carriers, fifteen smaller aircraft carriers, eleven cruisers, and numerous smaller warships, submarines, and support vessels.
lm_description: 801 Naval Air Squadron flew Seafire L.IIIs from Implacable from May 1945 as part of the 8th Carrier Air Group, escorting strikes on Truk and Japan until after VJ-Day. 812 Squadron, equipped with Barracuda IIs aboard Vengeance, was at sea on VJ-Day heading for Taiwan with TG 111.2, diverted to Hong Kong, arriving 29 August. 814’s Barracuda IIs on Venerable saw no action, while 820’s Avengers on Indefatigable, after raiding Palembang and the Sakashima Gunto with 849, joined the 7th Carrier Air Group for Tokyo strikes from June 1945. 827’s Barracuda IIs on Colossus operated in the Indian Ocean from June 1945, BPF service unclear. 828 mixed Barracudas and Avengers on Implacable, 8th CAG, attacked Truk and Japan. 837’s Barracuda IIs on Glory, 16th CAG, saw no action but covered the Rabaul surrender. 848’s Avengers on Formidable hit Sakishima Gunto and Formosa, then joined 2nd CAG for July Japan strikes. 849’s Avengers on Victorious, No 2 Strike Wing, bombed Pangkalan Brandon and Palembang, then Sakashima Gunto, Formosa, and Tokyo, scoring the first bomb hit on carrier Kaiyo. 854’s Avengers on Illustrious struck Belawan Deli and Palembang, then Sakishima Gunto, joined 3rd CAG in July but saw no further action. 857’s Avengers on Indomitable raided Belawan Deli, Pangkalan Brandan, Palembang, and hammered Sakishima Gunto and Formosa, then fought suicide boats off Hong Kong on 31 August–1 September. 880’s Seafires on Implacable escorted Truk strikes, merged into 8th CAG, and attacked Japan. 885’s Hellcats on Ruler provided fleet cover, re-equipped June 1945 but saw no more action. 887’s Seafires on Indefatigable bombed Palembang, Sakashima Gunto, and Tokyo. 888’s Hellcats on Indefatigable operated over Sumatra, stayed in Ceylon when BPF sailed. 894’s Seafires on Indefatigable hit Palembang, Sakishima Gunto, and the mainland before VJ-Day. 899’s Seafire pool trained aboard Chaser and was on Arbiter at VJ-Day. 1770’s Fireflies on Indefatigable raided Palembang, Sakashima Gunto, and Formosa. 1771’s Fireflies on Implacable, 8th CAG, struck Truk in June 1945 and the mainland. 1772’s Fireflies on Indefatigable attacked the mainland until VJ-Day.

title: Matthew Rhys
intro: Matthew Rhys Evans (born 4 November 1974; /riːs/) is a Welsh actor. He is known for playing Kevin Walker in Brothers & Sisters (2006-2011) and Philip Jennings in the The Americans (2013-2018), for which he received two Golden Globe Award nominations and a Primetime Emmy Award. In film, he has appeared as Dylan Thomas in the film The Edge of Love (2008), Daniel Ellsberg in the film The Post (2017) and starred in A Beautiful Day in the Neighborhood (2019).
lm_description: Matthew Rhys debuted on screen in 1997 as Boyo in House of America, then played Demetrius in Titus and Ray Smith in Whatever Happened to Harold Smith? both in 1999. He followed with Carl in Sorted (2000), Nob in Very Annie Mary (2001), James Strang in The Abduction Club, Doc Fairweather in Deathwatch and Eddie in Shooters (all 2002), and the Welsh mythic hero Lleu Llaw Gyffes in Y Mabinogi (2003). After portraying Nick Edwards in Fakers (2004), Rhys took the roles of Peter Simon in Love and Other Disasters (2006), Count Dzerzhinsky in Virgin Territory (2007), Dylan Thomas in The Edge of Love (2008), Marc in The Think Tank (2009), Mateo in Patagonia (2010), Damien in Everything Carries Me To You (2011) and the dual role of John Standing and Johnny Spence in The Scapegoat (2012). He later appeared as Reece in Burnt and Percy in En mai, fais ce qu’il te plait (both 2015), and as Daniel Ellsberg in The Post (2017).

title: 2012 Montreal Impact season
intro: The 2012 Montreal Impact season was the club's inaugural season in Major League Soccer, the top flight of both American and Canadian soccer. Including the former club, this was the 19th season of a team under the moniker Montreal Impact. For the 2012 season, outside of MLS, the Impact competed in the 2012 Canadian Championship, Canada's domestic cup competition, which determined the Canadian entrant in the CONCACAF Champions League, in which they lost the semi-final. Jesse Marsch was hired to be the head coach in the club's inaugural season in MLS. Mauro Biello, Preston Burpo and Mike Sorber were hired as assistant coaches for the inaugural season.
lm_description: Nelson Rivas joined from Inter Milan on a free transfer 3 October 2011 to anchor the defence wearing number 2, while fellow centre-back Hassoun Camara, Evan Bush in goal, and midfielder Siniša Ubiparipović were all promoted from the NASL side on frees between 11 October and 1 November. On 23 November Montreal plundered the Expansion Draft, selecting Zarek Valentin from Chivas USA, Justin Mapp from Philadelphia, Jeb Brovsky from Vancouver, Collen Warner from Real Salt Lake, Josh Gardner from Columbus and Sanna Nyassi from Colorado, then immediately traded for Chivas striker Justin Braun, sending James Riley the other way. That same day they landed Tyson Wahl from Seattle for allocation money, and within five days added Fort Lauderdale’s Bryan Arguez on a free. Late November brought captain Davy Arnaud from Sporting KC in exchange for Seth Sinovic and allocation money, and Jamaican goalkeeper Donovan Ricketts from Los Angeles for allocation money. December saw Miguel Montaño arrive on a free from Seattle, Greg Sutton from New York, Danish-based Canadian international Patrice Bernier from Lyngby, and Brazilian Felipe from FC Lugano, while Duke forward Andrew Wenger was selected first overall in the 2012 MLS SuperDraft on 12 January.

On 23 November Montreal plundered the Expansion Draft, selecting Zarek Valentin from Chivas USA, Justin Mapp from Philadelphia, Jeb Brovsky from Vancouver, Collen Warner from Real Salt Lake, Josh Gardner from Columbus and Sanna Nyassi from Colorado, then immediately traded for Chivas striker Justin Braun, sending James Riley the other way. That same day they landed Tyson Wahl from Seattle for allocation money, and within five days added Fort Lauderdale’s Bryan Arguez on a free. Late November brought captain Davy Arnaud from Sporting KC in exchange for Seth Sinovic and allocation money, and Jamaican goalkeeper Donovan Ricketts from Los Angeles for allocation money. December saw Miguel Montaño arrive on a free from Seattle, Greg Sutton from New York, Danish-based Canadian international Patrice Bernier from Lyngby, and Brazilian Felipe from FC Lugano, while Duke forward Andrew Wenger was selected first overall in the 2012 MLS SuperDraft on 12 January.

title: List of flag bearers for North Macedonia at the Olympics
intro: This is a list of flag bearers who have represented North Macedonia at the Olympics. Flag bearers carry the national flag of their country at the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games.
lm_description: North Macedonia’s first Olympic flag bearer was wrestler Shaban Tërstena at the 1996 Summer Games. Alpine skier Jana Nikolovska carried the flag twice, in the 1998 Winter Olympics and again in 2002. Basketball player Blagoja Georgievski led the delegation at the 2004 Summer Games, followed by alpine skier Gjorgji Markovski in 2006. Canoeist Atanas Nikolovski had the honor in 2008, and alpine skier Antonio Ristevski in 2010. Swimmer Marko Blaževski was the flag bearer for the 2012 Summer Olympics, while cross-country skier Darko Damjanovski did so in 2014. Swimmer Anastasia Bogdanovski carried the flag at the 2016 Summer Games, and cross-country skier Stavre Jada in the 2018 Winter Olympics.

title: 2011 A Championship
intro: The 2011 A Championship was the fourth and final season of the A Championship. The season was sponsored by Newstalk. The league featured 16 teams. Derry City A were the champions, while UCD A finished as runners up.

title: Endorsements in the 2012 Republican Party presidential primaries
intro: This article is a list of endorsements made by members of the 112th United States Congress and other elected officials during the 2012 Republican Party presidential primaries. Endorsements of statesmen and celebrities are also important to candidates. Late in the Republican race cycle, Romney toured Israel and Poland after a visit to the London 2012 Olympics. He received the endorsement of former President of Poland Lech Wałęsa, and soon after, the endorsement of actor and Second Amendment proponent Clint Eastwood. The winning of endorsements, also known as the Endorsement Race or Endorsement Derby, is argued to be a vital feature of the United States presidential race and the political party system. [by whom?]
lm_description: Sharron Angle, former Nevada assemblywoman and 2010 GOP Senate nominee, backed Rick Santorum on 2 January 2012, as did Colorado’s ex-lieutenant governor Jane Norton, ex-congressmen Bob Schaffer and Tom Tancredo—though Tancredo, a Constitutionalist who had first backed Herman Cain, joined the Santorum column the same day. Idaho treasurer Ron Crane followed on 14 February, joined that day by Megadeth front-man Dave Mustaine; Ohio attorney general Mike DeWine, who had earlier endorsed Mitt Romney, switched to Santorum on 17 February. Contemporary-Christian star Michael W. Smith capped the spree on 12 March. All endorsements were later rendered moot when Santorum suspended his campaign.
