title: List of medical schools in the United Kingdom
intro: There are thirty three medical schools in the United Kingdom that are recognised by the General Medical Council and where students can study for a medical degree. There are twenty-five such schools in England, five in Scotland, two in Wales and one in Northern Ireland. All but Warwick Medical School and Swansea Medical School offer undergraduate courses in medicine. The Bute Medical School (University of St Andrews) and Durham Medical School offer undergraduate pre-clinical courses only, with students proceeding to another medical school for clinical studies. Although Oxford University and Cambridge University offer both pre-clinical and clinical courses in medicine, students who study pre-clinical medicine at one of these universities may move to another university for clinical studies. At other universities students stay at the same university for both pre-clinical and clinical work.
lm_description: Aston Medical School, opened in 2015, confers the MBChB, while Anglia Ruskin School of Medicine welcomed its first 100-student cohort in 2018 for the same degree. Barts and The London School of Medicine and Dentistry, tracing teaching to 1123 and formally established in 1785, awards the MBBS after merging the historic Medical College of St Bartholomew’s and London Hospital Medical College under Queen Mary. Birmingham Medical School, dating from 1825, and Bristol Medical School, from 1833, both grant MBChB after their respective mergers with Mason Science College and University College, Bristol. Brighton and Sussex Medical School, created jointly by the universities of Brighton and Sussex in 2002, offers the BMBS. Cambridge’s School of Clinical Medicine, re-established in 1976 after centuries of intermittent teaching since 1540, awards the MB BChir. UCLan School of Medicine in Preston, recruiting international students since 2015 and UK-funded students from 2018, grants the MBBS. Exeter Medical School, formed in 2013 from the split of Peninsula College, awards the BMBS, as does the 2020-founded Kent and Medway Medical School, a collaboration between Kent and Canterbury Christchurch supervised by Brighton and Sussex. Hull York Medical School, affiliated with both Hull and York since 2003, confers the MBBS. Imperial College School of Medicine, established in 1997 from multiple mergers including Charing Cross Hospital (1818), awards the MBBS. Keele, beginning undergraduate clinical teaching in 2003 and awarding Manchester’s MBChB until 2012, now grants its own MBChB. King’s College London School of Medicine and Dentistry, merging in 1998 with roots at St Thomas’s from 1550, awards the MBBS. Lancaster Medical School, initially awarding Liverpool’s MBChB via a consortium, has granted Lancaster’s own MBChB since 2013. Leeds (1831), Leicester (1975), Liverpool (1834) and Manchester (1824, with teaching from 1752) all confer the MBChB, while Lincoln Medical School, anticipated in 2019, will award the MBBS.

title: List of Alpha Kappa Alpha sisters
intro: This list of Alpha Kappa Alpha sorors (commonly referred to as AKAs) includes initiated and honorary members of Alpha Kappa Alpha (ΑΚΑ), the first inter-collegiate Greek-letter sorority established for Black college women. Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority was founded on January 15, 1908, at Howard University in Washington, D.C., by nine women who were known as The Original Group of 1908, and seven sophomores, who were accepted as honor initiates and are known as The Sophomores of 1910. Alpha Kappa Alpha has a membership of more than 200,000 women in over 950 chapters in the United States and several other countries. Membership is extended to female college undergraduate and graduate students. The sorority also bestows honorary membership as its highest honor.
lm_description: Elmer Lucille Allen, initiated at Beta Epsilon chapter, became a ceramic artist and one of the first African-American female chemists in the United States. Barbara Chase-Riboud, a Delta Mu sister, gained recognition as both a sculptor and author. Kristye Addison Dudley, from Lambda Theta, works as a visual artist and painter. Honorary member Jan Spivey Gilchrist built her reputation as an illustrator. Anita Posey Lowe, initiated through Nu chapter, specializes in ceramic art. Barbara Madden-Swain, an Alpha Omicron Omega sister, also practices ceramic artistry. Laura Wheeler Waring, honored with honorary membership, created art as a painter and writer. Meta Vaux Warrick Fuller, another honorary member, established herself as an artist and sculptor. Mary Park Washington, from Kappa Omega chapter, works across multiple mediums as a painter, illustrator, and collage artist.

title: Liga EBA
intro: Liga Española de Baloncesto Aficionado (EBA), commonly known as Liga EBA, is a Spanish basketball championship that is the fourth tier level in the Spanish basketball league system, after the Liga ACB, LEB Oro, and LEB Plata. It is administered by the FEB. It was previously the Spanish second tier level competition from 1994 to 1996, the third tier level from 1996 to 2000, and the fifth tier level, from 2007 to 2009. The Liga EBA is made up of five inter-regional groups. After the regular season, sixteen teams advance to the playoffs, where only four teams are promoted to the LEB Plata. The lowest ranked teams of each group, are relegated to the Primera División.
lm_description: Aquimisa Carbajosa plays out of the Municipal gym in Carbajosa de la Sagrada, Castile and León, while Ávila Auténtica Carrefour El Bulevar hosts rivals at the Carlos Sastre arena in Ávila and Basket León uses León’s Palacio de los Deportes. Caja Rural de Zamora performs in the Ángel Nieto sports hall in Zamora and Universidad de Valladolid competes at Fuente de la Mora in Valladolid, keeping the Castile and León contingent at five clubs. Galicia supplies six teams: Calvo Basket Xiria from Carballo’s Vila de Noia, Estudiantes Lugo Leyma Natura at Lugo’s Pazo dos Deportes, KFC Culle in Culleredo’s O Burgo, Obradoiro B Silleda at Santiago’s Fontes do Sar, Porriño Baloncesto Base in the Porriño 2 pavilion, Santo Domingo Betanzos in Betanzos’ Municipal hall, and Ucoga Seguros CB Chantada in Chantada’s Municipal gym. Gijón Basket 2015 represents Asturias in the Palacio de Deportes of Gijón, and USAL La Antigua completes the group, playing at the Würzburg arena in Salamanca, Castile and León.

title: Cornwall League 1
intro: Cornwall 1, known as Tribute Cornwall 1 for sponsorship reasons, is an English level nine rugby union league for clubs based in Cornwall. It has been running continually since 1987-88. The champions are promoted to the Tribute Cornwall/Devon league, and the runner-up plays the second team in Tribute Devon 1, with the winning team gaining promotion. One or two teams are usually relegated to Tribute Cornwall 2. Saltash are the most successful team having won the league on five occasions and have been runner-up three times; they currently play in Tribute Cornwall/Devon. From the 2016-17 season Cornwall 1 and Cornwall 2 were amalgamated to create the Tribute Cornwall League with fifteen teams playing each other once in a first phase. After Christmas the teams split into two leagues with the top eight playing in Cornwall One and the remainder playing in Cornwall Two. Hayle won both phase one and phase two, winning the title with two matches to play. They are promoted to the Cornwall/Devon league, following their relegation from that league in 2015-16. Newquay Hornets finished in second place and were due to play their counterparts from Devon, Torrington for the second promotion spot. Newquay did not want promotion and declined to play the match. For the 2018-19 season Cornwall 1 and Cornwall 2 would revert to being two separate divisions.
lm_description: Camborne School of Mines, playing at Memorial Park on Kernick Road in Penryn, finished 3rd last season. Helston, based at King George V Playing Field in Helston, ended 6th. Illogan Park, from Illogan, placed 4th at Paynters Lane Playing Field. Lanner, hailing from Lanner, earned promotion from Tribute Cornwall 2. Liskeard-Looe, playing at Lux Park in Liskeard, were relegated from Tribute Cornwall/Devon. Perranporth, at Ponsmere Valley in Perranporth, came 5th. St Agnes, promoted from Tribute Cornwall 2, play at Enys Parc in St Agnes. Veor, from Camborne, finished 2nd last season at Wheal Gerry.

title: 1995 in Australian television
intro: This is a list of programs which made their premiere on an Australian television network that had previously premiered on another Australian television network. The networks involved in the switch of allegiances are predominantly both free-to-air networks or both subscription television networks. Programs that have their free-to-air/subscription television premiere, after previously premiering on the opposite platform (free-to air to subscription/subscription to free-to air) are not included. In some cases, programs may still air on the original television network. This occurs predominantly with programs shared between subscription television networks.
lm_description: In April 1995, TV1 handed a fresh free-to-air run to a wave of vintage favourites: The A-Team, Friday the 13th: The Series, TJ Hooker and The Jeffersons all resurfaced on Network Ten (the latter two under the old Channel 0 branding), while Battlestar Galactica and The Incredible Hulk docked at the Seven Network and Benson, B. J. and the Bear, Fonz and the Happy Days Gang, Knight Rider, McHale’s Navy, Miami Vice and Webster migrated to the Nine Network; Dennis the Menace (1959) was shared by Seven, Nine and Ten. The same month, TV1 also kept The Bionic Woman, Dragnet, Gimme a Break! and She Wolf of London exclusive to its own schedule. Later, on 7 August, Max gave Twinkle the Dream Being its Australian television encore.

title: 2013 FA WSL
intro: The 2013 FA WSL was the third season of the FA WSL, the top-level women's football league of England. The season began on 14 April and ended on 29 September. Arsenal were the defending champions, having won their ninth consecutive English title last season. The top two teams qualified for the 2014-15 UEFA Women's Champions League. The season was the last before the creation of a second division of the WSL. All teams had to reapply for a place in WSL 1 in the next season. Doncaster Belles were the only current WSL team not granted a WSL 1 place, thus they played in the WSL 2 the following season. This decision had already been taken before Doncaster finished the season bottom of the WSL with the lowest points tally, as no relegation to the WSL 2 based on points was scheduled until the WSL 2 had completed its inaugural season to produce a corresponding promotion team. The reason for Doncaster's relegation from WSL 1 was a failed reapplication based on financial criteria, which is an aspect of the WSL the FA monitors very closely since it funds the participating teams and the teams must regularly prove they can match the FA funding. The Belles' place in the top flight the following season was taken by the Manchester City Ladies team from the FA Women's Premier League National Division, but now re-branded as Manchester City Women. Likewise, Lincoln Ladies retained their place in WSL 1 but relocated and re-branded as Notts County Ladies for the following season.
lm_description: Arsenal, reigning champions from Borehamwood, entered the 2013 FA WSL season as 2012 winners and played at Meadow Park. Birmingham City, runners-up the previous year, competed from Stratford-upon-Avon at The DCS Stadium. Bristol Academy, who finished fourth in 2012, were based in Filton and hosted matches at Stoke Gifford Stadium. Chelsea, sixth-place finishers in 2012, played home games at Wheatsheaf Park in Staines. Doncaster Rovers Belles, seventh in 2012, operated from Doncaster’s Keepmoat Stadium. Everton, third in 2012, played out of Crosby at The Arriva Stadium. Lincoln Ladies, fifth the prior season, used Sincil Bank in Lincoln as their ground. Liverpool, who ended 2012 in eighth, played at Halton Stadium in Widnes.

title: Christian Television Network
intro: Christian Television Network (CTN) is a non-profit broadcast television network of small owned-and-operated stations (O&O) that broadcasts religious programming. It is based in Largo, Florida (with a mailing address of Clearwater), and the flagship station is WCLF channel 22, which signed on the air in the Tampa Bay region in 1979. It is now available on DirecTV channel 376 and Dish Network channel 267/9399. It was founded by Robert D'Andrea, who is still the president.
lm_description: Christian Television Network’s flagship is WCLF channel 22, serving Clearwater, Tampa and St. Petersburg, Florida. KFXB-TV 40 in Dubuque, Cedar Rapids, Iowa City and Waterloo, Iowa, dropped Fox in 2004. WYBU-CD 16 Columbus, Georgia, once carried the call letters WCGT. WFGC 61 covers West Palm Beach, Florida, while WGNM 45 Macon, Georgia, paired UPN with CTN until September 2006. WHBR 33 straddles Pensacola, Florida and Mobile, Alabama, and WHTN 39 serves Murfreesboro and Nashville, Tennessee. In Puerto Rico, Senda Educational Broadcasting owns WSJN-CD 20 San Juan, WVQS-LD 50 Isabel Segunda, WELU 32 Aguadilla and WUSP-LD 25 Ponce, all operated by CTN; WQSJ-CD 48 Quebradillas relays WSJN-CD, and W50EN-D 50 Caguas rebroadcasts WVQS-LD. WLCN-CD 18 Charleston, South Carolina, WRXY-TV 49 Fort Myers, Florida, WVLR 48 Knoxville, Tennessee, KEEN-CD 17 Las Vegas, WVUP-CD 45 Tallahassee, Florida, WTJR 16 Quincy, Illinois, and WHNO 20 New Orleans round out the network.

Christian Television Network
Christian Television Network (CTN) is a non-profit broadcast television network of small owned-and-operated stations (O&O) that broadcasts religious programming. It is based in Largo, Florida (with a mailing address of Clearwater), and the flagship station is WCLF channel 22, which signed on the air in the Tampa Bay region in 1979. It is now available on DirecTV channel 376 and Dish Network channel 267/9399. It was founded by Robert D'Andrea, who is still the president.
Christian Television Network’s flagship is WCLF channel 22, serving Clearwater, Tampa and St. Petersburg, Florida. KFXB-TV 40 in Dubuque, Cedar Rapids, Iowa City and Waterloo, Iowa, dropped Fox in 2004. WYBU-CD 16 Columbus, Georgia, once carried the call letters WCGT. WFGC 61 covers West Palm Beach, Florida, while WGNM 45 Macon, Georgia, paired UPN with CTN until September 2006. WHBR 33 straddles Pensacola, Florida and Mobile, Alabama, and WHTN 39 serves Murfreesboro and Nashville, Tennessee. In Puerto Rico, Senda Educational Broadcasting owns WSJN-CD 20 San Juan, WVQS-LD 50 Isabel Segunda, WELU 32 Aguadilla and WUSP-LD 25 Ponce, all operated by CTN; WQSJ-CD 48 Quebradillas relays WSJN-CD, and W50EN-D 50 Caguas rebroadcasts WVQS-LD. WLCN-CD 18 Charleston, South Carolina, WRXY-TV 49 Fort Myers, Florida, WVLR 48 Knoxville, Tennessee, KEEN-CD 17 Las Vegas, WVUP-CD 45 Tallahassee, Florida, WTJR 16 Quincy, Illinois, and WHNO 20 New Orleans round out the network.

title: Minnesota Vikings draft history
intro: This page is a list of the Minnesota Vikings NFL Draft selections. The first draft the Vikings participated in was the 1961 NFL Draft, in which they made Tommy Mason of Tulane their first ever selection.
lm_description: In the first round Minnesota claimed Florida defensive tackle Sharrif Floyd at 23rd overall, followed immediately by Florida State cornerback Xavier Rhodes at 25th overall and Tennessee wide receiver Cordarrelle Patterson at 29th overall. The Vikings waited until the fourth round to add Penn State linebacker Gerald Hodges with the 120th pick, then doubled up on UCLA specialists by selecting punter Jeff Locke 155th overall and guard Jeff Baca 196th overall. They closed the draft by choosing Penn State linebacker Michael Mauti 213th overall, North Carolina guard Travis Bond 214th overall, and Florida State defensive tackle Everett Dawkins 229th overall, giving them two linebackers, two guards, and two defensive tackles among their nine selections.

Minnesota Vikings draft history
This page is a list of the Minnesota Vikings NFL Draft selections. The first draft the Vikings participated in was the 1961 NFL Draft, in which they made Tommy Mason of Tulane their first ever selection.
In the first round Minnesota claimed Florida defensive tackle Sharrif Floyd at 23rd overall, followed immediately by Florida State cornerback Xavier Rhodes at 25th overall and Tennessee wide receiver Cordarrelle Patterson at 29th overall. The Vikings waited until the fourth round to add Penn State linebacker Gerald Hodges with the 120th pick, then doubled up on UCLA specialists by selecting punter Jeff Locke 155th overall and guard Jeff Baca 196th overall. They closed the draft by choosing Penn State linebacker Michael Mauti 213th overall, North Carolina guard Travis Bond 214th overall, and Florida State defensive tackle Everett Dawkins 229th overall, giving them two linebackers, two guards, and two defensive tackles among their nine selections.

title: E number
intro: E numbers (E stands for Europe) are codes for substances used as food additives for use within the European Union (EU) and European Free Trade Association (EFTA). Commonly found on food labels, their safety assessment and approval are the responsibility of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). Having a single unified list for food additives was first agreed upon in 1962 with food colouring. In 1964, the directives for preservatives were added, 1970 for antioxidants and 1974 for the emulsifiers, stabilisers, thickeners and gelling agents.
lm_description: Cholic acid (E1000) and choline salts (E1001) serve as emulsifiers, while amylase (E1100) and the proteases—protease, papain, bromelain and ficin grouped under E1101—double as stabilisers and flavour enhancers. Glucose oxidase (E1102) acts as an antioxidant, invertase (E1103) as a stabiliser, lipases (E1104) are listed without an assigned purpose, and lysozyme (E1105) functions as a preservative. Polydextrose (E1200) works simultaneously as a stabiliser, thickening agent, humectant and carrier, whereas polyvinylpyrrolidone (E1201) and polyvinylpolypyrrolidone (E1202) act purely as stabilisers; polyvinyl alcohol (E1203) and pullulan (E1204) appear without specified roles. The dextrin roasted to white and yellow shades (E1400), acid-treated starch (E1401), alkaline-modified starch (E1402), bleached starch (E1403) and monostarch phosphate (E1410) are all thickening agents, with oxidized starch (E1404) also emulsifying, while enzyme-treated starch (E1405) is included without a declared purpose.

title: Dixie Series
intro: The Dixie Series was an Interleague Minor League Postseason Series pitting the playoff champions of the Southern Association and the Texas League in a best-of-seven matchup from 1920 to 1958. The series was not held from 1943 to 1945 due to World War II. It was revived for one year in 1967, pitting the Southern League champion against the Texas League champion.
lm_description: Fort Worth dominated the Dixie Series’ first decade, claiming the 1920 title 4-2-1 over Little Rock Travelers and repeating in 1921 against Memphis Chicks. After Mobile Bears briefly interrupted with a 4-2-1 Southern Association triumph in 1922, Fort Worth reeled off three straight: 1923 over New Orleans Pelicans, 1924 over Memphis, and 1925 over Atlanta Crackers. Dallas Steers defeated New Orleans 4-2-1 in 1926, Wichita Falls Spudders swept the Pelicans in 1927, and Houston Buffaloes topped Birmingham Barons 4-2 in 1928, before Birmingham returned the favor against Dallas in 1929. Fort Worth resumed control in 1930, downing Memphis 4-1. Birmingham Barons reclaimed Southern pride in 1931, edging Houston 4-3, and Chattanooga Lookouts followed by ousting Beaumont Exporters 4-1 in 1932. New Orleans Pelicans then secured back-to-back crowns, 4-2 over San Antonio Missions in 1933 and 4-2 over Galveston Buccaneers in 1934. Oklahoma City Indians snapped the streak for the Texas League in 1935, 4-2 over Atlanta, before Tulsa Oilers blanked Birmingham 4-0 in 1936. Fort Worth Cats reappeared to beat Little Rock Travelers 4-1 in 1937 and outlasted Nashville Vols 4-3 in 1939, while Atlanta Crackers sandwiched a 4-0-1 victory over Beaumont Exporters in 1938.

title: 2012 K-League
intro: The 2012 K-League was the 13th season of the K-League since its establishment in 1983. The 2012 season was known as Hyundai Oilbank K-League 2012 due to the competition's sponsorship by Hyundai Oilbank. Jeonbuk Hyundai Motors were the defending champions, having won their second title the previous season. After 30 matches, the league split into two sections of eight teams each, with teams playing every other team in their section twice at home and away. The exact matches were determined upon the league table at the time of the split. This system was temporarily enforced for the 2012 season.
lm_description: Busan IPark, based at Busan Asiad Stadium, finished 5th in the 2011 league and 6th in the playoffs. Chunnam Dragons of Gwangyang play at Gwangyang Football Stadium and came 7th. Daegu FC, at Daegu Stadium, placed 12th, while Daejeon Citizen, home at Daejeon World Cup Stadium, ended 15th. Gangwon FC, splitting home games between Gangneung Stadium and Chuncheon Stadium, propped up the table in 16th. Gwangju FC, at Gwangju World Cup Stadium, were 11th, and Gyeongnam FC of Changwon, at Changwon Football Center, were 8th. Incheon United, at Incheon Football Stadium, took 13th, and Jeju United of Seogwipo, at Jeju World Cup Stadium, were 9th. Reigning champions Jeonbuk Hyundai Motors, from Jeonju World Cup Stadium, won both the 2011 league and the playoffs. Pohang Steelers, at Pohang Steel Yard, secured 2nd in the league and 3rd in the playoffs. Sangju Sangmu Phoenix, at Sangju Civic Stadium, were 14th. Seongnam Ilhwa Chunma, at Tancheon Sports Complex, finished 10th. FC Seoul, at Seoul World Cup Stadium, were 3rd in the league and 5th in the playoffs. Suwon Samsung Bluewings, at Suwon World Cup Stadium, placed 4th in both league and playoffs. Ulsan Hyundai, at Ulsan Munsu Football Stadium, were 6th in the league and playoff runners-up.

title: 2012 Cambodian League
intro: 2012 Cambodian League is the 28th season of the Cambodian League. A total of 10 teams are competing in the league. The regular season will be played from March 3 to August 8 and will once again feature playoffs at the end of the season to determine the league champions, just like in the 2009 and 2010 campaigns to add more excitement to the league.
lm_description: Boeung Ket Rubber Field, Kirivong Sok Sen Chey and Phnom Penh Crown all wear Kappa kits, led respectively by captains Keo Sokngon, In Vicheka and Kouch Sokumpheak and coached by Prak Sovuthy, Nguyen Chov Hoang and Englishman David Booth. National Defense Ministry and Preah Khan Reach are Nike-outfitted sides, with Khek Khemrin captaining the military team under Op Sam Ath and Sok Rithy skippering Preah Khan Reach for Som Vandeth. National Police Commissary sport Joma kits, captain Say Piseth and coach Ung Kangyanith, while Nagacorp FC have Om Thavrak as skipper and Prak Sovannara on the bench. Build Bright United’s captain Dan Ito plays for Meas Sam Oeurn, and Chhlam Samuth’s Silva Sunday takes orders from Kim Pheakdey.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Butler County, Kentucky
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places listings in Butler County, Kentucky. This is intended to be a complete list of the properties and districts on the National Register of Historic Places in Butler County, Kentucky, United States. The locations of National Register properties and districts for which the latitude and longitude coordinates are included below, may be seen in a map. There are 16 properties and districts listed on the National Register in the county, of which 6 are part of a National Historic Landmark spread across multiple counties. Another property was once listed but has been removed.
lm_description: The Annis Mound and Village Site, listed 21 December 1985, occupies the western bank of the Green River in Horseshoe Bend northeast of Logansport. The Baby Track Rock Petroglyphs, added 8 September 1989 with location restricted, lie near Morgantown. Carlston Annis Shell Mound, recorded 1 April 1986, sits on the east side of the Green River off Kentucky Route 403 outside Schulztown. Morgantown’s 205 S. Main St. holds the John Carson House, enrolled 26 July 1991, while the Carson-Annis Ferry Farm at 1086 Annis Ferry Road joined the Register 31 July 1998. One block north of US 231 and KY 403 stands the Confederate-Union Veterans’ Monument, listed 17 July 1997. DeWeese Shell Mound, added 1 April 1986, crowns the eastern riverbank in Horseshoe Bend west of Taylor Lake above Highview. Woodbury’s junction of KY 403 and Hime Street hosts the Finney Hotel, registered 7 November 1995; the same town’s Woodbury Park contains the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Superintendent’s House and Workmen’s Office, listed 19 June 1980. Beside US 231, the Ice House on Little Muddy Creek entered the Register 8 January 1987. Rayburn Johnson Shell Mound, Read Shell Mound, Russell Shell Mound and Woodbury Shell Midden all joined on 1 April 1986, occupying respective river bends near Prentiss, Monticello, Logansport and Woodbury. Reedyville Petroglyphs along Lock 5 Road north of the Green River and Turkey Rock Petroglyphs near Morgantown, both with restricted details, were listed 8 September 1989.

title: Double (association football)
intro: The Double, in association football, is the achievement of winning a country's top tier division and its primary cup competition in the same season. The lists in this article examine this definition of a double, while derivative sections examine much less frequent, continental instances. The Double can also mean beating a team both home and away in the same league season, a feat often noted as doing the double over a particular opponent. The first club to achieve a double was Preston North End in 1889, winning the FA Cup and The Football League in the inaugural season of the league. The team that holds the record for the most doubles is Linfield of Northern Ireland, with a total of 24.
lm_description: Austria Wien dominate Austria’s double roll of honour with ten, earned in 1923-24, 1925-26, 1948-49, 1961-62, 1962-63, 1979-80, 1985-86, 1991-92, 2002-03 and 2005-06. Rapid Wien follow with six, collected in 1918-19, 1919-20, 1945-46, 1967-68, 1982-83 and 1986-87, while Red Bull Salzburg have matched that tally in the modern era through 2011-12, 2013-14, 2014-15, 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2018-19. Admira Wacker have five doubles to their credit from 1927-28, 1931-32, 1933-34, 1946-47 and 1965-66. Wacker Innsbruck achieved the feat twice, in 1972-73 and 1974-75, and four clubs have managed it once apiece: LASK Linz in 1964-65, Swarovski Tirol in 1988-89, Sturm Graz in 1998-99 and Grazer AK in 2003-04.

title: Minnesota Vikings draft history
intro: This page is a list of the Minnesota Vikings NFL Draft selections. The first draft the Vikings participated in was the 1961 NFL Draft, in which they made Tommy Mason of Tulane their first ever selection.
lm_description: In the first round the Vikings doubled up, nabbing North Carolina State cornerback Dewayne Washington 18th overall and California offensive tackle Todd Steussie one slot later at 19. They returned in the second round for two more impact players, choosing Alabama wide receiver David Palmer 40th overall and Jackson State defensive end Fernando Smith at 55. After a quiet third round, Iowa defensive tackle Mike Wells came off the board to Minnesota at 125, followed by Penn State defensive back Shelly Hammonds 134th overall in the fifth. Western Carolina tight end Andrew Jordan was the 179th selection in the sixth round, and the Vikings closed the draft by bringing hometown linebacker Pete Bercich from Notre Dame aboard at 211.
to_index_text:
Minnesota Vikings draft history
This page is a list of the Minnesota Vikings NFL Draft selections. The first draft the Vikings participated in was the 1961 NFL Draft, in which they made Tommy Mason of Tulane their first ever selection.
In the first round the Vikings doubled up, nabbing North Carolina State cornerback Dewayne Washington 18th overall and California offensive tackle Todd Steussie one slot later at 19. They returned in the second round for two more impact players, choosing Alabama wide receiver David Palmer 40th overall and Jackson State defensive end Fernando Smith at 55. After a quiet third round, Iowa defensive tackle Mike Wells came off the board to Minnesota at 125, followed by Penn State defensive back Shelly Hammonds 134th overall in the fifth. Western Carolina tight end Andrew Jordan was the 179th selection in the sixth round, and the Vikings closed the draft by bringing hometown linebacker Pete Bercich from Notre Dame aboard at 211.

title: Eve (rapper)
intro: Eve Jihan Jeffers Cooper (born November 10, 1978) is an American rapper and actress from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. She has released four studio albums, Let There Be Eve.Ruff Ryders' First Lady (1999), Scorpion (2001), Eve-Olution (2002) and Lip Lock (2013). Eve achieved chart success with the singles, Let Me Blow Ya Mind, Who's That Girl, Gangsta Lovin' and Tambourine. Besides solo materials, Eve earned chart-topping entries with collaborations, including Rich Girl, 4 My People, Who's That Girl and Like This. Her accolades include a Grammy Award, BET Award, MTV Video Music Award, Teen Choice Award, and Washington DC Area Film Critics Association Award. Eve ranked at number 46 on VH1's list of 50 Greatest Hip Hop Artists. As an actress, Eve is known for her role as Terri Jones in the films Barbershop, Barbershop 2: Back in Business and Barbershop: The Next Cut, as well as Shelley Williams on the UPN television sitcom Eve. She also appeared in films The Woodsman (2004), The Cookout (2004) and Whip It (2009). Since 2017, Eve has been one of the hosts of the CBS Daytime talk show, The Talk. She had a clothing line called Fetish from 2003 to 2009.
lm_description: In 2002 Eve debuted on screen as J.J. in *XXX* and immediately followed as Terri Jones in *Barbershop*. She cameoed as herself in 2003’s *Charlie’s Angels: Full Throttle*, then 2004 saw her portray Mary-Kay in *The Woodsman*, reprise Terri Jones in *Barbershop 2: Back in Business*, and play Becky in *The Cookout*. After appearing as Ophelia Franklin in 2008’s *Flashbacks of a Fool*, she surfaced as herself in 2009’s *Good Hair* and took the role of Rosa Sparks in *Whip It*. She stepped into Latisha for 2010’s *4.3.2.1*, then twice joined the *Gumball 3000* documentaries as herself in 2011 and 2012, the same year she played Natalie in *All Wifed Out*. She closed out with Mocha Sujata in 2013’s *Bounty Killer*, Barbara in 2014’s *Animal*, and returned once more as Terri Jones in 2016’s *Barbershop: The Next Cut*.

title: List of ships of the Royal Australian Navy
intro: Since its foundation in 1913, the Royal Australian Navy has operated a large number of vessels, including various types of warship, support and supply craft, and auxiliary vessels drawn from civilian service when required.
lm_description: HMAS Wagga, a Bathurst-class corvette, served from 1942 to 1962, while her sister Wallaroo, also a Bathurst corvette, was lost in 1943 after only a year. The name Wallaroo reappeared in the 1990s when MSA Wallaroo, a Bandicoot-class minesweeper, patrolled from 1991 into the 2010s. Wallaby and Warrigal, both Wallaby-class water/fuel lighters, operated alongside each other from 1983 and 1984 respectively until 1997. HMAS Waree, an auxiliary tug, worked 1942-1946, joined by HMAS Wato (1941-1945) and the civilian tug Wattle (1934-1971); a later Wattle became a crane stores lighter from 1972 to 1997. The Tribal-class destroyer Warramunga served 1942-1963, and the V-class destroyer Waterhen 1933-1941. Two ships carried the name Warrego: a River-class torpedo-boat destroyer (1912-1928) and a Grimsby-class sloop (1940-1963). HMAS Warrnambool first sailed as a Bathurst corvette 1941-1947, then re-entered service as a Fremantle patrol boat 1981-2005. Westralia began as an armed merchant ship 1939-1949 and later, as a Leaf-class replenishment ship, served 1989-2006. HMAS Wewak, a Balikpapan landing craft, operated 1973-2012, while the auxiliary oiler Whangape supported the fleet briefly in 1914.

The name Wallaroo reappeared in the 1990s when MSA Wallaroo, a Bandicoot-class minesweeper, patrolled from 1991 into the 2010s. Wallaby and Warrigal, both Wallaby-class water/fuel lighters, operated alongside each other from 1983 and 1984 respectively until 1997. HMAS Waree, an auxiliary tug, worked 1942-1946, joined by HMAS Wato (1941-1945) and the civilian tug Wattle (1934-1971); a later Wattle became a crane stores lighter from 1972 to 1997. The Tribal-class destroyer Warramunga served 1942-1963, and the V-class destroyer Waterhen 1933-1941. Two ships carried the name Warrego: a River-class torpedo-boat destroyer (1912-1928) and a Grimsby-class sloop (1940-1963). HMAS Warrnambool first sailed as a Bathurst corvette 1941-1947, then re-entered service as a Fremantle patrol boat 1981-2005. Westralia began as an armed merchant ship 1939-1949 and later, as a Leaf-class replenishment ship, served 1989-2006. HMAS Wewak, a Balikpapan landing craft, operated 1973-2012, while the auxiliary oiler Whangape supported the fleet briefly in 1914.

title: List of Games for Windows titles
intro: This is a list of Games for Windows titles video games under Microsoft's Games for Windows label. With the closure of the Xbox.com PC marketplace in August 2013; no games were devolved for the platform past 2013. The clients software and the servers are still available.
lm_description: Kalypso Media released 3D Hunting 2010 on 20 April 2010, while Funcom shipped Age of Conan: Rise of the Godslayer on 11 May 2010; neither title supports LIVE or Games on Demand. Rebellion Developments’ Aliens vs. Predator launched on 16 February 2010 under Sega, likewise eschewing both services, whereas Obsidian Entertainment’s Alpha Protocol, published by Sega on 1 June 2010, is available only via Games on Demand. Viva Media’s Alter Ego arrived on 3 August 2010 without either feature, but Rocksteady Studios’ Batman: Arkham Asylum Game of the Year Edition, issued by Eidos Interactive on 11 May 2010, carries both LIVE and Games on Demand badges. 2K Marin’s BioShock 2, released by 2K Games on 9 February 2010, supports both services; its Russian edition, published by 1C on 18 June 2010, keeps LIVE but drops Games on Demand. Zombie Studios’ Blacklight: Tango Down, UTV Ignition’s 14 July 2010 release, and Arc System Works’ BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger, launched on 2 September 2010, both embrace LIVE and Games on Demand. Singapore-MIT GAMBIT Game Lab’s CarneyVale: Showtime, Synetic’s Crash Time 4: The Syndicate, Airtight’s Dark Void, Capcom Vancouver’s Dead Rising 2, Giants Software’s Demolition Company, Akella’s Disciples III: Renaissance, Stardock’s Elemental: War of Magic, Creative Assembly’s Empire & Napoleon Total War GOTY, Codemasters’ F1 2010, and Obsidian’s Fallout: New Vegas round out 2010’s Games for Windows roster with varying LIVE and Games on Demand support.

title: 1990 NFL Draft
intro: The 1990 NFL draft was the procedure by which National Football League teams selected amateur college football players. It is officially known as the NFL Annual Player Selection Meeting. The draft was held April 22-23, 1990, at the Marriot Marquis in New York City, New York. The league also held a supplemental draft after the regular draft and before the regular season. The Dallas Cowboys would have had the #1 overall pick in the draft for the second consecutive year by virtue of their league-worst 1-15 record in 1989. However, the Cowboys forfeited their first-round pick by selecting quarterback Steve Walsh in the first round of the previous year's supplemental draft. The first pick instead went to the Atlanta Falcons, who traded it to the Indianapolis Colts.
lm_description: Buffalo chose Vernon Turner, a Carson-Newman running back and wide receiver from the SAC, while Cincinnati doubled up with Syracuse quarterback Todd Philcox and Montana guard Kirk Scrafford of the Big Sky. Dallas selected Kentucky kicker Ken Willis out of the SEC, and Indianapolis used two picks on Pittsburgh defensive tackle Tony Siragusa and Michigan State linebacker Matt Vanderbeek. Kansas City took Santa Clara punter Bryan Barker from the WFC, the Los Angeles Raiders grabbed Fresno State tight end Rich Bartlewski of the Big West, and the Rams countered with Stanford tight end Jim Price from the Pac-10. Miami drafted Eastern Illinois defensive tackle John Jurkovic of the Gateway Conference. Minnesota paired Notre Dame safety Pat Eilers with Texas A&I defensive tackle John Randle of the Lone Star, New England added Montana safety Tim Hauck from the Big Sky, New Orleans claimed Tennessee offensive tackle Richard Cooper from the SEC, and the Giants took Michigan linebacker Bobby Abrams of the Big Ten. Philadelphia picked Missouri cornerback Otis Smith from the Big Eight, Phoenix chose Florida A&M guard Vernice Smith of the MEAC, Pittsburgh selected Houston fullback Kimble Anders from the SWC, San Francisco drafted San Jose State offensive tackle Ricky Siglar of the Big West, and Seattle closed with Oregon running back Derek Loville from the Pac-10.

title: Miss Venezuela 2010
intro: Miss Venezuela 2010 was the 57th edition of the Miss Venezuela pageant held on October 28, 2010 at the Palacio de Eventos de Venezuela in Maracaibo, Venezuela. At the end of the event, outgoing titleholder Marelisa Gibson crowned Vanessa Gonçalves of Miranda as her successor.
lm_description: Ivian Lunasol Sarcos Colmenares, 21, carried Amazonas from Guanare at 180 cm, while 18-year-old Verónica Liliana González Castillo represented Anzoátegui from Caracas at 176 cm. Ana Tábata Rodríguez Donnarumma, 18, towered at 185 cm for Apure and hailed from San Fernando de Apure; Caroline Gabriela Medina Peschiutta, also 18, represented Aragua from Maracay at 178 cm. Kelly Stephanny Martínez Dominguez, 22, held Barinas’s banner from Caracas at 178 cm, matching Bolívar’s 19-year-old Angela La Padula Peluso from Ciudad Guayana. Estefanía Nebot Peña, 22, represented Canaima from Caracas at 176 cm, the same height as 20-year-old Romina Palmisano Giacche from Valencia for Carabobo and 24-year-old Eliana Catherina Calicchia Arcila from Valencia for Cojedes. Karen Andrea Soto Lugo, 18, represented Costa Oriental from Maracaibo at 179 cm, alongside Delta Amacuro’s 21-year-old Yaisbel Nohely Arteaga Polanco from Puerto Cabello and Distrito Capital’s 22-year-old Jessica Cristina Barboza Schmidt from Maracaibo. Axel Carolina López Aldana, 20, carried Dependencias Federales from Caracas at 176 cm, while Liliana María Flores Arenas, 23, represented Falcón from Coro at 175 cm. Andrea Estefanía Vásquez Annicchiarico, 19, held Guárico from Caracas at 178 cm, matching Lara’s 18-year-old María José Zavarce Alvarado from Barquisimeto at 180 cm. María Teresa Iannuzzo Lucena, 22, represented Mérida from Carora at 176 cm. Vanessa Andrea Gonçalves Gómez, 24, Miranda’s representative from Baruta, stood 178 cm. Angela Julieta Ruiz Pérez, 18, carried Monagas from Maturín at 178 cm, and Melanie Reza Félix, 18, represented Nueva Esparta from Caracas at 180 cm.

title: Deloitte Football Money League
intro: The Deloitte Football Money League is a ranking of football clubs by revenue generated from football operations. It is produced annually by the accountancy firm Deloitte and released in early February of each year, describing the season most recently finished.
lm_description: Barcelona overtook Real Madrid to top the 2020 money league with €840.8 million, while Madrid slipped to second on €757.3 million. Manchester United stayed third on €711.5 million, Bayern Munich fourth on €660.1 million, and Paris Saint-Germain rose one place to fifth on €635.9 million. Manchester City fell to sixth on €610.6 million, Liverpool remained seventh on €604.7 million, and Tottenham Hotspur jumped two spots to eighth on €521.1 million. Chelsea dropped to ninth on €513.1 million, Juventus edged up to tenth on €459.7 million, and Arsenal tumbled two places to eleventh on €445.6 million. Borussia Dortmund, Atlético Madrid and Internazionale all held station at twelfth, thirteenth and fourteenth respectively on €377.1 million, €367.6 million and €364.6 million. Schalke 04 climbed one place to fifteenth on €324.8 million, Roma slipped to sixteenth on €231.0 million, and Lyon soared eleven places to seventeenth on €220.8 million. West Ham United rose two spots to eighteenth on €216.4 million, Everton fell to nineteenth on €213.0 million, and Napoli rounded out the top twenty on €207.4 million.

title: Double (association football)
intro: The Double, in association football, is the achievement of winning a country's top tier division and its primary cup competition in the same season. The lists in this article examine this definition of a double, while derivative sections examine much less frequent, continental instances. The Double can also mean beating a team both home and away in the same league season, a feat often noted as doing the double over a particular opponent. The first club to achieve a double was Preston North End in 1889, winning the FA Cup and The Football League in the inaugural season of the league. The team that holds the record for the most doubles is Linfield of Northern Ireland, with a total of 24.
lm_description: Kedah and Johor Darul Ta'zim each captured three doubles, Kedah in 1993, 2007 and 2008, Johor Darul Ta'zim in 2016, 2017 and 2019. Selangor managed the feat twice, in 1984 and again in 2009. Kuala Lumpur, Johor FA, Pahang, Singapore Lions and Kelantan each secured one double, respectively in 1988, 1991, 1992, 1994 and 2012.

title: Aksys Games
intro: Aksys Games Localization, Inc. is a video game publisher that specializes in translating and localizing Japanese video games for English-speaking markets. It was founded by Akibo Shieh in 2006. Some of its clients include Namco Bandai Games, Xseed Games, and Atlus USA. Aksys Games is best known for its involvement in the Guilty Gear series. It has become a full-fledged game publisher with the announcement of Eagle Eye Golf for PlayStation 2, and has expressed a desire to publish for all current platforms from Microsoft, Nintendo, and Sony. The company's name is coincidentally similar to Arc System Works, with whom it has a partnership. Despite their similar names, and the partnership between them, neither company owns the other. Aksys Games publishes many games for Arc System Works in North America, and has even assisted the latter in releasing the Bit.Trip series in Japan. Aksys is also the North American distributor for the European publisher Rising Star Games.
lm_description: Aksys Games brought Arc System Works’ Guilty Gear XX Accent Core Plus to PlayStation Portable on April 7, 2009, followed on February 25, 2010 by BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger Portable, and on May 31, 2011 by BlazBlue: Continuum Shift II, all for PSP. March 25, 2010 saw the PSP debut of extreme’s shooter Cho Aniki Zero via PSN, while Kogado Studio and Premium Agency’s Mimana Iyar Chronicle reached PSP on March 30, 2010. Goshow’s Gladiator Begins launched September 14, 2010, Neverland’s tactical RPG Blazing Souls Accelate arrived October 19, 2010, and Opus Studio’s Jikandia: The Timeless Land released March 15, 2011, each exclusively on PSP. Type-Moon’s Fate/Extra materialized November 1, 2011, Idea Factory and Otomate’s otome title Hakuoki: Demon of the Fleeting Blossom debuted February 14, 2012, and its spin-off Hakuoki: Warriors of the Shinsengumi followed November 6, 2012, all on PSP. GungHo, Apollosoft and Chime’s Ragnarok Tactics landed February 19, 2013, while Idea Factory, Otomate and Comcept’s puzzle visual-novel hybrid Sweet Fuse: At Your Side closed the PSP slate on August 27, 2013.

title: 2004 MLS Expansion Draft
intro: The 2004 MLS Expansion Draft was held on November 19, 2004 and consisted of 10 rounds. The two new teams, Chivas USA and Real Salt Lake, drafted players from the other 10 Major League Soccer teams. Existing MLS teams were allowed to protect 12 players on their senior roster, and players on the developmental roster were exempt from the draft. Teams were allowed to leave no more than one Senior International player unprotected. After each player was selected, his team was allowed to remove one exposed player from their list. Teams were not able to lose more than three players.
lm_description: Chivas USA opened the 2004 MLS Expansion Draft by selecting midfielder Arturo Torres from the Los Angeles Galaxy, and Real Salt Lake answered by claiming Chicago Fire midfielder Andy Williams. The Fire were hit again when Chivas USA took defender Orlando Perez third overall, and Chicago lost a third player when Real Salt Lake chose goalkeeper D.J. Countess at pick four. Chivas USA continued with defender Ezra Hendrickson from D.C. United, while Real Salt Lake selected MetroStars midfielder Pablo Brenes. Francisco Gomez moved from Kansas City Wizards to Chivas USA, Brian Kamler left New England Revolution for Real Salt Lake, Antonio de la Torre departed Colorado Rapids for Chivas USA, and Nelson Akwari switched from Columbus Crew to Real Salt Lake to close the first ten selections. In the second half of the draft, Chivas USA added forward Matt Taylor from Kansas City Wizards, Real Salt Lake claimed midfielder Chris Brown from San Jose Earthquakes, and Chivas USA selected defender Craig Ziadie from MetroStars. Real Salt Lake then picked defender Matt Behncke from F.C. Dallas, Chivas USA took midfielder Jamil Walker from San Jose Earthquakes, and Real Salt Lake chose defender Rusty Pierce from New England Revolution. The final three selections saw Thiago Martins move from D.C. United to Chivas USA, Kevin Ara depart D.C. United for Real Salt Lake, Jeff Stewart leave Colorado Rapids for Chivas USA, and Erick Scott transfer from Columbus Crew to Real Salt Lake to complete the twenty-player draft.

title: List of lacrosse teams in Canada
intro: The following is a list of lacrosse teams in Canada. It includes the league(s) they play for and championships won.
lm_description: Akwesasne’s Jr. Indians, founded in 2007, sat out 2012 and have yet to claim any league or Minto Cup crowns. Brampton’s 1883-born Excelsiors—once the ABC’s and Bramalea Excelsiors—have pocketed three league titles since 1961 and one Minto Cup. Barrie’s 2000-born Tornado, scoreless in both championship columns, moved to OLA Jr A in 2009 and captured the Founders Cup in 2003. Burlington Chiefs, tracing back through the Hamilton and Bay Area Bengals since 1976, remain without titles. Kitchener-Waterloo Braves, established 1976 and formerly the Kitchener Braves, earned one Junior B league banner and two Founders Cups before joining the top tier. Mississauga Tomahawks, cycling through Athletics, Sullivan Homes, Merchants and Arrowheads since 1973, collected two Junior B league titles and one Founders Cup. Orangeville Northmen, born 1975 as the Stingers, own four league titles and three Minto Cups, adding one Junior C, two Junior B league banners and two Founders Cups along the way. Orillia Rama Kings—once Lions, 501 Kings and Rogers Kings—since 1973 have three Junior B league titles and two Founders Cups. Ottawa Titans, launched 2005, are still awaiting their first trophy. Peterborough Lakers, whose lineage winds through Legionnaires, Petes, Tee-Pees, Gray-Munros, Century 21, James Gang, Maulers, Traders, Javelins and P.C.O.s, lead with 13 league titles and 12 Minto Cups. St. Catharines Athletics, formerly Supertests, Lakesides and Legionaires, count five league and three Minto Cup victories. Six Nations Arrows, begun 1974 as the Braves, hold six league titles and two Minto Cups after climbing through Junior C and B. Toronto Beaches, founded 1976, emerged from Junior B without silverware. Whitby Warriors, once Consolidated Builders, have seven league titles and five Minto Cups.

title: Kenya at the 2008 Summer Olympics
intro: Kenya competed in the 2008 Summer Olympics held in Beijing, People's Republic of China from August 8 to August 24, 2008. Kenya won a total of 14 medals, 6 of them gold, its best ever performance at the Olympics. Kenya sent a total of 46 athletes, 28 men and 18 women, to the 2008 Summer Olympics. Four Kenyan men won six gold medals, while the other two were awarded to the women. The remaining medals won by Kenyans were four silver and six bronze medals. Among the nation's gold medalists was Brimin Kipruto, who brought home the nation's seventh straight medal in the steeplechase since 1984. Coming in at a close third was Richard Matelong who was unable to surpass the Frenchman Mahiedine Mekhissi-Benabbad. Kenya also marked its Olympic debut in taekwondo by sending two athletes, one man and one woman. For the first time in Olympic history, the Kenyan athletes had participated in the women's 800 meter event final. Shortly after the 3,000 meter steeplechase, the women captured a gold medal against many odds. Along with the gold, they also took home the silver as well. Pamela Jelimo led her fellow Kenyan Janeth Jepkosgei Busienei to a one-two finish.
lm_description: Kenya’s six Beijing golds came from Pamela Jelimo in the women’s 800 m, Brimin Kipruto in the men’s 3000 m steeplechase, Wilfred Bungei in the men’s 800 m, Nancy Lagat in the women’s 1500 m, Samuel Wanjiru in the men’s marathon and Asbel Kiprop in the men’s 1500 m. Silver medals were earned by Janeth Jepkosgei in the women’s 800 m, Catherine Ndereba in the women’s marathon, Eunice Jepkorir in the women’s 3000 m steeplechase and Eliud Kipchoge in the men’s 5000 m. Bronze medals went to Richard Mateelong in the men’s 3000 m steeplechase, Micah Kogo in the men’s 10 000 m, Alfred Kirwa Yego in the men’s 800 m, Edwin Cheruiyot Soi in the men’s 5000 m, Sylvia Kibet in the women’s 5000 m and Linet Masai in the women’s 10 000 m.
to_index_text:
Kenya at the 2008 Summer Olympics
Kenya competed in the 2008 Summer Olympics held in Beijing, People's Republic of China from August 8 to August 24, 2008. Kenya won a total of 14 medals, 6 of them gold, its best ever performance at the Olympics. Kenya sent a total of 46 athletes, 28 men and 18 women, to the 2008 Summer Olympics. Four Kenyan men won six gold medals, while the other two were awarded to the women. The remaining medals won by Kenyans were four silver and six bronze medals. Among the nation's gold medalists was Brimin Kipruto, who brought home the nation's seventh straight medal in the steeplechase since 1984. Coming in at a close third was Richard Matelong who was unable to surpass the Frenchman Mahiedine Mekhissi-Benabbad. Kenya also marked its Olympic debut in taekwondo by sending two athletes, one man and one woman. For the first time in Olympic history, the Kenyan athletes had participated in the women's 800 meter event final. Shortly after the 3,000 meter steeplechase, the women captured a gold medal against many odds. Along with the gold, they also took home the silver as well. Pamela Jelimo led her fellow Kenyan Janeth Jepkosgei Busienei to a one-two finish.
Kenya’s six Beijing golds came from Pamela Jelimo in the women’s 800 m, Brimin Kipruto in the men’s 3000 m steeplechase, Wilfred Bungei in the men’s 800 m, Nancy Lagat in the women’s 1500 m, Samuel Wanjiru in the men’s marathon and Asbel Kiprop in the men’s 1500 m. Silver medals were earned by Janeth Jepkosgei in the women’s 800 m, Catherine Ndereba in the women’s marathon, Eunice Jepkorir in the women’s 3000 m steeplechase and Eliud Kipchoge in the men’s 5000 m. Bronze medals went to Richard Mateelong in the men’s 3000 m steeplechase, Micah Kogo in the men’s 10 000 m, Alfred Kirwa Yego in the men’s 800 m, Edwin Cheruiyot Soi in the men’s 5000 m, Sylvia Kibet in the women’s 5000 m and Linet Masai in the women’s 10 000 m.

title: List of autocannon
intro: Autocannons are automatic guns with calibers of 20mm or more. There are many types including chain guns, gast guns, revolver cannons, and rotary cannons. They are being used as military aircraft main guns, naval guns, anti-aircraft weapons, infantry fighting vehicle main guns and are occasionally found on reconnaissance vehicles like the BTR-80.
lm_description: The United States fielded the 20 mm M39 cannon during the Cold War, while Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union both relied on internal-power 20 mm designs—the Mauser MG 213 and the ShVAK respectively—during World War II. The Soviet Union later introduced the 23 mm Rikhter R-23, another Cold-War-era internal-power weapon. Germany’s 27 mm Mauser BK-27 continued the Cold-War lineage, and the modern Rheinmetall RMK30, externally powered, pushed caliber to 30 mm. Britain and France each produced 30 mm internal-power cannons—the ADEN and DEFA—during the Cold War, whereas France also fielded the externally powered GIAT 30 in the same era. Switzerland’s Oerlikon Millennium 35 mm Naval Revolver Gun System represents the modern period with its 35 mm internal-power design.

title: Bandundu Province
intro: Bandundu is one of eleven former provinces of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. It bordered the provinces of Kinshasa and Bas-Congo to the west, Équateur to the north, and Kasai-Occidental to the east. The provincial capital is also called Bandundu (formerly Banningstad/Banningville).
lm_description: Bagata, Bulungu, Dibaya-Lubwe, Gungu, Idiofa, Mangai and Masi-Manimba all lie within Kwilu District, their 2010 populations ranging from 7,591 in Feshi up to 58,637 in Idiofa, while Kikwit, the district’s lone chartered city, counted 370,328 inhabitants. Across Kwango District, Feshi Territory holds 7,591 people, Kahemba 18,061, Kasongo-Lunda 22,860, Kenge 42,884 and Popokabaka 12,564. Mai-Ndombe District embraces the provincial capital Bandundu with 137,460 residents, alongside Inongo at 46,657, Kutu at 37,405, Kiri at 14,033 and Oshwe at 21,681. In Plateaux District, Bolobo Territory numbers 31,735 and Mushie Territory 42,409.

Bagata, Bulungu, Dibaya-Lubwe, Gungu, Idiofa, Mangai and Masi-Manimba all lie within Kwilu District, their 2010 populations ranging from 7,591 in Feshi up to 58,637 in Idiofa, while Kikwit, the district’s lone chartered city, counted 370,328 inhabitants. title: List of Michigan State Historic Sites in Allegan County
intro: The following is a list of Michigan State Historic Sites in Allegan County, Michigan. Sites marked with a dagger (†) are also listed on the National Register of Historic Places in Allegan County, Michigan.
lm_description: All Saints Episcopal Church, a National Register property, stands at 252 Grand Street on Saugatuck’s southwest corner of Hoffman Street and was listed as a Michigan State Historic Site on April 24, 1981. Allegan County’s informational marker at 125 Chestnut Street in Allegan dates to November 14, 1961, while the Allegan Road Commemorative Designation in Saugatuck’s River Bluff Park was recognized on February 17, 1994. Castle Park Lodge, 6700 Bryant Avenue within Castle Park in Holland, joined the rolls on September 10, 1979, the same year the Church of the Good Shepherd at 101 Walnut Street in Allegan had already been listed since July 26, 1973. The Clipson Brewery Ice House, also known as Twin Gables Hotel, 900 Lake Street in Saugatuck, was designated on April 28, 1987, followed by the John Crispe House at 404 East Bridge Street in Plainwell on April 25, 1988, and the Delano House at 302 Cutler Street in Allegan on July 26, 1973. Douglas Union School, another National Register entry at 130 Center Street in Douglas, was listed on December 20, 1990, while Dutcher Lodge at 86 Center Street in Douglas was recognized on January 13, 1985. Ebenezer Reformed Church’s informational marker at 5166 Ottogan Street in Holland dates to February 27, 1970, and the Dorr E. Felt Mansion, 6597 138th Avenue in Holland, entered both the state and national registers on January 17, 2006. The Fifty-Seventh Street Bridge over the Kalamazoo River at 57th Street in New Richmond was listed on April 4, 1978, and the First Congregational Church at 296 Hoffman in Saugatuck on March 21, 1991. The Francis Metallic Surfboat at 130 W. Center Street in Douglas was designated on January 17, 2016, the Ganges Fractional District No. 1 School House at 6292 124th Avenue in Fennville on July 26, 1978, and the Dr. Asa Goodrich House at 112 Center Street in Douglas on December 5, 1986. Graafschap Christian Reformed Church, located on A-621 (48th Avenue) between Graafschap Road and Washington Avenue in Holland, was listed on December 14, 1976, the Hacklander Site (20AE78) at 130th Avenue and 63rd Street in Saugatuck Township on April 14, 1972, and the Henika Ladies’ Library at 149 South Main Street in Wayland on November 26, 1985.

title: History of RNA biology
intro: Numerous key discoveries in biology have emerged from studies of RNA (ribonucleic acid), including seminal work in the fields of biochemistry, genetics, microbiology, molecular biology, molecular evolution and structural biology. As of 2010, 30 scientists have been awarded Nobel Prizes for experimental work that includes studies of RNA. Specific discoveries of high biological significance are discussed in this article. For related information, see the articles on History of Molecular Biology and History of Genetics. For background information, see the articles on RNA and nucleic acid.
lm_description: Sidney Altman and Thomas Cech shared the 1989 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for RNA work, while David Baltimore, Françoise Barré-Sinoussi, Elizabeth Blackburn, Sydney Brenner, Andrew Fire, Carol Greider, Robert Holley, François Jacob, H. Gobind Khorana, Craig Mello, Jacques Monod, Luc Montagnier and Marshall Nirenberg earned Nobel Prizes in Physiology or Medicine across 1962–2009. Renato Dulbecco joined Baltimore as a 1975 laureate, Walter Gilbert received the 1980 chemistry award, Aaron Klug the 1982 chemistry prize, and Roger Kornberg the 2006 chemistry honor. Francis Crick, born 1916 and deceased 2004, gained his 1962 Nobel early in the RNA chronicle.

title: Ebertfest
intro: Ebertfest is an annual film festival held every April in Champaign, Illinois, United States, organized by the College of Media at the University of Illinois. Roger Ebert, the TV and Chicago Sun-Times film critic, was a native of the adjoining town of Urbana, Illinois and is an alumnus of the University. Founded in 1999 as Roger Ebert's Overlooked Film Festival, this event is the only long-running film festival created by a critic. Despite Eberts death in 2013, the festival continues to operate based on Eberts notes and vision for the kinds of films he championed.
lm_description: Rolf de Heer’s 1998 drama Dance Me to My Song, starring Heather Rose, John Brumpton and Joey Kennedy, screened with Rose herself answering questions afterward. David D. Williams brought his 1997 film Thirteen, featuring Hermine Douglas, Brandon Flynn Wells and Alan Douglas, and was set to discuss it live. Nancy Savoca’s 1993 Household Saints, with Tracey Ullman, Vincent D’Onofrio and Lili Taylor, was accompanied by Savoca and producer-co-writer Richard Guay. Sergei Eisenstein’s 1925 Battleship Potemkin, headlined by Aleksandr Antonov, Vladimir Barsky and Grigori Aleksandrov, received a new Concrete Orchestra score performed live. Hirokazu Koreeda’s 1995 Maborosi showcased Makiko Esumi, Takashi Naitō and Tadanobu Asano. Kevin DiNovis introduced his 1998 Surrender Dorothy, in which he also appears alongside Peter Pryor and Jason Centeno. Dale Rosenbloom’s 1996 family tale Shiloh, starring Michael Moriarty, Scott Wilson and Blake Heron, brought Rosenbloom, Wilson and producer Carl Borack to the post-screening discussion. Jan Troell’s 1996 Hamsun presented Max von Sydow and Ghita Nørby. Éric Rohmer’s 1998 Autumn Tale united Béatrice Romand, Marie Rivière and Alain Libolt. Finally, Steven Lisberger’s 1982 Tron, with Jeff Bridges, Bruce Boxleitner and David Warner, closed the lineup as Lisberger and Warner faced the audience for a Q&A.

title: List of football stadiums in South Korea
intro: The following is a list of football stadiums in South Korea, ordered by capacity. All stadiums with a seating capacity of 10,000 or more are included.
lm_description: Seoul’s Olympic Stadium, seating 69,950 since 1984, hosts Seoul E-Land FC, while across the capital the 66,704-seat Seoul World Cup Stadium, opened in 2001, is home to FC Seoul. Daegu Stadium, also from 2001, holds 66,422 spectators, and Busan Asiad Main Stadium, built the same year, accommodates 53,769 fans for Busan IPark. Incheon Munhak Stadium, seating 52,179 since 2001, stands without a listed tenant, as does the 44,102-seat Ulsan Munsu Football Stadium, yet Ulsan Hyundai FC plays there. Suwon Samsung Bluewings occupy Suwon World Cup Stadium, built in 2001 for 43,959, while Jeonbuk Hyundai Motors FC fill Jeonju World Cup Stadium, opened the same year with room for 42,477. Goyang Stadium, completed in 2003, seats 41,311, and Daejeon Hana Citizen FC play in the 40,535-seat Daejeon World Cup Stadium, both from 2001. Gwangju FC call the 40,245-seat Gwangju World Cup Stadium home, Jeju United FC play in the 35,657-seat Jeju World Cup Stadium in Seogwipo, and Hwaseong FC occupy the 35,265-seat Hwaseong Stadium, built in 2011. Ansan Greeners FC use the 35,000-seat Ansan Wa~ Stadium from 2007, matching the capacity of 1984’s Gumi Civic Stadium and 2002’s Uijeongbu Stadium, neither listing a tenant. Bucheon FC 1995 play in the 34,456-seat Bucheon Stadium, also from 2001, while Duryu Park Stadium, dating to 1977, holds 32,500 in Daegu, Gimcheon Stadium seats 32,000 since 2000, and Incheon Asiad Main Stadium, opened in 2014, provides 30,000 places.

title: Supreme Commander of the Swedish Armed Forces
intro: The Supreme Commander (Swedish: Överbefälhavaren; acronym: ÖB) is the highest ranked professional military officer in the Swedish Armed Forces, and is by NATO terminology the Swedish chief of defence equivalent. The Supreme Commander is the agency head of the Swedish Armed Forces and formally reports to the Government of Sweden, though normally through the Minister for Defence. [b] The primary responsibilities and duties of the Supreme Commander (and the charter for the Armed Forces) are prescribed in an ordinance issued by the Government. The Supreme Commander is, apart from the honorary ranks held by the King of Sweden and in the past other members of the Swedish Royal Family, by unwritten convention normally the only professional military officer on active duty to hold the highest rank (a four-star General or Admiral). An exception was made 2009-2014 when Håkan Syrén was chairman of the European Union Military Committee. The present Supreme Commander, General Micael Bydén, took office on 1 October 2015.
lm_description: Olof Thörnell became the first Supreme Commander on 8 December 1939 and led the Army for 4 years and 114 days until 31 March 1944, when Helge Jung took over, extending Army leadership through 1 April 1944 to 31 March 1951, a tenure of 6 years and 364 days. Nils Swedlund succeeded him on 1 April 1951 and remained until 30 September 1961, serving 10 years and 182 days in the Army. Torsten Rapp then became the first Air Force officer to hold the post, serving from 1 October 1961 to 30 September 1970, nearly nine years. Stig Synnergren returned leadership to the Army from 1 October 1970 to 30 September 1978, followed by Lennart Ljung who held the same Army role from 1 October 1978 to 30 September 1986. Bengt Gustafsson continued the Army streak from 1 October 1986 until 30 June 1994, totaling 7 years and 272 days. Owe Wiktorin, another Air Force officer, served from 1 July 1994 to 30 June 2000. Johan Hederstedt led the Army from 1 July 2000 to 31 December 2003. Håkan Syrén, from the Navy’s Amphibious Corps, held office from 1 January 2004 to 24 March 2009. Sverker Göranson returned command to the Army from 25 March 2009 to 30 September 2015, when Micael Bydén, Air Force, took over and remains incumbent.

Olof Thörnell became the first Supreme Commander on 8 December 1939 and led the Army for 4 years and 114 days until 31 March 1944, when Helge Jung took over, extending Army leadership through 1 April 1944 to 31 March 1951, a tenure of 6 years and 364 days. title: List of largest hydroelectric power stations
intro: This article provides a list of the largest hydroelectric power stations by generating capacity. Only plants with capacity larger than 2,000 MW are listed. The Three Gorges Dam in Hubei, China, has the world's largest instantaneous generating capacity (22,500 MW), with the Itaipu Dam in Brazil/Paraguay in second place (14,000 MW). Despite the large difference in installed capacity these two power stations generate nearly equal amounts of electrical energy during the course of an entire year - Itaipu 103.1 TWh in 2016 and Three Gorges 98.8 TWh in 2014, because the Three Gorges experiences six months per year when there is very little water available to generate power, while the Paraná River that feeds the Itaipu has a much lower seasonal variance in flow. Energy output of the Three Gorges reaches 125 TWh in years of high feed availability. The Three Gorges (22,500 MW - 32 × 700 MW and 2 × 50 MW) is operated jointly with the much smaller Gezhouba Dam (2,715 MW), the total generating capacity of this two-dam complex is 25,215 MW. The Itaipu on the Brazil-Paraguay border has 20 generator units with overall 14,000 MW of installed capacity, however the maximum number of generating units allowed to operate simultaneously cannot exceed 18 (12,600 MW). The Jinsha River (the upper stream of Yangtze River) complex is the largest hydroelectric generating system currently under construction. It has three phases. Phase one includes four dams on the downstream of the Jinsha River. They are Wudongde Dam, Baihetan Dam, Xiluodu Dam, and Xiangjiaba Dam, with generating capacity of 10,200 MW, 16,000 MW, 13,860 MW, and 6,448 MW respectively. Phase two includes eight dams on the middle stream of the Jinsha River.
lm_description: China’s Jinsha River will host two of the world’s next giants: the 16,000 MW Baihetan Dam due 2021-2022 and the 10,200 MW Wudongde Dam due 2020-2021. Downstream on the Salween, Myanmar’s 7,110 MW TaSang project is on indefinite hold, while the 3,600 MW Myitsone on the Irrawaddy faces the same fate. Ethiopia is racing to finish the 6,450 MW Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam on the Blue Nile by 2022 and the 2,160 MW Koysha Dam on the Omo in 2021. Pakistan is pairing the 4,500 MW Diamer-Bhasha and the 4,320 MW Dasu, both on the Indus, for commissioning in 2023. Tajikistan’s 3,600 MW Rogun on the Vakhsh is scheduled across the decade ending 2029. Nigeria plans 3,050 MW from the Mambilla station on the Donga by 2024, while China’s 3,000 MW Lianghekou on the Yalong should spin up between 2021 and 2023. Colombia’s Ituango on the Cauca targets 2,456 MW, possibly in 2021, whereas Venezuela’s 2,320 MW Tocoma on the Caroní is stalled. Angola is building the 2,172 MW Caculo Cabaça for 2024 and expanding the 2,069.5 MW Lauca through 2020. China will add 2,200 MW with Maerdang on the Yellow River and 2,000 MW with Shuangjiangkou on the Dadu, while India’s 2,000 MW Subansiri Lower remains on hold.

The Jinsha River (the upper stream of Yangtze River) complex is the largest hydroelectric generating system currently under construction. It has three phases. Phase one includes four dams on the downstream of the Jinsha River. They are Wudongde Dam, Baihetan Dam, Xiluodu Dam, and Xiangjiaba Dam, with generating capacity of 10,200 MW, 16,000 MW, 13,860 MW, and 6,448 MW respectively. Phase two includes eight dams on the middle stream of the Jinsha River.
China’s Jinsha River will host two of the world’s next giants: the 16,000 MW Baihetan Dam due 2021-2022 and the 10,200 MW Wudongde Dam due 2020-2021. Downstream on the Salween, Myanmar’s 7,110 MW TaSang project is on indefinite hold, while the 3,600 MW Myitsone on the Irrawaddy faces the same fate. Ethiopia is racing to finish the 6,450 MW Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam on the Blue Nile by 2022 and the 2,160 MW Koysha Dam on the Omo in 2021. Pakistan is pairing the 4,500 MW Diamer-Bhasha and the 4,320 MW Dasu, both on the Indus, for commissioning in 2023. Tajikistan’s 3,600 MW Rogun on the Vakhsh is scheduled across the decade ending 2029. Nigeria plans 3,050 MW from the Mambilla station on the Donga by 2024, while China’s 3,000 MW Lianghekou on the Yalong should spin up between 2021 and 2023. Colombia’s Ituango on the Cauca targets 2,456 MW, possibly in 2021, whereas Venezuela’s 2,320 MW Tocoma on the Caroní is stalled. Angola is building the 2,172 MW Caculo Cabaça for 2024 and expanding the 2,069.5 MW Lauca through 2020. China will add 2,200 MW with Maerdang on the Yellow River and 2,000 MW with Shuangjiangkou on the Dadu, while India’s 2,000 MW Subansiri Lower remains on hold.

title: List of Georgia Institute of Technology alumni
intro:
This list of Georgia Institute of Technology alumni includes graduates, non-graduate former students, and current students of Georgia Tech. Notable administration, faculty, and staff are found on the list of Georgia Institute of Technology faculty. Georgia Tech alumni are generally known as Yellow Jackets. According to the Georgia Tech Alumni Association,
.
lm_description: Rawi Abdelal, Georgia Tech class of 1993, teaches business administration at Harvard Business School. Ronald W. Allen, a 1964 graduate, led Delta Air Lines as president, chairman and CEO from 1987 to 1997 and later chaired Aaron’s, Inc. Gil Amelio, from the class of 1965, served as CEO of National Semiconductor and Apple and is an IEEE Fellow. Charles Garry Betty, 1979 alumnus, ran EarthLink as president and CEO from 1996 to 2007. W. Frank Blount, class of 1961, chairs JI Ventures, once led Cypress Communications and directed Telstra in Australia. John F. Brock, 1971 graduate, chairs and runs Coca-Cola Enterprises. Paul J. Brown, 1989 alumnus, heads Inspire Brands. Gary C. Butler, 1968 graduate, is CEO of Automatic Data Processing. Brook Byers, also 1968, is a Kleiner Perkins venture capitalist. George G. Crawford, 1890 alumnus, once headed the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company. Quentin Dastugue, 1977 graduate, founded Property One and served four terms in the Louisiana House. Cecil B. Day, 1958 alumnus, created Days Inn Hotels. David Dorman, 1975 graduate, is chairman and CEO emeritus of AT&T. Mike Duke, 1971 alumnus, formerly ran Wal-Mart Stores. Walter Ehmer, 1989 graduate, presides over Waffle House. David C. Garrett Jr., 1955 alumnus, captained Delta from 1978 to 1987. Jaime Gilinski, 1978 graduate, chairs JGB Financial. Frank Gordy, 1929 alumnus, founded The Varsity, the world’s largest drive-in. James Gerald Gulliver, 1950 graduate, built Argyll Foods into a UK retail giant. Dennis Hayes, 1973 alumnus, founded Hayes Communications and pioneered PC modems.

title: 2000 Austrian Grand Prix
intro: The 2000 Austrian Grand Prix (formally the XXIV Großer A1 Preis von Österreich) was a Formula One motor race held on 16 July 2000 at the A1-Ring near Spielberg, Styria, Austria. It was the tenth round of the 2000 Formula One season and the 24th Austrian Grand Prix. The 71-lap race was won by McLaren driver Mika Häkkinen after starting from pole position. His teammate David Coulthard finished second with Rubens Barrichello third for the Ferrari team. Michael Schumacher, the eventual Drivers' Champion, led the Championship going into the race and started from fourth position alongside Barrichello. At the first corner BAR's Ricardo Zonta ran into the rear of Michael Schumacher. The incident forced the German to retire and caused a safety car deployment. After the safety car pulled in after one lap Häkkinen and Coulthard extended a comfortable lead over the rest of the field. When Häkkinen made his pit stop on lap 38, he rejoined behind Coulthard, but ahead of Barrichello. Coulthard made a pit stop on lap 41, allowing Häkkinen back into the lead which he held to clinch his second victory of the 2000 season. As a consequence of the race, Coulthard's second place narrowed the gap to Michael Schumacher in the Drivers' Championship to six points, while Häkkinen's win meant he closed to within two points of Coulthard. After the Grand Prix, McLaren were docked 10 points for a post-race technical infringement, resulting in Ferrari maintaining their lead in the Constructors' Championship with a four-point gap over McLaren, with seven races of the season remaining.
lm_description: Mika Häkkinen planted his McLaren-Mercedes on pole with a 1:10.410 lap, 0.385 s clear of team-mate David Coulthard who lined up second. Rubens Barrichello’s Ferrari split the silver cars by a whisker, his 1:10.844 only 0.049 s adrift of Coulthard and 0.434 s behind Häkkinen. Championship leader Michael Schumacher shared the second row with Barrichello, the German’s 1:11.046 leaving him 0.636 s off pole. Jarno Trulli headed row three for Jordan-Mugen-Honda at 1:11.640, just seven-thousandths ahead of BAR-Honda pair Ricardo Zonta and Jacques Villeneuve, who posted 1:11.647 and 1:11.649 respectively. Giancarlo Fisichella’s Benetton-Playlife slotted eighth at 1:11.658, with Mika Salo’s Sauber-Petronas ninth on 1:11.761 and Jos Verstappen’s Arrows-Supertec rounding out the top ten in 1:11.905. Pedro Diniz and Pedro de la Rosa filled the next two spots for Sauber and Arrows, 1:11.931 and 1:11.978, while Nick Heidfeld’s Prost-Peugeot, Alexander Wurz’s Benetton and Heinz-Harald Frentzen’s Jordan followed within a hundredth of each other. Johnny Herbert’s Jaguar, Jean Alesi’s Prost, Jenson Button and Ralf Schumacher’s Williams-BMWs, and Marc Gené’s Minardi completed the 20-car grid, Gené trailing Häkkinen by 2.312 s.

title: List of New York University faculty
intro: Following is a partial list of notable faculty (either past, present or visiting) of New York University. As of 2014, among NYU's past and present faculty, there are at least 159 Guggenheim Fellows, over 7 Lasker Award winners, and at least 68 are currently elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
lm_description: NYU’s professorial ranks include former Caltech provost Steven E. Koonin, ex-Cornell president Jeffrey S. Lehman, Swarthmore’s onetime president Alfred Bloom, Rice’s seventh president David Leebron, and Princeton’s sitting twentieth president Christopher L. Eisgruber. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew, Pulitzer poet Yusef Komunyakaa, Fields medalist Martin Hairer, Turing laureate Frances E. Allen, and Abel winner Louis Nirenberg all teach there. Anthropologist Thomas A. Abercrombie holds a 2004-2005 Guggenheim, while emeritus computer scientist Martin Davis co-invented the Davis-Putnam and DPLL algorithms and framed Post-Turing machines. International-law scholar Philip Alston, the UN Special Rapporteur on Extrajudicial Executions, occupies NYU’s John Norton Pomeroy chair, and illusionist David Copperfield has offered a class on magic. Olympic luger Cammy Myler, 1985-1998 national-team veteran of four Winter Games, is on faculty; finance professor Edward Altman, hired in 1977, devised the Altman Z-Score. Poet-in-residence Yehuda Amichai collected the 1969 Brenner, 1976 Bialik, and 1982 Israel prizes. Dramatist Awam Amkpa directs NYU’s Africana studies, bioethicist Jacob M. Appel serves as visiting faculty, and Roger S. Bagnall, director of NYU’s Institute for the Study of the Ancient World, visits as professor.

title: List of cathedrals in France
intro: This is a list of cathedrals in France and in the French overseas departments, territories and collectivities, including both actual and former diocesan cathedrals (seats of bishops). Almost all cathedrals in France are Roman Catholic, but any non-Roman Catholic cathedrals are listed here as well. The list is intended to be complete as far as current cathedrals and co-cathedrals are concerned. It is not yet an exhaustive list of former cathedrals, although it includes most of them. A number of large churches in France are known as cathedral as a mark of distinction or historical importance but have never been the seats of bishops. These are not included here.
lm_description: Agde Cathedral, dedicated to Saint Stephen, stands in Agde under Montpellier’s jurisdiction but lost its cathedral status when the bishopric was suppressed in 1801. Agen Cathedral honours Saint Caprasius in Agen itself, serves as the diocese’s cathedral, and is listed as a World Heritage Site. Aire Cathedral, dedicated to Saint John the Baptist, rises in Aire-sur-l’Adour for the combined diocese of Aire et Dax. Aix Cathedral, the Holy Saviour church in Aix-en-Provence, functions as cathedral and minor basilica. Ajaccio Cathedral, dedicated to the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary, is the cathedral of Ajaccio. Albi Cathedral, dedicated to Saint Cecilia in Albi, holds both cathedral rank and minor-basilica status. Alès Cathedral, once the Saint John the Baptist seat in Alès under Nîmes, was reduced to a former cathedral in 1801. Alet Cathedral, now ruined, was the Blessed Virgin Mary cathedral at Alet-les-Bains until its 1801 suppression. Aleth Cathedral, dedicated to Saint Peter in Saint-Servan, was replaced by Saint-Malo in 1146 and destroyed by 1255. Amiens Cathedral, Notre-Dame in Amiens, is a cathedral, minor basilica and World Heritage Site. Angers Cathedral honours Saint Maurice in Angers; Angoulême Cathedral honours Saint Peter in Angoulême; Annecy Cathedral honours Saint Peter in Annecy. Antibes Cathedral, dedicated to Notre-Dame de la Platéa, lost its cathedral standing in 1801. Apt Cathedral, dedicated to Saint Ann, was suppressed the same year. Arles’ former cathedral, now Church of St Trophime, honours Saint Trophimus and lost archiepiscopal status in 1822. Arras Cathedral, dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary and Saint Vedast, is a cathedral and minor basilica. Auch Cathedral, dedicated to Saint Mary, is a cathedral, minor basilica and World Heritage Site. Autun Cathedral, dedicated to Saint Lazarus, is a 12th-century cathedral and minor basilica, while the Old Autun Cathedral, dedicated to Saint Nazarius, served from the 5th to the 12th century.
