title: 2001 German Grand Prix
intro: The 2001 German Grand Prix (formally the LXIII Großer Mobil 1 Preis von Deutschland) was a Formula One motor race held on 29 July 2001 at the Hockenheimring, Baden-Württemberg, Germany. It was the twelfth round of the 2001 Formula One season and the 63rd German Grand Prix. The 45-lap race was won by Williams driver Ralf Schumacher after starting from the second position. Rubens Barrichello finished second for Ferrari with BAR driver Jacques Villeneuve third scoring his last F1 podium finish. Juan Pablo Montoya started from pole position alongside Ralf Schumacher. Michael Schumacher, the eventual Drivers' Champion started fourth, behind Mika Häkkinen of McLaren. The race was marked by an airborne accident going into the first corner involving Michael Schumacher and Luciano Burti for Prost, which caused the track to be scattered with shreds of carbon fibre and the race restarted as a result. Both Williams drivers retained their positions at the end of the first lap, with Michael Schumacher passing Häkkinen for third. Over the course of the race, Montoya extended a considerable lead over Ralf Schumacher. Montoya lost the lead on lap 24 when an issue with a refueling rig caused him to be stationary for more than 20 seconds. Ralf Schumacher thus inherited the lead and held it to win his third victory of the season. As a consequence of the race, Michael Schumacher retained his points advantage in the Drivers' Championship over nearest rival David Coulthard as both drivers retired from the event.
lm_description: Juan Pablo Montoya planted his Williams-BMW on pole with a 1:38.117 lap, only 0.019 s ahead of team-mate Ralf Schumacher. Mika Häkkinen’s McLaren-Mercedes slotted third at 1:38.811, followed by Michael Schumacher’s Ferrari a further 0.13 s back. David Coulthard made it two silver arrows in the top five, 1.457 s off the pace, while Rubens Barrichello’s second Ferrari was sixth. Sauber’s Nick Heidfeld and rookie Kimi Räikkönen lined up seventh and eighth, Pedro de la Rosa’s Jaguar and Jarno Trulli’s Jordan completing the top ten. Eddie Irvine edged Jacques Villeneuve’s BAR by 0.066 s for 11th, with Olivier Panis a further 0.173 s behind in the sister BAR. Jean Alesi’s Prost, Ricardo Zonta’s Jordan, Luciano Burti’s Prost and the Benetton pair of Giancarlo Fisichella and Jenson Button filled rows 14-18, all within 0.7 s. Arrows teammates Enrique Bernoldi and Jos Verstappen rounded out the grid, Bernoldi 0.202 s ahead of Verstappen but 3.551 s adrift of Montoya’s benchmark.

title: List of Arizona Cardinals first-round draft picks
intro: The Arizona Cardinals are a professional American football franchise based in Glendale, Arizona. The Cardinals compete in the National Football League as a member club of the league's National Football Conference (NFC) West division. The Cardinals were founded as the Morgan Athletic Club in 1898, and are the oldest continuously run professional football team in the World. Officially known as the NFL Draft, the event is the NFL's primary mechanism for distributing newly professional players finished with their college football careers to its teams. The draft order is determined based on the previous season's standings; the teams with the worst win-loss records receive the earliest picks. Teams that qualified for the NFL playoffs select after non-qualifiers, and their order depends on how far they advanced. The final two selections in the first round are reserved for the Super Bowl runner-up and champion. Draft picks are tradable, and players or other picks can be acquired with them.
lm_description: In 1960 the Cardinals used the second overall pick on Notre Dame quarterback George Izo, then followed with Auburn tackle Ken Rice at eighth overall in 1961. They doubled up in 1962, grabbing Northwestern defensive tackle Fate Echols sixth and Kentucky center Irv Goode twelfth, and did the same in 1963 when LSU safety Jerry Stovall went second and Purdue defensive end Don Brumm thirteenth. Louisville defensive tackle Ken Kortas was the ninth selection in 1964, Alabama quarterback Joe Namath the twelfth in 1965, Oklahoma linebacker Carl McAdams the eighth in 1966, and Washington wide receiver Dave Williams the sixteenth in 1967. Utah State running back MacArthur Lane arrived thirteenth in 1968, Missouri defensive back Roger Wehrli nineteenth in 1969, Texas A&M running back Larry Stegent eighth in 1970, and Utah cornerback Norm Thompson seventeenth in 1971. Oregon hybrid back Ahmad Rashad was the fourth pick in 1972, Purdue defensive tackle Dave Butz fifth in 1973, Colorado tight end J. V. Cain seventh in 1974, Texas A&M defensive back Tim Gray twenty-first in 1975, Arizona defensive tackle Mike Dawson twenty-second in 1976, and Missouri quarterback Steve Pisarkiewicz nineteenth in 1977.

title: List of aircraft of World War II
intro: The List of aircraft of World War II includes all the aircraft used by those countries which were at war during World War II from the period between their joining the conflict and the conflict ending for them. Aircraft developed but not used operationally in the war are in the prototypes section at the end. Prototypes for aircraft that entered service under a different design number are ignored in favour of the service version. The date the aircraft entered service, or was first flown if the service date is unknown or it did not enter service follows the name, followed by the country of origin and major wartime users. Aircraft used for multiple roles are generally only listed under their primary role unless specialized versions were built for other roles in significant numbers. Aircraft used by neutral countries such as Spain, Switzerland and Sweden or countries which did no significant fighting such as most of those in South America (except Brazil), are not included.
lm_description: The US fielded the Aeronca L-3 in 1941, while its earlier Barkley-Grow T8P-1 dated from 1937 and the twin-beech Beechcraft 17 Staggerwing, also known as the UC-43 Traveler, had been flying since 1933; the larger Beechcraft Model 18 family—C-45, JRB, SNB, AT-7 and AT-11 Expeditor—followed in 1937, and the Cessna 165 appeared in 1935. Britain’s Airspeed Envoy entered service in 1934 and the Avro 652 in 1935. Italy’s wartime inventory included the AVIA FL.3 (1939), the Breda Ba.44 (1934) and the Caproni Ca.164 (1938). France relied on a string of Caudron types: the C.272 from 1931, the C.280/C.400/C.410 series from 1932, the C.440 Goéland from 1934, and the C.480 Frégate, C.600 Aiglon and C.635 Simoun all from 1935, plus the Bloch MB.81 ambulance aircraft and MB.120 mailplane, likewise dating from 1935. Czechoslovakia contributed the Beneš-Mráz Be-555 Super Bibi in 1936, and Brazil the CAP CAP-4 Paulista in 1935.

List of aircraft of World War II
The List of aircraft of World War II includes all the aircraft used by those countries which were at war during World War II from the period between their joining the conflict and the conflict ending for them. Aircraft developed but not used operationally in the war are in the prototypes section at the end. Prototypes for aircraft that entered service under a different design number are ignored in favour of the service version. The date the aircraft entered service, or was first flown if the service date is unknown or it did not enter service follows the name, followed by the country of origin and major wartime users. Aircraft used for multiple roles are generally only listed under their primary role unless specialized versions were built for other roles in significant numbers. Aircraft used by neutral countries such as Spain, Switzerland and Sweden or countries which did no significant fighting such as most of those in South America (except Brazil), are not included.

title: List of Texas state symbols
intro: The following is a list of symbols of the U.S. state of Texas.
lm_description: Texas honors the Commemorative Air Force as its official air force and pan de campo as the state bread, while the Dutch oven reigns as the designated cooking implement and the towering Sauroposeidon claims the dinosaur title. Chili became the state dish in 1977, Texas 42 the official domino game, and cotton the celebrated fiber and fabric in 1997. The Guadalupe bass took its place as state fish in 1989, square dance became the folk dance in 1991, and the Texas red grapefruit was named state fruit in 1993. The Lone Star Cut distinguishes Texas as the only state with its own gemstone cut, while Texas blue topaz has served as state gem since 1969. Sideoats grama became the state grass in 1971, the monarch butterfly the insect symbol in 1995, and the buckyball molecule represents Texas scientific heritage. Western swing fills the air as state music, the acoustic guitar the musical instrument, and the native pecan has been the state nut since 1919. Among peppers, the native chiltepin and the jalapeño, designated in 1995, share official recognition.

title: Gatorade Player of the Year awards
intro: The Gatorade Player of the Year awards are given annually to up and coming high school student-athletes in the United States. They are given for boys' baseball, boys' football, girls' softball, girls' volleyball, boys' basketball, girls' basketball, boys' cross country, girls' cross country, boys' soccer, girls' soccer, boys' track & field, and girls' track & field. A State Player of the Year award is given to the best student-athlete in each of the twelve sports in the District of Columbia and each of the fifty states, where each sport is recognized as an interscholastic sport. Selection is based on three criteria: athletic achievement, academic excellence, and exemplary character (including sportsmanship, and participation in community and other activities). Twelve National Player of the Year awards are then given, to the best student-athlete in each of the twelve sports, chosen from the state winners in the respective sport. Finally, one male Athlete of the Year and one female Athlete of the Year are selected from the twelve National Player of the Year recipients. The two winners are voted on by a national panel that includes approximately 400 sports journalists, coaches, and others. The two athletes of the year receive their awards at a special ceremony prior to The ESPY Awards, in Los Angeles, California. The Gatorade Company established these awards in 1986. The selection process was administered by ESPN RISE, which was ESPN's division for high-school sports. The selection process is currently administered by the Gatorade Player of the Year Selection Committee. Past national winners include Peyton Manning and Emmitt Smith for football, LeBron James and Kobe Bryant for basketball, Allyson Felix for track and field, and Kerri Walsh for volleyball.
lm_description: Allyson Felix of North Hills, California, claimed the 2003 honor for track & field before heading to USC, while Candace Parker took the 2004 basketball award from Naperville, Illinois, and enrolled at Tennessee. Stanford-bound Cynthia Barboza earned the 2005 volleyball prize from Long Beach, California, and Connecticut-bound post players dominated the next three seasons: Tina Charles from Middle Village, New York, in 2006, Maya Moore from Lawrenceville, Georgia, in 2007, and Notre Dame-bound Skylar Diggins from South Bend, Indiana, in 2009, with Stanford’s Chiney Ogwumike of Cypress, Texas, winning in 2010. Breanna Stewart continued the UConn lineage in 2012 out of North Syracuse, New York. Soccer’s 2011 winner, Morgan Brian, came from St. Simons Island, Georgia, and chose Virginia, while 2013 recipient Morgan Andrews from Milford, New Hampshire, picked Notre Dame. Brianna Turner kept Notre Dame on the women’s basketball map in 2014, arriving from Manvel, Texas. Track standouts included Tennessee-bound Chanelle Price from Easton, Pennsylvania, in 2008, Candace Hill of Conyers, Georgia, in 2015 forgoing college, and Kentucky-bound Sydney McLaughlin repeating from Scotch Plains, New Jersey, in 2016 and 2017. Katelyn Tuohy of Thiels, New York, swept cross country and track & field in 2018, and Kelley Lynch closed the span as 2019 softball winner from Sharpsburg, Georgia, bound for Washington.

title: African Slave Trade Patrol
intro: African Slave Trade Patrol was part of the suppression of the Atlantic slave trade between 1819 and the beginning of the American Civil War in 1861. Due to the abolitionist movement in the United States, a squadron of U.S. Navy warships were assigned to catch slave traders in and around Africa. The operations were largely ineffective as after 42 years only about 100 suspected slave ships were captured.
lm_description: Between 1858 and 1860, U.S. Navy cruisers intercepted nine suspected slavers off Cuba. On 21 August 1858, Dolphin seized the Putnam in Cuban waters. Mohawk captured Cygnet on 18 November 1859 near Cuba, then Wildfire on 26 April 1860. Wyandotte took William on 9 May 1860 off Cuba, while Crusader captured Bogota on 23 May, W.R. Kibby on 23 July, and Joven Antonio on 14 August, all in Cuban waters. Closing the year, Mohawk detained Toccoa on 20 December and Mary J. Kimball on 21 December at Havana.

African Slave Trade Patrol

Mohawk captured Cygnet on 18 November 1859 near Cuba, then Wildfire on 26 April 1860. Wyandotte took William on 9 May 1860 off Cuba, while Crusader captured Bogota on 23 May, W.R. title: Cloud-computing comparison
intro: The following is a comparison of cloud-computing software and providers.
lm_description: fluid Operations eCloudManager, launched on 1 March 2009 under a proprietary license and built in Java and Groovy, is the only platform listed that cannot be consumed as a service yet can be installed locally. AppScale followed six days later, offering Apache-licensed code written in Python, Ruby and Go, and both service and local deployment options. Cloud Foundry arrived on 12 April 2011 with Ruby, C, Java and Go under the Apache license, while Cloud.com/CloudStack debuted on 4 May 2010 in Java and C, both supporting service and local use. Eucalyptus, dating to 29 May 2008, carries dual proprietary and GPL v3 licensing in Java and C, and Flexiant Limited, the earliest from 15 January 2007, remains proprietary in Java and C, both enabling service and local operation. Nimbus, released 9 January 2009, and OpenNebula, from March 2008, use Apache licenses—Nimbus in Java and Python, OpenNebula in C++, C, Ruby, Java, shell, lex and yacc—each service-ready and locally installable. OpenQRM, also March 2008, opts for GPL licensing with C++, PHP and shell, while OpenShift, launched 4 May 2011, uses Apache-licensed Go; both provide service and local modes. OpenStack, 21 October 2010, contributes Apache-licensed Python, OnApp, 1 July 2010, offers proprietary Java, Ruby and C++, and Jelastic, 27 January 2011, multi-licensed under GPL, Apache and BSD, blends Java, JavaScript, Perl and shell, all service and local capable. oVirt, newest on 9 August 2012, Apache-licensed in Java and Python, supports local installation while its service status is unspecified.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Talladega County, Alabama
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places listings in Talladega County, Alabama. This is intended to be a complete list of the properties and districts on the National Register of Historic Places in Talladega County, Alabama, United States. Latitude and longitude coordinates are provided for many National Register properties and districts; these locations may be seen together in a Google map. There are 24 properties and districts listed on the National Register in the county, including 2 National Historic Landmarks.
lm_description: The Benjamin H. Averiett House and the nearby William Averiett House, both off State Route 8 in Sylacauga, entered the National Register on August 28, 1986. Boxwood at 406 E. North St. in Talladega was listed June 9, 1983, while the Charles Butler House stands at the junction of 1st St. and 10th Ave. in Childersburg, added February 26, 1996. Sylacauga’s B.B. Comer Memorial Library, 711 N. Broadway Ave., joined the register September 6, 2005, the same town where the Goodwin-Hamilton House on Marble Valley Rd. and the Hightower Brothers Livery Stable at 413 Norton Ave. were listed August 28, 1986, and July 3, 1997, respectively. The J.L.M. Curry House, 3 miles northeast of Talladega on State Route 21, dates to October 15, 1966, and the Elston House, 10 miles north on Turner’s Mill Rd., to October 8, 1976. Talladega’s First Presbyterian Church at 130 North St. was listed November 17, 1983, Idlewild on State Route 5 north of Route 21 on October 15, 1993, and the Silk Stocking District roughly bounded by Coffee, 2nd, McMillan, and Court Sts. on December 13, 1979. The Jemison House Complex south of the Chocolocco and Cheaha Creeks confluence in Eastaboga was added October 1, 1990. Kymulga Mill and Covered Bridge, 4.5 miles northeast of Childersburg on State Route 46, entered October 29, 1976, and the Lawler-Whiting House along State Route 21 south of Talladega on May 22, 1986. Oxford’s Dudley Snow House on Peek Dr. was listed February 4, 1982. Swayne Hall on the Talladega College campus and the adjacent Talladega College Historic District at Battle St. and Martin Luther King Dr. were registered December 2, 1974, and August 23, 1990. The Sylacauga Historic Commercial District, roughly bounded by Broadway Ave., W. 1st, Anniston Ave., and W. 4th St., joined June 2, 2004, and the Talladega Courthouse Square Historic District, centered on Courthouse Sq., was entered October 18, 1972.

title: Survivor Series (1995)
intro: Survivor Series (1995) was the ninth annual Survivor Series professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event produced by the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now WWE). It took place on November 19, 1995, at the USAir Arena in Landover, Maryland, and was the first Survivor Series to take place on a Sunday night. Each previous edition had taken place either on Thanksgiving or Thanksgiving Eve; the company would not do another non-weekend pay-per-view event until 2004, when Taboo Tuesday debuted. The main event was a No Disqualification match between Diesel and Bret Hart for the WWF World Heavyweight Championship. Hart won the match and the title by pinfall, becoming a three-time champion and ending Diesel's 358-day reign - the longest of the 1990s. The undercard featured Shawn Michaels, Ahmed Johnson, British Bulldog, and Sycho Sid versus Yokozuna, Owen Hart, Razor Ramon, and Dean Douglas in a four-on-four Survivor Series elimination match, The Darkside (The Undertaker, Savio Vega, Fatu, and Henry Godwinn) versus The Royals (King Mabel, Jerry Lawler, Isaac Yankem and Hunter Hearst Helmsley) in a four-on-four Survivor Series elimination match, Goldust versus Bam Bam Bigelow and Bertha Faye, Aja Kong, Tomoko Watanabe, and Lioness Asuka versus Alundra Blayze, Kyoko Inoue, Sakie Hasegawa, and Chaparita Asari in a four-on-four Survivor Series elimination match and The BodyDonnas (Skip, Rad Radford, Dr. Tom Prichard and 1-2-3 Kid) versus The Underdogs (Marty Jannetty, Hakushi, Barry Horowitz and Bob Holly) in a four-on-four Survivor Series elimination match.
lm_description: Bob Holly pinned Dr. Tom Prichard at 5:17, only to be pinned himself six seconds later by Skip. Rad Radford eliminated Hakushi at 8:10, but Barry Horowitz returned the favor against Radford at 11:26. The 1-2-3 Kid then ousted Horowitz at 12:25, Marty Jannetty eliminated Skip at 15:02, and the Kid finally pinned Jannetty at 18:45 to close the match.

title: List of baronies of Ireland
intro: This is a list of the baronies of Ireland. Baronies were subdivisions of counties, mainly cadastral but with some administrative functions prior to the Local Government (Ireland) Act 1898.
lm_description: Antrim’s baronies split into Lower and Upper pairs during 1792-1798: Antrim Lower stretches across 80,826 acres and Antrim Upper over 36,489, both named for Antrim town; Belfast Lower covers 56,142 acres and Belfast Upper 32,942, both echoing the town now city; Dunluce Lower holds 30,575 acres and Dunluce Upper 52,788, both linked to Dunluce Castle; Glenarm Lower extends 64,945 acres and Glenarm Upper 24,032, both named after Glenarm village; Toome Lower comprises 36,135 acres and Toome Upper 47,571, both taking their name from Toome village. Carrickfergus, recorded by 1325 and once the County of the Town of Carrickfergus, spans 16,702 acres. Cary, anglicised from Cathraí and known since 1672, covers 75,035 acres and recalls the ancient Cothrugu tribe. Kilconway, Coill Chonmaí in Irish, meaning “forest of the Conmhaícne,” embraces 68,640 acres. Massereene Lower, 27,228 acres, and Massereene Upper, 56,675 acres, both created 1792-1798, honour Viscount Massereene and a monastery once called “Queen’s hill.” Armagh barony, documented by 1609, occupies 47,645 acres and is named for Armagh town now city. Fews Lower, 29,757 acres, and Fews Upper, 47,433 acres, split by 1745 but Fews known since 1609, derive from “Na Feadha,” the lengths. Oneilland East, 20,890 acres, and Oneilland West, 57,584 acres, divided 1792-1807 yet Oneilland recorded by 1609, commemorate the Uí Nialláin tribe and are distinct from the O’Neills.

title: Dancing with the Stars (Australian season 11)
intro: The eleventh season of Dancing with the Stars premiered on Sunday 8 May 2011 at 6:30 pm on Channel Seven. Daniel MacPherson and Sonia Kruger returned as hosts, along with judges Todd McKenney and Helen Richey. Australian dancer Joshua Horner joined the judging panel as a replacement for Mark Wilson. My Kitchen Rules presenter Manu Feildel and his partner, Alana Patience, won the competition over model Haley Bracken. Alana is the first professional to win the competition twice, having won the prior season with Rob Palmer.
lm_description: Retired cricketer Nathan Bracken and his partner Masha Belash were the first to leave on 15 May 2011, followed a week later by retired golfer Jan Stephenson and Mark Hodge. Surfer Mark Occhilupo and Jade Brand exited on 29 May, Home and Away actor Dan Ewing and Luda Kroitor on 5 June, socialite Brynne Edelsten and Arsen Kishishian on 12 June, model Nick Bracks—son of Steve Bracks—and Jessica Raffa on 19 June, model Lara Bingle and Carmelo Pizzino on 26 June, and Sunrise newsreader Samantha Armytage with Brendon Midson on 3 July. Singer-songwriter Damien Leith and Melanie Hooper claimed third place on 10 July, while model Haley Bracken—wife of Nathan Bracken—and Aric Yegudkin finished runner-up the same night. Chef and My Kitchen Rules presenter Manu Feildel and Alana Patience won the title on 10 July 2011, making Alana the first professional to win twice after her previous victory with Rob Palmer.

Alana is the first professional to win the competition twice, having won the prior season with Rob Palmer.
Retired cricketer Nathan Bracken and his partner Masha Belash were the first to leave on 15 May 2011, followed a week later by retired golfer Jan Stephenson and Mark Hodge. Surfer Mark Occhilupo and Jade Brand exited on 29 May, Home and Away actor Dan Ewing and Luda Kroitor on 5 June, socialite Brynne Edelsten and Arsen Kishishian on 12 June, model Nick Bracks—son of Steve Bracks—and Jessica Raffa on 19 June, model Lara Bingle and Carmelo Pizzino on 26 June, and Sunrise newsreader Samantha Armytage with Brendon Midson on 3 July. Singer-songwriter Damien Leith and Melanie Hooper claimed third place on 10 July, while model Haley Bracken—wife of Nathan Bracken—and Aric Yegudkin finished runner-up the same night. Chef and My Kitchen Rules presenter Manu Feildel and Alana Patience won the title on 10 July 2011, making Alana the first professional to win twice after her previous victory with Rob Palmer.

title: List of Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology people
intro: This is a list of Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology people. This list of people includes alumni as well as current and former students and faculty of the Australian (RMIT University) and Vietnamese (RMIT University Vietnam) branches of the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT). It also includes alumni as well as former students and faculty from its antecedents: Melbourne Technical College (MTC) and Working Men's College (WMC); amalgamations with: Emily McPherson College of Domestic Economy (EMC), Melbourne College of Decoration, Melbourne College of Printing and Graphic Art and Melbourne College of Textiles; and merger with Phillip Institute of Technology (PIT).
lm_description: Ian Browne, Steven Hooker and Bill Lawry all attended RMIT before claiming Olympic or Commonwealth gold, while Jared Tallent is still studying there after adding Olympic silver to his Commonwealth race-walking title. Elizabeth Gardner, Lydia Lassila and Nick Morris each earned a Bachelor of Applied Science (Human Movement) at RMIT, with Lassila later soaring to Winter Olympic gold and Morris becoming a Paralympic champion wheelchair basketballer. Current student David Morris continues the tradition as a freestyle skier, and fellow student Elizabeth Patrick coxes the rowing squad. Carrie Graf, who captained and coached the Australian women’s basketball team, holds the same degree, as does James Tomkins, the triple-Olympic-gold rower who also works as a financial analyst after completing a Bachelor of Business. Julien Wiener, the first Jewish Test cricketer for Australia, also studied business management at RMIT. Allan Hahn, Emeritus Professor at the Australian Institute of Sport, received an honorary Doctor of Applied Science from RMIT where he taught, and Charlie Walsh, former national cycling coach, developed the RMIT-AIS Olympic Superbike while on faculty. Gus Johnston, armed with a BA in Advertising, campaigns against homophobia in sport after representing Australia in hockey, and Max Walker, architect via RMIT’s Diploma of Architecture, played both Test cricket and AFL for Melbourne. Colin Ridgway, another attendee, became the first Australian to play in the NFL with the Dallas Cowboys, and golf great Peter Thomson took physics classes at RMIT en route to five British Open titles.

title: Spiel des Jahres
intro: The Spiel des Jahres (German: [ˈʃpiːl dəs ˈjaːʁəs], Game of the Year) is an award for board and card games, created in 1978 with the stated purpose of rewarding excellence in game design, and promoting top-quality games in the German market. It is thought that the existence and popularity of the award is one of the major drivers of the quality of games coming out of Germany. A Spiel des Jahres nomination can increase the typical sales of a game from 500-3000 copies to around 10,000; and the winner can usually expect to sell 300,000 to 500,000 copies.
lm_description: Ludovic Roudy and Bruno Sautter’s party game Just One earned the 2019 Spiel des Jahres for Repos Production, while Michael Kiesling’s Azul took the 2018 prize under Next Move/Plan B Games. Bruno Cathala’s Kingdomino won for Pegasus Spiele in 2017, the same publisher that released Donald X. Vaccarino’s Kingdom Builder, the 2012 laureate. Vlaada Chvátil’s word-association hit Codenames brought 2016 glory to Czech Games Edition, preceded by Christophe Raimbault’s train-robbing Colt Express for Ludonaute in 2015 and Steffen Bogen’s racing camels in Camel Up via Eggertspiele the year before. Antoine Bauza’s cooperative fireworks puzzle Hanabi won for Abacusspiele in 2013, and Susan McKinley Ross’s tile-laying Qwirkle did so for Mindware Spiele in 2011, one year after Jean-Louis Roubira’s dreamy storytelling game Dixit claimed the title for Libellud. Donald X. Vaccarino also designed 2009 winner Dominion, published by Rio Grande Games, while Reiner Knizia’s Keltis earned Kosmos the 2008 award. Michael Schacht’s zoo-building Zooloretto won for Abacus Spiele in 2007, Andreas and Karen Seyfarth’s postal-themed Thurn and Taxis did so for Hans im Glück in 2006, and Thomas Liesching’s rapid Niagara earned Zoch Verlag the 2005 prize. Alan R. Moon’s cross-country Ticket to Ride won for Days of Wonder in 2004, Dirk Henn’s palace-building Alhambra gave Queen Games the 2003 honor, Bill Payne’s balancing Villa Paletti earned Zoch Verlag the 2002 nod, Klaus-Jürgen Wrede’s medieval Carcassonne won for Hans im Glück in 2001, and the architectural strategy game Torres by Wolfgang Kramer and Michael Kiesling closed the millennium with the 2000 award for Ravensburger.

title: Newington College
intro: Newington College is a multi-campus independent Uniting Church single-sex and co-educational early learning, primary and secondary day and boarding school for boys, located in Stanmore, an inner-western suburb of Sydney, New South Wales, Australia. Established in 1863 at Newington House, Silverwater, the College celebrated its sesquicentenary in 2013. The college is open to boys of all faiths and denominations. Newington has been governed by an Act of Parliament since 1922. Newington has two preparatory schools, Wyvern House, in Cambridge Street, Stanmore, and a school at Lindfield, on Sydney's Upper North Shore. Newington currently caters for approximately 2,000 students from Year K to Year 12. Edmund Webb House, a boarding facility, is in Cambridge Street, Stanmore. The Robert Glasson Memorial Boat Shed is on the Parramatta River at Abbotsford and contains a boarding facility for thirty boys. The College is a member of the Association of Heads of Independent Schools of Australia (AHISA), the Junior School Heads Association of Australia (JSHAA), the Australian Boarding Schools' Association, and a founding member of the Athletic Association of the Great Public Schools of New South Wales (AAGPS). The College prepares students for the International Baccalaureate Diploma Programme and the NSW Higher School Certificate.
lm_description: Rev. James Egan Moulton, educated at Kingswood School and founding headmaster of Tupou College in Tonga, led Newington from its 1863 opening. George Metcalfe, Melbourne and Sydney graduate who had founded Druitt Town Public School and run Goulburn High, succeeded him 1867-69. Trinity Dublin and Melbourne alumnus Michael Howe, previously founding head of Galt Grammar School and head of Toronto’s Jarvis Collegiate, served 1868-77. Joseph Coates, Huddersfield College alumnus and founding head of Sydney Boys’ High, held office 1877-83. Cambridge classicist William Williams, former professor at the University of Tasmania, guided the college 1884-92. Arthur Lucas, Kingswood and Balliol graduate, ex-head of Sydney Grammar and Tasmanian mathematics professor, led 1893-98. Edward Cornwall, Oxford classicist and former acting head of Ipswich Grammar, served briefly in 1899. Rev. Charles Prescott, Worcester College alumnus who founded Wesleyan Ladies’ College, held the post 1900-31. Philip Le Couteur, Melbourne Queen’s and Oxford graduate who had headed Methodist Ladies’ College and Perth’s Hale School, served 1931-48. Mervyn Austin, Melbourne Grammar and Oxford classicist and former UWA professor, led 1950-51. Lawrence Pyke, Wesley and Oxford-educated dean of Melbourne graduate studies, headed the school 1952-60. Otago and Columbia mathematician Ernest Duncan, ex-Rutgers professor, served 1962. Rev. Douglas Trathen, Sydney graduate and former Wolaroi head, led 1963-70. Scots College and Sydney alumnus Tony Rae, ex-Albury Grammar head, served 1972-93. Michael Smee, King’s School and Sydney graduate, former Pulteney Grammar head, led 1993-2003. David Scott, with three WA universities, previously head of Kingswood College and Brisbane’s Anglican Church Grammar, served 2003-09. David Mulford, ex-Radford and Blue Mountains Grammar principal, led 2009-18. Since 2019 James Ruse and Sydney graduate Michael Parker, former Oxley head and Cranbrook deputy, has governed the college.

title: Country Senior High Schools Carnival (Western Australia)
intro: Country Week or Country Senior High Schools Carnival is an annual multi-sport event carnival held in Perth, Western Australia between rural high schools from Western Australia. The carnival is organised by School Sport WA. The carnival includes sports such as Australian rules football, hockey, soccer, netball, volleyball and basketball in a range of divisions. Non-sporting competitions in areas such as speech, debating and dance have also been added to the event schedule. Country Week is recognised as being the biggest event of its kind in the southern hemisphere. The event typically involves about 40 schools with around 3,000 students and over 200 teachers and support staff. The carnival is held toward the end of the second school term in late June and early July and lasts for one week. The Amanda Young Foundation has supported the event by donating water bottles to all participating students. The bottles carry messages about the dangers of sharing water bottles to prevent the spread of meningococcal disease. In 2015 the number of participants at the carnival was approximately 3,700, with the RAC sponsoring the event distributing water bottles as part of a road safety campaign, highlighting the over representation of young drivers dying on country roads.
lm_description: In 2005 Bunbury Senior High School won the boys basketball title while Geraldton Senior College claimed both the boys football and boys hockey crowns, and Albany Senior High School took out the boys soccer championship. Geraldton Senior College repeated as basketball victors in 2006, the same year Mandurah Senior College won football, Bunbury Cathedral Grammar School won hockey, and Newton Moore Senior High School won soccer. Australind Senior High School secured both basketball and soccer honours in 2007, with Newton Moore Senior High School winning football and Bunbury Cathedral Grammar School retaining the hockey title. Eastern Goldfields College won the 2008 basketball competition, Pinjarra Senior High School won football, Great Southern Grammar won hockey, and Mandurah Senior College won soccer. Bunbury Senior High School regained the basketball title in 2009, Mandurah Senior College repeated as football champions, Great Southern Grammar kept the hockey crown, and Australind Senior High School again won soccer. Bunbury Senior High School won basketball once more in 2010, Albany Senior High School won football, Great Southern Grammar continued its hockey dominance, and Bunbury Cathedral Grammar School won soccer. Denmark High School won the 2011 basketball title, Albany Senior High School won football, Bunbury Cathedral Grammar School won hockey, and Mandurah Senior College won soccer. Bunbury Senior High School won basketball again in 2012, Albany Senior High School won both football and soccer, and Narrogin Senior High School won hockey. Bunbury Senior High School achieved a triple in 2013, winning basketball, hockey, and soccer, while Newton Moore Senior High School won football. Geraldton Senior College won basketball in 2014, Great Southern Grammar won football, Narrogin Senior High School won hockey, and Albany Senior High School won soccer. Australind Senior High School won basketball in 2015, Newton Moore Senior High School won football, Narrogin Senior High School retained hockey, and Bunbury Cathedral Grammar School won soccer. Busselton Senior High School won the 2016 basketball title, Newton Moore Senior High School won football again, Great Southern Grammar won hockey, and Albany Senior High School won soccer.

title: List of sportspeople educated at the United States Military Academy
intro:
The United States Military Academy (USMA) is an undergraduate college in West Point, New York that educates and commissions officers for the United States Army. The Academy is a member of the Division I Patriot League in most sports, but its men's ice hockey program competes in the Atlantic Hockey league and its football program competes independent of a league. The Academy fields 24 club sports teams. In addition, about 65% of the cadets compete in intramural sports, known at the academy as company athletics. This list is drawn from alumni of the Military Academy who are athletes or athletic coaches. Eleven alumni have competed in the Olympic Games as athletes or coaches. The first was George S. Patton (class of 1909) in the modern pentathlon at the 1912 Summer Olympics. The most recent is Mike Krzyzewski (class of 1969), who was head coach of the U.S. men's basketball team at the 2016 Summer Olympics. Three alumni are recipients of college football's Heisman Trophy: Doc Blanchard (class of 1947), Glenn Davis (class of 1947), and Pete Dawkins (class of 1959). Bob Mischak (class of 1954)
was named No. 7 on NFL.com's list of Top Ten All Time NFL Players from service academies and was a 3x Super Bowl winner. (Note - There are at least 2 others who were on the US Olympic Team Handball squad .
lm_description: Abner Doubleday, class of 1842, became a Civil War major general and the apocryphal inventor of baseball. Guy Henry, 1898, won equestrian bronze at the 1912 Olympics while earning two Army Distinguished Service Medals and the Silver Star across four wars. Paul Bunker, 1903, earned All-America football honors in 1901-02, was retroactively awarded the 1902 Heisman by Sports Illustrated, and entered the College Football Hall of Fame. George S. Patton, 1909, placed fifth in the 1912 Olympic modern pentathlon before commanding armies from North Africa to the Rhine. Elmer Oliphant, 1918, set a world record in the 220-yard low hurdles and starred as one of college football’s greatest players. P.C. Hains, 1924, competed in the 1928 Olympic modern pentathlon after graduating. John Roosma, 1926, became a Basketball Hall of Famer and namesake of West Point’s MVP award. Robin Olds, 1943, flew in World War II and Vietnam, earned the Air Force Cross and four Silver Stars, and joined the College Football Hall of Fame. Doc Blanchard, 1947, won the 1945 Heisman, Maxwell and Sullivan awards as “Mr. Inside.” Glenn Davis, 1947, captured the 1946 Heisman as “Mr. Outside” after the 1944 Maxwell. James Hartinger, 1949, flew in Korea and Vietnam, entered the National Lacrosse Hall of Fame, and inspired the Hartinger Medal for space contributions. Dan Foldberg, 1951, spurned the Detroit Lions to become an infantry colonel after earning All-America honors in football and lacrosse. Bill Carpenter, 1959, earned the Distinguished Service Cross in Vietnam and football immortality as the “Lonesome End.” Pete Dawkins, 1959, uniquely combined Brigade Commander, class president, football captain, top-five academic standing, 1958 Heisman and Maxwell awards, Rhodes Scholarship, Princeton Ph.D., and two Bronze Stars in Vietnam. Ronald Zinn, 1962, placed sixth in the 1964 Olympic racewalk before dying in Vietnam in 1965. Mike Silliman, 1966, captained the 1968 Olympic gold-medal basketball team. Napoleon McCallum, 1985, became a Raiders draft pick. Michael Thornberry, 1994, competed in handball at the 1996 Olympics. Dan Browne, 1997, won the 2002 U.S. Marathon title and raced 10 km and marathon at the 2004 Olympics. Ronnie McAda, 1997, became “Mr. Irrelevant” as the final 1997 NFL draft pick by Green Bay.

title: European Rugby Challenge Cup
intro: The European Rugby Challenge Cup is an annual European rugby union competition organised by European Professional Club Rugby (EPCR). It is the second-tier competition for European clubs behind the European Rugby Champions Cup. From its inception in 1996 to 2014, it was known as the European Challenge Cup and governed by European Rugby Cup (ERC). Following disagreements in the structure of the tournament's format and division of revenue, the English and French leagues withdrew to form the EPCR, which has organized the Challenge Cup and the Champions Cup since the 2014-15 season. The Challenge Cup is contested between 20 teams; 18 qualifying from the three main European domestic leagues (Premiership Rugby, Top 14, and Pro14), and two qualifying from the Continental Shield competition between teams from second-tier level Rugby Europe nations. Clermont are the current Challenge Cup holders, having won the 2018-19 European Rugby Challenge Cup.
lm_description: Clermont and Harlequins each have lifted the European Rugby Challenge Cup three times and finished once as runners-up, with Clermont contesting the Top 14 and Harlequins the Aviva Premiership. Gloucester have twice been champions and twice runners-up in the Aviva Premiership, while fellow English sides Northampton Saints and Sale Sharks each have two titles and no final defeats. Cardiff Blues, representing Pro14, have won twice and never lost a final. Bath have one title and three final losses in the Aviva Premiership, Bourgoin and Stade Français each have one Top 14 title and two final defeats, and Pau have one win and one loss in the Top 14. Biarritz, Colomiers, Montpellier, Leinster and Wasps each have a single title with no runner-up finishes, Leinster competing in Pro14 and Wasps in the Aviva Premiership. Castres and Toulon have each reached two finals without winning in the Top 14, while Agen, Edinburgh and La Rochelle have each been runners-up once, Agen and La Rochelle in the Top 14 and Edinburgh in Pro14.

The Challenge Cup is contested between 20 teams; 18 qualifying from the three main European domestic leagues (Premiership Rugby, Top 14, and Pro14), and two qualifying from the Continental Shield competition between teams from second-tier level Rugby Europe nations. Clermont are the current Challenge Cup holders, having won the 2018-19 European Rugby Challenge Cup.
Clermont and Harlequins each have lifted the European Rugby Challenge Cup three times and finished once as runners-up, with Clermont contesting the Top 14 and Harlequins the Aviva Premiership. Gloucester have twice been champions and twice runners-up in the Aviva Premiership, while fellow English sides Northampton Saints and Sale Sharks each have two titles and no final defeats. Cardiff Blues, representing Pro14, have won twice and never lost a final. Bath have one title and three final losses in the Aviva Premiership, Bourgoin and Stade Français each have one Top 14 title and two final defeats, and Pau have one win and one loss in the Top 14. Biarritz, Colomiers, Montpellier, Leinster and Wasps each have a single title with no runner-up finishes, Leinster competing in Pro14 and Wasps in the Aviva Premiership. Castres and Toulon have each reached two finals without winning in the Top 14, while Agen, Edinburgh and La Rochelle have each been runners-up once, Agen and La Rochelle in the Top 14 and Edinburgh in Pro14.

title: Georgetown Hoyas men's basketball
intro: The Georgetown Hoyas men's basketball program represents Georgetown University in NCAA Division I men's intercollegiate basketball and the Big East Conference. Georgetown has competed in men's college basketball since 1907. The current head coach of the program is Patrick Ewing. Georgetown won the National Championship in 1984 and has made the Final Four on five occasions. They have won the Big East Conference Tournament a record seven times, and have also won or shared the Big East regular season title ten times. They have appeared in the NCAA Tournament thirty times and in the National Invitation Tournament thirteen times. The Hoyas historically have been well regarded not only for their team success, but also for generating players that have succeeded both on and off the court, producing NBA legends such as Patrick Ewing, Dikembe Mutombo, Alonzo Mourning, and Allen Iverson, as well as United States Congressman Henry Hyde and former NFL Commissioner Paul Tagliabue.
lm_description: Allen Iverson became the first overall pick of the 1996 NBA Draft when Philadelphia selected him, while that same year Detroit took Jerome Williams 26th overall and Houston chose Othella Harrington 30th. Two years earlier, Charlotte had drafted Alonzo Mourning second overall in 1992, and Denver selected Dikembe Mutombo fourth overall in 1991. Reggie Williams was the fourth pick in 1987, going to the Los Angeles Clippers. The 1986 draft saw four Hoyas selected: David Wingate 44th to Philadelphia, Michael Jackson 47th to the New York Knicks, Michael Graham 76th to Seattle, and Ralph Dalton 142nd to Cleveland. In 2013, Otto Porter Jr. was chosen third overall by Washington, while Greg Monroe went seventh overall to Detroit in 2010. Roy Hibbert was the 17th pick in 2008, selected by Indiana, and that same year Sacramento chose Patrick Ewing Jr. 42nd overall. Jeff Green was the fifth overall pick in 2007, heading to Boston, while Mike Sweetney was selected ninth overall by the New York Knicks in 2003. DaJuan Summers was the 35th overall pick in 2009, also going to Detroit, and Ruben Boumtje-Boumtje was chosen 50th overall by Portland in 2001. Jahidi White was selected 43rd overall by Washington in 1998, and Don Reid was the 58th overall pick in 1995, going to Detroit.

title: List of web analytics software
intro: This is a list of web analytics software used to collect and display data about visiting website users.
lm_description: Adobe Systems offers Adobe Analytics version 15 and Data Workbench 6.51, both negotiating price and tracking through JavaScript cookies. Microsoft’s Bing Webmaster Tools and Google Analytics are free, with Google also selling a Premium tier at $150,000 annually. AT Internet’s Analyzer, priced by negotiation, and Bango plc’s Bango Mobile Web Analytics at $49 monthly, both rely on JavaScript cookies, though Bango adds mobile ID tracking. WizRocket’s CleverTap, Mixpanel, and SimilarWeb provide free starter tiers plus monthly plans, while LiveChat starts at $36 monthly and StatCounter ranges from free to $119 monthly. Quantcast, Mapmyuser.com, and the discontinued Yahoo! Web Analytics are completely free. Webtrekk Q3 begins at $202 monthly, Woopra scales from free to over $999 monthly, and Webtrends’ price is unlisted; all use JavaScript cookies for tracking.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Traill County, North Dakota
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places listings in Traill County, North Dakota. This is intended to be a complete list of the properties and districts on the National Register of Historic Places in Traill County, North Dakota, United States. The locations of National Register properties and districts for which the latitude and longitude coordinates are included below, may be seen in a map. There are 22 properties and districts listed on the National Register in the county. Another 5 properties were once listed but have been removed.
lm_description: The Caledonia Bridge, listed on 27 February 1997, carries an unnamed county road across the Goose River one mile west of the Minnesota line in Caledonia. Mayville’s Delchar Theater, added 14 November 1985, stands at 20 W. Main St., while the First National Bank next door at 22 W. Main joined the Register five days later; the Goose River Bank at 45 Main St. E. and the Lura Building at 29 W. Main were listed the same day as the theater. The Grinager Mercantile at 37 Main St. E. and the Mayville Historic District—roughly bounded by 3rd St. NE, 5th Ave. NE, Main St. E., and 2nd–3rd Ave. NE—both entered on 19–20 November 1985, as did the Grandins’ Mayville Farm District on 2 Brunsdale W. and the Great Northern Railway Depot on Front St., listed 5 October 1977. Hatton claims the Carl Ben Eielson House at 405 8th St., listed 11 April 1977, and the Andres O. Ness House at Oak Ave. and 6th St., added 15 July 1977. The First State Bank of Buxton, 423 Broadway St., was listed 14 February 1978. Out in the countryside, the Ellingson Farm District sits one mile north and 2.5 miles west of Hillsboro, while Lucken Farm lies north of Portland. The Norway Bridge, like the Caledonia Bridge, spans the Goose River six miles east and three miles south of Mayville, both bridges listed 27 February 1997. Hillsboro’s Amos and Lillie Plummer House at 306 W. Caledonia Ave. was added 4 January 1996, and the Traill County Courthouse at 114 W. Caledonia Ave. on 25 November 1980.

title: Major League Soccer records and statistics
intro: The following is a compilation of notable Major League Soccer records and statistics for teams and players.
lm_description: Ezequiel Barco’s 2018 arrival at Atlanta United from Independiente cost a league-record $15 million, eclipsing the $14 million Atlanta paid River Plate for Pity Martínez the next year. Toronto FC splurged twice in 2014: $11 million to pry Jermain Defoe from Tottenham Hotspur and $10.8 million to bring Michael Bradley from Roma. Clint Dempsey moved from Tottenham to Seattle Sounders FC for $9.3 million in 2013, while Giovani Dos Santos left Villarreal for Los Angeles Galaxy at $8.9 million in 2015. Miguel Almirón joined Atlanta United from Lanús for $8.2 million in 2017, and fellow Lanús alum Lucas Melano headed to Portland Timbers for $6.4 million in 2015, the same fee Seattle later paid Boca Juniors for Nicolás Lodeiro in 2016. Huracán’s Kaku completed the top-ten list when New York Red Bulls secured him for $6.2 million in 2018.

title: Carrier Air Wing Five
intro: Carrier Air Wing Five (CVW-5) is a United States Navy aircraft carrier air wing based at Marine Corps Air Station Iwakuni and Naval Air Facility Atsugi, Japan. The air wing is attached to the aircraft carrier USS Ronald Reagan. It was initially formed in 1943. It has participated in the Second World War, the Korean War, the Gulf War, Operation Southern Watch, the War in Afghanistan, and the War in Iraq. The wing's officially stated mission is 'To conduct carrier air warfare operations and assist in the planning, control, coordination and integration of seven air wing squadrons in support of carrier air warfare including; Interception and destruction of enemy aircraft and missiles in all-weather conditions to establish and maintain local air superiority. All-weather offensive air-to-surface attacks, Detection, localization, and destruction of enemy ships and submarines to establish and maintain local sea control. Aerial photographic, sighting, and electronic intelligence for naval and joint operations. Airborne early warning service to fleet forces and shore warning nets. Airborne electronic countermeasures. In-flight refueling operations to extend the range and the endurance of air wing aircraft and Search and rescue operations.' The fixed-wing squadrons of the air wing transferred to Marine Corps Air Station Iwakuni in Yamaguchi prefecture in 2017 and early 2018.
lm_description: Carrier Air Wing Five fields nine squadrons: VFA-27 Royal Maces, VFA-102 Diamondbacks, VFA-115 Eagles and VFA-195 Dambusters each fly variants of the F/A-18 Super Hornet, with the Royal Maces and both Eagles and Dambusters on single-seat F/A-18Es while the Diamondbacks operate the two-seat F/A-18F. VAW-125 Tiger Tails provide airborne early warning with E-2D Hawkeyes, VAQ-141 Shadowhawks bring electronic attack capability via EA-18G Growlers, and VRC-30 Det. 5 Providers handle carrier onboard delivery using C-2A Greyhounds. Rotary-wing assets are split between HSC-12 Golden Falcons flying MH-60S Seahawks for sea combat support and HSM-77 Saberhawks operating MH-60R Seahawks for maritime strike missions.

title: List of legislative buildings
intro: This is a list of buildings in which legislatures sit.
lm_description: Albania’s 1924 Albanian Parliament Building is slated for replacement, while Andorra only obtained its New Parliament of Andorra in 2014. Austria has legislated from the 1883 Austrian Parliament Building since the late 19th century, and Belarus from the 1934 House of Government. Belgium’s 1783 Palace of the Nation houses both the Chamber of Representatives and the Senate of the Belgian Federal Parliament. Bosnia-Herzegovina’s Parliament Building dates to 1982, Bulgaria’s 1886 National Assembly to the late 19th century, and Croatia’s 1911 Parliament Palace—called Sabor—to the early 20th. The Czech Republic splits its chambers: the Chamber of Deputies occupies the 1726 Thun Palace in Malá Strana, while the Senate meets in the 1630 Wallenstein Palace. Denmark’s Folketing gathers in the 1928 Christiansborg Palace, and Estonia’s Riigikogu in Toompea Castle, whose oldest parts reach back to the early 13th century but whose parliamentary hall was added in 1922. Finland’s 1931 Parliament House, France’s 1728 Palais Bourbon for the National Assembly and 1615 Luxembourg Palace for the Senate, Germany’s 1894 Reichstag for the Bundestag and 1904 House of Lords of Prussia for the Bundesrat, Greece’s 1843 Old Royal Palace for the Hellenic Parliament, Hungary’s 1904 Hungarian Parliament Building, and Iceland’s 1881 Alþingishúsið for the Althing complete the list.

title: List of fictional rodents in literature
intro: This list of fictional rodents in literature is subsidiary to the list of fictional animals and covers all rodents appearing in printed works of literature including beavers, chipmunks, gophers, guinea pigs, marmots, prairie dogs, and porcupines plus the extinct prehistoric species (such as Rugosodon).
lm_description: Stephen Gilbert’s 1968 horror novel Ratman’s Notebooks gives us two rats: Ben, the menacing star who reappears in both Willard films, and the white Socrates, befriended and exploited for evil. Terry Pratchett’s near-blind albino guru Dangerous Beans alone resists Spider’s mind control in The Amazing Maurice and his Educated Rodents, while China Miéville’s fallen monarch King Rat, father of Saul, wages centuries of war with the Piper. Eduard Uspenskiy tucks Lariska, Old Lady Shapoklyak’s purse-dwelling pet, into the Cheburashka tales, and W. H. Beck’s class-pet Malcolm redeems his “menace” reputation by rescuing a kidnapped iguana in Malcolm at Midnight. Frances Hodgson Burnett’s Sara Crewe nicknames the domestic rat Melchisedec her “Bastille rat” during her servitude at Miss Minchin’s Seminary, and Robert C. O’Brien appoints the wise Nicodemus leader of the scientifically enhanced rats of NIMH. Eve Titus pits Basil of Baker Street against the master-criminal Professor Ratigan, Jules Verne sends the heroic Ratine to break the evil magician Gardafour’s spells, and Lynne Jonell gives Emmy the comforting, power-wielding Ratty. Suzanne Collins supplies Ripred, the giant gnawer who commands the rat resistance in The Underland Chronicles, while Beatrix Potter’s Samuel Whiskers and Anna Maria nearly turn Tom Kitten into a roly-poly pudding. J. K. Rowling’s Scabbers lounges in Ron Weasley’s pocket, Louisa May Alcott’s March girls keep the pet rat Scrabble, and E. B. White’s barnyard gourmand Templeton begrudgingly aids Wilbur. Barbara Wersba’s literate Walter courts the like-minded Miss Pomeroy, and Paul Zindel’s white pet Surfer becomes the music-and-dance-loving leader of mutant rats. Finally, Cameron Stelzer renames circus escapee Wentworth Winterbottom as Whisker when he joins Captain Black Rat’s Pie Rat crew aboard the Apple Pie.

title: Offshoring Research Network
intro: The Offshoring Research Network is an international network of researchers and practitioners studying organizations in their transition to globalizing their business functions, processes and administrative services. The ORN conducts annual surveys tracking global sourcing strategies, drivers, concrete implementations and plans across all business functions and processes. The ORN is managed by Duke University, The Fuqua School of Business, Center for International Business Education and Research (CIBER). It involves partner universities in Europe, Asia and Australia. The ORN has over 3,000 corporate participants across all industries from all over the world. Based on annual surveys, the ORN research team maintains a comprehensive database of firms and governmental organizations and their implemented and planned offshore sourcing projects over time. In addition, the ORN research team collects data on service providers offering offshore services. Offshoring, according to the ORN, refers to the process of sourcing business functions or processes supporting home-based or global operations from a foreign country, either through wholly owned organizational units (captive offshoring/shared services) or external service providers (offshore outsourcing). The ORN project captures a wide range of business functions and processes, such as information technology (IT), finance & accounting, contact centers, human resources, legal services (LPO), analytical and knowledge services (KPO), software development, procurement, marketing and sales, engineering and new product development. The ORN studies do not cover offshoring of manufacturing activities, nor do they capture outsourcing or shared services activities onshore/domestically. Based on their research, ORN partners have published a number of academic and practitioner-oriented articles. In addition, the ORN has completed various research projects as well as case studies; organized academic and practitioner-oriented workshops and webcasts; delivered executive education programs and completed commissioned studies for corporate members of the ORN.
lm_description: Duke University’s Fuqua School of Business launched the Offshoring Research Network in 2004, with Prof. Arie Y. Lewin leading a sequence of colleagues: Dr. Carine Peeters through 2006, Dr. Stephan Manning until 2009, and Dr. Nidthida Perm-Ajchariyawong from 2008 onward. The United Kingdom joined in 2005 when Prof. Silvia Massini brought the University of Manchester’s Manchester Business School into the consortium. A four-school European wave followed in 2006: Copenhagen Business School’s Center for Strategic Management and Globalization added Profs. Torben Pedersen and Bent Petersen; Rotterdam School of Management at Erasmus University enlisted Prof. Henk Volberda; Solvay Brussels School (ULB) welcomed back Prof. Carine Peeters; IESE Business School at the University of Navarra placed Prof. Joan E. Ricart on the team; and Germany’s WHU – Otto Beisheim School of Management installed Prof. Thomas Hutzschenreuter. Australia entered in 2008 through a joint venture between the University of Newcastle’s Business School and the University of Western Sydney’s Centre for Industry and Innovation Studies, represented by Profs. Stephen Chen and Oscar Hauptman. France’s EMLYON Business School, South Korea’s Kyung Hee University, and the University of Tokyo all completed the roster in 2010, respectively under Profs. Christiane Prange, Geon-Cheol Shin, and the duo of Takahiro Fujimoto and Youngwon Park.

title: List of cities, towns and villages in Solomon Islands
intro: This is a list of populated places in the nation state of Solomon Islands, it excludes areas within the Solomon Islands archipelago that fall under a different jurisdiction, such as Bougainville.
lm_description: Honiara, the capital, counted 49,107 residents on Guadalcanal in 1999, dwarfing Auki’s 4,022 on Malaita and Gizo’s 5,323 on Ghizo Island in Western Province. Buala on Santa Isabel held 2,438 people, while fellow Isabel village Kamaosi lacked a census figure. Kirakira on Makira tallied 979 inhabitants, and tiny Maniora on the same island recorded only 100. On New Georgia, Noro registered 3,482, whereas Munda’s count was unavailable. Taro Island settlement reported 440 residents within Choiseul Province. Far southeast, Lata on Nendo Island and Tigoa on Rennell Island both lacked 1999 data, the latter lying in Rennell and Bellona Province. Off Guadalcanal’s north coast, Tulagi Island’s town counted 1,333 people under Central Province.
to_index_text:
List of cities, towns and villages in Solomon Islands
This is a list of populated places in the nation state of Solomon Islands, it excludes areas within the Solomon Islands archipelago that fall under a different jurisdiction, such as Bougainville.
Honiara, the capital, counted 49,107 residents on Guadalcanal in 1999, dwarfing Auki’s 4,022 on Malaita and Gizo’s 5,323 on Ghizo Island in Western Province. Buala on Santa Isabel held 2,438 people, while fellow Isabel village Kamaosi lacked a census figure. Kirakira on Makira tallied 979 inhabitants, and tiny Maniora on the same island recorded only 100. On New Georgia, Noro registered 3,482, whereas Munda’s count was unavailable. Taro Island settlement reported 440 residents within Choiseul Province. Far southeast, Lata on Nendo Island and Tigoa on Rennell Island both lacked 1999 data, the latter lying in Rennell and Bellona Province. Off Guadalcanal’s north coast, Tulagi Island’s town counted 1,333 people under Central Province.

title: List of NFL franchise post-season droughts
intro: This is a list of current National Football League (NFL) franchise post-season and Super Bowl droughts (multiple consecutive seasons of not winning). Listed here are both appearance droughts and winning droughts in almost every level of the NFL playoff system. As of the 2018 NFL season, every active NFL team has qualified for and won a game in the playoffs. Teams that have never made it beyond each successive milestone are listed under the year in which they began NFL play. Of the 12 teams that have never won the Super Bowl, four (4) are expansion franchises younger than the Super Bowl itself (Bengals, Panthers, Jaguars, and the Texans). The Falcons began playing during the season in which the Super Bowl was first played. The seven (7) other clubs (Cardinals, Lions, Oilers/Titans, Chargers, Browns, Bills, and Vikings) all won an NFL or AFL championship prior to the AFL-NFL merger; in the case of the Vikings, however, the Super Bowl existed at the time they won their league title, leaving them and the Falcons as the only two teams to have existed for as long as or longer than the Super Bowl that have never secured the highest championship available to them. The longest drought since a championship of any kind is that of the Cardinals, at 72 seasons. Note that for continuity purposes, the Cleveland Browns are officially considered to have suspended operations for the 1996, 1997, and 1998 seasons. Since returning 21 years ago, they have only made the playoffs once, while the Baltimore Ravens are considered to be a separate team that began play in 1996. The Ravens, as a result of the Cleveland Browns relocation controversy, absorbed the Browns' personnel upon their suspension, but not their history.
lm_description: The Cleveland Browns have gone 27 seasons since their last AFC Central crown in 1989, the longest active title drought. Detroit’s Lions have waited 26 seasons since topping the NFC Central in 1993, while the Buffalo Bills have spent 24 seasons chasing another AFC East flag after 1995. The Las Vegas Raiders and New York Jets share a 17-season gap since each last ruled the AFC West and AFC East, respectively, in 2002. Tampa Bay has endured 12 seasons without an NFC South title since 2007, and both Miami and Tennessee have 11-season waits after 2008 AFC East and AFC South triumphs. The Los Angeles Chargers have gone a decade without an AFC West crown after 2009, and the New York Giants have faced eight seasons of NFC East frustration since 2011. Indianapolis last seized the AFC South in 2014, putting its drought at five seasons, while Arizona, Carolina, Cincinnati, Denver and Washington all stand four seasons removed from 2015 division titles in the NFC West, NFC South, AFC North, AFC West and NFC East. Seattle and Atlanta have three-season gaps since 2016 NFC West and NFC South wins, and both Pittsburgh and Jacksonville have waited only two seasons since 2017 AFC North and AFC South championships.

title: List of caves in Italy
intro: The following article shows a list of caves in Italy.
lm_description: Addaura cave rises 70 m above sea level in Palermo, Sicily, while the Ear of Dionysius, also in Syracuse, Sicily, reaches 400 m and extends only 65 m. Along the Ligurian coast, Arene Candide sits at 90 m in Finale Ligure and Borgio Verezzi cave at 200 m in its namesake village. Tuscany hosts Antro del Corchia at 600 m in Stazzema, Giusti cave 200 m long at 570 m in Monsummano Terme, and Maona, likewise 200 m, at 255 m in Montecatini Terme. Trentino-Alto Adide’s Grotto Calgeron lies at 400 m in Grigno, the Blue Grotto opens at sea level off Anacapri in Campania, and Castelcivita cave stretches 3 km beneath 94 m in Campania’s Castelcivte, mirrored by Castellana’s 3 km at 290 m in Apulia. Sardinia offers Bue Marino and Is Zuddas at sea level in Dorgali and Santadi, Ispinigoli perched at 1,300 m in Dorgali, and Neptune cave at 5 m in Alghero. Abruzzo’s Cavallone cave runs 1 km at 1,300 m between Lama dei Peligni and Taranta Peligna, Sicily’s Gelo cave crowns 2,043 m in Randazzo, Lauro cave sits at 1,068 m in Alcara li Fusi, while Marche’s Frasassi system winds 5 km at 300 m in Genga and Friuli’s Giant cave measures 280 m at 265 m in Sgonico.

title: NYPD Blue (season 2)
intro: The second season of NYPD Blue, an American television police drama set in New York City, aired as part of the 1994-95 United States network television schedule for ABC, premiering on October 11, 1994 and concluding on May 23, 1995. The show explores the internal and external struggles of the fictional 15th precinct of Manhattan. Each episode typically intertwines several plots involving an ensemble cast. The season earned three Primetime Emmy Awards, one for Outstanding Drama Series, another for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Drama Series (Shirley Knight), and a Creative Arts Emmy for its casting. The show received an additional 10 nominations.
lm_description: David Caruso led the first four episodes as Detective John Kelly before departing, after which Jimmy Smits stepped in as Bobby Simone for the remainder of the season. Dennis Franz anchored every episode as the grizzled Andy Sipowicz, supported throughout by James McDaniel’s Lieutenant Arthur Fancy, Nicholas Turturro’s Officer James Martinez, Sharon Lawrence’s Assistant District Attorney Sylvia Costas, Gordon Clapp’s Detective Greg Medavoy, and Gail O’Grady’s civilian aide Donna Abandando. Amy Brenneman appeared only in the first two episodes as Janice Licalsi, while Justine Miceli’s Detective Adrienne Lesniak recurred sporadically from episode 3 through the finale. Kim Delaney entered late as Detective Diane Russell, recurring from episode 19 to 22, and Bill Brochtrup’s administrative aide John Irvin did the same from episode 17 onward.
to_index_text:
NYPD Blue (season 2)

The show received an additional 10 nominations.
David Caruso led the first four episodes as Detective John Kelly before departing, after which Jimmy Smits stepped in as Bobby Simone for the remainder of the season. Dennis Franz anchored every episode as the grizzled Andy Sipowicz, supported throughout by James McDaniel’s Lieutenant Arthur Fancy, Nicholas Turturro’s Officer James Martinez, Sharon Lawrence’s Assistant District Attorney Sylvia Costas, Gordon Clapp’s Detective Greg Medavoy, and Gail O’Grady’s civilian aide Donna Abandando. Amy Brenneman appeared only in the first two episodes as Janice Licalsi, while Justine Miceli’s Detective Adrienne Lesniak recurred sporadically from episode 3 through the finale. title: List of winners of the Boston Marathon
intro: The Boston Marathon is an annual marathon held in the Greater Boston area in Massachusetts. The event is held on Patriots' Day, the third Monday of April. The Boston Marathon has been held annually since 1897 and is the oldest annual marathon in the world.
lm_description: Robert Hall of Massachusetts won the 1975 Boston Marathon in 2:58:00 and repeated in 1977 with a 2:40:10 finish. After no official result in 1976, George Murray from Florida took 1978 in 2:26:57 and returned in 1985 to lower the clock to 1:45:34. Ken Archer of Ohio claimed 1979 in 2:38:59, while Curt Brinkman of Utah set 1:55:00 in 1980 and Jim Martinson of Washington 2:00:41 in 1981. California’s Jim Knaub began a streak, winning 1982 in 1:51:31, improving to 1:47:10 for his second title in 1983, adding a third in 1991 at 1:30:44, a fourth in 1992 at 1:26:28, and a fifth in 1993 at 1:22:17. Canada’s André Viger interrupted with victories in 1984 (2:05:20), 1986 (1:43:25), and 1987 (1:55:42). France’s Mustapha Badid triumphed in 1988 at 1:43:19 and again in 1990 at 1:29:53, while fellow Frenchman Philippe Couprie set 1:36:04 in 1989. Switzerland’s Heinz Frei closed the span in 1994 at 1:21:23.

title: Disney Sing It: Pop Hits
intro: Disney Sing It: Pop Hits is a karaoke video game and sequel to High School Musical: Sing It!, Disney Sing It and Disney Sing It! - High School Musical 3: Senior Year. It was released on October 6, 2009 across multiple platforms. Unlike the previous two releases in the Sing It series, Pop Hits does not feature an Xbox 360 release. New features to the game include a new score system, an upgraded version of Sing It Pro, playback performances through Sing It Encore, or Run The Risk which allows players to outbid each other's scores.
lm_description: Miley Cyrus dominates the Disney Sing It: Pop Hits tracklist with four of her songs—7 Things from 2008, plus Fly on the Wall, The Climb and Hoedown Throwdown all issued in 2009—each stamped with Disney affiliation. Demi Lovato follows with three Disney-branded entries: Get Back and La La Land from 2008 and the 2009 single Don’t Forget. The Jonas Brothers contribute five Disney-affiliated cuts spanning 2007 to 2008—Hold On, SOS, When You Look Me In The Eyes, Lovebug and Burnin’ Up. Vanessa Hudgens adds her 2008 Disney-tied Sneakernight, while non-Disney voices include Colbie Caillat’s 2008 Realize and 2007 Bubbly, Jesse McCartney’s 2008 It’s Over (marked US exclusive) and 2009 How Do You Sleep, Taylor Swift’s 2006 I’m Only Me When I’m With You and 2008 Change, plus OneRepublic’s 2006 Apologize; none of these carry Disney affiliation, regional locks or release-year clustering.

title: Tungurahua Province
intro: Tungurahua (Spanish: Provincia del Tungurahua, literally Province of the Tungurahua; pronounced [tuŋɡuˈɾawa]) is one of the twenty-four provinces of Ecuador. Its capital is Ambato. The province takes its name from the Tungurahua volcano, which is located within the boundaries of the provinces.
lm_description: Ambato, the provincial capital, dominates Tungurahua with 387,282 inhabitants spread across 1,009 km². Baños de Agua Santa, better known simply as Baños, holds 19,112 residents within 1,065 km². Cevallos, the smallest canton at only 19 km², shelters 8,873 people, while neighboring Mocha covers 86 km² for its 8,371 inhabitants. Patate’s 16,771 residents occupy 315 km², and Pelileo (San Pedro de Pelileo) rises to 58,988 people across 202 km². Píllaro (Santiago de Píllaro) contains 44,925 inhabitants within 443 km², Quero (Santiago de Quero) has 23,187 residents in 173 km², and Tisaleo’s 14,525 citizens live on 59 km².

title: 1971 International Cross Country Championships
intro:
The 1971 International Cross Country Championships was held in San Sebastián, Spain, at the Lasarte Hippodrome on March 20, 1971. A report on the event was given in the Glasgow Herald. Complete results for men, junior men, women, medallists, 
 and the results of British athletes were published.
lm_description: England’s sextet of Dave Bedford, Trevor Wright, Peter Standing, Tony Simmons, Frank Briscoe and Andy Holden dominated the 1971 International Cross Country Championships with a commanding 56-point victory. Belgium followed 120 points adrift as Gaston Roelants, René Goris, Willy Polleunis, Karel Lismont, Eddy van Butsele and Paul Thijs totaled 176. France took third on 186 points from Noel Tijou, Lucien Rault, Antoine Borowski, Michel Bernard, Jean-Yves Le Flohic and Jean-Pierre Dufresne. New Zealand’s Eddie Gray, Rod Dixon, Bryan Rose, Rex Maddaford, John Sheddan and Martin Simmons amassed 194 for fourth, while Spain’s Javier Álvarez, Mariano Haro, Juan Hidalgo, Julio Gude, Ramon Tasende and Fernando Aguilar scored 198 for fifth. Morocco’s Lahcen El Hachmi, Moha Aït Bassou, Miloud Chenna, Haddou Jaddour, Ben Assou El Ghazi and Moumoh Haddou earned 215, just ahead of Scotland’s Ian Stewart, Dick Wedlock, Norman Morrison, Jim Alder, Alistair Blamire and Lachie Stewart on 216. Finland, Wales, Poland, Ireland, Switzerland, Italy, Algeria and Northern Ireland completed the field with totals of 229, 293, 362, 392, 462, 521, 557 and 636 respectively.

title: Uzbekistan Super League
intro: Uzbekistan Super League (Uzbek: O'zbekiston Superligasi / Ўзбекистон Суперлигаси), also called Coca-Cola Uzbekistan Super League (Uzbek: Coca-Cola O'zbekiston Superligasi / Coca-Cola Ўзбекистон Суперлигаси) due to sponsorship by Coca-Cola, is the top division of football in Uzbekistan, and is operated under the auspices of the Uzbekistan Professional Football League and Uzbekistan Football Association. It was founded in 1992 and is participate by 14 teams (since 2019). The top three teams get a chance to compete in the AFC Champions League, while the one last ranked teams are relegated to the Uzbekistan Pro League.
lm_description: Mirjalol Qosimov’s AGMK of Olmaliq plays at the 12,000-seat AGMK Stadium wearing Joma kits, while Ildar Sakaev’s Andijan side fills Soglom Avlod’s 18,360 places in Adidas. Vadim Abramov’s Bunyodkor, the capital’s Nike-clad giant, hosts 34,000 at Bunyodkor Stadium, dwarfing Andrey Fyodorov’s Lokomotiv who occupy only 8,000 at Lokomotiv Stadium across town. Bakhtiyar Ashurmatov’s Bukhoro packs 22,700 into Bukhara Arena in Joma, and Numon Hasanov’s Kokand 1912 outfits 10,500 Adidas fans at Kokand Stadium. In Bekabad, Andrey Shipilov’s Metallurg commands 15,000 at Metallurg Stadium in Adidas, while Ruziqul Berdiyev’s Nasaf fills Qarshi Markazi’s 16,000 in the same brand. Andrei Kanchelskis guides Navbahor from Namangan’s 22,000-seat Namangan Markazi Stadium in Adidas, and Shota Arveladze’s record-holding Pakhtakor fills the league’s largest ground, 35,000-seat Pakhtakor Stadium, also in Adidas. Sergey Lushan’s Sogdiana of Jizzakh wears Nike while hosting 11,650 at Soghdiana Stadium; Hamidjon Aktamov’s Qizilqum outfits 12,500 Adidas supporters at Zarafshan’s Progress Stadium. Davron Fayziev’s Dinamo Samarqand plays in Joma before 13,800 at Dinamo Stadium, and Andrei Miklyaev’s Surkhon, the league’s smallest, welcomes 6,000 to Termez’s Alpamish stadium in Adidas.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in New Rochelle, New York
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places entries in New Rochelle, New York. See also National Register of Historic Places listings in Westchester County, New York for all others in the county.
lm_description: Davenport House at 157 Davenport Road entered the National Register on 30 April 1980, followed on 7 September 1979 by the paired landmark of First Presbyterian Church and Lewis Pintard House fronting Pintard Avenue. The Knickerbocker Press Building, 50-52 Webster Avenue, gained recognition 11 May 2000, while Leland Castle, 29 Castle Place, had already been listed 27 August 1976. Nearby, the Lispenard-Rodman-Davenport House, 180 Davenport Avenue, was added 22 September 1986. New Rochelle Railroad Station, standing between North Avenue and Memorial Highway, joined the register 14 October 2009, and the 20 Sicard Avenue home of Thomas Paine Cottage had been honored since 28 November 1972. Pioneer Building, 14 Lawton Street, was designated 29 December 1983, and the leafy streets of Rochelle Park-Rochelle Heights Historic District—The Circle, The Boulevard, The Serpentine, Hamilton Avenue—were collectively listed 6 July 2005. Trinity-St. Paul’s Episcopal Church, 311 Huguenot Street, followed a year later on 12 July 2006. The city’s main post office at 255 North Avenue was entered 11 May 1989, and the cliff-side mansion Wildcliff, 42 Wildcliff Road, rounded out the roster on 31 December 2002.
to_index_text:

Nearby, the Lispenard-Rodman-Davenport House, 180 Davenport Avenue, was added 22 September 1986. New Rochelle Railroad Station, standing between North Avenue and Memorial Highway, joined the register 14 October 2009, and the 20 Sicard Avenue home of Thomas Paine Cottage had been honored since 28 November 1972. Pioneer Building, 14 Lawton Street, was designated 29 December 1983, and the leafy streets of Rochelle Park-Rochelle Heights Historic District—The Circle, The Boulevard, The Serpentine, Hamilton Avenue—were collectively listed 6 July 2005. Trinity-St. Paul’s Episcopal Church, 311 Huguenot Street, followed a year later on 12 July 2006. The city’s main post office at 255 North Avenue was entered 11 May 1989, and the cliff-side mansion Wildcliff, 42 Wildcliff Road, rounded out the roster on 31 December 2002.

title: List of films and television shows set or shot in Liverpool
intro: The city of Liverpool, England, is a popular location for the filming and setting of films and television series, both fictional and real. The following article provides a list of films and television shows which have been partially or wholly set in or shot in Liverpool. The list includes a wide array of films and TV shows, ranging from those that were almost entirely shot and set in the city (e.g. The 51st State, Brookside) to those where only a small number of scenes were set or shot in Liverpool (e.g. Across the Universe). Media is an important component of Liverpool's economy and in 2019 brought over £17.6m into the local area, with 324 productions racking up 1,750 production days. After London, it is the most filmed city in the United Kingdom. The Liverpool Film Office, founded in 1989, was the first of its kind in the United Kingdom and along with North West Vision and Media and the UK Film Council acts to promote the city to film and television producers. In addition to attracting outside producers, Liverpool is also home to Lime Pictures, the UK's largest independent television production company. Liverpool's rich architectural base means it is frequently used as a double for major cities across the globe, including Chicago, London, Moscow, New York, Paris and Rome. It is also able to utilise a large number of historic sites within the city that are openly available for filming, including the now decommissioned courtrooms of St. George's Hall, or the nineteenth century warehouses around Stanley Dock.
lm_description: Mitchell and Kenyon’s 1901 The Arrest of Goudie, arguably the world’s first filmed crime reconstruction, was shot in Liverpool, while the 1965 musical Ferry ’Cross the Mersey brought Gerry & The Pacemakers to the city. Albert Finney’s 1971 dark comedy Gumshoe follows a would-be private eye through Liverpool streets, and Educating Rita, though filmed in Dublin, sets its story there in 1983. Coast to Coast, a 1987 comedy thriller starring Lenny Henry, was both set and shot in Liverpool the same year as Business as Usual and The Dressmaker, with Distant Voices, Still Lives following in 1988 alongside the British thriller The Fruit Machine, likewise set and filmed in the city. Dancin’ Thru the Dark appeared in 1990, the same year as Hear My Song, a drama about tenor Josef Locke that used Liverpool for part of its setting and filming. Blood on the Dole and Dark Summer both date from 1994, Dockers from 1999, Going Off Big Time—a gangster tale shot in and around Liverpool—from 2000, Digital Reaper from 2004, Dead Man’s Cards from 2006, and Charlie Noades R.I.P., a 2009 comedy, rounds out the list, with the BBC and WGBH’s 1999 David Copperfield also filming there.
