title: List of number-one albums of 2009 (Australia)
intro: The highest-selling albums in Australia are ranked in the Australian Recording Industry Association albums chart, also known as the ARIA Charts, published by the Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA). The data are compiled from a sample that includes music stores, music departments at electronics and department stores, and Internet sales (in other words, both digital as well as CD sales). ARIA also issues a weekly singles chart. In addition, data from these weekly charts are used to compile an end of year albums and singles chart. Alternative rock band Kings of Leon's Only by the Night had the longest non-consecutive run among the releases that reached peak position in 2009; it spent 14 non-consecutive weeks atop the chart, beginning in the 2008 chart year and continuing until 13 April, with a break between 16 February and 23 March. The Essential Michael Jackson by Michael Jackson, and I Dreamed a Dream by Susan Boyle had the longest consecutive run atop the chart, spending 7 weeks each at number one. In total, there were 19 number one albums during 2009. During 2009, six acts received their first Australian number one album, these being Lily Allen, Natalie Bassingthwaighte, Paramore, Ronan Keating, Short Stack and Susan Boyle. I Dreamed a Dream, which debuted at number one on 30 November, was 2009's highest selling album on the ARIA end-of-year albums chart, ahead of Pink's album Funhouse.
lm_description: Kings of Leon’s Only by the Night opened 2009 at number one, holding the top spot through 13 January, 19 January, 26 January, 2 February and 9 February, then returned for 23 March, 30 March, 6 April and 13 April after Lily Allen’s It’s Not Me, It’s You interrupted for 16 and 23 February and Natalie Bassingthwaighte’s 1000 Stars led on 2 March, while U2’s No Line on the Horizon ruled 9 and 16 March. Allen reclaimed the summit on 20 April. Ronan Keating’s Songs for My Mother then dominated 27 April, 4 May, 11 May and 18 May, followed by Eminem’s Relapse on 25 May and 1 June. Eskimo Joe’s Inshalla topped 8 June, The Black Eyed Peas’ The E.N.D. 15 June, Hilltop Hoods’ State of the Art 22 and 29 June. Michael Jackson’s posthumous The Essential Michael Jackson reigned for seven straight weeks from 6 July to 17 August. Short Stack’s Stack Is the New Black peaked 24 August, The E.N.D. returned 30 August, Jimmy Barnes’ The Rhythm and the Blues led 7 and 14 September, Muse’s The Resistance 21 September, Pearl Jam’s Backspacer 28 September, Paramore’s Brand New Eyes 5 October, The E.N.D. again 12 October, and Michael Bublé’s Crazy Love closed the survey period atop the chart on 19, 26 October and 2 November.

title: List of Michelin 3-star restaurants
intro: Michelin stars are a rating system used by the red Michelin Guide to grade restaurants on their quality. The guide was originally developed in 1900 to show French drivers where local amenities such as restaurants and mechanics were. The rating system was first introduced in 1926 as a single star, with the second and third stars introduced in 1933. According to the Guide, one star signifies a very good restaurant, two stars are excellent cooking that is worth a detour, and three stars mean exceptional cuisine that is worth a special journey. The listing of starred restaurants is updated once a year.
lm_description: Barcelona hosts two Michelin 3-star temples: Lasarte, where Martín Berasategui and Paolo Casagrande have held the accolade since 2016, and ABaC, placed under Jordi Cruz since 2018. Down the Mediterranean coast, Quique Dacosta’s eponymous Dénia restaurant has commanded three stars since 2012, while Ángel León’s Aponiente in El Puerto de Santa María joined the elite in 2018. Girona’s El Celler de Can Roca, headed by Joan Roca, has been a three-star destination since 2009, and nearby Larrabetzu’s Azurmendi, led by Eneko Atxa, followed in 2013. In the Basque town of Lasarte-Oria, Martín Berasategui’s flagship restaurant has enjoyed the guide’s highest honour continuously since 2001. Madrid’s only 3-star establishment, DiverXO, belongs to David Muñoz, awarded in 2014. San Sebastián claims two longstanding laureates: Arzak, where Juan Mari Arzak and daughter Elena have kept the rating since 1989, and Akelare, under Pedro Subijana, promoted in 2015. The newest Spanish entry is El Cenador de Amós in Villaverde de Pontones, where Jesús Sánchez earned his third star in 2020.

title: WD postcode area
intro: The WD postcode area, also known as the Watford postcode area, is a group of eleven postcode districts in England, within seven post towns. These cover south-west Hertfordshire, plus very small parts of Buckinghamshire and Greater London. Mail for this area is sorted at the Home Counties North Mail Centre in Hemel Hempstead, having been sorted at the Watford Mail Centre until its closure in 2011. The area covered includes all of the borough of Watford, most of the Three Rivers district, the western part of the Hertsmere district and small parts of the Dacorum and St Albans districts. WD3 also covers the village of Chenies in the Chiltern district of Buckinghamshire, plus a small protrusion of Harefield in the London Borough of Hillingdon.
lm_description: Rickmansworth’s WD3 district blankets Rickmansworth, Chorleywood, Croxley Green, Loudwater, Mill End, Maple Cross, Sarratt, Batchworth, Chenies, West Hyde, Heronsgate and Chandler’s Cross, with spill-overs into part of Harefield, falling under Three Rivers, Chiltern and Hillingdon councils. Kings Langley’s WD4 covers Kings Langley, Chipperfield, Hunton Bridge, Rucklers Lane and Bucks Hill, split between Dacorum and Three Rivers. Abbots Langley’s WD5 serves Abbots Langley and Bedmond, straddling Three Rivers and St Albans. Borehamwood’s WD6 encompasses Borehamwood, Elstree and Well End within Hertsmere. Radlett’s WD7 includes Radlett and Shenley, shared by Hertsmere and St Albans. Watford town centre, Cassiobury and Nascot Wood lie in WD17, West Watford and Holywell in WD18, Oxhey, South Oxhey and Carpenders Park in WD19, North Watford in WD24, while WD25 stretches across Garston, Leavesden, Aldenham and Letchmore Heath, touching Watford, Hertsmere, Three Rivers and St Albans. Bushey’s WD23 covers Bushey and Bushey Heath, split between Hertsmere and Watford. A non-geographic WD99 code is reserved for the Watford Jobcentre Plus.

title: 10,000 metres world record progression
intro: The official world records in the 10,000 metres are held by Kenenisa Bekele with 26:17.53 minutes for men and Almaz Ayana from Ethiopia with 29:17.45 minutes for women. The first world record in the men's 10,000 metres was recognized by the International Association of Athletics Federations in 1912. The first ratified record, Jean Bouin's time of 30:58.8 minutes, had been run the year before. As of June 21, 2009, 37 men's world records have been ratified by the IAAF in the event. The first world record in the women's 10,000 metres was recognized by the International Association of Athletics Federations in 1981. As of June 21, 2009, eight women's world records have been ratified by the IAAF in the event. Before the event was recognised by the IAAF as an official world record event the 3000 metres was the most common international women's long-distance track event, although women did sometimes compete over 10,000 m before its addition to the World Championships and Olympic programme in 1987 and 1988, respectively.
lm_description: Gertrud Schmidt opened 1966 with 39:25.0, only to be overtaken weeks later by compatriot Hannelore Middeke’s 39:10.0. Ann O’Brien trimmed the Irish mark to 38:06.4 on 26 March 1967 in Gormanstown. Paola Pigni sliced over two minutes off in Milan on 9 May 1970, stopping the clock at 35:30.5. Kathy Gibbons lowered the U.S. record to 34:51.0 in Phoenix on 12 June 1971, before Julie Brown edged back to 35:00.4 in Los Angeles on 29 March 1975. Christa Vahlensieck then pushed the West German best to 34:01.4 in Wolfsburg on 20 August 1975. Loa Olafsson first brought Denmark into the spotlight with 33:34.2 in Hvidovre on 19 March 1977, only for Peg Neppel to take the U.S. record to 33:15.09 in Los Angeles on 9 June 1977. Natalia Mărăşescu raised the Romanian standard to 32:43.2 at Băile Felix on 22 January 1978, yet Olafsson reclaimed the Danish mark at 32:45.40 in Copenhagen on 6 April 1978. Olga Krentser closed the pre-IAAF era at 32:30.80 in Moscow on 7 August 1981.

title: David Zucker (director)
intro: David S. Zucker (born October 16, 1947) is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter. Associated mostly with parody comedies, Zucker is recognized as the director and writer of the critically successful 1980 film Airplane! as well as being the creator of The Naked Gun franchise and for directing Scary Movie 3 and Scary Movie 4.
lm_description: Anthony Anderson, Anna Faris, Regina Hall, Kevin Hart, Edward Moss, Leslie Nielsen, Simon Rex and Charlie Sheen all appear in neither Scary Movie 3 nor Scary Movie 4. Carmen Electra and Bill Pullman are absent from Scary Movie 4, while Michael Madsen and Molly Shannon likewise do not appear in that installment. Jenny McCarthy is not in Scary Movie 3.

title: 2004 World Sports Acrobatics Championships
intro: 19th World Sports Acrobatics Championships were held in Liévin, France from May 21 to May 23, 2004.
lm_description: Ekaterina Stroynova, Ekaterina Loginova and Gouzel Khassanova topped the 2004 World Sports Acrobatics Championships in Liévin with 22.420 points for Russia. Jessica Stamenovic, Tara Bushbridge and Veronica Gravolin took second place for Australia on 19.670, just 0.040 ahead of Danielle Heider, Samantha Schabow and Jennifer Da Silva who claimed third for the United States with 19.630. Fourth place went to Olexandra Gorkovenko, Alla Basiuk and Larisa Semeniuk of Ukraine on 19.210, while another Russian squad—Elena Kirilova, Elena Moiseeva and Tatiana Alexeeva—ranked fifth with 18.990. Kazakhstan’s Gaukhar Ahmetova, Alexandra Yenina and Aigul Dukenbayeva scored 18.910 for sixth, Great Britain’s Yvonne Weish, Stefanie Akroyd and Victoria Pattison posted 18.810 for seventh, and Germany’s Sophie Schwassmann, Susanne Schaeffer and Natalia Arent closed the top eight on 17.610.

title: United Kingdom by-election records
intro: This is an annotated list of notable records from Parliamentary by-elections in the United Kingdom. A by-election occurs when a Member of Parliament (MP) vacates a House of Commons seat (due to resignation, death, disqualification or expulsion) during the course of a parliament.
lm_description: Bill Boaks, standing for the Public Safety Democratic Monarchist White Resident label, polled just 5 votes in the 1982 Glasgow Hillhead by-election, a tally matched by Smiley Smilie running as an Independent in 2016 Tooting, Bobby Smith with no description in 2019 Peterborough, and Kailash Trivedi of the Independent Janata Party in the 1988 Kensington contest. John Connell, campaigning under the banner “Peace – stop ITN manipulation,” received 7 votes in 1984 Chesterfield. Esmond Bevan, describing himself as Systems Designer, secured 8 votes in the 1983 Bermondsey by-election, the same figure achieved by Independents Tony Farnon and Norman Scarth in 2008 Haltemprice and Howden. Bobby Smith doubled his appearance with 9 votes in 2016 Tooting, this time listed for Bring Back Elmo.
to_index_text:
United Kingdom by-election records

Bill Boaks, standing for the Public Safety Democratic Monarchist White Resident label, polled just 5 votes in the 1982 Glasgow Hillhead by-election, a tally matched by Smiley Smilie running as an Independent in 2016 Tooting, Bobby Smith with no description in 2019 Peterborough, and Kailash Trivedi of the Independent Janata Party in the 1988 Kensington contest. John Connell, campaigning under the banner “Peace – stop ITN manipulation,” received 7 votes in 1984 Chesterfield. Esmond Bevan, describing himself as Systems Designer, secured 8 votes in the 1983 Bermondsey by-election, the same figure achieved by Independents Tony Farnon and Norman Scarth in 2008 Haltemprice and Howden. Bobby Smith doubled his appearance with 9 votes in 2016 Tooting, this time listed for Bring Back Elmo.

title: List of BBC properties
intro: The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) occupies many properties in the United Kingdom, and occupied many other in previous years. The headquarters of the corporation is Broadcasting House in London; with many other divisions located in London and around the UK. Since 2007 the BBC has been developing a significant base at MediaCityUK in Salford, to which it has relocated several departments. There are also production bases in Belfast, Birmingham, Bristol, Cardiff and Glasgow. The BBC also owns news bureaux and relay stations outside the UK.
lm_description: BBC Park Western in Acton doubles as the production base for Silent Witness and the hub of BBC Newsgathering Operations handling outside broadcasts, while the BBC Elstree Centre in Borehamwood serves as a dedicated studio centre. On Great Portland Street, BBC Great Portland Street houses the BBC Trust, next-door Wogan House—once called Western House—and Yalding House, formerly the home of BBC Radio 1 and BBC 1Xtra. Broadcasting House on Langham Place is the corporation’s headquarters and hosts both BBC News and BBC Television. Maida Vale’s BBC Maida Vale is a studio centre that shelters the BBC Symphony Orchestra and its recording studios, and the BBC Archive Centre in Perivale safeguards the BBC Archives. At the Southbank Centre the BBC leases small technical spaces in both the Queen Elizabeth Hall and the Royal Festival Hall to record events. Four Millbank in Westminster provides a parliamentary studio leased from ITV, White City’s BBC Centre House contains the BBC Research South Lab, the neighbouring BBC Television Centre—once the heart of BBC Television—now mostly sold yet still partly occupied by BBC Worldwide, BBC Studios staff and BBC Studioworks, while the BBC White City complex, comprising the Broadcast Centre and Lighthouse, functions as a large office and production centre.

Broadcasting House on Langham Place is the corporation’s headquarters and hosts both BBC News and BBC Television. Maida Vale’s BBC Maida Vale is a studio centre that shelters the BBC Symphony Orchestra and its recording studios, and the BBC Archive Centre in Perivale safeguards the BBC Archives. At the Southbank Centre the BBC leases small technical spaces in both the Queen Elizabeth Hall and the Royal Festival Hall to record events. Four Millbank in Westminster provides a parliamentary studio leased from ITV, White City’s BBC Centre House contains the BBC Research South Lab, the neighbouring BBC Television Centre—once the heart of BBC Television—now mostly sold yet still partly occupied by BBC Worldwide, BBC Studios staff and BBC Studioworks, while the BBC White City complex, comprising the Broadcast Centre and Lighthouse, functions as a large office and production centre.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Valley County, Idaho
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places listings in Valley County, Idaho. This is intended to be a complete list of the properties and districts on the National Register of Historic Places in Valley County, Idaho, United States. Latitude and longitude coordinates are provided for many National Register properties and districts; these locations may be seen together in a map. There are 26 properties and districts listed on the National Register in the county. More may be added; properties and districts nationwide are added to the Register weekly.
lm_description: Big Creek Commissary, listed on April 21, 2000, stands in Yellow Pine within Payette National Forest. Off a pack trail near Suicide Rock, the Braddock Gold Mining and Milling Company Log Building and Forge Ruins were entered on September 12, 1985, in Thunder City. Cabin Creek Ranch, added June 27, 1990, sits where Cabin Creek meets Big Creek in Payette National Forest outside Black Butte. Elo School, recorded July 26, 1982, lies southeast of State Highway 55 on Farm-to-Market Road in McCall. Also in McCall, the Matt N. Hill Homestead Barn and the Charles Koski Homestead were listed November 17, 1982, while the Johnson Flying Service Hangar at 103 S. 3rd St. joined the Register on November 20, 2019, and the McCall District Administrative Site at the junction of West Lake and Mission streets was added December 30, 1991. Near Lake Fork, the Thomas Jarvi, John G. Johnson (Rintakangas), John S. Johnson (Sampila), Gust Laituri, and Herman Ojala homesteads—all along Pearson Road—were listed November 17, 1982, as was the Long Valley Finnish Church southeast of town. Donnelly claims the John Korvola, Jacob and Herman Mahala, and Jacob Maki homesteads, all listed November 17, 1982. The Krassel Ranger Station, along the South Fork Salmon River west of Yellow Pine, was entered November 19, 1992. The North Fork Payette River Bridge, roughly 2.5 miles north of Smiths Ferry on State Highway 55, was listed April 2, 1999, and the Payette Lakes Club at 1858 Warren Wagon Road in McCall was added April 24, 2017.

title: 1458 papal conclave
intro: The papal conclave of 1458 (August 16-19), convened after the death of Pope Callixtus III, elected as his successor Cardinal Enea Silvio Piccolomini who took the name Pius II.
lm_description: Giorgio Fieschi, Genovese Dean of the Sacred College and bishop of Albenga, held the cardinalatial see of Ostia e Velletri since Eugenius IV elevated him on 18 December 1439. On that same day the Greek humanists Isidore of Kiev, Latin Patriarch of Constantinople and administrator of Nicosia, and Bessarion of Nicea, protector of the Basilians and administrator of Mazara del Vallo and Pamplona, received the suburban sees of Sabina and Frascati. Joining them were the French Benedictine Guillaume d’Estouteville, archbishop of Rouen and protector of the Augustinians, the Castilian Dominican Juan de Torquemada, administrator of Palestrina and abbot of Subiaco, and the Venetian cardinal-nephew Pietro Barbo, bishop of Vicenza and archpriest of the Vatican Basilica. Nicholas V continued the series on 20 December 1448, promoting the Catalan Antonio de la Cerda, bishop of Lerida and administrator of Giovinazzo, the Roman Latino Orsini, administrator of Bari and archpriest of the Lateran, the French Alain de Coëtivy, bishop of Avignon and administrator of Nîmes and Dol, and the Bolognese cardinal-nephew Filippo Calandrini, bishop of Bologna. Callixtus III added his own circle in 1456: on 20 February the Catalan cardinal-nephew Luis Juan del Mila y Borja, administrator of Segorbe and legate in Bologna, and the Portuguese archbishop of Lisbon, Jaime de Portugal, administrator of Paphos; on 17 December the Castilian Juan de Mella, bishop of Zamora, the Milanese Giovanni Castiglione, bishop of Pavia, the Sienese humanist Enea Silvio Piccolomini, bishop of both Siena and Warmia, and the Neapolitan Giacomo Tebaldi, archbishop of Naples and camerlengo. Prospero Colonna, protodeacon since Martin V raised him on 24 May 1426, and Rodrigo Borgia, Catalan cardinal-nephew, vice-chancellor, administrator of Valencia and papal generalissimo, completed the electorate that chose Pius II.
to_index_text:

On that same day the Greek humanists Isidore of Kiev, Latin Patriarch of Constantinople and administrator of Nicosia, and Bessarion of Nicea, protector of the Basilians and administrator of Mazara del Vallo and Pamplona, received the suburban sees of Sabina and Frascati. title: List of longest tunnels
intro: This list of longest tunnels ranks tunnels that are at least 13 km (43,000 ft) long. Only continuous tunnels are included. Pipelines, even those that are buried, are excluded. The longest tunnels have been constructed for water distribution, followed by tunnels for railways.
lm_description: The 661 km Yunnan-Guizhou Water Tunnel, due for completion in 2025, will dwarf every other conduit as an inter-river-basin water transfer in Yunnan, China. New York City Water Tunnel No. 3, finished in 2020, stretches 96.6 km to augment the city’s supply and, once fully linked, will rank third globally. Paris Metro’s circular Line 15, rolling out between 2022 and 2030, will ring the petite couronne for 75 km, overtaking Moscow’s 69 km Bolshaya Koltsevaya circular line completed in 2023. Barcelona’s L9/L10 metro reaches 43.7 km underground between 2009 and 2016, while Singapore’s 43 km Thomson-East Coast Line opens fully in 2024. The 36.7 km Woodsmith Mine Tunnel beneath England’s North York Moors, finished in 2021, conveys potash by conveyor. China’s 34.6 km Gaoligongshan rail tunnel, bored from 2017 to 2022, links Dali with Ruili. Austria’s 32.9 km Koralm Tunnel, 2025, and 27.3 km Semmering Base Tunnel, 2026, will speed Baltic-Adriatic trains, while the 55 km Brenner Base Tunnel, due 2028, will merge with the Inntal Tunnel to create a 64 km continuous rail tube under the Stubai Alps. Norway’s 26.7 km Rogfast road tunnel, under construction since 2018, will become both the longest and deepest undersea road tunnel at 392 m below sea level when it opens in 2026. Nepal’s 26 km Melamchi Water Tunnel, financed by the Asian Development Bank, has supplied Kathmandu since 2015. Thailand’s Mae Taeng-Mae Ngat and Mae Ngat-Mae Kuang water tunnels, 25.6 km and 23 km respectively, were completed in 2021. South Korea’s 25.1 km Musil Tunnel on the Jungang Line opened in 2018, Spain’s 24.7 km Pajares Base Tunnel awaits resolution of water-leak issues, Norway’s 19.5 km Follo Line started running in 2021, Sydney’s 19 km WestConnex road tunnel partially opened in 2019 and will finish in 2023, and Stockholm’s 16.5 km Förbifart road tunnel is scheduled for 2030.

title: List of Galatasaray S.K. records and statistics
intro: Below are statistics and records related to Galatasaray.
lm_description: Badou Ndiaye left Galatasaray for Stoke City in 2018 after the club pocketed €16 million, the highest fee the Lions have ever received. A year earlier, Bruma’s €15 million move to RB Leipzig ranked second, while Arda Turan’s €12 million switch to Atlético Madrid in 2011 once held the record. In 2019, two departures followed close behind: Ozan Kabak joined VfB Stuttgart for €11 million and Garry Rodrigues headed to Al-Ittihad for €9 million. Hakan Şükür’s €8.2 million transfer to Internazionale back in 2000 still places sixth, narrowly ahead of Kader Keïta’s €8.15 million sale to Al-Sadd in 2010. Burak Yılmaz moved to Beijing Guoan for €8 million in 2016, Adrian Ilie left for Valencia at €7 million in 1998, and Alex Telles completed the top ten when Porto paid €6.5 million for him in 2016.

title: Basketball League of Serbia B
intro: Second Men's League of Serbia (Serbian Cyrillic: Друга мушка лига Србије), previously Basketball League of Serbia B, is the second-tier level men's professional basketball league in Serbia. It was founded in 2006.
lm_description: Beovuk 72 and Radnički Beograd both call Belgrade home yet split the 2,000-seat SC Šumice, while Zemun Fitofarmacija stakes out the capital’s 5,000-capacity Pinki Hall. In Niš, Fair Play plays at Dušan Radović School Hall and Konstantin commands the 4,000-seat Čair Sports Center. Mladost SP occupies the 500-seat Vuk Karadžić School Hall in Smederevska Palanka, Pirot hosts matches in its 835-seat Pirot Kej Hall, and Proleter Naftagas fills Zrenjanin’s 3,000-seat Crystal Hall. Radnički Kragujevac packs Jezero Hall’s 3,750 seats, Sloga takes Kraljevo Sports Hall with 3,350, and Spartak brings 3,000 fans to Subotica’s SC Dudova Šuma. Sveti Đorđe of Žitište plays in Nikola Tesla School Hall, Zdravlje commands Leskovac’s 3,600-seat SRC Dubočica, and Železničar rules Čačak’s 4,000-seat Borac Hall.
to_index_text:
Basketball League of Serbia B
Second Men's League of Serbia (Serbian Cyrillic: Друга мушка лига Србије), previously Basketball League of Serbia B, is the second-tier level men's professional basketball league in Serbia. It was founded in 2006.
Beovuk 72 and Radnički Beograd both call Belgrade home yet split the 2,000-seat SC Šumice, while Zemun Fitofarmacija stakes out the capital’s 5,000-capacity Pinki Hall. In Niš, Fair Play plays at Dušan Radović School Hall and Konstantin commands the 4,000-seat Čair Sports Center. Mladost SP occupies the 500-seat Vuk Karadžić School Hall in Smederevska Palanka, Pirot hosts matches in its 835-seat Pirot Kej Hall, and Proleter Naftagas fills Zrenjanin’s 3,000-seat Crystal Hall. Radnički Kragujevac packs Jezero Hall’s 3,750 seats, Sloga takes Kraljevo Sports Hall with 3,350, and Spartak brings 3,000 fans to Subotica’s SC Dudova Šuma. Sveti Đorđe of Žitište plays in Nikola Tesla School Hall, Zdravlje commands Leskovac’s 3,600-seat SRC Dubočica, and Železničar rules Čačak’s 4,000-seat Borac Hall.

title: Alicia Silverstone
intro: Alicia Silverstone (/ˈsɪlvərstoʊn/; born October 4, 1976) is an American actress. She made her film debut in The Crush (1993), earning the 1994 MTV Movie Award for Best Breakthrough Performance, and gained further prominence at the age of 16 as a teen idol when she appeared in the music video for Aerosmith's Cryin'. She starred in the comedy hit Clueless (1995), which earned her a multi-million dollar deal with Columbia Pictures, and in the big-budget film Batman & Robin (1997), playing Barbara Gordon/Batgirl. For her role in the short-lived NBC series Miss Match (2003), Silverstone received a Golden Globe nomination for Best Actress - Television Series Musical or Comedy. She has continued to act in film and television and on stage. A vegan, Silverstone has endorsed PETA activities and has published a vegan cookbook, The Kind Diet.
lm_description: Alicia Silverstone first appeared onscreen in 1993 as Darian/Adrian Forrester in The Crush. During 1995 she juggled four roles: Trudy Wadd in Le Nouveau monde, Regina Harrison in Hideaway, the iconic Cher Horowitz in Clueless, and Jennifer in The Babysitter. She followed with Mary Giordano in 1996’s True Crime, then tackled Barbara Wilson/Batgirl in 1997’s Batman & Robin and Emily Hope in Excess Baggage the same year. After playing Eve Rustikoff in 1999’s Blast from the Past, she portrayed The Princess of France in 2000’s Love’s Labour’s Lost. The 2000s brought Natalie Nat Bevin in Global Heresy (2002), Sheila Rio in Scorched (2003), Heather Jasper Howe in Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed (2004), Lynn in Beauty Shop (2005), Violet in Silence Becomes You (2005), Jack Starbright in Stormbreaker (2006), and a cameo as herself in 2008’s Tropic Thunder. She rounded out the period as Ms. Herman in The Art of Getting By (2011), Jill Emmet in Butter (2011), and Goody in 2012’s Vamps.

title: List of Persepolis F.C. players
intro: This is a list of notable players who have played for Persepolis Football Club by decade.
lm_description: Aziz Asli guarded Persepolis’s goal from 1968 to 1971, sharing the keeper role with Hadi Tavoosi, who served two spells, 1968-69 and 1970-74. Hamid Shirzadegan led the attack from 1968 to 1974, while defenders Ebrahim Ashtiani, Büyük Vatankhah, Jafar Kashani and Reza Vatankhah each returned after the 1969 hiatus to anchor the back line until 1976, 1974, 1975 and 1980 respectively. Forwards Nazem Ganjapour and Hossein Kalani, plus midfielder Fereydoun Moeini, mirrored that split-career pattern, rejoining after 1969 and staying through 1972, 1975 and 1976. Mahmoud Khordbin, already aboard in 1969, stayed a full decade through 1980. Homayoun Behzadi, Mehrab Shahrokhi, Safar Iranpak and Esmaeil Haj Rahimipour all signed in 1970 and remained until 1975 or 1978, while Ali Parvin, arriving the same year, became a club legend with an 18-year midfield tenure ending in 1988. Iraj Soleimani and Mohammad Reza Khalatbari joined in 1971 and left in 1975 and 1978, Bahram Mavaddat kept goal from 1973 to 1976, and Javad Allahverdi patrolled the defence from 1974 to 1981.

title: Scottish Junior Football East Region Premier League North
intro:
The Scottish Junior Football East Region Premier League North also known for sponsorship reasons as the McBookie.com East Premier League North, is the second-tier division of the East Region of the Scottish Junior Football Association and sits parallel with the East Region Premier League South. The league came into existence under the 'North' name for the 2006-07 season, although a 'Tayside District league' had been in place below the East Super League since 2002-03, using the structure of a common 'East Region' top tier and lower regional divisions in place of the old structure of three separate regional leagues in that part of Scotland, with the Tayside Junior Football League the historic local competition. The North Division 
was further expanded for 2013-14 season following league reconstruction in the East Region, by absorbing the more northerly clubs from the dissolved East Region Central Division. Up until season 2017-18, there was a Premier League at tier 2 and North and South Divisions at tier 3. The large-scale movement of clubs to the East of Scotland Football League has resulted in the structure being flattened. Further league reconstruction for the 2019-20 season split the Super League into North and South divisions, reducing the number of Premier League North teams. It now comprises 8 clubs who each play each other home and away to give 24 league fixtures.
lm_description: Arbroath Victoria play at Ogilvy Park in Arbroath and ended 2018-19 in 10th place, while Blairgowrie, home at Davie Park, finished 8th. Brechin Victoria occupy Victoria Park in Brechin and came 9th, and Coupar Angus, based at Foxhall Park, placed 12th. Dundee Violet, who host matches at Glenesk Park, finished 6th, narrowly ahead of East Craigie, another Dundee side playing at Craigie Park, who took 5th. Forfar Albion, grounded at Guthrie Park, ended 11th, and Lochee Harp, from Dundee’s Downfield Park, closed the campaign 7th.

title: List of Grand Slam singles champions in Open Era with age of first title
intro: This is a list of all Open Era tennis Grand Slam singles champions and how old they were when winning their first title. Players who won a title before the Open Era are designated with an asterisk (*), but those results do not factor into these lists.
lm_description: Ken Rosewall, already a champion before the Open Era, captured his first Open Era Slam at 33 years 220 days on 9 June 1968 at Roland-Garros, the first of four he would claim. Rod Laver, likewise marked with pre-Open credentials, began his five-Slam run at 29 years 332 days by winning Wimbledon on 6 July 1968. Arthur Ashe, born 10 July 1943, opened his three-title collection at 25 years 60 days during the 1968 US Open. Jan Kodeš, born 1 March 1946, earned the first of three Slams at 24 years 98 days in the 1970 French Open, while John Newcombe, another pre-Open star, started his five-title haul at 26 years 42 days on 4 July 1970 at Wimbledon. Stan Smith, born 14 December 1946, took the first of two Slams at 24 years 241 days in the 1971 US Open. Andrés Gimeno, born 3 August 1937, became the oldest first-time Open Era champion at 34 years 306 days on 4 June 1972 in Paris. Ilie Năstase, born 19 July 1946, secured the first of two titles at 26 years 53 days in the 1972 US Open. Jimmy Connors, born 2 September 1952, launched his eight-Slam streak at 21 years 121 days in the 1974 Australian Open, and Björn Borg, born 6 June 1956, announced his eleven-title reign at barely 18 years 10 days on 16 June 1974 at Roland-Garros. Manuel Orantes, born 5 February 1949, won his lone Slam at 26 years 214 days in the 1975 US Open. Mark Edmondson, born 24 June 1954, surprised the draw at 21 years 195 days in the 1976 Australian Open. Adriano Panatta, born 9 July 1950, claimed his only Slam at 25 years 340 days in the 1976 French Open. Roscoe Tanner, born 15 October 1951, struck in the January 1977 Australian Open at 25 years 87 days. Guillermo Vilas, born 17 August 1952, began his four-title run at 24 years 292 days in the 1977 French Open. Vitas Gerulaitis, born 26 July 1954, captured his sole Slam at 23 years 159 days in the December 1977 Australian Open. John McEnroe, born 16 February 1959, opened his seven-title account at 20 years 205 days in the 1979 US Open. Brian Teacher, born 23 December 1954, won his only Slam at 26 years 13 days in the 1980 Australian Open. Johan Kriek, born 5 April 1958, started his two-title tally at 23 years 273 days in the 1981 Australian Open. Finally, Mats Wilander, born 22 August 1964, became the youngest first-time champion at 17 years 293 days on 11 June 1982 at Roland-Garros, the first of seven he would collect.
to_index_text:
List of Grand Slam singles champions in Open Era with age of first title
This is a list of all Open Era tennis Grand Slam singles champions and how old they were when winning their first title. Players who won a title before the Open Era are designated with an asterisk (*), but those results do not factor into these lists.
Ken Rosewall, already a champion before the Open Era, captured his first Open Era Slam at 33 years 220 days on 9 June 1968 at Roland-Garros, the first of four he would claim. Rod Laver, likewise marked with pre-Open credentials, began his five-Slam run at 29 years 332 days by winning Wimbledon on 6 July 1968. Arthur Ashe, born 10 July 1943, opened his three-title collection at 25 years 60 days during the 1968 US Open. Jan Kodeš, born 1 March 1946, earned the first of three Slams at 24 years 98 days in the 1970 French Open, while John Newcombe, another pre-Open star, started his five-title haul at 26 years 42 days on 4 July 1970 at Wimbledon. Stan Smith, born 14 December 1946, took the first of two Slams at 24 years 241 days in the 1971 US Open. Andrés Gimeno, born 3 August 1937, became the oldest first-time Open Era champion at 34 years 306 days on 4 June 1972 in Paris. Ilie Năstase, born 19 July 1946, secured the first of two titles at 26 years 53 days in the 1972 US Open. Jimmy Connors, born 2 September 1952, launched his eight-Slam streak at 21 years 121 days in the 1974 Australian Open, and Björn Borg, born 6 June 1956, announced his eleven-title reign at barely 18 years 10 days on 16 June 1974 at Roland-Garros. Manuel Orantes, born 5 February 1949, won his lone Slam at 26 years 214 days in the 1975 US Open. Mark Edmondson, born 24 June 1954, surprised the draw at 21 years 195 days in the 1976 Australian Open. Adriano Panatta, born 9 July 1950, claimed his only Slam at 25 years 340 days in the 1976 French Open. Roscoe Tanner, born 15 October 1951, struck in the January 1977 Australian Open at 25 years 87 days. Guillermo Vilas, born 17 August 1952, began his four-title run at 24 years 292 days in the 1977 French Open. Vitas Gerulaitis, born 26 July 1954, captured his sole Slam at 23 years 159 days in the December 1977 Australian Open. John McEnroe, born 16 February 1959, opened his seven-title account at 20 years 205 days in the 1979 US Open. Brian Teacher, born 23 December 1954, won his only Slam at 26 years 13 days in the 1980 Australian Open. Johan Kriek, born 5 April 1958, started his two-title tally at 23 years 273 days in the 1981 Australian Open. Finally, Mats Wilander, born 22 August 1964, became the youngest first-time champion at 17 years 293 days on 11 June 1982 at Roland-Garros, the first of seven he would collect.

title: List of Old World monkey species
intro: Old World monkeys are all simian primates. They are more closely related to the apes than they are to the New World monkeys.
lm_description: Allen’s swamp monkey, Allenopithecus nigroviridis, was classified by Pocock in 1907 and remains of least concern. The Angolan talapoin, Miopithecus talapoin, dates to Schreber’s 1774 description and is also least concern, while its close relative the Gabon talapoin, Miopithecus ogouensis, was distinguished much later by Kingdon in 1997 and shares the same status. The long-limbed patas monkey, Erythrocebus patas, was named by Schreber in 1775 and is still least concern. Within Chlorocebus, Linnaeus himself described both the green monkey and the grivet in 1758, both least concern; Neumann’s 1902 Bale Mountains vervet, C. djamdjamensis, is vulnerable, whereas Ogilby’s 1841 tantalus monkey, F. Cuvier’s 1821 vervet monkey, and Scopoli’s 1786 malbrouck all remain least concern. Among Cercopithecus, Schwarz’s 1932 Dryas monkey is critically endangered, Linnaeus’s 1758 Diana monkey is vulnerable, Schreber’s 1774 roloway monkey is endangered, and Matschie’s 1905 golden monkey is also endangered, while Linnaeus’s 1766 greater spot-nosed monkey, Wolf’s 1822 blue monkey, Pocock’s 1907 silver monkey, Sykes’s 1831 Sykes’s monkey, Schreber’s 1774 mona monkey, and Waterhouse’s 1838 Campbell’s mona monkey are all listed as least concern.

title: Mohammad Rouyanian
intro: Mohammad Reza Rouyanian (Persian: محمدرضا رویانیان ) is an Iranian businessman, football administrator and former Revolutionary Guard commander. He was the chairman of famous multisport club Persepolis Athletic and Cultural Club from 20 September 2011 until his resignation on 22 January 2014. He was Head of Transportation Management Center from 2007 to 2011. Before that, he was Commissioner of the City of Tehran Transportation Police between 2005 and 2007.
lm_description: Saeid Ghadami arrived from Foolad in 2011 as the first signing, followed the same year by Éamon Zayed from Derry City. Mehdi Mahdavikia joined from Damash Gilan in 2012, the same year Hossein Hooshyar came from Shahrdari Yasuj and Hossein Kanaani was promoted from the youth system. 2012 also saw Mehrdad Pooladi arrive from Mes Kerman, Bosnian keeper Asmir Avdukić from Borac Banja Luka, and a trio from Zob Ahan: Mohammad Ghazi, Shahab Gordan and Hossein Mahini. Jalal Hosseini and Mohsen Bengar both moved from Sepahan in 2012, while Mohammad Reza Khanzadeh came from Rah Ahan, Afshin Esmaeilzadeh from Damash, and Karim Ansarifard from Saipa. Brazilian midfielder Roberto Sousa was signed from Marítimo, Amir Abedzadeh returned from LA Blues, Mehrzad Madanchi arrived from UAE side Al-Shaab, and goalkeeper Nilson Corrêa came from Portuguese club Guimarães, all in 2012. Reza Haghighi completed the sequence, joining from Fajr Sepasi in 2013.

title: 2006 in video games
intro: 2006 saw the release of several sequels and prequels in video games, prominently including New Super Mario Bros, alongside many prominent new releases including Bully, Company of Heroes, Dead Rising, Gears of War, Just Cause, Lost Planet: Extreme Condition, Prey, Resistance: Fall of Man, Saints Row and Thrillville.
lm_description: Nintendo released The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess twice in late 2006, first for Wii on November 19 with Metacritic 95 and GameRankings 94.58%, then for GameCube on December 2 scoring 96 and 95%. Microsoft Game Studios launched Gears of War for Xbox 360 on November 7, earning 94 and 93.97%. 2K Games issued The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion for Xbox 360 and Windows on March 20, both versions achieving 94 Metacritic while the 360 edition held 93.85% and the PC 93.29%. THQ brought Company of Heroes to Windows on September 13 with 93 and 93.93%. Capcom’s Ōkami arrived on PlayStation 2 April 20, scoring 93 and 92.65%. RedOctane shipped Guitar Hero II for PS2 on November 7, tallying 92 and 92.07%. Square Enix debuted Final Fantasy XII on PS2 March 16 with 92 and 90.77%, and later Final Fantasy VI Advance for Game Boy Advance on November 30, reaching 92 and 91.02%. Ubisoft’s Tom Clancy titles spanned the year: Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter on Xbox 360 March 9 with 90 and 90.47%, Splinter Cell: Double Agent on Xbox October 24 at 89 and 89.31%, and Rainbow Six: Vegas on Xbox 360 November 22 scoring 88 and 89.39%. 10tacle Studios released GTR 2 – FIA GT Racing Game for Windows on September 29, achieving 90 and 89.4%. Nintendo’s New Super Mario Bros debuted for Nintendo DS on May 15 with 89 and 89.07%. Electronic Arts launched Burnout Revenge for Xbox 360 on March 7, tallying 89 and 88.57%. Peter Stock’s Armadillo Run hit Windows on April 22, scoring 88 and 89%. Nintendo’s Elite Beat Agents arrived for DS on November 6 with 87 and 88.33%. Namco Bandai’s Tekken 5: Dark Resurrection released for PlayStation Portable on July 6, earning 88 and 88.27%. EA Sports issued NCAA Football 07 for Xbox on July 18, achieving 88 and 88.12%.

title: List of Philadelphia Flyers award winners
intro: The Philadelphia Flyers are a professional ice hockey team based in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. They are members of the Metropolitan Division of the National Hockey League's (NHL) Eastern Conference. The Flyers were founded in 1967 as one of six expansion teams, increasing the size of the NHL at that time to 12 teams. Since the franchise was established, the team has won the Stanley Cup two times as league champions in 1974 and 1975, the Clarence S. Campbell Bowl six times - twice as division champions and four times as conference champions - and the Prince of Wales Trophy as conference champions four times. Prior to the Presidents' Trophy first being award in 1985-86, the Flyers led the league in points three times in 1974-75, 1979-80, and 1984-85, but have not led the league in points at the end of the regular season since. Only Bobby Clarke and Eric Lindros have won regular season most valuable player honors as Flyers. Clarke won the Hart Memorial Trophy three times in 1972-73, 1974-75 and 1975-76 while Lindros won in 1994-95. Both Clarke and Lindros also won the Lester B. Pearson Award, awarded to the most outstanding player as voted by the players and now known as the Ted Lindsay Award, Clarke in 1973-74 and Lindros in 1994-95. Four Flyers players have won the Conn Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player of the playoffs, twice when the Flyers won the Stanley Cup - Bernie Parent in 1974 and 1975 - and twice when they lost in the finals - Reggie Leach in 1976 and Ron Hextall in 1987. Parent and Hextall account for two of the three Flyers goaltenders to win the Vezina Trophy, Parent in 1973-74 and 1974-75, Pelle Lindbergh in 1984-85, and Hextall in 1986-87. Nineteen people - thirteen players and six builders - who spent time with the Flyers have been inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame. The Flyers have inducted twenty-five people into a team hall of fame since 1988 and six of those inductees have also had their numbers retired.
lm_description: Brian Boucher guarded the crease in 1999-2000, the same season Simon Gagne broke in as a forward. Thomas Eriksson patrolled the blue line in 1983-84, one year before Pelle Lindbergh tended goal in 1982-83. Ron Hextall followed as goaltender in 1986-87, while Eric Lindros arrived up front in 1992-93. Mikael Renberg featured as a forward in 1993-94, Chris Therien played defense in 1994-95, Janne Niinimaa in 1996-97, Joni Pitkanen in 2003-04, and Shayne Gostisbehere in 2015-16.

title: 1949 International Cross Country Championships
intro:
The 1949 International Cross Country Championships was held in Dublin, Ireland, at the Baldoyle Racecourse on March 26, 1949. A report on the event was given in the Glasgow Herald. Complete results, medallists, 
 and the results of British athletes were published.
lm_description: Alain Mimoun of France won in 47:50, just one second ahead of compatriot Raphaël Pujazon who clocked 47:51, while Charles Cérou completed a French sweep of the first three places in 47:55. Steve McCooke gave Ireland fourth place in 47:59, followed by England’s Geoff Saunders fifth in 48:14 and France’s André Paris sixth in 48:27. Frank Aaron took seventh for England in 48:32, Roger Petitjean eighth for France in 48:37, and Spain’s Constantino Miranda ninth in 48:46, with Reg Gosney securing tenth for England in 48:48. Jose Coll placed eleventh for Spain in 48:55, John Doms twelfth for Belgium in 49:01, and Mohamed Brahim thirteenth for France in 49:06. Ireland’s John Barry finished fourteenth in 49:07, Scotland’s Andy Forbes fifteenth in 49:14, and England’s Harry Hicks sixteenth in 49:15. Raymond Allix earned seventeenth for France in 49:16, Lucien Theys eighteenth for Belgium in 49:20, Patrick Fahy nineteenth for Ireland in 49:21, and Willy De Neef twentieth for Belgium in 49:22.

title: Victorian Football League
intro: The Victorian Football League (VFL) is the major state-level Australian rules football league in Victoria. The league evolved from the former Victorian Football Association (VFA), and has been known by its current name since 1996. For historical purposes, the present VFL is sometimes referred to as the VFA/VFL, to distinguish it from the present day Australian Football League, which was known until 1990 as the Victorian Football League and is sometimes referred to as the VFL/AFL. The VFA was formed in 1877 and is the second-oldest Australian rules football league, replacing the loose affiliation of clubs that had been the hallmark of the early years of the game. Initially serving a primarily administrative function, the VFA premiership served as the top level of club competition in Victoria until 1896. The VFA became the secondary level of club competition from 1897 after its eight strongest clubs seceded to form the VFL. From 1897 until 1995, the VFA remained independent from the VFL as Victoria's secondary senior club competition. Although always much less popular than the VFL/AFL, the VFA enjoyed peaks of popularity in the 1940s with a faster-paced rival code of rules, and in the 1970s bolstered by playing on Sundays at a time when the VFL was played solely on Saturdays. Since 1995, the league has been administered by AFL Victoria (and its predecessors), and serves as one of the second-tier regional Australian semi-professional competitions which sits underneath the fully professional Australian Football League. From the 2018 season it will comprise 15 teams from throughout Victoria, nine of which have a continuous VFA heritage. Since 2000, the VFL has served partially as a reserves competition for the AFL, with some Victorian-based clubs fielding their reserves teams in the VFL and others affiliated such that their reserves player can play in VFL teams. AFL Victoria also operates a women's football competition under the Victorian Football League brand, known as the VFL Women's, which was established in 2016.
lm_description: William Clarke, MLC, of Melbourne served as the first president from 1877 to 1881, followed by Cr James Garton, who held office from 1882 to 1886. Frank Grey Smith, also from Melbourne, then led from 1887 to 1896. Theodore Fink, MLA, of Richmond presided from 1897 to 1900, succeeded by James Hall of Williamstown for 1901–1902. Cr John George Aikman of Essendon (A.) held the longest tenure, 1903–1928, after which Cr John James Liston of Williamstown served from 1929 to 1944. Henry Zwar, MLA, of Preston led 1944–1946, followed by Squire Reid, MLA, of Oakleigh, 1947–1949, and Dr Frank Hartnett of Camberwell, 1949–1950. Lewis Page of Brighton presided 1951–1953, then Cr Alex Gillon of Brunswick from 1954 to 1980. Alan Wickes of Frankston served 1981–1984, Brook Andersen of Brunswick 1985–1989, John Grieve of Williamstown 1989–1992, and Tony Hannebery of Williamstown closed the sequence from 1993 to 1994.

title: Grammy Award for Best Contemporary R&B Gospel Album
intro: The Grammy Award for Best Contemporary R&B Gospel Album was an honor presented at the Grammy Awards, a ceremony that was established in 1958 and originally called the Gramophone Awards, to recording artists for quality gospel albums incorporating contemporary R&B music. Honors in several categories are presented at the ceremony annually by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences of the United States to honor artistic achievement, technical proficiency and overall excellence in the recording industry, without regard to album sales or chart position. In 1991, the award originated as Best Contemporary Soul Gospel Album, and renamed in 2007. Previously, a similar award, the Grammy Award for Best Soul Gospel Performance, Contemporary, was given from 1978 to 1983. According to the category description guide for the 52nd Grammy Awards, the award is presented to a newly recorded album with at least fifty-one percent R&B Gospel vocal tracks. A solo artist with a choir or chorus is eligible when the choir/chorus provides backing on what is considered an album for the solo artist. The award was discontinued in 2012 in a major overhaul of Grammy categories. From 2012 forward, recordings in this category have been shifted to the Best Gospel Album category.
lm_description: Take 6 won the first Best Contemporary Soul Gospel Album Grammy in 1991 for *So Much 2 Say*, edging out The Winans’ *Return*, Richard Smallwood Singers’ *Portrait*, Edwin Hawkins’ *Face to Face* and Daryl Coley’s *He’s Right On Time/Live from Los Angeles*. BeBe & CeCe Winans repeated for *Different Lifestyles* the next year, while producer Mervyn Warren and friends took 1993 with the soulful re-imagining *Handel’s Messiah: A Soulful Celebration*. The Winans themselves claimed 1994’s trophy with *All Out*, after which Take 6 collected a second win for 1995’s *Join the Band*. CeCe Winans went solo to triumph in 1996 with *Alone In His Presence*, and Kirk Franklin & the Family exploded onto the scene, winning 1997’s *Whatcha Lookin’ 4* and 1999’s *The Nu Nation Project*. Between those victories, Take 6 secured their third title with 1998’s *Brothers*. Yolanda Adams then dominated the new century, seizing 2000’s *Mountain High … Valley Low* and 2002’s concert set *The Experience*. Mary Mary and producer Warryn Campbell broke through in 2001 with *Thankful*, Eartha surprised in 2003 with *Sidebars*, and Donnie McClurkin followed in 2004 with *… Again*. Smokie Norful’s 2005 debut *Nothing Without You* earned him the prize, CeCe Winans returned in 2006 with *Purified*, and Kirk Franklin added two more wins for 2007’s *Hero* and 2009’s *The Fight of My Life*, while Fred Hammond’s 2008 *Free to Worship* and Heather Headley’s 2010 *Audience of One* closed the category’s final seasons before its 2012 retirement.

Smokie Norful’s 2005 debut *Nothing Without You* earned him the prize, CeCe Winans returned in 2006 with *Purified*, and Kirk Franklin added two more wins for 2007’s *Hero* and 2009’s *The Fight of My Life*, while Fred Hammond’s 2008 *Free to Worship* and Heather Headley’s 2010 *Audience of One* closed the category’s final seasons before its 2012 retirement.

title: List of castles and palaces in Sweden
intro: This is a list of castles and palaces in Sweden. In the Swedish language the word slott is used for both castles, châteaus and palaces; this article lists all of them as well as fortresses.
lm_description: Carlsten Fortress, raised in 1667 on the rocky coast of Bohuslän, now welcomes visitors as a museum, while the slightly older Charlottenborg manor house from 1651 in Östergötland serves the same purpose. Charlottenlund Castle in Scania, built in 1849, remains a private home, as does Dagsnäs Castle in Västergötland, completed in 1874. The exotic Chinese Pavilion at Drottningholm, dating to 1769, and Christinehof Castle from 1740 in Scania are both museums, whereas Claestorp Castle in Södermanland, finished in 1754, operates as a hotel. Dalaborg, the 1304 fortress in Dalsland, stands today as a ruin, and 15th-century Djursholm Castle in Stockholm houses offices. Drottningholm Palace, begun in 1580 in Stockholm, functions as both private residence and museum. Dybäck Castle, a 14th-century Scania stronghold, is still privately owned. Edsberg Castle in Uppland, built in 1630, is now a school, as is 17th-century Ekebyholm Castle nearby. Ekenäs Castle in Östergötland, originating in the 15th century, is a museum, while Ekebyhov Castle from the 1670s in Uppland shares that role. Ekensholm Castle in Södermanland, erected in the 1820s, remains a private residence. Eketorp Fort on Öland, a 5th-century ringfort, survives as a museum ruin. Ekholmen Castle in Uppland, completed in 1857, and 17th-century Ekolsund Castle in the same province both serve as hotels, while Elghammar Castle in Södermanland, built in 1807, is a private home.

title: 2011 Rugby League Four Nations
intro: The 2011 Rugby League Four Nations tournament (also known as the 2011 Gillette Rugby League Four Nations due to sponsorship by Gillette) was the third staging of the Rugby League Four Nations tournament and was played in England and Wales during October and November 2011, which was contested by regular contestants Australia, England and New Zealand, in addition to Wales, who had qualified for their first Four Nations by winning the 2010 European Cup. The tournament saw the return of international rugby league to London's Wembley Stadium for the first time since 1997, with a double-header played on 5 November 2011. Australia won the tournament, defeating England in the final at Elland Road, Leeds, on 19 November 2011. The match was the last of the 17-year professional career of Australia's captain Darren Lockyer.
lm_description: Darren Lockyer, captain of the Brisbane Broncos and Queensland, wore Australian cap 661, while vice-captain Cameron Smith, also of Melbourne Storm, held 738. Queenslanders dominated the squad: North Queensland Cowboys Johnathan Thurston (724) and Willie Tonga (723), South Sydney’s Greg Inglis (737), Melbourne Storm trio Billy Slater (751), Cooper Cronk (744) and Cameron Smith, plus Brisbane’s Sam Thaiday (739) and the uncapped Corey Parker and Jharal Yow Yeh. New South Wales supplied Penrith’s Luke Lewis (715), Cronulla’s Paul Gallen (750), Manly pair Anthony Watmaugh (758) and Tony Williams, Wests Tigers hooker Robbie Farah (764), Canterbury centre Josh Morris (767), Canberra prop David Shillington (765) and Newcastle flyer Akuila Uate. Darius Boyd (761) crossed from St George Illawarra, while Manly’s Daly Cherry-Evans, yet to earn a cap, completed the 2011 Four Nations roster.

title: Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre
intro: Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre Co., Ltd. (CMLL; Spanish pronunciation: [konˈsexo munˈdjal de ˈlutʃa ˈliβɾe], World Wrestling Council) is a lucha libre professional wrestling promotion based in Mexico City. The promotion was previously known as Empresa Mexicana de Lucha Libre (EMLL) (Mexican Wrestling Enterprise). Founded in 1933, it is the oldest professional wrestling promotion still in existence. CMLL has been nicknamed The serious and the stable, referencing their very conservative booking style and their traditional structure to how wrestlers are used and allowed to express themselves. Outside live television broadcasts, CMLL has not shown matches where one of the competitors bleeds. They have a few steel cage matches and on occasion have Super Libre matches where there are no disqualifications, but otherwise do not promote any variety of matches that would be considered hardcore wrestling, nor match types such as Ladder matches. CMLL has on occasion fired wrestlers for excessive violence, like the use of chairs, during a match or for using profanity while addressing the crowd during a show. CMLL currently recognizes and promotes twelve World Championships for various weight divisions and classifications, six national level and six regional level championships. The CMLL Anniversary Show series is the longest running annual major show, starting in 1934, with the CMLL 85th Anniversary Show being the most recent. CMLL also regularly promotes major events under the names Homenaje a Dos Leyendas (Homage to two legends), Sin Piedad (No Mercy), Sin Salida (No Escape), Infierno en el Ring (Inferno in the Ring) during the year. CMLL has promoted their regular weekly Super Viernes (Super Friday) on a regular basis since the 1930s. Founder Salvador Lutteroth funded the building of Arena Coliseo in 1943, making it the first building in Mexico built specifically for professional wrestling.
lm_description: Ricky Marvin was the final CMLL Japan Super Lightweight champion, holding the belt from its 27 February 1999 creation until the title vanished on 6 August 2000, while the CMLL Japan Tag Team straps lasted barely five months, ending 7 July 1999 with Masato Yakushiji and Naohiro Hoshikawa as last champions, and the CMLL Japan Women’s crown disappeared on 13 February 2000 with Chikako Shiratori as its last holder. Místico carried the LLA Azteca Championship from its birth 19 December 2009 until it was abandoned 12 May 2013. Blue Panther was the last Mexican National Middleweight champion, reigning from 1933 until the belt was dropped in 1992, and Los Destructores—Tony Arce and Vulano—were the final 1957-created Mexican National Tag Team champions before that title ended in 1993, whereas Mascarita Dorada held the Mexican National Mini-Estrella title from its 8 January 1993 debut until it was retired 5 November 2004. El Faraón’s NWA Intercontinental Heavyweight reign lasted only one month, October to November 1990. El Texano Jr, Averno, and Mephisto were the last holders of the 1952-born NWA World Light Heavyweight, 1939-born NWA World Middleweight, and 1946-born NWA World Welterweight championships respectively, all three belts ceasing on 12 August 2012. Pluma Negra was the final Occidente Lightweight champion, the 1985-created title ending in 2006, and La Parka held the IWC World Heavyweight title from its September 1995 creation until it was gone in July 1996.

title: List of flag bearers for Mexico at the Olympics
intro: This is a list of flag bearers who have represented Mexico at the Olympics. Flag bearers carry the national flag of their country at the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games.
lm_description: Daniela Campuzano carried Mexico’s flag in cycling at the 2016 Summer Games, while Hubertus von Fürstenberg-von Hohenlohe performed the same honor in alpine skiing for both the 2014 and 2010 Winter Olympics. Taekwondo athlete María Espinoza was the 2012 Summer bearer, preceded by diver Paola Espinosa in 2008 and Fernando Platas, who led the delegation twice, in 2004 and again in 2000. Roberto Tamés represented Mexico in bobsleigh at the 2002 Winter ceremony, and Nancy Contreras did so in cycling at the 1996 Summer Games. Von Fürstenberg-von Hohenlohe also opened the 1994 Winter Olympics for Mexico, just as Jesús Mena did for diving at the 1992 Summer Games and Roberto Alvárez for cross-country skiing at the 1992 Winter edition. Ernesto Canto carried the flag in athletics during the 1988 Summer Olympics, the same year Riccardo Olavarrieta did so in figure skating for the Winter event. Ivar Sisniega led the 1984 Summer athletics delegation, Carlos Girón the 1980 diving squad, Teresa Díaz the 1976 gymnastics team, Felipe Muñoz the 1972 swimmers, David Bárcena the 1968 track athletes, and Fidel Negrete the 1964 athletics corps.

title: Sharreth
intro: Sharreth (Malayalam: ശരത്), is an Indian music director and singer. He predominantly composes film scores and songs for Malayalam films, but has gone on to compose for Tamil, Telugu and Hindi films too. He won the Filmfare Award for the best music director in 2008. He won the Kerala State Film Award for Best Music Director in 2011 for the film Ivan Megharoopan. He was also the first recipient of the Kerala State Film Award for Best Classical Music Singer for his song Bhavayami in the film Meghatheertham. He was one of the permanent judges of Idea Star Singer till the end of Season 5 and played a huge role in making the show a rage across Kerala. From 26 September 2011, he has become a judge along with Bhavagayakan P. Jayachandran on the Amrita TV musical reality show Super Star - the Ultimate. From May 2012, he has become a judge along with Ouseppachan and S. P. Shylaja on the Kairali TV Ghandharava sangeetham 2012. From February 2013, he has become a judge along with K. S. Chithra, Sreenivas and Sujatha on the Mazhavil manorama Indian Voice season 2 and Indian Voice Juinor. His memoir (written by Sanjeev Pillai) titled Aathmaraagam (ആത്മരാഗം) was published by Litmus Publications (an imprint of D C Books) in 2014. Now he is the permanent judge of Mazhavil Manorama musical reality show paadam nammukku paadam
lm_description: Sharreth first sat on the Asianet panel for Idea Star Singer 2007, returned for the 2008 edition, stayed through season 4 spanning 2009-2010, and closed the stint with season 5 in 2010-2011. In 2009 he crossed to Zee Tamil to judge Sa Re Ga Ma Pa 2009 Challenge. Kairali TV enlisted him for Gandharva Sangeetham in 2012, Amrita TV brought him aboard Super star the ultimate in 2013 and kept him for Super Star in 2014, later recalling him for Super Star Junior in 2016. Mazhavil Manorama engaged him twice in 2013—Josco Indian voice season 2 and Candyman Indian Voice Junior—then welcomed him back for Super 4 in 2018 and, from 2019 to the present, for Padaam namuk Paadam. Flowers TV added him to Bhima Indian Music League in 2015.

title: 1984 New York Cosmos season
intro: The 1984 New York Cosmos season was the fourteenth season for the New York Cosmos playing in the now-defunct North American Soccer League. It was the final year of the original Cosmos playing in the original NASL; they would play three friendlies in 1985 before disbanding. During the 1984 season, the Cosmos finished in third place in the Eastern Division, failing to qualify for the playoffs for the first time since 1975. It was also the first season since 1978 that the Cosmos failed to finish first in the overall league table, ending a streak of six premierships.
lm_description: Dan Canter, wearing the number 3 jersey, arrived from Team America to anchor the Cosmos defense, joined by Polish veteran Władysław Żmuda, who switched from Hellas Verona to take the number 6 slot. Up front, Giuseppe Damiani crossed from Milan to claim the number 7 shirt, while Stan Terlecki moved from the Golden Bay Earthquakes to wear 14 and fellow forward Andrew Parkinson, formerly of Team America, was handed the number 20 strip. Midfield reinforcements came from across the continent: Pedro DeBrito joined from the Tampa Bay Rowdies to occupy the number 22 role, Gerry Gray and Carmine Marcantonio both transferred from the defunct Montreal Manic to take 25 and 27 respectively, and Gerry Reardon arrived from the Tulsa Roughnecks as the squad’s number 30. Chico Borja, another Team America export, was given the number 28 forward berth, and defender Doc Lawson completed the incoming class, swapping the indoor New York Arrows for the outdoor Cosmos while inheriting the number 32 shirt.

title: List of shopping malls in India
intro: This is a list of shopping malls in India, sortable by name, location, year opened and size.
lm_description: BM Habitat Mall opened in Jayalakshmipura, Mysuru, in 2012 with 240,000 sq ft of leasable space. City Centre Mall on K S Rao Road, Mangaluru, launched in 2011 offering 540,000 sq ft, while its smaller sibling at KSTRC Bus Station, Shivamogga, debuted in 2014 with 85,000 sq ft. Elements Mall on Thanisandra Main Road, Nagavara, Bengaluru, arrived in 2012 with 260,000 sq ft, the same year Empire Mall appeared on Mahatma Gandhi Road, Mangaluru, without a listed size. Mantri Square in Malleswara, Bengaluru, opened in 2010 spanning 924,000 sq ft, dwarfing The Forum in Koramangala, Bengaluru, which opened in 2004 with 365,000 sq ft. Forum Centre City Mall in Nazarbad, Mysuru, launched in 2018 with 347,000 sq ft, while The Forum Value in Whitefield, Bengaluru, opened in 2009 with 300,000 sq ft. Forum Fiza Mall on K S Rao Road, Mangaluru, opened in 2014 with 686,892 sq ft. Garuda Mall on Magrath Road, Bengaluru, launched in 2005 with 280,000 sq ft, and Inorbit Mall in Whitefield, Bengaluru, opened in 2012 with 339,000 sq ft. Lotus Mall in Kulshekar, Mangaluru, opened in 2015 with 900,000 sq ft, while Mak Mall in Kankanady, Mangaluru, opened in 2013 with 70,000 sq ft. Mall of Mysore on M.G. Road, Mysuru, launched in 2012 with 262,000 sq ft. Orion Mall in Malleswara-Rajajinagara, Bengaluru, opened in 2012 with 850,000 sq ft, and Park Square Mall in Whitefield, Bengaluru, offers 400,000 sq ft. Phoenix Market City in Whitefield, Bengaluru, opened in 2010 with 1,400,000 sq ft, Urban Oasis Mall on Gokul Road, Hubballi, opened in 2012 with 375,000 sq ft, and UB City on Vittal Mallya Road, Bengaluru, opened in 2008 with 130,000 sq ft.

title: 1979 Torneo Descentralizado
intro: The 1979 Torneo Descentralizado, the top category of Peruvian football (soccer), was played by 16 teams. The national champion was Sporting Cristal. The season was divided into 2 stages. On the first stage, top 8 teams qualified to play for the championship with a points bonus of 3, 2 and 1 for the top 3; bottom eight qualified to play for relegation with a points penalty of -1, -2 and -3 for bottom three. Teams entered the second stage without carrying their whole season records. As three teams tied on points the last place of Relegation Group they had to enter a Relegation Playoff that was played in Lima.
lm_description: Alfonso Ugarte of Puno plays at the 20,000-seat Enrique Torres Belón on grass, while Alianza Lima uses Lima’s 35,000-capacity Alejandro Villanueva, also on grass. Atlético Chalaco and Sport Boys share Callao’s 15,000-seat Miguel Grau grass pitch, and Atlético Torino’s home is Talara’s 8,000-capacity Campeonísimo grass ground. CNI draws 24,000 fans to Iquitos’ Max Augustín on grass, Coronel Bolognesi fills Tacna’s 19,850-seat Jorge Basadre, and Deportivo Junín hosts matches in Huancayo’s 20,000-capacity Huancayo stadium, all on grass. Deportivo Municipal, Sporting Cristal and Universitario all play on Lima’s Nacional, a 45,750-seat grass arena. Juan Aurich entertains 24,500 at Chiclayo’s Elías Aguirre, Juventud La Palma 12,000 at Huacho’s Segundo Aranda Torres, and León de Huánuco 15,000 at Huánuco’s Heraclio Tapia, each on grass. Melgar’s 20,000-seat Mariano Melgar in Arequipa and Unión Huaral’s 10,000-seat Julio Lores Colan in Huaral complete the sixteen-team slate, every surface grass.

Deportivo Municipal, Sporting Cristal and Universitario all play on Lima’s Nacional, a 45,750-seat grass arena. Juan Aurich entertains 24,500 at Chiclayo’s Elías Aguirre, Juventud La Palma 12,000 at Huacho’s Segundo Aranda Torres, and León de Huánuco 15,000 at Huánuco’s Heraclio Tapia, each on grass. Melgar’s 20,000-seat Mariano Melgar in Arequipa and Unión Huaral’s 10,000-seat Julio Lores Colan in Huaral complete the sixteen-team slate, every surface grass.

title: Historic Chapels Trust
intro: The Historic Chapels Trust is a British Registered Charity set up to care for redundant non-Anglican churches, chapels, and places of worship in England. To date, its holdings encompass various nonconformist Christian denominations and Roman Catholic sites.
lm_description: Farfield Friends Meeting House, erected in Addingham, West Yorkshire in 1689 on an earlier burial ground, is a modest Quaker meeting house whose forecourt still holds five rare chest tombs, and it is listed Grade II*. Walpole Old Chapel, Suffolk, likewise built in 1689 from a converted farmhouse after the Act of Toleration, served Independents, then Congregationalists, then Primitive Methodists, and is also Grade II*. Cote Baptist Chapel, Bampton, Oxfordshire, built 1703-04 for Baptists from beyond the Thames, was enlarged in the 1750s, restored in the 1850s and 1990s, and is now hired for weddings and concerts, Grade II*. Salem Chapel, East Budleigh, Devon, begun in 1719 for Presbyterians, later housed Congregationalists and Assemblies of God, and is still used for occasional services and events, Grade II*. Coanwood Friends Meeting House, isolated near Haltwhistle, Northumberland, built 1720, retains its original benches and typical Quaker gravestones commemorating the founding Wigham family, Grade II*. Grittleton Strict Baptist Chapel, Wiltshire, opened 1721, keeps its galleries, box pews, child’s pew and pulpit, Grade II*. St George’s German Lutheran Church, Alie Street, London, 1762-63, served Lutherans until 1996 and now hosts concerts and the Trust’s offices, Grade II*. St Benet’s Chapel, Netherton, Merseyside, 1793, hides behind a presbytery and is being restored to pre-Vatican II appearance, Grade II*. Bethesda Methodist Chapel, Hanley, Staffordshire, 1819, once the “Cathedral of the Potteries,” closed 1985 and is undergoing £2.5 million repairs, Grade II*. Biddlestone Chapel, Northumberland, c. 1820, built as a private Roman Catholic chapel for the Selby family on a medieval pele tower, survives alone in remote countryside, Grade II*. Dissenters’ Chapel, Kensal Green Cemetery, London, 1832, the first Nonconformist chapel in a public cemetery, had its wings rebuilt after 1970s decay, Grade II*. Thorndon Park Chapel, Essex, c. 1850, William Wardell’s Decorated-style chantry and mausoleum for the Petre family, features angel-roof and carved reredos, Grade II*. Wainsgate Baptist Church, Hebden Bridge, West Yorkshire, 1859-60, elevated above the town, closed 2001 and now hosts concerts, Grade II*. Todmorden Unitarian Church, West Yorkshire, 1865-69, John Gibson’s 196-ft spired Gothic monument by the Fielden mill-owners, restored for £1 million, Grade I. Westgate Methodist Chapel, Bishop Auckland, County Durham, 1871, Primitive Methodist, closed 2007 with all Victorian fittings intact, Grade II*. Umberslade Baptist Church, Hockley Heath, West Midlands, 1877, George Ingall’s blue-lias Decorated church for G. F. Muntz, repaired for £500,000, Grade II. Penrose Methodist Chapel, St Ervan, Cornwall, 1861, single-storey rectangle with box pews and musicians’ benches, Grade II*. Longworth Roman Catholic Chapel, Bartestree, Herefordshire, rebuilt 1869-70 from a medieval manor chapel, probably by E. W. Pugin, Grade II*. Wallasey Memorial Unitarian Church, Merseyside, 1899, Arts and Crafts brick church by Waring & Rathbone with Bromsgrove Guild Art-Nouveau fittings, Grade II*. Shrine of Our Lady of Lourdes, Blackpool, Lancashire, 1955-57, Portland-stone thanksgiving for wartime safety, now becoming a community centre, Grade II*.

title: List of bus transit systems in the United States
intro: The following is a list of presently-operating bus transit systems in the United States with regular service. The list excludes charter buses, private bus operators, paratransit systems, and trolleybus systems. Figures for daily ridership, number of vehicles, and daily vehicle revenue miles are accurate as of 2009 and come from the FTA National Transit Database.
lm_description: Allegany County Transit serves Cumberland in Allegany County, while Annapolis Transit operates in Anne Arundel County with Annapolis as its focal city. Cecil Transit connects Elkton within Cecil County, and Harford Transit centers on Bel Air in Harford County. Metrobus spans the Washington Metropolitan Area, anchored by Washington, D.C., whereas MTA Maryland covers the broader Baltimore-Washington Metropolitan Area with Baltimore as its primary city. Ocean City Transportation operates within Worcester County, serving the coastal city of Ocean City. RTA Central Maryland links Columbia and Laurel across Anne Arundel, Howard, and Prince George’s counties. Ride On operates solely within Montgomery County, and Shore Transit connects Salisbury across Somerset, Wicomico, and Worcester counties. TheBus serves Prince George’s County, TransIT operates in Frederick County with Frederick as its hub, and Washington County Transit centers on Hagerstown in Washington County.

title: List of public art at the Indiana Statehouse
intro: This is a list of public art in and around the Indiana Statehouse, the Indiana Government Center North, and the Indiana Government Center South, which make up the Indiana Statehouse Public Art Collection.
lm_description: Enrico Vittori’s 1920 bronze Columbus rises 39 by 23 by 29 inches on granite, while Rudolph Schwarz and Marie Stewart’s 1906 bronze Lincoln relief stretches 65 by 35 inches. Donald De Lue’s 1959 Washington stands nine feet four inches tall and weighs 900 pounds. Eric Ernstberger’s 1991 Tulip to Life blooms in stainless steel, copper, and limestone, spanning fifteen by eighteen feet. The 2001 Indiana Law Enforcement and Firefighters Memorial spreads multiple bronze, granite, and limestone pieces across the plaza. Schwarz returned in 1907 to cast the ten-foot Morton monument in bronze and granite, and Frances Goodwin’s 1911 Robert Dale Owen Memorial measures 45.5 by 42.5 by 70 inches in bronze. Richard Henry Park’s 1890 Hendricks Monument rises 132 inches high on red granite, and John J. Szaton’s 1966 Coal Miner, eighty-five inches tall, stands on black granite. Herman Carl Mueller’s 1878 limestone Westward Journey presents four groupings and single figures twelve feet high. Daniel Edwards’s 1995 Workers’ Memorial rises in bronze on limestone, and David K. Rubins’s 1962 Young Abe Lincoln reaches 108 inches on granite. Thomas Dow Jones’s 1862 plaster Lincoln bust measures 33 by 25 by 18 inches, Henry Dexter’s 1860 Willard plaster bust is 9 by 11.5 by 23.5 inches, and Richard Peglow’s Benjamin Harrison bust lacks date and dimensions. An unknown sculptor carved the 47.5-inch marble Calvin Fletcher, Belle Kinney Scholz’s 1913 bronze Colonel Richard Owen stands 70 by 40 by 21 inches, James Paxton Voorhees modeled the 31-inch plaster Daniel W. Voorhees, David McLary cast the 1987 plaster George Rogers Clark, and Jean-Antoine Houdon’s 1932 plaster Washington bust, owned by the Indiana Historical Bureau, measures 25 by 18 by 18 inches.

title: List of BBC properties
intro: The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) occupies many properties in the United Kingdom, and occupied many other in previous years. The headquarters of the corporation is Broadcasting House in London; with many other divisions located in London and around the UK. Since 2007 the BBC has been developing a significant base at MediaCityUK in Salford, to which it has relocated several departments. There are also production bases in Belfast, Birmingham, Bristol, Cardiff and Glasgow. The BBC also owns news bureaux and relay stations outside the UK.
lm_description: The BBC’s local presence stretches from Barnsley Digital Media Centre, which serves as the Barnsley studio for BBC Radio Sheffield, to the Barnstaple Civic Centre housing BBC Radio Devon’s studio. Barrow-in-Furness hosts BBC Broadcasting House (Cumbria) for BBC Radio Cumbria, while Basingstoke College of Technology provides the local studio for BBC Radio Berkshire. In Bath, BBC Bath supports BBC Radio Bristol, and Bedford County Hall is home to BBC Three Counties Radio. Birmingham’s Mailbox is the base for BBC WM, complemented by the BBC Drama Village in the same city. Blackburn’s BBC Blackburn serves BBC Radio Lancashire, and Boston Business Centre hosts the local studio for BBC Lincolnshire. Bradford’s National Media Museum contains the BBC Radio Leeds studio, while BBC Brighton operates BBC Sussex. Bristol’s BBC Broadcasting House (Bristol) is shared with BBC Radio Bristol, and Bromsgrove District Council House supports BBC Hereford and Worcester. Burton upon Trent Town Hall hosts the local studio for BBC Radio Derby, Cambridge’s BBC Broadcasting House (Cambridge) is for BBC Radio Cambridgeshire, and Canterbury Christ Church University provides the local studio for BBC Radio Kent. Carlisle’s BBC Broadcasting House (Carlisle) also serves BBC Radio Cumbria, Chatham’s Sun Pier Chambers supports BBC Radio Kent, and Chelmsford’s BBC Broadcasting House (Chelmsford) is home to BBC Essex.

title: List of Australian club rugby union competitions
intro: In Australia, what is considered the third tier of Rugby is often referred to as club rugby, grade rugby or premier rugby. Club Rugby often focuses on the major metropolitan areas of the respective unions, with teams representing various districts and suburbs. The teams represented in the first grade can and have changed over time, and are open to change at the discretion of the governing body.
lm_description: Bond University, founded on the Gold Coast in 1996, entered the top flight as the Breakers in 1997. Brothers, the 1905-established Albion club nicknamed the Butcher Bhoys, the Brethren and the Filth, has been in premier grade since its first season. Eastern Districts, formed in 1947 at Coorparoo, became the Tigers or Easts and waited until 1950 for admission. GPS Old Boys, the 1887 Ashgrove outfit known as Jeeps, joined premier grade in 1931. North Brisbane, created in 1931 at Wooloowin, competed as Eagle Junction in 1933, Teachers in 1961 and Teachers-Norths in 1974 before the Eagles or Norths finally secured premier status in 1991. University of Queensland, the 1911 St Lucia club called the Red Heavies, stepped up in 1912. Southern Districts, the 1948 Annerley Magpies or Souths, entered premier grade the same year they were founded. Sunnybank, born in 1969, became the Dragons and won admission in 1989. West Brisbane, the 1951 Toowong Bulldogs or Wests, joined premier grade in 1955.

title: 5th Parliament of British Columbia
intro: The 5th Legislative Assembly of British Columbia sat from 1887 to 1890. The members were elected in the British Columbia general election held in July 1886. William Smithe formed a government. Following his death in May 1887, Alexander Edmund Batson Davie became premier. After Davie died in 1889, John Robson became premier. There were four sessions of the 5th Legislature:
lm_description: George Thomson won Nanaimo on 3 January 1887 after W. Raybould died 3 December 1886. Henry Fry took Cowichan on 5 May 1887 following William Smithe’s death 28 March 1887. Thomas Basil Humphreys was elected in Comox on 30 December 1887 after A. M. Stenhouse resigned to join the LDS Church. Simeon Duck entered for Victoria City on 25 January 1888 when E. G. Prior stepped down to contest a federal by-election. James Tolmie secured Victoria on 30 June 1888 after R. F. John became warden of the provincial gaol. Ithiel Blake Nason won Cariboo on 26 November 1888 when R. McLeese left to pursue a federal by-election. Andrew Haslam took Nanaimo on 14 June 1889 after Robert Dunsmuir died 12 April 1889. Alfred Wellington Smith was chosen in Lillooet on 21 September 1889 following premier Alexander Edmund Batson Davie’s death 1 August 1889. Thomas Cunningham entered for New Westminster City on 25 November 1889 after H. N. Bole resigned to join the County Court of British Columbia.
