title: 2006 Roger Federer tennis season
intro: Roger Federers 2006 season was dominant and he ended the year with a 92-5 record. The world No.1 reached all four Grand Slam finals in 2006, winning three of them. His only Grand Slam loss came against Rafael Nadal in the French Open final in four sets, 6-1, 1-6, 4-6, 6-7(4-7). This was the first time they had met in a Major final. In the other three Grand Slams of 2006, Federer defeated Nadal in the final of the Wimbledon Championships, 6-0, 7-6(7-5), 6-7(2-7), 6-3. He defeated Marcos Baghdatis, 5-7, 7-5, 6-0, 6-2, at the Australian Open and Andy Roddick, 6-2, 4-6, 7-5, 6-1, at the US Open. In addition, Federer made it to six ATP Masters Series 1000 finals (out of the seven events he entered), winning four on hard surfaces and losing two on clay to Nadal. Also, Federer won one ATP 500 series event in Tokyo, three ATP 250 series events in Doha, Halle, and Basel, and captured the Year-End Championship for the third time in his career. In December 2011, Stephen Tignor, chief editorial writer for Tennis.com, ranked Federer's 2006 season as the second greatest open era season behind Rod Laver's Calendar Grand Slam year of 1969,1970.
lm_description: Roger Federer opened 2006 by pocketing $142,000 for winning the Qatar ExxonMobil Open, then collected $922,560 for his Australian Open triumph, pushing his early-season earnings to $1,064,560. A $98,600 payday at the Dubai Duty Free Tennis Championships—plus a modest $1,500 for a doubles cameo—lifted him to $1,164,660 before March. He then secured $490,000 at the Pacific Life Open and another $1,750 in doubles there, nudging his running total to $1,656,410, and followed with $533,350 for capturing the NASDAQ-100 Open, reaching $2,189,760. Clay brought $200,000 for Monte Carlo and $7,050 more in doubles, edging him to $2,396,810, and another $200,000 at the Internazionali BNL d'Italia took him to $2,596,810. After a $598,350 runner-up cheque at the French Open he stood at $3,195,160, then added $113,000 for the Gerry Weber Open and a career-best $1,190,725 for Wimbledon, surging to $4,498,885. A $400,000 Rogers Cup final and a small $15,000 Cincinnati consolation moved him to $4,513,885, before the $1,200,000 US Open title catapulted him to $5,713,885. Late-season victories in Tokyo ($118,000), Madrid ($450,000) and Basel ($142,000) carried him to $6,423,885, and he closed the year by claiming a $1,520,000 windfall at the Tennis Masters Cup, finishing with a record $7,943,885 in single-season prize money.

title: Dancing Stars (Austrian season 6)
intro: The sixth edition of Dancing Stars was broadcast from March 11 to May 27, 2011 on ORF1 and was presented by Mirjam Weichselbraun and Klaus Eberhartinger.
lm_description: Astrid Wirtenberger dominated the leaderboard, earning perfect 40s for her sparkling Foxtrot and Jive, plus top marks of 36 for Mambo and 34 for Samba, while her 33 in Waltz still kept her ahead. Alexandra Meissnitzer proved the season’s other standout, posting the highest Cha Cha Cha (37), Quickstep (36), Paso Doble (34) and Tango (39). Alfons Haider and Mirna Jukić jointly peaked at 33 for Rumba, and Haider later collected 32 for Viennese Waltz, yet he also sank to the Cha Cha Cha basement alongside Mirna Jukić with 23. Dieter Chmelar shouldered most of the low scores: 19 in Foxtrot and Samba, 15 in Jive, 17 in Quickstep and Waltz. Markus Wolfahrt bottomed out at 17 in both Rumba and Tango, Mike Galeli hit 25 in Viennese Waltz and 29 in Mambo with Alfons Haider, and Reinhard Nowak joined Chmelar at 17 in Quickstep.
to_index_text:

Alfons Haider and Mirna Jukić jointly peaked at 33 for Rumba, and Haider later collected 32 for Viennese Waltz, yet he also sank to the Cha Cha Cha basement alongside Mirna Jukić with 23. Dieter Chmelar shouldered most of the low scores: 19 in Foxtrot and Samba, 15 in Jive, 17 in Quickstep and Waltz. Markus Wolfahrt bottomed out at 17 in both Rumba and Tango, Mike Galeli hit 25 in Viennese Waltz and 29 in Mambo with Alfons Haider, and Reinhard Nowak joined Chmelar at 17 in Quickstep.

title: List of Jewish actors
intro: This is a list of notable Jewish actors and actresses.
lm_description: Israeli actress Reymond Amsalem, born 1978, is known for *Hostages*, while compatriot Mili Avital, born 1972, starred in *Stargate*. American actors Dave Annable (1979), Eric Balfour (1977), Dani Behr (1971, British), Michael Ian Black (1971), and Caprice Bourret (1971, American/British) are listed without specific roles. Shiri Appleby (1978) appeared in *Roswell*, David Arquette (1971) in *Scream* and *See Spot Run*, and Elizabeth Banks (1974) in *The Hunger Games*. Sacha Baron Cohen (1971), British, created *Ali G*, *Borat*, *Brüno*, and *The Dictator*. Justin Bartha (1978) acted in *Gigli*, *National Treasure*, and *The Hangover*. Amber Benson (1977) featured in *Buffy the Vampire Slayer*, Elizabeth Berkley (1972) in *Saved By The Bell* and *Showgirls*, and Josh Bernstein (1971) hosted *Digging for the Truth*. Jon Bernthal (1976) is recognized for *The Walking Dead*, Mayim Bialik (1975) for *Blossom* and *The Big Bang Theory*, Selma Blair (1972) for *Cruel Intentions* and *Hellboy*, and Alex Borstein (1973) voices *Family Guy*.

title: 2008 Aerobic Gymnastics World Championships
intro: 10th Aerobic Gymnastics World Championships were held in Ulm, Germany from April 25 to April 27, 2008.
lm_description: Marcela Lopez of Brazil topped the standings with 22.050 points, followed closely by Romania’s Cristina Simona Nedelcu at 21.350 and New Zealand’s Angela McMillan on 21.200. Bulgaria’s Lili Yordanova placed fourth with 21.150, while China’s Huang Jinxuan earned 20.850 for fifth. Italy fielded two finishers: Giula Bianchi took sixth on 20.650 and Adrianna Ciucci eighth on 20.500, the pair separated by France’s Aurélie Joly who scored 20.600 for seventh. Spain’s Elmira Dassaeva closed the list in ninth at 20.250.

title: National Register of Historic Places listings in Carver County, Minnesota
intro: This is a list of the National Register of Historic Places listings in Carver County, Minnesota. It is intended to be a complete list of the properties and districts on the National Register of Historic Places in Carver County, Minnesota, United States. The locations of National Register properties and districts for which the latitude and longitude coordinates are included below, may be seen in an online map. There are 33 properties and districts listed on the National Register in the county. Many structures are built of local Chaska brick, which has a distinctive cream color. A supplementary list includes four additional sites that were formerly listed on the National Register.
lm_description: Emile Amblard’s circa-1900 guest house at 32-36 N. Vine St. in Waconia, listed on 4 January 1980, is the best-preserved remnant of the town’s resort era and the only surviving building designed by the promoter of Coney Island of the West, itself listed on 11 August 1976 as the 31-acre island ruins in Lake Waconia that drew crowds from the 1880s to the 1920s. In Chaska, the Brinkhaus Saloon Livery Barn of c. 1875 at 112 W. 4th St., entered 4 January 1980, now shelters the Chaska Historical Society, while nearby cream-colored Chaska brick defines the 1895 Albertine and Fred Heck House on Audubon Road in Chanhassen and the 1878 J. Carsten and Magaretha Harms Farmhouse off County Road 152 near Cologne. Frederick E. DuToit’s c. 1870 house at 121 Hickory St. in Chaska, listed the same day, honors the newspaper publisher and politician whose family shaped the city, as did the 1871 Herald Block at 123 W. 2nd St., long home to their Chaska Herald. Queen Anne elegance surfaces in the c. 1900 Eder-Baer House at 105 Elm St., while the c. 1870 Frederick Greiner House at 319 E. 3rd St. recalls an early hotelkeeper and public official. Cologne’s Philip Guettler House of 1902 at Adams and Mill Streets marks the second-generation owner of the town’s 1880 mill, and the adjacent 1905 John Knotz House belonged to a railroad doctor and his wife Rosa, three-time mayor and women’s-rights advocate. Victoria’s 1878 Laketown Moravian Brethren’s Church on County Highway 11 bridges plain early sanctuaries and later ornate brick churches, and the 1938 Chaska Historical Marker on County Highway 61 exemplifies National Park Service rustic style wayside rests. Off County Highway 11 in Carver Park Reserve, the 160-acre Wendelin Grimm Farmstead, listed 30 December 1974, preserves the 1876 house where Grimm developed winter-hardy alfalfa, now a Three Rivers educational facility. King Oscar’s Settlement on County Highway 40 near Carver holds an 1865 cottage, 1866 church, 1874 parsonage, and parish hall that birthed Gustavus Adolphus College within the first Swedish American settlement, while Hamburg’s 1907 Jacob Hebeisen Hardware Store on Railroad and Maria Streets became a 1919 consumer cooperative heralding Minnesota’s cooperative movement.

title: 2007 NCAA Division I Baseball Tournament
intro: The 2007 NCAA Division I Baseball Tournament was held from June 1 to 24, 2007. Sixty-four NCAA Division I college baseball teams advanced to the post season tournament after having played through a regular season, and for some, a conference tournament. The 2007 tournament culminated with 8 teams advancing to the College World Series at historic Rosenblatt Stadium in Omaha, Nebraska, on June 15. Unseeded Oregon State repeated as national champions, winning all five of its games in the 2007 CWS. Oregon State went undefeated through the College World Series, posting a 5-0 record. The Beavers, led by head coach Pat Casey, won all three games in their four-team bracket and then defeated North Carolina in two games in the best-of-three championship series. Oregon State became the fifth team to win consecutive NCAA titles (last done by LSU in 1996-97), and were the first team to win four games in a CWS by six or more runs. As of 2019, 2007 Oregon State remains the only team to have ever won at least four games by six or more runs in the same College World Series. Their opener against Cal State Fullerton was a tight 3-2 victory, but OSU's last four games in the CWS were not close, impressive for a team seeded in the lower half of the 64-team tournament. The Beavers also became the first team to win the CWS after having posted a losing conference record. Oregon State was a disappointing 10-14 (.417) in the Pac-10, placing sixth among the nine baseball-playing schools (Oregon dropped baseball in 1981, but revived it in 2009.) However, the Beavers' non-conference record during the regular season was an impressive 28-3 (.903), and as defending NCAA champions, just enough to gain a berth in the 64-team tournament.
lm_description: The Atlantic Coast Conference placed seven schools in the 2007 NCAA Division I Baseball Tournament—Clemson, Florida State, Miami (FL), North Carolina, NC State, Virginia, and Wake Forest—while the Big 12 sent six: Baylor, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma State, Texas, and Texas A&M. The Southeastern Conference was represented by five teams—Arkansas, Ole Miss, Mississippi State, South Carolina, and Vanderbilt—and the Big West and Conference USA each earned four bids, with UC Irvine, UC Riverside, Cal State Fullerton, and Long Beach State comprising the Big West contingent, and East Carolina, Memphis, Rice, and Southern Miss making up the C-USA group. The Pac-10, despite Oregon State’s eventual national title, received only four invitations: Arizona, Arizona State, Oregon State, and UCLA. The Big East, Big Ten, and Sun Belt each claimed three spots—Louisville, Rutgers, and St. John’s from the Big East; Michigan, Minnesota, and Ohio State from the Big Ten; and Louisiana-Lafayette, New Orleans, and Troy from the Sun Belt. Jacksonville and Stetson carried the Atlantic Sun, Creighton and Wichita State represented the Missouri Valley, Western Carolina and Wofford came from the Southern Conference, and Pepperdine and San Diego earned West Coast Conference berths. Single-bid leagues included Charlotte (Atlantic 10), Albany (America East), Coastal Carolina (Big South), VCU (Colonial), UIC (Horizon), Brown (Ivy), and LeMoyne (Metro Atlantic).

title: 26th United States Congress
intro: The Twenty-sixth United States Congress was a meeting of the legislative branch of the United States federal government, consisting of the United States Senate and the United States House of Representatives. It met in Washington, D.C. from March 4, 1839, to March 4, 1841, during the third and fourth years of Martin Van Buren's presidency. The apportionment of seats in the House of Representatives was based on the Fifth Census of the United States in 1830. Both chambers had a Democratic majority.
lm_description: Tilghman Howard, a Democrat, took the vacant Indiana 7th seat on August 5, 1839, the same day credentials were presented for the originally elected Howard. Albert G. Harrison’s death on September 7, 1839, opened Missouri’s at-large seat for fellow Democrat John Jameson, installed December 12. Massachusetts 6th Whig James C. Alvord died September 27, 1839, and Osmyn Baker, also a Whig, succeeded him on January 14, 1840. William W. Potter’s October 28, 1839, death in Pennsylvania’s 14th led to Democrat George McCulloch being seated November 20. Charles F. Mercer resigned Virginia’s 14th on December 26, 1839, and Whig William M. McCarty replaced him January 25, 1840. Thomas Corwin quit Ohio’s 4th on May 30, 1840, to run for governor, and Whig Jeremiah Morrow took over October 13. William L. Storrs left Connecticut’s 2nd in June 1840, with Whig William W. Boardman filling the seat December 7. Anson Brown’s June 14, 1840, death in New York’s 11th brought Whig Nicholas B. Doe in on December 7. Tilghman Howard resigned Indiana’s 7th on July 1, 1840, flipping the seat to Whig Henry S. Lane, seated August 3. Walter T. Colquitt left Georgia’s at-large seat July 21, 1840, and Whig Hines Holt succeeded him February 1, 1841. Rice Garland resigned Louisiana’s 3rd on July 21, 1840, for a judgeship, with Whig John Moore installed December 17. Richard Biddle quit Pennsylvania’s 22nd on July 21, 1840, and Whig Henry M. Brackenridge took over October 13. Simeon H. Anderson’s August 11, 1840, death in Kentucky’s 5th led to Whig John B. Thompson’s December 7 seating. Abbott Lawrence resigned Massachusetts 1st on September 18, 1840, and Whig Robert C. Winthrop replaced him November 9. William S. Ramsey died October 17, 1840, in Pennsylvania’s 13th, and Democrat Charles McClure succeeded him December 7. William W. Chapman’s term as Iowa Territory’s delegate expired by law October 27, 1840, and Democrat Augustus C. Dodge began his term the next day. Joel Holleman resigned Virginia’s 1st in December 1840, and Whig Francis Mallory was seated December 28. George Evans vacated Maine’s 4th on March 3, 1841, upon election to the Senate, leaving the seat unfilled for the remainder of the term.

title: List of vaccine topics
intro: This is a list of vaccine-related topics. A vaccine is a biological preparation that improves immunity to a particular disease. A vaccine typically contains an agent that resembles a disease-causing microorganism, and is often made from weakened or killed forms of the microbe or its toxins. The agent stimulates the body's immune system to recognize the agent as foreign, destroy it, and remember it, so that the immune system can more easily recognize and destroy any of these microorganisms that it later encounters.
lm_description: Bacillus anthracis causes anthrax and is prevented by the BioThrax anthrax vaccine. Bordetella pertussis triggers whooping cough and is targeted by the DPT vaccine, sold as Boostrix, Adacel, Daptacel, Infanrix, Tripedia, Kinrix, Pediarix, Pentacel, Tetramune, Quinvaxem, Pentavac PFS, Easyfive TT, Shan-5, and ComBE Five. Clostridium tetani produces tetanus, Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria, and both are likewise covered by the same DPT vaccine brands plus Decavac and Tenivac. Coxiella burnetii leads to Q fever and is blocked by the Q-Vax Q fever vaccine. Haemophilus influenzae type B provokes epiglottitis, meningitis, and pneumonia, and is countered by the Hib vaccine available as Hiberix, Pentacel, ActHIB, Pedvax HIB, Tetramune, Quinvaxem, Pentavac PFS, Easyfive TT, Shan-5, and ComBE Five. Mycobacterium tuberculosis causes tuberculosis and is addressed by the Tice BCG tuberculosis vaccine. Neisseria meningitidis provokes meningococcal meningitis; serotype C vaccines are Neisvac C and Meningitec, serotypes A/C/W-135/Y are covered by Mencevax, Nimenrix, Menveo, and Menactra, while serotype B is prevented by Bexsero. Salmonella typhi brings typhoid fever and is thwarted by Typhim Vi, Typherix, and Ty21a typhoid vaccines. Streptococcus pneumoniae causes pneumococcal pneumonia and is met by Pneumovax and Prevnar pneumococcal conjugate and polysaccharide vaccines. Vibrio cholerae triggers cholera and is checked by Dukoral and Shanchol cholera vaccines.

title: List of best-selling albums
intro:
This is a list of the world's best-selling albums of recorded music. To appear on the list, the figure must have been published by a reliable source and the album must have sold at least 20 million copies. This list can contain any types of album, including studio albums, extended plays, greatest hits, compilations, various artists, soundtracks and remixes. The figures given do not take into account the resale of used albums. [a]
 All albums included on this list have their available claimed figures supported by at least 30% in certified copies. The percentage amount of certified sales needed increases the newer the album is, so albums released before 1975 are only expected to have their claimed figures supported by at least 30% in certified copies. However, newer albums, such as 21 and Come Away with Me, are expected to have their claimed figures supported by at least 70% in certified copies. Certified copies are sourced from available online databases of local music industry associations. This is the reason why albums that would otherwise make the list, such as The Sound of Music, In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida, Parallel Lines, Spirits Having Flown, Private Dancer, Janet, Believe, Bolo Ta Ra Ra., Human Clay, Laundry Service and Back to Black, have not been included. As a result of the methodology that the American and Canadian certification-awarding bodies (the RIAA and Music Canada respectively) use, each disc in a multi-disc set is counted as one unit toward certification, leading to many double albums on the list - such as Pink Floyd's The Wall and the Beatles' The Beatles - being certified with a number double the number of copies sold there. Such albums have the certifications for the number of copies (not discs) shipped indicated. Conversely, the American certification level for double albums that fit onto one compact disc, such as the Saturday Night Fever soundtrack reflect the actual number of copies sold.
lm_description: Bon Jovi’s 1986 hard-rock and glam-metal landmark Slippery When Wet and Mariah Carey’s 1993 pop-and-R&B blockbuster Music Box have each sold 28 million copies. Madonna’s 1986 dance-pop classic True Blue, Linkin Park’s 2000 nu-metal/rap-metal Hybrid Theory, Eminem’s 2002 hip-hop statement The Eminem Show and Norah Jones’ 2002 jazz debut Come Away with Me all stand at 27 million. Eric Clapton’s 1992 acoustic rock and blues set Unplugged has moved 26 million, while Bob Marley & The Wailers’ 1984 reggae anthology Legend, Carole King’s 1971 pop masterpiece Tapestry, Phil Collins’ 1985 pop-rock release No Jacket Required, Queen’s 1981 rock compilation Greatest Hits, Simon & Garfunkel’s 1970 folk-rock Bridge over Troubled Water, U2’s 1987 rock epic The Joshua Tree, Prince and The Revolution’s 1984 pop-rock/new-wave/R&B soundtrack Purple Rain, Britney Spears’ 1999 pop debut ...Baby One More Time and George Michael’s 1987 pop/R&B/funk/soul album Faith have all reached 25 million. Elton John’s 1974 pop collection Greatest Hits, the Backstreet Boys’ 1997 self-titled/Backstreet’s Back and their 1999 Millennium, plus the Spice Girls’ 1996 pop debut Spice, close the list with 24 million and 23 million respectively.

Eric Clapton’s 1992 acoustic rock and blues set Unplugged has moved 26 million, while Bob Marley & The Wailers’ 1984 reggae anthology Legend, Carole King’s 1971 pop masterpiece Tapestry, Phil Collins’ 1985 pop-rock release No Jacket Required, Queen’s 1981 rock compilation Greatest Hits, Simon & Garfunkel’s 1970 folk-rock Bridge over Troubled Water, U2’s 1987 rock epic The Joshua Tree, Prince and The Revolution’s 1984 pop-rock/new-wave/R&B soundtrack Purple Rain, Britney Spears’ 1999 pop debut ...Baby One More Time and George Michael’s 1987 pop/R&B/funk/soul album Faith have all reached 25 million. Elton John’s 1974 pop collection Greatest Hits, the Backstreet Boys’ 1997 self-titled/Backstreet’s Back and their 1999 Millennium, plus the Spice Girls’ 1996 pop debut Spice, close the list with 24 million and 23 million respectively.

title: Copa de Honor Cousenier
intro: Copa de Honor Cousenier was an international football club competition which was played 13 times between representatives of the Argentina and Uruguay associations between 1905 and 1920.
lm_description: Nacional dominated the Copa de Honor Cousenier, lifting the trophy four times in 1905, 1915, 1916 and 1917. CURCC, later Peñarol, celebrated three victories in 1909, 1911 and 1918. Alumni won the 1906 edition, Belgrano Athletic Club triumphed in 1907, and Wanderers secured the 1908 title. River Plate (M) earned its lone honour in 1912, Racing followed with success in 1913, and Boca Juniors closed the competition’s history by claiming the 1920 crown.
to_index_text:
Copa de Honor Cousenier
Copa de Honor Cousenier was an international football club competition which was played 13 times between representatives of the Argentina and Uruguay associations between 1905 and 1920.
Nacional dominated the Copa de Honor Cousenier, lifting the trophy four times in 1905, 1915, 1916 and 1917. CURCC, later Peñarol, celebrated three victories in 1909, 1911 and 1918. Alumni won the 1906 edition, Belgrano Athletic Club triumphed in 1907, and Wanderers secured the 1908 title. River Plate (M) earned its lone honour in 1912, Racing followed with success in 1913, and Boca Juniors closed the competition’s history by claiming the 1920 crown.

title: 2012 Malaysia FAM League
intro: The 2012 FAM League is the sixtieth season of the FAM League since its establishment in 1952. The season began on 3 March 2012 and is due to end on 1 July 2012. Betaria are the defending champions, having won their 1st league title the previous season. A total of 9 teams are contesting in the league.
lm_description: Malacca FA entered the 2012 Malaysia FAM League led by coach G. Selvamohan, with Amrie Abdullah captaining the side in Ambros kits bearing Metaforce branding. Edres Selamat guided Melodi Jaya SC, whose captain Mohd Fairuz Abdul Rahman wore Nike shirts sponsored by PJM. Zabidi Hassan coached Penang Water Supply Board, where Mat Saiful Mohamad skippered Line7 kits emblazoned with PBAPP. Jánós Krécská directed Penang FA, whose captain Hasmawi Hassan donned Adidas gear carrying Allianz University College of Medical Science across the chest. Tajuddin Nor oversaw KP Shahzan Muda FC, captained by Raja Mohd Hafillah Raja Mamat in Kappa apparel without a shirt sponsor. Halim led Kepala Batas FC, with Safuan Azwan Abdul Shukor as captain wearing Lancast kits. Mohd Nizam Jamil coached KL SPA FC, where Sazali Suwandi captained the team in Joma shirts sponsored by Suruhanjaya Perkidmatan Awam. Abdul Kamal commanded Tentera Darat, with Josep Amar as captain in adidas kits featuring Honda sponsorship. Azman Eusoff guided UiTM FC, whose captain Ahmad Shahir Ismail wore Umbro shirts carrying the UiTM name.

title: List of FC Barcelona records and statistics
intro: Futbol Club Barcelona is a professional football club, based in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. Founded in 1899 by a group of Swiss, English and Catalan footballers led by Joan Gamper, the club has become a symbol of Catalan culture and Catalanism, hence the motto Més que un club (More than a club). The official Barça anthem is the Cant del Barça, written by Jaume Picas and Josep Maria Espinàs. Unlike many other football clubs, the supporters own and operate Barcelona. It is the world's second richest football club in terms of revenue, with an annual turnover of €495 million in 2011-12 season. Barcelona played its first friendly match on 8 December 1899 against the English colony in Barcelona in the old velodrome in Bonanova. Initially, Barcelona played against other local clubs in various Catalan tournaments. In 1929, the club became one of the founding members of La Liga, Spain's first truly national league, and has since achieved the distinction of being one of only three clubs to have never been relegated, along with Real Madrid and Athletic Bilbao. Barcelona is the only European club to have played continental football every season since 1955. Barcelona holds a long-standing rivalry with Real Madrid, with matches between the two teams referred to as El Clásico (El Clàssic in Catalan). Matches against city rivals Espanyol are known as the Derbi barceloní. Barcelona has amassed various records since its founding.
lm_description: Lionel Messi, the Argentine phenomenon who arrived in 2004, towers over every scorer in Barça’s history with 433 goals. Spain’s César netted 190 between 1942 and 1955, while today’s Uruguayan striker Luis Suárez has already struck 142 since 2014. Hungarian magician László Kubala amassed 131 from 1950 to 1961, and Cameroonian Samuel Eto’o hit 108 during his 2004-2009 reign. Spaniards Mariano Martín and Josep Escolà registered 97 and 93 respectively across the 1940s, Dutchman Patrick Kluivert claimed 90 between 1998 and 2004, fellow Spaniard Estanislao Basora 89 from 1946 to 1958, and Brazilian Rivaldo 86 from 1997 to 2002.

title: List of Virtual Console games for Wii (North America)
intro: The following is a list of the 427 games that were available on the Virtual Console for the Wii in North America. These games could also be played on the Wii U through Wii Mode, but lack the additional features found in Wii U Virtual Console releases. The games are sorted by system and in the order they were added in the Wii Shop Channel. To sort by other columns, click the corresponding icon in the header row. Nintendo discontinued the Wii Shop Channel on January 31, 2019, with the purchase of Wii Points for new games having ended on March 26, 2018. But Wii Shop Channel users can still continue to redownload previously purchased content as of February 1, 2019.
lm_description: Super Mario 64 kicked off the North American Wii Virtual Console on 19 November 2006, followed by Mario Kart 64 on 29 January 2007 and The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time on 26 February 2007, all published by Nintendo with an E rating. Star Fox 64 arrived on 2 April 2007, F-Zero X on 25 June 2007, and Intelligent Systems’ Paper Mario on 16 July 2007, while Wave Race 64 surfaced on 6 August 2007 and Yoshi’s Story on 17 September 2007. Treasure’s T-rated Sin and Punishment debuted on 1 October 2007, and HAL Laboratory with Pax Softnica released Pokémon Snap on 10 December 2007. Nintendo’s 1080° Snowboarding landed on 28 January 2008, HAL Laboratory’s Kirby 64: The Crystal Shards on 25 February 2008, and Midway Games’ Cruis’n USA on 31 March 2008, all carrying an E rating. Pokémon Puzzle League from Nintendo Software Technology and Intelligent Systems arrived on 5 May 2008, Camelot Software’s Mario Golf on 6 October 2008, and Nintendo EAD’s The Legend of Zelda: Majora’s Mask on 18 May 2009. HAL Laboratory’s Super Smash Bros. joined on 21 December 2009, Quest and Dual Corporation’s T-rated Ogre Battle 64: Person of Lordly Caliber on 29 March 2010, Camelot’s Mario Tennis on 28 June 2010, and Hudson Soft’s Mario Party 2 closed the list on 20 December 2010.

title: List of Major League Baseball hit records
intro: This is a list of Major League Baseball hit records. Bolded names mean the player is still active and playing.
lm_description: Ichiro Suzuki set a consecutive-years record with 10 seasons from 2001-2010 for Seattle. Pete Rose achieved 10 seasons across 1965-1966, 1968-1970, 1973, 1975-1977 with Cincinnati and 1979 with Philadelphia-NL. Ty Cobb had 9 seasons in 1907, 1909, 1911-1912, 1915-1917, 1922, 1924 for Detroit. Paul Waner recorded 8 seasons during 1927-1930, 1932, 1934, 1936-1937 with Pittsburgh. Lou Gehrig earned 8 seasons in 1927-1928, 1930-1932, 1934, 1936-1937 for New York-AL. Willie Keeler had 8 seasons from 1894-1898 with Baltimore and 1899-1901 with Brooklyn-NL. Derek Jeter achieved 8 seasons in 1998-2000, 2005-2007, 2009, 2012 for New York-AL. Rogers Hornsby had 7 seasons during 1920-1922, 1924-1925 with St. Louis-NL, 1927 with New York-NL, and 1929 with Chicago-NL. Charlie Gehringer earned 7 seasons in 1929-1930, 1933-1937 for Detroit. Wade Boggs achieved 7 consecutive seasons from 1983-1989 with Boston-AL. George Sisler had 6 seasons in 1920-1922, 1925, 1927 with St. Louis-AL and 1929 with Boston-NL. Sam Rice recorded 6 seasons in 1920, 1924-1926, 1928, 1930 for Washington-AL. Al Simmons achieved 6 seasons during 1925, 1929-1932 with Philadelphia-AL and 1933 with Chicago-AL. Stan Musial had 6 seasons in 1943, 1946, 1948-1949, 1951, 1953 for St. Louis-NL. Steve Garvey earned 6 seasons in 1974-1976, 1978-1980 with Los Angeles-NL. Michael Young achieved 6 seasons during 2003-2007, 2011 for Texas. Chuck Klein had 5 consecutive seasons from 1929-1933 with Philadelphia-NL. Kirby Puckett recorded 5 seasons in 1986-1989, 1992 for Minnesota. Tony Gwynn achieved 5 seasons in 1984, 1986-1987, 1989, 1997 with San Diego.

title: 2013 European Trophy
intro: The 2013 European Trophy was the fourth and final season of the European Trophy, an annually held European ice hockey tournament. It was also the eighth tournament since its predecessor, the Nordic Trophy, was launched in 2006. The regulation round began on 6 August 2013 with the South Division game between Piráti Chomutov-Sparta Praha, and ended on 8 September 2013. The playoffs were played between 19-22 December 2013 in Berlin. The preliminary schedule for the regulation round was released on 15 April 2013. JYP won the tournament, defeating Färjestad BK in the final 2-1. Like last year's tournament, the same 32 teams participated in the tournament, marking the first time since 2007 that the teams remained the same from last year. For the first time in tournament history, Eisbären Berlin hosted the playoffs, the Red Bulls Salute. It marked the first time that the playoffs were hosted in a single city, as well as the first time that the playoffs weren't hosted in Austria.
lm_description: Mika Pyörälä of Oulun Kärpät led all scorers with 11 points in 7 games as a forward. Vienna Capitals goalie Matt Zaba posted 10 points in 6 games, the highest total among goaltenders. Bílí Tygři Liberec forward Tomáš Filippi and Jokerit forward Steve Moses each collected 8 points, Filippi in 7 games and Moses in 8. Adler Mannheim goalie Felix Brückmann recorded 7 points in just 4 games, matching the 7-point outputs of ERC Ingolstadt forward John Laliberte in 8 games, HC Škoda Plzeň goalie Matěj Machovský in 4 games, and TPS forward Dan Sexton in 8 games. Hamburg Freezers forward Morten Madsen totaled 6 points in 7 games, while Red Bull Salzburg goalie Bernd Brückler achieved 6 points in only 3 appearances.

title: List of members of the Senate of Belgium, 2014–2019
intro: N/A
lm_description: Bert Anciaux of sp.a, Dutch-speaking, entered the Senate as a co-opted member, as did French-speaking Anne Barzin from MR, cdH’s Christophe Bastin, and Groen’s Petra De Sutter. Jan Becaus, another Dutch-language co-opted senator, represents N-VA. Geert Bourgeois, Karin Brouwers, Ann Brusseel, Sonja Claes, Cathy Coudyser, Rik Daems, Sabine de Bethune, Jean-Jacques De Gucht and Annick De Ridder all secured their seats by being chosen from within the Flemish Parliament, with party affiliations N-VA, CD & V and Open Vld. Jacques Brotchi, French-speaking MR member, was appointed by the Brussels-Capital Region’s French language group parliament, while Valérie De Bue and Alain Destexhe reached the Senate via the Parliament of the French Community. Christine Defraigne, François Desquesnes and Olivier Destrebecq, all French-speaking, were sent by the Walloon Parliament: Defraigne and Destrebecq from MR, Desquesnes from cdH.

title: List of doping cases in athletics
intro: The use of performance-enhancing drugs (doping) is prohibited within the sport of athletics. Athletes who are found to have used such banned substances, whether through a positive drugs test, the biological passport system, an investigation or public admission, may receive a competition ban for a length of time which reflects the severity of the infraction. Athletes who are found to have banned substances in their possession, or who tamper with or refuse to submit to drug testing can also receive bans from the sport. Competitive bans may also be given to athletes who test positive for prohibited recreational drugs or stimulants with little performance-enhancing effect for competitors in athletics. The sports body responsible for determining which substances are banned in athletics is the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA). Typically, any athlete who tests positive for banned substances after having served a previous ban receives a lifetime ban from the sport of athletics. Many high-profile sportspeople to receive doping bans have come from the sport of athletics, with significant past cases concerning Ben Johnson, Lance Armstrong, Alberto Contador, Shane Warne, Diego Maradona, Shoaib Akhtar, Marion Jones and Tim Montgomery. Furthermore, a number of athletes who underwent state-sponsored doping programmes in East Germany between the 1960s and 1980s were competitors in athletics, but the quality of the international anti-doping work was so poor that only one East German athlete ever tested positive. Following allegations of state-sponsored doping in Russia, the IAAF suspended the country's athletes from competition, including the 2016 Summer Olympics.
lm_description: Finnish long-distance runner Kaarlo Maaninka admitted in 1980 to using blood transfusions, a practice not yet banned, and received no sanction. Czechoslovakian shot-putter Remigius Machura first tested positive for stanozolol in 1985, confessed to earlier anabolic-steroid use dating back to 1981, and had a life ban cut to two years; in 2010, competing for the Czech Republic, he drew another two-year ban after a HGH violation. British javelin thrower Colin Mackenzie served a three-month ban in 1994, while Canadian counterpart Mike Mahovlich’s 1986 case is listed without detail. South African sprinter Simon Magakwe received two years in 2014 for refusing doping control, and compatriot long-jumper Luvo Manyonga got 18 months in 2012 for methamphetamine. Brazilian long-jumper Maurren Maggi tested positive for clostebol in 2003 and sat out two years. Portuguese pole-vaulter Edi Maia drew only a public warning and event disqualification in 2008 for cannabis. Swiss sprinter Pascal Mancini was publicly warned in 2011 for undisclosed norandrosterone and banned for two years in 2012. Russian middle-distance runner Irina Maracheva earned a two-year sanction in 2012 via biological-passport anomalies. French hurdler Pascal Maran received a public warning and disqualification in 1997 for ephedrine, while Romanian middle-distance runner Natalia Mărășescu served eight months in 1979 for anabolic steroids. Dutch sprinter Brian Mariano drew four years in 2016 for stanozolol, Croatian discus thrower Martin Marić two years in 2014 for the SARM ostarine, and Israeli high-jumper Itay Margalit was sanctioned in 1999 for nandrolone. Moldovan hammer throwers Marina and Zalina Marghieva tested positive for stanozolol in 2012 and for dehydrochloromethyltestosterone plus stanozolol in 2009 (retested 2013), each incurring two-year bans. Azerbaijani hammer thrower Dzmitry Marshin received four years in 2015 for dehydrochloromethyltestosterone, and American hurdler LaVonna Martin-Floreal had her 1991 furosemide sanction reduced from two years to 14 months.

title: Strictly Come Dancing (series 8)
intro: Strictly Come Dancing returned for its eighth series on BBC One with a red carpet launch show on 11 September 2010, and the competitive live shows began on 1 October. The series concluded on 18 December when Kara Tointon and Artem Chigvintsev won the competition. According to BARB data, this series was the consistently highest rated of the show to date, peaking at 14.28 million viewers. Len Goodman, Bruno Tonioli, Craig Revel Horwood and Alesha Dixon returned as judges. Five professional dancers from the last series didn't return for this series, Matthew Cutler, Brian Fortuna, Ian Waite and married Darren Bennett and Lilia Kopylova. Three male professionals joined this years series, Artem Chigvintsev, Robin Windsor and Jared Murillo. For series 8 the set has been totally revamped to try to attract more viewers to the programme, the backstage room where scores were given has been replaced by a tower above the dancefloor so the couples can watch as their teammates perform (much like the so-called 'celebriquarium' on the American version of the programme). In week 8 of the competition the live show was transmitted from the Blackpool Tower Ballroom. Bruce Forsyth and Tess Daly returned to present the main show on BBC One. For the results show, Daly is joined by Strictly Come Dancing: It Takes Two presenter Claudia Winkleman. The celebrities did not know their professional partners until they were introduced to each other at the launch show. At the age of 61, Pamela Stephenson became the oldest contestant to ever make it to the finale.
lm_description: Pamela Stephenson and Kara Tointon shared the American Smooth high of 37, while Ann Widdecombe bottom-scored that dance with 14. Kara Tointon’s Argentine Tango earned the maximum 38, dwarfing Tina O’Brien’s 28. Pamela topped the Cha Cha Cha with 32 as Paul Daniels managed only 16. Her Charleston peak of 38 left Peter Shilton and Widdecombe on 17. Pamela and Gavin Henson both hit 33 in the Foxtrot, yet Widdecombe again trailed on 20. Scott Maslen’s Jive soared to 39, with Gavin’s 22 the low. Kara’s Paso Doble reached 37, treble Ann’s 16. Pamela’s perfect 40 Quickstep contrasted with Ann’s 18. Kara’s Rumba scored 39 to Ann’s 14, and her Salsa 36 to Ann’s 12. Matt Baker’s Samba high of 38 overshadowed Ann’s 13. Pamela’s Showdance 37 bettered Matt’s 34. Kara earned 5 in the Swing-a-thon, Gavin just 1. Kara and Matt shared Tango highs of 38, Ann again low on 21. Pamela’s Viennese Waltz achieved 40, Felicity Kendal 26. Finally, Kara’s Waltz peaked at 38, Ann’s closed on 17.

Strictly Come Dancing (series 8)

The series concluded on 18 December when Kara Tointon and Artem Chigvintsev won the competition. According to BARB data, this series was the consistently highest rated of the show to date, peaking at 14.28 million viewers. Len Goodman, Bruno Tonioli, Craig Revel Horwood and Alesha Dixon returned as judges. title: List of constituencies of the Lok Sabha
intro: The Lok Sabha, the lower house of the Parliament of India, is made up of Members of Parliament (MPs). Each MP, represents a single geographic constituency. There are currently 543 constituencies. The maximum size of the Lok Sabha as outlined in the Constitution of India is 550 members made up of up to 530 members representing people of the states of India and up to 20 members representing people from the Union Territories on the basis of their population.
lm_description: Kachchh, numbered 1, is a Scheduled Caste seat, while Banaskantha (2), Patan (3), Mahesana (4), Sabarkantha (5), Gandhinagar (6), Ahmedabad East (7), Surendranagar (9), Rajkot (10), Porbandar (11), Jamnagar (12), Junagadh (13), Amreli (14), Bhavnagar (15), Anand (16), Kheda (17), Panchmahal (18) and Vadodara (20) are open contests. Ahmedabad West, at position 8, is also reserved for Scheduled Castes, and Dahod, nineteenth in order, is the single Scheduled Tribe constituency in this segment.

List of constituencies of the Lok Sabha

The maximum size of the Lok Sabha as outlined in the Constitution of India is 550 members made up of up to 530 members representing people of the states of India and up to 20 members representing people from the Union Territories on the basis of their population.
Kachchh, numbered 1, is a Scheduled Caste seat, while Banaskantha (2), Patan (3), Mahesana (4), Sabarkantha (5), Gandhinagar (6), Ahmedabad East (7), Surendranagar (9), Rajkot (10), Porbandar (11), Jamnagar (12), Junagadh (13), Amreli (14), Bhavnagar (15), Anand (16), Kheda (17), Panchmahal (18) and Vadodara (20) are open contests. Ahmedabad West, at position 8, is also reserved for Scheduled Castes, and Dahod, nineteenth in order, is the single Scheduled Tribe constituency in this segment.

title: 1995 in video games
intro: 1995 has seen many sequels and prequels in video games and several new titles such as Mario's Picross, Chrono Trigger, Mega Man 7, Rayman, Twisted Metal, Star Wars: Dark Forces, Destruction Derby and Super Mario World 2: Yoshi's Island.
lm_description: Nintendo’s Donkey Kong Country ruled the 1995 charts for eight months at #1, while its own fighting title Killer Instinct peaked at #1 across four. Acclaim matched that top spot with the basketball slam of NBA Jam: Tournament Edition, which stayed six months, and again with the run-and-gun Judge Dredd, though Dredd lasted only three. Acclaim’s Justice League Task Force fought its way to #2 for the same three-month span, and their Spider-Man action game reached #4 for four. Williams Entertainment’s Mortal Kombat 3 climbed to #2 in three months, Kyle Petty’s No Fear Racing parked at #3, and Nintendo rounded out the list with Kirby’s Avalanche and EarthBound each peaking at #4 after three charting months.
to_index_text:
1995 in video games
1995 has seen many sequels and prequels in video games and several new titles such as Mario's Picross, Chrono Trigger, Mega Man 7, Rayman, Twisted Metal, Star Wars: Dark Forces, Destruction Derby and Super Mario World 2: Yoshi's Island.
Nintendo’s Donkey Kong Country ruled the 1995 charts for eight months at #1, while its own fighting title Killer Instinct peaked at #1 across four. Acclaim matched that top spot with the basketball slam of NBA Jam: Tournament Edition, which stayed six months, and again with the run-and-gun Judge Dredd, though Dredd lasted only three. Acclaim’s Justice League Task Force fought its way to #2 for the same three-month span, and their Spider-Man action game reached #4 for four. Williams Entertainment’s Mortal Kombat 3 climbed to #2 in three months, Kyle Petty’s No Fear Racing parked at #3, and Nintendo rounded out the list with Kirby’s Avalanche and EarthBound each peaking at #4 after three charting months.

title: Minnesota Vikings draft history
intro: This page is a list of the Minnesota Vikings NFL Draft selections. The first draft the Vikings participated in was the 1961 NFL Draft, in which they made Tommy Mason of Tulane their first ever selection.
lm_description: James White from Oklahoma State was the Vikings’ first-round choice at 25th overall, followed by Grambling State wide receiver Sammy White at 54th overall in the second round. Tulsa guard Wes Hamilton went 85th overall in the third, Ohio State receiver Leonard Willis 118th in the fourth, and Wisconsin defensive back Steve Wagner 133rd in the fifth, the same round that produced Boston College running back Keith Barnette at 149th. Minnesota-Duluth defensive back Terry Egerdahl was taken 180th in the sixth, Rice safety Larry Brune 206th in the seventh, Southern receiver Isaac Hagins 262nd in the ninth, and Northern Iowa quarterback Bill Salmon 289th in the tenth. Montana State supplied two late picks: running back Steve Kracher 316th in the eleventh and defensive back Randy Hickel 457th in the sixteenth. San Francisco State defensive back Robert Sparks went 345th in the twelfth, Colorado State end Gary Paulson 372nd in the thirteenth, Purdue tackle Jeff Stapleton 401st in the fourteenth, Macalester running back Ron Groce 428th in the fifteenth, and West Virginia defensive tackle Dick Lukowski 484th in the seventeenth.

title: Top 14
intro: The Top 14 (French pronunciation: ​[tɔp katɔʀz]) is a professional rugby union club competition that is played in France created in 1892. The Top 14 is at the top of the national league system operated by the French National Rugby League, also known by its French initialism of LNR. There is promotion and relegation between the Top 14 and the next level down, the Rugby Pro D2. The fourteen best rugby teams in France participate in the competition, hence the name Top 14. The competition was previously known as the Top 16. The league is one of the three major professional leagues in Europe (along with the English Premiership and the Pro14, which brings together top clubs from Ireland, Wales, Scotland, Italy and South Africa), the most successful European teams from which go forward to compete in the European Rugby Champions Cup, the pan-European championship which replaced the Heineken Cup after the 2013-14 season. The first ever final took place in 1892, between two Paris-based sides, Stade Français and Racing Club de France, which were the only teams playing the competition that year, with the latter becoming the inaugural champions. The competition has been held on an annual basis since, except from 1915 to 1919 - because of World War I - and from 1940 to 1942 - because of World War II. Toulouse is the most successful club in the competition with 20 titles.
lm_description: Vincent Clerc tops the all-time try chart with 101 touchdowns amassed for Grenoble, Toulouse and Toulon between 2002 and 2018. One behind him, Laurent Arbo crossed 100 times while turning out for Pau, Castres, Montpellier and Perpignan across 1991-2007. Aurélien Rougerie’s entire 1999-2018 career at Clermont yielded 96 tries, good for third. Fellow Clermont star Napolioni Nalaga added 87 in two spells there and at Lyon from 2006-2017. Still active Toulouse full-back Maxime Medard has 81 since 2004, while Montpellier’s Timoci Nagusa has 78 from 2010 onward. Julien Arias, shuttling between Colomiers and Stade Français since 2001, stands on 76. Cédric Heymans punched 65 for Toulouse before retiring in 2013, and Castres-Racing-La Rochelle winger Marc Andreu has 60. Julien Candelon rounds out the elite ten with 58 tries for Narbonne and Perpignan during 2003-2012.

title: Germany at the 2013 World Aquatics Championships
intro: Germany competed at the 2013 World Aquatics Championships in Barcelona, Spain between 20 July to 4 August 2013.
lm_description: Patrick Hausding and Sascha Klein struck gold in the men’s 10 m synchronized platform on 21 July, while Thomas Lurz, Christian Reichert and Isabelle Härle captured the open-water team title four days later. Lurz doubled his tally by winning the men’s 25 km on 27 July, having already taken silver in the 10 km on 22 July and bronze in the 5 km on 20 July. Angela Maurer matched the spectrum, earning silver in the women’s 25 km and bronze in the 10 km. Marco Koch added a swimming silver in the men’s 200 m breaststroke on 2 August, Sascha Klein claimed diving bronze in the individual 10 m platform on 28 July, and Anna Bader rounded out Germany’s medals with bronze in the women’s high diving on 30 July.
to_index_text:
Germany at the 2013 World Aquatics Championships
Germany competed at the 2013 World Aquatics Championships in Barcelona, Spain between 20 July to 4 August 2013.

Lurz doubled his tally by winning the men’s 25 km on 27 July, having already taken silver in the 10 km on 22 July and bronze in the 5 km on 20 July. Angela Maurer matched the spectrum, earning silver in the women’s 25 km and bronze in the 10 km. Marco Koch added a swimming silver in the men’s 200 m breaststroke on 2 August, Sascha Klein claimed diving bronze in the individual 10 m platform on 28 July, and Anna Bader rounded out Germany’s medals with bronze in the women’s high diving on 30 July.

title: List of Serbian football champions
intro: The Serbian football champions indicates all past winners of the top-tier football leagues in which clubs from Serbia were inserted in. It includes the Serbian SuperLiga and chronologically all the predecessor leagues.
lm_description: In the inaugural 1945 season SR Serbia took the title ahead of JNA and SR Croatia, with JNA’s Stjepan Bobek scoring 8 goals. Partizan claimed the 1946-47 championship, edging Dinamo Zagreb and Crvena Zvezda while Dinamo’s Franjo Wölfl hit 28 goals. Wölfl repeated as top scorer with 22 goals the next year as Dinamo Zagreb won, followed by Hajduk Split and Partizan. Partizan regained the crown in 1948-49, with Hajduk’s Frane Matošić topping the charts on 17 goals. Hajduk Split won 1950, pushing Crvena Zvezda and Partizan down to second and third, while Partizan’s Marko Valok led scorers with 17. Crvena Zvezda took 1951 ahead of Dinamo Zagreb and Hajduk, their own Kosta Tomašević scoring 16. Hajduk won again in 1952, BSK Belgrade’s Stanoje Jocić leading scorers with 13. Crvena Zvezda returned to the summit in 1952-53, Todor Živanović hitting 17. Dinamo Zagreb won 1953-54, Partizan’s Stjepan Bobek scoring 21. Hajduk Split secured 1954-55, with Predrag Marković, Kosta Tomašević and Bernard Vukas sharing the 20-goal top-scorer honour. Crvena Zvezda won 1955-56, 1956-57, 1958-59 and 1959-60, Todor Veselinović claiming the scoring title in 1956-57 with 28 and in 1957-58 with 19, while Bora Kostić struck 25 and 19 in the latter two seasons. Dinamo Zagreb interrupted in 1957-58. Partizan then won 1960-61, 1961-62, 1962-63 and 1964-65, Crvena Zvezda taking 1963-64 in between, with Zlatko Dračić topping scorers in the last of those seasons with 23 goals.

title: DA postcode area
intro: The DA postcode area, also known as the Dartford postcode area, is a group of eighteen postcode districts in England, within eleven post towns. These cover parts of south-east London and north-west Kent. The main sorting office in Dartford ceased operating in 2012 and became a Delivery Office. The area served includes most of the London Borough of Bexley and very small parts of the London Borough of Bromley and the Royal Borough of Greenwich, while in Kent it covers almost all of the Borough of Dartford, most of the Gravesham district, the northeastern part of the Sevenoaks district and a very small part of the borough of Tonbridge and Malling.
lm_description: DA1 covers Dartford, Crayford and Barnes Cray, straddling Dartford and Bexley councils, while DA2 extends eastward to Stone, Wilmington, Bean, Hawley, Darenth and part of Joyden’s Wood under Dartford and Sevenoaks. DA3 leaves the Dartford post town, serving Longfield, Hartley, New Ash Green, New Barn and Fawkham across Dartford, Sevenoaks and Gravesham, whereas DA4 returns to Dartford post town for Farningham, Eynsford, South Darenth, Sutton-at-Hone and Horton Kirby, split between Sevenoaks and Dartford. DA5, centred on Bexley, covers Bexley Village, Blendon and slices of Albany Park and Joyden’s Wood, shared by Bexley and Dartford. Bexleyheath post town hosts DA6 for Bexleyheath and Upton wholly within Bexley, and DA7 for north Bexleyheath and Barnehurst, also Bexley-only. Erith post town handles DA8 for Erith, Northumberland Heath and Slade Green in Bexley, while Greenhithe post town covers DA9 for Greenhithe and Stone in Dartford. Swanscombe post town serves DA10 for Swanscombe and Ebbsfleet, likewise Dartford. Gravesend post town spreads across DA11 for west Gravesend and Northfleet, touching Gravesham and Dartford; DA12 for east Gravesend, Chalk, Shorne and Cobham, wholly Gravesham; and DA13 for Meopham, Istead Rise, Vigo and Southfleet, reaching into Gravesham, Dartford, Sevenoaks and a sliver of Tonbridge and Malling. Sidcup post town splits into DA14 for Sidcup, Foots Cray, North Cray, Longlands, Ruxley and part of Albany Park, spanning Bexley and Bromley, and DA15 for north Sidcup, Blackfen, Lamorbey, Longlands and part of Avery Hill, shared by Bexley and Greenwich. Welling post town covers DA16 for Welling, Falconwood and East Wickham, again Bexley and Greenwich, while Belvedere post town serves DA17 for Belvedere, Lessness Heath and part of Abbey Wood within Bexley. Finally, Erith post town returns for DA18, covering Erith Marshes and part of Thamesmead, wholly in Bexley.

title: The World's Billionaires
intro: The World's Billionaires is an annual ranking by documented net worth of the wealthiest billionaires in the world, compiled and published in March annually by the American business magazine Forbes. The list was first published in March 1987. The total net worth of each individual on the list is estimated and is cited in United States dollars, based on their documented assets and accounting for debt. Royalty and dictators whose wealth comes from their positions are excluded from these lists. This ranking is an index of the wealthiest documented individuals, excluding and ranking against those with wealth that is not able to be completely ascertained. In 2018, there was a record of 2,208 people on the list, that included 259 newcomers mostly from China and the U.S.; there were 63 people under 40 and it had a record number of 256 women. The average net worth of the list came in at US$4.1 billion, up US$350 million from 2017. Added together, the total net worth for 2018's billionaires was US$9.1 trillion, up from US$7.67 trillion in 2017. As of 2018[update], Microsoft founder Bill Gates had topped the list 18 of the past 24 years, while Amazon founder Jeff Bezos is ranked at the top for the first time and he became the first centibillionaire included in the ranking. In 2017, Mark Zuckerberg was the only person in the top 10 billionaires list who is under the age of 50, and the only one in the top 20 billionaires list who is under the age of 40. In 2017, 500 of the richest people in the world became richer by $1 trillion, according to a report by Bloomberg News. According to a 2017 Oxfam report, the top eight billionaires own as much combined wealth as the poorest half of the human race.
lm_description: Bill Gates leads the ranking with $40.7 billion at age 47, his fortune rooted in Microsoft. Warren Buffett follows with $30.5 billion at 72, drawn from Berkshire Hathaway. Germany’s Karl and Theo Albrecht, 83, share $25.6 billion from Aldi Süd. Paul Allen, 50, holds $20.1 billion, also from Microsoft. Saudi Arabia’s Al-Waleed bin Talal, 46, commands $17.7 billion through Kingdom Holding Company. Oracle’s Larry Ellison, 58, claims $16.6 billion. Five Waltons—Alice, 54; Helen, 83; Jim, 55; John, 57; and S. Robson, 59—tie at $16.5 billion each, their wealth anchored in Wal-Mart.

According to a 2017 Oxfam report, the top eight billionaires own as much combined wealth as the poorest half of the human race.
Bill Gates leads the ranking with $40.7 billion at age 47, his fortune rooted in Microsoft. Warren Buffett follows with $30.5 billion at 72, drawn from Berkshire Hathaway. Germany’s Karl and Theo Albrecht, 83, share $25.6 billion from Aldi Süd. Paul Allen, 50, holds $20.1 billion, also from Microsoft. Saudi Arabia’s Al-Waleed bin Talal, 46, commands $17.7 billion through Kingdom Holding Company. Oracle’s Larry Ellison, 58, claims $16.6 billion. Five Waltons—Alice, 54; Helen, 83; Jim, 55; John, 57; and S. Robson, 59—tie at $16.5 billion each, their wealth anchored in Wal-Mart.

title: List of black superheroes
intro: This is a list of black superheroes that lists characters found in comic books and other media. The characters are superheroes depicted as black people.
lm_description: Ambrose Chase debuts in Planetary, while Anansi, Black Badge, Black Rapier, Blue Knight, Cleopatra, Jack-in-the-Box and MPH all first appear in Astro City. Jackson King fights as Battalion, Victoria Ngengi is Flint, and Zachary Johnson becomes Jack-in-the-Box. Parsifal Congo operates as the Hoodoo Priest in Top 10, where John Corbeau serves as King Peacock and Doctor Sally-Jo Jessell shrinks to Micro-Maid. Sophie Bangs embodies Promethea from ABC Comics, Willie Beaumont gambles probability as Stochastic Fats, Malcolm King warps reality as Strafe, and Wanda Jackson perceives all senses at once as Synaesthesia. Rite enters Stormwatch, and New American steps onto the page in The American Way #1.

title: 2013 Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League
intro: The 2013 Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League season (known as the Castle Larger Premier Soccer League for sponsorship reasons) will be the thirty third season of the Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League since its establishment in 1980. The season began on 28 March 2013. Dynamos are the defending champions, having won the previous 2012 Zimbabwe Premier Soccer League season. The season will feature 12 teams from the 2012 ZPSL season and four new teams promoted from the 2012 Zifa Division One League: How Mine, Triangle United F.C., Triple B and Black Rhinos who replace relegated Buffaloes F.C., Harare City, Hardbody and Quelaton.
lm_description: Black Mambas play in Harare at the 5,000-seat Morris Depot Police Camp, while fellow Harare sides Black Rhinos, Dynamos and Harare City all share the 35,000-capacity Rufaro Stadium; CAPS United, also from the capital, occupy the giant 60,000-seat National Sports Stadium. Bulawayo’s Chicken Inn use the 8,000-seat Luveve Stadium, whereas city rivals Highlanders command the 32,000-seat Barbourfields and promoted How Mine stage matches at White City Stadium, which holds 20,000. FC Platinum and Shabanie Mine, both based in Zvishavane, host at Mandava Stadium (3,000) and Maglas Stadium (5,000) respectively. Mutare’s Buffaloes welcome fans to 10,000-seat Sakubva Stadium, Hwange’s Hwange play at the 15,000-capacity Colliery Stadium, Monomotapa United utilise Harare’s 10,000-seat Gwanzura Stadium, Motor Action’s home is the tiny 1,000-seat Motor Action Sports Club, Triangle United F.C. operate from Chiredzi’s 3,000-seat Gibbo Stadium, and Triple B draw support in Beitbridge at the 4,000-capacity Dulibadzimu Stadium.

title: Zurich Airport
intro: Zurich Airport (German: Flughafen Zürich, IATA: ZRH, ICAO: LSZH) is the largest international airport of Switzerland and the principal hub of Swiss International Air Lines. It serves Zürich, Switzerland's largest city, and, with its surface transport links, much of the rest of the country. The airport is located 13 kilometres (8 mi) north of central Zürich, in the municipalities of Kloten, Rümlang, Oberglatt, Winkel, and Opfikon, all of which are within the canton of Zürich. In 2019, the airport received the World Travel Award in the category Europe's leading airport for the 17th time in a row. The Skytrax Award also ranks Zurich Airport among the top 10 airports in the world for millions of travellers each year.
lm_description: London leads departures from Zurich with 888,876 travellers, followed by Berlin’s 508,589 and Vienna’s 492,968. Düsseldorf claims 403,759, just edging out Amsterdam’s 402,922. Frankfurt sends 330,326 passengers skyward, Paris 322,188, Barcelona 318,050, Hamburg 300,526, and Madrid closes the top ten with 290,174.

title: 2011 Korea National League
intro: The 2011 Korea National League season was the ninth season of the Korea National League. The postseason playoff's teams were expanded by 6 teams and the playoffs were operated in the same format as the K-League Championship. In the 2011 season, Yesan FC withdrew from the league due to financial difficulties[citation needed].
lm_description: Ansan Hallelujah play in Ansan at the 35,000-seat Ansan Wa~ Stadium, while Busan Transportation Corporation occupy Busan’s 24,363-capacity Gudeok Stadium. Changwon City host matches at the 15,500-seat Changwon Football Center, Cheonan City use Cheonan Stadium with 32,000 seats, and Chungju Hummel play in front of 15,000 at Chungju Stadium. Daejeon Korea Hydro & Nuclear Power take the field at Daejeon Hanbat Stadium, capacity 20,618, and Gangneung City fill Gangneung Stadium, which holds 22,333. Gimhae City’s home is the 30,000-seat Gimhae Stadium, whereas Goyang KB Kookmin Bank split their fixtures between Goyang Stadium and Uijeongbu Stadium, whose capacities are 41,311 and 35,000 respectively. Incheon Korail’s matches are staged on the 5,000-capacity practice pitch beside Incheon Munhak Stadium. Mokpo City play at the 5,952-seat Mokpo International Football Center, Suwon City alternate between the 24,670-seat Suwon Sports Complex and the 1,044-seat Suwon World Cup Stadium Auxiliary Pitch, Ulsan Hyundai Mipo Dockyard Dolphin draw 19,665 to Ulsan Stadium, and Yongin City’s games are held at the 12,000-seat Yongin Football Center.
